





Abelia latent tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.DE.01. (8) First
reported in Abelia grandiflora. (9) From Maryland, U.S.A. (10) By Waterworth
et al. (1975). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Abelia grandiflora symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the North
American region. (39) Spreads in the USA <eastern>. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions,
mosaic or no symptoms. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions, bright
systemic chlorosis. Datura stramonium and Glycine max yellow mosaic. Atropa
belladonna, Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis and Vicia faba systemic, but
symptomless. Nicotiana clevelandii and N. glutinosa chlorotic local lesions,
systemic mosaic. Lycopersicon esculentum systemic mosaic. (44) Capsicum
frutescens, Cucurbita pepo, Dianthus barbatus, Spinacia oleracea and Zea mays.
(47) Abelia grandiflora, or Abelmoschus esculentus, or Acer palmatum, or
Amaranthus caudatus, or Atropa belladonna, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel,
or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lobelia erinus, or Lycopersicon esculentum,
or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis peruviana, or Sesamum
indicum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Tithonia speciosa, or Torenia fournieri, or Vicia faba.
(48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or
Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Dianthus barbatus, or Ipomoea nil, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesbania exaltata, or Spinacia oleracea, or Theobroma
cacao, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Aceraceae
<1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Campanulaceae <1/1>,
or Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or Compositae <1/3>, or
Cruciferae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/4>, or Gramineae <1 /2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <11/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or Compositae <2/3>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/4>, or
Gramineae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or Scrophulariaceae <1
/2>, or Solanaceae <1/12>, or Sterculiaceae <1/1>. (53) Waterworth et al.
(1975). (54) TIP: 74-78 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 50 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 8-9. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Waterworth et al.
(1975). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (76) Two sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 114
S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 54 S <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio <1.71; (B)>. (84)
Virions contain 39 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 61 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid <B>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(100) Base composition 13.6 % G. (101) Base composition 23.8 % A. (102) Base
composition 33.5 % C. (103) Base composition 29.1 % U. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (179) Tymovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: eggplant mosaic (SDI 2-5),
Andean potato latent (3-7), belladonna mottle (4-6) and physalis mosaic (4-5).
(187) Waterworth, H.E., Kaper, J.M. and Koenig, R. (1975). Phytopathology 65:
891.


Abutilon mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) H. Jeske, 1987 and F.J. Morales, 1988. (2) Synonyms: bean dwarf
mosaic geminivirus, infectious chlorosis of Malvaceae, malvaceous chlorosis
geminivirus (Christie et al., 1986), possibly bean chlorotic mottle virus. (3)
Standard acronym: AbMV. (4) Strains: abutilon mosaic A West Indies virus,
abutilon mosaic B Brazil virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.002. (8) First
reported in Malva parviflora. (9) From Germany. (10) By Baur (1906); see also
Abouzid and Jeske (1986). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally <depending on light
intensity>. (13) Abutilon spp., Sida spp., Hibiscus spp., Gossypium hirsutum
yellow mosaic. Malva sp., Phaseolus vulgaris mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci.
(18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide <in ornamental plants>. (38) Spreads in the South and
Central American region. (39) Spreads in Argentina. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellow
mosaic, vein clearing. (43) Malva parviflora, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop
systemic mosaic, vein clearing. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Alubia systemic, severe
stunting. Sida spp. systemic golden mosaic. (45) Malva parviflora, M.
sylvestris, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Top Crop, Imuna, Stringless Green Refugee
and Amanda, Sida micrantha, S. rhombifolia. (46) Malva spp. (W), Phaseolus
vulgaris cvs Top Crop, Alubia and Imuna (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Abutilon, or Arachis hypogaea, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Glycine
max, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Hibiscus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Malva
parviflora, or Malva sylvestris, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sida, or Sida micrantha, or Sida
rhombifolia, or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Cucurbita pepo, or Lupinus albus. (50)
Cucurbitaceae <3/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/6>, or Malvaceae <9/9>,
or Solanaceae <7/7>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/6>. (53) Costa (1955); Costa and Carvalho (1960a, 1960b). (54) TIP: 45-55
°C. (55) LIV: 0.25-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (57) Infectivity of sap
not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: glutaraldehyde fixation needed before
negative staining. (60) Method: Abouzid and Jeske (1986); Morales et al.
(1988). (61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm
in diameter. (65) Virions <the dimer is> 29-33 nm in length. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations, or two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <about> 90
S. (78) Of the other(s) <about> 70 S. (81) Density in Cs2SO4 1.30 g cm3. (84)
Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 82 % protein. (88) Genome
consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size
5.299 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
larger> 2.663 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.636 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10815.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): S67640 Em(40)_vi:S67640
Gb(84)_vi:S67640S1 Ac1...Av1 (DNA A) Abutilon mosaic virus, mRNA, 4 genes, 399
nt, segment 1 of 2. 11/93 399bp. S67693 Em(40)_vi:S67693 Gb(84)_vi:S67640S2
Ac1...Av1 (DNA A) Abutilon mosaic virus, mRNA, 4 genes, 304 nt, segment 2 of
2. 11/93 304bp S67833 Em(40)_vi:S67833 Gb(84)_vi:S67833S1 Bc1, Bv1 (DNA B)
Abutilon mosaic virus, mRNA, 206 nt, segment 1 of 3. 11/93 206bp. S67843
Em(40)_vi:S67843 Gb(84)_vi:S67833S2 Bc1, Bv1 (DNA B) Abutilon mosaic virus,
mRNA, 224 nt, segment 2 of 3. 11/93 224bp. S67851 Em(40)_vi:S67851
Gb(84)_vi:S67833S3 Bc1, Bv1 (DNA B) Abutilon mosaic virus, mRNA, 249 nt,
segment 3 of 3. 11/93 249bp X15983 Em(40)_vi:GEABMVA Gb(84)_vi:GEABMVA
Abutilon mosaic virus subgenome DNA A. 9/93 2,629bp. X15984 Em(40)_vi:GEABMVB
Gb(84)_vi:GEABMVB Abutilon mosaic virus subgenome DNA B. 11/90 2,581bp. M88179
Em(40)_vi:GEBDMARAL Gb(84)_vi:BDMARAL13A Bean dwarf mosaic virus coat protein
(AR1) gene, putative replicative protein (AL1) gene comp M88180
Em(40)_vi:GEBDMBRL1 Gb(84)_vi:BDMBRL1A Bean dwarf mosaic virus (BR1 and BL1)
genes, complete cds. 9/92 2,576bp. 9 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) two.
(133) Mr <of the larger> 28000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 27000. (145) Method of
preparation: Abouzid and Jeske (1986); Morales et al. (1988). (164) Genome
replicates in nuclei <multiplication depending on daylength>. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves,
roots, vascular parenchyma, mesophyll, phloem and companion cells. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, in chloroplasts, and in cell vacuoles.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in
the nucleus, viroplasms, and unusual in shape. (176) Fibrillar bodies. (177)
They contain virions. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean golden
mosaic, African cassava mosaic and mung bean yellow mosaic viruses. (184)
Genome homologous with those of bean golden mosaic, tomato golden mosaic and
African cassava mosaic bigeminiviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: often
in mixed infections with the closely related bean golden mosaic virus, making
identification difficult. (186) The bean dwarf mosaic strain destroyed over
40,000 hectares of beans in 1978-81 in north west Argentina, where it causes
`achaparramiento' disease. (187) Abouzid, A. and Jeske, H. (1986). J.
Phytopath. 115: 344. Baur, E. (1906). Sitzber. Klg. preuss. Akad. Wiss. 1: 11.
Christie, R.G., Ko, N.J., Falk, B.W., Hiebert, E., Lastra, R., Bird, J. and
Kim, K.S. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 124. Cooper, J.I. (1979). In: Virus
Diseases of Trees and Shrubs. Inst. Terr. Ecol., Oxford, U.K. Costa, A.S.
(1975). In: Tropical Diseases of Legumes, p. 27; eds J. Bird and K.
Maramorosch. Academic Press, New York. Costa, A.S. (1955). Phytopath. Z. 24:
97. Costa, A.S. and Carvalho, A.M.B. (1960a). Phytopath. Z. 37: 259. Costa,
A.S. and Carvalho, A.M.B. (1960b). Phytopath. Z. 38: 129. Gröning, B.R.,
Abouzid, A. and Jeske, H. (1987). Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 84: 8996.
Jeske, H. (1980). Eur. J. Cell Biol. 22: 549. Jeske, H. (1986). J. Phytopath.
115: 243. Jeske, H. and Abouzid, A. (1986). Mitt. biol. BundesAnst. Land.
Forstw. 232: 403. Jeske, H. and Schuchalter-Eicke, G. (1984). Phytopath. Z.
109: 353. Jeske, H. and Werz, G. (1978). Phytopath. Z. 91: 1. Jeske, H. and
Werz, G. (1980a). Phytopath. Z. 97: 43. Jeske, H. and Werz, G. (1980b).
Virology 106: 155. Jeske, H., Menzel, D. and Werz, G. (1977). Phytopath. Z.
89: 289. Morales, F., Niessen, A., Ramirez, C. and Castano, M. (1988).
Phytopathology 78: 858. Orlando, A. and Silberschmidt, K. (1946). Arch. Inst.
Biol., Sao Paulo. 17: 1. Schuchalter-Eicke, G. and Jeske, H. (1983).
Phytopath. Z. 108: 172.


Abutilon yellows (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Abutilon spp. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Duffus et al. (1986).
(13) Abutilon spp. conspicuous leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Trialeurodes abutilonea.
(18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(38) Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in the USA
<California>. (47) Abutilon. (50) Malvaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus. (184) The
virions and type of vector of this virus are like those of lettuce infectious
yellows, beet pseudo-yellows and diodia yellow vein viruses, which may form a
sub-group of closteroviruses (Duffus et al., 1986). (187) Duffus, J.E.,
Larsen, R.C. and Liu, H.Y. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 97.


Ageratum yellow vein bigeminivirus

      (1) S.M. Wong, 1993. (3) Standard acronym: AYVV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.005. (8) First reported in Ageratum conyzoides. (9) From Singapore.
(10) By Wong et al. (1993). (13) Ageratum conyzoides vein yellowing. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (24) Not transmitted by
aphids. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in India, Singapore, and
Thailand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Asystasia nemorum leaf
downcurling, chlorosis and mosaic. Emilia sonchifolia leaf downcurling, vein
yellowing. Oxalis barrelieri vein yellowing, leaf downcurling, leaf
distortion. Phyllanthus debilis vein yellowing. Synedrella nodiflora vein
yellowing, mosaic, stunting. (44) Carica papaya, Citrullus lanatus, Cleome
rutidosperma, Cucumis melo, Eclipta prostrata. (45) Ageratum conyzoides. (46)
Ageratum conyzoides (W). (47) Ageratum conyzoides, or Asystasia nemorum, or
Emilia sonchifolia, or Oxalis barrelieri, or Phyllanthus debilis, or
Synedrella nodiflora. (48) Carica papaya, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cleome
rutidosperma, or Cucumis melo, or Eclipta prostrata, or Glycine max, or
Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Acanthaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <3/4>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Oxalidaceae <1/1>. (51) Caricaceae <1/1>, or
Cleomaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (52) AYVV seems not to be transmitted by
whitefly to ornamental Ageratum hybrids. (53) Tan and Wong (1993). (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: best by ISEM. (61) Virions
geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65)
Virions 30 nm in length. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular.
(92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.741 kb. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 44560. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X74516
Em_vi:AYVV Gb_vi:AYVV ageratum yellow vein virus V1, V2, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5
genes. 12/95 2741 bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Fibrillar rings. (179) Bigeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: cassava African mosaic virus. (187) Tan, H.N.P. and Wong,
S.M. (1993). J. Phytopathology 139: 165. Wong, S.M., Swanson, M.M. and
Harrison, B.D. Plant Path. 42: 137.


Agropyron mosaic rymovirus

      (1) W.G. Langenberg and N.L. Robertson, 1991. (2) Synonyms: agropyron
green mosaic virus, agropyron streak mosaic virus, agropyron yellow mosaic
virus, couch grass streak mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: AgMV. (4)
Strains: PV75 severe isolate, PV101, mild isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.2.0.002. (8) First reported in Elytrigia repens. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By McKinney, 1937. (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13) Elytrigia
repens, Triticum aestivum, T. durum light green/yellow mosaic; leaves may
become chlorotic and plants stunted. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by Abacarus hystrix. (19) Transmitted
by Eriophyidae. (24) Not transmitted by Aculus mckenziei, Eriophyes tulipae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by
Slykhuis (1962; 1969). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the North
American region. (39) Spreads in Canada, or Finland, or the USA. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic mottle and streaks. (43) Elytrigia repens, Elytrigia intermedia,
Lophopyrum elongatum, Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum, T. durum light
green/yellow mosaic in leaves; plants may die. (44) Avena sativa, Bromus
inermis, Echinochloa crus-galli, Hordeum jubatum, Lolium perenne. (45)
Elytrigia repens, Triticum aestivum. (46) Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Bromus
secalinus, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Elytrigia repens, or Hordeum vulgare,
or Lolium multiflorum, or Lophopyrum elongatum, or Poa pratensis, or Secale
cereale, or Setaria viridis, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum. (48)
Avena sativa, or Bromus inermis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Echinochloa
crus-galli, or Hordeum jubatum, or Lolium perenne. (50) Gramineae <11/17>.
(51) Gramineae <6/17>. (53) Slykhuis (1961; 1973); Slykhuis and Bell (1966).
(54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58)
Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Staples and Brakke (1963);
Slykhuis and Bell (1966). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 700-760 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 165 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8-10 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8-10 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Langenberg and Robertson: polyadenylated full-length RNA
genomes were obtained from partially purified virions with proteinase K and
SDS, phenol/chloroform extraction, ethanol precipitation, and oligo-d(T)
cellulose chromatography. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a VPg. (111) Poly A
region the 3' end has a poly (A) tail. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 41763. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA not
found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (134) Coat protein.
(152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Langenberg (1991)>. (153) One
protein found. (154) Mr 68000-72000. (155) Pinwheels. (164) Genome replicates
<presumably> in cytoplasm. (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the
cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, epidermis and the meristems. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Rymovirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: hordeum mosaic and wheat streak mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: oat necrotic mottle and ryegrass mosaic
viruses. (184) The 3' ends of the genomes of agropyron mosaic and hordeum
mosaic viruses are 73% homologous. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: use ISEM
and immunogold labelling. (187) Langenberg, W.G. (1991). J. gen. Virol. 72:
493. McKinney, H.H. (1937). U.S. Dept Agric. Circular No. 442, 23 pp.
Robertson, N.L., French, R. and Langenberg, W.G. (1990). Phytopathology 80:
1018. Slykhuis, J.T. (1961). Can. J. Pl. Sci. 41: 211. Slykhuis, J.T. (1962).
Can. J. Bot. 40: 1439. Slykhuis, J.T. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 29. Slykhuis,
J.T. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 118, 4 pp. Slykhuis, J.T. and
Bell, W. (1966). Can. J. Bot. 44: 1191. Staples, R. and Brakke, M. (1963).
Phytopathology 53: 969.


Ahlum waterborne (?) carmovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: AWBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.002. (8) First reported in water from River Ahlum. (9) From Germany.
(10) By Yi et al. (1992). (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Germany. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. quinoa, Nicotiana benthamiana and N. clevelandii. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <2/2>. (60) Method: Gallitelli et al. (1985). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.7 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.7 kb. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 37800. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Bean mild
mosaic, blackgram mottle, carnation mottle, cucumber leaf spot, cucumber
soil-borne, elderberry latent, galinsoga mosaic, glycine mottle, hibiscus
chlorotic ringspot, melon necrotic spot, narcissus tip necrosis, pelargonium
flower break, saguaro cactus, tephrosia symptomless and turnip crinkle
carmoviruses and 12 tombusviruses. (184) In Northern blot hybridization tests,
the genomic RNA showed some homology with that of Weddel waterborne
carmovirus. (187) Gallitelli, D., Hull, R. and Koenig, R. (1985). J. gen.
Virol. 66: 1523. Yi, L., Lesemann, D.-E., Koenig, R., Rüdel, M. and
Pfeilstetter, E. (1992). J. Phytopath. 134: 121.


Alfalfa 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) G.P. Accotto, 1991. (2) Synonyms: alfalfa temperate virus (in part).
(3) Standard acronym: ACV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.002. (8) First
reported in Medicago sativa. (9) From Japan. (10) By Natsuaki et al. (1986);
Luisoni et al. (1987). (13) Medicago sativa symptomless. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35)
Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region
and the Middle East. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the
Eurasian region, the Middle East and Japan. (45) Medicago sativa. (47)
Medicago sativa. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Accotto et al. (1990). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.34-1.35 g cm3
in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 3.67 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 1.9 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 1.77 kb
<pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by phenol/chloroform extraction in
the presence of 0.5% SDS. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the
larger> 67000. (134) P1 protein possible RNA-dependent RNA polymerase,
obtained from in vitro translation of the large RNA segment. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 53000. (136) P2 coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Accotto et
al. (1990). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae.
(180) : Partitiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
hop trefoil 1 alphacryptovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: beet 1, carnation 1, radish yellow edge, red clover, vicia and white
clover 1 alphacryptoviruses. (187) Accotto, G.P., Marzachi, C., Luisoni, E.
and Milne, R.G. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 433. Boccardo, G., Lisa, V.,
Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171. Luisoni, E.,
Milne, R.G., Accotto, G.P. and Boccardo, G. (1987). Intervirology 28: 144.
Natsuaki, K.T., Natsuaki, T., Okuda, S., Teranaka, M., Yamashita, S. and Doi,
Y. (1984). J. Agric. Sci. 29: 49. Natsuaki, T., Natsuaki, K.T., Okuda, S.,
Teranaka, M., Milne, R.G., Boccardo, G. and Luisoni, E. (1986). Intervirology
25: 69.


Alfalfa 2 (?) betacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ACV-2. (5) ICTV decimal code
49.0.4.T.006. (8) First reported in Medicago sativa. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Boccardo et al. (1987). (13) Medicago sativa symptomless. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Japan and Italy. (47) Medicago sativa. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>.
(61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 38 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (179) <Possible> Betacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) :
Partitiviridae. (186) The virus was first found occurring in complex with
alfalfa 1 alphacryptovirus. (187) Accotto, G.P., Marzachi, C. Luisoni, E. and
Milne, R.G. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 433. Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni,
E. and Milne, R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171.


Alfalfa mosaic alfamovirus

      (1) L. van Vloten-Doting, 1981. Revised 1987 by A.J. Gibbs. (2)
Synonyms: lucerne mosaic virus, potato calico virus. (3) Standard acronym:
AMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in Medicago
sativa. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Weimer (1931). (11) Symptoms persist, or
disappear soon after infection. (13) The virus naturally infects many species
including: Caryopteris incana white fleck. Cicer arietinum wilting.
Lycopersicon esculentum severe necrosis. Apium graveolens, A. graveolens var.
rapaceum, Lactuca sativa, Malva parviflora, Trifolium incarnatum, T. repens,
Viburnum opulus mosaic. Medicago sativa mosaic, mottle, malformation, but
often symptomless during summer. Nicotiana tabacum, Lupinus spp. mosaic and
mottle. Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata, V. radiata, Astragalus
glycyphyllos, Glycine max, Lablab purpureus, Lens culinaris, Capsicum annuum
necrotic or chlorotic local lesions, sometimes mosaic. Philadelphus sp. white
mottle. Pisum sativum necrosis. Solanum tuberosum calico and tuber necrosis.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Myzus persicae and at least 13 other species. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <50% in
alfalfa seeds from individual infected plants and up to 10% in commercial
seed>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by
Gibbs (1962); Garran and Gibbs (1982); Edwardson and Christie (1986). (37)
Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, mottles or
ringspots. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions;
systemic chlorotic and necrotic flecks which distinguish this virus from
cucumber mosaic virus. Ocimum basilicum systemic yellow mosaic. Phaseolus
vulgaris most strains induce necrotic local lesions, some induce chlorotic
local lesions or a systemic mottle, vein necrosis and leaf malformation. Pisum
sativum local lesions and/or wilting of inoculated leaves; systemic stem
necrosis and plant death. Vicia faba black necrotic local lesions, stem
necrosis and plant death, a few isolates induce systemic mottle. Vigna
unguiculata necrotic local lesions, not systemic, some isolates induce various
systemic symptoms. Nicotiana tabacum necrotic and chlorotic local lesions
(some strains induce no local symptoms); systemic mottle, vein banding,
ringspots, rarely malformation. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L,W), C. quinoa (L,W), Phaseolus vulgaris (L,W),
Vigna unguiculata (L). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Ageratum conyzoides, or
Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium
graveolens, or Apium graveolens var. rapaceum, or Arachis hypogaea, or
Astragalus glycyphyllos, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Caryopteris incana, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or
Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Cichorium
endiva, or Coriandrum sativum, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Daucus
carota <var. sativa>, or Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or
Emilia sagittata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lablab purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Linum usitatissimum, or Lupinus
albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Malva
parviflora, or Matthiola incana, or Medicago hispida, or Medicago sativa, or
Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum
basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Philadelphus, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Phytolacca
americana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum melongena, or
Solanum nigrum, or Solanum nodiflorum, or Solanum rostratum, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium dubium, or Trifolium hybridum, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Tropaeolum majus, or Viburnum opulus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or
Zinnia elegans. (48) Atriplex hortensis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata,
or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Datura
stramonium, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lotus corniculatus, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Sesbania exaltata, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia sativa,
or Vicia villosa. (50) Amaranthaceae <4/4>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <3/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/9>, or
Compositae <8/9>, or Cruciferae <3/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <27 /31>, or Linaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae
<2/2>, or Philadelphaceae <1/1>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae
<1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <20/23>, or Tetragoniaceae <1
/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <4/4>, or Verbenaceae <1/1>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <3/9>, or Compositae <1/9>, or Cruciferae <1/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/31>, or
Solanaceae <3/23>. (53) Thornberry (1966); Hull (1969); Schmelzer et al.
(1973). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 1-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: most negative stains
disrupt virions unless they are first fixed with formaldehyde. The virions of
some strains are stable in AM (Price and McLean, 1982). (60) Method: Van
Vloten-Doting and Jaspars (1972). (61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (65) Virions <mostly> 30, 35, 43, and 56 nm in length. (71) Virions
18 nm wide. (76) Four sedimenting components in purified preparations <at
least>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 94 S <B>. (78) Of the
other(s) 82 S <M>, or 78 S <Ta>, or 66 S <Tb; minor components of 53 S and 60
S found in some isolates>. (79) Density 1.381 g cm3 in CsCl <Ta>, or 1.385 g
cm3 in CsCl <B>. (81) Density in Cs2SO4 1.278 g cm3. (82) Isoelectric point pH
4.6. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.7-1.8. (84) Virions contain 16 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 84 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.27 kb. (92)
Genome of three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest, RNA-1>
3.64 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.59 kb <RNA-2>. (95) The 3rd largest 2.04 kb
<RNA-3>. (100) Base composition 23 % G. (101) Base composition 25 % A. (102)
Base composition 23 % C. (103) Base composition 29 % U. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap. (108) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with proteases, or decreased when deproteinised with proteases.
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent
<provided RNA-4 is present>. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional
factor required for infectivity. (113) Additional factor coat protein mRNA or
RNA-4 of 0.88 kb. RNA-1 and RNA-2 alone can infect protoplasts. (114) Genome
has no tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Cornelissen et
al. (1983); Collot et al. (1977); Barker et al. (1983); Ravelonandro et al.
(1984); Gunn and Symons (1980); Koper-Zwarthoff et al. (1980); Houwing and
Jaspars (1982). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12321. (118) Sequence database accession

mutant Tbts7 RNA3 (coat protein-encoding), 5' end fragment. (120) Nongenomic

24250. (145) Method of preparation: Kruseman et al. (1971). (146) Amino acid
sequence: Van Beynum (1977) for AMV-425 and Castel (1979) for AMV-VRU. (165)
Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in chloroplasts. (173) Virions found in
cytoplasmic invaginations in the chloroplasts. (174) Inclusions <cytoplasmic>
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176)
Vacuolated bodies derived from spheroidal and granular bodies, vacuolated or
non-vacuolated bodies containing nucleoprotein and hexagonal crystals. (177)
They contain virions <aggregated). Also tubular bodies are found in the
nucleus (Hull et al., 1969>. (179) Alfamovirus: Bromoviridae <the type
species>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (184) No other viruses are definitive
alfamoviruses. However, sunflower ringspot virus (J. Dale, pers. comm.) and a
virus isolated from Mercurialis perennis in the U.K. (A.A. Brunt, pers. comm.)
have virions of similar shape, but are not serologically related. Cassava
Ivorian bacilliform virus (Fargette et al., 1991), and allied viruses, is
unrelated. Some alfalfa mosaic virus genes are homologous to those of the
ilar-, bromo- and cucumoviruses. (187) Barker, R.F., Jarvis, N.P., Thompson,
D.U., Loesch-Fries, L.S. and Hall, T.C. (1983). Nucl. Acids Res. 11: 2881.

Alligatorweed stunting (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: AWSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.T.U.01. (8) First reported in Alternanthera philoxeroides. (9) From
Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Hill and Zettler (1973). (13) Alternanthera
philoxeroides leaf reddening and malformation; severe stunting. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the North American
region. (39) Spreads in the USA <Florida>. (47) Alternanthera philoxeroides.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 1717 nm.
(171) Virions found in leaves and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(179) <Possible> Closterovirus. (187) Hill, H.R. and Zettler, F.W. (1973).
Phytopathology 63: 443. Milne, R.G. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 4, The
Filamentous Plant Viruses, p.3; ed. R.G. Milne. Plenum Press, New York.


Alsike clover vein mosaic virus

      (1) K. Lindsten, 1981. Checked 1986. (2) Synonyms: clover Alsike vein
mosaic virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.01. (8) First reported in
Trifolium hybridum. (9) From Sweden. (10) By Gerhardson and Lindsten (1971).
(11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Trifolium hybridum vein chlorosis,
malformation. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, not
systemic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna
unguiculata chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Lathyrus odoratus chlorotic
local lesions, wilting, death. Pisum sativum necrotic local lesions; leaf
malformation, death. Trifolium hybridum, T. incarnatum systemic mosaic,
chlorosis. Vicia faba necrotic and chlorotic local lesions; usually not
systemic. (45) Trifolium hybridum. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/13>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<3/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/13>, or Solanaceae <7/7>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Gerhardson et al. (1971). (54) TIP: 76 °C. (55) LIV: 64 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 7. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 123 S. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: red clover necrotic mosaic, red clover mottle, alfalfa
mosaic and arabis mosaic viruses. (187) Gerhardson, B. and Lindsten, K.
(1971). Phytopath. Z. 72: 76.


Alstroemeria (?) ilarvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Alstroemeria caryophylla `Ligtu' hybrids. (9) From England. (10)
By Brunt and Phillips (1981). (13) Alstroemeria caryophylla `Ligtu' hybrids
faint chlorosis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus
not transmitted by contact between plants. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in England. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible <but only 6
families have been tested>. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
local lesions, systemic chlorosis, mosaic, mosaic line patterns. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor, C. murale, Gomphrena globosa local
lesions; severe systemic chlorosis and malformation. Nicotiana megalosiphon
local etched rings; systemic chlorosis or white necrotic line patterns.
Petunia × hybrida systemic mosaic. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mild
chlorotic vein-banding. (44) Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana rustica,
Brassica juncea. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, N. benthamiana,
Chenopodium quinoa, Petunia × hybrida. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L and W),
Nicotiana megalosiphon (L and W), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Alstroemeria
caryophylla <`Ligtu' hybrids>, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Brassica
juncea, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana rustica. (50)
Alstroemeriaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <8/10>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/10>. (53) Phillips and Brunt
(1986). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4 <purified preparation>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: usually only seen in
purified preparations. (60) Method: Phillips and Brunt (1986). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25-32 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (179) <Possible> Ilarvirus:
Bromoviridae. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: prunus necrotic ringspot, spinach latent, hydrangea mosaic and
tobacco streak (dewberry latent isolate) viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: asparagus 2, crimson clover latent, elm
mottle and tobacco streak (asparagus and dahlia isolates) viruses. (187)
Brunt, A.A. and Phillips, S. (1981). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1979, p.
151. Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A. (1986). Acta Hort. 177: 227.


Alstroemeria mosaic potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: AlMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Alstroemeria psittacina. (9) From England.
(10) By Brunt (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Alstroemeria caryophylla and
Alstroemeria psittacina some flower break and variable leaf chlorosis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian
region and the North American region. (39) Spreads in the Netherlands and the
USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show faint chlorotic local lesions, mild systemic chlorosis.
(43) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, N. benthamiana faint chlorotic
lesions and mild systemic veinal chlorosis. Chenopodium quinoa, C. murale, C.
capitatum, Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions, not systemic.
(44) Narcissus pseudonarcissus, Cucumis sativus, Belamcanda chinensis,
Trifolium incarnatum, Solanum tuberosum. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
benthamiana, N. megalosiphon. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Chenopodium
quinoa (L), C. murale (L). (47) Alstroemeria caryophylla, or Alstroemeria
psittacina, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana plumbaginafolia, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Belamcanda chinensis,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lilium formosanum,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Physalis floridana, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Alstroemeriaceae <2/2>,
or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or Solanaceae <8/18>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10 /18>.
(53) Phillips and Brunt (1986). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Phillips and Brunt (1986). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 745-750 nm.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 145 S. (79)
Density 1.296 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Brunt et al. (1980). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in
the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32500. (134) Coat protein.
(145) Method of preparation: Brunt et al. (1980). (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in
shape. (176) Conical or cylindrical. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: iris severe
mosaic (SDI 2), narcissus late season yellows (SDI 2), potato Y (SDI 3-7),
clover yellow vein (SDI 7), watermelon mosaic 2 (SDI 7) and pea mosaic (SDI 9)
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: asparagus I,
bean yellow mosaic (crocus and gladiolus isolates), carnation vein mottle,
datura shoestring, henbane mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, iris mild mosaic,
lettuce mosaic, narcissus degeneration, narcissus yellow stripe, nerine yellow
stripe, passiflora woodiness, pepper veinal mottle, potato Y (veinal necrosis
strain), tobacco etch and turnip mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: ISEM with `decoration'. (187) Brunt, A.A. (1975). Rep. Glasshouse
Crops Res. Inst. for 1974: 117. Brunt, A.A. Barton, R.J., Phillips, S. and
Lana, A.O. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 37. Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A.
(1986). Acta Hort. 177: 227. Maat, D.Z. (1977). Rep. Res. Inst. Pl. Prot. for
1976: p.63.


Alstroemeria streak (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994; S.M. Wong, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: AlSV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.001. (8) First reported in Alstroemeria sp. (9)
From New York, U.S.A. (10) By Wong et al. (1992). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms streaking and stunting. (13) Alstroemeria streaking, stunting and
mosaic of leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Macrosiphum euphorbiae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted
by contact between plants. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Netherlands, UK and USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic streaking. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Hyoscyamus niger, Tetragonia tetragonioides local
chlorotic lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N.
hesperis 67A, N. occidentalis P1 local chlorotic lesions, systemic chlorosis.
Nicotiana occidentalis systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana occidentalis Japan
systemic chlorotic streaks parallel to midrib. (44) Nicotiana glutinosa,
Chenopodium quinoa. (45) Nicotiana occidentalis Japan. (46) Nicotiana
occidentalis Japan (W). (47) Alstroemeria, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana hesperis <cv. 67A>, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana glutinosa. (50)
Alstroemeriaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <5/6>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <1/6>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Wong et al. (1992). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.34. (92) Genome unipartite.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels <and laminated aggregates>. (179) <Possible>
unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: alstroemeria mosaic virus. (187) De Blank, C.M., van Zaayen,
A. and Bouwen, I. (1994). Acta Hort. 377: 199. Wong, S.M., Chang, C.G.,
Reiser, R.A. and Horst, R.K. (1994). Acta. Hort. 377: 63. Wong, S.M., Reiser,
R.A. and Horst, R.K. (1992). Phytopathology 82: 722. Van Zaayen, A., de Blank,
C. and Bouwen, I. (1994). Europ. J. Pl. Path. 100: 85.


Amaranthus leaf mottle potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips and O. Lovisolo, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: AmLMV. (4)
Strains: type and Cirsium (Casetto et al., 1986). (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Amaranthus deflexus. (9) From Turin,
Italy. (10) By Lovisolo and Lisa (1976). (12) Symptoms leaf mottling. (13)
Amaranthus deflexus leaf mottling, blistered mosaic and growth reduction.
Cirsium arvense leaf mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian
region. (39) Spreads in Italy, Morocco, and Spain. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local chlorotic
lesions; systemic chlorosis. (43) Amaranthus caudatus, A. hybridus, A.
tricolor, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii systemic leaf chlorosis.
Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions, systemic
mottling. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Saxa chlorotic local lesions, not systemic.
(44) Cucurbita pepo, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, Pisum sativum,
Vigna unguiculata. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Amaranthus deflexus, or Amaranthus hybridus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or
Amaranthus tricolor, or Atriplex hortensis, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cirsium arvense, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lupinus albus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum,
or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (48) Beta vulgaris, or
Capsicum annuum, or Celosia cristata, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo,
or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Pisum sativum, or Trifolium pratense, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae
<6/7>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/6>, or Solanaceae <5/9>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/7>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/7>, or Cucurbitaceae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/6>, or Solanaceae <4/9>. (53) Lovisolo
and Lisa (1976 and 1979); Casetto et al. (1986). (60) Method: Lovisolo and
Lisa (1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 780 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.16. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in leaves. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: plum pox and
bean yellow mosaic viruses, also Lisianthus potyvirus (Lisa et al., 1990),
peanut mottle (Rajeshwari et al., 1983) and zucchini yellow mosaic (Lisa and
Lecoq, 1984) viruses distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: clover yellow vein (English isolate and pea necrosis strain), lettuce
mosaic, watermelon mosaic 2, wisteria vein mosaic, celery mosaic, henbane
mosaic, potato Y, turnip mosaic and papaya ringspot viruses. (183) The Cirsium
strain infects Cirsium arvense, Lactuca sativa, Physalis floridana and
Trigonella foenum-graecum. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM and
decoration. (187) Casetta, A., D'Agostino, G. and Conti, M. (1986). Inform.
Fitopatol. 36:43 Lisa, V., Dellavalle, G., Vaira, A.M., Milne, R.G., Masenga,
V., Boccardo, G. and D'Aquilio, M. (1990). Lisa, V. and Lecoq, H. (1984).

Amaranthus mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. (2) Synonyms: pigweed mosaic virus (Singh et al.,
1972). (4) Strains: Coimbatore strain (Govindaswamy et al., 1967). (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.DE.05. (8) First reported in Amaranthus lividus and A.
viridis. (9) From Delhi, India. (10) By Phatak (1965). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Amaranthus lividus, A. viridis systemic blotchy mosaic and mottle,
sometimes with severe vein yellowing. A. caudatus, A. tricolor systemic
mosaic, leaves puckered. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Govindaswamy et
al. (1967); Mali (1985); Phatak (1965); Singh et al. (1972). (38) Spreads in
the Central Asian region. (39) Spreads in India <Coimbatore (Tamil Nadu) and
Delhi (Andhra Pradesh)>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics and mottling. (43)
Amaranthus cruentus, A. dilatum, A. leucocarpus, A. tricolor systemic mosaic
and mottling. (44) Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, Capsicum annuum,
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Nicandra physalodes, Solanum nigrum. (45)
Amaranthus viridis, A. caudatus and A. tricolor. (46) Amaranthus caudatus (W).
(47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus cruentus, or Amaranthus dilatum, or
Amaranthus leucocarpus, or Amaranthus lividus, or Amaranthus tricolor, or
Amaranthus viridis, or Gomphrena globosa, or Petunia × hybrida. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis melo, or Cucurbita moschata,
or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum
melongena, or Solanum nigrum. (50) Amaranthaceae <8/8>, or Solanaceae <1/8>.
(51) Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/8>. (53) Govindaswamy et
al. (1967). Phatak (1965). Singh et al. (1972). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV:
1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 700-728 nm.
(71) Virions 14 nm wide. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae.
(184) Phatak (1965) reported a mosaic disease of Amaranthus lividus and A.
viridis from Delhi, India in 1965 and called it amaranthus mosaic virus. This
has been regarded as the type culture of AMV. Subsequently a variant has been
reported by Govindaswamy et al. (1967) from Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, India in
naturally infected A. caudatus and A. tricolor. The Coimbatore isolate differs
from the type culture (strain) in infecting Gomphrena globosa and Petunia ×
hybrida. Singh et al. (1972) reported its virion morphology and it has since
been considered a member of the potyvirus group (Mali, 1985), but its possible
relationship with amaranthus leaf mottle potyvirus (Hollings and Brunt, 1981;
Lovisolo and Lisa, 1976) needs to be tested. (187) Govindasamy, C.V.,
Mariappan, V., Kandaswamy, T.K. and Padmanabham, C. (1967). Madras Agric. J.
54: 35. Hollings, M. and Brunt, A.A. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
245, 7 pp. Lovisolo, O. and Lisa, V. (1976). 4th Congr. Medit. Phytopath.
Union, Poljopr Znanst Smotra 39: 553. Mali, V.R. (1985). Int. J. Trop. Pl.
Dis. 3: 93. Phatak, H.C. (1965). Curr. Sci. 34: 645. Singh, S., Varma, A.,
Chenulu, V.V. and Verma, V.S. (1972). Phytopath. Z. 75: 82.


Amaryllis (?) alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Amaryllis sp. (9) From India. (10) By Raizada et al. (1983). (12)
Symptoms Amaryllis sp. symptomless. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in India. (47) Amaryllis. (50) Amaryllidaceae <1/1>. (179) <Possible>
Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: ELISA. (187) Raizada, R.K., Srivasta, K.M. and Singh, B.P. (1983).
Ind. J. Exp. Biol. 21: 299.


Amazon lily mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: ALiMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.002. (8) First reported in Eucharis grandiflora. (9) From Japan. (10)
By Terami et al. (1993). (13) Eucharis grandiflora leaf mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (37) Geographical distribution probably
restricted. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads in Japan.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions,
not systemic. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic leaf mosaic. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Eucharis grandiflora, or
Nicotiana benthamiana. (50) Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>. (60) Method: Terami et al. (1993). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760 nm. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.32. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 10.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
35000. (134) Coat. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) <Possible> unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: alstroemeria mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, hyacinth mosaic, onion
yellow dwarf, ornithogalum mosaic, potato Y, watermelon mosaic-2 and zucchini
yellow mosaic potyviruses. (187) Terami, F., Honda, Y. and Fukumoto, F.
(1993). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 59: 334.


Anthoxanthum latent blanching hordeivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ALBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
32.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Anthoxanthum odoratum. (9) From
Aberystwyth, Wales, U.K. (10) By Catherall and Chamberlain (1981a and b). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Anthoxanthum odoratum inconspicuous chlorotic stripes
in leaves, or symptomless infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in the UK

odoratum inconspicuous chlorotic leaf stripes in some plants. Avena sativa,
Hordeum vulgare symptomless systemic infection. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa local lesions; no systemic infection. Lagurus ovatus inconspicuous leaf
chlorosis, soon followed by wilting and death of leaves. Zea mays brown
streaks in systemically infected leaves. (44) Beta vulgaris, Dactylis
glomerata, Festuca elatior, Lolium perenne, Triticum aestivum. (45)
Anthoxanthum odoratum. (46) Anthoxanthum odoratum (W). (47) Anthoxanthum
odoratum, or Avena sativa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium

not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with clear modal

Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <in aggregates>.
(179) Hordeivirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: barley

Anthriscus (?) carlavirus

      (1) P. van Dijk and L. Bos, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: AntV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 14.0.T.1.001. (8) First reported in Anthriscus sylvestris. (9)
From the Netherlands. (10) By Van Dijk and Bos (1989). (11) Symptoms none.
(13) Anthriscus sylvestris, Angelica sylvestris, Carum carvi symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Cavariella aegopodii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the Netherlands. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mottles,
mosaics or symptomless. (43) Ammi majus interveinal chlorosis and systemic
yellow mosaic. Anthriscus cerefolium interveinal yellowing or mottling,
necrotic striping and leaf rolling. Apium graveolens chlorotic local lesions
by some isolates. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa pin-point local
lesions. (44) Nicotiana benthamiana, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Ammi majus,
Nicotiana pavicola. (46) Ammi majus (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L). (47) Ammi majus, or Angelica sylvestris, or Anthriscus cerefolium,
or Anthriscus sylvestris, or Apium graveolens, or Carum carvi, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana pavicola, or Pastinaca
sativa. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Celosia argentea, or Coriandrum sativum, or
Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Solanaceae <1/8>, or
Umbelliferae <7/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or

Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 690 nm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions

electron microscopy. (187) Van Dijk, P. and Bos, L. (1989). Neth. J. Pl.
Path.95 Suppl. 2: 34pp.


Anthriscus yellows waikavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: AYV. (5) ICTV decimal code
65.0.2.0.002. (8) First reported in Anthriscus sylvestris. (9) From the U.K.
(10) By Murant and Goold (1968). (13) Anthriscus sylvestris no conspicuous
symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (29) Virus can help the vector
transmission of another virus <parsnip yellow fleck sequivirus>. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian
region. (39) Spreads in the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Anthriscus cerefolium systemically infected leaves faintly chlorotic, then
reddish purple and slightly distorted; plants stunted. Coriandrum sativum
slight yellowing of systemically infected leaves; plants stunted. (44)
Bupleurum rotundifolium, Daucus carota, Eryngium planum, Pastinaca sativa,
Pimpinella anisum, Trinia glauca. (45) Anthriscus cerefolium. (46) Anthriscus
cerefolium (W). (47) Anthriscus cerefolium, or Anthriscus sylvestris, or
Coriandrum sativum. (48) Bupleurum rotundifolium, or Daucus carota, or
Eryngium planum, or Pastinaca sativa, or Pimpinella anisum, or Trinia glauca.
(50) Umbelliferae <3/9>. (51) Umbelliferae <6/9>. (53) Murant and Goold
(1968). (55) LIV: <purified virions in 1 mM CaCl2 or less remain intact for>
45 days <at 4°C>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Hemida et
al. (1989). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
29 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.52 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.27 g cm3 in CsCl <T>.
(83) A260/A280 ratio 1.83 <B>, or 0.73 <T>. (84) Virions contain 42 % nucleic
acid <B>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 58 % protein <B>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 10.6 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 10.6 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) four. (133) Mr <of the largest> 35000.
(134) Coat protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 28400. (136) Coat. (137) Mr of 3rd
largest 24300. (138) Coat. (139) Mr of 4th largest 22300. (140) Coat. (168)
Acts as helper for another virus. (169) Acts as a helper for parsnip yellow
fleck sequivirus. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Waikavirus:
Sequiviridae. (180) : Sequiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: maize chlorotic dwarf and rice tungro spherical viruses.
(187) Elnager, S. and Murant, A.F. (1976a). Ann. appl. Biol. 84: 153. Elnager,
S. and Murant, A.F. (1976b). Ann. appl. Biol. 84: 169. Hemida, S.K., Murant,
A.F. and Duncan, G.H. (1989). Ann. appl. Biol. 114: 71. Murant, A.F. and
Goold, R.A. (1968). Ann. appl. Biol. 62: 123. Murant, A.F. and Roberts, I.M.
(1977). Ann. appl. Biol. 85: 403. Murant, A.F., Roberts, I.M. and Elnager, S.
(1976). J. gen. Virol. 53: 321.


Apple chlorotic leaf spot trichovirus

      (1) R.M. Lister, 1987. (2) Synonyms: pear ring pattern mosaic virus
(Cropley, 1969), apple latent virus type 1, plum pseudopox virus, quince stunt
virus. (3) Standard acronym: ACLSV. (4) Strains: peach strain, apple strain,
(Chairez and Lister; 1973). (5) ICTV decimal code 76.0.1.0.001. (8) First
reported in Malus spp. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Mink and Shay (1959; 1962);
Lister et al. (1965). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Malus platycarpa
line patterns and chlorotic rings. Malus sylvestris cv. R12740-7A chlorotic
leaf spots and stem pitting. Malus sylvestris cv. Spy chlorotic spots and stem
pitting, chlorosis and stunting. Malus sylvestris cv. Virginia Crab stem
pitting. Cydonia oblonga (Quince) C7/1 chlorotic rings and spots. Pyronia
veitchii chlorosis and stunting. Pyrus communis ring patterns, mosaic.
Crataegus spp. chlorotic ring spots. Prunus armeniaca ring patterns, mosaic.
Prunus spinosa chlorotic ringspot patterns. Prunus persica dark green mottle.
Prunus domestica bark split and pseudopox. Prunus armeniaca stock scion
incompatibility and pseudopox (Bar-Joseph et al., 1979; Cropley, 1968;
Cropley, 1969; Dunez et al., 1972; Lister and Bar-Joseph, 1981; Luckwill and
Campbell, 1963; Marenaud, 1968; Pena-Iglesias and Gonsalves, 1975; Posnette
and Ellenberger, 1957; Yanase, 1974; Yanase et al., 1975). (17) Transmitted by
eudorylamoid nematodes (Fritzsche and Kegler, 1968); an unconfirmed report.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting <possibly by root-grafts; Gilmer et al., 1971>. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Bar-Joseph et al. (1979); Lister
and Bar-Joseph (1981). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <and probably
wherever apples are cultivated>. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region, the
Eurasian region, the North American region, and the Pacific region. (39)
Spreads in Australia, China, and New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Malus sylvestris cv. R12740-7A asymmetric blotches and
malformation of young leaves. M. platycarpa (Long Ashton clone) irregular
chlorotic rings and line patterns, small leaves shed prematurely,
malformation. Chenopodium quinoa large etched local lesions, becoming
necrotic, systemic chlorotic spotting, mottling, ring and line patterns,
chlorosis and necrosis. C. amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions, surrounded
by necrotic dots. Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Pinto, Bountiful, Kinghorn
purple-brown necrotic spots or rings (1-3 mm), not systemic. (44) Nicotiana
glutinosa. Apple stem grooving capillovirus, but not apple chlorotic leafspot
trichovirus causes Virginia Crab stem grooving symptoms in Malus. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crataegus, or Cydonia
oblonga <C7/1>, or Malus platycarpa, or Malus sylvestris, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Prunus armeniaca, or Prunus domestica, or Prunus persica, or
Prunus spinosa, or Pyronia veitchii, or Pyrus communis. (48) Nicotiana
glutinosa. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or
Rosaceae <10/10>. (51) Solanaceae <1/1>. (52) For symptoms in other species
and horticultural varieties of Malus and woody Rosaceae, see Luckwill and
Campbell (1963); Cropley (1969); Sweet (1980). (53) Barnett and Murant (1971);
Cropley (1968); Lister et al. (1965); Nemec (1967); Saksena and Mink (1969);
Sweet (1980). (54) TIP: 52-55 °C <Lister et al., 1965>. (55) LIV: 1 days <at
20°C>, or 10 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: best stained with UA or UF; breakage
occurs in PTA (Lister et al., 1965). (60) Method: de Sequeira and Lister
(1969); Lister and Hadidi (1971). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 720-740 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure <laterally>. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix
3.8-3.9 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 96 S. (81) Density 1.27 g cm3 in Cs2SO4 (Bar-Joseph
et al., 1974). (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 7.555 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 7.555 kb <Lister and Bar-Joseph, 1981; Bar-Joseph et al., 1979>. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lister and Bar-Joseph, (1981); Bar-Joseph et
al. (1974; 1979). (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap
<probably>. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region 3' terminus.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12175. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D14996
Em(40)_vi:APC2165K Gb(84)_vi:APCCOMS Apple chlorotic leaf spot virus, complete
sequence. 2/94 7,552bp. M58152 Em(40)_vi:APCCG Gb(84)_vi:APCCG Apple chlorotic
leaf spot virus, complete genome. 8/91 7,555bp. 2 sequences. (125) 5 virus
specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus
specified dsRNA 7.56 kbp <pairs>. (127) 2nd largest 6.5 kbp <pairs>. (128) 3rd
largest 5.5 kbp <pairs>. (132) Virion protein(s) one <Lister and Bar-Joseph,
1981; Bar-Joseph et al., 1979>. (133) Mr 23500. (145) Method of preparation:
Chairez and Lister (1973); Bar-Joseph et al. (1979). (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins isolated <Chairez and Lister (1973); Lister and Bar-Joseph
(1981)>. (153) Two proteins found. (154) Mr <c.> 200000. (155) Polymerase
module. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 45000. (157) Movement protein, possibly. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant probably. (179) Trichovirus <the type species>. (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: Virus identified by serological tests, electron
microscopy, symptoms in Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor and Phaseolus
vulgaris cvs Kinghorn, Pinto and Bountiful, and symptoms in graft infected
Russian apple R-127407A. (186) The virus was originally considered a
definitive closterovirus, then became a tentative closterovirus, but is now
the type species of the Trichovirus genus (Martelli et al., 1994). (187)
Bar-Joseph, M., Garnsey, S.M. and Gonsalves, D. (1979). Adv. Virus Res. 25:
93. Cadman, C.H. (1963). Pl. Dis. Reptr 47: 459. Cropley, R. (1968). Ann.
appl. Biol. 61: 361. Cropley, R. (1969). Comm. Bur. Hort. Pl. Crops. Tech.
Commun. No. 30, Suppl. 2/3/4: 10. de Sequeira, O.A. and Lister, R.M. (1969).
Phytopathology 59: 1740. Fritzsche, R. and Kegler, H. (1968). TagBer. dt.
Akad. Landw. Berlin 97: 289. German, S., Candresse, T. Lanneau, M., Pernollet,
J.C. and Dunez, J. (1990). Virology 179: 104. German, S., Candresse, T., Le
Gall, O., Lanneau, M. and Dunez, J. (1992). J. gen. Virol. 73: 767. Lister,
R.M. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 30, 4 pp. Lister, R.M., Bancroft,
J.B. and Nadakavukaren, M.J. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 859. Lister, R.M. and
Bar-Joseph, M. (1981). Closteroviruses. In: Handbook of Plant Virus Infections
and Comparative Diagnosis, p. 809; ed. E. Kurstak. Elsevier/North-Holland
Biomedical Press. Luckwill, L.C. and Campbell, A.I. (1963). Commonw. Bur.
Hort. Pl. Crops. Tech. Commun. No. 30: 789. Martelli, G.P., Candresse, T. and
Namba, S. (1994). Arch. Virol. 134: 451. Nemec, S. (1967). Pl. Dis. Reptr 51:
283. Okhi, S.T., Yoshikawa, N., Inouye, N., and Inouye, T. (1989). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 55: 245. Saksena, K.N. and Mink, G.I. (1969).
Phytopathology 59: 84. Sato, K., Yoshikawa, N. and Takahashi, T. (1993). J.
gen. Virol. 74: 1927. Sweet, J.B. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 94: 83.


Apple mosaic ilarvirus

      (1) R.W. Fulton, 1985. (2) Synonyms: birch line pattern virus, birch
ringspot virus, Dutch plum line pattern virus, European plum line pattern
virus, hop A virus, horse chestnut yellow mosaic virus, rose mosaic virus
(Thomas, 1980; 1981; 1982; 1984a and b). (3) Standard acronym: ApMV. (4)
Strains: mild apple mosaic virus, severe apple mosaic virus. (5) ICTV decimal
code 10.0.2.03.01. (8) First reported in Rosa spp. and Malus domestica. (9)
From the U.S.A. (10) By White (1928) and Bradford and Joley (1933). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Malus domestica and Malus spp. mosaic. Rosaceae (many
species) necrotic ringspots. Humulus spp. mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting <of roots>. (34)
Virus <possibly> not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus <but probably>
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show necrotic and chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottles,
mosaics and ringspots. (43) Amaranthus tricolor, Teramnus uncinatus small
brown local lesions. Catharanthus roseus, Vigna unguiculata systemic chlorotic
lines and rings. Chenopodium quinoa mottling. Crotalaria juncea veinal
necrosis. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions, systemic chlorosis,
stunting. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba necrotic local lesions. Torenia fournieri
bright yellow mosaic. (44) Beta vulgaris, Datura stramonium, Helianthus
annuus, Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Catharanthus roseus, Cucumis
sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris (only certain isolates), Vigna unguiculata (only
certain isolates). (46) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L), Cucumis sativus, (W).
(47) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Amaranthus tricolor, or Cassia occidentalis,
or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Crotalaria juncea, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Fragaria vesca,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Humulus, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Ipomoea nil, or
Malus domestica, or Melilotus albus, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Phaseolus
vulgaris <some isolates>, or Phlox drummondii, or Ricinus communis, or Rosa,
or Rosaceae, or Teramnus uncinatus, or Torenia fournieri, or Tropaeolum majus,
or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Sesbania exaltata. (50)
Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Cannabidaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/5>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/8>, or Polemoniaceae <1 /1>, or Rosaceae <3/3>,
or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/10>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/8>, or Solanaceae <3/10>. (53) Fulton (1952);
Kristensen and Thomson (1963); Posnette and Ellenberger (1963). (54) TIP: 54
°C <in extracts stabilized with mercaptoethanol>. (55) LIV: 0.1-0.2 days <2-4
hours in buffered extracts, 2-5 minutes in crude sap>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3
<in stabilized 2-mercapto-ethanol sap diluted in buffer>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: treat with 1% glutaraldehyde
before negative staining. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 25 and 29 nm in diameter <and probably a third size>. (66)
Virions rounded in profile <and pleomorphic>. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 117 S.
(78) Of the other(s) 88 and 95 S. (84) Virions contain 16 % nucleic acid <all
components>. (85) Virions 84 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome of three parts. (99) Genomic

required for infectivity <coat protein>. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12319. (118)

cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 25000. (145) Method of

Apple necrosis (?) ilarvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.T.DE.2. (8) First
reported in Malus spp. (9) From Japan. (10) By Y. Doi (in Hull et al., 1989).

(1989). In: Virology: Directory and Dictionary of Animal, Bacterial and Plant
