Apple stem grooving capillovirus

      (1) R.M. Lister, 1986. (2) Synonyms: Virginia Crab stem grooving virus,
chenopodium dark green epinasty virus, brown line disease virus. (3) Standard
acronym: ASGV. (4) Strains: apple latent virus Type 2 isolate C431 (Lister et
al., 1965); E-36. (5) ICTV decimal code 13.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in
Malus sylvestris cv. Virginia Crab. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Lister et al.
(1965); de Sequeira (1965 and 1967); Waterworth and Gilmer (1969). (11)
Symptoms <in Virginia Crab apple> persist. (13) Malus sylvestris cv. Virginia
Crab stem grooves, abnormal graft union. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <from
apple, especially in spring, by inoculating extracts from buds, young leaves
or petals ground in 0.05 M phosphate buffer, pH 7-8. Additives such as 2%
(w/v) nicotine base or 2% (w/v) PVP or hide powder help but are not
essential>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<in Chenopodium quinoa>. (36) Studies reported by Mink and Shay (1962). The
disease has been eliminated from some apple scions by heat therapy (30 days at
36°C; de Sequeira and Posnette, 1969). (37) Probably distributed worldwide.
(39) Spreads in Australia, China, India, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, New
Zealand, Portugal, and the UK <probably occurs wherever apple trees are
cultivated>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, systemic
mosaics or necrosis. (43) Malus sylvestris cv. Virginia Crab grooves in the
wood. Strain `E-36' causes graft union to be brown, fragile, swollen and
sunken areas on the stem. Chenopodium quinoa etched necrotic local lesions,
systemic chlorotic rings and mottle, tip malformed; some isolates induce
epinasty. Nicotiana glutinosa systemic yellow mosaic, line patterns. Phaseolus
vulgaris purple brown spots, chlorotic local lesions, systemic necrosis. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa for propagation. Nicotiana glutinosa, Phaseolus vulgaris
for maintaining cultures. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Pinto (L). (47) Aizoaceae, or Amaranthaceae, or Chenopodiaceae, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucurbitaceae, or Fabaceae, or Lamiaceae, or Malus sylvestris, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Rosaceae, or Scrophulariaceae,
or Solanaceae. (50) Aizoaceae, or Amaranthaceae, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae, or Labiatae, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Rosaceae
<1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (52) Reported to infect about
20 species, usually symptomlessly, in 9 dicotyledonous families: Aizoaceae,
Amaranthaceae, Chenopodiaceae, Cucurbitaceae, Lamiaceae, Fabaceae, Rosaceae,
Scrophulariaceae, Solanaceae. (53) Lister et al. (1965); de Sequeira (1967);
Waterworth and Gilmer (1969); Lister et al. (1967); de Sequeira and Cropley
(1968); de Sequeira and Posnette (1969); de Sequeira and Lister (1969b);
Barnett and Murant (1971). (54) TIP: 60-63 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
best stained with UA or UF; breakage occurs in PTA (Lister et al., 1965; de
Sequeira and Lister 1969b). (60) Method: Lister et al. (1965); de Sequeira and
Lister (1969); Lister (1970). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 600-700 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4-3.7 nm
<Lister and Bar-Joseph, 1981>. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 112 S. (82) Isoelectric point pH
4.3 <ionic strength of 0.1>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(91) Total genome size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (110) Poly A region
present. (111) Poly A region 3' terminus. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 28347. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D14995 Em(40)_vi:ASG241KP
Gb(84)_vi:ASG241KP Apple stem grooving virus genome, complete sequence. 1/94
6,496bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27000. (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins isolated. (153) Two proteins found. (154) Mr 240000. (155)
Probably polymerase. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 36000. (157) Possibly movement
protein. (171) Virions found in cambium, probably. (179) Capillovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: potato virus T (Salazar and
Harrison, 1977; 1978). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
apple chlorotic leaf spot (Lister et al., 1965; de Sequeira, 1967). In
cross-protection experiments in Virginia Crab apple the virus seemed to be
unrelated to apple stem grooving virus (de Sequeira and Cropley, 1968). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: this virus is not transmitted to Solanum tuberosum,
like potato virus T (Salazar and Harrison, 1978), nor to Nicotiana glutinosa
like apple chlorotic leaf spot virus. Symptoms in Chenopodium quinoa,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Russian apple R-12740-7A and Virginia Crab distinguish
apple chlorotic leaf spot and apple stem grooving viruses (de Sequeira and
Cropley, 1968; de Sequeira and Posnette, 1967). Chenopodium quinoa is best for
isolating this virus because other apple viruses such as tobacco mosaic and
apple chlorotic leaf spot virus replicates poorly in that species and their
local lesions develop 2-3 days later. When both viruses are present, symptoms
are much more severe. (187) Bar-Joseph, M., Garnsey, S.M. and Gonsalves, D.
(1979). Adv. Virus Res. 25: 93. de Sequeira, O.A. (1965). Zast. Bilja 16: 247.
de Sequeira, O.A. (1967). Ann. appl. Biol. 60: 59. de Sequeira, O.A. and
Cropley, R. (1968). TagBer. dt. Akad. Landw. Berlin 97: 35. de Sequeira, O.A.
and Lister, R.M. (1969a). Phytopathology 59: 572. de Sequeira, O.A. and
Lister, R.M. (1969b). Phytopathology 59: 1740. de Sequeira, O.A. and Posnette,
A.F. (1969). Commonw. Bur. Hort. Pl. Crops. Tech. Commun. No. 30, Suppl.
2/3/4, 76a. Hull, R., Brown, F. and Payne, C. (1989). Directory and Dictionary
of Animal, Bacterial and Plant Viruses, p. 76. MacMillan Reference Books,
London. Lister, R.M. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 31, 4 pp. Lister,
R.M., Bancroft, J.B. and Nadakavukaren, M.J. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 859.
Lister, R.M., Bancroft, J.B. and Shay, J.R. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 819.
Lister, R.M. and Bar-Joseph, M. (1981). Closteroviruses. In: Handbook of Plant
Virus Infections and Comparative Diagnosis, p. 809; ed. E. Kurstak.
Elsevier/North- Holland, Biomedical Press, Amsterdam. Ohki, S.T., Yoshikawa,
N., Inouye, N. and Inouye, T. (1989). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 55: 245.
Waterworth, H.E. and Gilmer, R.M. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 334 Yoshikawa,
N., Takahashi, T. (1988). J. gen. Virol. 69: 241. Yoshikawa, N. and Takahashi,
T. (1992). J. gen. Virol. 73: 1313. Yoshikawa, N. Sasaki, E., Kato, M. and
Takahashi, T. (1992). Virology 191: 98.


Apple stem pitting virus

      (1) H. Koganezawa, 1992. (2) Synonyms: apple spy 227 epinasty and
decline virus (Gilmer. 1962; Mink et al., 1971; Desvignes and Savio, 1975),
hawthorn ring pattern mosaic virus, pear necrotic spot virus (Yanase et al.,
1989; Koganezawa and Yanase, 1990), pear stony pit virus (Koganezawa and
Yanase, 1990; Németh, 1986; Van der Meer, 1986), pear vein yellows virus
(Yanase et al., 1989; Van der Meer, 1986). (3) Standard acronym: ASPV. (4)
Strains: mild and severe strains recognised. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.02. (8) First reported in Malus sylvestris. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By Smith (1954). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Malus sylvestris commercial
cultivars show decline when grafted to sensitive rootstocks such as Virginia
Crab and M. sieboldii. Malus sieboldii dieback, inner bark necrosis. Malus
sieboldii var. arborescens leaf epinasty, inner bark necrosis. Pyrus communis
vein yellowing. Crataegus spp., Sorbus mitchelli latent infection. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Welsh and
Nyland (1965); Mink et al. (1973); Cutting and Montgomery (1973); Fridlund
(1980a); Németh (1986). (39) Spreads in Australia, or Austria, or Bulgaria, or
Canada, or China, or the former Czechoslovakia, or Denmark, or France, or
Germany, or Greece, or Hungary, or Israel, or Italy, or Japan, or Korea
Republic, or the Netherlands, or New Zealand, or Norway, or Poland, or
Portugal, or Romania, or South Africa, or Spain, or Sweden, or Switzerland, or
the UK, or the USA, or the former USSR, or Uruguay, or the former Yugoslavia.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana occidentalis 37B vein
yellowing and leaf necrosis. N. occidentalis ssp. obliqua necrotic local
lesions. Malus sylvestris cv. Spy 227 leaf epinasty and decline. M. sylvestris
cv. Virginia Crab stem pitting. M. sylvestris cvs Radiant or Sparkler leaf
epinasty. M. sieboldii MO65 dieback, inner bark necrosis and necrotic leaf
spot. Pyrus communis cv. Nouveau Poiteau necrotic leaf spot. Pyronia veitchii
chlorotic spot on leaves and epinasty. (44) Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus
vulgaris. (45) Any susceptible Malus sp., Nicotiana occidentalis 37B. (46)
Nicotiana occidentalis ssp. obliqua (L), Malus sylvestris cvs Virginia Crab,
Spy 227, Radiant, Sparkler (W), M. sieboldii MO65 (W). (47) Celosia cristata,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crataegus, or Cucumis
sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Malus platycarpa, or Malus sieboldii, or
Malus sieboldii var. arborescens, or Malus sylvestris, or Nicotiana
occidentalis <cv. 37B>, or Nicotiana occidentalis ssp. obliqua, or Physalis
floridana, or Pyronia veitchii, or Pyrus communis, or Sesamum indicum, or
Sorbus mitchelli, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <8/8>, or Solanaceae <3/8>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/8>. (53) Mink et al. (1971); Yanase (1974); Sweet
(1980); Fridlund (1980b); Németh (1986); Van Dijk et al. (1987); Stouffer
(1989); Yanase et al. (1989); Koganezawa and Yanase (1990). (54) TIP: 55-60
°C. (55) LIV: 0.3-1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Koganezawa and Yanase (1990). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 800 nm. (71) Virions 12-15
nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations <isopycnic centrifugation>, or
three sedimenting components in purified preparations <sucrose density
gradient>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92)
Genome unipartite. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Koganezawa and Yanase
(1990). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35350. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
D21829 Em(40)_vi:AITASPV Gb(84)_vi:AITASPV Apple stem pitting virus (ASPV)
RNAs for putative viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, triple D21828
Em(40)_vi:PAVYV Gb(84)_vi:PAVYV Pear vein yellows-associated virus (PVYV) RNA
for coat protein, complete cds. 6/94 1,598bp. 2 sequence. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 48000. (134) Coat protein. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells.
(178) Other cellular changes: disorganisation of chloroplasts (Koganezawa and
Yanase, 1990). (179) (Ungrouped). (183) See Welsh and Uyemoto (1980). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: The virus can be distinguished from others with
filamentous virions with similar length by finding end-to-end aggregates of
virions in leaf dip preparations by electron microscopy. Also by grafting to
woody indicator plants. (186) Although filamentous virions are associated with
apple stem pitting disease, this virus has not yet been transmitted back to
apple. Pear vein yellows virus, pear stony pit virus, pear necrotic spot virus
and quince sooty ringspot virus are probably identical with apple stem pitting
virus (Desvignes and Savio, 1975; Kegler et al., 1979; Yanase et al., 1989).
(187) Cutting, C.V. and Montgomery, H.B.S. (1973). More and Better Fruit with
East Malling and Long Ashton Research Stations, U.K. Desvignes, J.C. and
Savio, A. (1975). Acta Hort. 44: 139. Fridlund, P.R. (1980a). Plant Dis. 64:
826. Fridlund, P.R. (1980b). Acta Phytopath. Acad. Sci. Hung. 15: 153. Gilmer,
R.M. (1962). Phytopathology 52: 1027. Kegler, H., Verderevskaja, T. and Fuchs,
E. (1979). Arch. Gartenb. 27: 325. Koganezawa, H. and Yanase, H. (1990). Plant
Dis. 74: 610. Machita, I. (1991). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 57: 90. Mink,
G.I., Shay, J.R., Gilmer, R.M. and Stouffer, R.F. (1971). Search Agric. 1: 9.
Mink, G.I., Yanase, H., Yamaguchi, Y. and Sawamura, K. (1973). Hort. Sci. 8:
296. Németh, M. (1986). In: Virus, Mycoplasma and Rickettsia Diseases of Fruit
Trees, 841 pp. Akademia Kiado, Budapest. Smith, W.W. (1954). Proc. Am. Soc.
Hort. Sci. 63: 101. Stouffer, R.F. (1989). In: Virus and Virus-Like Diseases
of Pome Fruits and Similar Noninfectious Disorders, p. 138; ed. P.R. Fridlund.
Washington State University Coop. Ext. Spec. Publ. Sweet, J.B. (1980). J.
hort. Sci. 55: 103. Van Dijk, P., van der Meer, F.A. and Piron, P.G.M. (1987).

H. (1974). Bull. Fruit Tree Res. Stn, Ser. C 1: 47. Yanase, H., Koganezawa, H.
and Fridlund, P.R. (1989). Acta Hort. 235: 157.

Aquilegia (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: AqV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.005. (8) First reported in Aquilegia sp. (9) From Italy. (10) By
Marani and Pisi (1976). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Aquilegia sp. necrotic
ringspots in leaves, and flower deformation. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in
Italy. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa necrotic local lesions; systemic chlorosis and/or necrotic spotting.
Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris symptomless systemic infection. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana tabacum, Ocimum basilicum, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L). (47) Aquilegia, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (48) Cucumis sativus, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>,
or Ranunculaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/2>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>,
or Solanaceae <1/2>. (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
6. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 700-800 nm.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Marani, F. and
Pisi, A. (1976). Phytopathol. Medit. 15: 137.


Arabis mosaic nepovirus

      (1) A.F. Murant, 1984. Revised 1985. (2) Synonyms: ash ring and line
pattern virus (Lana and Agrios, 1973), raspberry yellow dwarf virus (Cadman,
1960; Harrison, 1958), Rhabarber-Mosaik-Virus, rhubarb mosaic virus, forsythia
yellow net virus, probably jasmine yellow blotch virus (Cooper and Sweet,
1976). (3) Standard acronym: ArMV. (4) Strains: hop nettlehead virus, isolates
from hop are serologically identical to type strain, but differ in host range
and symptoms. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.002. (8) First reported in Arabis
hirsuta. (9) From England. (10) By Smith and Markham (1944). (11) Symptoms
disappear soon after infection <but plants may remain stunted>. (13) Anagallis
arvensis, Apium graveolens var. dulce, Arabis hirsuta, Arabis sp., Armoracia
rusticana, Asparagus officinalis, Astilbe sp., Bellis perennis, Beta vulgaris,
Buxus sempervirens, Capsella bursa-pastoris, Carum segetum, Chamaecyparis
lawsoniana, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo, Cyphomandra betacea, Daphne
mezereum, Daucus carota, Delphinium sp., Dianthus caryophyllus, Euonymus
europaeus, Forsythia × intermedia, Fragaria vesca, Fraxinus excelsior, Humulus
lupulus, Jasminum officinale, Lactuca sativa, Lamium amplexicaule, Ligustrum
vulgare, Melilotus officinalis, Mentha arvensis, Narcissus sp., Phaseolus
coccineus, Plantago lanceolata, Polygonum aviculare, P. persicaria, Prunus
avium, P. domestica, P. persica, Ranunculus repens, Rheum rhaponticum, Ribes
sp., Rosa spp., Rubus idaeus, R. procerus, Sambucus nigra, Senecio vulgaris,
Solanum nigrum, Stellaria media, Syringa vulgaris, Taraxacum officinale,
Trifolium repens, Tulipa spp., Urtica dioica, U. urens, Vitis vinifera
mosaics, mottling and chlorotic ringspots and sometimes necrosis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by
Xiphinema bakeri, X. coxi, X. diversicaudatum. (20) Transmitted by
Dorylamidae. (22) Principal natural vector(s): Xiphinema diversicaudatum. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <in 20 species of 14 families; up to 100% infection;
Murant, 1983>. (38) Spreads in the African region, the Eastern Asian region,
the Eurasian region, the North American region, and the Pacific region. (39)
Spreads in Australia, or Belgium, or Bulgaria, or Canada, or the former
Czechoslovakia, or Denmark, or Finland, or France, or Germany, or Hungary, or
Ireland, or Italy, or Japan, or Luxembourg, or the Netherlands, or New
Zealand, or Norway, or Poland, or Romania, or South Africa, or Sweden, or
Switzerland, or Turkey, or the UK, or the former USSR, or the former
Yugoslavia. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in North America and
Australia. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show necrotic or chlorotic local lesions and mosaics, ringspots
or mottles. Plants may recover. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
local lesions; systemic chlorotic mottling. Cucumis sativus local lesions,
systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley local lesions; systemic
chlorotic spots, rings and lines. Petunia × hybrida local lesions or necrotic

Araujia mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, and E. Hiebert, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: ArjMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Araujia angustifolia and
Morrenia odorata. (9) From Argentina. (10) By Charudattan et al. (1976). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Araujia angustifolia, Morrenia odorata mosaics. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis nerii, Aphis spiraecola, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(36) Studies reported by Charudattan et al. (1980). (38) Spreads in the South
and Central American region. (39) Spreads in Argentina. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics,
malformation. (43) Araujia angustifolia, A. hortorum, A. sericofera, Matelea
floridana, Morrenia brachystephana, Sarcostemma clausum systemic mosaic and
malformation. Hoya carnosa, H. coronaria symptomless. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana benthamiana,

32kDaprotein with antiserum to TEV capsid protein; the cylindrical inclusion
protein of araujia mosaic is serologically related to that of dasheen mosaic

antiserum to the helper component of tobacco vein mottling virus. (186)
Charudattan et al. (1980) suggest that the virus might be used to control

Arracacha A nepovirus

      (1) R.A.C. Jones, 1984. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: AVA. (5)

(arracacha). (9) From the Peruvian Andes. (10) By Jones and Kenten (1978).

Arracacha B (?) nepovirus

      (1) R.A.C. Jones, 1984. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: AVB. (4)
Strains: Type strain (T), Oca strain (O). (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.001.
(8) First reported in Arracacia xanthorrhiza (arracacha). (9) From the
Peruvian Andes. (10) By Jones and Kenten (1978). (11) Symptoms none. (13)
Arracacia xanthorrhiza, Oxalis tuberosa, Solanum tuberosum symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <5% of strain T in Chenopodium quinoa; 12% strain O in
Solanum tuberosum>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed <in Solanum
tuberosum; Jones, 1982>. (36) Studies reported by Jones (1981a, b; 1982)
indicate that the virus is disseminated in vegetative propagules (in root
pieces of arracacha). (38) Spreads in the South and Central American region
<where arracacha, oca and potato are grown; Jones and Kenten, 1983; Atkey and
Brunt, 1982>. (39) Spreads in Bolivia and Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein clearing
then systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis and may recover. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor local lesions; systemic mosaic or mottle and may
recover. C. murale systemic necrosis. Cucumis sativus systemic mosaic then
recovery. Tetragonia tetragonioides systemic mosaic or mottle. (44) Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Capsicum annuum, Datura metel,
Hyoscyamus niger. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L,W), C. murale (W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Anthriscus cerefolium, or Arracacia xanthorrhiza, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba,
or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oxalis
tuberosa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis
floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum chacoense, or Solanum tuberosum,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea var.
capitata <Cv. Golden Acre>, or Capsicum annuum, or Datura metel, or Hyoscyamus
niger, or Ipomoea setosa, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/5>, or Oxalidaceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <15/20>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <4 /4>.
(51) Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/5>, or Solanaceae <6/20>. (53) Kenten and Jones (1979); Jones and Kenten
(1981). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 12-19 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-5.
(60) Method: Kenten and Jones (1979). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 126 S. (79) Density 1.481 and 1.492 g cm3 in CsCl <for strain T;
and 1.484 and 1.495 g cm3 for strain O>. (84) Virions contain 40-41 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 59-60 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (132) Virion
protein(s) two <in ratio 3:1, larger:smaller>. (133) Mr <of the larger> 26000.
(135) Mr of 2nd largest 20000 <strain T>, or 22000 <strain O>. (145) Method of
preparation: Kenten and Jones (1979). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: strains T and O are
serologically distantly related (SDI 6-7), and induce distinct symptoms in
most indicator hosts (Jones and Kenten, 1981). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: Andean potato latent, Andean potato mottle,
arracacha A, carnation Italian ringspot, carnation mottle, carnation ringspot,
cherry rasp leaf, cymbidium ringspot, narcissus tip necrosis, pelargonium
flower break, pelargonium leaf curl, pelargonium ringspot, pelargonium ring
pattern, red clover necrotic mosaic, saguaro cactus, southern bean mosaic,
sowbane mosaic, tomato bushy stunt, turnip crinkle, turnip rosette and turnip
yellow mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: See Jones and Kenten
(1983). Chenopodium murale is the best diagnostic host. (187) Atkey, P.T. and
Brunt, A.A. (1982). Phytopath. Z. 103: 294. Jones, R.A.C. (1981). Plant Dis.
65: 753. Jones, R.A.C. (1981b). In: Pests, Pathogens and Vegetation, p. 89;
ed. J.M. Thresh. Pitman, London. Jones, R.A.C. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 100:
315. Jones, R.A.C. and Kenten, R.H. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 85. Jones,
R.A.C. and Kenten, R.H. (1981). Phytopath. Z. 100: 88. Jones, R.A.C. and

and Jones, R.A.C. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 93: 31.


Arracacha latent (?) carlavirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: ALV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.T.1.002. (8) First reported in Arracacia xanthorrhiza. (9) From
Littlehampton, U.K. in material from South America. (13) Arracacia
xanthorrhiza latent infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (38) Spreads in the South and Central American region. (39)
Spreads in Bolivia and Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions, systemic chlorosis.
(43) Nicotiana clevelandii systemic chlorotic vein-banding. Gomphrena globosa
red local lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions;
not systemic. Nicotiana megalosiphon symptomless local and systemic infection.
(44) Trifolium incarnatum, Vigna unguiculata, Pisum sativum. (45) Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W). (47)
Arracacia xanthorrhiza, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <2/4>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51)
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>,
or Solanaceae <2/4>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: extract
Nicotiana leaves with 0.5 M KPO4 + 0.5% (w/v) Na2SO3 (pH 8.0), add 5% Triton
X-100 and then differentially centrifuge twice. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650 nm. (74) Basic helix obscure. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (179) <Probably> Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: lily symptomless (SDI 3), carnation latent (SDI
4) and chrysanthemum B (SDI 7) viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: narcissus latent, potato S, elder carlavirus, red clover
vein mosaic and honeysuckle latent viruses.


Arracacha Y potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Phillips, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: AVY. (5)

(9) From Littlehampton, U.K. in material from South America. (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Arracacia xanthorrhiza leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae,
Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in the South and
Central American region. (39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions,
chlorosis. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic or necrotic

globosa, Ullucus tuberosus. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, Nicotiana benthamiana.
(46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana
clevelandii (W), Nicotiana benthamiana (W). (47) Arracacia xanthorrhiza, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Solanum demissum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Ullucus tuberosus,
or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae
<4/8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae

Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <4/8>. (54) TIP: 65-70 °C <in
Nicotiana clevelandii sap>. (55) LIV: 32 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: A.A. Brunt and R.S. Phillips:

clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with

Artichoke curly dwarf (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: ACDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.001. (8) First reported in Cynara scolymus. (9) From California, USA.
(10) By Leach and Oswald (1950). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cynara scolymus
veinal necrosis, leaf distortion and stunting. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the North American region. (39)
Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show Leaf distortion and stunting. (43) Callistephus
chinensis, Helichrysum bracteatum chlorotic local lesions, systemic leaf
distortion. Centaurea cyanus, Cynara cardunculus, C. scolymus systemic veinal
necrosis, leaf distortion and stunting. Helianthus annuus chlorotic local
lesions, symptomless systemic infection. Tagetes symptomless local and
systemic infection. Zinnia elegans necrotic local lesions, systemic veinal
necrosis, leaf distortion and stunting. (44) Calendula officinalis, Cichorium
endiva, Cosmos bipinnatus, Lactuca sativa, Taraxacum officinale. (46) Zinnia
elegans (L). (47) Callistephus chinensis, or Centaurea cyanus, or Cynara

bracteatum, or Tagetes, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Calendula officinalis, or
Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cichorium endiva, or Cosmos bipinnatus, or
Lactuca sativa, or Taraxacum officinale. (50) Compositae <8/14>. (51)
Compositae <6/14>. (52) The virus seems only to infect species of the
Asteraceae; it failed to infect unnamed species in 18 other families. (53)
Leach and Oswald (1950), Morton (1961). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-3 days
<at 19oC>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 582 nm.
(179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (186) Although first reported in 1950, the virus
was probably present in California two or more decades earlier (Morton, 1961).
(187) Leach, L.D. and Oswald, J.W. (1950). Phytopathology 40: 967. Morton,
D.J. (1961). Phytopathology 51: 731.


Artichoke Italian latent nepovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond and D. Gallitelli, 1987. (3) Standard acronym:
AILV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.004. (8) First reported in Cynara
scolymus. (9) From Italy. (10) By Marjorana and Rana (1970); Vovlas et al.
(1971). (13) Cynara scolymus usually latent, plants stunted and yellow.
Cichorium intybus chlorotic mottle and bright yellow spots. Pelargonium zonale
severely malformed leaves, plant stunted. Vitis vinifera fanleaf-like
symptoms, stunted. Gladiolus sp., Sonchus arvensis yellow rings and line
pattern. Crepis neglecta, Helminthia echioides, Hypochoeris aetensis, Lactuca
virosa, Urospermum dalechampii, Lamium amplexicaule, Sonchus spp. symptomless.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted
by Longidorus apulus (Lamberti and Bleve Zacheo, 1977). (20) Transmitted by
Dorylamidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies
reported by Vovlas and Roca (1975); Roca et al. (1975). (38) Spreads in the
Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Bulgaria and Italy. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show ring local
lesions, then systemic mosaic, ringspots, recovery. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. La Victoire chlorotic and necrotic local lesions; tip necrosis or mottle;
then recovery. Gomphrena globosa pale necrotic, ring local lesions; sometimes
tip necrosis. Cucumis sativus chlorotic/necrotic local lesions; severe
systemic mosaic, and necrosis. Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley necrotic
ring local lesions; systemic ringspots and line patterns. (45) Cucurbita pepo,
Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. La
Victoire (L); Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium
intybus, or Crepis neglecta, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cynara
scolymus, or Gladiolus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helminthia echioides, or
Hypochoeris aetensis, or Lactuca virosa, or Lamium amplexicaule, or Nicotiana
tabacum <cv. White Burley>, or Pelargonium zonale, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or

(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <9/9>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>, or Vitidaceae
<1 /1>. (53) Martelli and Rana (1975); Vovlas et al. (1971); Vovlas and Roca
(1975); Vovlas (1974); Jankulova et al. (1976); Savino et al. (1977);
Quacquarelli et al. (1976a); Majorana and Rana (1970). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C.
(55) LIV: 3-14 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-5. (60) Method: Dunn and
Hitchborn (1965); Jankulova et al. (1976); Savino et al. (1977). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (76)
Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 121 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 96 S <M>, or 55 S
<T>. (84) Virions contain 41 % nucleic acid <B>, or 34 % nucleic acid <M>, or
0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B>, or 66 % protein <M>, or
100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 12.5 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest

al. (1976); Savino et al. (1977). (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and
parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: rows of membraneous tubules in
parenchyma cells (Vovlas et al., 1971). (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: grapevine
fanleaf, arabis mosaic, tomato black ring, tobacco ringspot, tomato ringspot,
peach rosette mosaic, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot,
grapevine chrome mosaic, cacao necrosis, cherry leaf roll, grapevine Bulgarian
latent and myrobalan latent ringspot viruses (Vovlas et al., 1971; Savino et
al., 1977). (184) The physico-chemical characters and hydrodynamic behaviour
of the virions have been used to assign it to a subgroup containing tomato
black ring and related viruses (Martelli, 1975; Quacquarelli et al. 1967b).

401. Dunn, D.B. and Hitchborn, J.H. (1965). Virology 25: 171. Jankulova, M.,

Artichoke latent potyvirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (2) Synonyms: artichoke Californian latent
virus, probably artichoke potyvirus (Schwarz, 1977). (3) Standard acronym:
ArLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Cynara
scolymus. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Costa et al. (1959). (11)
Symptoms persist, vary seasonally, and none. (12) Symptoms stunting and yellow
flecking of plants. (13) Cynara scolymus, C. cardunculus latent. May cause
symptoms in mixed infections (Rana et al., 1982). Petunia × hybrida systemic
mosaic, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis fabae, Brachycaudus cardui. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian
region, the Mediterranean region, the Middle East, the North American region,
and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Albania, or Algeria, or Australia
<Victoria>, or Egypt, or France, or Greece, or Israel, or Italy, or Lebanon,
or Malta, or Morocco, or Spain, or Tunisia, or Turkey, or the USA
<California>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show systemic mottling, mosaic, necrosis. (43)
Gomphrena globosa red-ring local lesions. Datura stramonium systemic mottle.
Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii severe systemic mosaic. (44) Brassica campestris
ssp. chinensis, Beta vulgaris, Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum, Pisum
sativum. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa
(L), C. amaranticolor (L), Gomphrena globosa (L), Nicotiana benthamiana (W),
N. clevelandii (W). (47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cynara cardunculus, or Cynara scolymus, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lens culinaris, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis,
or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or
Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Daucus carota, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum
melongena, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/6>, or Compositae <3/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Solanaceae <5/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/6>, or Compositae <2/5>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or Solanaceae <3/8>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>,
or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60-70 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Thompson et al.
(1988). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
725-746 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic

Sedimentation coefficient 145 S. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in CsCl. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.2. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 9
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli: phenol-SDS. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has <possible> a VPg. (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or

protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll,
epidermis, meristems, vascular parenchyma and companion cells. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean common mosaic, bean
yellow mosaic, beet mosaic, clover yellow vein, dasheen mosaic, lettuce
mosaic, papaya ringspot, potato Y, soybean mosaic, turnip mosaic, watermelon
mosaic 2 and zucchini yellow fleck viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
Serology (ISEM), molecular probes and cytopathology. (186) This virus is
frequently found in mixed infections with other viruses with filamentous
virions. (187) Costa, A.S., Duffus, J.E., Morton, D.J., Yarwood, C.E. and
Bardin, R. (1959). Phytopathology 49: 49. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond.
227: 680. Rana, G.L., Russo, M., Gallitelli, D. and Martelli, G.P. (1982).
Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 279. Schwarz (1977). B.Sc. Thesis, La Trobe University,
Melbourne, Australia. Thompson, S., Frazier, S.S. and Barnden, K.L. (1988). J.
virol. Meth. 20: 57.


Artichoke latent S (?) carlavirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ArLVS. (5) ICTV decimal
code 14.0.T.1.004. (8) First reported in Cynara scolymus. (9) From northern
Italy from in vitro meristem culture. (10) By Rana et al. (1989). (11)
Symptoms none. (13) Cynara scolymus symptomless. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus
persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in northern Italy. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic to
necrotic local lesions and systemic leaf chlorosis. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana
benthamiana systemic leaf chlorosis, leaf rolling. Zinnia elegans local and
systemic mottling. (44) Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, Cynara scolymus cv. Molese. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Nicotiana
benthamiana (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cynara scolymus, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Celosia
cristata, or Cucumis sativus, or Cynara scolymus <cvs Molese, Violetto di
Provenza, Camus de Bretagne>, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>,
or Compositae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/3>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Compositae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <2/3>. (53) Rana et al. (1989). (60) Method: Rana et al. (1989);
Gallitelli and Di Franco (1987). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 664
nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 150 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.6 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.6 kb. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
29000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (171)
Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in
chloroplasts, and in mitochondria. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and membranous bodies. (177)
They contain virions. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: poplar mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: potato S, potato M, carnation latent,
elderberry, helleborus, lily symptomless, pea streak, shallot latent, caper
latent, nerine latent and chrysanthemum B viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: serology. (187) Gallitelli, D. and Di Franco, A. (1987). J.
Phytopath. 119: 97. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Rana, G.L.,
Piazzolla, P., Lafortezza, R. and Greco, N. (1989). J. Phytopath. 125: 289.


Artichoke mottled crinkle tombusvirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1987. Revised 1991. (3) Standard acronym: AMCV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Cynara scolymus. (9)
From Italy. (10) By Russo et al. (1967, 1968). (11) Symptoms persist and vary
seasonally. (13) Cynara scolymus chlorotic blotching and puckering, flower
malformation and colour breaking; plants stunted. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy <in the south>. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic, necrosis and death. (43) Chenopodium
quinoa, Ocimum basilicum necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
benthamiana systemic mosaic, necrosis, death. Gomphrena globosa red-ringed
local lesions. (44) Nicotiana tabacum cvs Samsun, Xanthi, N. rustica. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Gomphrena

benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Ocimum
basilicum, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum,
or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or

profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One

132 S. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 82 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists

Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli et al. (1985); SDS. (108)

ID: 12142. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X16060

41kDaprotein, nucleotides 791242. ORF2 22kDaprotein, nucleotides 12831849.
ORF3 19kDaprotein, nucleotides 13151830. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found
in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA and satellite RNA. (123) Subgenomic
mRNA found in infected cells. (124) About 2.1 kb and 1 kb. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41049. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Laemmli (1970). (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (168) Acts as helper for a
satellite RNA <0.7 kb>. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll,
epidermis, meristems, vascular parenchyma, xylem, phloem and companion cells.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm and crystals in the nucleus. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: several tombusviruses; see Koenig and Gibbs,
and Martelli et al. (1988 and 1989). (187) Gallitelli, D., Hull, R. and

(1985). J. gen. Virol. 66: 1533. Grieco, F. and Gallitelli, D. (1990). Nucl.

Artichoke vein banding (?) nepovirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: AVBV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.T.002. (8) First reported in Cynara scolymus. (9) From Apulia,
Italy. (10) By Gallitelli et al. (1978). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13)
Cynara scolymus cvs Bayrombasa, Sakiz, Mazzaferrata vein chlorosis. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Europe (Apulia, Italy. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions, severe systemic
mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa small chlorotic or necrotic
local lesions, severe mosaic and tip necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris pinpoint
necrotic local lesions, mosaic, malformation of trifoliate leaves. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Ocimum basilicum (L), Chenopodium
quinoa (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cynara scolymus, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or

vulgaris, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica oleracea

(50) Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/6>, or Compositae <2/6>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/8>,
or Solanaceae <5/11>. (51) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/6>, or Compositae <4/6>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/8>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<6/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae
<1/1>. (53) Gallitelli et al. (1978). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:
homogenize infected leaves in 100 mM neutral phosphate buffer. Clarify with
10% Mg-activated bentonite. Differential centrifugation. (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 124 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 92
S <M>, or 56 S <T>. (79) Density <virions are unstable even after fixation
with formaldehyde>. (84) Virions contain 37 % nucleic acid <B>, or 24 %
nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 63 % protein <B>, or
76 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 12.3 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7.8 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 4.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by : using phenol-SDS.

Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s)
four. (133) Mr <of the largest> 27000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 24000. (137) Mr
of 3rd largest 22000. (139) Mr of 4th largest 14300. (145) Method of
preparation: Laemmli (1970); Chu and Francki (1979). (171) Virions found in
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies and unusual in shape.
(176) Vesicles containing finely stranded material resembling nucleic acid.
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae.
(180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
arabis mosaic, artichoke Italian latent, artichoke yellow ringspot, cherry
leaf roll, cherry rasp leaf, chicory yellow mottle, cacao necrosis, grapevine
Bulgarian latent, grapevine chrome mosaic, grapevine fanleaf, myrobalan latent
ringspot, olive latent ringspot, peach rosette, raspberry ringspot, strawberry
latent ringspot, tobacco ringspot and tomato ringspot. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: use ISEM. In nature artichoke vein banding virus may be mixed with
artichoke latent potyvirus which has filamentous virions or with artichoke
mottled crinkle or artichoke Italian latent viruses which are serologically
distinct. (187) Chu, P.W.G. and Francki, R.I.B. (1979). Virology 93: 398.
Gallitelli, D., Martelli, G.P. and Rana, G.L. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.

Artichoke yellow ringspot nepovirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: AYRSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.0.005. (8) First reported in Cynara cardunculus (cardoon) and
Cynara scolymus (artichoke). (9) From Greece (north-east Poleponnesus) and
Italy (Sicily). (10) By Kyriakopoulou and Bem (1973); Rana et al. (1978). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Cynara scolymus, C. cardunculus, Nicotiana tabacum
chlorotic blotches, rings and lines. Anethum graveolens, Foeniculum sp.,
Nicotiana glauca, Phaseolus vulgaris, Reseda alba, Stellaria media, Vicia faba
chlorotic mottled and malformed leaves, plants stunted. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the seed <in Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petunia × hybrida>, or transmitted by
pollen to the pollinated plant <in Nicotiana clevelandii>. (38) Spreads in the
Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Greece and Italy. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa reddish local lesions; systemic yellow
ring and line patterns. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic/necrotic local lesions;
systemic mottling and tip necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris reddish necrotic local
lesions; systemic mosaic and leaf deformation. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local
lesions in cotyledons then mosaic, malformation and enations. Nicotiana
tabacum local and systemic chlorotic rings, line and oakleaf patterns. (45)
Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus.
(46) Chenopodium quinoa (L); Cucumis sativus (L); Canavalia ensiformis (L).
(47) Anethum graveolens, or Canavalia ensiformis, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cynara cardunculus, or Cynara scolymus, or Foeniculum, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glauca, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Reseda alba, or Stellaria media, or Vicia faba. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Resedaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/6>, or Umbelliferae <2 /2>. (53)
Kyriakopoulou and Bem (1973); Rana et al. (1978; 1980). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55)
LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Rana et al. (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations <T and B>. (79)
Density 1.2-1.3 g cm3 in CsCl <T>, or 1.4-1.53 g cm3 in CsCl <B>. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 11.6 kb. (92)
Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.3 kb
<RNA-1>. (94) The 2nd largest 5.3 kb <RNA-2>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Reijnders et al. (1974). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found
in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 53000. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm <stacked layers or between membranes or within tubular structures>,
or in nuclei <aggregates of empty virions>. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Tangled membranes
and vesicles containing finely stranded material resembling nucleic acid.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: cell wall
abnormalities (callose deposition and wall outgrowths) and paramural bodies;
dictyosomes are also affected and may take part in some steps of virus
multiplication. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: 13 other known members of the
genus. (184) Mr of its RNA-2 suggests artichoke yellow ringspot virus is in
the cherry leaf roll subgroup of nepoviruses (Martelli et al., 1978). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: the symptoms shown by infected artichoke and cardoon
plants are distinctive and unlike those caused by other viruses (Martelli et
al., 1981). (187) Kyriakopoulou, P.E. and Bem, F. (1973). Symp. Agric. Res.,
Athens, 1973. p.64. Martelli, G.P., Quacquarelli, A., Gallitelli, D., Savino,
V. and Piazzolla, P. (1978). Phytopathol. Medit. 17: 145. Martelli, G.P.,
Russo, M. and Rana, G.L. (1981). Atti 3° Congr. Int. Carciofo, Bari, 1979,
895. Rana, G.L., Kyriakopoulou, P.E. and Martelli, G.P. (1985). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 271, 4 pp. Rana, G.L., Rosciglione, B. and Cannizzaro, G.
(1978). Phytopathol. Medit. 17: 63. Rana, G.L., Gallitelli, D., Kyriakopoulou,
P., Russo, M. and Martelli, G.P. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 177. Reijnders,
L., Aalbers, A.M.J., van Kammen, A. and Thuring, R.W.J. (1974). Virology 60:
515.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.DE.01. (8) First

(38) Spreads in the South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in
Ecuador. (47) Asclepias curassavica. (50) Asclepiadaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (70) Virions of 300 nm. (71)

Asparagus 1 potyvirus

      (1) A. Bertaccini and W.E. Howell, 1991. (2) Synonyms: asparagus virus
B. (3) Standard acronym: AV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.006. (8) First
reported in Asparagus officinalis. (9) From Germany. (10) By Hein (1960). (11)
Symptoms none. (13) Asparagus officinalis symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora,
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal natural
vector(s): Myzus persicae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Macrosiphum
euphorbiae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (36) Studies reported by Yang and Clore (1976); Howell and Mink
(1985); Bertaccini et al. (1990). (37) Probably distributed worldwide
<wherever asparagus is grown commercially>. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian
region, the Eurasian region, and the North American region. (39) Spreads in
Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local
lesions. (43) Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Tetragonia
tetragonioides chlorotic or necrotic local lesions. (44) Beta vulgaris,
Cucumis sativus, Glycine max, Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Asparagus officinalis, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Chenopodium
quinoa (L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L). (47) Allium tuberosum, or Asparagus
officinalis, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Allium cepa, or Allium fistulosum, or
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum frutescens, or Celosia cristata, or
Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lilium elegans, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum
indicum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Alliaceae <1/3>, or Amaranthaceae <1/3>, or Asparagaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <2/3>, or
Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/6>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6 /6>, or Liliaceae
<1/1>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10/10>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>.
(53) Hein (1960); Mink and Uyeda (1977); Fujisawa et al. (1983). (54) TIP:
50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 2-11 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Fujisawa et al. (1983); Howell and Mink
(1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 740
nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 146 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.24. (84) Virions
contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in leaves, stems, roots and mesophyll. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean
yellow mosaic, lettuce mosaic and turnip mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: beet mosaic, iris mild mosaic and potato Y
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: asparagus 1 virus occurs naturally in
asparagus plants that often are infected with tobacco streak, asparagus 2 or
cucumber mosaic viruses. Few, if any, symptoms are caused. Asparagus 1 virus
is readily separated from the others because its host range is limited and it
causes only necrotic local lesions in Chenopodium quinoa and no symptoms in
Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris or Nicotiana tabacum. (186) Asparagus
infected with asparagus 1 and 2 viruses are significantly more susceptible to
damage caused by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. asparagi. (187) Bertaccini, A.,
Marani, F. and Passarelli, V. (1984). Atti Giornate Fitopatol., 1984,
Sorrento, Vol. 3, p. 437. Bertaccini, A., Giuncheoli, L. and Poggi Pollini, C.
(1990). Acta Hort. 271: 279. Evans, T.A. and Stephens, C.T. (1989).
Phytopathology 79: 253. Fujisawa, I., Goto, T., Tsuchizaki, T. and Chizuka, N.
(1983). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 49: 299. Gröschel, H. and Jan-Ladwig, R.
(1977). Phytopath. Z. 88: 183. Hein, A. (1960). Phytopath. Z. 67: 217. Hein,
A. (1969). Z. PflKrankh. PflPath. PflSchutz. 76: 395. Howell, W.E. and Mink,
G.I. (1985). Plant Dis. 69: 1044. Mink, G.I. and Uyeda, I. (1977). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 61: 398. Montasser, M.S. and Davis, R.F. (1987). Plant Dis. 71: 497.
Yang, H.J. (1979). Hort. Sci. 14: 734. Yang, H.J. and Clore, W.J. (1976).
Hort. Sci. 12: 140.


Asparagus 2 ilarvirus

      (1) A. Bertaccini, 1991. (2) Synonyms: asparagus virus C, asparagus
latent virus. (3) Standard acronym: AV-2. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.02.01.
(8) First reported in Asparagus officinalis. (9) From Denmark and Germany.
(10) By Paludan (1964) and Groschel (1976) respectively. (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Asparagus officinalis stunting, decline. (24) Not transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the seed and transmitted by pollen to the pollinated
plant. (36) Studies reported by Bertaccini et al. (1990); Yang and Clore
(1976). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the North American region.
(40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Europe and North America;
Denmark, Germany, Italy, the UK and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local
lesions and rings, vein chlorosis and mottling. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa local necrotic spots, systemic necrosis. Gomphrena
globosa white spots with red borders. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun local
necrotic rings and systemic vein yellowing and necrotic lines. Nicotiana
tabacum cv. White Burley local necrotic rings. (44) Cucumis melo, Datura
stramonium, Lactuca sativa. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L),
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun (W). (47) Asparagus officinalis, or Beta
vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium

Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Cucumis melo, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Asparagaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or

et al. (1987); Phillips and Brunt (1985); Uyeda and Mink (1981). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (66) Virions neither clearly angular or
nor rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 90 S <±2>. (78) Of the other(s) 104
S <±2>, or 95 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.31-1.36. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): X86352 Em(43)_vi:Aviirna3 Gb(89)_vi:Aviirna3 Asparagus
virus II RNA3 ORF1 & ORF2. 5/95 2,307bp. (174) Inclusions absent from infected
cells. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 2>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181)

variegation, elm mottle and Tulare apple mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: tobacco streak viruses. (187) Bertaccini, A.,
Macri, S., Poggi Pollini, C. and Martini, L. (1988). Inform. Fitopatol. 38:

Asparagus 3 potexvirus

      (1) I. Fujisawa, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: AV-3. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Asparagus sp. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Fujisawa (1986). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Asparagus spp. faint leaf
chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (24) Not
transmitted by aphids. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)

infected plants mostly show mosaic, mild mosaic and necrotic local lesions.

mosaic. (44) Allium cepa, A. fistulosum, Lycopersicon esculentum, Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, Cucurbita pepo. (45) Nicotiana debneyi, N. megalosiphon,

Aster chlorotic stunt (?) carlavirus

      (1) L.W. Stobbs, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Aster novae-angliae. (9) From Jordan Station, Ontario, Canada.
(10) By Stobbs and van Schagen (1991). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
systemic chlorosis, stunting, chlorotic local lesions. (13) Aster spp.
systemic chlorosis and stunting, curling of apical leaves, often elongated
with necrotic flecking. Rosetting caused by shortened internodes; irregular
chlorotic local lesions, often with necrotic centres, on basal leaves. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae, Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the North
American region. (39) Spreads in Canada <southern Ontario>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic
chlorosis, stunting, chlorotic local lesions. (43) Aster novae-angliae, A.
novi-belgii systemic chlorosis, necrotic flecking; stunting. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions, vein-netting and chlorotic
spotting. (44) Helenium autumnale, Impatiens walleriana, Dianthus barbatus, D.
caryophyllus. (45) Aster spp., Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (W). (47) Aster novae-angliae, or Aster novi-belgii,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa. (48) Achillea
filipendulina, or Achillea ptarmica, or Ajuga reptans, or Althaea rosea, or
Aurinia saxatilis var. compactum, or Begonia × tuberhybrida, or Callistephus
chinensis, or Chrysanthemum maximum, or Coreopsis tinctoria, or Cucumis
sativus, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or
Dianthus caryophyllus, or Gazania rigens, or Gerbera jamesonii, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Helenium autumnale, or Helianthus maximilianii, or Impatiens

× domesticum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Portulaca
grandiflora, or Primula malacoides, or Salvia splendens, or Saxifraga
cordifolia < Bergenia>, or Tagetes erecta, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <2/15>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Balsaminaceae <1/1>, or Begoniaceae <1/1>, or Boraginaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <13/15>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Geraniaceae <1 /1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or
Papaveraceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Primulaceae <1/1>, or
Saxifragaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7 /7>. (53) Stobbs and van Schagen (1991).
(54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 5 days <at 25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Stobbs and van Schagen
(1991). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
610-620 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic

unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8 kb. (108) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor not required

Carlavirus. (187) Stobbs, L.W. and van Schagen, J.G. (1991). Plant Dis. 75:
421.


Asystasia gangetica mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) J.-C.Thouvenel, 1986. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: AGMoV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.007. (8) First reported in Asystasia gangetica. (9)
From the Ivory coast. (10) By Thouvenel et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Asystasia gangetica vein mottle, lines and ringspots. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis spiraecola.

local lesions, mosaics, ringspots. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Tetragonia
tetragonioides necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana benthamiana

esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana

Bamboo mosaic (?) potexvirus

      (1) M.T. Lin, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: BaMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.002. (8) First reported in Bambusa multiplex and B. vulgaris. (9)
From Brasilia, Brazil. (10) By Lin et al. (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Ten species of bamboo, Bambusa beecheyana, B. beecheyana cv. pubescens, B.
edulis, B. multiplex, B. oldhamii, B. vulgaris, B. vulgaris cv. striata,
Dendrocalamus latiflorus, D. latiflorus cv. Mei-nung, Phyllostachys nigra
mosaic, necrotic streaks on culms, vascular discoloration. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in the
Philippines and Taiwan. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Brazil.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show mosaics, stunting. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium
amaranticolor necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Bambusa vulgaris cv.
Vittatu, Dendrocalamus latiflorus cv. Mei-nung systemic mosaic. (44) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Turkish, Oryza sativa. (45) Bambusa multiplex, B. vulgaris, Dendrocalamus
latiflorus. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Bambusa
vulgaris cv. Vittatu (W), Dendrocalamus latiflorus cv. Mei-nung (W). (47)
Bambusa beecheyana, or Bambusa edulis, or Bambusa multiplex, or Bambusa
oldhamii, or Bambusa vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Dendrocalamus
latiflorus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Phyllostachys nigra. (48) Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Oryza sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>,
or Gramineae <9/9>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/9>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <7/7>. (53) Lin et al. (1977; 1979). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Lin et al.
(1977). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 490 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35286. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): D26017 Em(43)_vi:Am1bamvgr Gb(89)_vi:Am1bamvgr bamboo
mosaic virus BaMV gRNA gene. 10/94 6,366bp. L22762 Em(43)_vi:Bbssatpro
Gb(89)_vi:Bbssatpro Bamboo mosaic virus satellite RNA, complete cds. 10/94
836bp. X57581 Em(43)_vi:Bomvcpa Gb(89)_vi:Bomvcpa Bamboo mosaic virus coat
protein gene. 6/94 729bp. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (173) Virions found in
vacuoles and attached to chloroplasts, as well as occurring abundantly in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm and crystals in the nucleus. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (187) Kitajima, E.W., Lin, M.T.,
Cupertino, F.P. and Costa, C.L. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 90: 180. Lin, M.T. and
Chen, C.C. (1991). Phytopathology 81: 1551. Lin, M.T., Chen, C.C., Kiang, T.
and Lin, W.C. (1979). Taiwan Forest Res. Inst. Bull. No. 317. Lin, M.T.,
Kitajima, E.W., Cupertino, F.P. and Costa, C.L. (1977). Phytopathology 67:
1439.


Banana bract mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: banana potyvirus. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.DE.01. (8) First reported in Musa sapientum. (9) From the
Philippines. (10) By Bateson and Dale, (1995). (13) Musa sapientum chlorosis,
especially obvious in bracts. (38) Spreads in the South and Central American
region. (39) Spreads in the Philippines. (47) Musa sapientum. (50) Musaceae
<1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 45661.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: the virus reacts with antiserum prepared to the
conserved core regions of a mixture of potyviruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: sugarcane mosaic potyvirus. (184) The coat
protein gene of the virus is 71% identical to that of maize dwarf mosaic
virus, and its 3'UTR is most similar to that of ornithogalum mosaic virus
(40%). (187) Bateson, M.F. and Dale, J.L. (1995). Arch. Virol. 140: 515.


Banana bunchy top nanavirus

      (1) J.L. Dale, 1986. Revised 1991. (2) Synonyms: abaca bunchy top virus.
(3) Standard acronym: BBTV. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.1.001. (8) First
reported in Musa spp. (9) From Fiji. (10) By Magee (1953). (11) Symptoms
persist. (12) Symptoms chlorosis, stunting. (13) Musa spp. chlorosis,
stunting, death. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Pentalonia nigronervosa. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus <probably> retained when
the vector moults. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of
the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies
reported by Magee (1940 and 1953). (38) Spreads in the African region and the
Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Australia, Burundi, Egypt, Gabon, the
Philippines, and Taiwan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis, stunting. (43) Musa
sapientum cv. Cavendish chlorosis, stunting. (45) Musa spp. (47) Musa, or Musa
sapientum <cv. Cavendish>. (50) Musaceae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
18-20 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (92) Genome of three parts <J. Dale, personal
communication>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 1.3 kb. (94)
The 2nd largest 1.3 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 1.171 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Dale et al. (1986). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12585. (118)

(133) Mr 20000. (134) Virion protein. (171) Virions found in phloem. (179)
Nanavirus. (184) In nucleic acid hybridization tests, its genome reacts
distantly with that of abaca bunchy top virus. It was originally thought to be
a luteovirus: infected plants sometimes contain dsRNA, but these may come from
a contaminant virus. (187) Dale, J.L. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 33: 301. Magee,
C.J.P. (1940). J. Aust. Inst. Agric. Sci. 6: 109. Magee, C.J.P. (1953). J.
Proc. R. Soc. N.S.W. 87: 3.


Banana streak badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux, and B.E. Lockhart, 1987. (3) Standard
acronym: BSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 07.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Musa
spp. (9) From Morocco. (10) By Lockhart (1986). (13) Musa spp. chlorotic leaf
streaks, necrosis. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Morocco. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic and necrotic streaks.
(43) Musa spp. chlorotic and necrotic leaf streaks. (44) Hordeum vulgare,
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum, Zea mays. (47) Musa. (48)
Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Zea mays. (50)
Musaceae <1/1>. (51) Gramineae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (53) Lockhart
(1986). (60) Method: Lockhart (1986). (61) Virions bacilliform. (65) Virions
119 nm in length. (71) Virions <c.> 30 nm wide. (179) Badnavirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cacao swollen shoot and rice
tungro bacilliform viruses. (187) Lockhart, B.E. (1986). Phytopathology 76:
995. Lockhart, B.E.L. and Autrey, J.C. (1988). Plant Dis. 72: 230.


Barley dubia (?) tenuivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Hordeum vulgare. (9) From Germany. (10) By Kempiak (1972). (13)
Hordeum vulgare. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Javesella pellucida, J. dubia. (18) Transmitted by
Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (47) Hordeum vulgare.
(50) Gramineae <1/1>. (179) <Possibly> Tenuivirus. (184) See Gingery (1988).
(187) Gingery, R.E. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 4, The Filamentous
Plant Viruses, p. 303; ed. R.G. Milne. Plenum Press, New York. Kempiak, G.
