Barley mild mosaic bymovirus

      (1) M.J. Adams, 1990. (2) Synonyms: barley yellow mosaic virus
mechanically transmissible strain, BaYMV Streatley strain. (3) Standard
acronym: BaMMV. (4) Strains: two serotypes have been reported from Japan. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.3.0.002. (8) First reported in Hordeum vulgare. (9)
From Germany. (10) By Huth et al. (1984). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally <in
winter or early spring only>. (12) Symptoms yellow streaks, brown necrosis.
(13) Hordeum vulgare yellow streaks, especially in younger leaves and
sometimes in leaf sheath, also brown necrotic patches. Leaves may roll making
the plant look `spiky'. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a
fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis (Mastigomycotina). (21)
Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (22) Principal natural vector(s): Polymyxa
graminis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Huth (1989).
(39) Spreads in Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, and
the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show yellow streaks. (43) Hordeum vulgare, Lagurus ovatus,
Eremopyrum hirsutum, Aegilops kotschyi, A. searsii, A. speltoides systemic
leaf streaking. (44) Avena sativa, Oryza sativa, Secale cereale, Triticum
aestivum, Zea mays. (45) Hordeum vulgare (but some cultivars are immune). (46)
Hordeum vulgare (W). (47) Aegilops kotschyi, or Aegilops searsii, or Aegilops
speltoides, or Eremopyrum hirsutum, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lagurus ovatus.
(48) Agrostis tenuis, or Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Avena sativa, or Bromus
inermis, or Bromus mollis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Echinochloa crus-galli,
or Elymus junceus, or Elytrigia repens, or Festuca pratensis, or Lolium
multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Lolium temulentum, or Oryza sativa, or
Panicum maximum, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Poa pratensis, or Secale cereale,
or Setaria viridis, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <6/27>.
(51) Gramineae <21/27>. (53) Proeseler (1988). (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Huth et al. (1984); Adams et al.
(1987); Pröls et al. (1990). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions <slightly> usually flexuous. (69) Virions with clear
modal lengths <two>. (70) Virions of 270-290 nm, or 570-600 nm. (71) Virions
12 nm wide <PTA>, or 15 nm wide <UA>. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (79) Density 1.314 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size <c.> 12 kb. (92)
Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 8 kb
<approximately>. (94) The 2nd largest <c.> 4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Batista et al. (1989). (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (111)
Poly A region found at the 3' end of both genome segments. (112) Additional
factor not required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12466. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D10947 Em(40)_vi:BMMNA1 Gb(84)_vi:BMMNA1

coat protein. 8/93 1,476bp X75933 Em(43)_vi:Bammvrna2 Gb(89)_vi:Bammvrna2

polyprotein. 4/95 2,428bp. X84802 Em(44)n:Bmmvrna2a Barley mild mosaic virus
RNA 2 complete sequence. 7/95 2,428bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found
in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35000. (145) Method of
preparation: Huth et al. (1984); Ehlers and Paul (1986). (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins isolated <Ehlers (1987)>. (153) One protein found. (154) Mr
72000. (155) Possibly pinwheel inclusion protein. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll,
epidermis, vascular parenchyma and the companion cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
membranous bodies and pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions <but
virions may be attached to pinwheels>. (179) Bymovirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: barley
yellow mosaic, wheat spindle streak mosaic (syn. wheat yellow mosaic) and oat
mosaic viruses. (184) The virus was reported to have virions serologically
related to those of bean yellow mosaic potyvirus and those of one isolate of
turnip mosaic potyvirus (Stanarius et al., 1989) but was not confirmed by Chen
and Adams (1991). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: longitudinal streaks on
unfurling leaves in winter or early spring distinguish this from barley yellow
dwarf luteovirus. Serological tests or sequencing are necessary to distinguish
it from barley yellow mosaic bymovirus. (187) Adams, M.J. (1991). Pl. Path.
40: 53. Adams, M.J., Jones, P. and Swaby, A.G. (1987). Ann. appl. Biol. 110:
321. Batista, M.F., Antoniw, J.F., Swaby, A.G., Jones, P. and Adams, M.J.
(1989). Pl. Path. 38: 226. Chen, J. and Adams, M.J. (1991). Pl. Path. 40: 226.
Ehlers, V. (1987). Ph.D. Thesis, Technischen Universitat Carlo-Wilhelmina,
Braunschweig, Germany. Huth, W. (1988). In: Viruses with Fungal Vectors, p.
61; eds J.I. Cooper and M.J.C. Asher. Association of Applied Biologists,
Wellesbourne, U.K. Huth, W. (1989). EPPO Bulletin 19: 547. Huth, W. and Adams,
M.J. (1990). Intervirology 31: 38. Huth, W., Lesemann, D.-E. and Paul, H.L.
(1984). Phytopath. Z. 111: 37. Proeseler, G. (1988). Arch. Phytopath.
Pflanzen. 24: 267. Pröls, M., Davidson, A., Schell, J. and Steinbiss, H.-H.
(1990). J. Phytopath. 130: 249. Stanarius, A., Proeseler, G. and Richter, J.
(1989). Arch. Phytopath. Pflanzen. 25: 303.


Barley mosaic virus

      (1) S.L. Bhattiprolu, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.03. (8)
First reported in Hordeum vulgare. (9) From Delhi, India. (10) By Dhanraj and
Raychaudhuri (1969). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mosaic and stunting.
(13) Hordeum vulgare mosaic and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Rhopalosiphum maidis. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
India. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show mosaic. (43) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum
mosaic in systemically infected leaves. (45) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare,
Triticum aestivum. (46) Avena sativa (W), Hordeum vulgare (W), Triticum
aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Triticum aestivum.
(50) Gramineae <3/3>. (53) Dhanraj and Raychaudhuri (1969). (54) TIP: 53-55
°C. (55) LIV: 0.33 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 40 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (171) Virions found in leaves. (179) (Ungrouped). (187)
Dhanraj, K.S. and Raychaudhuri, S.P. (1969). Pl. Dis. Reptr 53: 766.


Barley stripe mosaic hordeivirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: barley false stripe virus,
possibly barley yellow stripe virus, barley mild stripe virus, oat stripe
mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: BSMV. (4) Strains: type strain, Russian,
Norwich (ND 18), Canadian severe, Argentine mild (AM), Rothamsted (R). (5)
ICTV decimal code 32.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Hordeum vulgare and
Triticum aestivum. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By McKinney (1951). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum mild stripe mosaic to lethal
necrosis. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to
90-100%>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (36)
Studies reported by McKinney (1953); Gold et al. (1954); Gardner (1967);
Sprague et al. (1963); McNeal et al. (1976); Sandfaer (1971). (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region, the North American
region, and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China, the UK, the
USA, and the former USSR. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show stripe mosaic in monocotyledonous
species, and chlorotic local lesions in dicotyledonous species. (43) Hordeum
vulgare, Triticum aestivum, Avena sativa systemic stripe mosaic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. album large chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. Beta vulgaris chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Zea mays
systemic stripe mosaic. Spinacia oleracea systemic mosaic. Nicotiana tabacum
cv. Samsun local chlorotic lesions; not systemic. (45) Hordeum vulgare,
Triticum aestivum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L); Chenopodium quinoa (L).
(47) Anthoxanthum aristatum, or Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Avena sativa, or
Beta vulgaris, or Bromus secalinus, or Bromus tectorum, or Chenopodium album,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Dactylis glomerata, or
Echinochloa crus-galli, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or
Festuca pratensis, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lagurus ovatus, or Lolium
multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Lolium persicum, or Lolium temulentum, or
Lophopyrum elongatum, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Oryzopsis
miliacea, or Panicum capillare, or Panicum miliaceum, or Phalaris arundinacea,
or Phalaris paradoxa, or Phleum arenarium, or Phleum pratense, or Poa annua,
or Poa pratensis, or Secale cereale, or Setaria italica, or Setaria
macrostachya, or Setaria viridis, or Sorghum bicolor, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum, or Zea mays. (50) Chenopodiaceae <5/5>,
or Gramineae <35/35>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Nitzany and Gerechter (1962);
Ohmann-Kreutzberg (1962); McKinney and Greeley (1965); Kirstensen and Engsbro
(1970); Novikov and Atabekov (1970); Polak and Slykhuis (1972). (54) TIP:
60-68 °C <McKinney, 1951; Kassanis and Slykhuis, 1959>. (55) LIV: 15-22 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 2-4. (60) Method: Novikov (1970). (61) Virions
rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 112-150 nm <Gold et al.,
1954; Harrison et al., 1965>. (71) Virions 18-24 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obvious. (73) Axial canal 3-4 nm in diameter <Gibbs et al., 1963; Harrison et
al., 1965; Finch, 1966>. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix
2.5-2.6 nm. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 199 S. (78) Of the other(s) 166-194
S <Brakke and Palomar, 1976; Harrison et al., 1965>. (82) Isoelectric point pH
4.5. (83) A260/A280 ratio 0.99 <corrected>. (84) Virions contain 3.8-4 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 96 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size
10.289 kb. (92) Genome of three parts <RNA-a, RNA-b and RNA-g are separately
encapsidated>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 4 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 3.289 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 3.164 kb <or smaller depending on
the strain. The Agentine strain has another RNA component of 2.5 kb>. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lane (1974); Gustafson and Armour (1986).
(100) Base composition 20.3-23.5 % G. (101) Base composition 27-30.9 % A.

<Atabekov and Novikov, 1971>. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated

Features of the genome: RNA-a has one ORF that encodes the 130 kDa (?
replicase); RNA-b encodes the 22 kDa (coat protein) and the 60, 17 and 14 kDa
(movement proteins); RNA-g has 2 ORFs and encodes the 87 kDa (? polymerase)
and 17 kDa (regulator of the translation of RNA-b genes. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is tRNA. (122) Nongenomic nucleic
acid generated from the 3'-end of genome and of 1.830 and 0.788 kb. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 21500. (134) It is coat protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Atabekov et al. (1968); Gumpf and Hamilton (1968). (146) Amino
acid sequence: Gustafson and Armour (1986). (147) Amino acid composition:
Atabekov et al. (1968); Gumpf and Hamilton (1968). (148) Virion proteins
glycosylated. (149) Are are the coat proteins (Gumpf et al., 1977; Partridge
et al., 1976). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins identified by genomic
sequence analysis <Gustafson and Armour (1986)>. (153) <At least> three
proteins found. (154) Mr 58087. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 17378. (158) Mr of 3rd
14119. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
nuclei. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular
changes: peripheral vesicles in chloroplasts (Carroll, 1970). (179)
Hordeivirus <the type species>. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: lychnis ringspot virus, but distantly (Gibbs et al., 1963). (184) The
genomic RNA do not hybridize with those of lychnis ringspot and poa semilatent
hordeiviruses. (187) Atabekov, J.G. and Novikov, V.K. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr.

Barley yellow dwarf luteovirus

      (1) W.F. Rochow, 1986; R.J. Sward and P.M. Waterhouse, 1987. (2)
Synonyms: cereal yellow dwarf virus, hordeum nanescens virus, oat red leaf
virus, rice giallume virus, ryegrass chlorotic streak virus (Clark and
Christensen, 1972; Catherall, 1974), possibly maize leaf fleck virus (Stoner,
1952). (3) Standard acronym: BYDV-MAV, BYDV-PAV, BYDV-RGV, BYDV-RMV, BYDV-RPV,
BYDV-SGV. (4) Strains: Subgroup 1: (1) BYDV-MAV transmitted by Macrosiphum
(Sitobion) avenae. (2) BYDV-PAV transmitted by Rhopalosiphum padi and by
Macrosiphum avenae. (3) BYDV-SGV transmitted by Schizaphis graminum. Subgroup
2: (4) BYDV-RMV transmitted by Rhopalosiphum maidis. (5) BYDV-RPV Transmitted
by Rhopalosiphum padi. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.1.001. (8) First reported
in Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare and Triticum aestivum. (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Oswald and Houston (1951; 1953a; 1953b). (11) Symptoms persist,
or vary seasonally, or disappear soon after infection <cool temperatures and
supplementary light are needed for conspicuous symptoms to develop in plants
grown in greenhouses>. (13) Hordeum vulgare chlorotic leaf symptoms. Avena
sativa, A. byzantina floret blast, chlorotic and red leaves. Triticum aestivum
leaf chlorosis. Oryza sativa yellow to orange leaves (rice giallume disease).
Lolium perenne, L. multiflorum, Secale cereale, Zea mays often symptomless,
but sometimes purple or crimson leaf streaking. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aulocorthum circumflexum
(synonyms Amphorophora circumflexa, Macrosiphum circumflexa, Myzus
circumflexus, Aulacorthum circumflexum, Siphonophora circumflexa); Ceruraphis
eriophori; Acyrthosiphon (Metopolophium) dirhodum (synonyms Acyrthosiphon
dirhodum, Macrosiphum dirhodum); Myzus persicae; Rhopalosiphum insertum
(synonyms Rhopalosiphum annuae, Rhopalosiphum fitchii); Rhopalosiphum maidis
(synonym Aphis maydis); Rhopalosiphum padi (synonyms Anuraphis padi,
Rhopalosiphum prunifoliae); Rhopalosiphum rufiabdominalis; Schizaphis graminum
(synonym Toxoptera graminum); Sipha agropyrella; Macrosiphum (Sitobion) avenae
(synonym Macrosiphum granarium); Macrosiphum (Sitobion) fragariae);
Macrosiphum (Sitobion) avenae miscanthi, Sitobion avenae miscanthi (synonyms
Sitobion avenae ssp. miscanthi, Macrosiphum avenae miscanthi cf. Jedlinski,
1981). Subgroup 1: (1) BYDV-MAV is transmitted usually by Macrosiphum
(Sitobion) avenae, but rarely by Rhopalosiphum padi, R. maidis and Schizaphis
graminum. (2) BYDV-PAV is transmitted usually by R. padi and M.(S.) avenae,
erratically by Sch. graminum, but rarely by R. maidis. (3) BYDV-SGV is
transmitted regularly by Sch. graminum, but rarely if at all by M.(S.) avenae,
R. padi or R. maidis. Subgroup 2: (4) BYDV-RMV is regularly transmitted by R.
maidis, but infrequently by R. padi, M.(S.) avenae and Sch. graminum. (5)
BYDV-RPV is transmitted regularly by R. padi, erratically by Sch. graminum,
but rarely by R. maidis and M.(S.) avenae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Bruehl (1961); Jedlinski and Brown (1965); Rochow (1963;
1969; 1970; 1979); Rochow and Muller (1974); Paliwal (1982); Plumb (1976);
Smith and Plumb (1981); Watson and Mulligan (1960); Waterhouse (1986); Zhang
et al. (1983). See also Büchen-Osmond et al. (1988). Cultivars tolerant of the
virus are important for controlling the virus, which is probably the most
widely distributed virus affecting cereals. Losses great from early
infections. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis,
reddening, stunting. (43) Hordeum vulgare cv. Black Hulls, Avena sativa cvs
Clintland, Clintland 64 and Blenda (spring oat), Avena byzantina cvs Coast
Black and California Red (winter oat) leaf chlorosis. Avena byzantina cv.
Black: strains BYDV-RMV and BYDV-RPV little effect; BYDV-MAV moderate effect;
BYDV-PAV severe effect. (45) Avena byzantina cv. Coast Black. (46) Avena
sativa (W); Avena byzantina (W); Hordeum vulgare (W). (47) Agrostis alba, or
Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Avena byzantina, or Avena sativa, or Avena strigosa,
or Bromus inermis, or Bromus mollis, or Bromus racemosus, or Bromus secalinus,
or Bromus tectorum, or Chloris gayana, or Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia
intermedia, or Festuca pratensis, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium multiflorum,
or Lolium perenne, or Lolium temulentum, or Oryza sativa, or Panicum
dichotomiflorum, or Paspalum dilatatum, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Phleum
pratense, or Poa annua, or Poa pratensis, or Poa trivialis, or Secale cereale,
or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum, or Zea mays. (48) Agrostis alba, or
Bromus inermis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Festuca
pratensis, or Lolium perenne, or Phleum pratense, or Poa trivialis. (50)
Gramineae <30/30>. (51) Gramineae <8/30>. (52) At least 100 monocotyledonous
species are susceptible. (53) Bruehl (1961); Rochow (1961); Slykhuis (1967).
(54) TIP: 60-75 °C <Heagy and Rochow, 1965>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Rochow and Brakke (1964); Hebert (1963); Hewish and
Shukla (1983); D'Arcy et al. (1983); Hammond et al. (1983); Waterhouse et al.
(1987). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm
in diameter <negatively stained or in sections; Jensen, 1969>, or 30 nm in
diameter <approximately in shadowed preparations; Rochow and Brakke, 1964>.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) <Usually> one sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 115-118 S <for BYDV-MAV>. (79)
Density 1.4-1.405 g cm3 in CsCl <for BYDV-PAV>. (81) Density 1.335 g cm3 in
Cs2SO4 for BYDV-PAV. (84) Virions contain 28 % nucleic acid <in BYDV-MAV-like
isolate; Paliwal, 1978>. (85) Virions 72 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 5.673 kb <Gerlach et al., 1987>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 5.6 kb <BYDV-RPV; 5.677 for BYDV-PAV>. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Brakke and Rochow (1974). (100) Base
composition 24.6 % G. (101) Base composition 29.6 % A. (102) Base composition
23.8 % C. (103) Base composition 22 % U. (110) Poly A region absent. (116)
Nucleotide sequence references: Miller et al. (1987). (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12037. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D10206 Em(40)_vi:BYDNYRPV

complete cds. 11/93 5,600bp. D11028 Em(40)_vi:BYDMAV Gb(84)_vi:BYDMAV Barley

Em(40)_vi:BYDMAVCP Gb(84)_vi:BYDMAVCP Barley yellow dwarf virus (isolate
MAV-PS1) coat protein gene. 1/93 600bp. X17261 Em(40)_vi:BYDPAVCP
Gb(84)_vi:BYDPAVCP Barley yellow dwarf virus (isolate P-PAV) coat protein
gene. 1/93 603bp. X53174 Em(40)_vi:LUBYDCP Gb(84)_vi:LUBYDCP Barley yellow
dwarf virus genomic RNA for capsid protein. 9/93 655bp. X56050
Em(40)_vi:BYDCPG Gb(84)_vi:BYDCPG Barley yellow dwarf virus gene for capsid
protein. 1/92 984bp X80050 Gb(84)n:BYDV13T Barley yellow dwarf Virus RNA (13t)
for 3' terminal. 8/94 855bp. Z14123 Em(40)_vi:BYDVCP Gb(84)_vi:BYDVCP Barley
yellow dwarf virus gene for capsid protein. 7/92 647bp. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in the virions <Miller et al., 1987>. (121) Is satellite
RNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells <Gerlach et al., 1987>.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23500 <MAV>, or 24400 <PAV>, or 24450
<RPV) (Scalla and Rochow, 1977; Hammond et al., 1983>. (145) Method of
preparation: Scalla and Rochow (1977). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins
identified by genomic sequence analysis. (153) Six proteins found. (154) Mr
95000. (155) Probably a polymerase, read through protein. (156) Mr of 2nd
largest 69000. (157) Possibly with a transport function. (158) Mr of 3rd
34000. (159) Probably a polymerase. (160) Mr of 4th 22000. (161) Coat protein.
(162) Mr of 5th and smaller 6000. (163) Possibly VPg; 17000 internal gene
coding for coat protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in phloem (Jensen, 1969). (172) Virions found in cytoplasm
and in nuclei. (173) Virions found in and around plasmodesmata. Viruses of
different BYDV subgroups alter the nucleus in different ways (Gill and Chong,
1975, 1976, 1979a, 1979b). (178) Other cellular changes: the degeneration of
phloem tissue to which virions are confined. Subgroup 1 viruses initially
cause malformation and lobing of the nucleus, in which, later, masses of
densely stained material accumulate, before it disintegrates (Gill and Chong,
1975). Subgroup 2 viruses induce changes that are quite different.
Heterochromatin disappears during the later phases of infection, and the
nucleus devlops a double membrane with defunct nucleoplasm. (179) Luteovirus
<BYDV-MAV, the type species>. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: BYDV-MAV, BYDV-PAV and BYDV-SGV belong to one group and are related
to soybean dwarf virus, whereas BYDV-RPV (including ryegrass chlorotic streak
isolates), BYDV-RGV and BYDV-RMV belong to a second which is closely related
to beet western yellows virus (BWYV; Duffus and Rochow, 1978; Rochow and
Duffus, 1978; Martin and D'Arcy, 1990), potato leafroll and carrot red leaf
viruses, and more distantly to pea enation mosaic and southern bean mosaic
sobemovirus. BYDV-RPV and BWYV are serologically close, induce similar
cytological effects and have similar genome sequences, which are related to
those of carmoviruses, dianthoviruses and tombusviruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: field symptoms easily confused with nutrient or water deficiencies.
The disease resembles aster yellows MLO in small grains (Banttari, 1965; Gill
et al., 1969). (187) Aapola, A.I.E. (1968). Ph.D. Thesis, Cornell University,
U.S.A. Aapola, A.I.E. and Rochow, W.F. (1968). Phytopathology 58: 398.
Banttari, E.E. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 838. Barbara, D.J., Kawata, E.E.,
Ueng, P.P., Lister, R.M. and Larkins, B.A. (1987). J. gen. Virol. 68: 2419.
Brakke, M.K. and Rochow, W.F. (1974). Virology 61: 240. Bruehl, G.W. (1961).
Am. Phytopathol. Soc. Monograph No. 1. Büchen-Osmond, C., Crabtree, K.J.,
Gibbs, A.J. and McLean, G.D. (1988). In: Viruses of Plants in Australia, p.
402, Aust. Nat. Univ., Canberra. Catherall, P.L. (1974). Pl. Path. 23: 116.
Clark, M.F. and Christensen, M.J. (1972). N.Z. J. agric. Res. 15: 179. D'Acry,
C.J., Hewings, A.D., Burnett, P.A. and Jedlinski, H. (1983). Phytopathology
73: 755. Duffus, J.E. and Rochow, W.F. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 45. Gerlach,
W., Miller, A. and Waterhouse, P.M. (1987). BYDV Newsl. 1: 17. Gill, C.C. and
Chong, J. (1975). Virology 66: 440. Gill, C.C. and Chong, J. (1975). Virology
75: 33. Gill, C.C. and Chong, J. (1975). Phytopathology 69: 363. Gill, C.C.
and Chong, J. (1975). Virology 95: 59. Gill, C.C., Westdal, P.H. and
Richardson, H.P. (1975). Phytopathology 59: 527. Hammond, J., Lister, R.M. and
Foster, J.E. (1983). J. gen. Virol. 64: 667. Hebert, T.T. (1963).
Phytopathology 53: 362. Heagy, J. and Rochow, W.F. (1965). Phytopathology 55:
809. Hewish, D.R. and Shukla, D.D. (1983). J. virol. Meth. 7: 223. Jedlinski,
H. (1972). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 230. Jedlinski, H. and Brown, C.M. (1969).

Barley yellow mosaic bymovirus

      (1) M.J. Adams, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BaYMV. (4) Strains: six
reported from Japan (Kashiwazaki et al.. 1989a); the M and Streatley strains
in Europe are now recognised as strains of barley mild mosaic bymovirus. Two
strains reported from Germany (Huth, 1989a) and elsewhere in Europe. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.3.0.003. (8) First reported in Hordeum vulgare. (9) From
Japan. (10) By Ikata and Kawai (1940); Miyamoto (1958); Inouye (1964). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms yellow streaks especially on youngest
leaves in winter or spring. (13) Hordeum vulgare yellow streaking, especially
of younger leaves and sometimes of leaf sheath, also brown necrotic patches.
Leaves may roll so the plants appear `spiky'. Vigour reduced. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa
graminis. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Huth (1989b); Usugi (1988). (38) Spreads in the Eastern
Asian region and the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Belgium, China, France,
Germany, Greece, Japan, and the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellow leaf streaking. (43) Hordeum
vulgare systemic leaf streaking. (44) Avena sativa, Oryza sativa, Secale
cereale, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays. (45) Hordeum vulgare. (46) Hordeum
vulgare (W). (47) Hordeum vulgare. (48) Avena sativa, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Lolium multiflorum, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea
mays. (50) Gramineae <1/7>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <6/7>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Miyamoto (1958); Ruan and Jin (1983). (56) DEP: log10
minus 2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Huth et al. (1984);
Pröls et al. (1990). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with clear modal lengths <two>.
(70) Virions of 270-290 nm, or 570-600 nm. (71) Virions 12-15 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in
CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.14. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.217 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7.632 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
3.585 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Kashiwazaki et al. (1989b).
(100) Base composition 22.1 % G. (101) Base composition 27.4 % A. (102) Base
composition 24 % C. (103) Base composition 26.5 % U. (110) Poly A region
present. (111) Poly A region at the 3' terminus of both RNAs. (112) Additional
factor not required for infectivity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references:
Kashiwazaki et al. (1990); Kashiwazaki et al. (1991); Davidson et al. (1991).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12465. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00544
Em(40)_vi:BYMCP Gb(84)_vi:BYMCP Barley yellow mosaic virus capsid protein
gene, 3' end. 8/92 1,370bp. D01091 Em(40)_vi:BYMR1P Gb(84)_vi:BYMR1P Barley
yellow mosaic virus RNA 1 encoding polyprotein. 8/92 7,632bp. D01092
Em(40)_vi:BYMR2P Gb(84)_vi:BYMR2P Barley yellow mosaic virus RNA 2 encoding
polyprotein. 8/92 3,585bp. D01099 Em(40)_vi:BYMGR2P Gb(84)_vi:BYMGR2P Barley
yellow mosaic virus RNA 2 encoding polyprotein. 1/94 3,585bp. X69757
Em(40)_vi:BAYMVRNA1 Gb(84)_vi:BAYMVRNA1 Barley yellow mosaic virus RNA for
polyprotein RNA1. 1/93 7,648bp. X69836 Em(40)_vi:BYMV270KD Gb(84)_vi:BYMV270KD
Barley Yellow Mosaic Virus-2 DNA for 70 kDa protein. 3/93 621bp. Z24677
Em(40)_vi:BYCOAPROA Gb(84)_vi:BYCOAPROA Barley yellow mosaic virus coat
protein mRNA, complete CDS. 7/93 1,313bp. 7 sequences. (119) Features of the
genome: RNA 1: single ORF encoding a 270 kDa protein which is processed to
produce the capsid protein (c-terminal) and at least 3 non-structural
proteins. RNA 2: single ORF encoding a 98 kDa protein; function not yet
determined. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32234. (145) Method of preparation: Huth et
al. (1984); Usugi et al. (1989). (146) Amino acid sequence: Kashiwazaki et al.
(1989b). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma and
companion cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies, membranous bodies, and
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Bymovirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: rice
necrosis mosaic, oat mosaic, wheat yellow mosaic and wheat spindle streak
mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: barley
mild mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: leaf streaking and
unfurling distinguish this from barley yellow dwarf luteovirus. Serological
tests required to distinguish it from barley mild mosaic bymovirus with which
it is sometimes associated. (187) Davidson, A.D., Pröls, M., Schell, J. and
Steinbiss, H.-H. (1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 989. Huth, W. (1988). In: Viruses
with Fungal Vectors, p. 61; eds J.I. Cooper and M.J.C. Asher, Association of
Applied Biologists. Huth, W. (1989a). Nach. dtsch. PflSchutz. 41: 6. Huth, W.
(1989b). EPPO Bulletin 19: 547. Huth, W. and Adams, M.J. (1990). Intervirology
31: 38. Huth, W., Lesemann, D.-E. and Paul, H.L. (1984). Phytopath. Z. 111:
37. Ikata, S. and Kawai, I. (1940). Noji Kairyo Shiryo 154: 1. Inouye, T.
(1964). Nogaku Kenkyu 50: 117. Kashiwazaki, S., Ogawa, K., Usugi, T., Omura,
T. and Tsuchizaki, T. (1989a). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 55: 16. Kashiwazaki,
S., Hayano, Y., Minobe, Y., Omura, T., Hibino, H. and Tsuchizaki, T. (1989b).
J. gen. Virol. 70: 3015. Kashiwazaki, S., Minobe, Y., Omura, T. and Hibino, H.
(1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 2781. Kashiwazaki, S., Minobe, Y. and Hibino, H.
(1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 995. Miyamoto, Y. (1958). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.

Barley yellow streak mosaic virus

      (1) N.L. Robertson, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.04. (8) First
reported in Hordeum vulgare. (9) From Conrad, Montana, U.S.A. (10) By
Robertson and Carroll (1988). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically over a few weeks
and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms light green to yellow dashes, streaks and
stripes parallel to the mid-rib, producing mosaic pattern. (13) Echinochloa
crus-galli, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium persicum, Setaria viridis, Triticum
aestivum mosaic and banding. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
a mite. (17) Transmitted by Petrobia latens. (19) Transmitted by
Tetranychidae. (24) Not transmitted by Endria inimica, Macrosteles fascifrons,
Balchutha neglecta, Psammotettix alienus, P. lividellus, Hebecephalus
occidentalis, Dicraneura probicarneola, Amblysellus grex, Auridius auratus,
Sorhoanus uhleri, Athysanella attenuata, A. acuticauda, A. occidentalis,
Rhopalosiphum padi, R. maidis, Macrosiphum (Sitobion) avenae, Limothrips
denticornis, Anapothrips obscurus brachypterus, Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella
triici, F. fusca. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus
not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Robertson
(1987); Robertson and Carroll (1988). (38) Spreads in the North American
region. (39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa few necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic
and necrotic local lesions and rings; new leaves show systemic symptoms of
vein-chlorosis and yellow mosaics. Severely diseased plants were reduced in
height and leaf size. Remission occurs on plants with faint chlorotic spots or
mild mosaics. Echinochloa crus-galli, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium persicum,
Setaria viridis, Triticum aestivum mosaic of streaks and dashes, some banding;
systemic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. glutinosa. (45) Hordeum vulgare, Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Hordeum vulgare (W), Nicotiana
benthamiana (W). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium persicum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Setaria
viridis, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp.
chinensis, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis melo,
or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Elytrigia
repens, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Physalis floridana. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Gramineae <5/7>, or
Solanaceae <1/12>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/7>, or Solanaceae
<11/12>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (52) Susceptible monocotyledons are only
infected by the mite vector, not by sap inoculation, whereas the reverse is
true for Nicotiana benthamiana. (53) Robertson and Carroll (1988; 1991. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions, or contains many virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: aldehyde fixation helps to keep virions intact. (60) Method:
Robertson and Carroll (1991). (61) Virions unusually shaped. (63) Virions
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 127-4000 nm. (71) Virions 52-81 nm wide. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 10 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 10 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Robertson and Carroll
(1991). (109) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent.
(132) Virion protein(s) two <at least>. (133) Mr <of the larger> 100. (135) Mr
of 2nd largest 32. (145) Method of preparation: Robertson and Carroll (1991).
(164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots,
mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma, xylem, phloem, companion cells and
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm. (179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: electron
microscopy of leaf dips; infected leaf sap mechanically inoculated to
Nicotiana benthamiana seedlings. (187) Robertson, N.L. (1987). Ph.D. Thesis,
Montana State University, U.S.A. Robertson, N.L. and Carroll, T.W. (1988).
Science 240: 1188. Robertson, N.L. and Carroll, T.W. (1989). J. Ultrastruct.
and Mol. Struct. Res. 102: 139. Robertson, N.L. and Carroll, T.W. (1991).
Plant Dis. 75:: 839.


Barley yellow striate mosaic cytorhabdovirus

      (1) R.G. Milne and M. Conti, 1985. (2) Synonyms: cereal striate mosaic
virus (Matthews, 1982). (3) Standard acronym: BYSMV. (4) Strains: maize
sterile stunt virus (Greber, 1982; 1983a and b; 1984a and b; Milne et al.,
1986), Moroccan wheat rhabdovirus (Milne et al., 1986), wheat chlorotic streak
virus (Signoret et al. 1976), wheat chlorotic streak mosaic virus (Milne et
al., 1986; Signoret et al., 1972; 1977). (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.4.0.002.
(8) First reported in Triticum durum, T. compactum, T. aestivum. (9) From
northern Italy. (10) By Conti (1969a); Signoret et al. (1972). (13) Elytrigia
repens, Triticum durum, T. compactum, T. aestivum, Zea mays chlorotic stripes
or mosaic. Avena sativa, Secale cereale yellow mosaic, red basal leaves.
Setaria viridis, Setaria spp. chlorotic streaks and stripes in leaves;
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Laodelphax striatellus (Conti 1969a, 1969b, 1974, 1980; Conti
and Plumb, 1977; Leclant and Signoret, 1976; Signoret et al., 1976; Signoret
et al., 1977). Javesella pellucida transmits the virus experimentally (Conti,
1980). (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (28) Virus transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed <Conti, 1980>. (36) Studies reported by Conti (1969a);
Signoret et al. (1976); Conti and Milne, (1977); Amici et al. (1978); Conti
(1980) Lockhart and Elyamani (1983). (38) Spreads in the African region, the
Eurasian region, the Middle East, and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in
Australia, France, Iran, Italy, and Morocco. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis,
reddening. (43) Avena sativa cv. Alba yellow mosaic, reddening of basal
leaves. Bromus aleutensis, B. arvensis, B. rigidus (=B. maximus) stunting.
Hordeum vulgare cv. Delisa bright yellow mosaic. Setaria italica chlorotic
stripes. (44) Digitaria sanguinalis, Echinochloa crus-galli, Festuca
pratensis, Holcus lanatus, Phleum pratense. (45) Hordeum vulgare. (46) Hordeum
vulgare (W). (47) Avena, or Avena sativa, or Briza, or Bromus, or Bromus
aleutensis, or Bromus arvensis, or Bromus mollis, or Bromus rigidus, or
Dactylis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia repens, or Hordeum, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Lagurus, or Lolium, or Panicum, or Poa, or Secale, or Secale
cereale, or Setaria italica, or Setaria viridis, or Trisetum, or Triticum, or
Triticum aestivum, or Triticum compactum, or Triticum durum, or Zea, or Zea
mays. (48) Digitaria sanguinalis, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Festuca
pratensis, or Holcus lanatus, or Phleum pratense. (50) Gramineae <28/33>. (51)
Gramineae <5/33>. (52) Transmitted by the plant hopper vector to 26 of 44
species in Gramineae only (Conti, 1980). (53) Conti (1969a); Signoret et al.,
(1976); Conti and Milne (1977); Amici et al., (1978); Conti (1980); Lockhart
and Elyamani (1983). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days <at 22°C and 2-4
days at 5°C (Conti, 1980)>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix in glutaraldehyde; unfixed virions
disrupt in neutral PTA and UA. (60) Method: Luisoni (1969); Milne and Conti
(1986). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 270 nm <Conti, 1969a), but
longer in thin sections or UA (Conti and Appiano, 1974; Appiano and Conti,
1973; Conti and Plumb, 1977)>. (71) Virions 55 nm wide. (74) Basic helix <of
nucleocapsid> obvious <after envelope has been removed with chloroform, 0.2%
Nonidet P 40 or 0.2% Triton X-100>. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.4 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded <Bassi et al., 1980>. (166) Replication does not depend on
a helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (173) Virions found in within membrane-bound cisternae, from which
the virus buds, but not found in nucleus or perinuclear space. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (179)
Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: Moroccan wheat rhabdovirus, wheat chlorotic
streak, maize sterile stunt (SDI:2), northern cereal mosaic (SDI:6), digitaria
striate and wheat rosette stunt (SDI:6) viruses. Maize sterile stunt (MSSV) is
a serotype of BYSMV (2 SDI units) (Greber, 1984b). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: festuca leaf streak virus. (187) Amici, A.,
Faoro, F. and Tornaghi, R. (1978). Riv. Patol. veg. S IV 14: 85. Appiana, A.
and Conti, M. (1974). J. Submicrosc. Cytol. 6: 105. Bassi, M., Barbieri, N.,
Appiano, A., Conti, M., D'Agostino, G. and Caciagli, P. (1980). J. Submicrosc.
Cytol. 12: 201.Conti, M. (1969a). Phytopath. Z. 66: 275. Conti, M. (1969b).
Ric. Sci. 39: 701. Conti, M. (1972). Phytopath. Z. 73: 39. Conti, M. (1974).

and Appiano, A. (1973). J. gen. Virol. 21: 315. Conti, M. and Plumb, R.T.
(1977). J. gen. Virol. 34: 107. Conti, M. and Milne, R.G. (1977). Annls.
Phytopath. 9: 255. Greber, R.S. (1979). Aust. J. agric. Res. 30: 43. Greber,
R.S. (1982). Aust. J. agric. Res. 33: 13. Greber, R.S. (1983a). Aust.

Bean calico mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) J.K. Brown, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: BCaMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.007. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From Mexico. (10)
By Brown et al. (1988). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13)
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red Kidney, Phaseolus lunatus leaf curl, yellow mosaic.
Malva parviflora yellow mosaic, leaves stunted and puckered. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia
tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Brown et al. (1989). (38) Spreads in the North
American region. (39) Spreads in Mexico. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics, mottles,
ringspots or necrosis first on youngest leaves as vein clearing. (43)
Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Red Kidney, Top Crop, Phaseolus lunatus yellow mosaic,
stunted. Vigna radiata, Phaseolous acutifolius, Glycine max cv. Frost Beater
systemic vein clearing and necrosis, mosaic curled leaves. Vigna unguiculata
cv. Californian Blackeye malformed leaves and recovery. (44) Gossypium

geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65)

resuspend purified virions in Tris-EDTA (10mM each) plus 0.1M NaCl, pH 8.0, 1%
SDS; add 50ug/ml proteinase K; incubate 42°C 1 hour; phenol:CHCl3: (50:48:2)

Bean common mosaic necrosis potyvirus

      (2) Synonyms: bean common mosaic virus serotype A. (3) Standard acronym:
BCMNV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.008. (61) Virions filamentous. (70)
Virions of 810-818 nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 43240. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.


Bean common mosaic potyvirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1981. Revised 1987. Condensed by A.J. Gibbs, 1995. (2)
Synonyms: bean common mosaic virus serotype B, bean mosaic virus, bean western
mosaic virus (Bos, 1964), mungbean mosaic virus (Abu Kassim, 1981; Kaiser and
Mossahebi, 1974; Rao et al., 1986). (3) Standard acronym: BCMV. (4) Strains:
Many strains of the virus have been distinguished (Drijfhout et al., 1978).
Those once grouped as serotype A are now considered isolates of a separate
potyvirus species bean common necrosis virus and several viruses, once
considered to be distinct, have now been shown to be strains of this virus
(McKern et al., 1992). The latter include: azuki bean mosaic virus, blackeye
cowpea mosaic virus, cowpea (aphid-borne) mosaic virus, cowpea (blackeye)
mosaic virus, cowpea vein-banding mosaic virus, peanut blotch virus, peanut
stripe virus and some isolates from soybean. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From New York,
U.S.A. (10) By Stewart and Reddick (1917); Pierce (1934). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris, Phaseolus coccineus tolerant cultivars
develop mosaic and malformation, sensitive ones show rugosity of lower leaves,
mosaic, malformation of leaves and pods, those with the dominant necrosis gene
develop vein necrosis, `black root' and death (especially above 26°C). (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis craccivora, A. fabae, Myzus persicae and other spp.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <up to 83% in Phaseolus vulgaris and from 7-22% in tepary bean>. (35)
Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by Drijfhout
(1978) on breeding for resistance. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in
Phaseolus beans wherever they are grown>. (39) Spreads in China and the USA.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible <strain specific response>. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics, local lesions, necrosis
very variable. (43) Chenopodium quinoa faint chlorotic local lesions
developing into green rings; not systemic. Macroptilium lathyroides necrotic
local lesions; systemic necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Dubbele Witte,
Stingless Green Refugee green vein-banding, malformed leaves (Morales and Bos,
1987). Pisum sativum, Vicia faba symptomless. (44) Cucumis sativus, Medicago
sativa, Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa, Pisum sativum. (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris cvs Dubbele Witte and Stringless Green Refugee susceptible to all
known strains. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris;
Pisum sativum, Vicia faba latent or no infection. (47) Cajanus cajan, or
Cassia tora, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer
arietinum, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine
max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus
angustifolius, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus coccineus, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesbania exaltata, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium subterraneum,
or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Bauhinia purpurea, or
Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Lablab
purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum,
or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium
repens, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <23/31>, or Solanaceae <2/7>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/31>, or
Solanaceae <5/7>. (53) Zaumeyer and Goth (1964); Thornberry (1966); Edwardson
(1974); Drijfhout et al. (1977). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 1-4 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Morales
(1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 847-886 nm. (71) Virions 12-15 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 154-158 S. (79)

(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: 17 potyviruses, including
potato Y, watermelon mosaic 2, bean yellow mosaic, blackeye cowpea mosaic and
soybean mosaic viruses. (183) Isolates originally called azuki bean mosaic
virus (Matsumoto, 1922) were first reported in Japan inducing mosaic and green
vein banding in Vigna angularis. They are found throughout the East Asian
region. They probably differ from type isolates in infecting Nicotiana
tabacum, but neither Chenopodium amaranticolor nor Vicia faba. References.
Hampton, R., Beczner, L., Hagedorn, D., Bos, L., Inouye, T., Barnett, O.,
Musil, M. and Meiners, J. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 989. Matsumoto, T.
(1922). Byochugai Zasshi 9: 517. Isolates originally called blackeye cowpea
mosaic virus (Anderson, 1995), cowpea (aphid-borne) mosaic virus, cowpea
(blackeye) mosaic virus and cowpea vein-banding mosaic virus were first
reported in the U.S.A. inducing mosaics, mottles, streaks and leaf
malformation in Crotalaria spectabilis and Vigna unguiculata. They are found
worldwide, and also do not infect Vicia faba. Some gene sequences have been
determined. Sequence database accession codes: S66253 Em(40)_vi:S66253

and Conti, M. (1966). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 72: 265. Tsuchizaki, T., Senboku, T.,
Iwaki, M., Pholauporn, S., Srithongchi, W., Deema, N. and Ching, A.O. (1984).

Fukumoto et al., 1986; Wongkaew and Dollet, 1990), peanut mild mottle virus
(Zeyong et al., 1983; Demski et al., 1988), peanut mosaic virus and sesame
yellow mosaic virus were first found in Georgia, U.S.A. in Arachis hypogaea,
which is not infected by type isolates. They cause severe mosaic, striping and
stunting in several other legumes including Lupinus albus, Glycine max and
Sesamum spp., and are transmitted not only by Aphis craccivora, but also A.
glycines and Rhopalosiphum maidis. Some gene sequences have been determined.

Bean distortion dwarf (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: BDDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From China. (10)
By Xi et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris small
distorted leaves, systemic necrosis and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci.
(18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in China. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata mild systemic chlorosis, production of
small distorted leaves, systemic necrosis and plant stunting. (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris (W). (47) Capsicum
annuum, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (53) Xi et al. (1982). (61) Virions geminate. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (83) A260/A280 ratio
1.36. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (171) Virions found in
leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) <Possible>
bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (186) The reported size
of the virions is unusually small for a geminivirus. (187) Xi, Z., Xu, S. and
Mang, K. (1982). Acta Microbiol. Sin. 22: 293.


Bean golden mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) S. Haber and A.J. Howarth, 1983. Revised A.J. Howarth, 1990. (2)
Synonyms: virus del mosaico dorado. (3) Standard acronym: BGMV. (4) Strains:
isolates from Venezuela and Puerto Rico differ in DNA hybridization analyses.
(5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.009. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris.
(9) From Costa Rica. (10) By Galvez and Castano (1976). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Macroptilium lathyroides, Phaseolus vulgaris, P. lunatus, Malvastrum
coromandelianum vein yellow net, interveinal chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci
(Sida race). (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus <some isolates> transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Brazil, the Dominican Republic,
Guatemala, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, and Venezuela. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis. (43)
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop, Phaseolus lunatus systemic vein chlorosis,
golden mosaic. (44) Glycine max, Rhynchosia minima (distinguishes the virus
from Rhynchosia mosaic). (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop. (46) Phaseolus
vulgaris cvs Top Crop and Red Kidney (W) and Red Mexican 35 (L). (47) Cajanus
cajan, or Glycine max, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Malvastrum
coromandelianum, or Pachyrhizus erosus, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or Phaseolus
coccineus, or Phaseolus longipedunculatus, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna mungo. (48) Glycine max, or Rhynchosia
minima. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/11>, or Malvaceae <1/1>. (51)
Cyperaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/11>. (53) Galvez and
Castano (1976); J. Bird (unpublished). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 72 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: aldehyde fixation essential unless PTA used at pH 4. (60) Method:
Goodman et al. (1977); Goodman and Bird (1978). (61) Virions geminate. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 18-20 nm in diameter. (65) Virions
<dimers> 30 nm in length. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 69 S. (79) Density 1.717
g cm3 in CsCl <without aldehyde fixation>. (81) Density 1.31 in Cs2SO4. (82)

Bean leaf roll luteovirus

      (1) J.W. Ashby, 1981. Revised 1989 by R.R. Martin and for chickpea stunt
strain by Y.L. Nene, 1981 and revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: alfalfa Michigan
luteovirus (Thottappilly et al. 1977), legume yellows virus, pea leaf roll
virus, pea tip yellowing virus, pea top yellows virus. (3) Standard acronym:
BLRV. (4) Strains: chickpea stunt virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.007.
(8) First reported in Pisum sativum and Vicia faba. (9) From Germany. (10) By
Quantz and Volk (1954). (11) Symptoms persist, or disappear soon after
infection. (13) Medicago sativa usually symptomless. Pisum sativum chlorotic,
leaves rolled downward. Trifolium repens yellowed, rolled leaves. Vicia faba
chlorotic leaves and flowers abscissed. Phaseolus vulgaris, Cicer arietinum,
Vigna unguiculata, Lens culinaris leaves yellowed. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
pisum, Myzus persicae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Megoura viciae, Aphis
craccivora (chickpea stunt strain). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (29) Virus can help the
vector transmission of another virus <bean yellow vein banding umbravirus>.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted
by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (39) Spreads in Ethiopia, Germany, Iran, Lebanon, Pakistan, Sudan,
Syria, Tunisia, Turkey, the UK, and the USA <California, the Midwest and
Northwest>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorosis, leaf rolling. (43) Medicago hispida systemic
chlorosis. Pisum sativum cv. Onyx tip leaves chlorotic, leaves rolled (cv.
Kelvedon Wonder is insusceptible). Trifolium subterraneum red leaf margins.
Vicia faba interveinal chlorosis, leaves rolled upward. (44) Beta vulgaris,
Capsella bursa-pastoris, Lactuca sativa, Pisum sativum cv. Kelvedon Wonder.
(45) Pisum sativum cvs Galaxy, Onyx, Eurofin, Vicia faba, Medicago sativa.
(46) Pisum sativum cv. Onyx (W), Trifolium subterraneum cv. Bacchus Marsh (W).
(47) Arachis hypogaea, or Astragalus sinicus, or Cicer arietinum, or Glycine
max, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus cosentinii, or
Medicago hispida, or Medicago sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum,
or Trifolium dubium, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia
faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. napus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens culinaris,
or Linum usitatissimum, or Lotus corniculatus, or Lupinus albus, or Melilotus
albus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum <cv. Kelvedon Wonder>, or
Senecio vulgaris, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium pratense, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <20/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <3/3>, or
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/24>, or Linaceae <1/1>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Cockbain and Gibbs (1973), Johnstone et al.,
(1984). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Takanami and Kubo
(1979); Ashby and Huttinga (1979). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (81) Density 1.32 in Cs2SO4. (84) Virions
contain 37.8 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 6 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by R.R. Martin;
use hot phenol. (110) Poly A region absent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12041. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): X53865 Em(40)_vi:LUBLRVCP
Gb(84)_vi:LUBLRVCP Bean leaf roll virus gene for coat protein. 9/93 591bp.
U15978 Em(43)_vi:Bl15978 Gb(89)_vi:Blu15978 Bean leaf roll virus coat protein
mRNA, complete cds. 11/94 591bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000
<type strain>, or 30000-35000 <chickpea stunt strain>. (171) Virions found in
phloem parenchyma mainly in necrotic sieve-tube cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular
changes: necrosis and collapse of phloem. (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: soybean dwarf, beet western yellows,
potato leafroll, carrot red leaf and barley yellow dwarf (RPV) viruses. (183)
The chickpea stunt strain of the virus (Kaiser and Danesh, 1966) has been
recorded in the same geographical areas as the type strain. Hosts recorded for
the chickpea stunt strain but not for the type strain are: Chenopodium
amaranticolor (I); Cucumis sativus (I); Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (I); Datura
stramonium (I); Nicotiana glutinosa (I); Nicotiana tabacum (I); Phaseolus
lunatus (S); Vicia villosa (S); Vigna radiata (I) (Anon., 1978/79). (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: ELISA tests with MAbs very effective. (187) Anon.

Bean mild mosaic carmovirus

      (1) H. Waterworth, 1981. Revised by A.V. Karasev, 1991. (3) Standard
acronym: BMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.0.003. (8) First reported in
Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Waterworth et al. (1977). (13)
Phaseolus vulgaris mild chlorotic vein banding and mosaic. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Epilachna
varivestis, Diabrotica undecimpunctata howardi, D. balteata, Ceratoma
ruficornis, Gynandrobrotica variabilis. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the South and
Central American region. (39) Spreads in Colombia and El Salvador. (41)

show chlorosis, mosaic. (43) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Lablab purpureus,
Phaseolus vulgaris cvs 27R, Top Crop mild systemic chlorotic mosaic. (44)

Bean pod mottle comovirus

      (1) J.P. Fulton, 1981. Revised 1985. (2) Synonyms: pod mottle virus. (3)
Standard acronym: BPMV. (4) Strains: desmodium virus (Lee and Walters, 1970).
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. Tendergreen. (9) From Charleston, U.S.A. (10) By Zaumeyer and Thomas
(1948). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris severe mottling,
malformed leaves and pods. Glycine max mottling and streaking of seed coats.
Desmodium paniculatum mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Ceratoma trifurcata, Diabrotica balteata, D.
undecimpunctata howardii, Colaspis flavida, C. lata, Epicauta vittata,
Epilachna varivestis. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in the
North American region. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show mottling, malformation. (43) Glycine max severe
mottling and malformation of leaves, pods and seed coats. Phaseolus vulgaris
cvs Black Valentine, Bountiful, Tendergreen, Cherokee Wax severe leaf
mottling, malformation. Mucuna deeringianum, Trifolium incarnatum, Lespedeza
striata mottling. (45) Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Black Valentine,
Cherokee Wax, Bountiful. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Pinto, Kentucky Wonder,
Tendergreen (L). (47) Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Desmodium paniculatum, or Glycine max, or Lens
culinaris, or Lespedeza stipulacea, or Lespedeza striata, or Mucuna
deeringianum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum,
or Sesbania exaltata, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa,
or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/22>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <12/22>, or
Solanaceae <6/6>. (53) Skotland (1958); Thornberry (1966); Hampton et al.
(1978). (54) TIP: 70-75 °C. (55) LIV: 62-93 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Bancroft (1962). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 112 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 91
S <M>, or 54 S <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.8 <slow>, or 5.3 <fast>. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.77 <B>, or 1.7 <M>. (84) Virions contain 37 % nucleic acid

lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 12.8 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 8 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.8 kb. (100) Base
composition 19.1 % G. (101) Base composition 33.4 % A. (102) Base composition
16.7 % C. (103) Base composition 30.8 % U. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12260. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): M62738 Em(40)_vi:COMBPMCO
Gb(84)_vi:BPMCOAT Bean pod mottle virus coat protein gene, complete cds,
complete middle component (M) RNA. 4/9 1 sequence. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and unusual in shape. (176) Masses of
clustered membranous vesicles and bundles of filamentous structures. (177)
They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: prominent cell wall
protrusions containing virions embedded in tubules. (179) Comovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related

Bean rugose mosaic comovirus

      (1) P.W.G. Chu, 1985. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: virus del mosaico
rugoso de frijol, virus ampollado del frijol, bean mosaico-em-desenho. (3)
Standard acronym: BRMV. (4) Strains: three strains that differ biologically
but are serologically close. 1. Type strain (from Costa Rica and Guatemala).
2. Ampollado strain (VAF) severe strain. 3. BMDV strain. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From Costa Rica.
(10) By Gamez (1971; 1972). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris
severe mosaic, mottling, malformation of leaves and pods (type strain); or
severe stunting and blistering of leaves (Ampollado strain); or symmetric
mosaic patterns on leaves (BMDV strain). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Ceratoma ruficornis, Diabrotica
balteata, D. adelpha. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus
not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed <in Phaseolus vulgaris>.
(36) Studies reported by Gamez (1972, 1982); Fulton and Scott (1977); Fulton
et al. (1981); Cupertino et al. (1982); Gamez and Moreno (1983). (39) Spreads
in Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Panama. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
severe systemic mosaics and malformation. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor
necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Plentiful severe
mosaic, rugosity, mottling and malformation of leaves and pods. Some cultivars
develop necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Vicia faba mild mottle. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Kentucky Wonder, Potomac and
Tendergreen, Vigna unguiculata cv. Early Ramshorn and Nicotiana tabacum cv.
White Burley. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Plentiful, Col. 109-R, Mex. 27-R.
(46) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs TCAPijao, Top Crop, Pinto III, Jamapa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cvs Plentiful, Col. 109-R,
Mex. 27-R, TCA-Pijao, Top Crop, Pinto III, Jamapa>, or Vicia faba. (48)
Chenopodium album, or Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cvs Kentucky Wonder, Potomac, Tendergreen>, or
Physalis floridana, or Raphanus sativus, or Vigna unguiculata <cv. Early
Ramshorn>, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/3>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae
<1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (52) Host differences
alone do not distinguish this virus from closely related comoviruses such as
bean pod mottle and cowpea mosaic viruses. (53) Gamez (1972, 1982). (54) TIP:
65-75 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (57) Infectivity of
sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Bancroft (1962); Gamez (1982); Van Kammen and de Jager
(1978). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25-30
nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations, or three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 113 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 97 S <M>, or 59 S <T>. (79) Density 1.45 g cm3 in
CsCl <B>, or 1.414 g cm3 in CsCl <M2>, or 1.401 g cm3 in CsCl <M1>, or 1.293 g
cm3 in CsCl <T>. (84) Virions contain 36 % nucleic acid <B>, or 29 % nucleic
acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 64 % protein <B>, or 71 %
protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (87) Also coat
proteins contain polysaccharides. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.25 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.75 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 4.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Ramirez et al.
(1987). (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a VPg. (110) Poly A region present. (111)
Poly A region presumably on the 3' end. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not
found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest>
41000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 23000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 21000. (145)
Method of preparation: Acosta et al. (1986); Ramirez et al. (1987). (148)
Virion proteins glycosylated. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and trichomal cells. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (173) Virions found in and in
the plasmodesmata. Virions tend to aggregate in areas rich in membranous
vesicles and tubules and are sometimes surrounded by membranes. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm and unusual in shape. (176) And sometimes in dense amorphous
material. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: collapsed
cells with densely staining vacuoles, cytoplasm very vesiculated. (179)
Comovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: bean pod mottle, cowpea severe mosaic, and
cowpea mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
quail pea mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: host range does not
distinguish the virus from bean pod mottle and cowpea mosaic viruses,
serological tests are also required; Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Tendergreen and
Vigna unguiculata cv. Early Ramshorn insusceptible to the virus but not to
bean pod mottle and cowpea mosaic comovirus. (187) Acosta, O., Alegria, A. and
Lastra, R. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 1182. Bancroft, J.B. (1962). Virology
16: 419. Cupertino, F.P., Costa, A.S., Lin, M.T. and Kitajima, E.W. (1982).
Fitopatol. Bras. 7: 269. Fulton, J.P. and Scott, H.A. (1977). Fitopatol. Bras.
2: 9. Fulton, J.P. and Scott, H.A. (1979). Phytopathology 69: 305. Fulton,
J.P., Scott, H.A. and Gamez, R. (1981). In: Vectors of Plant Pathogens. pp.
115-132; eds K. Maramarosch and K.F. Harrison. Academic Press, New York.

Bean southern mosaic sobemovirus

      (1) O.P. Sehgal, 1980. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: southern bean mosaic
virus, southern bean mosaic virus 1. (3) Standard acronym: SBMV. (4) Strains:
cowpea strain (strain C), Ghana strain (strain G), severe bean mosaic strain
or Mexican strain (strain M) (Tremaine and Hamilton 1983), type strain (strain
B). (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Phaseolus
vulgaris. (9) From samples from Louisiana and California, U.S.A. (10) By
Zaumeyer and Harter (1943). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris,
Vigna unguiculata, V. mungo and Glycine max mosaic and/or mottle, and stunting
(especially in Vigna unguiculata). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Chrysomelidae: Ceratoma
trifurcata, Epilachna variestis. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <3-7% in V. unguiculata cv. Early Wilt Resistant Ramshorn>. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the seed and transmitted by pollen to the pollinated
plant. (38) Spreads in the African region, the North American region, and the
South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in France. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Glycine max systemic vein clearing and mild
mottling. Phaseolus lunatus necrotic local lesions; no systemic infection.
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto local lesions systemic mottling, leaf curling,
stunting. Vigna unguiculata chlorotic spots, systemic vein clearing and
banding, leaf deformation, stunting; cv. Clay is a local lesion host of the
cowpea strain. Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis local lesions followed by
systemic chlorosis and vein clearing. (44) Cassia tora, Cicer arietinum,
Lupinus albus, Melilotus albus. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful (bean
strain), Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye (cowpea strain). (46) Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Pinto (bean strain) (L), Vigna unguiculata cv. Clay (cowpea
strain) (L). (47) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica campestris, or
Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium album,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens culinaris, or
Lotus corniculatus, or Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or
Sesbania exaltata, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata,
or Zinnia elegans. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <17/24>, or Solanaceae <6/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1
/1>. (53) Zaumeyer and Harter (1943); Shepherd and Fulton (1962); Lamptey et
al. (1974). (54) TIP: 90-95 °C. (55) LIV: 20-165 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58)
Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Hull (1977); Sehgal and Hsu
(1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified

terminus of RNA has a VPg. (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor required for
infectivity. (113) Additional factor a genome-linked protein. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Wu et al. (1987) for the cowpea strain. (117) NCBI Taxon
ID: 12139. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): J02355 Em(40)_vi:SOB3

300,000-400,000 d>. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger>
30000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 12000. (145) Method of preparation: Hsu et al.

Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Crystalline aggregates in cowpea strain. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Sobemovirus <the type species>. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: none. (183) Bean (type) strain infects most Phaseolus
vulgaris cultivars systemically (but local lesions only in cv. Pinto), but it
does not infect cowpea. Only the bean strain infects Phaseolus lunatus. The
cowpea strain strain infects most cowpea cultivars systemically but not
Phaseolus vulgaris except cv. Pinto, in which it is symptomless. The Ghana
strain infects many cowpea cultivars and induces local or systemic symptomless
infection in some cultivars of Phaseolus vulgaris, but small necrotic spots in
Vigna radiata. The severe bean mosaic strain or Mexican strain induces more
severe symptoms in Phaseolus vulgaris than the bean strain, and also infects
cowpea (Tremaine and Hamilton 1983). (187) Abad-Zapatero, C., Abad-Meguid,
S.S., Johnon, J.E., Leslie, A.G.W., Rayment, I., Rossmann, M.G., Suck, D. and
