Bean yellow mosaic potyvirus

      (1) O.W. Barnett and Xu Zeyong, 1982. Revised 1987 by O.W. Barnett; data
on Croatian clover strain collated by N. Taraku, 1983. (2) Synonyms: bean
virus 2, canna mosaic virus (Brierley and Smith, 1948), gladiolus mosaic
virus, gloriosa stripe mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: BYMV. (4) Strains:
Croatian clover potyvirus, Croatian clover mosaic virus (Taraku et al. 1977),
dipladenia mosaic virus (Paludan et al., 1988), pea mosaic 1 virus, pea 2
virus, pisum 2 virus, pea common mosaic virus. There are many other strains,
Scott's isolate, B-25 and isolates from Gladiolus spp. are considered typical
isolates, pea mosaic virus (PMV) 204 and other isolates from clovers are more
distant. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Phaseolus
vulgaris. (9) From the U.S.A. and the Netherlands. (10) By Doolittle and Jones
(1925). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Phaseolus vulgaris and Pisum
sativum tip necrosis, mosaic (strains B25 and Scott). Gladiolus sp., Freesia
sp., Lupinus luteus, Robinia pseudoacacia, Trigonella foenum-graecum, Vicia
sativa, Papaver somniferum streaks, mosaics, mottling and leaf malformation.
Arachis hypogaea leaf mottling. Crotalaria spectabilis, Glycine max, Canna
spp., Trifolium subterraneum, Eustoma russellianum, Vicia faba, Medicago
sativa, Trifolium hybridum, T. vesiculosum, T. incarnatum, T. pratense, T.
repens mosaics. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by more than 20 spp. including Acyrthosiphon pisum,
Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus persicae, Aphis fabae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <to 3%>. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaic. (43) B-25 or Scott strains.
Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions with red border; some systemic
chlorotic vein banding and spots. Phaseolus vulgaris necrotic or chlorotic
local lesions; systemic mosaic. Pisum sativum Perfection types not infected;
systemic mosaic in others. Vicia faba mild systemic mosaic. (44) Cucumis
sativus (I), Trifolium repens (I) Scott strain. (45) Pisum sativum, Vicia
faba, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Cajanus cajan, or Canna, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Crotalaria
retusa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Eustoma russellianum, or Freesia, or Gladiolus, or Glycine
max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus
albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lupinus luteus, or Macrotyloma uniflorum,
or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Papaver somniferum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or
Phytolacca americana, or Pisum sativum, or Robinia pseudoacacia, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens,
or Trifolium subterraneum, or Trifolium vesiculosum, or Trigonella
foenum-graecum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna
angularis, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Beta macrocarpa, or Cassia tora, or Cheiranthus
cheiri, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Phlox
drummondii, or Trifolium repens <Scott strain>, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Amaranthaceae <2/3>, or Cannaceae <1/1>, or

: Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: clover

infects Nicotiana megalosiphon and Chenopodium murale, and is serologically
distinct from type strains. (184) With random primed cDNA and S1 nuclease,
several bean yellow mosaic potyvirus strains show close homology, but no
hybridization was detected between bean yellow mosaic strains and clover
yellow vein, bean yellow mosaic (PMV) 204-1 or sweet pea mosaic viruses
(Barnett et al., 1987). (187) Barnett, O.W., Randles, J.W. and Burrows, P.M.
(1987). Phytopathology 77: 791. Bays, D.C. and Demski, J.W. (1986). Plant Dis.

Bean yellow vein banding umbravirus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. From Cockbain 1983. (2) Synonyms: possibly pea
silky green virus (Cockbain et al., 1986). (3) Standard acronym: BYVBV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 78.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From
southern England. (10) By Cockbain (1978). (13) Vicia faba yellow
vein-banding, mottling; symptoms enhanced when co-infecting with pea enation
mosaic enamovirus. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis fabae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (29) Virus requires, for vector
transmission, a helper virus <pea enation mosaic enamovirus in the field; or
bean leaf roll luteovirus in glasshouse tests>. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the UK. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local chlorotic or
necrotic lesions; no symptoms. Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, Pisum
sativum, Trifolium incarnatum, Vicia faba, V. sativa no local symptoms;
systemic mottling. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 50-90 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (179) Umbravirus. (187) Cockbain, A.J. (1978). Rep.
Rothamsted Exp. Stn. for 1977, p. 221. Cockbain, A.J. (1983). The Faba Bean
(Vicia faba): A Basis for Improvement; ed. P.D. Hebblethwaite. Butterworths,
Sevenoaks, U.K. Cockbain, A.J. Jones, P. Woods, R.D. (1986). Ann. appl. Biol.
108: 59.


Beet 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) R.F. White, 1986. (2) Synonyms: beet temperate virus. (3) Standard
acronym: BCV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.003. (8) First reported in Beta
vulgaris. (9) From the U.K. (11) Symptoms none. (13) Beta vulgaris no
symptoms. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted
by seed <up to 100% in sugar beet>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the
seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Australian, the Eurasian region, Japan and the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (45) Beta vulgaris. (46) None. (47) Beta vulgaris. (48)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum,
or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or

glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/7>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Kassanis et al. (1977); Accotto and Boccardo (1986). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile, or angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) <Usually> one sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 120 S. (79) Density 1.36-1.38 g
cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 3.48 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part <the larger> 2.06 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 1.42
kb <pairs>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 52500-54500. (145) Method of
preparation: Accotto and Boccardo (1986). (171) Virions found in all parts of
the host plant. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) :
Partitiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: alfalfa
1, beet 2, carnation 1, carrot 1, fescue, garland chrysanthemum temperate, hop
trefoil 1, radish yellow edge, red clover 1, rhubarb temperate, ryegrass,
spinach temperate, vicia and white clover 1 and 3 alphacryptoviruses. (184)
The genomic dsRNAs have no significant sequence homology with those of beet 2
alphacryptovirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: cDNA probes can be used to
detect the virus in beet plants. (187) Antoniw, J.F., Linthorst, H.J.M.,

Beet curly top hybrigeminivirus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. (2) Synonyms: sugarbeet curly top virus, sugarbeet
curly-leaf virus, tomato yellows virus, western yellow blight virus. (3)
Standard acronym: BCTV. (4) Strains: tomato yellows virus. Many stable strains
described (Thomas and Mink, 1979). (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.2.0.001. (8)
First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From Western U.S.A. (10) By Ball (1909).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Spinacia oleracea, Cucurbitaceae, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Linum spp., Capsicum spp., Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum
tuberosum, and many other species vein-clearing, swelling and malformation in
young leaves; rigid, dwarfed, yellowed, twisted and malformed leaves; axillary
buds stimulated, phloem necrosis, exudation of fluid from phloem; death of
plant. Some hosts symptomless. Beta vulgaris leaf rolling, vein clearing,
leaves become dark, dull green in colour, thick crisp and brittle. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Circulifer tenellus in N. America, C. tenellus, C. opacipennis in
Mediterranean Basin. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does
not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the
progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation
<unless special procedures used>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting <by
dodder from plants that are not hosts of the vector>. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the African region, the Eurasian region,
the Mediterranean region, the North American region, and the South and Central
American region <in the arid and semi-arid regions of the west>. (39) Spreads
in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Costa Rica, Cyprus, Egypt, India, Iran,
Italy, Mexico, Puerto Rico, Spain, Turkey, the USA, and Uruguay. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (43) Beta vulgaris vein-clearing and upward and
inward rolling of leaves. Vein swelling and galling to give rough abaxial leaf
surface. Phloem exudate on petioles and large leaf veins, phloem necrosis in
roots. Cucumis sativus seedlings killed. Older plants stunted and malformed,
leaves rolled upward. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful first trifoliate leaf
epinastic. Buds of survivors proliferate, leaflets brittle, curled and
crinkled. (45) Beta vulgaris for maintenance cultures. Phaseolus vulgaris cvs
Romano, Bountiful, and Nicotiana tabacum cv. Turkish for propagation. (46) No
local-lesion host. Beta vulgaris (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium graveolens, or
Atriplex hortensis, or Bellis perennis, or Beta macrocarpa, or Beta
patellaris, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Calendula
officinalis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Cicer arietinum, or Citrullus
lanatus, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cucurbitaceae, or Dianthus barbatus,
or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Euphorbia marginata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Ipomoea setosa, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Linum usitatissimum, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Matthiola incana, or Medicago hispida, or Medicago sativa, or
Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Papaver
nudicaule, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii,
or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Phytolacca americana, or
Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Ricinus communis, or Salvia splendens,
or Senecio vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or
Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or
Vicia villosa, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna unguiculata, or Viola cornuta, or
Zinnia elegans. (48) Celosia argentea, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Sonchus oleraceus. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Apocynaceae
<1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <3/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <9/9>, or Compositae <5/6>,
or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or
Euphorbiaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1 /1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<16/17>, or Linaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or
Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <17/19>, or Tropaeolaceae < 1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>, or
Violaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or Compositae <1/6>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/17>, or Solanaceae <4/19>. (52) No
monocotyledonous species found to be susceptible. (53) Bennet (1971). (54)
TIP: 80 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Mink and Thomas (1974); Mumford (1974; 1977). (61)
Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 18-22 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations, or two sedimenting components in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 82 S <for single virions>. (78) Of the other(s)
86 S, or 55 S <Egbert et al. 1976>. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 2.8 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.8 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10840. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M24597 Gb(84)_vi:BCTCG028A

Beet distortion mosaic virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.05. (8) First
reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Liu et al. (1987). (13)
Beta vulgaris malformed and chlorotic leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by <probably> a fungus. (17) Transmitted by probably Polymyxa
betae. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA <California>. (47) Beta
vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
200-2400 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: wheat spindle streak mosaic virus. (187) Liu,
H.Y., Duffus, J.E. and Genk, J.S. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 1732.


Beet leaf curl (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) Sc.H. Kleinhempel, 1987. (2) Synonyms: beet leaf crinkle virus, beta
virus 3, Rübenkräusel-Virus, sugarbeet leafcurl rhabdovirus. (3) Standard
acronym: BLCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.002. (8) First reported in Beta
vulgaris. (9) From Germany. (10) By Wille (1928). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Beta vulgaris vein deformation, leaves curved towards the apex. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Heteroptera, Lygaeidae: Piesma quadratum. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(36) Studies reported by Proeseler (1980). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region
and the Mediterranean region. (39) Spreads in the former Czechoslovakia,
Germany, Poland, Turkey, and the former USSR. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein clearing,
leaf curling, stunting. (43) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa, Spinacia
oleracea, Tetragonia tetragonioides vein clearing, leaf curling, stunting.
(45) Beta vulgaris. (46) Beta macrocarpa (W), Atriplex patula (W), Chenopodium
murale (W), Spinacia tetranda (W). (47) Atriplex patula, or Beta macrocarpa,
or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or

Proll (1978). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped.

Beet mild yellowing luteovirus

      (1) H.G. Smith, 1991. (2) Synonyms: beet western yellows. (3) Standard
acronym: BMYV. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported in Beta
vulgaris. (9) From England. (10) By Russel (1958). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms yellowing of older leaves, which become curled, thickened and
brittle. Some reddening of older leaves of weed species. (13) Beta spp. golden
yellowing of older leaves, which become thick and brittle. Capsella
bursa-pastoris yellowing of older leaves, curling and reddening of leaves.
Stellaria media yellowing of older leaves. Lamium amplexicaule yellowing of
older leaves. Senecio vulgaris, Vernonia sp. yellowing of older leaves,
reddening of some older leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, M. (Sciamyzus) ascolonicus,
M. (Nectarosiphon) certus, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Acyrthosiphon (Aulocorthum)
solani, Myzus (Phorodon) humuli, Brachycaudus helichrysi. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Dunning et al. (1988). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show yellowing or reddening of older leaves, which also may become thickened
and brittle. Curling of leaves. Stunting. (43) Capsella bursa-pastoris and
Spinacia oleracea yellowing of older leaves, curling and thickening. Montia
perfoliata reddening of older leaves. Senecio vulgaris. (44) Brassica spp.,
Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana clevelandii, Pisum sativum, Trifolium incarnatum.
(45) Beta vulgaris, Capsella bursa-pastoris, Montia perfoliata. (46) Beta
vulgaris (W), Capsella bursa-pastoris (W), Montia perfoliata (W). (47) Beta
macrocarpa, or Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsella bursa-pastoris,
or Crambe abyssinica, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lamium

vulgaris, or Sinapis alba, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vernonia, or Viola cornuta, or Zinnia elegans.
(48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Atriplex hortensis, or

campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis,
or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Celosia argentea, or Celosia cristata,
or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium

Melandrium album, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or
Prunus persica, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum nigrum, or Sonchus oleraceus,
or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or
Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/5>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/13>, or Compositae <3/7>, or
Cruciferae <3/12>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <1 /9>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Violaceae <1/1>. (51)

(53) Peters (1988). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 16 days. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Govier (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions

virus genomic RNA. 8/95 5,722bp. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and
phloem. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Luteovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: beet western yellows virus,
closely. (184) The virus is considered by some virologists to be a synonym of
beet western yellows luteovirus. However, those working closely with the virus
consider it to be a distinct pathogen. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA
using polyclonal antiserum to distinguish it from beet yellows virus, with
which it is frequently associated in field-grown sugar beet. (187) Govier,
D.A. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 107: 439. Peters, D. (1988) In: Virus Yellows

Beet mosaic potyvirus

      (1) G.D. Heathcote and R.D. Woods, 1982. Revised by F. Nienhaus, 1987
and I. Fujisawa, 1988. Revised by H.G. Smith and A.V. Karasev, 1991. (2)
Synonyms: spinach mosaic virus, sugarbeet mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym:
BtMV. (4) Strains: dioscorea alata ring mottle virus, dioscorea alata ringspot
virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Beta
vulgaris. (9) From Braunschweig, Germany. (10) By Schneider and Mundry (1956);
Zimmer and Brandes (1956). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms flecking then
mosaic, malformation. (13) Beta maritima, Melilotus indicus, Trifolium
incarnatum vein yellowing or netting and leaf malformation. Beta vulgaris
small local lesions on tip leaves, then mottling and malformation. Spinacia
oleracea flecking, yellowing. Chenopodium album local lesions and curling of
leaves. Amaranthus retroflexus, Sonchus arvensis, Melilotus indicus vein
chlorosis, mottling. Trifolium incarnatum vein chlorosis, mottling, necrosis.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by more than 28 spp. including Myzus persicae, Aphis fabae, Rhopalosiphum
padi, Acyrthosiphon (Metopolophium) dirhodum, Macrosiphum (Sitobion) avenae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal natural vector(s): Myzus
persicae, Aphis fabae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Smith (1957). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in all major
beet growing areas (Russell 1971)>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaic, necrotic local
lesions. (43) Amaranthus caudatus, A. retroflexus, Beta patellaris necrotic
local lesions. Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium quinoa, Spinacia oleracea
chlorotic local lesions. Beta vulgaris systemic mosaic. Nicotiana bigelovii,
N. clevelandii, Phacelia campanularia, Pisum sativum, Samolus parviflorus.
Stellaria media necrotic spots; systemic mosaic. Glycine max systemic mosaic.
(45) Beta vulgaris, Spinacia oleracea, Stellaria media. (46) Amaranthus
caudatus (L), Kazakh isolate (W), A. retroflexus (L), Gomphrena globosa (L),

oleracea (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Amaranthus caudatus, or

type (Hoefert, 1969). (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular

Beet necrotic yellow vein furovirus

      (1) K.E. Richards, 1991. (2) Synonyms: possibly beet yellow vein virus.
(3) Standard acronym: BNYVV. (4) Strains: YS, CS, CR and NS. (5) ICTV decimal
code 27.0.1.T.007. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From Italy. (10)
By Canova (1966); Matsuda et al. (1965); Tamada (1975). (11) Symptoms persist.
(12) Symptoms rootlet proliferation, necrosis, stunting or death. (13) Beta
vulgaris rootlet proliferation from main tap root; necrosis of vascular
bundle; rootlet necrosis; stunting or death of infected plant. Occasional
bright yellow invasive chlorotic local lesions form on veins in the head. Beta
macrocarpa, Spinacia oleracea. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa betae. (21) Transmitted by
Plasmodiophorales. (24) Not transmitted by Polymyxa graminis, Myzus persicae,
Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide <where there are major sugarbeet industries>. (38)
Spreads in the Eastern Asian region, the Eurasian region, the Mediterranean
region, and the North American region. (39) Spreads in Austria, or Belgium, or
Bulgaria, or China, or the former Czechoslovakia, or France, or Germany, or
Greece, or Hungary, or Italy, or Japan, or Mongolia, or the Netherlands, or
Poland, or Romania, or St. Vincent and Grenadines, or Switzerland, or Turkey,
or the UK, or the USA, or the former USSR, or the former Yugoslavia. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local
lesions. (43) Beta vulgaris rootlet proliferation from main tap root; necrosis
of vascular bundle; rootlet necrosis; stunting or death of infected plant.
Occasional bright yellow invasive chlorotic local lesions form in veins.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic
local lesions. Beta macrocarpa, Spinacia oleracea chlorotic local lesions,
chlorotic mottle, yellow mosaic and flecks; systemic infection. Plants become
stunted and die prematurely. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L).
(47) Beta macrocarpa, or Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Astragalus sinicus, or Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or
Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Capsicum annuum, or Celosia cristata, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum
sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Secale cereale, or Senecio vulgaris, or
Sesamum indicum, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens,
or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <2/3>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <6/6>, or
Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<16/16>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <14
/14>. (53) Tamada and Baba (1973). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 5-8 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Putz and Kuszala (1978). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)
Virions of 70, 100, 265, and 390 nm. (71) Virions 20 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.6 nm. (76) Four
sedimenting components in purified preparations, or five sedimenting
components in purified preparations <in some Japanese isolates>. (84) Virions
contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 13.5 kb. (92)

vein mosaic virus (RG1)genomic RNA for transport proteins. 6/94 1,922bp.

Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Furovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: peanut clump,
potato mop-top and soil-borne wheat mosaic viruses. (183) RNA 3 and 4
components from different strains produce different symptom phenotypes: YS
(yellow spot) RNA 1+2+3+4. CS (chlorotic spot) and CR (chlorotic ring): RNA
1+2+4. NS (necrotic spot) RNA 1+2+deleted RNAs. (184) P42, P13 and P15 are
homologous to genes in carlaviruses, potexviruses and barley stripe mosaic
hordeivirus. (187) Brunt, A.A. and Richards, K.E. (1989). Adv. Virus Res. 36:

Beet pseudo-yellows (?) closterovirus

      (1) G.R. Johnstone, 1987. (2) Synonyms: cucumber yellows virus
(Yamashita et al., 1979), muskmelon yellows virus (Liu and Duffus, 1990; Lot
et al., 1982). (3) Standard acronym: BPYV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.T.3.01. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From Salinas,
California, U.S.A. (10) By Duffus (1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Beta
vulgaris, Lactuca sativa, Cichorium endiva yellowing, thickening, brittleness
of leaves. Capsella bursa-pastoris, Cucumis sativus yellowing, thickening,
brittleness and down-curling of leaf margins. Taraxacum officinale interveinal
reddening and chlorosis. Conium maculatum symptoms not described. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Trialeurodes vaporariorum. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted
in a semipersistent manner. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28)
Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Australia <Tasmania>, or France, or Japan, or the Netherlands, or the USA
<California>. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show yellowing, reddening, curling. (43) Beta vulgaris,
Capsella bursa-pastoris, Lactuca sativa yellowing, thickening, brittleness of
leaves. Taraxacum officinale, Chenopodium capitatum interveinal reddening and
chlorosis. Linum usitatissimum, Nicotiana glutinosa, Cucumis melo interveinal
yellowing. (44) Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum, Physalis
floridana, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (46) Capsella bursa-pastoris (W),
Lactuca sativa (W), Taraxacum officinale (W). (47) Aquilegia, or Beta
macrocarpa, or Beta vulgaris, or Callistephus chinensis, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Cichorium endiva, or Conium
maculatum, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or
Daucus carota, or Erodium cicutarium, or Geranium dissectum, or Lactuca
sativa, or Linum grandiflorum, or Linum usitatissimum, or Malva parviflora, or
Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis ixocarpa, or Physalis wrightii, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Solanum dulcamara, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Taraxacum officinale, or Urtica californica, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Abelmoschus esculentus, or Althaea rosea, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or
Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea purpurea, or Ipomoea tricolor, or Lavatera
assurgentiflora, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Malva sylvestris, or Medicago
sativa, or Nicandra physalodes, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana,
or Raphanus sativus, or Sisymbrium irio, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Thlaspi arvense. (50) Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Compositae <7/8>, or Cruciferae
<1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/5>, or Geraniaceae <2/2>, or Linaceae <2/2>, or
Malvaceae <1/6>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Ranunculaceae <1 /1>, or
Solanaceae <6/10>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>, or Urticaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae
<1/8>, or Convolvulaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <3/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/5>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <5/6>, or Solanaceae <4/10>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Duffus (1965). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 43259. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus.
(184) Beet pseudo-yellows virus seems similar to cucumber yellows virus, from
Japan and also transmitted by Trialeurodes vaporariorum, but has a host range
restricted to cucurbits and has flexuous virions of c. 1000 nm long (Yamashita
et al., 1979). (187) Duffus, J.E. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 450. Duffus, J.E.
(1973). Adv. Virus Res. 18: 347. Duffus, J.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1981).
Aust. Pl. Path. 10: 68. Lot, H., Delecolle, B. and Lecoq, H. (1982). Acta
Hort. 127: 175. Lot, H., Onillon, J.C. and Lecoq, H. (1980). Revue hort. 209:
31. Liu, H.Y. and Duffus, J.E. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 866. Van Dorst,
H.J.M., Huijberts, N. and Bos, L. (1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 311.
Yamashita, S., Doi, Y., Yora, K. and Yoshino, M. (1979). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 45: 484.


Beet soil-borne furovirus

      (1) C. Henry, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Norfolk virus, Barney Patch virus. (3)
Standard acronym: BSBV. (4) Strains: similar viruses have been found in
Germany and the U.S.A., but it is uncertain if they are strains. (5) ICTV
decimal code 27.0.1.T.008. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From
Barney, Norfolk, England. (10) By Ivanovic and Macfarlane (1982). (13) Beta
vulgaris. (14) Transmitted by <probably> a vector. (16) Transmitted by
<probably> a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa betae. (21) Transmitted by
Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus <may be> transmitted by contact between plants <but not easily>. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Sweden, Germany, Belgium and
England. Possibly found in the U.S.A. but not yet confirmed. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local
lesions and necrotic ringspots. (43) Beta vulgaris cv. Monoire chlorotic
rings. Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor chlorotic or necrotic ringspots.
Spinacia oleracea chlorotic spots sometimes. (44) Cucumis sativus, Avena
sativa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L). (47) Beta macrocarpa, or Beta
vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus
sativus, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <10/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <8 /8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53)
Henry et al. (1986). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
2-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 65, 150, and 300 nm. (71) Virions 19 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal <c.> 4.5 nm in diameter. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 46436. (125) 3 virus specified dsRNA species found in infected
cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 4.1 kbp. (127) 2nd largest
1.95 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 1.68 kbp. (171) Virions found in roots. (179)
Furovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet necrotic
yellow vein, potato mop-top, wheat soil-borne mosaic and hypochoeris mosaic
viruses. (184) Does not appear to have sequence homology with beet necrotic
yellow vein or potato mop-top viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
rod-shaped; few virions in sap; does not infect tobaccos or legumes; host
range is restricted to Chenopodiaceae; does not cross-react with antisera to
beet necrotic yellow vein virus. (187) Henry, C. and Hutchinson (1989).
Aspects Appl. Biol. 22: 109. Henry, C., Jones, R.A.C. and Coutts, R.H.A.
(1986). Pl. Path. 38: 585. Ivanovic, M. and Macfarlane, I. (1982). Ann. Rep.
Rothamsted Exp. Stn 1982 p. 190. Ivanovic, M., Macfarlane, I. and Wood (1983).
Ann. rep. for Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1983 p. 189. Lesemann, D.-E., Koenig, R.,
Lindsten, K. and Henry, C. (1989). EPPO Bulletin 19: 539. Verhoyen, M., van
den Bossche, M. and van Steyvoort, L. (1987). Revue Agric., Brux. 40: 1463.


Beet western yellows luteovirus

      (1) J.E. Duffus and G.R. Johnstone, 1983. (2) Synonyms: beet mild
yellowing virus (Russell, 1958), malva yellows virus (Costa et al., 1959), pea
leaf roll virus New Zealand, radish yellows virus (Duffus, 1960; 1961), turnip
mild yellows virus. (3) Standard acronym: BWYV. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris, Lactuca sativa, Spinacia
oleracea, Raphanus sativus. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Duffus (1960;
1961). (11) Symptoms persist, or vary seasonally. (13) More than 150 species
in 23 dicotyledonous families susceptible including such economically
important species as: Beta vulgaris (sugar and table beet), Spinacia oleracea,
Helianthus annuus, Lactuca sativa, Brassica napus var. napobrassica, B.
campestris ssp. napus, B. campestris ssp. rapa, B. nigra, B. oleracea var.
botrytis, Brassica oleracea var. capitata, Raphanus sativus, Crambe
abyssinica, Citrullus lanatus, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo, Cicer
arietinum, Glycine max, Pisum sativum, Trifolium subterraneum, Vicia faba,
Phlox drummondii, Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum mild chlorotic
spotting, yellowing, thickening and brittleness of older leaves. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani,
Brachycaudus helichrysi, Brevicoryne brassicae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus
(Sciamyzus) ascalonicus, M. ornatus, M. persicae, Myzus (Phorodon) humuli.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal natural vector(s): Myzus
persicae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus does not
require a helper virus for vector transmission and can help the vector
transmission of another virus <lettuce speckles mottle umbravirus>. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellowing, reddening, stunting.
(43) Gomphrena globosa, Crambe abyssinica, Trifolium subterraneum, Montia
perfoliata systemic leaf reddening. Lactuca sativa, Capsella bursa-pastoris,
Pisum sativum systemic leaf yellowing. Arachis hypogaea, Glycine max cv.
Shirotsuronoko, Lens culinaris stunting. Senecio vulgaris, Spinacia oleracea.
(44) Chenopodium capitatum, Lactuca sativa, Medicago sativa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Trifolium hybridum, T.
incarnatum. (45) Beta vulgaris, Capsella bursa-pastoris, Crambe abyssinica,
Montia perfoliata, Raphanus sativus, Physalis floridana. (46) Beta vulgaris
(W), Senecio vulgaris (W), Capsella bursa-pastoris (W), Crambe abyssinica (W),
Montia perfoliata (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Amaranthus retroflexus,
or Arachis hypogaea, or Arctotheca calendula, or Arundo donax, or Beta
macrocarpa, or Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp.
napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica napus var. napobrassica, or Brassica
nigra, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata,
or Calandrinia caulescens, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum annuum, or
Celosia argentea, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Cicer
arietinum, or Citrullus lanatus, or Clarkia pulchella, or Coronopus didymus,
or Crambe abyssinica, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Erodium moschatum, or Euphorbia peplus, or Gazania rigens, or Glycine
max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lactuca
serriola, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or
Lupinus cosentinii, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Malva parviflora, or
Matthiola incana, or Medicago hispida, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Papaver
rhoeas, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phlox drummondii, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Sinapis alba, or Sinapis arvensis, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Sonchus asper, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense,
or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia
faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vigna unguiculata, or Viola cornuta, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Brassica

<3/5>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/13>, or Compositae
<9/12>, or Cruciferae <16/19>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/6>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>,
or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1 /1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<16/21>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Onagraceae <1/1>, or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or

mild yellowing viruses are closely related; soybean dwarf, subterranean clover
red leaf, potato leafroll are more distantly related and bean leaf roll virus
is very distantly related. Beet mild yellowing virus is so close that some

Beet western yellows ST9-associated RNA virus

      (1) M.J. Gibbs (1995). (5) ICTV decimal code 64.0.5.2.T.10. (8) First
reported in Brassica oleracea var. botrytis (broccoli). (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Falk and Duffus (1984). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner <probably>. (29) Virus
requires, for vector transmission, a helper virus <beet western yellows
luteovirus>. (30) The virus genome is probably transcapsidated in the virions
of the helper virus (Falk and Duffus, 1984). (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation <when transcripts from a DNA encoding the genome of the
virus were inoculated to young plants of shepherd's purse (Capsella
bursa-pastoris>. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in California,
U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show stunting, yellowing and twisting. (43) Capsella bursa-pastoris
lethal yellowing and necrosis, but causes milder yellowing, twisting and
stunting when with beet western yellows luteovirus. (44) Cichorium endiva, C.
intybus, Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana clevelandii and Solanum nigrum. (45)
Capsella bursa-pastoris. (46) Capsella bursa-pastoris (W). (47) Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Raphanus sativus. (48)
Cichorium endiva, or Cichorium intybus, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Solanum nigrum. (50) Cruciferae <3/3>. (51) Compositae <3/3>,
or Solanaceae <2/2>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 2.843 kb <Chin et al., 1993>. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.843 kb. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent <Passmore et al., 1993>.
(110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor not required for
infectivity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Chin et al., 1993. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 12590. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L04281. (119)
Features of the genome: Four ORFs. Only ORF3 encodes a protein with
recognizable function, the polymerase. ORF2 may be translated after tRNA
suppression of the amber stop codon of ORF1, but sequence analysis suggests
that the reported sequence may be in error and that ORFs 2 and 3 may be a
single ORF (Gibbs, 1995). ORF4 is probably translated from a subgenomic RNA.
(123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (124) C. 400 bp long and
co-terminal with the 3' end. (125) 2 virus specified dsRNA species found in
infected cells <one from the helper virus and of c. 2.9 kb pairs>. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (167) ST9 a-virus does not
produce its own virion proteins or virions, however plants co-infected with it
and its helper produce 10 times more virions than the helper does alone
(Sanger et al., 1994). (179) (Ungrouped). (184) This virus is not sufficiently
similar to viruses in any of the currently recognized groups to be comfortably
placed with them. Its polymerase protein shows affinities with those of the
carmoviruses, dianthoviruses, type 1 and 2 luteoviruses, machlomoviruses,
necroviruses, tombusviruses, umbraviruses and pea enation mosaic virus RNA-2.
(186) This organism has features of a satellite RNA, but can replicate
independently, and therefore is included as a virus. (187) Chin, L.-S.,
Forster, J.L., Falk, B.W. and Bruening, G. (1993). Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA
90: 10168. Falk, B.W. and Duffus, J.E. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1224. Gibbs,
M.J. (1995). D. Phil. thesis, Oxford University. Sanger, M. Passmore, B.,
Falk, B.W., Bruening, G., Ding, B. and Lucas, W.J. (1994). Virology 200: 48.


Beet yellow net (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BYNV. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.T.001. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From Belgium; U.S.A.
(10) By Roland (1948); and by Sylvester (1948). (13) Beta vulgaris conspicuous
veinal chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Belgium and
the USA <California>. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein
clearing. (43) Beta vulgaris, Beta vulgaris ssp. cicla veinal chlorosis. (45)
Beta vulgaris. (46) Beta vulgaris (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Beta vulgaris
ssp. cicla. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (186)
Pathogenicity tests indicate that this virus is distinct from tobacco yellow
net (?) luteovirus. (187) Roland, G. (1948). Parasitica 4: 152. Sylvester,
E.S. (1948). Phytopathology 38: 429. Sylvester, E.S. (1949). Phytopathology
39: 117. Sylvester, E.S. (1956). J. econ. Ent. 49: 789. Sylvester, E.S.
(1958). J. econ. Ent. 51: 812. Waterhouse, P.M., Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone,
G.R. (1988). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 339, 9 pp.


Beet yellow stunt closterovirus

      (1) D.M. Wright, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BYSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.0.002. (9) From the U.S.A. in California. (10) By Duffus (1971). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Beta vulgaris yellowing, stunting. Lactuca sativa
severe stunting and chlorosis, severe necrosis of phloem tissue. Sonchus
oleraceus red or yellow interveinal colouration. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Hyperomyzus lactucae, Myzus
persicae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Hyperomyzus lactucae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (28)
Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in the U.K. in Scotland. (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Lactuca sativa, or Sonchus oleraceus. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae
<2/2>. (61) Virions filamentous. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35290. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): L20761 Gb(84)_vi:BEYRDRP Beet yellow stunt virus
RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene, 3' end and heat shock protein 70 g. (171)
Virions found in roots. (179) Closterovirus. (187) Duffus, J E. (1979).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 207, 4 pp.


Beet yellows closterovirus

      (1) H. Smith and A. Karasev, 1991. (2) Synonyms: sugarbeet yellows
closterovirus. (3) Standard acronym: BYV. (4) Strains: strains of differing
pathogenicity are known to exist. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.0.003. (8)
First reported in Beta vulgaris. (9) From Belgium. (10) By Roland (1936). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms yellowing and premature senescence of older
leaves. (13) Beta vulgaris vein clearing, then leaves become thick, brittle,
yellow with necrotic spots. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis fabae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Rhopalosiphum padi, Macrosiphum
(Sitobion) avenae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus
lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <with difficulty>. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Hull (1968); Harrington et al. (1989). (37) Probably
distributed worldwide <wherever Beta vulgaris is grown>. (39) Spreads in
China. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show yellowing or reddening, necrotic spots. (43) Tetragonia
tetragonioides stunting, vein clearing, yellowing. Montia perfoliata necrotic
spots, reddening and yellowing of older leaves. Beta vulgaris vein clearing
then yellowing, thickening and brittleness of leaves; necrotic spots. Spinacia
oleracea, Stellaria media yellowing. (44) Brassica spp., Lactuca sativa, Pisum
sativum, Nicotiana tabacum, Plantago lanceolata. (45) Montia perfoliata,
Tetragonia tetragonioides, Beta vulgaris. (46) Beta vulgaris (L and W), Montia
perfoliata (L and W), Chenopodium foliosum (L and W), C. quinoa (L). (47)
Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Lactuca sativa, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium hybridum. (48) Brassica campestris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica
juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var.
capitata, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or Plantago lanceolata, or Raphanus sativus, or
Senecio vulgaris, or Sinapis alba, or Solanum nigrum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <10/10>, or Compositae <1/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/7>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/5>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae <5/5>, or Cruciferae <11/11>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/7>, or Plantaginaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<4/5>. (53) Russell (1965). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Kassanis et al.
(1977); Karasev et al. (1989). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 1250 nm. (71) Virions 10 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3-3.4 nm. (76)
Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 110 S. (78) Of the other(s) 80-90 S. (79) Density
1.34 g cm3 in CsCl <fixed>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.44-1.54. (84) Virions
contain 5 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 14.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 14.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Karasev: two phenol/SDS extractions. (100) Base composition 23.4 % G. (101)
Base composition 26.3 % A. (102) Base composition 21 % C. (103) Base
composition 29.3 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated nucleotide
cap. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent.
(110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor not required for
infectivity. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: Karasev: 3'-terminal half (6746 nt). EMBL AC. No. X53462. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 12161. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M59452
Em(40)_vi:BYVVCPG Gb(84)_vi:BYVVCPG Beet yellows virus coat protein gene,
complete cds, and two ORFs. 8/91 2,724bp. X53462 Em(40)_vi:CLBYV3PH
Gb(84)_vi:CLBYV3PH Beet yellows virus genome 3'-proximal half, for capsid
protein HSP70 related protein, RNA-dep X73475 Em(40)_vi:BYVMBPA
Gb(84)_vi:BYVMBPA Beet yellows virus (isolate German BYV-G) genes for putative
membrane-binding protein, heat s X73476 Em(40)_vi:BYVUAA Gb(84)_vi:BYVUAA Beet
yellows virus (isolate Ukrainian BYV-U) complete genome. 2/94 15,480bp. 4
sequences. (119) Features of the genome: incomplete ORF 1 (nt 3-656) encodes
putative polymerase (219 AA). ORF 2 (nt 710-871) encodes 6.4kDa protein (AA
1-54). ORF 3 (nt 874-2667) encodes 65kDa homologue of HSP70 heat shock
proteins (AA 1-598). ORF 4 (nt 2576-4234) encodes 64kDa protein (AA1-553). ORF
5 (nt 4185-4832) encodes 24kDa protein, a diverged copy of capsid protein (AA
1-216). ORF 6 (nt 4906-5517) encodes 22.3kDa capsid protein (AA 1-204). ORF 7
(nt 5517-6056) encodes 20kDa protein (AA 1-180). ORF 8 (nt 6034-6564) encodes
21kDa protein (AA 1-177). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (125) 6 virus
specified dsRNA species found in infected cells <at least, including
genome-size dsRNA>. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 14.5 kbp.
(127) 2nd largest 6.3 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 4.8 kbp. (129) 4th largest 2.7
kbp. (130) 5th largest 1.6 kbp. (131) 6th largest 1 kbp. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 22.3 <KDa>. (134) Capsid protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Carpenter et al. (1977). (147) Amino acid composition: Carpenter
et al. (1977). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, vascular parenchyma, phloem,
companion cells and all parts of the host plant. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They
contain virions. (179) Closterovirus. (184) Its 6.4kDaprotein is apparently
related to 12kDaproteins of potex and carlaviruses. The putative polymerase is
related to polymerases of tricornaviruses (bromo and cucumoviruses). Its
capsid protein is a member of monophyletic family of capsid proteins encoded
by filamentous plant viruses, and its 65kDaprotein is a direct homologue of
cell HSP70 heat shock proteins. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA using
polyclonal antiserum to beet yellows closterovirus is routinely used to
identify the virus and distinguish it from beet mild yellowing virus which
often occurs with it in sugar beet crops. (187) Agranovsky, A.A., Boyko, V.P.,
Karasev, A.V., Lunina, N.A., Koonin, E.V. and Dolja, V.V. (1991). J. gen.
Virol. 72: 15. Agranovsky, A.A., Boyko, V.P., Karasev, A.V., Koonin, E.V. and
Dolja, V.V. (1991). J. mol. Biol. 217: 603. Bar-Joseph, M. and Hull, R.
(1974). Virology 62: 552. Carpenter, J.M., Kassasnis, B. and White, R.F.
(1977). Virology 77: 101. Dolja, V.V., Karasev, A.V. and Agranovsky, A.A.
(1990). In: New Aspects of Positive-Strand RNA Viruses, Amer. Soc. Micro.,
Washington D.C., U.S.A., p. 31. Esau, K. (1960). Virology 11: 317. Harrington,
R., Dewar, A.M. and George, B. (1989). Ann. appl. Biol. 114: 459. Heathcote,
G.D. (1988). In: Virus Yellows Monograph IIRB Pests and Diseases Study Group,

Carpenter, J.M., White, R.F. and Woods, R.D. (1977). Virology 77: 95. Russell,

Belladonna mottle tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Tollkirschenscheckungs virus. (3)
Standard acronym: BeMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported
in Atropa belladonna. (9) From Germany. (10) By Bode and Marcus (1959). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mottling. (13) Atropa belladonna mottling,
distortion. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Epithrix atropae (Jankulova et al., 1968). (18) Transmitted by
Coleoptera. (24) Not transmitted by aphids. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Bulgaria and Germany. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
necrosis, mosaics. (43) Chenopodium quinoa local lesions, not systemic. Datura
stramonium necrotic local lesions, mosaic. Nicotiana tabacum ring local
lesions, vein clearing, mosaic. (45) Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Nicotiana tabacum
(L). (47) Atropa belladonna, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium quinoa, or

log10 minus 6-7. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl

Bermuda grass etched-line marafivirus

      (1) A.A Brunt and B.E.L. Lockhart, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: BELV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 41.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Cynodon dactylon and
Sorghum halepense. (9) From Morocco. (10) By Lockhart et al. (1985). (11)
Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13) Cynodon dactylon white etched lines
and spots in leaves; plants stunted. Sorghum halepense chlorotic streaks in
leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Aconurella prolixa. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by Lockhart et al. (1985). (39) Spreads in
Morocco. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show streaks. (43) Avena sativa, Cynodon dactylon, Triticum
durum, Zea mays, Sorghum bicolor, S. halepense chlorotic spots and lines. (44)
Agrostis alba, Elytrigia repens, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium perenne, Saccharum
officinarum, Setaria viridis. (45) Cynodon dactylon, Zea mays. (46) Cynodon
dactylon (W), Zea mays (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Bromus inermis, or Cynodon
dactylon, or Festuca arundinacea, or Sorghum bicolor, or Sorghum halepense, or
Triticum durum, or Zea mays. (48) Agrostis alba, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or
Elytrigia repens, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium perenne, or Panicum
dichotomiflorum, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Saccharum officinarum, or Secale
cereale, or Setaria viridis. (50) Gramineae <8/18>. (51) Gramineae <10/18>.
(53) Lockhart et al. (1985). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:
Lockhart et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions <c.> 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67)
Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 119 S <(B)>. (78) Of the other(s) 57 S <(T)>. (79) Density 1.44 g cm3
in CsCl <(B)>, or 1.29 g cm3 in CsCl <(T)>. (81) Density in Cs2SO4 1.40 g/ml
(B) and 1.26 g/ml (T). (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.53 <B>, or 0.88 <T>. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.5
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.5 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lockhart: use standard phenol-SDS procedure.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 26500. (134) Coat protein. (148) Virion
proteins not glycosylated. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular
parenchyma and all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm
and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Marafivirus <the type species>. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: maize rayado fino and oat blue dwarf viruses. (187) Lockhart, B.E.L.,
Khaless, N., Lennon, A.M. and El Maataoui, M. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 1258.
Khaless, N. (1988). M.Sc. Thesis, University of Minnesota, 53 pp.

      (1) V. Muniyappa, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BYVMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.0.010. (8) First reported in Abelmoschus esculentus. (9) From
Bombay, India. (10) By Kulkarni (1924). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
vein clearing followed by yellowing and thickening, leaves and fruit reduced
in size. (13) Abelmoschus esculentus vein clearing, yellowing and thickening.

by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does

by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Sastry and Singh (1973). (39) Spreads in

(61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 16-18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions

Bidens mottle potyvirus

      (1) S.R. Christie, 1982. Revised by J.R. Edwardson, 1989. (3) Standard

Bidens pilosa, Lepidium virginicum. (9) From Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Christie
(1968). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Erigeron sp., Bidens sp., Senecio sp.,

Blackgram mottle (?) carmovirus

      (1) H.C. Phatak, 1983. (3) Standard acronym: BMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.T.014. (8) First reported in Vigna mungo. (9) From New Delhi, India.
(10) By Phatak (1974). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vigna mungo mottling,
puckering, vein clearing and malformation of leaves. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Ceratoma
trifurcata, Epilachna varivestis. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (29) Virus
does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <8% in
Vigna mungo>. (38) Spreads in the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Australia,
India, the Philippines, and Thailand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, mosaics.
(43) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Phaseolus lunatus, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto,
Vicia faba necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Black
Valentine systemic mosaic, leaf malformation. Vigna radiata necrotic local
lesions; systemic mosaic. (44) Chenopodium spp., Glycine max, Sesamum indicum,
Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Black Valentine. (46) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L), Macrotyloma uniflorum (L),
Phaseolus lunatus (L), P. vulgaris cvs Pinto, Puregold (L). (47) Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Lablab purpureus, or Macroptilium
lathyroides, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum indicum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna mungo,
or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Ocimum basilicum, or Sesamum indicum. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <12/12>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/12>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>.
(53) Phatak (1974). (54) TIP: 90-92 °C. (55) LIV: 45 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Scott and Phatak (1979).
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 122 S. (79) Density 1.364 g cm3
in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base
composition 24.9 % G. (101) Base composition 25.9 % A. (102) Base composition
25.2 % C. (103) Base composition 24 % U. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not
found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 38200. (145)
Method of preparation: Scott and Phatak (1979). (171) Virions found in
mesophyll, epidermis and in the lumen of xylem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in mitochondria. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells.
(178) Other cellular changes: cell membrane proliferation in association with
dictyosomes and endoplasmic reticulum, accumulation of Golgi vesicles. (179)
<Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: southern bean mosaic (type and cowpea
strain), broad bean mottle, cowpea severe mosaic, bean pod mottle, cowpea
chlorotic mottle, quail pea mosaic, cowpea mottle, bean mild mottle and more
than 35 other isometric viruses. (187) Phatak, H.C. (1974). Seed Sci. Technol.
2: 3. Scott, H.A. and Hoy, J.W. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 237, 4
pp. Scott, H.A. and Phatak, H.C. (1979). Phytopathology 69: 346.


Black raspberry necrosis virus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1991. (2) Synonyms: black raspberry mild mosaic
virus, raspberry black necrosis virus. (3) Standard acronym: BRNV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 79.0.P.DE.06. (8) First reported in Rubus idaeus. (9) From
Canada. (10) By Stace-Smith (1955). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection and none. (12) Symptoms mild leaf mottle. (13) Rubus idaeus, R.
fruticosus, R. procerus, R. ursinus, R. lasiocarpus, R. phoenicolasius, R.
loganobaccus symptomless. R. occidentalis stem necrosis, leaf mottle. R.
henryi stem necrosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Amphorophora agathonica, A. idaei, A.
rubicumberlandii, Illinoia rubicola. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Jones and
Jennings (1986). (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy,
the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, and the USA. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in Australia and New Zealand. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Gomphrena
globosa, Nicotiana debneyi, Petunia × hybrida, Spinacia oleracea local
chlorotic lesions. (45) Rubus idaeus, R. occidentalis. (46) Rubus occidentalis
(W), R. henryi (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Rubus fruticosus, or Rubus henryi, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus
lasiocarpus, or Rubus loganobaccus, or Rubus occidentalis, or Rubus
phoenicolasius, or Rubus procerus, or Rubus ursinus, or Spinacia oleracea.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Rosaceae <9/9>, or
Solanaceae <2/2>. (53) Jones and Murant (1972); Murant et al. (1976). (56)
DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Murant
et al. (1976). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 25-30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (171) Virions found in the leaves. (172) Virions found
in unusual sites. (179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: aphid
transmission to Rubus indicator hosts. (187) Jones, A.T. (1988). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 333, 4 pp. Jones, A.T. and Jennings, D.L. (1986). Ann.
appl. Biol. 96: 59. Jones, A.T. and Murant, A.F. (1972). Pl. Path. 21: 166.
Murant, A.D., Jones, A.T. and Roberts, I.M. (1976). Acta Hort. 66: 39.
Stace-Smith, R. (1955). Can. J. Bot. 33: 314. Stace-Smith, R. and Jones, A.T.
(1987). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse, U.S. Dep.
Agric. Hdbk No. 631, p. 178.


Blueberry leaf mottle nepovirus

      (1) D.C. Ramsdell, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: BLMV. (4) Strains:
blueberry leaf mottle virus M1 and blueberry leaf mottle virus NY. (5) ICTV
decimal code 18.0.3.0.006. (8) First reported in Vaccinium corymbosum. (9)
From Michigan, U.S.A. (10) By Ramsdell and Stace-Smith (1979). (13) Vaccinium
corymbosum cv. Rubel stem dieback and poor regrowth, hence stunting. Leaves
malformed and mottled. V. corymbosum cv. Jersey stem dieback. Regrowth
stunted. Leaves rosetted and mottled. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant <by honeybees>. (36) Studies
reported by Childress and Ramsdell (1986a); Childress and Ramsdell (1986b);
Childress and Ramsdell (1987). (39) Spreads in the USA <Michigan>. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in New York, USA (grapevine) and in Pleven,
Bulgaria. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show local lesions, mottle, tip necrosis. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa, C. album chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottle and tip
necrosis. C. amaranticolor systemic mottle. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic
necrosis. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa respectively. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (W), Nicotiana clevelandii (W). (47)
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vaccinium
corymbosum. (48) Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Momordica balsamina, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Plantago lanceolata, or Plantago major, or Sesbania
exaltata, or Tithonia speciosa, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/4>, or Ericaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Solanaceae <8/10>. (51) Apocynaceae
<1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or
Plantaginaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/10>. (53) Ramsdell and Stace-Smith
(1979). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 14-21 days <at 4°C>, or 5-7 days <at
20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Ramsdell and Stace-Smith (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 128 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 120 S <M>, or 53
S <T>. (79) Density 1.497 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.471 g cm3 in CsCl <M>. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 7.5. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 14.6 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7.6 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 7 kb.
(99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Ramsdell and Stace-Smith (1981). (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 38172. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): U20621
Em(43)_vi:Bl20621 Gb(89)_vi:Blu20621 Blueberry leaf mottle virus segment RNA2
polyprotein gene, partial cds. 5/95 3,082bp. U20622 Em(43)_vi:Bl20622
Gb(89)_vi:Blu20622 Blueberry leaf mottle virus segment RNA1 polyprotein gene,
partial cds. 5/95 1,908bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (133) Mr 54000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation:
Ramsdell and Stace-Smith (1981). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and blossoms. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (173) Virions found in the cytoplasm of parenchyma cells close
to endoplasmic reticulum but not with other organelles. (174) Inclusions
absent from infected cells. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: grapevine Bulgarian latent
virus is distantly related. (187) Childress, A.M. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1986a).
Acta Hort. 186: 87. Childress, A.M. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1986b). Phytopathology
76: 1333. Childress, A.M. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 167.
Ramsdell, D.C. (1987). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse.
U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 631, p. 112. Ramsdell, D.C. and Stace-Smith, R.
(1979). Acta Hort. 95: 37. Ramsdell, D.C. and Stace-Smith, R. (1980). Proc.
7th Meeting Int. Counc. for the Study of Viruses and Virus-Like Dis. of
Grapevine, Niagara Falls, Canada. Ramsdell, D.C. and Stace-Smith, R. (1981).
