Blueberry necrotic shock ilarvirus

      (1) R.R. Martin, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Blueberry shock virus. (3) Standard
acronym: BlShV. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.02.02. (8) First reported in
Vaccinium corymbosum. (9) From Washington State, U.S.A. (10) By MacDonald et
al. (1991). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms leaf and flower
necrosis. (13) Vaccinium corymbosum leaf and flower necrosis during bloom,
plants show symptoms for 14 years, then recover and remain symptomless and
produce good quality fruit. (15) Virus spreads quickly in a crop. Removal of
infected plants does not slow the spread of the virus significantly. (24) Not
transmitted by Fimbriaphis fimbriata, Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in the USA <Oregon and
Washington State>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N. sylvestris, N. tabacum cvs Samsun and
Havana-425 necrotic local lesions; systemic necrosis. Vaccinium corymbosum
necrosis of leaves and flowers. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus,
Gomphrena globosa, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii, Vaccinium corymbosum. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii
(W). (47) Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vaccinium corymbosum. (48) Brassica
juncea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Ericaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/6>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/6>.
(53) MacDonald et al. (1991). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
MacDonald et al. (1991). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.46-1.6 <uncorrected for light
scattering>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 7.717 kb. (92) Genome of four parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 2.901 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.366 kb. (95) The 3rd
largest 1.605 kb. (96) The 4th largest 0.845 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by proteinase K digest of coat protein. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 27300. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: MacDonald et
al. (1991). (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and mesophyll. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 2>. (180) :
Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: apple mosaic
and prunus necrotic ringspot viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: asparagus 2, citrus leaf rugose, citrus variegation, elm
mosaic, elm mottle, Humulus japonicus, prune dwarf, spinach latent, tobacco
streak and Tulare apple mosaic viruses. (187) MacDonald, S.G., Martin, R.R.
and Bristow, P.R. (1989). Acta Hort. 241: 295. MacDonald, S.G., Martin, R.R.
and Bristow, P.R. (1991). Phytopathology 81: 210.


Blueberry red ringspot caulimovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BRRV. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Vaccinium corymbosum. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Hutchinson and Varney (1954). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vaccinium
corymbosum, V. formosum and possibly V. macrocarpon red ringspots in leaves
and older stems; earlier, but decreased, fruit yield. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Vaccinium
corymbosum red ringspots in mature leaves of graft-inoculated plants. (45)
Vaccinium corymbosum. (47) Vaccinium corymbosum, or Vaccinium formosum, or
Vaccinium macrocarpon <possibly>. (50) Ericaceae <3/3>. (60) Method: Gillet
and Ramsdell (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 42-46 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 275 S. (78) Of the
other(s) 212 S. (79) Density 1.3 and 1.4 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point
pH 4. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 44000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in
leaves and the mesophyll. (172) Virions found in nuclei and in unusual sites.
(173) Virions found in but most are within cytoplasmic inclusions. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms
<enclosed within endoplasmic reticulum>. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Caulimovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
cauliflower mosaic, carnation etched ring, dahlia mosaic and figwort mosaic
viruses. (187) Gillet, J.M. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 862.
Gillet, J.M. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 327, 4 pp.
Hepp, R.F. and Converse, R.H. (1987). Plant Dis. 71: 536. Hutchinson, M.T. and
Varney, E.H. (1954). Pl. Dis. Reptr 38: 260. Kim, K.S., Ramsdell, D.C.,
Gillet, J.M. and Fulton, J.P. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 673.


Blueberry scorch carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and R.R. Martin, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BlSV. (4)
Strains: Sheep Pen Hill virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.003. (8) First
reported in Vaccinium corymbosum. (9) From Washington State, U.S.A. (10) By
Martin and Bristow (1988). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms flower
necrosis and leaf chlorosis and necrosis. (13) Vaccinium corymbosum marginal
necrosis or chlorosis of leaves, flowers aborted; some cultivars remain
symptomless. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(39) Spreads in the USA <Oregon and Washington>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Vaccinium corymbosum marginal leaf chlorosis. (45) Vaccinium
corymbosum. (46) Vaccinium corymbosum cv. Pemberton (W). (47) Chenopodium
quinoa, or Vaccinium corymbosum. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris
ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana benthamiana,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium repens, or
Verbesina encelioides, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Ericaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae
<2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or
Solanaceae <8/8>. (52) Only blueberry infected by most strains, one infects
Chenopodium quinoa. (53) Martin and Bristow (1988). (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Martin and Bristow (1988). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 690 nm. (71) Virions 14 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.28 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.2. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 8.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 8.4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Martin and Bristow
(1988). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31722. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
L25658 Em(40)_vi:BLUORF Gb(84)_vi:BLUORF Blueberry scorch carlavirus mRNA.
4/94 8,512bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35200. (134)
Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Martin and Bristow (1988). (171)
Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: carnation latent, chrysanthemum B, dandelion,
elderberry, helenium S, potato M, potato S, pea streak and red clover vein
mosaic carlaviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serological tests, ELISA
is best. Due to the low pH of blueberry leaf sap, it is necessary to ensure
the pH of homogenized leaves is above pH 6.0 by using a strong buffer (10 ×
PBS or 0.5% nicotine). (187) MacDonald, S.G., Martin, R.R. and Bristow, P.R.
(1989). Acta Hort. 241: 295. Martin, R.R. and Bristow, P.R. (1988).
Phytopathology 78: 1636. Martin, R.R. and MacDonald, S.G. (1988). Can. Pl.
Dis. Surv. 68: 98.


Blueberry shoestring sobemovirus

      (1) D.C. Ramsdell, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: BSSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 67.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Vaccinium spp. (9) From New Jersey,
U.S.A. (10) By Varney (1957). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13)
Vaccinium corymbosum, V. angustifolium "shoestring" disease; reddish streaks
on stems, narrow strap-like leaves, occasional flower-breaking, severe yield
reduction. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Masonaphis pepperi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner <probably>. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Morimoto and
Ramsdell (1985); Morimoto et al. (1985). (39) Spreads in the USA <in Michigan
and New Jersey>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show malformation, streaking. (43) Vaccinium spp. oak
leaf pattern on leaves malformed shoestring leaves, red streaks on stems;
blossoms pink. (45) Vaccinium corymbosum. (47) Vaccinium, or Vaccinium
angustifolium, or Vaccinium corymbosum. (50) Ericaceae <3/3>. (53) Ramsdell
(1979a). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Ramsdell (1979a);
Ramsdell (1979b). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 120 S. (79) Density
1.392 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density 1.273 in Cs2SO4 and 1.355 g/cm3. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 4.6-4.7. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid <in the
single component>. (85) Virions 80 % protein <in the single component>. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 4.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Ramsdell (1979b). (110) Poly A
region absent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (114)
Genome has no tRNAlike activity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in
the virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Ramsdell (1979b). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis, meristem, xylem, phloem
and palisade parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in
cell vacuoles <in small cytoplasmic vacuoles>. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: rod-like materials in palisade
cells (Hartman et al., 1973). (179) Sobemovirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: 33 viruses with isometric virions (Ramsdell,
1979a). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: look for reddish streaks on stems.
(187) Converse, R.H., Martin, R.R. and Spiegel, S. (1987). In: Virus Diseases
of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse. U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 631. Fraser,
N.W. (1970). In: Virus and Virus-Like Diseases of Small Fruit and Grapevines;
ed. N.W. Fraser. University of California, Berkeley, California, U.S.A..
Gillet, J.M., Morimoto, K.M., Ramsdell, D.C., Baker, K.K. Chaney, W.G. and
Esselman, W.J. (1982). Acta Hort. 129: 25. Hancock, J.F., Morimoto, K.M.,
Pritts, M.P. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1986). Hort. Science 21: 1059. Hancock, J.F.,
Morimoto, K.M., Roeche, J.M., Schulte, N.L. and Ramsdell, D.C. (1986). Fruit
Var. J. 40: 56. Hartman, J.X., Bath, J.E. and Hooper, G.R. (1973).
Phytopathology 63: 432. Klomparens, K.L., Petersen, J.F., Ramsdell, D.C. and
Chaney, W.G. (1986). J. Electron Micro. Tech. 4: 47. Lesney, M.S. and
Ramsdell, D.C. (1976). Acta Hort. 66: 105. Lesney, M.S., Ramsdell, D.C. and
Sun, M. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 295. Morimoto, K.M. and Ramsdell, D.C.
(1985). Phytopathology 75: 1217. Morimoto, K.M., Ramsdell, D.C., Gillet, J.M.
and Chaney, W.G. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 709. Ramsdell, D.C. (1979a).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 204, 4 pp. Ramsdell, D.C. (1979b).
Phytopathology 69: 1087. Schulte, N.L. (1985). J. Am. Soc. Hort. Sci. 110:
343. Varney, E.H. (1957). Phytopathology 47: 307.


Bramble yellow mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BrmYMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.009. (8) First reported in Rubus rigidus (wild trailing
blackberry). (9) From South Africa. (10) By Engelbrecht (1963). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Rubus rigidus yellow mosaic and line patterns in early spring;
later leaves symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in South Africa. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium murale, C. quinoa local lesions;
systemic necrotic ringspots or chlorotic mottling. Gomphrena globosa,
Nicotiana tabacum chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Chenopodium
murale. (46) Chenopodium murale (L/W). (47) Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Rubus rigidus. (48)
Cucumis sativus, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/2>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/2>. (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 730
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) Unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Engelbrecht, D.J. (1963). S. Afr. J.
Lab. clin. Med. 9: 140. Engelbrecht, D.J. (1976). Acta Hort. 66: 79.
Engelbrecht, D.J. and van der Walt, W.J.K. (1974). Phytophylactica 6: 311.

168 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (179) Unassigned

Broad bean B virus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.07. (8) First
reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Colmar, France. (10) By Putz and Kuszala
(1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vicia faba stunting. (39) Spreads in

plants mostly show stunting. (46) Vicia faba. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Pisum sativum, or Vicia

nm in diameter. (179) (Ungrouped). (187) Putz, C. and Kuszala, M. (1973).
Annls. Phytopath. 5: 447.


Broad bean mottle bromovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1981, Revised 1985. (3) Standard acronym: BBMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 10.0.3.0.002. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From the U.K.
(10) By Bawden et al. (1951). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vicia faba leaf
mottling and malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acalymma trivittata, Colaspis flavida,
Diabrotica undecimpunctata, Sitona lineata. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Portugal, Sudan,
and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally

amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba

sativum lethal systemic wilt. Vicia faba systemic blotchy mottle. Nicotiana
clevelandii mild mottle. (44) Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Vicia faba, Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L). (47) Chenopodium album, or

Broad bean necrosis furovirus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1981. Revised 1984. (3) Standard acronym: BBNV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 27.0.1.T.009. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Japan.

susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic or
chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.

      (1) G. Thottappilly, 1983. Revised 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code

By Thottappilly et al. (1975). (13) Vicia faba chlorosis, necrosis, leaf
malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.

inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA <Michigan>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Pisum sativum cv. Midfreezer systemic chlorosis, mosaic;
then necrosis and plant dies. (45) Pisum sativum cv. Midfreezer. (46) Pisum

Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions

2180-2450, 2970-3180, 3650-3850 and 4500-4700 nm>. (71) Virions 14 nm wide.

Broad bean stain comovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1981. Revised 1987. (2) Synonyms: virus de la mosaique
de la fève, MF virus, broad bean F1 virus (Gibbs et al., 1968), broad bean
Evesham stain virus. (3) Standard acronym: BBSV. (4) Strains: pea green mottle
virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Vicia faba.
(9) From the U.K. (10) By Lloyd et al. (1965). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically
over a few weeks, or vary seasonally. (13) Vicia faba systemic mottling,
necrosis and malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Apion vorax, Sitona spp. (18) Transmitted by
Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to 10% in some
Vicia faba cultivars>. (38) Spreads in the African region and the Eurasian

seed. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show mottle, mosaic, necrosis. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Tendergreen systemic mottle. Pisum sativum, Vicia faba systemic mottle;
necrosis. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto,
Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Tendergreen, Pisum sativum,
Vicia faba. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Tendergreen (L), Vicia faba (W). (47)

in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in

deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Rows of virions in tubules, finger-like

Broad bean true mosaic comovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1981. Revised 1987. (2) Synonyms: Vicia virus 1, Echtes
Ackerbohnenmosaikvirus. (3) Standard acronym: BBTMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Germany. (10) By
Quantz (1953). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically over a few weeks. (13) Vicia faba
mild mosaic and malformation, necrosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Apion vorax, Sitonia spp. and
other weevils. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the
African region and the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in China, Morocco, and
the UK. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Australia in crops
grown from imported seed. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Pisum
sativum systemic chlorosis, shoot necrosis. Vicia faba mottle, mosaic and
shoot necrosis. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45)
Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Pisum sativum (W), Vicia faba (W). (47) Cicer
arietinum, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or Melilotus albus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
repens, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa. (48) Antirrhinum
majus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium,
or Glycine max, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lotus corniculatus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Trifolium hybridum, or
Trifolium pratense. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/17>. (51)
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/17>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<4/4>. (53) Quantz (1953). (54) TIP: 65-75 °C. (55) LIV: 6-7 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Blevings and
Stace-Smith (1976). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components
in purified preparations <in reducing buffer>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
<of the fastest> 116 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 95 S <M>, or 59 S <T>. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.81 <B>, or 1.76 <M>. (84) Virions contain 35 % nucleic acid
<B>, or 26 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 65 %
protein <B>, or 74 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (100) Base composition 22.8 % G.
(101) Base composition 26.5 % A. (102) Base composition 18.4 % C. (103) Base
composition 32.3 % U. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
phenol or detergent. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 37500. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 24500. (145) Method of preparation: Blevings and Stace-Smith (1976).
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Are tubules from plasmodesmata containing rows of virus virions, also
vesiculated bodies and virus aggregates (Russo et al., 1982). (179) Comovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: broad bean stain, glycine mosaic, radish mosaic and squash mosaic
viruses. (187) Blevings, S. and Stace-Smith, R. (1976). J. gen. Virol. 31:
199. Cockbain, A.J., Cook, S.M. and Bowen, R. (1975). Ann. appl. Biol. 81:
331. Cockbain, A.J., Bowen, R. and Vorra-Urai, S. (1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 84:
321. Gibbs, A.J. and Paul, H.L. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 20, 4
pp. Gibbs, A.J., Giussani-Belli, G. and Smith, H.G. (1968). Ann. appl. Biol.
61: 99. Jones, A.T. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 88: 137. Quantz, L. (1953).
Phytopath. Z. 20: 421. Randles, J.W. and Dube, A.J. (1977). Australas. Pl.
Path. Soc. Newsl. 6: 37. Russo, M., Castellano, M.A. and Martelli, G.P.
(1982). J. Submicrosc. Cytol. 14: 149.


Broad bean V (?) potyvirus

      (1) Boswell from Cockbain 1983. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.01. (8)
First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Spain. (10) By Rubio-Huertos et al.
(1967). (13) Vicia faba mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis fabae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (47) Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vicia faba. (48) Nicotiana
tabacum. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/3>. (51)
Solanaceae <1/3>. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 657-750 nm. (179) Unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
distinguishable from bean yellow mosaic by the ability to infect Nicotiana
glutinosa, N. tabacum and Petunia × hybrida. (187) Cockbain, A.J. (1983). The
Faba Bean (Vicia faba) A Basis for Improvement; ed. P.D. Hebblethwaite.
Butterworths. Rubio-Huertos, M., Santaolalla and Moreno, S. (1967). An.
Edafol. Agrobiol. 26: 763.


Broad bean wilt fabavirus

      (1) J.W. Bowyer, 1980. (2) Synonyms: catalpa chlorotic leaf spot virus
(Schmelzer, 1970), tropaeolum ringspot virus (Cook and Gibbs, 1971),
nasturtium ringspot virus, Ringmosaikvirus der Kapuzinerkresse (Frowd and
Tomlinson, 1972), petunia ringspot virus (Hull and Plaskitt, 1973; 1974), P.O.
pea streak virus, parsley virus 3. (3) Standard acronym: BBWV, BBWV-1, BBWV-2.
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.2.0.001. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From
Melbourne, Australia. (10) By Stubbs (1947). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally.
(13) Vicia faba, Pisum sativum vein clearing, mottling and necrosis of shoot
apex, plant wilts, mottled, malformed and stunted. Spinacia oleracea wilting,
shoot die-back, leaves mottled. Petroselinum crispum symptomless. Tropaeolum
majus mosaic. Petunia × hybrida line-ring spots and oak leaf patterns.
Plantago lanceolata mottling, ringspots. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis
craccivora, A. faba, A. nasturtii, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, M. solanifolii, M.
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the African region, the Eurasian region,
the Middle East, the North American region, and the Pacific region. (39)
Spreads in Australia and China. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Argentina. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, ringspots, mosaic and systemic
necrosis. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions;
tip epinasty, leaves malformed and mottled. Spinacia oleracea systemic wilt,
necrosis and die-back. Vicia faba apical necrosis, wilting and mosaic. Vigna
unguiculata cv. Blackeye red or chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic and
malformation. Datura stramonium coalescent, necrotic local lesions; systemic
ringspots and line patterns. Nicotiana × edwardsonii necrotic local lesions;
systemic necrosis. N. glutinosa systemic mosaic with some ringspots. N.
tabacum cv. White Burley large ringspots; systemic leaf chlorosis. Petunia ×
hybrida systemic line and oak leaf patterns and ringspots. (45) Chenopodium
quinoa, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba, Nicotiana × edwardsonii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (Moroccan isolate only),
Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye (L), Datura stramonium (L). (47) Antirrhinum
majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura
metel, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Matthiola incana,
or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Ocimum basilicum, or
Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Plantago lanceolata, or
Solanum nigrum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna unguiculata. (48) Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Cajanus cajan, or
Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis melo, or Helianthus
annuus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or
Phaseolus lunatus, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum tuberosum, or Sonchus
oleraceus, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<5/5>, or Compositae <2/5>, or Cruciferae <4/6>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or
Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/10>, or Plantaginaceae <1/1>,
or Scrophulariaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <15/19>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Compositae <3/5>, or
Cruciferae <2/6>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/10>, or Solanaceae <4/19>. (53) Gracia and Feldman (1976); Schmelzer and
Stahl (1977). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Doel (1975). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter,
or 28-32 nm in diameter <for parsley virus 3>. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 126 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 100 S <M>, or 63
S <T>. (79) Density <in the presence of 2.34 w/v Igepon T73> 1.39 g cm3 in

0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 67 % protein <B>, or 78 % protein <M>, or
100 % protein <T>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 10.8 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.3 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 4.5 kb. (100) Base composition 26 % G. (101) Base composition 30 %
A. (102) Base composition 17.5 % C. (103) Base composition 26.5 % U. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132) Virion
protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 42000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 26000.
(145) Method of preparation: Doel (1975); Brown and Hull (1973). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm
<Russo et al., 1975>, or amorphous Xbodies <Russo and Martelli, 1975>. (177)
They contain virions <the inclusions are unlike those induced by members of
the comovirus group, yet are similar to those induced by some tymoviruses;
Edwardson and Christie, 1986>. (179) Fabavirus: Comoviridae <the Type species
of the genus>. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: all isolates are serologically closely related and indistinguishable.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: four comoviruses. (187)

Broad bean yellow ringspot virus

      (1) K.T. Natsuaki, 1981. Revised 1984. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.08. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Japan. (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Vicia faba chlorotic local lesions and ringspots. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (47) Vicia faba.
(50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and phloem.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Oval or round inclusions, 1-2 µ. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: swelling of the nucleus. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: cucumber mosaic virus (Japanese Y
strain). (187) Natsuaki, K.T. (1979). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 45: 84.


Broad bean yellow vein cytorhabdovirus

      (1) K.T. Natsuaki, 1981. Revised 1984. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.4.DE.01. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Natsuaki (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vicia faba chlorotic veins. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (47)
Vicia faba. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (70)
Virions of 230-250 nm. (71) Virions 110-130 nm wide. (171) Virions found in
mesophyll, epidermis and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Oval or rounded inclusions, 0.05-2.0 [Gm]m. (177) They do not contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: vesiculation of cytoplasm. Virions bud
from cytoplasm. (179) Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(187) Natsuaki, K.T. (1981). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 47: 410.


Broccoli necrotic yellows cytorhabdovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: BNYV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 62.0.4.0.003. (8) First reported in Brassica oleracea var. botrytis
(cauliflower-headed broccoli). (9) From England. (10) By Hills and Campbell
(1968). (13) Brassica oleracea var. botrytis (broccoli), Brassica oleracea
var. gemmifera (brussel sprouts) symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Brevicoryne brassicae
(Tomlinson, Webb and Faithfull, 1972). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (39) Spreads in Australia and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis,
necrosis, sometimes symptomless. (43) Brassica oleracea vein-clearing and
leaf-rolling, later symptomless. Datura stramonium chlorotic and necrotic
local lesions, then systemic mosaic and necrosis of veins. Nicotiana glutinosa
sometimes local lesions, then systemic mosaic. (45) Datura stramonium. (46)
Datura stramonium (L/W). (47) Brassica oleracea, or Brassica oleracea var.
botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. gemmifera, or Datura stramonium, or
Nicotiana glutinosa. (50) Cruciferae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (54) TIP: 50
°C. (55) LIV: 0.5-0.8 days <12-18 hours) at 23°C>, or 2 days <at 4°C>. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment with
diethyl ether <Lin and Campbell, 1972>. (59) Electron microscopy: preparations
stained with PTA-K have bullet-shaped virions. (60) Method: Lin and Campbell
(1972). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 266 nm <in PTA-K>, or 275
nm <in UA>. (71) Virions 66 nm wide <in PTA-K>, or 75 nm wide <in UA>. (74)
Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.5 nm. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 874 S
<±41>. (81) Density 1.183-1.195 g/cm3 in potassium tartrate (Lin and Campbell,
1972). (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm
<in membrane-bounded sacs; Hill and Campbell (1968)>. (174) Inclusions absent
from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: mitochondria swollen with
few cristae (Hill and Campbell, 1968). (179) Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae.
(180) : Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
lettuce necrotic yellows and barley yellow striate mosaic viruses. (184)
Virions of broccoli necrotic yellows and lettuce necrotic yellows viruses are
similar in size and intracellular location but these viruses differ in host
range, host reaction, geographical distribution and are serologically
distinct. (187) Campbell, R.N. and Lin, M.T. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 85, 4 pp. Garret, R.G. and O'Loughlin, G.T. (1976). Virology 76:
653. Hills, G.J. and Campbell, R.N. (1968). J. Ultrastruct. Res. 24: 134. Lin,
M.T. and Campbell, R.N. (1972). Virology 48: 30. Tomlinson, J.A., Webb, M.J.W.
and Faithfull, E.M. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 127.


Brome mosaic bromovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: weidelgrasmosaikvirus,
ryegrass streak virus, trespengrasmosaikvirus. (3) Standard acronym: BMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 10.0.3.0.003. (8) First reported in Bromus inermis. (9) From
the U.S.A. (10) By McKinney et al. (1942). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Bromus
inermis mosaic. (15) In laboratory tests, nematodes of the genus Xiphinema
transmitted the virus (Schmidt et al., 1963; Fritzsche, 1975). Attempts to
transmit the virus with aphids and mites have been unsuccessful (Lane, 1974).
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed <Lane, 1974>. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region <eastern>. (39)
Spreads in Australia, South Africa, and the USA <central>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local
lesions, systemic necrosis. (43) Zea mays lesions then systemic necrosis and
death. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. hybridum, C. quinoa local lesions; not
systemic. (45) Hordeum vulgare. (46) Chenopodium hybridum (L). (47) Bromus
inermis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Zea mays. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Gramineae <3/3>. (53) Lane (1974); Rochow (1959). (54) TIP: 80 °C. (55) LIV:
28 days <or longer>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Lane and Kaesberg (1971); Lane (1977). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement <Bancroft et al., 1967>. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 87.3 S <at pH 3-6>. (78)
Of the other(s) 78.7 S <at pH 7; Incardona and Kaesberg, 1964>. (79) Density
1.35 g cm3 in CsCl <Bancroft, 1971>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 6.8 <Rice and
Horst, 1972>. (84) Virions contain 22 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 78 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.216 kb. (92) Genome of
three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.234 kb
<RNA-1>. (94) The 2nd largest 2.865 kb <RNA-2>. (95) The 3rd largest 2.117 kb
<RNA-3>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Bockstahler and Kaesberg (1962;
1965). (100) Base composition 28 % G. (101) Base composition 27 % A. (102)
Base composition 21 % C. (103) Base composition 24 % U. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap <of 7-methyl guanosine>. (114) Genome has
tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts tyrosine. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: Bastin et al. (1976); P. Kaesberg in Lane (1977); DasGupta et al.
(1975). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12302. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):

(179) Bromovirus: Bromoviridae <the type species>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cowpea chlorotic mottle virus,
but distantly (Scott and Slack, 1971). (184) RNA-1 and RNA-2 from brome mosaic
virus and RNA-3 from cowpea chlorotic mottle virus form a viable genetic
hybrid, although this replicates more slowly and has a narrower host range
(Bancroft, 1972). This indicates their close relationship. Brome mosaic and
broad bean mottle viruses also are related as shown by their physical
properties of their virions and similar coat protein composition. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: Brome mosaic virus is distinguishable from most other
viruses of Gramineae by its symptoms in maize and by its ability to infect
several non-graminaceous hosts. (187) Ahlquist, P., Luckow and Kaesberg, P.

Brome streak mosaic (?) rymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: Brome streak virus. (3) Standard
acronym: BStV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.2.T.001. (8) First reported in
Bromus mollis, Hordeum murinum. (9) From Former Yugoslavia. (10) By MilicHicH
et al. (1980, 1982). (13) Bromus mollis, Hordeum murinum chlorotic leaf
streaking. (39) Spreads in the former Yugoslavia. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Avena, Bromus, Hordeum, Triticum and Vulpia spp. chlorotic
leaf streaking. (45) Bromus mollis (W). (47) Avena, or Bromus, or Bromus
mollis, or Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, or Hordeum, or Hordeum murinum, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Triticum, or Triticum aestivum, or Vulpia. (50) Gramineae
<9/9>, or Palmae <1/1>. (55) LIV: 5 days <or more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3.
(60) Method: MilicHicH et al. (1982). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 693
nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 42631. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
X78485 Gb(89)n:Bsmpnicp Brome Streak Mosaic Potyvirus mRNA for viral
polymerase, coat protein. 6/95 3,044bp. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) <Possible> Rymovirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) MilicHicH, D., Kujundzic, M.,

Burdock yellow mosaic (?) potexvirus

      (1) L.W. Stobbs, 1991. (4) Strains: 1 isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.D.01. (8) First reported in Arctium minus. (9) From the Niagara
region, Ontario, Canada. (10) By Stobbs and van Schagen (1988). (11) Symptoms
persist. (12) Symptoms bright yellow mosaic and stunting. (13) Arctium minus
stunting and bright yellow mosaic. Symptoms more pronounced in plants growing
in sunny positions than those in full shade. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector <possible>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Canada. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions,
latent and systemic infection. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Gomphrena
globosa, Nicotiana tabacum local lesions. Chenopodium murale latent infection.
C. quinoa systemic infection. (45) Arctium minus, Chenopodium quinoa for
propagation. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Gomphrena globosa (L),
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Harrow Velvet (L). (47) Arctium minus, or Chenopodium

globosa, or Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,

Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or Compositae <1/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <7/8>.
(54) TIP: 58 °C. (55) LIV: 91 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Stobbs and van Schagen (1988). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually

Allen and Dias (1977). (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells.
(179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: clover yellow mosaic and potato aucuba mosaic viruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: symptoms in Arctium minus are diagnostic for this virus.

and van Schagen, J.G. (1988). Plant Dis. 72: 314.


Burdock yellows closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: BuYV. (5) ICTV decimal code

Inouye and Mitsuhata (1971). (13) Arctium lappa faint chlorosis, often
marginal, or symptomless. Infected plants often also contain burdock mosaic

Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.6
nm. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.73. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and
vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions

Closterovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: carnation
necrotic fleck, citrus tristeza and wheat yellow leaf viruses. (187) Inouye,

Cacao necrosis nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1984. (2) Synonyms: cacao swollen shoot virus strain S.
(3) Standard acronym: CNV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.011. (8) First
reported in Theobroma cacao. (9) From Ghana. (10) By Kenten (1972). (13)
Theobroma cacao systemic, necrotic or chlorotic spots, streaks and mosaic.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode <possibly>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <up to 24% in Glycine max, Phaseolus lunatus and P.
vulgaris>. (39) Spreads in Ghana and Nigeria. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local
lesions, systemic mottling. (43) Beta vulgaris red local lesions. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa systemic leaf chlorosis. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic
local lesions or ringspots; systemic vein-banding and mottling. (44) Spinacia
oleracea, Trifolium repens, Vicia faba, Datura stramonium. (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris. (46) Beta vulgaris (L), but less sensitive than Phaseolus vulgaris
(L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Theobroma
cacao, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Datura stramonium, or
Daucus carota, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Pastinaca sativa, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or
Raphanus sativus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium repens, or Triticum
aestivum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/6>, or Solanaceae <4/9>,
or Sterculiaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/6>, or Solanaceae <5/9>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>.
(53) Kenten (1972). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 4-7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Kenten (1972). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 24-26 nm in
diameter <a minor component of 20-30 S has isometric virions 12 nm diameter>.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Four sedimenting components in purified preparations <one of
which may be polymerized coat protein>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 129 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 101 S <M>, or 54 S <T>. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.78 <B>, or 1.63 <M; both corrected for scattering>. (84)
Virions contain 38 % nucleic acid <B>, or 26 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 %
nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 62 % protein <B>, or 74 % protein <M>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome of two parts. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 60000. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tomato black ring virus, but
distantly, and grapevine chrome mosaic virus, very distantly. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, cherry leaf roll,
strawberry latent ringspot, tobacco ringspot and tomato ringspot viruses.
(187) Kenten, R.H. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 119. Kenten, R.H. (1977).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 173, 4 pp. Owusu, G.K. (1971). Trop. Agric.,
Trin. 48: 133. Thresh, J.M. and Tinsley, T.W. (1959). Tech. Bull. W. Afr.

Cacao swollen shoot badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1986. (2) Synonyms: theobroma virus 1, cacao swollen
shoot virus, cacao mottle leaf virus. (3) Standard acronym: CSSV. (4) Strains:
Many variants have been recorded; initially named alphabetically, they are now
named by where they were found. Well-known strains include Bisa, Bosumtwe,
Ikiri, Kpeve, Mampong, New Juaben, Nsaba and Offa Igbo. (5) ICTV decimal code
07.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Theobroma cacao (cocoa). (9) From Ghana.
(10) By Posnette (1940); Brunt and Kenten (1960). (11) Symptoms persist <in
some and disappears in others>. (13) Theobroma cacao interveinal chlorosis,
swollen stems and roots caused by many strains, a few cause root swelling
only, and some cause no symptoms. Ceiba pentandra, Cola chlamydantha, Cola
gigantea var. glabrescens, Sterculia tragacantha transient leaf chlorosis.
Adansonia digitata leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Planococcoides njalensis,
Planococcus citri, Planococcus kenyae, Planococcus sp. celtis, Dysmicoccus
brevipes, Ferrisia virgata, Pseudococcus longispinus (only Mampong strain).
(18) Transmitted by Pseudococcidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <with
difficulty>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Ollenu et al. (1989). (39)
Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Sri Lanka, and Togo
<and, possibly, Trinidad>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorosis, necrosis, swelling. (43)
Theobroma cacao (Amelonado) systemic red vein-banding, then leaf chlorosis.
Corchorus spp. lethal systemic necrosis. Adansonia digitata systemic mottling
and stunting. Ceiba pentandra, Ceiba chlamydantha, Cola gigantea transient
leaf chlorosis. Bombax brevicuspe chlorosis. (44) Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
clevelandii. (45) Theobroma cacao, Adansonia digitata, Bombax brevicuspe. (46)
Theobroma cacao (W). Cocoa cotyledons are readily infected by viruliferous
mealybugs or by mechanical inoculation. (47) Adansonia digitata, or Bombax
brevicuspe, or Ceiba chlamydantha, or Ceiba pentandra, or Cola chlamydantha,
or Cola gigantea, or Cola gigantea var. glabrescens, or Corchorus, or
Sterculia tragacantha, or Theobroma cacao. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Arachis hypogaea, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum melongena, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Bombacaceae <4/4>, or Sterculiaceae <5/5>, or Tiliaceae
<1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/7>.
(53) Legg and Lovi (1968); Legg and Lovi (1969); Tinsley and Wharton (1958).
(54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 28-85 days <at 2°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Adomako et al. (1983); Lot et
al. (1991), Hagen et al. (1993). (61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (65) Virions 130 nm in length. (71) Virions 28 nm wide. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
218 S. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (91)
Total genome size 7.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 7.4 kb. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Lot et al. (1991).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31559. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L14546
Em(40)_vi:CSHCG Gb(84)_vi:CSHCG Cacao swollen shoot virus polyprotein gene,
complete circular genome. 1/94 7,161bp. 1 sequence. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
absent from infected cells. (179) Badnavirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: banana streak, rice tungro bacilliform, taro
bacilliform, yam internal brown spotting and yucca bacilliform viruses. (187)
Adomako, D., Lesemann, D.E. and Paul, H.L. (1983). Ann. appl. Biol. 103: 109.
Brunt, A.A. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 10, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A. and
Kenten, R.H. (1960). Virology 12: 328. Brunt, A.A. and Kenten, R.H. (1962).
Ann. appl. Biol. 50: 749. Brunt, A.A. and Kenten, R.H. (1963). Virology 19:
388. Brunt, A.A., Kenten, R.H. and Nixon, H.L. (1964). J. gen. Microbiol. 36:
303. Hagen, L.S., Jacquemond, M., Lepingle, A., Lot, H. and Tepfer, M. (1993).

Cacao yellow mosaic tymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: CYMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
77.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Theobroma cacao. (9) From Giehuna, Sierra
Leone. (10) By Blencowe et al. (1963). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Theobroma
cacao leaves with yellow blotches or mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Sierra Leone.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show local lesions, mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
local lesions; systemic chlorosis. Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local
lesions; not systemic. Nicandra physalodes, Nicotiana clevelandii,
Catharanthus roseus systemic chlorosis. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, Physalis floridana. (45)
Catharanthus roseus, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicandra physalodes, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Theobroma cacao. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa
(L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W). (47) Adansonia
digitata, or Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Ceiba pentandra, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Theobroma cacao, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cucumis
sativus, or Dactylis glomerata, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium perenne, or

or Trifolium incarnatum, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Apocynaceae
<1/1>, or Bombacaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/6>, or Solanaceae <3/11>, or Sterculiaceae
<1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>,
or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/3>, or Gramineae <5/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/6>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<8/11>, or Umbelliferae <1 /1>. (53) Brunt et al. (1965). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C.
(55) LIV: 16-32 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Brunt et al. (1965). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation

681bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 19788. (134) Coat.

Kenten, R.H. and Lovi, N.K. (1963). Trop. Agric., Trin. 40: 233. Brunt, A.A.
(1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 11, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A., Kenten, R.H.,

Cactus X potexvirus

      (1) R. Koenig, 1987. (2) Synonyms: barrel cactus virus (Attathom et al,

none. (13) Opuntia vulgaris, Austrocylindropuntia cylindrica, Pereskia

infected symptomlessly. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide <in cultivated cacti>. (38) Spreads in the North American region.

Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, mottle.
(43) Amaranthus caudatus necrotic local lesions; rarely systemic. Gomphrena

cell vacuoles <occasionally>. (174) Inclusions <cytoplasmic> present in

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (2) Synonyms: caper vein banding virus. (3)
Standard acronym: CapLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.005. (8) First

globosa, Celosia cristata. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L),
Nicotiana megalosiphon (W), N. benthamiana (W). (47) Capparis spinosa, or
Capparis spinosa var. rupestris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium

preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper

Gallitelli, D. and Di Franco, A. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119: 97. Laemmli, U.K.
(1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680.

Caraway latent (?) nepovirus

      (1) P. van Dijk and L. Bos, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CawLV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 14.0.T.1.006. (8) First reported in Carum carvi. (9) From the
Netherlands. (10) By Van Dijk and Bos (1989). (11) Symptoms <usually> none.
(13) Carum carvi symptomless. (24) Not transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in the Netherlands. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions followed by chlorotic and often necrotic systemic symptoms. (43)
Celosia argentea, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local and systemic
necrosis. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local lesions and systemic etching
and chlorosis. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum
necrotic local lesions without systemic symptoms. Gomphrena globosa chlorotic
/necrotic local lesions and chlorotic systemic symptoms. Nicotiana glutinosa
chlorotic local lesions without systemic symptoms. Apium graveolens var.
rapaceum systemic vein mosaic followed by latent infection. (44) Catharanthus
roseus, Vicia faba, Vigna unguiculata, Pimpinella anisum. (45) Chenopodium
quinoa, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (W),
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Phaseolus vulgaris
(L). (47) Ammi majus, or Apium graveolens, or Apium graveolens var. rapaceum,
or Beta vulgaris, or Carum carvi, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Catharanthus roseus, or Pimpinella anisum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or
Solanaceae <5/5>, or Umbelliferae <4/5>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Umbelliferae <1/5>. (53) Van Dijk and Bos
(1989). (55) LIV: 9-13 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
25 nm in diameter. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: electron microscopy, serology,
inoculation to Chenopodium quinoa and C. amaranticolor and estimation of
longevity in vitro to distinguish caraway latent virus from heracleum latent,
cow parsnip mosaic, tobacco streak, parsnip leafcurl, arabis mosaic and HV3
viruses. (187) Van Dijk, P. and Bos, L. (1989). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 95: 34.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992 and M.L. Skotnicki, 1993. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.DE.01. (8) First reported in Cardamine lilacina. (9) From Australia.
(10) By Skotnicki et al. (1992, 1993). (13) Cardamine lilacina chlorotic leaf

Australia. (43) Arabidopsis thaliana, Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Cardamine
lilacina, Iberis coronaria chlorotic leaf flecking. (44) Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, Phaseolus vulgaris and Pisum sativum. (47) Arabidopsis
thaliana, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Cardamine lilacina, or Iberis
coronaria. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum. (50) Cruciferae <4/5>. (51) Cruciferae <1/5>, or

Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter.

Sequence database accession code(s): L16015 Em(40)_vi:CDKCG Gb(84)_vi:CDKCG
Cardamine chlorotic fleck carmovirus genome, including replicase, coat
protein, p8 protein, 1 sequence. (179) Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: turnip
crinkle virus. (184) The viral RNA shows significant sequence homology with
those of turnip crinkle and carnation mottle viruses but not with those of
cymbidium ringspot, tomato bushy stunt, turnip yellow mosaic and southern bean
mosaic viruses. (187) Skotnicki, M.L., Mackenzie, A.M., Torronen, M., Brunt,
A.A. and Gibbs, A.J. (1992). Australas. Pl. Path. 21: 120; Skotnicki, M.L.,

Cardamine latent (?) carlavirus

      (1) P.L. Guy, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: CaLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.T.1.007. (8) First reported in Cardamine spp. (9) From the Snowy
Mountains, NSW, Australia. (10) By Guy and Gibbs (1985). (13) Cardamine
lilacina ssp. B and C latent. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia <southern New South Wales, but probably
not in Tasmania>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show local lesions vein-clearing. (43) Chenopodium
quinoa large local lesions; not systemic. Sinapis alba cv. White Mustard
systemic vein clearing with leaves malformed. (44) Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis. (45) Cardamine lilacina spp. B and C. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L);
Sinapis alba (W). (47) Cardamine, or Cardamine lilacina <ssp. B, C>, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Sinapis alba. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Bellis perennis, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Catalpa bignonioides, or Clarkia amoena, or
Cucumis sativus, or Delphinium hybridum, or Eucalyptus cloeziana, or Euphorbia
marginata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae
<3/4>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Bignoniaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>,
or Cruciferae <1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Myrtaceae <1/1>, or
Onagraceae <1 /1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Ranunculaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) <Possible>
Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: lily
symptomless virus. (187) Guy, P.L. and Gibbs, A.J. (1985). Australas. Pl.
Path. 34: 532.


Cardamom mosaic potyvirus

      (1) D. Gonsalves, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: CdMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Elettaria cardamomum. (9) From New
York, U.S.A. (10) By Gonsalves et al. (1986). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Elettaria cardamomum mosaic, possibly the same as the `Katte' or marble
disease described in India. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Pentalonia nigronervosa. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Guatemala and India <possibly>. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
mosaic. (43) Elettaria cardamomum systemic mosaic. (45) Elettaria cardamomum.
(47) Elettaria cardamomum. (50) Zingiberaceae <1/1>. (60) Method: Gonsalves et
al. (1986). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 700-720 nm. (74) Basic helix obscure. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome
unipartite. (133) Mr 37500 <also fragments of 32200 and 29000>. (134) Capsid.
(145) Method of preparation: Gonsalves et al. (1986). (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: zucchini yellow mosaic, papaya ringspot and
several legume potyviruses. (187) Gonsalves, D., Trujillo, E. and Hoch, H.C.
(1986). Plant Dis. 70: 65.


Carnation 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) R.G. Milne, V. Lisa and C. Marzachí, 1991. (3) Standard acronym:
CCV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.006. (8) First reported in Dianthus
caryophyllus. (9) From Italy. (10) By Lisa et al. (1980); Lisa et al. (1981a,
b). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Dianthus caryophyllus symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<probably, and also in cuttings>. (37) Probably distributed worldwide
<wherever carnations are grown>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (45)
Dianthus caryophyllus. (47) Dianthus caryophyllus. (50) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM effective.
(60) Method: Lisa et al. (1981). Grind leaves in 0.5M phosphate buffer, pH 7,
containing 0.02 M Na2SO3, 0.005 M EDTA and 0.01 M DIECA. Shake with equal
volume of CHCl3, separate the aqueous phase by low speed centrifugation, and
pellet the virus at 78000 x g for 150 mins. Resuspend, band in a CsCl density
gradient. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 29
nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.337 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome of three parts. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Lisa et al. (1981). (113) Additional factor Marzachí
et al. (1988). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll and probably all parts of the host
plant. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Alphacryptovirus:
Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: white clover 1 and 2, beet 1 and 2, ryegrass, all three hop
trefoil viruses and poinsettia cryptoviruses. (183) No named or clearly
identified strains, but one isolate from Israel had serologically related, but
distinct, virions. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: the dsRNA pattern is
diagnostic. The small isometric virions can be confused with those of
carnation mottle virus, especially its attenuated forms; however, serology,
especially ISEM plus decoration, can distinguish the two and identify
mixtures. N.B. all antisera to other carnation viruses may contain antibodies
to carnation cryptic virus, as most carnations are infected. (187) Boccardo,
G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171.
Francki, R.I.B., Milne, R.G. and Hatta, T. (1985). In: An Atlas of Plant
Viruses Vol. 2. CRC Press, Boca Raton, Florida, U.S.A. Lisa, V., Luisoni, E.
and Milne, R.G. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 175. Lisa, V., Boccardo, G. and Milne,
R.G. (1981). Virology 115: 410. Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1981).
Ann. appl. Biol. 98: 431. Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1986).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 315, 4 pp. Marzachí, C., Milne, R.G. and
Boccardo, G. (1988). Virology 165: 115.

      (3) Standard acronym: CCV-2. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.T.001. (8)

Carnation etched ring caulimovirus

      (1) J. Hammond, R.H. Lawson and J.R. Moran, 1987. (3) Standard acronym:
CERV. (5) ICTV decimal code 15.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Dianthus
caryophyllus. (9) From England. (10) By Hollings and Stone (1960). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Dianthus caryophyllus often symptomless but
sometimes necrotic flecks and lines. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by
the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28)
Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Hakkaart and Jordanova (1968);
it is more difficult to eliminate by heat therapy and meristem culture than
other carnation viruses. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic
flecks, lines and chlorotic blotches. (43) Saponaria vaccaria cv. Pink Beauty
red ringspots or necrotic flecks, spots, lines and rings. Dianthus
caryophyllus cv. Joker typical "etched ring" symptoms. Silene armeria systemic
necrotic lines and blotches. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana tabacum. (45)
Dianthus caryophyllus, Saponaria vaccaria (Hsu and Lawson, 1985). (46) No
reliable host is known) Saponaria vaccaria cv. Pink beauty, can be used if
plants are grown under controlled light and temperature, and flowering is
prevented (Hearon and Lawson, 1981). (47) Dianthus caryophyllus, or Saponaria
vaccaria, or Silene armeria. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum.
(50) Caryophyllaceae <3/3>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/3>.
(54) TIP: 80-85 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM best using UA. (60) Method: Hull et
al. (1976). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
45 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 206 S. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular and linear <also super coiled>. (91)
Total genome size 7.932 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 7.932 kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Lawson and Civerolo (1976, 1978); Hull and Donson (1982). (108) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10640. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X04658
Em(40)_vi:CERVDNA Gb(84)_vi:CERVDNA Carnation etched ring virus (CERV) DNA.
9/93 7,932bp. 1 sequence. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins <Lawson and Civerolo (1978)>. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Caulimovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
cauliflower mosaic, sweet potato caulimo-like and dahlia mosaic viruses
(Hollings and Stone, 1969). (184) Distant homologies in nucleic acid
hybridization tests with other caulimoviruses (Hull and Donson, 1982; Donson
and Hull, 1983). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: difficult to detect in
carnations. (187) Donson, J. and Hull, R. (1983). J. gen. Virol. 64: 2281.
Hakkaart, F.A. and Jordanova, J. (1968). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 74: 146. Hearon,
S.S. and Lawson, R.H. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 645. Hollings, M. and Stone,
O.M. (1960). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1960, p. 94. Hollings, M. and
Stone, O.M. (1969). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1968, p. 102. Hsu, H.T.
and Lawson, R.H. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 778. Hull, R. and Donson, J.
(1982). J. gen. Virol. 60: 125. Hull, R., Shepherd, R.J. and Harvey, J.D.
(1976). J. gen. Virol. 31: 9246. Lawson, R.H. and Civerolo, E.L. (1976). Acta
Hort. 59: 49. Lawson, R.H. and Civerolo, E.L. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 182, 4 pp. Lawson, R.H. and Civerolo, E.L. (1978). Phytopathology
68: 181.


Carnation Italian ringspot tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: tomato bushy stunt virus carnation

Dianthus caryophyllus transient chlorotic spots and rings in leaves and slight
stunting. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Germany, Italy, the UK, and the USA.

Italian ringspot virus genomic sequence for ORF1,2,3,4,5. 3/95 4,760bp. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 37000. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in mitochondria. (179) Tombusvirus:
Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: Tomato bushy stunt virus. (184) The viral genome has sequence
homology with that of tomato bushy stunt virus. (186) The virus occurs in some
rivers in Germany. (187) Buttner, C., Jacobi, V. and Koenig, R. (1987). J.
Phytopathology 118: 131. Gallitelli, D., Hull, R. and Koenig, R. (1985). J.
