Carnation latent carlavirus

      (1) J.R. Moran, 1987. (2) Synonyms: dulcamara A virus, dulcamara B virus
(Phillips and Brunt, 1981). (3) Standard acronym: CLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in Dianthus caryophyllus. (9) From England.
(10) By Kassanis (1955). (13) Dianthus caryophyllus few or no symptoms. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <but
sometimes is difficult to transmit from carnation because its sap contains
inhibitors of infection>. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide <wherever carnations are grown>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions,
mottle. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa small chlorotic local
lesions; systemic mottle. (45) Dianthus barbatus. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L); C. quinoa (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus
caryophyllus, or Gynura aurantiaca, or Nicotiana clevelandii. (50)
Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 2-3 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Wetter and Paul
(1961). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight <or slightly curved>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length.
(70) Virions of 650 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure.
(74) Basic helix obscure. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.3 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
167 S. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 8.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite.
(99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Wetter and Milne (1981). (116)
Nucleotide sequence references: Haylor et al. (1990). The nucleotide sequence
of the 3' proximal region of the genomic RNA has been reported. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 12164. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X55897
Em(40)_vi:CLVTUCRF Gb(84)_vi:CLVTUCRF Carnation latent virus (CLV) 3' terminal
ORF. 9/93 393bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000.
(145) Method of preparation: Paul (1973). (179) Carlavirus <type member>.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cactus 2, chrysanthemum B,
helenium S, hop latent, lilac mottle, lily symptomless, mulberry latent,
muskmelon vein necrosis, nerine latent, passiflora latent, pea streak, potato
M, potato S and red clover vein mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: narcissus latent, poplar mosaic, shallot
latent and honeysuckle latent viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: use
ISEM decoration to distinguish carnation latent from carnation vein mottle
virus. (187) Haylor, M.T., Brunt, A.A. and Coutts, R.H.A. (1990). Nucl. Acids
Res. 18: 6127. Kassanis, B. (1954). Nature, Lond. 173: 109. Kassanis, B.
(1955). Ann. appl. Biol. 43: 103. Kassanis, B. (1958). Ann. appl. Biol. 43:
103. Paul, H.L. (1974). Phytopath. Z. 80: 330. Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A.
(1981). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1980, p. 152. Wetter, C. (1971).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 61, 3 pp. Wetter, C. and Milne, R.G. (1981).
In: Handbook of Plant Virus Infections and Comparative Diagnosis, p 695; ed.
E. Kurstak. Elsevier, Amsterdam. Wetter, C. and Paul, H.L. (1961). Phytopath.
Z. 43: 207.


Carnation mottle carmovirus

      (1) J.H. Tremaine and J.R. Moran, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: CarMV. (4)
Strains: PSR, PR4 and also attenuated forms. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.004. (8) First reported in Dianthus spp. (9) From the U.K. (10) By
Kassanis (1955). (13) Dianthus caryophyllus, D. barbatus, Saponaria vaccaria
mild mottle. Begonia elatior, Begonia × cheimantha, Daphne odora, Dianthus
chinensis, D. superbus, Saponaria officinalis mottle. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic and necrotic local
lesions. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor small chlorotic local lesions.
Chenopodium quinoa, Atriplex hortensis chlorotic spots, systemic chlorotic
flecks, spots and malformation. Gomphrena globosa fawn necrotic dots.
Tetragonia tetragonioides small chlorotic and/or necrotic local lesions. (45)
Dianthus caryophyllus, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L);
C. quinoa (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Anagallis arvensis, or Antirrhinum
majus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Begonia elatior, or Begonia × cheimantha, or
Beta vulgaris, or Calandrinia grandiflora, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Daphne odora, or Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or
Dianthus chinensis, or Dianthus superbus, or Digitalis purpurea, or Glechoma
hederacea, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lunaria annua, or Lychnis chalcedonica, or
Lychnis dioica, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phytolacca
americana, or Primula malacoides, or Rumex obtusifolius, or Saponaria
officinalis, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Silene armeria, or Spinacia oleracea,
or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or
Trifolium repens. (48) Ageratum conyzoides, or Ajuga reptans, or Amsonia
tabernaemontana, or Apium graveolens <var. dulce>, or Aquilegia coerulea, or

Carnation necrotic fleck closterovirus

      (1) J.R. Moran and A.A. Brunt, 1987. (2) Synonyms: carnation yellow
fleck virus (Bar-Joseph et al., 1976), carnation streak virus. (3) Standard
acronym: CNFV. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in
Dianthus caryophyllus. (9) From Japan. (10) By Inouye and Mitsuhata (1973).
(13) Dianthus caryophyllus mottling, streaking becoming necrotic; grey streaks
or red necrotic flecks. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent
manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <with
difficulty>. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (36)
Studies reported by Smookler and Loebenstein (1974); Poupet et al. (1975).
(37) Probably distributed worldwide <wherever carnations are grown>. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
vein clearing and flecking. (43) Dianthus chinensis, D. barbatus vein clearing
and flecking after 3-5 weeks. (44) Chenopodium quinoa. (45) Dianthus barbatus.
(46) Dianthus barbatus (L). (47) Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus,
or Dianthus chinensis, or Lychnis chalcedonica, or Montia perfoliata, or
Silene armeria. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Tetragonia tetragonioides.
(50) Caryophyllaceae <5/5>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53)
Bar-Joseph et al. (1979). (54) TIP: 40-45 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
virions fragile and do not stain well in carnation sap. (60) Method:
Bar-Joseph and Smookler (1976); Inouye (1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 1400-1500 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide.
(74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
122-128 S <80 S for broken virions>. (79) Density 1.325 g cm3 in CsCl. (84)
Virions contain 5.15 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94.85 % protein. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 12.8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 12.8 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Bar-Joseph and
Smookler (1976); Bar-Joseph et al. (1976). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133)
Mr 23500. (145) Method of preparation: Bar-Joseph et al. (1979); Short et al.
(1977). (147) Amino acid composition: Bar-Joseph et al. (1979); Short et al.
(1977). (171) Virions found in epidermis and phloem mainly in the parts of the
plant that show symptoms. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are membranous bodies. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Closterovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: beet
yellows and wheat yellow leaf viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: citrus tristeza and heracleum latent viruses and all
capilloviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: virions of CNFV are usually
found in large numbers in carnation sap and are easily detected by electron
microscopy. (187) Bar-Joseph, M., Inouye, T. and Sutton, J. (1976). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 60: 851. Bar-Joseph, M., Garnsey, S.M. and Gonsalves, D. (1979). Adv.
Virus Res. 25: 93. Bar-Joseph, M., Loebenstein, G. and Cohen, J. (1976). Proc.
7th. Conf. Int. Org. Citrus Virol., p. 39. Bar-Joseph, M. and Smookler, M.
(1976). Phytopathology 66: 835. Inouye, T. (1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses
No. 136, 3 pp. Inouye, T. and Mitsuhata, K. (1973). Ber. Ohara Inst. Landw.
Biol. 15: 195. Poupet, A., Cardin, L., Marais, A. and Cadilhac, B. (1975).
Ann. Phytopath. 7: 277. Short, M.N., Hull, R., Bar-Joseph, M. and Rees, M.W.
(1977). Virology 77: 408. Smookler, M. and Loebenstein, G. (1974).
Phytopathology 7: 277.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (2) Synonyms: carnation bacilliform virus. (3)

(1976). (13) Dianthus sp. (39) Spreads in New Zealand. (47) Dianthus barbatus,
or Dianthus caryophyllus. (50) Caryophyllaceae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or

Carnation ringspot dianthovirus

      (1) J.H. Tremaine and J.R. Moran, 1985. (2) Synonyms: Anjermozaick
virus. (3) Standard acronym: CRSV. (4) Strains: N, A and R. (5) ICTV decimal
code 23.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in Dianthus spp. (9) From the U.K. (10)
By Kassanis (1955). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dianthus caryophyllus, D.
barbatus leaf mottling and ringspotting, plant stunting and distortion, flower
distortion. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode
<Fritsche et al. (1979), Trudgill et al. (1983)>. (17) Transmitted by
Longidorus elongatus, L. macrosoma and Xiphinema diversicaudatum; reported,
but questioned. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide
<wherever carnations are grown>. (38) Spreads in the Central Asian region, the
Eurasian region, and the North American region. (39) Spreads in India. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Australia. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic and necrotic local lesions rings and flecks, sometimes systemic.
(43) Dianthus barbatus, Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris local and
systemic chlorotic and necrotic lesions rings and flecks. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides necrotic lesions, usually
not systemic. Vigna unguiculata necrotic local lesions, systemic mottling,
necrotic flecking and distortion. (45) Dianthus barbatus, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L); C. quinoa (L); Vigna unguiculata (L). (47) Alonsoa
warscewiczii, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Callistephus

Carnation vein mottle potyvirus

      (1) J.R. Moran, M. Verhoyen and G. van Caneghem, 1987. (3) Standard
acronym: CVMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.013. (8) First reported in
Dianthus caryophyllus. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Kassanis (1954). (13)
Dianthus caryophyllus chlorotic and darker green spots, flecks and mottling.
Flower breaking and malformation. Dianthus barbatus mottle. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Hollings et al.
(1977); Poupet et al. (1981). Stocks freed from virus by tip propagation and
heat treatment. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <wherever carnations are
grown>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorotic and necrotic local lesions rarely systemic. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic and necrotic local lesions; not systemic.
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic spots, local lesions; systemic spotting. Silene
pendula necrotic local lesions, systemic chlorotic or necrotic spots
(Tochihara et al., 1975). (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Dianthus barbatus. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lychnis
chalcedonica, or Plantago lanceolata, or Plantago major, or Portulaca
oleracea, or Rumex obtusifolius, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Silene armeria, or
Silene pendula, or Silene vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Ageratum
houstonianum, or Alonsoa warscewiczii, or Anchusa azurea, or Antirrhinum
majus, or Apium graveolens, or Aquilegia coerulea, or Arachis hypogaea, or

juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Calendula officinalis, or

or Oenothera biennis, or Oxalis corniculata, or Papaver rhoeas, or Pelargonium
× domesticum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox
drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Phytolacca americana, or Pisum sativum,

hybrida, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea
mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <8/10>,
or Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Plantaginaceae <2/3>, or Polygonaceae <1/5>, or
Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/3>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Asclepiadaceae <2/2>, or Begoniaceae <1/1>, or
Boraginaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/10>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/7>, or
Compositae <11/11>, or Convolvulaceae <3 /3>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Dipsacaceae <1/1>, or Geraniaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/8>, or Lythraceae
<1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Nyctaginaceae <1 /1>, or Onagraceae <1/1>, or
Oxalidaceae <1/1>, or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or
Plantaginaceae <1/3>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <4/5>, or
Primulaceae <1/1>, or Ranunculaceae <1 /1>, or Resedaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <12/12>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>, or Verbenaceae <1/1>. (53) Hollings and Stone (1977);
Tochihara et al. (1975). (54) TIP: 55-65 °C. (55) LIV: 2-10 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 2-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Hollings
and Stone (1971); Borges et al. (1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 790 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 144 S. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base composition 21 % G. (101)
Base composition 25 % A. (102) Base composition 28 % C. (103) Base composition
29 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000-34800. (171) Virions found
in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in unusual sites. (173)
Virions found in in a single, thin layer between two membranes just inside the
tonoplast. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Dense bands, loops and circles
(Weintraub, 1970) or tubular structures (Bergtrup, 1976). (177) They do not
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: elongated nuclei with
abnormally electron dense areas of chromatin. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean
yellow mosaic, pepper veinal mottle, pea mosaic, freesia streak, turnip mosaic
(cabbage black ring strain) and watermelon mosaic 2 viruses (Borges, 1981).
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: turnip mosaic (tigridia
mosaic strain), narcissus degeneration, clover yellow vein, narcissus yellow
stripe, hippeastrum mosaic, potato veinal necrosis, iris mosaic, potato Y,
sugar beet mosaic, tobacco severe etch and lettuce mosaic viruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: for electron microscopy use leaf sap, virus aggregates
are found in plant membranes. CVMV can be distinguished from carnation latent
virus either by ISEM decoration or by inoculation to Chenopodium
amaranticolor, which carnation latent infects systemically, but CVMV does not.
(187) Begtrup, J. (1976). Phytopath. Z. 86: 127. Borges, M. de L.V., Sequeira,
J.C. and Louro, D. (1981). Bolm Soc. broteriana 53: 933. Hollings, M. and
Stone, O.M. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 78, 4 pp. Hollings, M.,
Stone, O.M., Atkey, P.T. and Barton, R.J. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol. 85: 59.
Hooper, G.R. and Weise, M.V. (1972). Virology 47: 664. Kassanis, B. (1954).
Nature, Lond. 173: 1097. Poupet, A., Jacquemont, R., Beck, D., Onesto, J.P.
and Delomon, D. (1981). C. r. Séanc. Acad. Agric. Fr. 65: 427. Tochihara, H.,
Idei, T., Yabuki, S. and Fukumoto, F. (1975). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 41:
390. Weintraub, M. and Ragetli, H.W.S. (1970). Virology 40: 868.


Carnation yellow stripe (?) necrovirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CYSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 44.0.1.T.004. (8) First reported in Dianthus caryophyllus. (9) From
Apulia, southern Italy. (10) By Rana et al. (1977). (13) Dianthus caryophyllus
cv. Pink Shocking yellow leaf stripes. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor, C. album small chlorotic
local lesions, becoming necrotic. Chenopodium ambrosioides bright red local
lesions. Gomphrena globosa red-rimmed necrotic local lesions. Vigna
unguiculata systemic mosaic, chlorotic vein-banding. Saponaria vaccaria
chlorotic local lesions. (44) Hordeum vulgare, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. rustica, Vigna radiata. (45) Vigna unguiculata. (46) Vigna
unguiculata (W), Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L), Gomphrena
globosa (L), Dianthus barbatus (L). (47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lupinus albus, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Avena sativa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Dianthus barbatus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Triticum durum, or Vigna radiata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <3/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <1/3>. (51) Caryophyllaceae
<1/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or Solanaceae <2/3>. (53) Gallitelli et al.
(1979). (54) TIP: 80 °C. (55) LIV: 60 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 7. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Gallitelli et al. (1979). (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 99-105 S.
(79) Density 1.369 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.61. (84) Virions
contain 18 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 72 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli: phenol-SDS. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 27000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli
(1970). (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm and membranous bodies. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) <Possible> Necrovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: tobacco necrosis virus (grape strain). (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: inoculation onto Chenopodium quinoa and serology. (187) Gallitelli,
D., Castellano, M.A., Di Franco, A. and Rana, G.L. (1979). Phytopathol. Medit.
18: 31. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Rana, G.L., Di Franco,
A. and Castellano, M.A. (1977). Ann. Fac. Agr. Univ. Bari, 29: 397.


Carrot latent nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CtLtV (CLV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 62.U.P.0.005. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From
Japan. (10) By Ohki et al. (1978). (13) Daucus carota symptomless infection.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Brachycaudus (Semiaphis) heraclei. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (43)
Daucus carota symptomless infection. (45) Daucus carota. (47) Daucus carota.
(50) Umbelliferae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions
enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 220 nm <in
sections>. (71) Virions 70 nm wide <in vivo>. (171) Virions found in all parts
of the host plant. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (179) <Possible>
Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Ohki, S.T.,
Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1978). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 44: 22.


Carrot mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CtMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.014. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From Czechoslovakia.
(10) By Chod (1965a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Daucus carota chlorotic
spots and mosaic of leaves, and yellow spots on petioles. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
pisum, Cavariella aegopodii, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the former
Czechoslovakia. (43) Vigna unguiculata chlorotic flecks and chlorosis of
leaves. Chenopodium quinoa local chlorotic lesions. (47) Apium graveolens, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or
Daucus carota, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>.
(54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days <at 20-22°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 740 nm. (71)
Virions 15 nm wide. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187)
Chod, J. (1965a). Biologia Pl. 7: 463. Chod, J. (1965b). Ochr. Rost. 1: 49.
Chod, J. (1966). Biologia Pl. 8: 53.


Carrot mottle mimic umbravirus

      (1) M.J. Gibbs, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal code 78.0.1.DE.01. (8) First
reported in Daucus carota. (9) From New South Wales, Australia. (10) By Gibbs
(1991; 1995). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Daucus carota systemic yellowing and
mottling, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by probably Cavariella aegopodii. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (29) Virus requires, for
vector transmission, a helper virus <carrot red leaf luteovirus>. (30) The
virus genome is probably transcapsidated in the virions of the helper virus.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Australia, New Zealand and the U.S.A.; but may have
been confused with carrot mottle umbravirus. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein necrosis.
(43) Nicotiana megalosiphon necrotic ringspots, systemic necrotic and
chlorotic lesions, mostly along major veins. (45) Nicotiana megalosiphon, N.
clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana megalosiphon (W), N. clevelandii (W). (47)
Anthriscus cerefolium, or Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus carota, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon. (50) Solanaceae <4/4>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions <and these have the coat protein of carrot red leaf
luteovirus>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 4.203 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 4.203 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by as dsRNA by
Franklin column chromatography using Whatman CF-11 fibrous cellulose powder;
as described for carrot mottle umbravirus by Murant et al. (1985). (100) Base
composition 27 % G. (101) Base composition 25 % A. (102) Base composition 25.5
% C. (103) Base composition 22.4 % U. (108) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with proteases. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional
factor not required for infectivity. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity.
(116) Nucleotide sequence references: Gibbs (1995). (119) Features of the
genome: Four ORFs. ORF1 encodes a protein that may be part of the viral
replicase, ORF2 encodes the RNA dependent RNA polymerase, ORF3 encodes a
protein of unknown function and ORF4 encodes the movement protein gene. ORF2
overlaps ORF1 and is translated after a -1 ribosomal frameshift, ORFs 3&4 also
overlap and are translated from a sub-genomic RNA. (120) Nongenomic nucleic
acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA
found in infected cells. (124) C. 1.5kb co-terminal with 3' end of the genome.
(125) 2 virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (126) Size of
largest virus specified dsRNA 4.2 kbp. (127) 2nd largest <c.> 1.5 kbp. (132)
Virion protein(s) none. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are membranous bodies. (177) They do not contain virions. (179)
Umbravirus. (184) Genome sequence comparisons show the virus to be most
closely related to RNA-2 of pea enation mosaic enamovirus, in addition the
polymerase sequences show affinities to carmoviruses, dianthoviruses, type 1
and 2 luteoviruses, necroviruses, machlomoviruses, tombusviruses, beet western
yellows ST9 associated-RNA and oat chlorotic stunt virus. Comparisons of
movement protein sequences show affinities with bromo- and cucumoviruses.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: often confused with carrot mottle umbravirus,
distinguished by infection of Nicotiana megalosiphon and N. benthamiana;
carrot mottle mimic virus induces a mild chlorotic mottle in N. benthamiana
and severe symptoms in N megalosiphon, carrot mottle virus induces a more
severe chlorotic mottle in N. benthamiana, but no symptoms in N. megalosiphon.
(187) Gibbs, M.J. (1991). Grad. Dip. Thesis, Aust. Nat. Univ. Gibbs, M.J.
(1995). D. Phil. Thesis, Univ. Oxford. Murant, A.F., Waterhouse, P.M.,
Raschke, J.H. and Robinson, D.J. (1985). J. gen. Virol. 66: 1575.


Carrot mottle umbravirus

      (1) P.M. Waterhouse, 1986. (2) Synonyms: carrot motley dwarf virus
(Stubbs, 1948; 1952). (3) Standard acronym: CMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
78.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From England. (10) By
Watson et al. (1964). (13) Daucus carota, Anethum graveolens, Anthriscus
sylvestris symptomless but, with CRLV, induces yellowing and reddening. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Cavariella aegopodii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does
not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the
progeny of the vector. (29) Virus requires, for vector transmission, a helper
virus <carrot red leaf luteovirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, the
UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show local lesions, mottling. (43) Chenopodium quinoa
local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic vein etching. Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. `The Prince' brown local lesions. Coriandrum sativum systemic mottle. (44)
Lactuca sativa. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L);
Nicotiana clevelandii (W); Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Anethum graveolens, or
Anthriscus sylvestris, or Apium graveolens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus
carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Petroselinum
crispum, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (48) Lactuca sativa. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<4/4>, or Umbelliferae <6/6>. (51) Compositae <1/1>. (53) Waterhouse (1981);
Watson et al. (1964); Murant et al. (1969, 1973); Murant (1975); Frowd and
Tomlinson (1972). (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: 0.2-1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (60)
Method: Murant et al. (1969). (61) Virions unusually shaped. (62) Virions
virions not identified; vesicles reported, but unconfirmed. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
270 S. (79) Density 1.15 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.75 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.75 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
47736. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (178) Other
cellular changes: outgrowths from plasmodesmatal, seen by light microscopy.
(179) Umbravirus. (184) CMotV resembles viruses such as lettuce speckles
mottle and groundnut rosette and other sap-transmitted components of
luteovirus-containing virus symbioses; the name umbravirus has been proposed
for these viruses. Preliminary sequence information indicates a relationship
with the carmo/tombus/luteovirus cluster (M.J. Gibbs, unpublished text). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: Lettuce speckles mottle virus infects manually
inoculated lettuce, CMotV does not. (186) Carrot motley dwarf virus (Stubbs,
1948; 1952) is a complex of carrot red leaf and carrot mottle viruses. (187)
Frowd, J.A. and Tomlinson, J.A. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 72: 177.Halk, E.L.,
Robinson, D.J. and Murant, A.F. (1979). J. gen. Virol. 45: 383. Murant, A.F.
(1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 137, 4 pp. Murant, A.F. (1975). Can.
Pl. Dis. Surv. 55: 103. Murant, A.F., Goold, R.A., Roberts, I.M. and Cathro,
J. (1969). J. gen. Virol. 4: 329. Murant, A.F., Roberts, I.M. and Goold, R.A.
(1973). J. gen. Virol. 21: 269. Murant, A.F., Waterhouse, P.M., Raschke, J.H.
and Robinson, D.J. (1985). J. gen. Virol. 66: 1575. Stubbs, L.L. (1948). Aust.
J. sci. Res. 1: 303. Stubbs, L.L. (1952). Aust. J. sci. Res. 5: 399.
Waterhouse, P.M. (1981). Ph.D. Thesis, University of Dundee, U.K., 244 pp.
Watson, M.A., Serjeant, E.P. and Lennon, E.A. (1964). Ann. appl. Biol. 54:
153.


Carrot red leaf luteovirus

      (1) P.M. Waterhouse, 1986. (2) Synonyms: carrot motley dwarf virus
(Stubbs, 1948; 1952). (3) Standard acronym: CaRLV (CRLV, CtRLV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 39.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From
England. (10) By Watson et al. (1964). (11) Symptoms persist and vary
seasonally. (13) Daucus carota, Anethum graveolens chlorosis or reddening of
older leaves, but mostly symptomless. Anthriscus sylvestris reddening of leaf
margins. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus can help the vector
transmission of another virus <carrot mottle umbravirus>. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, the
UK, and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show yellowing, reddening. (43) Anthriscus cerefolium,
Apium leptophyllum, Coriandrum sativum yellowing and reddening of older
leaves. (44) Apium graveolens, Petroselinum crispum. (45) Anthriscus
cerefolium. (46) Anthriscus cerefolium (W); Apium leptophyllum (W); Coriandrum
sativum (W). (47) Anethum graveolens, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or Anthriscus
sylvestris, or Apium leptophyllum, or Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus carota.
(48) Apium graveolens, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Chenopodium capitatum,
or Chenopodium murale, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Petroselinum crispum, or Raphanus sativus, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Trifolium pratense. (50) Umbelliferae <6/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>, or Umbelliferae <2/8>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Waterhouse and Murant (1981). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile, or angular in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 104 S. (79) Density
1.403 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 28 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 72 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.75 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 5.75 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Murant et al. (1985). (132) Virion protein(s) four. (133) Mr
<of the largest> 60000. (134) Component 1. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 50000.
(136) Minor component 2. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 40000. (138) Minor component
3. (139) Mr of 4th largest 25000. (140) Coat protein (major component). (145)
Method of preparation: Murant et al. (1985). (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem and companion cells. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies and membranous bodies.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: barley yellow dwarf-RPV and beet western
yellows viruses moderately closely; tobacco necrotic dwarf, potato leafroll
and bean leaf roll viruses distantly; and soybean dwarf, barley yellow
dwarf-MAV viruses very distantly. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: This virus
is the only luteovirus known to infect Apiaceae and has a very narrow host
range. It is usually found in a complex with CMotV, which unlike CRLV is sap
transmitted. (186) Carrot motley dwarf virus (Stubbs, 1948; 1952) is a complex
of carrot red leaf and carrot mottle viruses. (187) Murant, A.F. (1974).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 137, 4 pp. Murant, A.F. and Roberts, I.M.
(1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 92: 343. Murant, A.F., Waterhouse, P.M., Raschke,
J.H. and Robinson, D.J. (1985). J. gen. Virol. 66: 1575. Stubbs, L.L. (1948).
Aust. J. sci. Res. 1: 303. Stubbs, L.L. (1952). Aust. J. Sci. Res. 5: 399.
Stubbs, L.L., Smith, P.R. and O'Loughlin, G.T. (1983). Abstr. 4th Int. Congr.
Pl. Path. Melbourne, Australia, 1983, p. 123. Waterhouse, P.M. (1981). Ph.D.
Thesis, University of Dundee, U.K., pp. 244. Waterhouse, P.M. and Murant, A.F.
(1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 97: 191. Waterhouse, P.M. (1985). Australas. Pl.
Path. 14: 32. Waterhouse, P.M. and Murant, A.F. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 249, 4 pp. Watson, M.A., Serjeant, E.P. and Lennon, E.A. (1964).
Ann. appl. Biol. 54: 153.


Carrot temperate 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CTeV-1. (5) ICTV decimal
code 49.0.3.0.007. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From Japan. (10)
By Natsuaki et al. (1983). (13) Daucus carota symptomless. (31) Virus not

Umbelliferae <1/1>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 30 nm in diameter. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded.
(92) Genome of three parts. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) :
Partitiviridae. (184) The dsRNA genome of the virus shows no significant
homology with those of carrot temperate 2, 3, 4 and 5 cryptoviruses. (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: the virus often occurs in mixed infections with
other carrot temperate cryptoviruses. (187) Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni,

Carrot temperate 2 betacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CTeV-2. (5) ICTV decimal

By Natsuaki et al. (1990). (13) Daucus carota symptomless infection. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by

spread, in Japan. (47) Daucus carota. (50) Umbelliferae <1/1>. (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Doublestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.95 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two
parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 2.55 kb <pairs>. (94)
The 2nd largest 2.4 kb <pairs>. (179) Betacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) :
Partitiviridae. (184) The viral dsRNA genome has no detectable sequence
homology with those of carrot temperate 1, 3 and 4 cryptoviruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: the virus often occurs in mixed infections with other
carrot temperate cryptoviruses. (187) Natsuaki, T., Muroi, Y., Okuda, S. and
Teranaka, M. (1990). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 56: 354.

Carrot thin leaf potyvirus

      (1) W.E. Howell and A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CTLV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.014. (8) First reported in Daucus carota. (9) From
Washington State, U.S.A. (10) By Howell and Mink (1976). (11) Symptoms
persist. (12) Symptoms malformation, leaf narrowing and some vein clearing.
(13) Daucus carota, Conium maculatum symptomless. Daucus carota ssp. sativus
leaflet lobes malformed and narrow, vein clearing and some chlorotic spots.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Cavariella aegopodii, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Howell and Mink (1977a and
b). (39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic thread like leaflets,
twisted leaves, vein clearing in Apiaceae; chlorotic and necrotic local
lesions in Chenopodium. (43) Anthriscus cerefolium thread like leaflets. Apium
australe chlorosis and death of older leaves. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic and
necrotic local lesions. C. amaranticolor chlorotic and red ring local lesions.
Coriandrum sativum, Daucus carota ssp. sativus thread like leaflets, vein
clearing. Pastinaca sativa, Petroselinum crispum, Zinnia elegans symptomless.
(44) Apium graveolens var. dulce, Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium,
Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Coriandrum
sativum, Daucus carota. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L),
Coriandrum sativum (W), Daucus carota (W). (47) Anthriscus cerefolium, or
Apium australe, or Atriplex hortensis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium endiva, or Conium maculatum, or Coriandrum
sativum, or Daucus carota, or Daucus carota ssp. sativus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum
crispum, or Pisum sativum, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Apium graveolens, or Apium
graveolens var. dulce, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,
or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum,
or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum
sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Sesbania exaltata, or Solanum melongena, or
Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium pratense, or Vicia sativa. (50) Chenopodiaceae <6/8>, or Compositae
<2/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/8>, or Solanaceae <1/12>, or
Umbelliferae <8/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/8>, or Compositae <1/3>, or
Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/8>,
or Solanaceae <11 /12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <2/10>. (53)
Howell and Mink (1976; 1977a). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Howell and
Mink (1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 736 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations, or two sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.18. (84) Virions contain 4 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 96 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves, stems and roots. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean common
mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, celery mosaic, clover yellow vein, iris mild
mosaic, parsnip mosaic, pea seed-borne mosaic, peanut mottle, potato Y,
soybean mosaic, sugarcane mosaic, tobacco etch and turnip mosaic viruses.
(187) Howell, W.E. (1974). Proc. Am. Phytopath. Soc. 1: 38. Howell, W.E. and
Mink, G.I. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 949. Howell, W.E. and Mink, G.I. (1976).

Carrot yellow leaf (?) closterovirus

      (1) P. van Dijk and L. Bos, 1991. (2) Synonyms: hogweed 6 virus,
heracleum 6 capillovirus. (3) Standard acronym: CYLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Daucus carota ssp. sativus. (9) From
Japan. (10) By Yamashita et al. (1976). (12) Symptoms yellowing in cultivated
Daucus carota and no visible symptoms in wild umbelliferae. (13) Daucus carota
yellowing and reddening. Heracleum sphondylium, Anthriscus sylvestris
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii, C. pastinacae, C. theobaldi. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (29)
Virus can help the vector transmission of another virus <heracleum latent (?)
closterovirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in Japan, the Netherlands and the U.K. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
yellowing and necrosis. (43) Anthriscus cerefolium, Coriandrum sativum,
Pimpinella anisum vein necrosis, severe leaf rolling and yellowing, leading to
plant death. Nicotiana benthamiana necrotic local lesions and systemic lethal
necrosis and yellowing. N. clevelandii necrotic local lesions without systemic
symptoms. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
occidentalis, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Anthriscus cerefolium (W), Coriandrum
sativum (W), Nicotiana benthamiana (W). (47) Anthriscus cerefolium, or
Anthriscus sylvestris, or Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus carota, or Daucus
carota ssp. sativus, or Heracleum sphondylium, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Pimpinella anisum. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Vicia faba. (50) Solanaceae <2/5>, or Umbelliferae <7/7>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/5>. (53) Van Dijk and Bos (1989). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: virions visible without
fixation and staining by PTA. (60) Method: Murant et al. (1984). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 1650 nm <±45 nm>. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.7
nm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (168) Acts as helper
for another virus. (169) Acts as a helper for heracleum latent virus. (170)
Acts as a helper by possibly phenotypic mixing. (171) Virions found in leaves
and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (178) Other
cellular changes: characteristic vesicles and morphological changes of
mitochondria in phloem cells (Yamashita et al., 1976). (179) <Possible>
Closterovirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: transfer by aphid to Anthriscus
cerefolium or Coriandrum sativum, and test these on Chenopodium quinoa, which
is susceptible to heracleum latent virus but not CYLV, and Nicotiana
benthamiana, which is susceptible to CYLV not heracleum latent virus. CYLV has
flexuous virions, anthriscus yellows virus has isometric ones. (187) Bem, F.
and Murant, A.F. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 92: 237. Van Dijk, P. and Bos, L.
(1985). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 91: 169. Van Dijk, P. and Bos, L. (1989). Neth. J.
Pl. Path. 95(2): 34. Murant, A.F. (1981). Ann. Rep. Scottish Hort. Res. Inst.
1980, p. 102. Murant, A.F. (1983). Ann. Rep. Scottish. Crop Res. Inst. 1982,
p. 191. Murant, A.F., Duncan, G.H. and Raschké, J.H. (1984). Ann. Rep.
Scottish Crop Res. Inst. 1983, p. 188. Yamashita, S., Ohki, S.T., Doi, Y. and
Yora, K. (1976). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 42: 382.


Cassava African mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. Revised by B.D. Harrison, 1989. (2)
Synonyms: cassava latent virus, cassava mosaic virus, cassava African mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: ACMV. (4) Strains: type strain isolate 844 (Bock
et al., 1978); Kenya coast (C) strain (Bock et al., 1981), Angola defective
isolates (Sequeira and Harrison, 1982). (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.004.
(8) First reported in Manihot esculenta. (10) By Warburg (1894); see also
Storey and Nichols (1938); Harrison et al. (1977); Bock et al. (1978). (11)
Symptoms persist and vary cyclically over a few weeks. (13) Manihot esculenta,
Jatropha multifida severe mosaic. Hewittia sublobata mosaic (probably the
natural host of the Kenya coast strain; Bock et al., 1981). Laportea
(=Fluerya) aestuans bright chlorosis (possibly the natural host in Nigeria;
Anon., 1979). Manihot glaziovii mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci (Chant, 1958;
Dubern, 1979). (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector <Dubern, 1979>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <with difficulty to cassava (Bock
and Woods, 1983) but more readily to Nicotiana benthamiana>. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Bock and Guthrie (1982); Bock (1984); Robertson (1984). Incidence
often exceeds 80%, but only a quarter of the cuttings of infected susceptible
cassava cultivars yield healthy plants (Bock, 1983). Virus-free cassava plants
can be produced by heat treatment and meristem-tip culture. Some cassava
genotypes resist infection. Two methods of control are advocated; in Kenya
(Bock and Guthrie, 1982; Bock, 1983) and the Ivory Coast (Fargette et al.,
1985), virus-free planting material of cultivars with moderate resistance to
infection is used, whereas in Nigeria cultivars with superior resistance to,
and tolerance of, infection are favoured (Hahn et al., 1980). (38) Spreads in
the African region. (39) Spreads in Angola, Kenya, Nigeria, and the
Seychelles. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions, systemic mosaic, leaf curling.
(43) Manihot esculenta bright mosaic 3-5 weeks after inoculation by whitefly
or by grafting. Leaves with symptoms may alternate with leaves showing few or
no symptoms. Nicotiana benthamiana diffuse chlorotic lesions then systemic
leaf curling, malformation and blotching. Nicotiana clevelandii the type
strain may induce chlorotic local lesions then severe malformation, and
irregular yellow veinbanding and blotching. The Kenya coast strain is milder
and less readily transmitted. Datura stramonium type strain induces chlorotic
and necrotic local lesions then systemic veinbanding, leaf curling and
malformation. (44) Cucurbita pepo, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Gomphrena
globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Manihot esculenta, Nicotiana benthamiana.
(46) Datura stramonium (L) for type strain; Nicotiana benthamiana (W) for
Kenya coast strain. (47) Datura ferox, or Datura stramonium, or Hewittia
sublobata, or Jatropha multifida, or Laportea aestuans, or Manihot esculenta,
or Manihot glaziovii, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum nigrum. (48) Atriplex
hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Ipomoea setosa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis peruviana, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum
melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Zea mays. (50)
Convolvulaceae <1/2>, or Euphorbiaceae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <10/17>, or
Urticaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/4>, or
Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <7 /17>. (53) Storey and Nichols (1938); Bock and Woods (1983);
Bock (1983); Bock et al. (1978); Bock et al. (1981); Anon. (1979); Dubern
(1979). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3 <type
strain in sap of Nicotiana clevelandii>. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed
by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: virions best detected by immunosorbent electron
microscopy. (60) Method: Sequeira and Harrison (1982). (61) Virions geminate.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65) Virions <the
dimer is> 30 nm in length. (66) Virions <slightly> angular in profile. (67)
Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest (main) component> 76 S. (78) Of the other(s) 50 S. (84) Virions
contain 22 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 78 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 5.503 kb. (92)
Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 2.779 kb
<DNA-1>. (94) The 2nd largest 2.724 kb <DNA-2>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Harrison et al. (1977); Sequeira et al. (1983). (100) Base
composition 23.5 % G <DNA-1 24.6%, DNA-2 22.3%>. (101) Base composition 27.7 %
A <DNA-1 26.9%, DNA-2 28.8%>. (102) Base composition 18.6 % C <DNA-1 19.9%,
DNA-2 17.3%>. (104) Base composition 30.2 % T <DNA-1 28.5%, DNA-2 31.9%>.
(108) Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with proteases. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent <isolated DNA
is 1-50% as infective as the same amount of DNA in virions>. (110) Poly A
region absent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity <cloned
DNA is infective>. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Stanley and Gay (1983); Stanley (1983). (117) NCBI Taxon
ID: 10817. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): J02057 Em(40)_vi:GE1G
Gb(84)_vi:CLV1G Cassava latent virus (West Kenyan 844), DNA 1 of complete
genome. 4/90 2,779bp. J02058 Em(40)_vi:GE2G Gb(84)_vi:CLV2G Cassava latent
virus (west kenyan 844), dna 2 of complete genome. 4/90 2,724bp. X17095
Em(40)_vi:GEN1G Gb(84)_vi:GEN1G African cassava mosaic virus (Nigerian strain)
DNA 1. 9/93 2,781bp. X17096 Em(40)_vi:GEN2G Gb(84)_vi:GEN2G African cassava
mosaic virus (Nigerian strain) DNA-2. 9/93 2,725bp. X68318 Em(40)_vi:ACPPCR6
Gb(84)_vi:ACPPCR6 African Cassava Mosaic Virus gene for coat protein (clone
pPCR6). 7/93 852bp. X68319 Em(40)_vi:ACPPCR5 Gb(84)_vi:ACPPCR5 African Cassava
Mosaic Virus gene for coat protein (clone pPCR5). 7/93 852bp. X68320
Em(40)_vi:ACPPCR4 Gb(84)_vi:ACPPCR4 African Cassava Mosaic Virus gene for coat
protein (clone pPCR4). 7/93 852bp. 5 sequences. (119) Features of the genome:
the two circular genome DNA species share a sequence of 193 nucleotides which
contains a stem and loop structure of 33 nucleotides. Transcription in both
directions. DNA-1 encodes one protein of more than 15 kDain the plus (virion
DNA) sense and three proteins more than 15 kDain the minus sense. DNA-2
encodes one protein more than 15 kDain each sense. Possible promoter and
terminator and polyadenylation signals are found in all six ORFs. RNA
transcripts of the expected sizes are found. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
found in the virions. (122) Nongenomic nucleic acid Non-genomic nucleic acid
is derived from DNA-2. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31800 <±700 (Sequeira, 1982) or 30200 when
translated from the nucleotide sequence (Stanley and Gay, 1983)>. (145) Method
of preparation: Bock et al. (1977); Sequeira (1982). (146) Amino acid
sequence: Stanley et al. (1985). (148) Virion proteins not glycosylated
<Sequeira, 1982>. (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins identified by genomic
sequence analysis. (153) Five proteins found. (154) Mr 40300. (156) Mr of 2nd
largest 33700. (157) 2L1, which assists virus movement. (158) Mr of 3rd 29300.
(159) 2R1, assisting virus movement. (160) Mr of 4th 15800. (162) Mr of 5th
and smaller 15100. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis, phloem and companion cells. (172)
Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) A granular material. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: the production of fibrillar rings in
the nuclei of phloem parenchyma cells (Horvat and Verhoyen, 1981; Adejare and
Coutts, 1982). (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean golden mosaic (SDI:2)
(Sequeira and Harrison, 1982), squash leaf curl (Cohen et al., 1983), tomato
golden mosaic (SDI:2) (Stein et al., 1983), euphorbia mosaic (Roberts et al.,
1984) and many other whitefly transmitted geminiviruses (M. Aiton and B.D.
Harrison, unpublished information). (184) There are sequence homologies
between the larger genome part (DNA-1) of African cassava mosaic virus and the
DNA of bean golden mosaic, tomato golden mosaic, tobacco leaf curl and tomato
leaf curl viruses (Roberts et al., 1984). DNA-1 of African cassava mosaic
virus shows clear sequence similarities with bean golden mosaic virus in
coding regions, but little in non-coding regions (Hamilton et al., 1984;
Harrison, 1985). No serological relationship or genome homology has been found
between African cassava mosaic virus and any monogeminiviruses. The close
serological relationship between biologically distinct geminiviruses can lead
to difficulties in virus identification, especially when plant species not
previously recorded as hosts are infected. However, African cassava mosaic
virus does not infect Phaseolus vulgaris or Cucurbita pepo whereas bean golden
mosaic and squash leaf curl viruses do. In hybridization tests, African
cassava mosaic virus DNA-2 probes do not react with extracts of plants
infected with bean golden mosaic, tobacco golden mosaic or tobacco leaf curl
and allied geminiviruses (Roberts et al., 1984). (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: African cassava mosaic virus is the only geminivirus reported from
cassava in Africa. However, in South America, similar symptoms are caused by
cassava common mosaic potexvirus which also causes local lesions in
Chenopodium amaranticolor and Gomphrena globosa and is not transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci (Costa and Kitajima, 1972). Viruses associated with two other
mosaic diseases of cassava in Colombia are not sap-transmissible to Nicotiana
benthamiana. Indian cassava mosaic virus is now considered to be a separate
geminivirus. (187) Adejare, G.O. and Coutts, R.H.A. (1982). Phytopath. Z. 103:
87. Anon. (1979). Rep. Int. Inst. Trop. Agric. 1978, p.107. Bock, K.R. (1983).
In: Plant Virus Epidemiology, p. 337; eds R.T. Plumb and J.M. Thresh. Oxford,
Blackwell Scientific Publications. Bock, K.R. (1984). ODA Crop Virol. Res.
Proj. Kenya Agric. Res. Inst., Final Report. Overseas Development
Administration, London. Bock, K.R. and Guthrie, E.J. (1982). Trop. Pest Manag.
28: 219. Bock, K.R. and Harrison, B.D. (1985). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
297, 6 pp. Bock, K.R. and Woods, R.D. (1983). Plant Dis. 67: 994. Bock, K.R.,
Guthrie, E.J. and Figueiredo, G. (1981). Ann. appl. Biol. 99: 151. Bock, K.R.,

Cassava Colombian symptomless (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.03. (8) First

(1987). (13) Manihot esculenta systemic, but symptomless. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Colombia. (43)
Chenopodium spp., Nicotiana benthamiana symptomless, not systemic. (47)
Chenopodium, or Manihot esculenta, or Nicotiana benthamiana. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (69) Virions with a clear

Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: narcissus
mosaic virus, but only distantly related to cassava common mosaic and cassava
X potexviruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: nine
other potexviruses (Aiton and Harrison, 1988). (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
this virus sometimes occurs with cassava X potexvirus or in plants with
frogskin or Caribbean mosaic symptoms but apparently is not the cause of these
diseases. (187) Aiton, M.M. and Harrison, B.D. (1988). Rep. Scottish Crop Res.
Inst. 1987, p. 192. Lennon, A.M., Aiton, M.M. and Harrison, B.D. (1987). Rep.

Cassava common mosaic (?) potexvirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1985. Revised by F.W. Zettler, 1989. (2) Synonyms:
Brazilian cassava common mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: CsCMV. (4)
Strains: chaya strain. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.005. (8) First reported
in Manihot esculenta. (9) From Sao Paulo, Brazil. (10) By Costa and Normanha
(1940). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cnidoscolus acontifolius, Manihot
esculenta mosaic. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (15)
Disseminated in infected cuttings. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Brazil, Colombia,
Mexico, Peru, Taiwan, and the USA <Florida>, or Cote d'Ivoire <possibly>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, not systemic. (43) Gomphrena
globosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C. quinoa, Gossypium hirsutum,
Manihot esculenta, Ricinus communis local lesions; not systemic. Cassia
occidentalis, Datura stramonium chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not
systemic (Chaya strain). Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic local lesions; mild
systemic chlorosis. (44) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Zea mays. (45)
Euphorbia heterophylla, Manihot esculenta. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L),

Euphorbia heterophylla, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or
Manihot esculenta, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Ricinus communis. (48)
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or

unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>,
or Euphorbiaceae <4/5>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Malvaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/12>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Compositae <1/1>,
or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/5>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <11/12>. (54) TIP: 65-70 °C.
(55) LIV: 128 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not
changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.

enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 495-525 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal

Brazilian strain defective RNA, complete sequence. 5/95 1,094bp. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 21000. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (176) Fibrous masses. (177) They contain virions. (179)
<Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
potato X and tulip X potexviruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically

and nerine X potexviruses. (183) Chaya strain, unlike type strain, infects
Chenopodium quinoa and induces nuclear inclusions. (187) Costa, A.S. and

Cassava green mottle nepovirus

      (1) A.M. Lennon, M.M. Aiton and B.D. Harrison, 1986. (3) Standard
acronym: CGMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.008. (8) First reported in

Scotland. (10) By Lennon et al. (1985). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection. (13) Manihot esculenta leaf mottling. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38)
Spreads in the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in the Solomon Islands. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
mottles, both in inoculated and other leaves, mosaic. (43) Manihot esculenta
local and systemic mottle. Chenopodium quinoa necrotic local lesions; systemic

vulgaris, Cucumis sativus systemic mottling. Ricinus communis necrotic local
lesions, mosaic. Ipomoea batatas symptomless systemic infection. Solanum
tuberosum local and systemic black necrotic spots. (44) Zea mays, Arachis
hypogaea, Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum, Brassica oleracea. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor
(L). (47) Apium graveolens, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or

debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (48) Arachis hypogaea,
or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica oleracea

Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>,

or Gramineae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>. (54) TIP: 60-65 °C.
(55) LIV: 12 days <or more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (57) Infectivity of
sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 27
nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile, or angular in profile. (67)
Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations, or three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.8-1.9 <uncorrected>. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 16.9
kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger>
9.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 7.4 kb. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132) Virion protein(s) one <or more>.
(133) Mr 53000. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (178) Other cellular changes: the virus occasionally being
found in tubules. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, arracacha A,
artichoke Italian latent, artichoke vein-banding, cherry leaf roll, cacao
necrosis, grapevine Bulgarian latent, grapevine fanleaf, grapevine Hungarian
chrome mosaic, hibiscus latent ringspot, lucerne Australian latent, mulberry
ringspot, olive latent ringspot, peach rosette mosaic, potato black ringspot,

Cassava Indian mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) V. Muniyappa, 1992. (2) Synonyms: Indian cassava mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: ICMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.020. (8) First reported
in Manihot esculenta cassava. (9) From India. (10) By Abraham (1956). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms mosaic, chlorosis and deformation of
leaves. (13) Manihot esculenta mosaic and irregular chlorotic patches on
leaves with distortion and stunting. Enations sometimes, on abaxial surfaces
of leaves. M. glaziovii leaf mosaic and deformation. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci.
(18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Alagianagalingam et al. (1966),
Malathi et al. (1985). (39) Spreads in India and Sri Lanka. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic lesions, systemic mosaic, vein thickening, leaf curling deformation
and stunting. (43) Datura stramonium, Nicandra physalodes, Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. debneyi, N. glutinosa, N. occidentalis, N. rustica, N.
sylvestris, N. tabacum (cv. Jaysree) and Petunia × hybrida vein-clearing,
chlorotic lesions, mosaic, curling and stunting. (44) Abelmoschus esculentus,
Chenopodium quinoa, Croton bonplandianus, Euphorbia heterophylla, Gomphrena
globosa. (45) Manihot esculenta, M. glaziovii, Nicandra physalodes, Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Jayasree and N. hybrida. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N.
glutinosa (W), N. hybrida (W), N. tabacum (cvs Jaysree and Samsun) (W). (47)
Datura stramonium, or Manihot esculenta, or Manihot glaziovii, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
hybrida, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida.
(48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Ageratum conyzoides, or Arachis hypogaea, or

<2/4>, or Solanaceae <14/19>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae

complete CDS. 3/94 2,815bp. Z24759 Em(40)_vi:ICMVBR1A Gb(84)_vi:ICMVBR1A

sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 34000. (134) Coat protein.

nuclei. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (186) Virus
isolates from cassava (Manihot esculenta) in India and Sri Lanka, although
earlier tentatively regarded as Group C isolates of African cassava mosaic
geminivirus, are now considered to be those of a distinct virus and named
Indian cassava mosaic geminivirus (Harrison et al., 1986; Harrison and
Robinson, 1988). The virus is transmitted by Bemisia tabaci, induces
conspicuous leaf symptoms in infected plants and causes ultrastructural
effects typical of geminiviruses (Roberts, 1989). The virus is serologically
more closely related to some other geminiviruses than to African cassava
mosaic geminivirus. (187) Abraham, A. (1956). Farm Bulletin No. 17. Ind.
Counc. Agric. Res. New Delhi, 20 pp. Alagianagalingam, M.N. and Ramakrishnan,
K. (1966). South Ind. Hort 14: 71. Malathi, V.G., Narr, N.G. and Santha, P.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. Revised 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.4.DE.1.

Cassia severe mosaic (?) closterovirus

      (1) R.G.T. Hicks, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.DE.2. (8) First
reported in Cassia corymbosa. (9) From Bath, U.K. (10) By Ngamyeesoon and
Hicks (1989). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms leaf mosaic, mottling and
malformation. (13) Cassia corymbosa mosaic, chlorotic spotting, flecking, vein
yellowing, leaf malformation, yellow blotching and mottling. (15) By
vegetative propagation. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the UK. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottle or mosaic. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions, systemic flecks and lines.
Cassia occidentalis local systemic mild mottle/mosaic; plants die. Nicotiana
clevelandii chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottle. N. tabacum cv. White
Burley faint chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Prince chlorotic local lesions/vein yellowing; systemic chlorotic flecks and
vein yellowing. Pisum sativum cv. Monteith systemic chlorotic mosaic and leaf
malformation; plants die. Trifolium repens cv. White Clover systemic vein
necrosis. Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis necrotic local lesions;
systemic necrotic spots and vein necrosis. (44) Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Cassia obtusifolia, Cucumis sativus cv. Parisienne Pickling,

corymbosa, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium album, or

megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum,
or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Cassia
obtusifolia, or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
