Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <3/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/7>, or
Solanaceae <3/7>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/7>, or
Solanaceae <4/7>. (53) Ngamyeesoon (1989); Ngamyeesoon and Hicks (1988). (54)
TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: <less than> 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: purification largely unsuccessful
due to fragility of virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 150-2168 nm. (71) Virions 10-12 nm wide. (72) Axial
canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (125) 1-3 virus specified dsRNA
species found in infected cells <major, also 8 minor>. (126) Size of largest
virus specified dsRNA 13-15 kbp. (127) 2nd largest 1.2-1.3 kbp. (128) 3rd
largest 0.4-0.5 kbp. (171) Virions found in leaves, epidermis and veins. (179)
<Possible> Closterovirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: virion properties
distinguish this virus from a carlavirus isolated from Cassia, and which does
not infect Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris and Pisum
sativum (Lin et al., 1979). (187) Ngamyeesoon, N. (1989). Ph.D. Thesis,
University of Bath, U.K. 343 pp. Ngamyeesoon, N. and Hicks, R.G.T. (1988).
Acta Hort. 234: 45.


Cassia yellow blotch bromovirus

      (1) J.L. Dale, 1984. Revised 1987. (3) Standard acronym: CYBV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 10.0.3.0.004. (8) First reported in Cassia pleurocarpa. (9) From
Mitchell, Queensland. (10) By Dale et al. (1984). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Cassia pleurocarpa yellow leaf blotches. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local
lesions, mottle, tip necrosis. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Cassia hirsuta, C. occidentalis,
Trifolium incarnatum systemic chlorotic mottle. Cicer arietinum tip necrosis.
Nicotiana clevelandii systemic green mottle. (44) Arachis hypogaea, Pisum
sativum, Vigna radiata. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L). (47) Cassia hirsuta, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia
pleurocarpa, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Cucumis sativus, or Desmodium tortuosum, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus
angustifolius, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Zea mays. (48) Arachis
hypogaea, or Avena sativa, or Cajanus cajan, or Cicer arietinum, or Clitoria
ternatea, or Datura stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Medicago sativa, or Pisum sativum, or Sorghum bicolor, or Trifolium pratense,
or Triticum aestivum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/5>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/16>, or Solanaceae <1/2>. (51)
Compositae <1/1>, or Gramineae <4/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/16>, or
Solanaceae <1/2>. (53) Dale et al. (1984). (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: best with UA or AM. (60) Method: Bancroft
et al. (1967); Dale et al. (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations <at pH 7>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
85 S. (82) Isoelectric point pH 3.6. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 8.7 kb. (92) Genome of three parts.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.4 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
3 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Dale
et al. (1984). (100) Base composition 24.4 % G. (101) Base composition 24.9 %
A. (102) Base composition 22.2 % C. (103) Base composition 28.5 % U. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 20800. (147) Amino acid composition: Dale et al. (1984). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Bromovirus: Bromoviridae. (180) :
Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: broad bean
mottle, brome mosaic and cowpea chlorotic mottle viruses. (187) Bancroft,
J.B., Hills, G.J. and Markham, R. (1967). Virology 31: 354. Dale, J.L. (1988).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 334, 3 pp. Dale, J.L., Gibbs, A.J. and
Behncken, G.M. (1984). J. gen. Virol. 65: 281.


Cassia yellow spot potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and O. Lovisolo, 1992. (2) Synonyms: cassia yellow blotch
virus. (3) Standard acronym: CasYSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.015. (8)
First reported in Cassia hoffmanseggi. (9) From Brazil (Pernambuco State).
(10) By Paguio and Kitajima (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cassia
hoffmanseggi chlorotic leaf blotching. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Uroleucon
ambrosiae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <in Cassia occidentalis (Souto et al., 1990)>. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in Brazil (Pernambuco State). (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
systemic mosaic, crinkle and growth reduction, necrotic local lesions. (43)
Cassia occidentalis, Phaseolus vulgaris, Canavalia ensiformis systemic mosaic,
crinkle and growth reduction. Vigna unguiculata (some cvs), Sesamum indicum
mosaic. Glycine max latent. Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions.
(44) Gomphrena globosa, Cucumis melo, Pisum sativum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
tabacum. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris (L and W),
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Canavalia ensiformis (W), Crotalaria juncea
(W). (47) Canavalia ensiformis, or Cassia hoffmanseggi, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Crotalaria juncea, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucurbita pepo, or Glycine max, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia tora, or
Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lupinus luteus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<2/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/11>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/11>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Souto (1990).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 700 nm. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean common mosaic,
canavalia acronecrosis, carnation vein mottle and passionfruit woodiness
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: blackeye cowpea
mosaic, papaya ringspot and watermelon mosaic viruses (Lovisolo and Kitajima,
1992; Lovisolo et al., 1991). (186) This virus was first designated cassia
yellow blotch virus (Paguio and Kitajima, 1980 and 1981) but, to avoid
confusion with cassia yellow blotch bromovirus, its name was later changed
(Souto et al., 1989). (187) Costa, C.L., Kitajima, E.W. and Marinho, V.L.A.
(1989). Fitopatol. Bras. 14: 115. Lovisolo, O. and Kitajima, E.W. (1992).
Arch. Virol., Suppl. 5: in press. Lovisolo, O., De Sa, P.B., Lima, J.A.A.,
Costa, C.L. and Kitajima, E.W. (1991). Fitopatol. Bras. 16: 24. Lovisolo, O.,
Marinho, V.L.A., Souto, E., Costa, C.L. and Kitajima, E.W. (1989). Fitopatolo.
Bras. 14: 119. Paguio, D.R. and Kitajima, E.W. (1980). Fitopatol. Bras. 5:
436. Paguio, D.R. and Kitajima, E.W. (1981). Fitopatol. Bras. 6: 187. Souto,
E.R. (1990). Inst. Cienc. Biol. Univ. de Brasilia, 93 pp. Souto, E.R. and
Kitajima, E.W. (1991). Fitopatol. Bras. 16: in press. Souto, E.R. and
Kitajima, E.W. (1991). Fitopatol. Bras. 16: 256. Souto, E.R., Costa, C.L. and
Kitajima, E.W. (1990). Fitopatol. Bras. 15: 136. Souto, E.R., Kitajima, E.W.,
Marinho, V.L.A. and Costa, A.F. (1988). Fitopatol. Bras. 13: 145. Souto, E.R.,
Marinho, V.L.A., Oliveira, C.R.B. and Kitajima, E.W. (1989). Fitopatol. Bras.
14: 114.


Cauliflower mosaic caulimovirus

      (1) R.G. Garrett, 1982. (2) Synonyms: brassica virus 3, broccoli mosaic
virus, cabbage mosaic virus, cabbage virus B. (3) Standard acronym: CaMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 15.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Brassica campestris and
B. oleracea. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Tompkins (1937). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Arabidopsis thaliana, Brassica spp., Raphanus spp. and other
species of the Brassicaceae, Resedaceae vein-clearing or banding mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Brevicoryne brassicae, Myzus persicae and at least 25 other species. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26)
Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show vein clearing, mosaic. (43) Brassica oleracea var.
botrytis, B. campestris vein clearing, mosaic. Brassica campestris ssp. napus
mosaic. (45) Brassica campestris cv. Just Right. (46) Brassica campestris cv.
Just Right. (47) Arabidopsis thaliana, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica
oleracea, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassicaceae, or Datura
stramonium, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Raphanus, or Resedaceae. (48)
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa. (50)
Cruciferae <9/9>, or Resedaceae, or Solanaceae <2/5>. (51) Solanaceae <3/5>.
(53) Tompkins (1937); Broadbent and Tinsley (1953). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C. (55)
LIV: 7-15 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed
by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: no special treatment required but virions flatten. (60)
Method: Gardner and Shepherd (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 50 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 208 S <Hull
et al., 1976>. (79) Density 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 16-17 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83-84 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular <linear molecules
found but not infective>. (91) Total genome size 8.032 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8.032 kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Shepherd et al. (1970). (105) Base composition of ds
genome 43 % (G + C). (110) Poly A region absent. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: Franck et al. (1980); Gardner et al. (1981). (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10641. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): A00001 Em(40)_vi:A00001

lobed nuclei, cell wall protrusions associated with vesicles and convoluted
tubules. (179) Caulimovirus <the type species>. (181) Virus(es) with

carnation etched ring viruses. (187) Al Ani, R., Pfeiffer, P. and Lebeurier,

Celery latent (?) potyvirus

      (1) E. Luisoni, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.03. (8) First
reported in Apium graveolens var. dulce. (9) From Italy, near Turin. (10) By
Brandes and Luisoni (1966); Luisoni (1966). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Apium
graveolens var. dulce, A. graveolens var. rapaceum symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (24) Not transmitted by
Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis fabae, Cavariella aegopodii, Macrosiphum
euphorbiae, Myzus persicae, Aulacorthum circumflexum. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Verhoyen et al. (1976); Bos et
al. (1978). The virus was detected in seedlings of commercial cultivars of
celery and celeriac. The virus seemed to reduce the yield and the use of
virus-free mother plants for seed production was advised. The availability of
antiserum facilitates this control. (39) Spreads in Belgium, Italy, and the
Netherlands. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show no symptoms. Some Chenopodium and Amaranthus
species and Atriplex hortensis give local lesions and generally systemic
rings, flecks, deformations and dwarfing. (43) Apium graveolens var. dulce, A.
graveolens var. rapaceum no visible symptoms. Anthriscus cerefolium,
Coriandrum sativum symptomless. Chenopodium quinoa local lesions, chlorotic
flecks and rings with slight leaf deformation. Chenopodium amaranticolor local
lesions; less distinct systemic symptoms. Amaranthus hypochondriacus necrotic
local lesions; sometimes severe systemic symptoms. (44) Anethum graveolens,
Daucus carota, Pastinaca sativa, Petroselinum crispum, Nicotiana rustica. (45)
Apium graveolens var. dulce (for maintaining the virus long term), Chenopodium
quinoa (for maintaining and propagating the virus short term). (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Amaranthus
hypochondriacus (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus hypochondriacus,
or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or Apium graveolens, or
Apium graveolens var. dulce, or Apium graveolens var. rapaceum, or Atriplex
hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Coriandrum sativum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, or
Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Anethum graveolens, or Brassica campestris
ssp. chinensis, or Calendula officinalis, or Conium maculatum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus
carota, or Glycine max, or Heracleum sphondylium, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Ocimum basilicum, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or
Physalis floridana, or Solanum nigrum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium
repens, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <4/4>, or Chenopodiaceae
<7/7>, or Compositae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/9>, or Solanaceae
<8/15>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <5/11>. (51) Compositae
<2/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/9>, or Solanaceae <7/15>, or Umbelliferae
<6/11>. (53) Bos et al. (1978); Brandes and Luisoni (1966); Luisoni (1966);
Verhoyen et al. (1976). (54) TIP: 54 °C. (55) LIV: 10 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Bos et al. (1978).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 860 nm. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 161 S. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178)
Other cellular changes: bundles of virions in the cytoplasm, often near or
parallel to the tonoplast (Verhoyen et al., 1976; Bos et al., 1978). (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae <possibly>. (180) : Potyviridae. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: ISEM and decoration is diagnostic. Susceptibility of C. quinoa is
not as some strains of celery mosaic virus. (187) Bos, L., Diaz-Ruiz, J.R. and
Maat, D.Z. (1978). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 84: 61. Brandes, J. and Luisoni, E.
(1966). Phytopath. Z. 57: 277. Luisoni, E. (1966). Atti Accad. Sci., Torino
100: 541. Luisoni, E. and Lisa, V. (1969). Annls. Phytopath. 1: 375. Verhoyen,
M., Esparza-Duque, J., Matthieu, J.L. and Horvat, F. (1976). Parasitica 32:
158.


Celery mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R.N. Campbell, 1986. (2) Synonyms: apium virus 1, celery western
mosaic virus, celery ringspot virus (Hollings, 1964; Pemberton and Frost,
1986). (3) Standard acronym: CeMV. (4) Strains: celery crinkle-leaf strain
(Freitag and Severin, 1945a), poison hemlock ringspot virus (Freitag and
Severin, 1945a and b; Sutabutra and Campbell, 1971). (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.015. (8) First reported in Apium graveolens var. dulce. (9) From
California, U.S.A. (10) By Severin and Freitag (1938). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Apium graveolens var. dulce mottling, malformation of leaflets. Conium
maculatum systemic mottle and malformation. Pastinaca sativa crinkly leaves
and mottle. Petroselinum crispum chlorosis and necrotic spots. Coriandrum
sativum chlorosis, stunted. Daucus carota mosaic. Anethum graveolens stunted
and malformed. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis middletonii, A. ferruginea-striata;
A. apigraveolens, A. apii, A. gossypii, A. rumicis, Cavariella capreae, Myzus
circumflexus, M. convolvuli, Rhopalosiphum melliferum; Cavariella aegopodii,
C. pastinacae (Severin and Freitag, 1968; Walkey et al., 1970). (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Milbrath in California, U.S.A.. Controlled by a celery-free period
(Milbrath, 1948). In Britain, the virus infects wild hemlock and other weeds
(Walkey, 1970), thus a celery-free period may not control the virus there.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide. (39) Spreads in Argentina <Gracia and
Feldman, 1977>, or Australia <western Australia>, or Canada <Kemp and Froud,
1975>, or the former Czechoslovakia <Chod, 1984)>, or France <Marchoux et al.,
1969>, or Germany <Brandes and Luisoni, 1966>, or Italy <Avgelis and
Quacquarelli, 1972>, or Japan <Iwaki and Komuro, 1970>, or New Zealand <Fry
and Proctor, 1968>, or the UK <Walkey et al., 1970>, or the USA <in the
western states and Florida (Purcifull and Shepard, 1967)>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mottle
leaf malformation. (43) Apium graveolens var. dulce mottled and malformed
leaflets. Conium maculatum mottled and leaves malformed (Sutabutra, 1968).
Pastinaca sativa leaves malformed. Daucus carota ssp. sativus chlorotic spots.
Coriandrum sativum systemic chlorosis. (45) Apium graveolens cv. Utah 10B.
(46) Apium graveolens (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47)
Anethum graveolens, or Apium graveolens, or Apium graveolens var. dulce, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Conium maculatum, or
Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus carota, or Daucus carota ssp. sativus, or
Heracleum sphondylium, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Umbelliferae <10/10>. (53) Severin and Freitag
(1938); Sutabutra and Campbell (1971); Frowd and Tomlinson (1970); Walkey et
al. (1970); Wolf (1969); Wolf and Schmelzer (1972). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55)
LIV: 6 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: Shepard and Grogan (1967b). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 780 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide <Walkey et
al., 1970>. (72) Axial canal obscure. (84) Virions contain 5.5 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 94.5 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 9.5-11 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9.5-11 kb. (108)
Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found
in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and
unusual in shape. (176) Tubules in cytoplasm (Purcifull and Shepard, 1967).
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: tobacco etch and potato Y (Shepard et al.,
1974) viruses. (183) Pastinaca sativa is not infected by the common strain,
but is susceptible to the crinkle leaf strain (Freitag and Severin, 1945a).
Daucus carota ssp. sativus cultivars, Western Red and Early Nantes, are not
infected by mechanical inoculation with British isolates (Walkey et al.,
1970). (187) Avgelis, A. and Quacquarelli, A. (1972). Phytopathol. Medit. 11:
124. Brandes, J. and Luisoni, E. (1966). Phytopath. Z. 57: 277. Chod, J.
(1984). Ochr. Rost. 20: 91. Freitag, J.H. and Severin, H.H.P. (1945a).
Hilgardia 16: 361. Freitag, J.H. and Severin, H.H.P. (1945b). Hilgardia 16:
389. Fry, P.R. and Proctor, C.H. (1968). N.Z. comml. Grow. 24: 23. Gracia, O.
and Feldman, J.M. (1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61: 905. Hari, V. (1981). Virology
112: 391. Hollings, M. (1964). J. hort. Sci. 39: 130. Iwaki, M. and Komuro, Y.
(1970). Ann. Phytopathol. Proc. Japan 36: 36. Kemp, W.G. and Frowd, J.A.
(1975). Pl. Dis. Reptr 59: 50. Marchoux, G., Navatel, J.C., Rougier, J. and
Duteil, M. (1969). Annls. Phytopath. 1: 227. Milbrath, D.G. (1948). Bull.
Calif. Dep. Agric. 37: 3. Pemberton, A.W. and Frost, R.R. (1974). Pl. Path.
23: 20. Pemberton, A.W. and Frost, R.R. (1986). Ann. appl. Biol. 108: 319.
Purcifull, D.E. and Shepard, J.F. (1967). Pl. Dis. Reptr 51: 502. Severin,
H.H.P. and Freitag, J.H. (1938). Hilgardia 11: 493. Shepard, J.F. and Grogan,
R.G. (1967a). Phytopathology 57: 1104. Shepard, J.F. and Grogan, R.G. (1967b).
Phytopathology 57: 1136. Shepard, J.F. and Grogan, R.G. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 50, 3 pp. Shepard, J.F., Secor, G.A. and Purcifull, D.E.
(1974). Virology 58: 464. Sutabutra, T. and Campbell, R.N. (1971). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 55: 328. Walkey, D.G.A., Tomlinson, J.A. and Frowd, J.A. (1970). Pl.
Dis. Reptr 54: 370. Wolf, P. (1969). TagBer. dt. Akad. Wiss., Berlin 11: 293.
Wolf, P. and Schmelzer, K. (1972). Zbl. Bakt. ParasitKde. Abt. 2, 127: 665.


Celery T (?) cytorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.4.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Apium graveolens var. rapaceum (celeriac). (9) From Turin, Italy.
(10) By D'Agostino et al. (1992). (13) Apium graveolens var. rapaceum, but
only found in plants also infected with celery mosaic potyvirus, so the
symptoms caused by CTV alone are unknown. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (38) Spreads in
the Mediterranean region. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (47) Apium graveolens, or Apium graveolens var. rapaceum. (50)
Umbelliferae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 360 nm. (71) Virions 65-70 nm wide. (171)
Virions found in Virions found within cisternae of the endoplasmic reticulum.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) <Probably> Cytorhabdovirus:
Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) D'Agostino, G., Luisoni, E. and
Lovisolo, O. (1992). Proc. Eur. EM (Granada, Spain) 3: 427.


Celery yellow mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CeYMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.016. (9) From Brazil. (10) By Kitajima and Costa (1968). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Apium graveolens conspicuous leaf chlorosis (except in
cv. Florida 683 strain K which is tolerant). (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Brazil. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Apium graveolens, Coriandrum sativum,
Petroselinum crispum systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa local lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Conium maculatum, Datura
stramonium, Glycine max, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Apium
graveolens, Coriandrum sativum, Petroselinum crispum. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Apium graveolens, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Petroselinum
crispum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris
ssp. chinensis, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or
Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum,
or Cassia occidentalis, or Chenopodium murale, or Conium maculatum, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura
stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or
Raphanus sativus, or Solanum nigrum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or Umbelliferae <3/5>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or Compositae <6/6>, or
Cruciferae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or
Malvaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <9/9>, or Umbelliferae <2/5>. (53) De Olivera
and Kitajima (1981). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 6 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
4. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 133 S. (84) Virions contain 5.5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94.5
% protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are viroplasms, pinwheels, and unusual in shape. (176) Are fibrous
proteinaceous nuclear inclusions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: celery mosaic
virus. (187) Da Cruz, N.D., Medina, D.M., Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S.
(1972). Bragantia 31: 217. de Olivera, M.L. and Kitajima, E.W. (1981).
Fitopatol. Bras. 6: 47. Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S. (1968). Bragantia 27:
7. Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S. (1968). Bragantia 27: 9. Kitajima, E.W. and
Costa, A.S. (1978). Fitopatol. Bras. 3: 287.


Celery yellow net (?) virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.13. (8) First
reported in Apium graveolens. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Hollings (1964). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Apium graveolens yellow flecking and vein banding,
leaves malformed. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the UK. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Apium graveolens yellow vein-netting vein-banding,
necrotic spotting and malformation. Petroselinum crispum green systemic
spotting then chlorotic or necrotic spots and rings. Daucus carota, Apium
repens transient spots or systemic yellow-netting. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Apium graveolens, Petroselinum crispum. (46) Apium
graveolens (W). (47) Apium graveolens, or Apium repens, or Daucus carota, or
Petroselinum crispum. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Umbelliferae <4/4>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (54) TIP: 45 °C. (55)
LIV: 2 days <at 18°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (179) (Ungrouped). (187)
Hollings, M. (1964). J. hort. Sci. 39: 130. Pemberton, A.W. and Frost, R.R.
(1986). Ann. appl. Biol. 108: 319.


Celery yellow spot (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CeYSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.T.002. (8) First reported in Apium graveolens. (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Severin and Freitag (1945). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Apium
graveolens pale green spots and stripes, with yellow spots and stripes along
veins. Conium maculatum symptomless infection. Pastinaca sativa mild leaf
chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Hyadaphis foeniculi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not
transmitted by Myzus persicae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation <usually>. (39) Spreads in the
UK and the USA <in California>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic spots and stripes, or
mild leaf chlorosis. (43) Apium graveolens systemic yellow spots and stripes
along the veins. Conium maculatum symptomless systemic infection. Pastinaca
sativa faint systemic leaf chlorosis. (44) Anthriscus cerefolium, Coriandrum
sativum, Cucumis sativus, Daucus carota, Foeniculum vulgare, Lycopersicon
esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petroselinum crispum, Petunia ×
hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Apium graveolens,
Pastinaca sativa. (46) Apium graveolens (W), Pastinaca sativa (W). (47) Apium
graveolens, or Conium maculatum, or Pastinaca sativa. (48) Anthriscus
cerefolium, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis sativus, or Daucus carota, or
Foeniculum vulgare, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (50) Umbelliferae <3/8>. (51)
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <5/8>. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus.
(187) Freitag, J.H. and Severin, H.H.P. (1945). Hilgardia 16: 375. Hollings,
M. (1964). J. hort. Sci. 39: 130. Pemberton, A.W. and Frost, R.R. (1986). Ann.
appl. Biol. 108: 319. Severin, H.H.P. and Freitag, J.H. (1938). Hilgardia 11:
493. Waterhouse, P.M., Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 339, 9 pp.


Centrosema mosaic (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1985. Revised 1987. (3) Standard acronym: CenMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.006. (8) First reported in Centrosema spp.,
Crotalaria spp. and other tropical legumes. (9) From Papua New Guinea. (10) By
Van Velsen and Crowley (1962). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Centrosema
pubescens, Crotalaria anagyroides, C. retusa, C. goreensis, C. mucronata,
Calopogonium mucunoides (which sets no seeds), Desmodium distortum
vein-clearing, mosaic, leaf malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Heteroptera: Lygaeidae and
Nysius spp. (18) Transmitted by an unusual insect group. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Papua New Guinea.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show mosaic. (43) Crotalaria spectabilis, C. juncea, C. retusa, C.
anagyroides, Centrosema pubescens and Trifolium subterraneum mosaic. (44)
Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Crotalaria anagyroides. (46) Crotalaria anagyroides (W).
(47) Calopogonium mucunoides, or Centrosema, or Centrosema pubescens, or
Crotalaria anagyroides, or Crotalaria goreensis, or Crotalaria juncea, or
Crotalaria mucronata, or Crotalaria retusa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or
Desmodium distortum, or Trifolium subterraneum. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cicer arietinum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesbania exaltata, or
Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/29>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <18/29>, or Solanaceae
<6/6>. (54) TIP: 55-58 °C. (55) LIV: 0.25 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(60) Method: Crowley and Francki, 1963. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 580 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (179) <Possible>
Potexvirus. (187) Crowley, N.C. and Francki, R.I.B. (1963). Aust. J. biol.
Sci. 16: 468. Van Velsen, R.J. and Crowley, N.C. (1962). Aust. J. agric. Sci.
13: 220.


Cereal chlorotic mottle (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) R.S. Greber, 1980. (3) Standard acronym: CerCMV (CCMV). (4) Strains:
CCMV-Morocco. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.007. (8) First reported in Zea
mays. (9) From Brisbane, Australia. (10) By Greber (1977; 1979). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Avena sativa, Digitaria ciliaris, Dinebra retroflexa,
Echinochloa colona, Hordeum vulgare, Leptochloa filiformis, Setaria
verticillata, Triticum aestivum, Urochloa panicoides, Zea mays chlorotic
streaking, variable stunting and sterility. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nesoclutha pallida, Cicadula
bimaculata, Cicadulina bipunctata ssp. bipunctella. (18) Transmitted by
Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Australia and Morocco. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible
<only Gramineae>. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic
striations. (43) Dinebra retroflexa chlorotic streaking. Leptochloa filiformis
chlorotic and necrotic streaking. Triticum spp. and × Triticosecale chlorotic
streaking. Zea mays chlorotic streaks, but cvs differ in susceptibility. (44)
Oryza sativa, Sorghum bicolor. (45) Dinebra retroflexa. (47) Avena sativa, or
Digitaria ciliaris, or Dinebra retroflexa, or Echinochloa colona, or Eleusine
coracana, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or Hordeum vulgare, or Leptochloa
filiformis, or Setaria verticillata, or Triticum aestivum, or Urochloa
panicoides, or × Triticosecale, or Zea mays. (48) Chloris gayana, or Digitaria
decumbens, or Oryza sativa, or Paspalum dilatatum, or Sorghum bicolor. (50)
Gramineae <13/18>. (51) Gramineae <5/18>. (53) Greber (1979). (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: use PTA-H. (60) Method:
Jackson and Christie (1977); Greber and Gowanlock (1979). (61) Virions rhabdo
or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 214 nm. (71) Virions 75 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (80) Density
1.165 g cm3 in sucrose. (132) Virion protein(s) five. (133) Mr <of the
largest> 82000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 52000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 45500.
(139) Mr of 4th largest 31800. (141) Mr of 5th largest 28900. (145) Method of
preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, phloem and companion cells. (172)
Virions found in the perinuclear space. (173) Virions found in cytoplasmic
vesicles. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: 8
rhabdoviruses of Poaceae, except for Moroccan cereal chlorotic mottle virus.
(187) Greber, R.S. (1977). Aust. Pl. Path. Soc. Newsl. 6: 17. Greber, R.S.
(1979). Aust. J. agric. Res. 30: 433. Greber, R.S. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 251, 4 pp. Greber, R.S. and Gowanlock, D.H. (1979). Aust. J. biol.
Sci. 32: 399. Jackson, A.O. and Christie, S.R. (1977). Virology 77: 344.
Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Lockhart, B.E.L. (1986). Plant
Dis. 70: 912.


Cereal flame chlorosis (?) virus

      (1) S. Haber, 1991. (4) Strains: flame chlorosis virus (FCV) is
associated with distinct dsRNA patterns in barley, bread and durum wheat and
oat. There may be barley, wheat and oat strains of FCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.14. (8) First reported in Hordeum vulgare cv. Argyle. (9) From
Manitoba, Canada near Newdale. (10) By Haber et al. (1990). (11) Symptoms
persist. (12) Symptoms flame-like chlorosis, stunting, prostrate growth. (13)
Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum, T. durum defined chlorosis
radiating in a flame-like pattern from the leaf base. Plants stunted and
prostrate. (15) Transmitted in soil; probably by fungi. (24) Not transmitted
by Polymyxa graminis. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by the disease is found often in fields frequently sown with spring
cereals, particularly barley. (39) Spreads in Canada <Manitoba>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
variegated yellow-whitish chlorosis. (43) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare,
Triticum aestivum variegated yellow-whitish to pale-green chlorosis. (45)
Hordeum vulgare is the best, but may also use Triticum aestivum and Avena
sativa. (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Triticum aestivum, or
Triticum durum. (50) Gramineae <4/4>. (53) Haber and Barr (1990). (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome of 7 parts to
of 15 parts <depending on isolate and variant>. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the largest> 3.5 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 0.25
kb <pairs; but varies in different isolates>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Haber and Barr (1990); Haber et al. (1990). (105) Base composition
of ds genome 56.8 % (G + C). (119) Features of the genome: from sequencing of
cDNA clones at least 1 ORF has been found; it encodes a putative 108
amino-acid histone-like polypeptide. Known sequence is in EMBL Data Library
(Ref. DS7101) X59248 HORDEUM, FLAME CHLOROSIS DNA; putative 108 amino-acid
basic polypeptide has possible (distant) similarity with tymovirus
nucleotide-binding fold. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (177) They do not contain virions. (178)
Other cellular changes: malformation and vesiculation of peripheries of
chloroplasts, mitochondria and leukoplasts (Haber et al., 1990). (179)
(Ungrouped). (184) Effects on chloroplasts resemble those caused by
tombusviruses and the vesicular inclusions resemble those of tymoviruses. The
pattern of numerous dsRNAs resembles those of some mycoviruses. (186) CFCV may
have arisen or spread recently as it was not seen before 1985. This
corresponds with increasing frequency of barley cultivation. Since 1985 it has
been found at greater distances from the site where it was orginally found; it
is expected that it will soon be found in border areas of North Dakota and
Minnesota. (187) Haber, S. (1990). Can. Pl. Dis. Surv. 70: 50. Haber, S.
(1991). Can. Pl. Dis. Surv. 7: in press. Haber, S. and Barr, D.J. (1990). In:
German Phytomedical Series Vol. 1. Proc. First Symp. of Int. Working Group on
Plant Viruses with Fungal Vectors, ed. R. Koenig, p. 169. Haber, S. and
Platford, R.G. (1991). Can. Pl. Dis. Surv. 71: 79. Haber, S., Kim, W.,
Gillespie, R. and Tekauz, A. (1990). J. Phytopath. 129: 245. Haber, S., Barr,
D.J.S. and Platford, R.G. (1991). Can. J. Pl. Pathol. 13: in press.


Cereal northern mosaic cytorhabdovirus

      (1) S. Toriyama, 1987. (2) Synonyms: northern cereal mosaic virus, wheat
rosette stunt virus (Lundsgaard et al., 1984; Gong et al., 1985; Milne et al.,
1986). (3) Standard acronym: NCMV. (4) Strains: barley yellow striate mosaic
cytorhabdovirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.4.0.006. (8) First reported in
Hordeum vulgare. (9) From Hokkaido, Japan. (10) By Ito and Fukushi (1944a).
(13) Hordeum vulgare. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in China and Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (47)
Alopecurus aequalis, or Alopecurus geniculatus, or Alopecurus japonicus, or
Alopecurus pratensis, or Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Avena byzantina, or Avena
fatua, or Avena sativa, or Avena strigosa, or Beckmannia syzigachne, or
Calamagrostis epigejos, or Chloris virgata, or Diplachne fusca, or Echinochloa
crus-galli, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or Eragrostis multicaulis, or
Eragrostis pilosa, or Eragrostis poaeoides, or Festuca elatior, or Holcus
lanatus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or
Panicum bisulcatum, or Panicum maximum, or Pennisetum alopecuroides, or Phleum
paniculatum, or Poa annua, or Polypogon fugax, or Secale cereale, or Setaria
faberi, or Setaria italica, or Setaria viridis, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea
mays. (48) Agrostis palustris, or Bromus inermis, or Cynodon dactylon, or
Dactylis glomerata, or Eleusine coracana, or Eleusine indica, or Festuca
ovina, or Festuca rubra, or Holcus mollis, or Leersia japonica, or Oryza
sativa, or Phleum pratense, or Poa compressa, or Poa pratensis, or Poa
trivialis, or Setaria faberi, or Sorghum vulgare, or Sporobolus elongatus.
(50) Gramineae <35/52>. (51) Gramineae <18/52>. (53) Ito and Fukushi (1944a);
Ito and Fukushi (1944b); Shinkai (1955); Liu and Chen (1982); Lin et al.
(1983). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 4-5 days <at 5°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3 <sap>, or 4 <insect extracts>. (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Toriyama: grind tissues with glycine at pH 7, Celite filtration,
sucrose density gradient centrifugation, zone electrophoresis. (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear
modal length. (70) Virions of 350 nm. (71) Virions 68 nm wide. (72) Axial
canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious <if stained with UA>. (75) Pitch of
basic helix 5.5 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(87) Also phospho-lipids and sterols. Composition of sterols 10.7%,
cholesterol 12.9%, campesterol 25.6%, stigmasterol 50.8% [Gb]-sitosterol. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 10.5 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 10.5 kb. (100) Base
composition 16.3 % G. (101) Base composition 30.3 % A. (102) Base composition
16.7 % C. (103) Base composition 36.6 % U <for wheat rosette stunt strain>.
(109) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132)
Virion protein(s) six. (133) Mr <(wheat rosette stunt strain only) of the
largest(L)> 140000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 60000-63000. (137) Mr of 3rd
largest 46000-47000. (139) Mr of 4th largest 40000. (141) Mr of 5th largest
19000. (148) Virion proteins glycosylated. (164) Genome replicates in
cytoplasm. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, epidermis,
meristem, vascular parenchyma, phloem, companion cells and in developing xylem
cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They do not contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: suppression of the elongation of cells in wheat
and barley: the proportion of glucose decreases and that of xylose arabinose
increases. (179) Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: wheat rosette stunt virus is
closely related and barley yellow striate mosaic virus is distantly related.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: festuca leaf streak
virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: After one day acquisition feeding and
about 10 days latent period, transmit the virus by Laodelphax striatellus to
wheat (or barley) and japonica type rice varieties. Ceral northern mosaic
virus infects wheat (or barley), but not rice. Infected wheat (or barley)
plants, first show chlorotic striping, then develop many tillers, one by one,
to give stunted rosettes. (187) Anon. (1979). Scientia Sin. 22: 573. Gong, Z.
and Zhen, Q. (1985). Acta Biochim. Biophys. Sin. 17: 650. Gong, Z., Zhen, Q.,
Peng, T. and Shikata, E. (1985). Chinese J. Virol. 1: 257. Ishii, M. (1966).
Res. Bull. Hokkaido natn agric. Exp. Stn 89: 49. Ishii, M. (1967). Jap. J.
appl. Ent. Zool. 11: 191. Ishii, M. and Matsumoto (1964). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 29: 280. Ito and Fukushi, T. (1944a). J. Sapporo Soc. Agric. For. 36:
62. Ito and Fukushi, T. (1944b). J. Sapporo Soc. Agric. For. 36: 65. Ito and
Fukushi, T. (1956). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 21: 3. Kung and Zheng (1985).

Cestrum (?) caulimovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CV. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.T.003. (8) First reported in Cestrum parqui. (9) From Italy. (10) By
Ragozzino (1974). (13) Cestrum parqui chlorotic oak-leaf patterns and
malformation. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Italy.
(47) Cestrum parqui. (50) Solanaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions isometric. (64)
Virions 35-40 nm in diameter. (179) <Possible> Caulimovirus. (187) Hull, R.
(1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 295, 4 pp. Ragozzino, A. (1974). Ann.
Fac. Sci. agr. Univ. Napoli IV 8: 249.


Chara australis (?) furovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs and M. Torronen, 1987 and 1991. (2) Synonyms: Chara
corallina virus. (3) Standard acronym: ChAV. (5) ICTV decimal code
27.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Chara australis. (9) From the A.C.T.,
Australia. (10) By Gibbs et al. (1975). (13) Chara australis plants
symptomless but with inclusions. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (36) Studies reported by Skotnicki et al. (1976). (39) Spreads in
Australia <south-eastern rivers, but not found in the United Kingdom (4spp.)
nor in a worldwide collection of charophyte species held in Lubbock, Texas (V.
Proctor and A.J. Gibbs, unpublished data)>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Chara australis infected by injection become chlorotic and
die. (44) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Chara australis. (46) Chara australis.
(47) Chara australis. (48) Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia faba. (50) Characeae <1/1>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Gibbs et al.
(1975). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: blend Chara plants
in 1-0.5 vol. of 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.5 containing 100 mM urea and 5 mM
disodium EDTA. Filter. Stir in 2% w/v sodium chloride 4% w/v polyethylene
glycol 6000 at 4°C overnight. Centrifuge at 3000 g for 30 minutes. Collect
pellet. Resuspend in original buffer containing 8.0% butanol at room
temperature. Emulsify with 10% chloroform. Centrifuge and collect supernatant.
Purify further by centrifuging in buffered sucrose gradients. (61) Virions
rodshaped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 532 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.75 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations, or two sedimenting components in purified preparations
<in some preparations>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 230 S. (82) Isoelectric
point pH 3.4-3.7. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 11 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 11 kb. (100) Base composition 24.5 % G. (101) Base composition 28 % A.
(102) Base composition 20 % C. (103) Base composition 27.5 % U. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 18700. (134) Coat protein with approximately 170 residues. (147)
Amino acid composition: Skotnicki et al. (1976). (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells <in the cytoplasm, are banana-shaped paracrystals>.
(177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible> Furovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: tobacco mosaic and odontoglossum ringspot
tobamoviruses, but very distantly. (184) The nucleotide sequence of the
replicase motif has closest homology to that of beet necrotic yellow vein
furovirus. (186) The host of this virus was incorrectly identified first as
Chara corallina. (187) Gibbs, A.J., Skotnicki, A.H., Gardiner, J.E., Walker,
E.S. and Hollings M. (1975). Virology 64: 571. Skotnicki, A.H., Gibbs, A.J.
and Wrigley, N.G. (1976). Virology 75: 457.


Cherry A capillovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt. (5) ICTV decimal code 13.0.1.DE.01. (8) First reported
in Prunus cerasus. (9) From Germany. (10) By Jelkmann (1995). (13) Prunus
cerasus unknown. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (38) Spreads in the
Eurasian region. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Germany. (47)
Prunus cerasus. (50) Rosaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no clear modal length. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (100) Base composition 20.7 % G. (101) Base
composition 30.8 % A. (102) Base composition 20.7 % C. (103) Base composition
29.8 % U. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region 3'-terminus. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 42882. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24000. (134) Coat
protein. (146) Amino acid sequence: Jelkmann (1995). (179) Capillovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple stem grooving, apple
chlorotic leafspot, apple stem pitting and cherry mottle viruses. (187)
Jelkmann, W. (1995). J. gen. Virol. 76: 2015.


Cherry leaf roll nepovirus

      (1) A.T. Jones 1986. (2) Synonyms: ash mosaic virus (Nienhaus and
Hamacher, 1990), sambucus ringspot and yellow net virus. (3) Standard acronym:
CLRV. (4) Strains: birch ring and line pattern virus (Cooper and Atkinson,
1975); blackberry and red raspberry strains (Cropley and Tomlinson, 1971;
Jones and Wood, 1978); berteroa ringspot virus (Lockhart, 1977); elm mosaic
strain (Varney and Moore, 1952; Jones and Murant, 1971); dogwood ringspot
strain (Waterworth and Lawson, 1973); golden elderberry strain (Hansen (1967);
Hansen and Stace-Smith, 1971; Jones and Murant, 1971); red elder ringspot
strain (Schmelzer, 1972b); rhubarb strain (Tomlinson and Walkey, 1967); type
(cherry) strain (Cropley, 1961); walnut black line virus (Cooper and Edwards,
1980; De Zoeten, 1982; Mircetich et al., 1980; Rowhani et al., 1985), walnut
line pattern and mosaic virus (Christoff, 1958), walnut yellow mosaic virus,
walnut ringspot and walnut yellow vein strains (Savino et al., 1977). (5) ICTV
decimal code 18.0.3.0.009. (8) First reported in Ulmus americana (American
elm), Prunus avium (cherry) and Juglans regia (walnut). Symptoms of walnut
blackline disease, now known to be caused by cherry leaf roll first described
in 1933 by Schuster and Miller. (10) By Swingle et al. (1941; 1943); Posnette
and Cropley (1955); Schuster and Miller (1933). (11) Symptoms persist and vary
seasonally. (13) Juglans regia leaf pattern and black line. Ulmus americana
chlorotic mosaic, ring pattern and dieback. Prunus avium leaf rolling and
death. Betula spp., Sambucus spp., Rubus spp., Cornus florida chlorotic
ringspot, leaf patterns and/or yellow vein netting. Ptelea trifoliata yellow
spotting. Olea europaea, Rheum rhaponticum, Berteroa incana, Delphinium
elatum, Rumex obtusifolius symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (17)
Transmitted by Xiphinema coxi, X. diversicaudatum and X. vuittenezi (cherry
isolates Fritzsche and Kegler (1964); Flegg (1969), but not the golden
elderberry and rhubarb isolates). (24) Not transmitted by X. americanum, X.
bakeri, Longidorus elongatus, L. leptocephalus, L. macrosoma or Paralongidorus
maximus (Van Hoof, 1971; Jones et al., 1981). The elm mosaic strain is not
transmitted by X. americanum (Fulton and Fulton, 1970) or by the aphid Myzus
persicae (Ford et al., 1972). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the North
American region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China, New Zealand, Turkey, and
the former USSR. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, systemic
necrosis or mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions; systemic mottle, necrosis and malformation. Cucumis
sativus chlorotic local lesions, occasional systemic mosaic. Nicotiana
rustica, N. tabacum cvs White Burley, Xanthi-nc necrotic local lesions and
rings; systemic necrotic or chlorotic rings. (45) Nicotiana rustica, N.
tabacum cvs White Burley, Xanthi-nc for maintaining virus cultures; Nicotiana
clevelandii and Chenopodium quinoa for propagation and purification of
virions. (46) Nicotiana rustica, N. tabacum cvs White Burley, Xanthi-nc (L),
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or
Atriplex hortensis, or Berteroa incana, or Beta macrocarpa, or Beta vulgaris,
or Betula, or Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia
argentea, or Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Commelina, or
Cornus florida, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Delphinium elatum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Helianthus annuus, or Juglans regia, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lavatera
trimestris, or Lobelia erinus, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Olea europaea, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis
peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Prunus avium, or Prunus cerasifera, or Prunus
persica, or Ptelea trifoliata, or Raphanus sativus, or Rheum rhaponticum, or
Rubus idaeus, or Rumex obtusifolius, or Sambucus racemosa, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or
Tinantia erecta, or Torenia fournieri, or Tropaeolum majus, or Ulmus
americana, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Arachis hypogaea,
or Cassia tora, or Catharanthus roseus, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Solanum rostratum, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Betulaceae
<1/1>, or Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/3>, or Chenopodiaceae
<8/8>, or Commelinaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cornaceae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <2 /2>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/6>, or Juglandaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/6>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Oleaceae
<1/1>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <2 /2>,
or Ranunculaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <4/4>, or Rutaceae <1/1>, or Sambucaceae
<1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <11/15>, or Tropaeolaceae
<1/1>, or Ulmaceae <1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/6>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/6>, or
Solanaceae <4/15>. (52) All isolates have a wide experimental host range in
more than 36 plant families. (53) Schmelzer (1966); Hansen and Stace-Smith
(1971); Horváth (1979); Tomlinson and Walkey (1967); Lockhart (1977); Ahmed
and Bailiss (1975); Walkey and Cooper (1973). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV:
4-16 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-5. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Jones (1973); Cooper and Atkinson (1975), Walkey et al. (1973). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations
<Jones, 1973; Haber and Hamilton, 1980>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of
the fastest> 128 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 115 S <M>, or 52 S <T>. (79)
Density 1.5 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.47 g cm3 in CsCl <M>. (84) Virions contain
46 % nucleic acid <B>, or 41 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 54 % protein <B>, or 59 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 16.5 kb. (92) Genome of two parts <both required for infectivity; Jones
and Mayo, 1972; Jones and Duncan, 1980; Haber and Hamilton, 1980>. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 9 kb <RNA-1>. (94) The 2nd largest
7.5 kb <RNA-2>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Jones and Mayo (1972);
Walkey et al. (1973); Murant et al. (1981). (100) Base composition <RNA-1 and
RNA-2,> 26.5 and 26.6 % G. (101) Base composition 21.4 and 22 % A. (102) Base
composition 22.3 and 22.8 % C. (103) Base composition 29.1 and 29.2 % U. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A
region present <in both RNA species; Massalski, 1984>. (112) Additional factor
required for infectivity. (113) Additional factor a genome-linked protein of
estimated M.Wt 3500 (C.U.T. Hellen and J.I. Cooper, personal communication),
although not yet known if required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12615. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): S63537 Em(40)_vi:S63537
Gb(84)_vi:S63537 polyprotein (RNA-2) cherry leaf roll nepovirus CLRV, birch
isolate I2, Genomic RNA, 1920 nt S84124 Em(40)_vi:S84124 Gb(84)_vi:S84124 (3'
terminal region, RNA-1) cherry leaf roll nepovirus, Genomic RNA, 1743 nt. 1/94
1,743bp. S84125 Em(40)_vi:S84125 Gb(84)_vi:S84125 (3' terminal region, RNA-2)
cherry leaf roll nepovirus, Genomic RNA, 1805 nt. 1/94 1,805bp. S84126
Em(40)_vi:S84126 Gb(84)_vi:S84126 (3' terminal region, R25) cherry leaf roll
nepovirus, Genomic RNA, 1182 nt. 1/94 1,182bp. U24694 Em(43)_vi:Cl24694
Gb(89)_vi:Clu24694 Cherry leaf roll virus RNA2, 3' end. 5/95 1,565bp. Z34265
Em(43)_vi:Clrvrn Cherry leaf roll virus (walnut) genomic RNA (1588bp). 11/94
1,588bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 54000. (145) Method of
preparation: Jones and Mayo (1972); Walkey et al. (1973); Murant et al.
(1981). (147) Amino acid composition: Walkey et al. (1973) (five strains).
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
leaves, roots, meristem and within tubules in pollen, ovules and mature seeds
(Walkey and Webb, 1968; 1970; Jones et al., 1973). (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
membranous bodies <connected with endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes; Jones
et al., 1973>. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes:
projections from cell walls (Jones et al., 1973; Cooper and Atkinson, 1975).
Birch leaves showing symptoms often contain chloroplasts with large densely
stained plastoglobuli and poorly defined lamellae (Cooper and Atkinson, 1975).
(179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: grapevine Bulgarian latent, lucerne
Australian latent, peach rosette mosaic (Jones and Duncan, 1980), arabis
mosaic, grapevine fanleaf, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot,
tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring, tomato ringspot and tomato top necrosis
viruses (Cropley, 1961; Hansen and Stace-Smith, 1971; Jones and Murant, 1971).
(183) Gomphrena globosa is only susceptible to some strains. Virions of elm
and dogwood strains are less stable than most others (Jones, 1976). Most
strains only produce M and B components, and the ratios of the components
differ between strains. (184) Varney and Moore (1952) found that plants
infected with tomato ringspot virus resisted infection with the elm mosaic
strain. Jones (1976) confirmed this using eight strains of cherry leaf roll
virus in Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc but found none of these protected
plants against infection by tomato ringspot virus. (187) Ahmed, A.H. and
Bailiss, K.W. (1975). J. hort. Sci. 50: 47. Callahan, K.L. (1957a). Diss.

Cherry mottle leaf (?) trichovirus

      (1) Delano James, 1993. (2) Synonyms: Cerasuvirus maculans virus, Marmor
cerasae virus, Marmor cerasi virus, Prunivir cerasi virus, Prunus virus 1. (5)
ICTV decimal code 76.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Prunus avium (cherry).
(9) From Oregon, USA. (10) By Zeller (1934). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms irregular chlorotic mottle and distortion of leaves, especially
terminal leaves. (13) Prunus avium irregular chlorotic mottling and distortion
of foliage, especially terminal leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by Eriophyes inaequalis. (19)
Transmitted by Eriophyidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Belgium, Canada, the
former Czechoslovakia, Italy, Poland, Romania, South Africa, and the USA. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor local lesions,
systemic leaf distortion, epinasty, chlorosis and stunting. C. quinoa local
chlorotic spots and stunting. (44) Chenopodium foetidum, Cucumis sativus,
Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii and N. benthamiana. (45) Chenopodium
quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (W). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Prunus armeniaca, or Prunus avium, or
Prunus cerasifera, or Prunus mahaleb, or Prunus persica, or Prunus serrulata.
(48) Chenopodium foetidum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana occidentalis. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Rosaceae <6/6>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/6>. (53) Cheney
and Parish (1976), James (1992), Nemeth (1986). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV:
1 days. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: James and Mukerji
(1993). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760
nm. (71) Virions 10.2 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.1 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.62. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.2 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by James and Mukerjee, 1993. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 20500. (134) Coat protein. (166) Replication does not depend on
a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves. (179) Trichovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple chlorotic leafspot
virus, several grapevine viruses (GLRV-1, GLRV-3, NY-1 and GVA) and heracleum
latent virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA, western blot using mAbs.
(187) Cheney, P.W. and Parish, C.L. (1976). U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 437, pp.
216. James, D. (1992). Acta Hort. 309: 39. James, D. and Mukerji, S. (1993).
Plant Disease 77: 271. McCarty, H.R. (1935). Northwest Assoc. Hort. Ent. Pl.
Pathol. 1: 5. Nemeth, M. (1986). In: Virus, Mycoplasma and Rickettsia Diseases
of Fruit Trees. pp. 296-8. Akademia Kiado, Budapest. Reeves, E.L. (1941). J.
Agric. Res. 62: 555. Zeller, S.M. (1934). Rep. Oregon State Hort. Soc. 26: 92.


Cherry rasp leaf nepovirus

      (1) A.J. Hansen, 1986. (2) Synonyms: flat apple virus. (3) Standard
acronym: CRLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.003. (8) First reported in
Prunus avium. (9) From the USA. (10) By Bodine and Newton (1942). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Prunus avium, P. mahaleb affected cherry branches are
very frost sensitive (Bodine et al., 1951; Hansen et al., 1974; Wagnon et al.,
1968) enations, stunting. Prunus persica enations, stunting, decline. Malus
sylvestris enations, flat fruit. Balsamorhiza sagittata, Taraxacum officinale,
Plantago major symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Xiphinema americana (Nyland et al., 1969;
Hansen et al., 1974). (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <10-20%>. (36) Studies reported by Luepschen et al.
(1974); Wagnon et al. (1968); Parish and Cheney (1974). (38) Spreads in the
North American region and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Canada, New
Zealand, South Africa, and the USA. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in the U.K. (Jones et al., 1985), China, Australia and New Zealand and
possibly South Africa. Prunus avium raspleaf symptoms have been found in many
countries associated with one or another of seven viruses (Hansen et al.,
1974). (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show necrotic or chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottle. (43)
Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions; systemic mottle. Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium quinoa mottle
and vein clearing. Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic mottle. Vigna
unguiculata, Physalis floridana, Sesbania exaltata local lesions but
unreliable. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus. (46) Cucumis sativus
(L), Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L). (47) Balsamorhiza sagittata, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Malus sylvestris, or Physalis floridana, or Plantago major,
or Prunus avium, or Prunus mahaleb, or Prunus persica, or Sesbania exaltata,
or Taraxacum officinale, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Plantaginaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Hansen
et al. (1974). (54) TIP: 58 °C. (55) LIV: 7 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4 <Stace-Smith and Hansen, 1976>. (60) Method: Stace-Smith and Hansen
(1976). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 128 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 96 S <M>, or 56 S <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 13.3 kb. (92) Genome of two parts.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
4.8 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 24000. (135) Mr
of 2nd largest 22500. (145) Method of preparation: Stace-Smith and Hansen
(1976). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in parenchyma and plasmodesmata (Stace-Smith and Hansen, 1976). (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape <tubular structures>. (177) They contain
virions. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: tobacco ringspot, tomato
ringspot, cherry leaf roll, peach rosette mosaic, raspberry ringspot, tomato
black ring and arabis mosaic viruses (Hansen et al., 1974). (184) Cherry rasp
leaf differs from Eola raspleaf and other cherry diseases that cause leaf
enations. (187) Bodine, E.W. and Newton, N. (1942). Phytopathology 31: 333.
Bodine, E.W., Blodgett, E.C. and Lott, T.B. (1951). Hdbk. U.S. Dep. Agric. 10:
71. Hansen, A.J., Nyland, G., McElroy, F.D. and Stace-Smith, R. (1974).
Phytopathology 64: 721. Jones, A.T., Mayo, M.A. and Henderson, S.J. (1985).
Ann. appl. Biol. 106: 101. Luepschen, N.S., Harder, H.H., Rohrback, K.G. and
Sisson, M.A. (1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr 58: 26. Nyland, G., Lownsbery, B.F., Lowe,
S.K. and Mitchell, J.F. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 1111. Parish, C.L. and
Cheney, P.W. (1974). Proc. Am. phytopath. Soc. 1: 52. Stace-Smith, R. and
Hansen, A.J. (1976). Acta Hort. 67: 193. Stace-Smith, R. and Hansen, A.J.
(1976). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 159, 4 pp. Wagnon, H.F., Traylor, J.,
Willams, H.E. and Weiner, A.C. (1968). Pl. Dis. Reptr 52: 618.


Chickpea bushy dwarf potyvirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: CpBDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.017. (8) First reported in Cicer arietinum. (9) From India (Andra
Pradesh). (10) By Anjaiah et al. (1989). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cicer
arietinum small chlorotic brittle leaves, axillary buds activated but stunted
giving bushy dwarf symptoms. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show mosaics, mottles, ringspots or
necrosis. (43) Cicer arietinum chlorotic bushy dwarf. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. murale, Cyamopsis tetragonoloba chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. Canavalia ensiformis, Chenopodium quinoa, Gossypium herbaceum,
Nicotiana benthamiana, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Bountiful, Pinto systemic
necrosis. Macrotyloma uniflorum, Cassia obtusifolia necrotic local lesions;
not systemic. (44) Arachis hypogaea, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa,
Pisum sativum cv. Bonneville, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop. (45) Cicer
arietinum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Canavalia ensiformis, or
Cassia obtusifolia, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Gossypium herbaceum, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cvs Bountiful, Pinto>. (48) Arachis
hypogaea, or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cv. Top Crop>, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/11>, or
Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/5>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/11>, or Solanaceae <4/5>. (53) Anjaiah et al.
(1989). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Anjaiah et al.
(1989). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
700-720 nm. (71) Virions 13-15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 10 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 10 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Anjaiah et al. (1989). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
32500 <, sometimes degraded to 29000>. (134) Virion coat protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Anjaiah et al. (1989). (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: azuki bean
mosaic, peanut mottle and soybean mosaic virus; peanut stripe and blackeye
cowpea mosaic are more distantly related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
In India, chickpea may be also infected with alfalfa mosaic, bean yellow
mosaic, cucumber mosaic and chickpea stunt viruses. In the U.S.A., chickpea
filiform potyvirus (Kaiser et al., 1988) also infects chickpea, and bean
yellow mosaic and beet western yellow luteovirus are found in chickpea in
other parts of the world. Serological and host range tests distinguishes
readily between these viruses. (187) Anjaiah, V., Reddy, D.V.R., Mahohar,
S.K., Naidu, R.A., Nene, Y.L. and Ratna, A.S. (1989). Pl. Path. 38: 520.
Kaiser, W.J., Wyatt, S.D., Hannan, R.M. and Cody, Y. (1988). Plant Dis. 72:
70.


Chickpea chlorotic dwarf (?) monogeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: CpCDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.1.T.014. (8) First reported in Cicer arietinum. (9) From India. (10) By
Horn et al. (1993). (13) Cicer arietinum reddening of leaflets, phloem
browning and severe stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Orosius orientalis. (18) Transmitted by
Cicadellidae. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in India. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Beta vulgaris,
Lens culinaris, Pisum sativum, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
tabacum systemic leaf chlorosis, sometimes leaf mottling and stunting. Cicer
arietinum leaf yellowing and reddening, leaf rolling, phloem browning and
stunting. (44) Arachis hypogaea, Cajanus cajan, Cucumis sativus, Glycine max,
Nicotiana occidentalis, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Cicer arietinum, Pisum
sativum. (46) Cicer arietinum (W), Pisum sativum (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Cicer arietinum, or Datura stramonium, or Lens culinaris, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana

Chickpea distortion mosaic potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.03. (8) First
reported in Cicer arietinum. (9) From Parbhani, Maharashtra State, India. (13)
Cicer arietinum mosaic, leaf malformation, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora
Koch., A. gossypii Glover, Myzus persicae Sulz. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Mali (1980, 1985, 1988a); Mali and Vyanjane (1980a,
1980c, 1981); Polajiwar (1985). (39) Spreads in India <Maharashtra State>.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Canavalia ensiformis systemic
mosaic and leaf malformation. Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica vein necrosis.
Glycine max, Phaseolus lunatus, Trigonella foenum-graecum, Vigna unguiculata,
Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mosaic, mottling. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic
or necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic and leaf malformation. (44)
Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Arachis hypogaea, Vicia faba.
(45) Cicer arietinum, Canavalia ensiformis, Phaseolus lunatus, P. vulgaris.
(46) Phaseolus vulgaris (W), P. lunatus (W), Cicer arietinum (W). (47)
Canavalia ensiformis, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cicer arietinum, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Lens culinaris, or Medicago sativa, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura

Linum usitatissimum, or Luffa acutangula, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Raphanus
sativus, or Ricinus communis, or Sesamum indicum, or Solanum melongena, or
Solanum nigrum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba. (50)
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <14/18>, or
Solanaceae <1/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/18>,
or Linaceae <1/1>, or Pedaliaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <10/11>. (53) Mali
(1985); Mali and Vyanjane (1980a); Mali and Vyanjane (1980b); Polajiwar
