log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Mali et al.
(1985, 1988a). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 750 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels <associated with scrolls, but not laminated aggregates in chickpea
infected cells. Inclusions like those of subdivision I of the potyvirus group
(Edwardson, 1974; Mali et al., 1988b)>. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean common
mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, peanut mottle, soybean mosaic, wisteria vein
mosaic and swordbean distortion mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: blackeye cowpea mosaic, celery mosaic, cowpea
aphid-borne mosaic, datura distortion mosaic, papaya ringspot, potato Y,
watermelon mosaic 1 and watermelon mosaic 2 viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: chickpea is known to be naturally infected with potyviruses like
bean yellow mosaic (BYMV) (Erwin and Snyder, 1958; Kaiser and Danesh, 1971),
and its strains chickpea narrow leaf virus (CNLV) (Chalam et al., 1985) and
chickpea filiform virus (CFV) (Kaiser et al., 1988). CpDMV is distinct from
BYMV in host range and inclusion (CCI) morphology which for the latter are
type II inclusions (Edwardson et al., 1987). (187) Chalam, T.V., Reddy,
D.V.R., Subbayya, J., Nene, Y.L. and Beniwal, S.P.S. (1985). Indian Phytopath.
38(4): 708. Edwardson, J.R. (1974). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 4, p. 1.
Edwardson, J.R., Christie, R.G. and Ko, N.J. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1111.
Erwin, D.C. and Snyder, W.C. (1958). Calif. Agric. 13: 6. Hollings, M. and
Brunt, A.A. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 245, 7 pp. Kaiser, W.J. and

Chickpea filiform (?) potyvirus

      (1) P. Jeyanandarajah, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: CpFV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.T.018. (8) First reported in Cicer arietinum. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Kaiser et al. (1988). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cicer
arietinum narrow, deformed leaflets, axillary buds proliferate and become
stunted; fewer pods with small misshapen seeds. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A. (Washington State), in chickpea
originating from India. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Cicer
arietinum filiform leaves, wilting and necrosis. Lens culinaris, Trigonella
foenum-graecum systemic leaf chlorosis, leaf curling and stunting. Nicotiana
clevelandii symptomless systemic infection. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Gomphrena globosa local lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Cassia
occidentalis, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Cicer arietinum. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lens culinaris, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Trigonella
foenum-graecum. (48) Cassia occidentalis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/13>, or Solanaceae <1/3>. (51)
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/13>, or Solanaceae <2/3>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Kaiser et al. (1988). (60) Method: Kaiser et al. (1988). (61)
Virions filamentous. (70) Virions of 770 nm. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic and blackeye cowpea mosaic
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: clover yellow
vein, pea mosaic and pea seedborne mosaic viruses. (187) Kaiser, W.J., Wyatt,
S.D., Hannan, R.M. and Cody, Y. (1988). Plant Dis. 72: 70.


Chicory X potexvirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ChVX. (5) ICTV decimal
code 56.0.1.DE.01. (8) First reported in Cichorium intybus. (9) From Apulia,
southern Italy. (10) By Gallitelli and Di Franco (1982). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Cichorium intybus leaf yellowing. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy <Apulia>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local
lesions. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions.
Gomphrena globosa red-rimmed lesions. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana
tabacum, N. benthamiana, N. glutinosa, Cucumis sativus. (45) Chenopodium
amaranticolor. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Gomphrena
globosa (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cichorium intybus, or Gomphrena globosa. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Celosia
argentea, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Compositae <1/2>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <9/9>. (53)
Gallitelli and Di Franco (1982). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 15 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Hammond
and Hull (1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 553 nm. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (79) Density 1.304 g cm3
in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.19. (84) Virions contain <c.> 5 % nucleic
acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by phenol-SDS. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
25000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves
and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Fibrous
aggregates of virions. (177) They contain virions. (179) Potexvirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: potato X, cactus X, viola
mottle, pepino mosaic, clitoria mosaic, clover yellow mosaic and white clover
mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: inoculation onto Chenopodium
amaranticolor and serology. (187) Gallitelli, D. and Di Franco, A. (1982).
Phytopath. Z. 105: 120. Hammond, J. and Hull, R. (1981). J. gen. Virol. 54:
75. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680.


Chicory yellow blotch (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: chicory yellows virus, chicory
blotch virus. (3) Standard acronym: ChYBV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.T.1.009.
(8) First reported in Cichorium intybus. (9) From the former Czechoslovakia.
(10) By KvicHala (1956). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cichorium intybus
vein-clearing, yellow flecks, necrosis and leaf distortion. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Czechoslovakia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Beta
vulgaris, Chenopodium giganteum, C. quinoa, Gomphrena globosa local lesions;
no systemic infection. Cichorium intybus conspicuous leaf chlorosis. (44)
Amaranthus caudatus, Cucumis sativus. (45) Cichorium intybus. (46) Chenopodium
giganteum (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium giganteum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium intybus, or Gomphrena globosa. (48)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Cucumis sativus. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days <at 1822°C>. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 657 nm. (71)
Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus.
(187) BrcHak, J. (1960). Biol. Pl.. Acad. Sci. bohemsl. 2: 244. BrcHak, J.
(1961). Biol. Pl.. Acad. Sci. bohemsl. 3: 215. BrcHak, J. and Cech, M. (1962).

617.


Chicory yellow mottle nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: parsley carrot leaf virus (Avgelis
and Quacquarelli, 1974). (3) Standard acronym: ChYMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.0.010. (8) First reported in Cichorium intybus. (9) From Italy. (10) By
Vovla et al. (1971). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cichorium intybus ringspots,
line pattern and bright yellow mottling of leaves. Petroselinum crispum
reduction of leaf laminae. (15) Possibly by nematodes. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Italy. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Cucurbita pepo chlorotic
local lesions; systemic chlorosis, ringspots and necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris

116 S <M>, or 51 S <T>. (84) Virions contain 42 % nucleic acid <B>, or 39 %

Coat protein. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: tomato ringspot virus. (187)

and Quacquarelli, A. (1974b). Phytopath. Medit. 13: 97. Piazzolla, P.,

Chilli veinal mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. Revised 1992. (3) Standard acronym: ChiVMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Capsicum annuum. (9)
From Malayasia. (10) By Burnett (1947). (12) Symptoms veinal mottle,
malformation. (13) Capsicum annuum, C. frutescens dark green mottling adjacent
to main leaf veins, reduction in leaf area and distortion; plants stunted
(severity dependent upon cultivar and duration of infection). Capsicum spp.
veinal mottle, malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, A. spiraecola,
Myzus persicae, Toxoptera citricidus, Hysteroneura setarieae, Rhopalosiphum
maidis. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Korea D.P.R. (North), Korea Republic, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and
Thailand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Capsicum annuum systemic
vein clearing, followed by leaf mottling. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Datura
stramonium, Gomphrena globosa, Cucumis sativus. (45) Capsicum annuum, Nicandra
physalodes, Nicotiana megalosiphon, Physalis floridana, Nicotiana tabacum.
(46) Capsicum annuum (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana. (48) Ageratum conyzoides, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Luffa acutangula, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Passiflora
edulis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis , or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Solanaceae <7/13>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<4/4>, or Passifloraceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <6/13>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae.

pepper veinal mottle and pepper mottle (S.K. Green, personal communication).

Series No. 33, p. 3. Burnett, F. (1947). Rep. Agric. Malaya 1946, 85 pp. Ong,
C.A., Varghese, G. and Poh, T.W. (1979). MARDI Res. Bull. 7: 78.


Chinese yam necrotic mosaic (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Molyneux, 1986 and F. Nienhaus, 1987. (3) Standard
acronym: ChYNMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.T.1.010. (8) First reported in

(1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dioscorea batatas chlorotic and necrotic
spots or netting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae and Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (39) Spreads in Japan. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorosis. (43) Dioscorea batatas chlorosis and necrosis. (45) Dioscorea

batatas f. typica. (50) Dioscoreaceae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Fukumoto and Tochihara (1978). (61) Virions filamentous.

Carlavirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: The virus can be detected and
identified rapidly by electro-blot immuno-assay. (187) Fukumoto, F. and
Tochihara, H. (1978). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 44: 1. Shirako, Y. and Ehara,
Y. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 453.


Chino del tomaté bigeminivirus

      (1) J.K. Brown, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: CdTV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.011. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From Mexico.
(10) By Brown and Hine (1984). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13)
Lycopersicon esculentum leaf mottling, yellowing, curling. Capsicum annuum
vein-puckering and striping on stems and fruit. This virus together with
pepper mild tigré virus and another uncharacterised virus induces symptoms in
peppers a disease described as tigré, in Mexico and south Texas. Malva
parviflora leaf mottling, yellowing and malformation. Datura stramonium severe
mosaic and leaf malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by
Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Brown and
Nelson (1988). (39) Spreads in Mexico and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics,
mottles, ringspots or necrosis and leaf curling. (43) Lycopersicon esculentum
cv. Pole Boy, Malva parviflora, Nicotiana benthamiana, Datura stramonium, Lens
culinaris cv. Chilean Lentil 78 systemic mottling and leaf curling. (44)
Lactuca sativa cv. Empire, Citrullus lanatus cv. Charleston Gray, Pisum
sativum, Gossypium hirsutum cv. DP90, Solanum melongena cv. Black Beauty. (45)
Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Pole Boy, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Lycopersicon esculentum (W), Datura stramonium (W), Capsicum
annuum (W), Lens culinaris (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens,
or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lens culinaris, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Malva parviflora, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Chenopodium album, or Cicer
arietinum, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Medicago sativa, or
Physalis peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum
melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea,
or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>, or Malvaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <11/14>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <4/4>, or
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/7>, or Malvaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <3 /14>,
or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Brown and Nelson (1988). (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: labile even after fixation with
buffered (pH 7) 0.25% glutaraldehyde. (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 20
nm in diameter. (65) Virions 30 nm in length. (84) Virions contain 20 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 5.2 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 2.6-2.7 kb. (94)
The 2nd largest 2.6-2.7 kb. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (187) Brown, J.K. and Hine, R.B. (1984). Phytopathology 74:
844. Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R. (1988). Plant Dis. 72: 866. Brown, J.K.,
Goldstein, D.E. and Nelson, M.R. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 862.


Chloris striate mosaic monogeminivirus

      (1) R. Greber, 1986. (2) Synonyms: Australian wheat striate mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: CSMV. (4) Strains: Chloris (C) and Microlaena.
(5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Chloris gayana. (9)
From Australia. (10) By Grylls (1963). (13) Gramineae including Chloris
gayana, Ixophorus unisetus and Dactylis glomerata and cereals such as Triticum
spp., Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Zea mays streaking or mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Nesoclutha (obscura) pallida. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (34) Virus <possibly> transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic streaks. (43) Chloris
gayana, Hordeum vulgare yellow or grey streaks. (45) Chloris gayana for
maintaining cultures by vegetative propagation, the leaves are a good source
of virus. (46) Chloris gayana (W) and the vector Nesoclutha pallida assayed by
feeding on Chloris gayana (Grylls and Waterford, 1976; Francki et al., 1979).
(47) Avena sativa, or Chloris gayana, or Dactylis glomerata, or Eleusine
coracana, or Hordeum vulgare, or Ixophorus unisetus, or Triticum aestivum, or
Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <8/8>. (53) Grylls (1963). (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: use UA not PTA-H. (60) Method: Francki
et al. (1979). (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65)
Virions 30 nm in length <Hatta and Francki, 1979>. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl <after
fixation in glutaraldehyde>. (84) Virions contain 19 % nucleic acid. (88)
Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome
size 2.75 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.75
kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10820. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
M20021 Em(40)_vi:GECHMGEN Gb(84)_vi:CHMGEN Chloris striate mosaic virus DNA,
complete genome. 7/89 2,750bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133)
Mr 28000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll,
meristem and phloem (Francki et al., 1979). (172) Virions found in nuclei.
(173) Virions found in sometimes in the cytoplasm and cell vacuole (Francki et
al., 1979). (179) Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean golden mosaic virus,
cassava African mosaic virus (Francki et al., 1979, 1980). (187) Derrick, K.S.
and Brlansky, R.H. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 815. Francki, R.I.B. (1980).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 221, 4 pp. Francki, R.I.B., Hatta, T., Grylls,
N.E. and Grivell, C.J. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 91: 51. Francki, R.I.B.,
Hatta, T., Boccardo, G. and Randles, J.W. (1980). Virology 101: 233. Grylls,
N.E. (1963). Aust. J. agric. Res. 14: 143. Grylls, N.E. and Waterford, C.J.

Chrysanthemum B carlavirus

      (1) J.R. Moran, 1987. (2) Synonyms: chrysanthemum virus Q, chrysanthemum
dwarf mottle virus, chrysanthemum mild mosaic virus (Hollings, 1957),

acronym: CVB. (4) Strains: chrysanthemum vein mottle virus (Hakkaart and Maat,
1974). (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Chrysanthemum
morifolium. (9) From the Netherlands. (10) By Noordam (1952). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Chrysanthemum morifolium sometimes mottling, vein clearing or
necrotic streaks, but often symptomless. Gynura aurantiaca symptomless
infection. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Acyrthosiphon
(Aulacorthum) solani, Coloradoa rufomaculata and Macrosiphoniella
(Pyrethromyzus) sanborni (Hollings, 1957). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Hollings (1957). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <wherever
chrysanthemums are grown>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions, systemic

chlorotic spots. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mottling, vein clearing. (44)

not reliable. (47) Aster amellus, or Chrysanthemum carinatum, or Chrysanthemum

<2/2>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae

Citrus enation woody gall (?) luteovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. Revised by R.F. Lee, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal
code 39.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Citrus species as Citrus limon, C.
aurantifolia and C. paradisi. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Wallace and
Drake (1953). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Citrus limon abaxial enations on
main leaf veins of seedlings and woody galls in older trees. C. aurantifolia,
C. paradisi, C. sinensis enations on leaves of seedling. C. reticulata few or
no symptoms. Also found in Ficus sp., Ulmus sp., Morus sp., Rosa sp., Prunus
domestica, Viburnum sp., Eucalyptus sp. in coastal regions of N.S.W.,
Australia woody galls. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Toxoptera citricidus, Myzus persicae and Aphis
gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting <of buds>. (39) Spreads in Australia <the central coast region of
N.S.W., citrus trees are found far from citrus plantations. Such feral trees
are often infected with woody gall, and similar galls are occasionally seen on
other species>, or South Africa and the USA <in California and most citrus
growing countries>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Citrus limon
enation in seedlings and galls after 18 months. (45) Citrus limon. (46) Citrus
limon (W). (47) Citrus aurantifolia, or Citrus aurantium, or Citrus limon, or
Citrus paradisi, or Citrus reticulata, or Citrus sinensis, or Eucalyptus, or
Ficus, or Morus alba, or Prunus domestica, or Rosa, or Ulmus, or Viburnum.
(50) Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Moraceae <2/2>, or Myrtaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae
<2/2>, or Rutaceae <6/6>, or Ulmaceae <1/1>. (53) Fraser and Broadbent (1979).
(61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 24-26 nm in diameter <Hooper et al.,
1974; Maharaj and da Graca, 1988>. (171) Virions found in phloem, companion
cells and the bark in cambium. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (187) Fraser, L.R.
(1959). Proc. Linn. Soc. N.S.W. LXXIV: 332. Fraser, L.R. and Broadbent, P.
(1979). "Virus and Related Diseases of Citrus in New South Wales", p. 50. Dep.
Agric. N.S.W. Surrey Beatty and Sons Pty Ltd, Australia. Hooper, G.R., Spink,
G.C. and Myers, R. (1974). Virology cited by P.R. Desjardins et al. (1974)
Proc. 6th Conf. Int. Org. Citrus Virol., Univ. California, Riverside, U.S.A.
Maharaj, S.B. and da Graca, J.V. (1988). Phytophylactica 20: 357. McLean,
A.P.D. (1954). S. Afr. J. Sci. 50: 147. Wallace, J.M. and Drake, R.J. (1953).
Calif. Citrogr. 38: 180. Wallace, J.M. and Drake, R.J. (1960). Pl. Dis. Reptr
44: 580. Wallace, J.M. and Drake, R.J. (1961). Pl. Dis. Reptr 45: 682.


Citrus leaf rugose ilarvirus

      (1) P. Barkley, 1987. Checked by R.F. Lee, 1989. (2) Synonyms: citrus
psorosis virus complex, citrus crinkly leaf ilarvirus. (3) Standard acronym:
CiLRV. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.02.03. (8) First reported in Citrus limon.
(9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Fawcett (1936). (11) Symptoms persist, or vary
seasonally. (13) Citrus aurantifolia, C. limon, C. paradisi flecking of young
leaves and malformation of old leaves (particularly of Eureka lemons), fruit
small and lumpy. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red Kidney necrotic local lesions, no
systemic infection. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus <possibly> transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the USA
<California>. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Australia. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Citrus limon Eureka lemon asteroid local
lesions. Citrus sinensis, C. limon, C. reticulata crinkling and flecking.
Vigna unguiculata vein clearing, malformation. Crotalaria spectabilis systemic
chlorotic veinbanding. (45) Any Citrus species. (46) Vigna unguiculata cv.
`Blackeye' No. 5. (L). (47) Catharanthus roseus, or Citrus aurantifolia, or
Citrus limon, or Citrus paradisi, or Citrus reticulata, or Citrus sinensis, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cv. Red Kidney>, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or

sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 105 S. (78) Of the other(s) 98 S <also 89 and 79>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.4-1.46 <mixed components>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.888 kb. (92) Genome of
three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 3.099 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
2.817 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 1.972 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 37126. (118)

protein genes, complete cds. 4/95 2, U17726 Em(43)_vi:Cl17726

ilarvirus putative viral replicase gene, complete cds. 8/95 3,404bp. (120)

Citrus leprosis (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1985. Revised by R.F. Lee, 1989. (3) Standard
acronym: CiLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.T.001. (8) First reported in
Citrus sinensis. (9) From Sao Paolo, Brazil. (10) By Bitancourt (1940). (11)
Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Citrus sinensis large chlorotic
blotches on fruits, leaves and twigs. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by Brevipalpus phoenicis. (19)
Transmitted by Tetranychidae. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Argentina, Brazil,
and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Citrus sp. (46) Citrus
sp. (W). (47) Citrus aurantifolia, or Citrus sinensis. (50) Rutaceae <2/2>.
(61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (70) Virions
of 100-110 nm. (71) Virions 30 nm wide. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in nuclei <commonly associated with its envelope>. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177)
They do not contain virions. (179) <Possible> unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Bitancourt, A.A. (1940). Biologico 6: 39. Chagas, C.M.
and Rossetti, V. (1980). Fitopatol. Bras. 5: 211. Fawcett, H.S. (1936). In:
Citrus Diseases and their Control, 2nd ed. McGraw Hill, New York. Kitajima,
E.W., Muller, G.W., Costa, A.S. and Yuki, W. (1972). Virology 50: 254. Knorr,
C.L. (1950). Phytopathology 40: 15. Knorr, L.C. (1968). Proc. 4th Conf. Int.
Org. Citrus Virol., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, p. 332.


Citrus ringspot virus

      (1) K.S. Derrick, 1989. (2) Synonyms: citrus psorosis virus complex A
and B (Whiteside et al., 1988; da Graca et al., 1991). (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.15. (8) First reported in Citrus sp. (9) From Florida and
California, U.S.A. (10) By Swingle and Webber (1896); Fawcett (1933); Wallace
and Drake (1968). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Citrus sp. epinasty, chlorotic
flecks, leaf mottling, ringspots or large, irregular chlorotic patterns on
mature leaves. (15) Possibly by a vector as, in Argentina spread is not
related to grafting. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by in Compendium of
Citrus Diseases (1988). (39) Spreads in Argentina <controlled by using
virus-free budwood>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles,
ringspots or necrosis. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red
Kidney local lesions. Zinnia elegans cv. Thembelina symptomless. (45) Citrus
sp. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrus
aurantifolia, or Citrus aurantium, or Citrus limon, or Citrus medica, or
Citrus paradisi, or Citrus sinensis, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis
sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Nicotiana benthamiana,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Poncirus trifoliata, or Sesamum indicum, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Rutaceae <7/7>, or Solanaceae <6 /6>. (53) Timmer et
al. (1978). (55) LIV: 2 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (57)
Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Derrick et al. (1988). (61) Virions
filamentous. (62) Virions they vary in length. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous <extremely>. (70) Virions of 300-500 nm, or
1500-2500 nm. (71) Virions <c.> 8-10 nm wide. (76) Two sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (88) Genome <probably> consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (92) Genome of two parts. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133)
Mr 48000. (134) Probably coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Derrick et
al. (1988). (171) Virions found in leaves (isolated from leaf tissue). (179)
(Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: see Derrick et al. (1988). (187)
Compendium of Citrus Diseases (1988). Amer. Phytopath. Soc.. Eds J.O.
Whiteside, S.M. Garnsey and L.W. Timmer. APS Press. Da Graca, J.V., Lee, R.F.,
Moreno, P., Civerolo, E.L. and Derrick, K.S. (1991). Plant Dis. 75: 613.
Derrick, K.S., Brlansky, R.H., Da Graca, J.V., Lee, R.F., Timmer, L.W. and
Nguyen, T.K. (1988). Phytopathology 78: 1298. Derrick, K.S., Lee, R.F.,
Hewitt, B.G., Barthe, G.A. and Da Graca, J.V. (1991). Proc. 11th Conf. Int.
Org. Citrus Virol. Fawcett, H.S. (1933). Phytopathology 23: 930. Swingle, W.T.
and Webber, H.J. (1896). U.S. Dep. Agr. Div. Veg. Phys. Path. Bull. 8: 42 pp.
Timmer, L.W., Garnsey, S.M. and McRitchie, J.J. (1978). Pl. Dis. Reptr 62:
1054. Wallace, J.M. and Drake, R.J. (1968). Proc. 4th Conf. Int. Org. Citrus
Virol. Ed. J.F.L. Childs. Florida Press, Gainesville, Florida, U.S.A..
Whiteside, J.O., Garnsey, S.M. and Timmer, L.W. (1988). In: Compendium Citrus
Diseases, pp. 88. Amer. Phytopath. Soc., St. Paul, Minnesota, U.S.A.


Citrus tatter leaf capillovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. Revised by R.F. Lee, 1989. (2) Synonyms:
citrange stunt virus (Roistacher, 1988). (3) Standard acronym: CTLV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 13.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Citrus limon cv. Meyer lemon.
(9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Wallace and Drake (1962). (11) Symptoms
vary seasonally. (13) Citrus limon cv. Meyer tatter leaf; blotchy and
malformed leaves. C. excelsa tatter leaf or symptomless. C. sinensis
symptomless. Poncirus trifoliata interveinal chlorosis. (15) Probably is moved
and dispersed only in infected budwood. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <in lily>. (36) Studies reported by Takahara et al. (1988); Koizumi
(1984); Navarro et al. (1989); Miyakawa (1980); Roistacher et al. (1980). (38)
Spreads in the African region, the Eastern Asian region, the North American
region, and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China, Japan, Korea
D.P.R. (North), Korea Republic, South Africa, Taiwan, and the USA. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in N.S.W., Australia. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible to few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show tatter leaf, systemic mottle. (43) Citrus excelsa
tatter leaf. Poncirus trifoliata interveinal chlorosis. Nicotiana clevelandii,
N. glutinosa chlorotic veinal blotching. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local
lesions, systemic mottle and curling. Citrus sinensis × Poncirus trifoliata
cv. Rusk, Poncirus trifoliata × Citrus paradisi cv. Swingle leaf malformation
and twisted stems. (45) Citrus excelsa, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa,
Vigna unguiculata. (46) Citrus excelsa (W), Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrus aurantifolia, or Citrus excelsa, or Citrus
limon, or Citrus medica, or Citrus sinensis, or Citrus sinensis × Poncirus
trifoliata <cv. Rusk>, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Poncirus trifoliata, or Poncirus trifoliata × Citrus paradisi <cv. Swingle>,
or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Crotalaria
spectabilis, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>,
or Rutaceae <8/8>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (53) Garnsey (1974);
Fraser and Broadbent (1979); Marais and Lee (1986). (60) Method: Semancik and
Weathers (1965). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650 nm. (71) Virions 19 nm
wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 33759. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D14455 Em(43)_vi:Ctlvcc Gb(89)_vi:Ctlvcc
Citrus tatter leaf virus RNA for viral polymerase protein, cell to cell
movement proteinD16368 Em(40)_vi:CTLA Gb(84)_vi:CTLA Citrus tatter leaf virus

Capillovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: apple stem
grooving virus. (186) Recent tests indicate that this virus is probably a
closely related strain of apple stem grooving capillovirus rather than a
distinct virus (Ohira et al., 1994). (187) Catara, A. and Wallace, J.M.
(1970). Phytopathology 70: 737. Fulton, R.W. (1966). Phytopathology 56: 575.

Citrus tristeza closterovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1986; D.J. Gumpf, 1987, U.S.A. Revised by R.F.
Lee, 1989. (2) Synonyms: citrus quick decline virus (Fawcett and Wallace,
1946), grapevine A virus, hassaku dwarf virus, lime dieback closterovirus. (3)
Standard acronym: CTV. (4) Strains: seedling yellows virus (Fraser, 1952),
grapefruit stem pitting virus (Oberholzer et al., 1946), grapefruit stunt bush
virus (Anon, 1950), lime die-back virus (Hughes and Lister, 1949), Ellendale
mandarin decline virus (Stubbs, 1952). (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.1.01.
(8) First reported in Citrus sinensis and C. aurantifolia. (9) From Italy and
California, U.S.A. (10) By Meneghini (1946); Fawcett and Wallace (1946);
Kitajima et al. (1964). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Citrus spp. grafted onto
Citrus aurantifolia (sour orange) root stock quick decline, pitted stems. C.
paradisi (grapefruit) stunt. C. aurantifolia (lime) die-back. C. aurantifolia
(Seville orange) seedling yellows. C. reticulata (mandarin) decline. Aeglopsis
chevalieri, Afraegle paniculata, Pamburus missionis, Passiflora gracilis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Toxoptera citricidus (Meneghini, 1946; Costa and Grant, 1951), Aphis gossypii,
A. spiraecola and Toxoptera aurantii (Dickson et al., 1951; Norman and Grant,
1956). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Costa and Muller (1980). (37) Probably distributed worldwide
<whereever citrus is grown>. (38) Spreads in the African region, the Eastern
Asian region, the Eurasian region, the Mediterranean region, the North
American region, and the Pacific region. (39) Spreads in Algeria, or American
Samoa, or Antigua and Barbuda, or Argentina, or Australia, or Belize, or
Bermuda, or Bolivia, or Brazil, or Brunei Darussalam, or Cameroon, or the
Central African Republic, or Chad, or China, or Colombia, or Costa Rica, or
Cyprus, or the Dominican Republic, or Ecuador, or Egypt, or El Salvador, or
Ethiopia, or Fiji, or French Polynesia, or Gabon, or Ghana, or Guyana, or
India, or Indonesia, or Iran, or Israel, or Italy, or Jamaica, or Japan, or
Kenya, or Korea Republic, or Malaysia, or Mauritius, or Morocco, or
Mozambique, or Nepal, or Netherlands Antilles, or New Caledonia, or New
Zealand, or Nicaragua, or Nigeria, or Pakistan, or Panama, or Paraguay, or
Peru, or the Philippines, or Portugal, or Puerto Rico, or Saudi Arabia, or
Spain, or Sri Lanka, or Suriname, or Taiwan, or Tanzania, or Thailand, or
Trinidad and Tobago, or Turkey, or the USA, or Uganda, or Uruguay, or
Venezuela, or Vietnam, or Zaire, or Zambia, or Western Samoa, or the former
Yugoslavia, or Zimbabwe. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Citrus
aurantifolia cvs West Indian lime, Key lime, Mexican lime, Galego lime, Kagzi
lime chlorotic vein flecks, leaves cupped or canoe-shaped; stem pitting
(Wallace and Drake, 1951). C. sinensis on rootstock C. aurantifolia sudden
wilt, decline and death, overgrowth on bud union and `honeycombing' just below
union. C. sinensis, C. paradisi stem pitting. (45) Citrus aurantifolia, C.
excelsa, C. sinensis. (46) Citrus aurantifolia (W). (47) Aeglopsis chevalieri,
or Afraegle paniculata, or Citrus aurantifolia, or Citrus aurantium, or Citrus
excelsa, or Citrus limon, or Citrus medica, or Citrus paradisi, or Citrus
reticulata, or Citrus sinensis, or Pamburus missionis, or Passiflora gracilis.
(50) Passifloraceae <1/1>, or Rutaceae <11/11>. (53) Wallace and Drake (1951);
Knorr (1956); Müller et al. (1974). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Bar-Joseph et al. (1970). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 2000 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 140 S
<±10>. (81) Density 1.257 g/ml. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 17-20 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 17-20 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Bar-Joseph et al. (1985). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12162. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): L12175 Em(40)_vi:CTVCOATB Gb(84)_vi:CTVCOATB Citrus
tristeza virus coat protein mRNA, complete cds. 12/93 672bp. M76485

complete cds. 7/92 1,080bp. S67800 Em(40)_vi:S67800 Gb(84)_vi:S67800 coat

defective RNA DCTV-RNA. 4/95 2,424bp. (145) Method of preparation: Lee et al.
(1988). (147) Amino acid composition: Lee et al. (1988). (166) Replication

Citrus variegation ilarvirus

      (1) P. Barkley, 1987. Checked by R.F. Lee, 1989. (2) Synonyms: citrus
psorosis virus complex infectious variegation component. (3) Standard acronym:
CVV. (4) Strains: CVV-I, CVV-II. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.02.04. (8) First
reported in Citrus limon. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Fawcett and
Klotz (1939). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally <with growth flushes>.
(13) Citrus aurantifolia, C. limon and other species malformation and
young-leaf flecking (psorosis): more severe in sour orange and lemon. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus <possibly> transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by
Wallace (1978). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <occurs in most citrus
growing countries, but is not common>. (39) Spreads in Australia and the USA.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Citrus aurantifolia, C. limon
cv. Eureka leaf flecking, mosaic and malformation. (45) Any Citrus species.
(46) Vigna unguiculata (W), Capsicum frutescens var. grossum (W). (47)
Capsicum frutescens, or Capsicum frutescens var. grossum, or Citrus
aurantifolia, or Citrus aurantium, or Citrus limon, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Rutaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (61)
Virions unusually shaped. (62) Virions irregularly isometric. (64) Virions
26-35 nm in diameter. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 37127. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): U17389 Em(43)_vi:Cv17389 Gb(89)_vi:Cvu17389 Citrus
variegation virus RNA 3 movement protein and coat protein genes, complete cds.
5/95 2. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 2>. (180) : Bromoviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: citrus leaf rugose virus
(but distinct). (187) Calvert, L.A., Lee, R.F. and Hiebert, E. (1987). Proc.
10th Conf. Int. Org. Citrus Virol., p. 114. Corbett, M.K. and Grant, T.J.
(1967). Phytopathology 57: 137. Davino, M. and Garnsey, S.M. (1980). Proc. 9th

(1970). Virology 40: 746. Fawcett, H.S. and Klotz, L.J. (1939). Phytopathology
29: 911. Garnsey, S.M. (1974). Proc. 6th Conf. Int. Org. Citrus Virol., p.
169. Gonsalves, D. and Garnsey, S.M. (1976). Proc. 7th Conf. Int. Org. Citrus
Virol., p. 109. Rana, G.L., Quacquarelli, A. and Martelli, G.P. (1974). Proc.

In: Citrus Industry Vol. 4, p. 72.


Clitoria mosaic (?) potexvirus

      (1) K.M. Srivastava and R.K. Raizada, 1984. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.D.04. (8) First reported in Clitoria ternatea. (9) From Lucknow,
India. (10) By Srivastava and Singh (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Clitoria ternatea, Crotalaria spectabilis systemic mosaic. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic
lesions, systemic mosaic or veinal necrosis. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor
necrotic local lesions. Crotalaria spectabilis systemic mosaic. Vigna
unguiculata necrotic local lesions, systemic veinal necrosis. (44) Cucumis
sativus, Arachis hypogaea, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa. (45) Vigna
unguiculata. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Clitoria ternatea, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Datura

basilicum, or Oryza sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or

splendens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Viola cornuta, or Zea mays, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/10>, or Solanaceae <2/9>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <6/6>, or

Clitoria yellow vein tymovirus

      (1) K. Bock, 1980. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: CYVV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 77.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Clitoria ternatea. (9) From
Kenya. (10) By Bock et al. (1977a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Abrus
precatorius mottle. Clitoria ternatea systemic vein chlorosis. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Kenya. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic or chlorotic local
lesions, systemic vein chlorosis or mosaic. (43) Bauhinia purpurea, Cajanus
cajan vein netting. Clitoria ternatea systemic mosaic and vein netting.
Glycine max systemic vein netting, chlorosis. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Long Tom
necrotic or chlorotic local lesions, systemic vein netting. Vigna radiata
necrotic local lesions. V. unguiculata systemic mottle. Vigna subterranea
systemic mottle. Datura metel systemic vein netting. Nicotiana clevelandii
systemic vein netting. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Glycine max, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Datura metel, Nicotiana clevelandii. (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Abrus precatorius, or Arachis hypogaea, or Bauhinia purpurea, or Cajanus
cajan, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cicer arietinum, or Clitoria ternatea, or
Datura metel, or Desmodium tortuosum, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum nigrum, or
Vigna angularis, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna subterranea, or Vigna unguiculata.
(48) Adansonia digitata, or Beta vulgaris, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum
annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Ceiba pentandra, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Crotalaria
spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Datura ferox, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Ipomoea setosa, or Lycopersicon

albus, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum,

Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba. (50) Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/21>, or Malvaceae <1/2>, or

or Sterculiaceae <1 /1>. (53) Bock et al. (1977a; 1977b). (54) TIP: 72 °C.
(55) LIV: 21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 8. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Bock et al. (1977a). (61) Virions isometric. (63)

sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 19429. (145) Method of

Clover enation (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) P.W.G. Chu, 1985. (2) Synonyms: clover enation mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: CLOEV (ClEV). (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.010. (8) First
reported in Trifolium repens. (9) From Northern Italy. (10) By Rubio-Huertos
and Bos (1969). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium repens enations on main
veins of leaves. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Italy <the north>. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show tumours. (43) Vicia faba vein
clearing, then vein swelling to give chains of spindle-shaped tumours. (47)
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia
faba. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>. (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length.
(70) Virions of 200 nm. (71) Virions 80 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious.
(171) Virions found in in leaf tissue with enations. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in mitochondria. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the nucleus <arrays of
tubular virions>, or membranous bodies <formed by the endoplasmic reticulum>.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: enations on the
abaxial surface of the main leaf veins, containing tumorous virus-containing
cells with enlarged nuclei and nucleoli surrounded by normal virus-free cells.
(179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(186) A MLO is thought to cause a similar disease. (187) Bogatyrenko, T.N.
(1977). Biol. Nauki 20: 120. Francki, R.I.B. (1973). Adv. Virus Res. 18: 257.
Matthews, R.E.F. (1982). 2nd Report of ICTV. Rubio-Huertos, M. and Bos, L.
(1969). Neth J. Pl. Path. 75: 329.


Clover mild mosaic virus

      (1) B. Gerhardson. 1982. Revised 1983. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.16. (8) First reported in Trifolium pratense. (9) From Sweden. (10)
By Gerhardson (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium pratense, T.
hybridum mosaic and malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Sweden. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris
necrotic local lesions. Pisum sativum systemic mosaic, ringspots, leaf shape
malformation. Trifolium hybridum, Vicia faba systemic mosaic, leaf
malformation. (45) Pisum sativum, Trifolium hybridum, Vicia faba. (46)
Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (47) Lathyrus odoratus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium repens, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/12>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<4/12>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1
/1>. (53) Gerhardson (1977). (54) TIP: 56-60 °C. (55) LIV: 7-14 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Gerhardson
(1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 27-28
nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Four sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 121 S.
(78) Of the other(s) 101 S, or 82 S, or 54 S. (179) (Ungrouped). (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: red clover mottle, broad bean
stain, broad bean true mosaic, broad bean wilt, alsike clover vein mosaic and
arabis mosaic viruses. (187) Gerhardson, B. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 89: 116.


Clover wound tumor phytoreovirus

      (1) L.M. Black, 1981. Revised 1984 and 1986. (2) Synonyms: wound tumor
virus, clover big vein virus, Aureogenus magnivena virus, Trifoliumvirus
nervicrassans virus. (3) Standard acronym: WTV. (4) Strains: NJ and WT. (5)
ICTV decimal code 60.0.8.0.004. (8) First reported in Melilotus officinalis
clone C10, and the vector Agallia constricta. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By
Black (1944). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium incarnatum, Melilotus
officinalis irregular vein enlargement on the abaxial surface of leaves,
depression of veins on the adaxial surface, root tumours at bases of lateral
roots. Catharanthus roseus no symptoms described (Hillman et al., 1991). (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Agalliopsis novella, Agallia constricta, A. quadripunctata. (18) Transmitted
by Cicadellidae. (24) Not transmitted by Aceratagallia sanguinolenta. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector <2% of vector eggs>. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(38) Spreads in the North American region. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show tumours. (43)
Rumex acetosa tumours at bases of lateral roots. Melilotus officinalis.
Trifolium incarnatum irregular vein enlargement on abaxial surface of leaf,
depression of veins on adaxial surface. (45) Melilotus officinalis, Trifolium
incarnatum. (46) Trifolium incarnatum (W), and quantitative assays using
vector cell monolayers. (47) Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Catharanthus roseus,
or Dianthus barbatus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus officinalis
<clone C10>, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Rumex acetosa,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium incarnatum,
or Trifolium pratense. (48) Melilotus albus. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/4>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/3>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>. (53) Black
(1945), and L.M. Black (pers. comm.). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: <1 year at
0°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (60) Method: Reddy and Black (1973). (61)
Virions isometric. (64) Virions 73 nm in diameter <but when the outer
amorphous layer is removed a shell of distinct capsomeres, 5963 nm in
diameter, is revealed, and within that a core without spikes c.50 nm in
diameter>. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement <unless the outer shell is removed>. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
510 S <Kalmakoff et al., 1969>. (79) Density 1.39 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions
contain 22 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 78 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (91) Total genome size 25.277 kb <pairs>. (92)
Genome of 12 parts <named S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
largest> 4.131 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.532 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd
largest 3.205 kb <pairs>. (96) The 4th largest 2.565 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th
largest 2.613 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 1.726 kb
<pairs; also 1.700, 1.472, 1.182, 1.192, 1.128 and 0.851 kb pairs>. (105) Base
composition of ds genome 39 % (G + C). (108) Infectivity decreased when
deproteinised with proteases <after removal of 2 virion proteins with trypsin
or chymotrypsin>. (109) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10987. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): J03020 Em(40)_vi:WTVDI Gb(84)_vi:WTVDI Wound tumor virus genome
segment S5 encoding polypeptide P5, complete cds. 7/89 2,613bp. J04344

Clover yellow mosaic potexvirus

      (1) O.W. Barnett, R.H. Baum, S. Scott, B. Reddick and J.C. Tu, 1981.
Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: pea mottle virus. (3) Standard acronym: ClYMV. (4)
Strains: broad bean mild mosaic virus (Yu, 1979). (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Trifolium repens. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By Johnson (1942); Pratt (1961). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium spp.,
Pisum sativum, Chenopodium album, Malus pumila, Medicago alba, M. sativa,
Vicia sativa, Stellaria media mosaic with necrotic streaks. (24) Not
transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Anuraphis bakeri (Pratt 1961; Purcifull
1968). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
Canada <in the south-west>, or the USA <in the north-west>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. (43) Chenopodium quinoa,
Gomphrena globosa systemic mosaic. Medicago sativa local lesions (some strains
only). Pisum sativum necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. Vigna
unguiculata local infection. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (46)
Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium quinoa. (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus,
or Lablab purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Malus pumila,
or Medicago alba, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Stellaria media, or Tithonia speciosa, or Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens,
or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Antirrhinum majus,
or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Lespedeza stipulacea, or Lilium formosanum, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Raphanus sativus, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <3/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or

more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Barnett and Gibson (1975); Rao et al. (1980); Welsh et al. (1973).

virions. (179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
white clover mosaic, cactus X and hydrangea ringspot viruses, but distantly.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: often found with white clover mosaic
potexvirus (WCMV) but causes systemic mosaic in Chenopodium quinoa, which WCMV
infects only locally. By contrast WCMV infects Vigna unguiculata systemically,
but CYMV only locally. (187) Agrawal, H., Bos, L. and Chessin, M. (1962).

Clover yellow vein potyvirus

      (1) O.W. Barnett, R.H. Baum, S. Scott, B. Reddick, 1981. Revised 1987;
and on the broad bean mild mosaic strain by Tien Po, 1983. (2) Synonyms:
dendrobium mosaic virus, pea mottle virus (Pratt, 1961; Johnson, 1942), pea
necrosis virus (Bos et al., 1977), probably alsike clover mosaic virus, pea
western ringspot virus. (3) Standard acronym: ClYVV. (4) Strains: broad bean
mild mosaic virus (Yu, 1939; 1979), CYVV Hollings and CYVV-Pratt are `typical'
isolates. CYVV-PQ and other Australian isolates are distantly related to the
type isolates. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.017. (8) First reported in
Trifolium repens. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Hollings and Nariani (1965). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Coriandrum sativum, Daucus carota (wild and
domestic), Pisum sativum, Trifolium hybridum, T. incarnatum, T. pratense, T.
repens, T. subterraneum, T. vesiculosum mosaics, mottles or streaks, vein
yellowing or netting. Limonium sinuatum (Lawson et al., 1985). Lupinus luteus,
Lupinus sp. (Abu-Samah et al., 1983). Glycine max (Jones et al., 1977). (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus persicae
(Singh et al., 1971). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide <wherever white clover occurs>. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions systemic mosaic or necrosis. (43)
CYVV-Pratt strain): Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions;
systemic mosaic and necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local lesions;
systemic mosaic. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic or necrotic local lesions;
systemic mosaic and necrosis. N. tabacum necrotic ringspots; not systemic.
Trifolium repens mosaic and chlorotic banding or symptomless. (44) Cucumis
sativus, but susceptible to pea necrosis strain. (45) Pisum sativum, Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii.
(47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or
Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Cassia occidentalis, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus,
or Cucurbita pepo, or Daucus carota, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Helianthus annuus, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Limonium sinuatum, or Lupinus, or
Lupinus luteus, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium hybridum, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Trifolium vesiculosum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia villosa, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Apium graveolens, or Capsicum
annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lespedeza stipulacea, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Ocimum basilicum, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum
crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phlox drummondii, or
Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Tithonia speciosa, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Compositae <2/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <19/22>, or
Plumbaginaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <7 /16>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <2/5>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <2/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/22>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <9/16>, or Umbelliferae <3 /5>. (53) Singh et al. (1971); Edwardson
and Christie (1986); Bos et al. (1974); Lindsten et al. (1976); Hampton et al.

days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: different lengths are obtained in different media. (60)

X-100 and Cs2SO4 gradients; complete rapidly to avoid coat protein
degradation. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions

coefficient 159.5 S. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 %

strain B, Genomic RNA, 1018 nt 2 sequences. (152) Viruscoded nonvirion
proteins isolated <Nagel et al. (1983)>. (153) Two proteins found. (154) Mr
<of the largest> 59000. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 49000. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Small crystals in close association with the nucleus, or large and
irregular shaped in the nucleus, and cylindrical in the cytoplasm consisting
of pinwheels, bundles and laminated aggregates (Edwardson's Group II). (177)
They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean yellow
mosaic, pea mosaic, blackeye cowpea mosaic and soybean mosaic viruses. (183)
The broad bean mild mosaic strain in China gives mottled elongated leaves in
Vicia faba (Yu, 1979), and is transmitted in the non-persistent manner by
Aphis rumicis and Macrosiphum pisum, unlike the type strain it infects
Trifolium pratense and T. repens. (184) With random primed cDNA and S1
nuclease, several CYVV strains show close homology but no hybridization was
detected between CYVV strains and bean yellow mosaic, BYMV (PMV) 204-1, or
sweet pea mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: often confused with
bean yellow mosaic potyvirus especially in white clover. (186) Pea western
ringspot virus is probably a mixed infection with cucumber mosaic virus; R.O.
Hampton, personal communication). (187) Abu-Samah, N. and Randles, J.W.
(1983). Ann. appl. Biol. 103: 97. Barnett, O.W., Randles, J.W. and Burrows,
P.M. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 791. Bos, L., Lindsten, K. and Maat, D.Z.

Monog. No. 14, p. 410. Gibbs, A.J., Hecht Poinar, E., Woods, R.D. and McKee,
R.K. (1966). J. gen. Microbiol. 44: 177. Hampton, R., Beczner, L., Hagedorn,

Clover yellows closterovirus

      (1) S.T. Ohki, 1981. Revised 1984. (3) Standard acronym: CYV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 17.0.1.DE.02. (8) First reported in Trifolium repens. (9) From
Tokyo, Japan. (10) By Ohki et al., 1976. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium
repens, T. incarnatum yellowing or reddening. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellowing,
reddening. (43) Pisum sativum, Vicia faba systemic yellowing. (45) Pisum
sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (47) Pisum sativum, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba. (48) Beta vulgaris,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/5>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae

al. (1976). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 1700 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.7
nm. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)

Phytopath. Soc. Japan 42: 313.


Cocksfoot alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.DE.01. (8) First
reported in Dactylis glomerata. (9) From Scotland, U.K. (10) By Torrance et
al. (1994). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Dactylis glomerata symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in U.K. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (45) Dactylis glomerata. (47) Dactylis glomerata. (50) Gramineae
<1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Torrance et al.
(1994). (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (91)
Total genome size 3.85 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 2 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 1.85 kb <pairs>. (179)
<Possible> Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: ryegrass, beet 1 and 2
alphacryptoviruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
carnation and vicia alphacryptoviruses. (187) Torrance, L., Jones, A.T. and
Duncan, G.H. (1994). Ann. appl. Biol. 124: 579.


Cocksfoot mild mosaic (?) sobemovirus

      (1) W. Huth, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CMMV. (4) Strains: brome stem
leaf mottle virus (Catherall and Chamberlain, 1975 and 1977; Paul et al.,
1980), cocksfoot necrosis and mosaic virus (Hariri and Lapierre, 1977),
festuca mottle virus (Catherall and Chamberlain, 1977; Gibson and Boyes, 1974;
Paul et al., 1980), holcus transitory mottle virus (Catherall and Chamberlain,
1975; Paul et al., 1980), phleum mottle virus (Catherall, 1966; Catherall and
Chamberlain, 1975; Paul et al., 1973/74; Paul et al., 1980). (5) ICTV decimal
code 67.0.1.T.012. (8) First reported in Phleum pratense, Dactylis glomerata.
(9) From the U.K. and Germany. (10) By Carr (1966); Huth (1968). (11) Symptoms
persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms light green streaks. (13) Agrostis
stolonifera, Bromus mollis, Dactylis glomerata, Festuca pratensis, Holcus
lanatus, Phleum pratense, Poa trivialis faint leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae and
Coleoptera <inefficiently, and probably non-specifically>. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Canada, the former Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France,
Germany, Norway, and the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show light green streaks. (43) Hordeum
vulgare light green streaks. Avena sativa, Dactylis glomerata, Festuca
pratensis, Secale cereale, Setaria italica diffuse systemic mild mosaics. (44)
Elytrigia repens, Anthoxanthum odoratum, Lolium perenne. (45) Setaria italica.
(46) Dactylis glomerata, Festuca pratensis, Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale,
Setaria italica. (47) Agrostis stolonifera, or Avena sativa, or Avena
strigosa, or Bromus inermis, or Bromus mollis, or Bromus racemosus, or Bromus
secalinus, or Bromus tectorum, or Dactylis glomerata, or Festuca pratensis, or
Holcus lanatus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lamarckia aurea, or Lolium multiflorum,
or Lolium persicum, or Lolium temulentum, or Panicum miliaceum, or Paspalum
membranaceum, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Phleum arenarium, or Phleum
pratense, or Poa compressa, or Poa trivialis, or Secale cereale, or Setaria
italica, or Setaria viridis, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48)
Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Elytrigia repens, or Lolium
perenne, or Poa annua. (50) Gramineae <28/33>. (51) Gramineae <5/33>. (54)
TIP: 80-85 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Huth et al. (1970). (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 105 S <±1>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.65 <±0.02>. (84) Virions
contain 23.5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 76.5 % protein. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.7 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite <sometimes also a minor component of 1.5 kb>. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 5.7 kb. (100) Base composition 26.6 % G. (101) Base
composition 23.4 % A. (102) Base composition 28.4 % C. (103) Base composition
21.6 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24900. (134) Coat protein.
(174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) <Possible> Sobemovirus.
(184) The virus is distantly serologically related to molinia streak virus
(Querfurth and Bercks, 1976), which is now considered to be a strain of
panicum mosaic sobemovirus (Paul et al., 1980). There have also been
unconfirmed and disputed reports of serological cross-reactions with virions
of tobacco mosaic virus and some viruses of the turnip yellow mosaic virus
group. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: cocksfoot mottle and cocksfoot streak
viruses are often found in mixed infections in Dactylis glomerata and the
quickest diagnostic method is by serological testing. (187) A'Brook, J. and
Benigno, D.A. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 72: 169. Benigno, D.A. (1972). Ann.
appl. Biol. 72: 43. Benigno, D.A. and A.'Brook, J. (1972). Pl. Path. 21: 142.
Bercks, R. and Querfurth, G. (1971). Phytopath. Z. 72: 354. Bercks, R. and
Querfurth, G. (1972). Phytopath. Z. 75: 215. Carr, A.J.H. (1966). Rep. Welsh
Pl. Breed. Stn 1965, p. 90. Carr, A.J.H. (1967). Rep. Welsh Pl. Breed. Stn
1966, p. 110. Catherall, P.L. (1966). Rep. Welsh Pl. Breeding Stn. 1965, p.
94. Catherall, P.L. (1982). Rep. Welsh Pl. Breed. Stn. 1981, p. 161.
Catherall, P.L. and Chamberlain, J.A. (1975). Pl. Path. 24: 217. Catherall,
P.L. and Chamberlain, J.A. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol. 87: 147. Chamberlain, J.A.
and Catherall, P.L. (1976). J. gen. Virol. 30: 41. Chamberlain, J.A. and
Catherall, P.L. (1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 83: 475. Gibson, R.W. and Boyes, D.
(1974). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1973, p. 137. Hariri, D. and Lapierre, H.
(1977). Annls. Phytopath. 9: 281. Hariri, D. and Lapierre, H. (1979). Annls.
Phytopath. 11: 246. Hull, R. (1977). J. gen. Virol. 36: 289. Huth, W. (1968).
Phytopath. Z. 62: 300. Huth, W. and Paul, H.L. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 107, 4 pp. Huth, W., Brandes, J. and Paul, H.L. (1970). Phytopath.
Z. 68: 367. Paul, H.L. (1974). Acta Biol. Jugosl. Ser. B. Microb. 11: 193.
Paul, H.L. and Huth, W. (1970). Phytopath. Z. 69: 1. Paul, H.L., Huth, W. and

Cocksfoot mottle sobemovirus

      (1) P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (2) Synonyms: cocksfoot necrotic mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: CoMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.0.003. (8)
First reported in Dactylis glomerata. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Serjeant
(1963). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms streaking and mottling of leaves.
(13) Dactylis glomerata, Triticum aestivum conspicuous yellow streaking and
mottling of leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Chrysomelid beetles, Lema melanopa, L. lichenis.
(18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed. (39) Spreads in France, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, and the UK. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
yellow streaking and mottling with necrosis. (43) Avena sativa, Dactylis
glomerata, Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum systemic leaf streaking,
mottling and necrosis. (44) Musa balbisiana, Oryza sativa, Poa pratensis,
Sorghum halepense, Zea mays. (45) Dactylis glomerata. (47) Avena sativa, or
Dactylis glomerata, or Hordeum vulgare, or Triticum aestivum. (48)
Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Bromus mollis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Elytrigia
repens, or Lilium formosanum, or Lolium perenne, or Musa balbisiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza
sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Poa pratensis, or Poa
trivialis, or Sorghum halepense, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae
<4/13>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae
<9/13>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Musaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 4-6 days <at 20°C>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 118
S. (79) Density 1.39 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.6. (84) Virions
contain 25 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 75 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.35 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.35 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
40979. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): Z36903 Gb(89)n:Cmvrep
Cocksfoot mottle virus gene for putative replicase. 6/95 2,838bp. Z48630
Em(44)n:Cfmvseq Gb(90)_vi:Cfmvseq Cocksfoot Mottle Virus genes for
polyprotein, RNA dependent RNA polymerase and coat protein. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (179) Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: cynosurus mottle virus (New Zealand isolate). (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: cynosurus mottle virus (European
isolate). (184) The genome of a New Zealand isolate is reported to have 58%
nucleotide sequence homology with that of cynosurus mottle virus. (186)
Although the virus alone will not infect Cynosurus cristatus, it induces
systemic infection when present together with cynosurus mottle (?)
sobemovirus. (187) Catherall, P.L. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 23,
3 pp. Hariri, D. and Lapierre, H. (1978). C.N.R.A., I.N.R.A., Versailles,
France, p. 281. Hull, R. (1977a).J. gen. Virol. 36: 289. Hull, R. (1977b).
Virology 79: 50. Hull, R. (1977c). Virology 79: 58. Huth, W. (1968).
Phytopath. Z. 62: 300. Mohamed, N.A. (1980). J. agric. Res. 23: 273. Mohamed,
N.A. and Mossop, D.W. (1981). J. gen. Virol. 55: 63. Rabenstein, F. and
Schmidt, H.B. (1979). Arch. Phytopath. Pflanzenschutz 15: 351. Serjeant, E.P.
(1963). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1962, p. 112. Serjeant, E.P. (1964). Pl.
Path. 13: 23. Serjeant, E.P. (1967). Ann. appl. Biol. 59: 31. Taliansky, M.E.,
Malyshenko, S.I., Pshannikova, E.S. and Atabekov, J.G. (1982). Virology 122:
