Cocksfoot streak (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: orchard grass mosaic virus
(McKinney, 1956), cocksfoot mosaic virus (Slykhuis, 1957). (3) Standard
acronym: CSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.018. (8) First reported in
Dactylis glomerata. (9) From England. (10) By Smith (1952); Storey (1952).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dactylis glomerata chlorotic streaks on leaves;
decreased tillering. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Hyalopteroides humulus, Macrosiphum avenae, M.
euphorbiae, Acyrthosiphon (Metopolophium) dirhodum, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Canada, the UK, and
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Dactylis glomerata chlorotic
streaks in leaves; tillering and seed set reduced. Lolium multiflorum, L.
perenne pale green leaf streaking. Paspalum membranaceum, Setaria macrostachya
conspicuous yellow leaf streaking. Phalaris paradoxa, Lamarckia aurea yellow
leaf spotting. (45) Dactylis glomerata. (46) Dactylis glomerata (W), Paspalum
membranaceum (W). (47) Anthoxanthum aristatum, or Avena strigosa, or Bromus
mollis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Lagurus ovatus, or Lamarckia aurea, or
Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Paspalum membranaceum, or Phalaris
paradoxa, or Setaria macrostachya, or Setaria viridis. (48) Avena sativa. (50)
Gramineae <12/13>. (51) Gramineae <1/13>. (53) Ohmann-Kreutzberg (1963). (54)
TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 16 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 750 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: anthoxanthum mosaic potyvirus. (187) Brandes,
J. (1959). Phytopath. Z. 35: 205. Catherall, P.L. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 59, 3 pp. Catherall, P.L. and Griffiths, E. (1966). Ann. appl.
Biol. 57: 141. McKinney, H.H. (1956). Pl. Dis. Reptr 40: 524.
Ohmann-Kreutzberg, G. (1963). Phytopath. Z. 47: 113. Slykhuis, J. (1957).
Proc. Canad. phytopath. Soc. 25: 17. Slykhuis, J. (1958). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull.
6: 129. Smith, K.M. (1952). Pl. Path. 1: 118. Storey, I.F. (1952). Pl. Path.
1: 101. Watson, M.A. and Mulligan, T.E. (1960). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn for
1959, p. 101.


Coconut foliar decay nanavirus

      (1) J.W. Randles, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: CFDV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.1.002. (8) First reported in Cocos nucifera. (9) From Saraoutou,
Vanuatu. (10) By Calvez et al. (1980). (13) Cocos nucifera necrosis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Cixiidae: Myndus crudus. (18) Transmitted by an unusual insect group. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner, or in a persistent manner. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by
grafting <coconuts will not graft>. (39) Spreads in Vanuatu. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show progressive yellowing and necrosis.
(43) Cocos nucifera. (45) Cocos nucifera. (46) Cocos nucifera cv. Malayan Red
Dwarf (W). (47) Cocos nucifera. (50) Palmae <1/1>. (59) Electron microscopy:
virions not seen in sap extracts. (60) Method: Randles and Hanold (1989). (61)
Virions isometric. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (81)
Density 1.211.25 g/ml in Nycodenz; 1.30 g/ml in CS2SO4. (88) Genome consists
of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 1.29 kb.
(92) Genome <possibly> unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 1.29 kb.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12474. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M29963
Em(40)_vi:CFDCG Gb(84)_vi:CFDCG Coconut foliar decay virus, complete genome.
7/90 1,291bp. 1 sequence. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and meristem.
(179) Nanavirus. (184) Resembles subterranean clover stunt, banana bunchy top,
milk vetch dwarf and faba bean necrotic yellows viruses, and also porcine
circovirus, in the size of its circular single stranded DNA genome; but the
latter does not hybridize with that of subterranean clover stunt virus in dot
blot hybridization tests. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: isolate and
characterize DNA. (187) Calvez, C., Renard, J.L. and Marty, G. (1980).
Oleagineux 35: 443. Randles, J.W. and Hanold, D. (1989). Intervirology 30:
177. Rohde, W., Randles, J.W. and Langridge, P. (1990). Virology 176: 648.


Coffee ringspot (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) C.M. Chagas, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: CoRSV. (4) Strains: Coffee
ringspot from the Philippines is reported to be seed-borne, that from Brazil
is not. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.011. (8) First reported in Coffea
arabica. (9) From Brazil. (10) By Kitajima and Costa (1972). (11) Symptoms
persist <while viruliferous mites present>. (13) Coffea arabica chlorotic
lesions. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a mite. (17)
Transmitted by Tenuipalpidae: Brevipalpus phoenicis. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Brazil and the Philippines. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions.
Coffea arabica chlorotic spots on leaves about 40 days after infestation with
viruliferous mites. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Coffea arabica. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo,
or Datura stramonium, or Diodia teres, or Genipa americana, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Hamelia patens, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Manetia cordifolia,
or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Rubiaceae <1/5>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Rubiaceae <4/5>, or Solanaceae <7 /7>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 70-75 °C. (55) LIV: <19-22 days at 4°C>. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions
enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 178-224 nm
<in thin sections>. (71) Virions 59-76 nm wide <in thin sections>. (72) Axial
canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 8 nm in diameter. (171) Virions found in
lesions of leaves and in fruit pulp. (172) Virions found in nuclei and in the
perinuclear space. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Chagas, C.M. (1978). Ph.D. Thesis, Univ. Sao Paolo,
Brazil. Chagas, C.M. (1980). Phytopath. Z. 99: 301. Chagas, C.M., July, J.R.
and Alba, A.P.C. (1981). Phytopath. Z. 102: 100. Kitajima, E.W. and Costa,
A.S. (1972). Cienc. Cult. 24: 542.


Cole latent (?) carlavirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CoLV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 14.0.T.1.011. (8) First reported in Brassica oleracea var. acephala. (9)
From Brazil. (10) By Kitajima et al. (1970). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Brassica
oleracea usually symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, but transmits infrequently.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Brazil <in the
states of San Paulo and the Federal District>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show latent infection,
some show local lesions. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Malva parviflora local lesions. Brassica oleracea var. acephala, B.
oleracea var. botrytis, Raphanus sativus, Citrullus lanatus, Glycine max,
Solanum melongena latent. (44) Dianthus caryophyllus, Lactuca sativa, Zea
mays, Phaseolus vulgaris, Capsicum annuum. (45) Brassica oleracea var.
acephala, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa
(L), Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica
juncea, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica oleracea var. acephala, or Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Malva parviflora, or Raphanus sativus, or Rubus idaeus,
or Solanum melongena. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Beta vulgaris, or
Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium murale, or Cichorium endiva, or Coriandrum
sativum, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura
stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or
Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Passiflora edulis, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea
mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Cruciferae <7/7>,
or Cucurbitaceae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>, or Malvaceae
<1/2>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/4>, or
Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Malvaceae <1/2>, or
Passifloraceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7 /8>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (53) Mello
et al. (1987). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: extraction,
clarification, precipitation with PEG 6000, differential centrifugation (2
cycles). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650
nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (84) Virions contain 8.5 % nucleic acid. (171) Virions found in
leaves, mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Are masses of virions. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: potato S virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
Chenopodium amaranticolor and Gomphrena globosa are susceptible. (187) Costa,
A.S., Kitajima, E.W., Costa, C.L. and Nagai, H. (1972). Rev. Olericult. 12:
82. Kitajima, E.W., Camargo, I.J. and Costa, A.S. (1970). Bragantia 29: 181.
Mello, S.M., Cupertino, F.P., Kitajima, E.W. and Lin, M.T. (1987). Fitopatol.
Bras. 12: 353. Mello, S.M. (1981). M.Sc. Dissertation, 56 pp., Univ. Brasilia.


Colocasia bobone disease (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) R. Plumb, 1984. Revised by A.A. Brunt, 1990. (3) Standard acronym:
CBDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.012. (8) First reported in Colocasia
esculenta. (9) From in samples from the Solomon Islands, South Pacific. (10)
By James et al. (1973). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13)
Colocasia esculenta thickened malformed and brittle leaves, severe stunting.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Tarophagus proserpina. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in
a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Colocasia esculenta malformation, puckering and thickening of leaves
followed by recovery. Philodendron selloum leaf chlorosis. (44) No natural
infection recorded in Xanthosoma sp., Caladium sp., Cyrtosperma sp., Alocasia
sp. and not transmitted to Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Colocasia
esculenta. (46) Colocasia esculenta (W). (47) Colocasia esculenta, or
Philodendron selloum. (48) Alocasia, or Caladium, or Cyrtosperma, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Xanthosoma. (50) Araceae <2/6>. (51) Araceae
<4/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Gollifer et al. (1977); Shaw et al.
(1979). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <generally, but often aggregated>.
(60) Method: James et al. (1973). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
300-335 nm. (71) Virions 50-55 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious <can be seen
in broken virions>. (73) Axial canal 7 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.5 nm. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 285
S <±15>. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and phloem sieve tubes. (172)
Virions found in the perinuclear space. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (178)
Other cellular changes: formation of crystalline arrays of virions. (179)
<Possible> unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (183) Isolates that
differ in virulence are found in different Pacific Island countries. (186)
"Male" taro plants in Papua New Guinea and Solomon Islands also containing
taro badnavirus develop a very severe disease described as "alomae". (187)
Gollifer, D.E. and Brown, J.E. (1972). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 597. Gollifer, D.E.,
Jackson, G.V.H., Dabek, A.J., Plumb, R.T. and May, Y.Y. (1977). PANS 23: 171.
Jackson, G.H.V. (1980). Diseases and Pests of Taro. South Pacific Commission,
Noumea. James, M., Kenten, R.H. and Woods, R.D. (1973). J. gen. Virol. 21:
145. Kenten, R.H. and Woods, R.D. (1973). PANS 19: 38. Shaw, D.E., Plumb, R.T.
and Jackson, G.V.H. (1979). Papua New Guinea agric. J. 30: 71.


Commelina diffusa potyvirus

      (1) F.W. Zettler, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.04. (8) First
reported in Commelina diffusa. (9) From Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Morales and
Zettler (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Commelina diffusa mosaic.
Tradescantia spathacea mild mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted
by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Morales and Zettler (1977);
Baker and Zettler (1988). (39) Spreads in Puerto Rico and the USA <Florida>.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis. (43) Commelina diffusa
mosaic. Tradescantia spathacea mild mosaic. (44) Aneilema aequinoctiale,
Commelina benghalensis, Commelina erecta, Murdannia nudiflora, Tradescantia
zebrina. (45) Commelina diffusa, Tradescantia spathacea. (46) Commelina
diffusa (W). (47) Commelina diffusa, or Tradescantia spathacea. (48) Aneilema
aequinoctiale, or Apium graveolens, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Capsicum
annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Commelina benghalensis, or Commelina
erecta, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura stramonium, or
Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Murdannia nudiflora, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Philodendron
selloum, or Pisum sativum, or Tradescantia zebrina, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Zea mays. (50) Commelinaceae <2/7>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Araceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Commelinaceae <5/7>, or Cucurbitaceae
<2/2>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/3>, or Solanaceae <4/4>, or Umbelliferae <2 /2>. (53) Morales and Zettler
(1977); Baker and Zettler (1988). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 12-20 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
F.W. Zettler: several methods have been tried and been unsuccessful, due to
the viscosity of Commelina diffusa extracts. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 734 nm. (71) Virions <c.> 13 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in leaves,
epidermis, companion cells, probably roots, probably mesophyll, vascular
parenchyma and probably phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <probably>.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bidens mottle, blackeye
cowpea mosaic, dasheen mosaic, lettuce mosaic, pepper mottle, potato Y,
tobacco etch and turnip mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: can be
distinguished from cucumber mosaic virus in naturally infected plants by the
symptoms (Morales and Zettler, 1977). (187) Baker, C.A. and Zettler, F.W.
(1988). Plant Dis. 72: 513. Morales, F.J. and Zettler, F.W. (1977).
Phytopathology 67: 839.


Commelina mosaic potyvirus

      (1) F.J. Morales, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: ComMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.020. (8) First reported in Commelina spp. (9) From Florida,
U.S.A. (10) By Morales and Zettler (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Commelina diffusa systemic mottling and mosaic. Tradescantia spathacea. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA. (46) Commelina diffusa (W). (47)
Commelina, or Commelina diffusa, or Tradescantia spathacea. (48) Apium
graveolens, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura stramonium,
or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Philodendron selloum, or Pisum sativum, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Commelinaceae <3/3>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Araceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Gramineae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or
Solanaceae <4/4>, or Umbelliferae <2 /2>. (53) Morales and Zettler (1977).
(54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: <less than> 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 707-808 nm.
(171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
bidens mottle, blackeye cowpea mosaic, dasheen mosaic, lettuce mosaic, pepper

and Zettler, F.W. (1977). Phytopathology 67: 839.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: ComVX. (5) ICTV decimal code

Trifolium incarnatum symptomless local and systemic infection. Chenopodium

amaranticolor, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vicia faba, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium murale (L). (47)
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or

Coriander feathery red vein nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CFRVV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.013. (8) First reported in Coriandrum sativum, Pastinaca sativa. (9)
From the U.S.A. (10) By Misari and Sylvester (1983). (13) Coriandrum sativum,

Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Hydaphis foeniculi, Myzus

veinal chlorosis and, later, interveinal chlorosis. (44) Chenopodium quinoa,
Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Physalis floridana, Nicotiana tabacum.
(45) Apium graveolens, Coriandrum sativum, Nicotiana glutinosa. (46)

Cotton leaf crumple bigeminivirus

      (1) J.K. Brown, 1987 and A.A. Brunt, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: CLCrV.
(4) Strains: Mild and severe strains recognised (Erwin and Meyer, 1961). (5)
ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.012. (8) First reported in Gossypium hirsutum. (9)
From California, U.S.A. (10) By Dickson et al. (1954). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Species of Gossypium, Abutilon, Althaea, Hibiscus, Malva and of
Castanospermum, Glycine, Phaseolus, Vicia mosaic and malformation. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27)
Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally
to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Brown et al. (1983); Brown et
al. (1987); Duffus and Flock (1982); Erwin and Meyer (1961); Brown et al.
(1986). (38) Spreads in the Middle East. (39) Spreads in India, Mexico, and
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorosis and malformation. (43) Malva parviflora,
Gossypium hirsutum `Delta Pine 70', Vigna angularis (Azuki bean) and
Castanospermum australe (Delgado bean) systemic chlorosis and malformation.
(44) Cucumis melo, Abelmoschus esculentus, Spinacia oleracea, Nicotiana
glutinosa, Zinnia elegans. (45) Gossypium hirsutum, Malva parviflora and a
useful purification host is Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Gossypium hirsutum (W),
Malva parviflora (W). (47) Abutilon, or Althaea, or Castanospermum, or
Castanospermum australe, or Glycine, or Glycine max, or Gossypium, or
Gossypium hirsutum, or Hibiscus, or Hibiscus cannabinus, or Malva, or Malva
parviflora, or Phaseolus, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Vicia, or Vigna angularis. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Cucumis melo, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Spinacia oleracea, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/9>, or Malvaceae <8/9>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/9>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Brown and Nelson (1984); Brown et al. (1986). (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fixation with
glutaraldehyde is essential. UA is better than PTA. (60) Method: Brown and
Nelson (1984). (61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
17-20 nm in diameter. (65) Virions <dimers> 30-32 nm in length. (171) Virions
found in phloem. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells <in phloem and
parenchyma only>. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Spherical or
amorphous. They are more numerous in younger leaves. (178) Other cellular
changes: hypertrophy of cells containing inclusions. (179) Bigeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (187) Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R.
(1984). Phytopathology 74: 987. Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R. (1987). Plant
Dis. 71: 522. Brown, J.K., Mihail, J.D. and Nelson, M.R. (1987). Plant Dis.
71: 699. Brown, J.K., Butler, G.D. and Nelson, M.R. (1983). Phytopathology 73:
787. Brown, J.K., Nelson, M.R. and Lambe, R.C. (1986). Plant Dis. 70: 981.
Dickson, R.C., Johnson, M.M. and Laird, E. (1954). Phytopathology 44: 479.
Duffus, J.E. and Flock, R.A. (1982). Calif. Agric. 36: 4. Erwin, D.C. and
Meyer, R. (1961). Phytopathology 51: 472. Tsao, P.M. (1963). Phytopathology
53: 243.

vulgaris, or Cajanus cajan, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or

or Solanaceae <4/7>. (53) Kuhn (1964); Lane (1974, 1981). (54) TIP: 67-76 °C.
(55) LIV: 1-44 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-5. (57) Infectivity of sap
increased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many

composition 26.4 % G. (101) Base composition 25.3 % A. (102) Base composition
20.3 % C. (103) Base composition 28.2 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a
methylated nucleotide cap. (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
proteases, or decreased when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region
absent. (114) Genome has tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts tyrosine.

(1981). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12303. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):

distantly; broad bean mottle virus is very distantly related. (187) Ahlquist,

CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 49, 4 pp. Bancroft, J.B., Hiebert, E., Rees,
M.W. and Markham, R. (1968). Virology 34: 224. Casey, R. (1979). J. gen.
Virol. 43: 143. Christie, R.G. and Edwardson, J.R. (1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn
Monog. No. 9, p. 115. Dzianott, A.M. and Bujarski, J.J. (1991). Virology 185:

Cowpea golden mosaic (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) H.W. Rossel and A.A. Brunt, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: CPGMV
(CpGMV). (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.T.051. (8) First reported in Vigna
unguiculata. (9) From northern and southern Nigeria. (10) By Rossel (1977a and
b). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vigna unguiculata bright yellow mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (36) Studies reported by Rossel and Thottappilly (1985) who found that
wild cowpeas are likely perennial sources of infection for cowpea crops in
Nigeria. See also Anno-Nyako et al. (1983); Vetten and Allen (1983). (39)
Spreads in India, Kenya, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Pakistan, and Tanzania.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis. (43) Vigna unguiculata
yellow mosaic. (44) Phaseolus lunatus. (45) Vigna unguiculata. (46) Vigna
unguiculata (W). (47) Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. dekindtiana
var. dekindtiana , or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Phaseolus
lunatus. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>. (51)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>. (53) Rossel and Thottappilly (1985). (179)
Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (184) The failure of
reciprocal transmission tests using grafting and Bemisia tabaci indicate that
the virus is distinct from the whitefly-transmitted virus inducing similar
symptoms in Phaseolus lunatus (Lima bean) in Nigeria (Williams, 1976). (186)
Rossel and Thottappilly (1985) note that similar cowpea diseases occur in
Pakistan, East Africa and Niger (Ahmad, 1978; Sharma and Varma, 1976; Singh
and Allen, 1979). (187) Ahmad, M. (1978). Pl. Dis. Reptr 62: 224. Anno-Nyako,
F.O., Vetten, H.J., Allen, D.J. and Thottappilly, G. (1983). Ann. appl. Biol.
102: 319. Rossel, H.W. (1977a). Tropical Grain Legume Bulletin 8: 41. Rossel,
H.W. (1977b). Rep. Int. Inst. Trop. Agric. 1977, pp. 28, 89. Rossel, H.W. and
Thottappilly, G. (1985). Virus Diseases of Important Food Crops in Tropical
Africa: Ibadan, Nigeria, Int. Inst. Trop. Agric., p. 35. Sharma, S.R. and
Varma, A. (1976). Indian Phytopath. 29: 421. Singh, S.R. and Allen, D.J.
(1979). In: Cowpea Pests and Diseases. Ibadan, Nigeria. Int. Inst. Trop.
Agric. Vetten, H.J. and Allen, D.J. (1983). Ann. appl. Biol. 102: 219.
Williams, R.J. (1976). Pl. Dis. Reptr 60: 853.


Cowpea green vein-banding potyvirus

      (1) M.T. Lin, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: CGVBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.022. (8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata. (9) From Brazil. (10)
By Lin et al. (1979a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vigna unguiculata green
vein banding. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Brazil. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions, mosaic, leaf curling. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions; not systemic.
Phaseolus acutifolius systemic vein clearing, mosaic, leaf curling. P.
arborigenus local vein necrosis. P. vulgaris cv. Black Turtle Soup local and
systemic infection. P. vulgaris cv. Bountiful chlorotic local lesions. Vigna
unguiculata cv. TVu 4536 systemic green vein banding. (44) Glycine max cv.
Bragg, Medicago sativa cv. du Puits, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto III, Pisum
sativum cv. Dark Skin Perfection, Datura stramonium. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. Rico 23, Vigna unguiculata cvs Sempre Verde, TVu 4536. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Rico 23 (W). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Phaseolus acutifolius, or Phaseolus arborigenus, or Phaseolus lunatus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Brassica
oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Cichorium endiva, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Helianthus annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris < cv. Pinto III>, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum,
or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Zea mays.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae
<2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/8>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<10/10>. (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 780 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177)
They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cowpea rugose
mosaic virus is related closely. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: bean common mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, blackeye cowpea mosaic and
soybean mosaic viruses. (187) Lin, M.T., Anjos, J.R.N., Kitajima, E.W. and
Rios, G.P. (1979a). Fitopatol. Bras. 4: 120. Lin, M.T., Anjos, J.R.N.,
Kitajima, E.W. and Rios, G.P. (1979b). Fitopatol. Bras. 4: 203.


Cowpea mild mottle (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1980. Revised 1989 by N.M. Horn. (2) Synonyms: bean
angular mosaic virus (Costa et al., 1983; Gaspar et al., 1985), voandezia
mosaic virus, groundnut crinkle virus, probably Psophocarpus necrotic mosaic
virus (Fauquet and Thouvenel, 1987; Fortuner et al., 1979). (3) Standard
acronym: CPMMV. (4) Strains: tomato pale chlorosis virus (Antignus and Cohen,
1987; Cohen and Antignus, 1982), voandzeia mosaic virus (Fauquet and
Thouvenel, 1987). (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.T.2.002. (8) First reported in
Vigna unguiculata. (9) From Tafo, Ghana. (10) By Brunt et al. (1973). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye chlorotic
blotches, systemic mottling and malformation. Arachis hypogaea necrotic local
lesions, chlorotic rings, systemic chlorosis, rolling, veinal necrosis.
Canavalia ensiformis, Glycine max vein mosaic and chlorosis, apical necrosis
and malformation. Vigna subterranea, Lycopersicon esculentum mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus <some isolates> transmitted by seed <and others not; Horn et al., 1991;
Jeyanandarajah and Brunt, 1993>. (39) Spreads in Brazil, Cote d'Ivoire, Egypt,
Fiji, Ghana, India, Indonesia, Israel, Kenya, Malaysia, Nigeria, the Solomon
Islands, Tanzania, Thailand, and Yemen. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local
lesions, systemic mottle or not systemic. (43) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium
murale, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Arachis hypogaea, Cajanus cajan,
Canavalia ensiformis, Glycine max, Vigna unguiculata, Nicotiana clevelandii
systemic mottle. Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. (45) Cajanus cajan, Canavalia ensiformis, Glycine max, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa. (47)
Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Cajanus cajan, or Canavalia ensiformis,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Theobroma
cacao, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vigna subterranea, or Vigna unguiculata.
(48) Ageratum conyzoides, or Atriplex hortensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Cicer
arietinum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Dahlia pinnata, or
Datura stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or Lens culinaris, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Physalis floridana, or Phytolacca americana, or Pisum sativum, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Torenia fournieri, or
Tropaeolum majus, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata,
or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae
<6/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/14>, or Solanaceae <2/13>, or
Sterculiaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/7>, or Compositae <6/6>, or Cruciferae
<3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/14>, or Phytolaccaceae <1 /1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <11/13>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (53)
Brunt et al. (1973). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Brunt et al. (1973).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650 nm. (71)
Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (73) Axial canal 2-3 nm in
diameter. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 165 S. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (112) Additional factor not required for
infectivity. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35700. (171) Virions found
in mesophyll, epidermis and palisade parenchyma. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (176) Of brush-like structure. (177) <Apparently> they
contain virions. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: 12 recognised members of the carlavirus group
(Iwaki et al., 1982; Adams and Barbara, 1982; Brunt et al., 1983). (187)
Adams, A.N. and Barbara, D.J. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 495. Anon. (1987).
Rep. Int. Inst. Trop. Agric. 1986, Ibadan. Antignus, Y. and Cohen, S. (1987).
Ann. appl. Biol. 110: 563. Brunt, A.A. and Kenten, R.H. (1973). Ann. appl.
Biol. 74: 67. Brunt, A.A. and Kenten, R.H. (1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses
No. 140, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A. and Phillips, S. (1981). Trop. Agric. Trinidad 58:
177. Brunt, A.A., Atkey, P.T. and Woods, R.D. (1983). Intervirology 20: 137.
Cohen, S. and Antignus, Y. (1982). Phytoparasitica 10: 101. Costa, A.S.,
Gaspar, J.O. and Vega, J. (1983). Fitopatol. Bras. 8: 325. Dubera, J. and
Dollet, M. (1981). Phytopath. Z. 101: 337. Fauquet, C. and Thouvenel, J.-C.
(1987). In: Plant Viral Diseases in the Ivory Coast, No. 46, p. 132. ORSTOM,
Paris. Fortuner, R., Fauquet, C. and Lourd, M. (1979). Pl. Dis. Reptr 63: 194.
Gaspar, J.O., Beriam, L.O.S., Alves, M.N., Oliveira, A.R. and Costa, A.S.
(1985). Fitopatol. Bras. 10: 195. Horn, N.M., Nasin, S. and Yuliantoro, B.
(1989). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 97 125. Iizuka, N., Rajeshwari, R., Reddy, D.V.R.,
Goto, T., Muniyappa, V., Bharathan, N. and Ganekar, A.M. (1984). Phytopath. Z.
109: 245. Jeyanandarajah, P. and Brunt, A.A. (1993). J. Phytopathology 137:

Cowpea Moroccan aphid-borne mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (2) Synonyms: cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus,
possibly passiflora South African potyvirus (Brand et al., 1993; McKern et
al., 1994). (3) Standard acronym: CABMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.021.
(8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata. (9) From Morocco. (10) By Fischer and
Lockhart (1976). (13) Vigna unguiculata severe leaf chlorosis (symptoms even
more severe when co-infected with cucumber mosaic virus. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (38)
Spreads in the African region. (39) Spreads in Morocco and South Africa. (47)
Vigna unguiculata. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (61) Virions
filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 765 nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12199. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (186) The virus was originally called cowpea
aphid-borne mosaic virus, like that described by Lovisolo and Conti (1966).
The latter was probably an isolate of bean common mosaic virus, but is no
longer available for comparative tests, and hence a nomen nudum. This virus is
best differentiated from the latter by adding "Moroccan" to its name. (187)
Brand, R.J., Burger, J.T. and Rybicki, E.P. (1993). Arch. Virol. 128: 29.
Fischer, H.U. and Lockhart, B.E.L. (1976). Phytopath. Z. 84: 43. Lovisolo, O.
and Conti, M. (1966) Neth. J. Pl. Path. 72: 265. McKern, N.M., Strike, P.M.,
Barnett, O.W., Dijkstra, J., Shukla, D.D. and Ward, C.M. (1994). Arch. Virol.
136: 207.


Cowpea mosaic comovirus

      (1) C.P. de Jager, 1980. Revised 1983. Revised by G. Bruening. (2)
Synonyms: cowpea yellow mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: CPMV. (4) Strains:
cowpea mosaic comovirus SB strain and cowpea mosaic comovirus Vu strain
(Agrawal, 1964). (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in
Vigna unguiculata. (9) From Nigeria. (10) By Chant (1959). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Vigna unguiculata, Cajanus cajan, Crotalaria juncea mosaic, vein
yellowing, leaf malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Ootheca mutabilis, Paraluperodes quaternus,
Nematocerus acerbus, Ceratoma variegata, C. ruficornis, C. trifurcata,
Diabrotica balteata, D. undecimpunctata howardi, D. virgifera, Acalymma
vittatum. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <1-5%>. (39) Spreads in Cuba, Kenya, Nigeria, Suriname, and Tanzania.
(40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic
or chlorotic local lesions and systemic mosaic, necrotic or chlorotic streaks.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions, systemic chlorotic
spots and streaks, and apical deformation. Canavalia ensiformis. Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Pinto necrotic or chlorotic local lesions. Vigna unguiculata cv.
Blackeye chlorotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. Vigna unguiculata cv.
Chinese Red × Iron pinpoint necrotic local lesions. (44) Nicotiana glutinosa.
(45) Vigna unguiculata cvs Blackeye Early Ramshorn, Blackeye 5. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Canavalia ensiformis (L), Phaseolus vulgaris
cvs Pinto (L), Scotia (L), Vigna unguiculata cv. Early Red (L). (47)
Antirrhinum majus, or Cajanus cajan, or Canavalia ensiformis, or Cassia tora,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crotalaria juncea, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab purpureus, or Mucuna
deeringianum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna radiata, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (48) Apium graveolens, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum frutescens, or Crotalaria retusa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris,
or Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus
albus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Physalis peruviana, or
Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia
villosa. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<17/30>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/12>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/30>, or
Solanaceae <8/12>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53)
Thornberry (1966); Swaans and van Kammen (1973); Hampton et al. (1978). (54)
TIP: 55-65 °C. (55) LIV: 4-10 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (57) Infectivity
of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: Klootwijk et al. (1977). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20-24 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 119 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 98 S <M>, or 60 S
<T>. (79) Density 1.447 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.406 g cm3 in CsCl <M2>, or
1.395 g cm3 in CsCl <M1>, or 1.288 g cm3 in CsCl <T>. (82) Isoelectric point
pH 5-7. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.74 <B>, or 1.61 <M>. (84) Virions contain 34.5
% nucleic acid <B>, or 24 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 65.5 % protein <B>, or 76 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (87)
Also 1.9% carbohydrates and polyamines: spermidine 5.05 [Gm]g/mg, spermine
0.17 [Gm]g/mg. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 10.4 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 6.6 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.8 kb. (100) Base
composition 23.5 % G. (101) Base composition 27.9 % A. (102) Base composition
18.1 % C. (103) Base composition 30.5 % U. (108) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with proteases, or decreased when deproteinised with proteases.
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110)
Poly A region present <El Manna and Bruening, 1973>. (114) Genome has no
tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Van Wezenbeek et al.
(1983); Lomonossoff and Shanks (1983). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12264. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): J02064 Em(40)_vi:COBRNA Gb(84)_vi:MCPBRNA
cowpea mosaic virus bottom comp. (b-rna); rgn of 1st aug. 4/90 149bp. J02065
Em(40)_vi:COMRNA Gb(84)_vi:MCPMRNA cowpea mosaic virus middle comp. (b-rna);
rgn of 1st aug. 4/90 325bp. M10534 Em(40)_vi:COMMCPM5 Gb(84)_vi:MCPM5E Cowpea
mosaic virus M RNA, 5' end. 7/89 87bp. M10535 Em(40)_vi:COMMCPB5
Gb(84)_vi:MCPB5E Cowpea mosaic virus B genmic RNA, 5' end. 7/89 79bp. M25438

sequence. 7/90 80bp. M25439 Gb(84)_vi:MCPRNA3B Cowpea mosaic virus B RNA 3'
terminal sequence. 9/90 80bp. X00206 Em(40)_vi:COCPMVB Gb(84)_vi:COCPMVB

Cowpea mottle (?) carmovirus

      (1) R. Bozarth, 1980. Revised 1990. (3) Standard acronym: CPMoV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.T.015. (8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata. (9)
From Ibadan, Nigeria. (10) By Shoyinka et al. (1978). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Vigna unguiculata mottling or mosaic. Vigna subterranea green mottle,
shortening of petioles. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Ootheca mutabilis, Paraluperodes lineata. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <10% in V. unguiculata>. (39) Spreads in
Nigeria. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions, vein necrosis, mottling,
malformation. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa diffuse chlorotic
local lesions; not systemic. Cajanus cajan, Vigna unguiculata severe systemic
chlorotic or green mottle, leaf malformation. Necrosis in youngest primary
leaves. Glycine max, Macroptilium lathyroides, Phaseolus acutifolius, P.
lunatus, P. vulgaris, Vigna radiata, V. mungo systemic mosaic. (45) Vigna
unguiculata. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Vigna
unguiculata (L). (47) Cajanus cajan, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Glycine max, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or
Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or
Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna radiata, or
Vigna subterranea, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Atriplex hortensis, or
Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<11/12>, or Solanaceae <1/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Compositae <1/1>,
or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/12>, or Solanaceae
<6/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Shoyinka et al. (1978). (54) TIP: 60 °C.
(55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6 <x 2>. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Shoyinka et al. (1978). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
122 S. (79) Density 1.3492 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 3.94 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 3.94 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12627. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M65155 Em(40)_vi:MCCCP
Gb(84)_vi:MCCCP Cowpea mottle virus capsid protein gene. 8/91 1,104bp. 1
sequence. U20976 Em(44)n:Cm20976 Gb(90)_vi:Cmu20976 Cowpea mottle virus
polyprotein genes, complete cds. (125) 3 virus specified dsRNA species found
in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 4.4 kbp. (127)
2nd largest 1.9 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 1.35 kbp. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 44500 <±1500>. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation:
Bozarth and Shoyinka (1979). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated.
(153) Three proteins found. (154) Mr <of the largest> 50000. (156) Mr of 2nd
largest 27000. (158) Mr of 3rd 11000. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: almond
mosaic, apple mosaic, arabis mosaic, artichoke crinkle, bean mild mosaic, bean
pod mottle, bean rugose mosaic, broad bean mottle virus, brome mosaic,
carnation ringspot, cowpea severe mosaic, cucumber necrosis, cynosurus mottle,
eggplant mosaic, elm mosaic, hibiscus chlorotic ringspot, okra mosaic,
pelargonium ringspot, southern bean mosaic, sowbane mosaic, squash mosaic
virus, tobacco ringspot, tobacco streak and tomato ringspot viruses. (187)
Bozarth, R.F. and Shoyinka, S.A. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 212, 3
pp. Kim, J.W. (1989). Ph.D. Thesis. Indiana State University, Terra Haute,
Indiana, U.S.A. Shoyinka, S.A., Bozarth, R.F., Reese, J. and Rossel, H.W.

Cowpea rugose mosaic potyvirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CPRMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.020. (8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata.
(9) From Piaui State, Brazil. (10) By Santos (1981); Santos et al. (1981).
(11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms rugose mosaic. (13) Vigna unguiculata
ssp. unguiculata. (14) Transmitted by a vector <probably>. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis neri. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis coreopsidis, A. citricola, Dactynotus
sp. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Brazil <Praui>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Vigna
unguiculata, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, C. murale, Gomphrena globosa, Centrosema sp. (44) Glycine max,
Crotalaria paulina, Nicotiana tabacum, Sonchus oleraceus, Zea mays. (45) Vigna
unguiculata ssp. unguiculata, Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L),
Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata (W). (47) Centrosema, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata. (48) Cassia obtusifolia, or Cichorium
endiva, or Crotalaria paulina, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or
Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum melongena, or Sonchus
oleraceus, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/7>. (51) Compositae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>,
or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>, or
Solanaceae <6/6>. (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 7-9 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Kitajima:
extraction in phosphate buffer + EDTA + Na2SO3. Clarification in 8% n-butanol.
Differential centrifugation, then into sucrose cushion, and finally density
gradient. Yields c. 6 mg per kg. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 730 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll
and epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
soybean mosaic, blackeye cowpea mosaic, turnip mosaic, bean common mosaic and
watermelon mosaic 1 viruses. (187) Santos, A.A. (1981). M.Sc. Dissertation,
Univ. Brasilia. Santos, A.A., Lin, M.T. and Kitajima, E.W. (1981).
Phytopathology 71: 890.


Cowpea severe mosaic comovirus

      (1) C.P. de Jager, 1980. Revised 1983. Revised 1989 by G. Bruening. (2)
Synonyms: Puerto Rico cowpea mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: CPSMV. (4)
Strains: see Beier et al. (1977); Agrawal (1964). (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata. (9) From Louisiana,
Arkansas and Indiana, U.S.A. (10) By Perez and Cortez-Monllor (1970). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Calopogonium mucunoides, Canavalia ensiformis,
Centrosema pubescens, Crotalaria juncea, Desmodium canescens, Glycine max,
Macroptilium lathyroides, Phaseolus vulgaris, Psophocarpus tetragonolobus,
Vigna radiata, V. unguiculata chlorotic lesions, concentric ringspots often
becoming necrotic; vein clearing, then mosaic, and malformation and blistering
of younger leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Ceratoma arcuata, C. ruficornis, C. trifurcata, C.
variegata, Chalcodermus bimaculatus, Diabrotica balteata, D. speciosa, D.
virgifera, D. undecimpunctata, Diphaulaca sp., Epilachna varivestis, Acalymma
vittatum. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <10% in V. unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis, 8% in V. unguiculata, varies with strain and cultivar>. (35)
Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (38) Spreads in the North American
region and the South and Central American region. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto necrotic local
lesions; not systemic. Vigna unguiculata systemic mosaic, vein yellowing or
yellow netting, leaf malformation. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Prince, Vigna
unguiculata cvs Blackeye, Early Ramshorn, Blackeye 5, Pituiba. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Canavalia ensiformis (W),
Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Pinto, Scotia, (L) Vigna unguiculata cv. Arlington (W).
(47) Cajanus cajan <cvs Khaki, Saragateado, Amarillo, 6 Selections>, or
Calopogonium mucunoides, or Canavalia ensiformis, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Centrosema pubescens, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Crotalaria juncea, or Datura stramonium, or Desmodium canescens, or Glycine
max <8 cultivars>, or Gomphrena globosa, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum <cvs
Samsun NN, Ambalena, Virginia 115, Wisonsin Havana 425>, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris <18/25 cultivars>, or Pisum sativum <cv. Dwarf
Telephone>, or Psophocarpus tetragonolobus, or Sesbania exaltata, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata <cvs Going, Early Red, PI
221731, Blackeye Early Ramshorn>. (48) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <15/16>, or
Solanaceae <5/5>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/16>. (52) Cowpea severe
mosaic comovirus has a wider host range among cowpea cvs than cowpea mosaic
comovirus (Beier et al., 1977). (53) Perez and Cortez-Monllor (1970); Swaans
and van Kammen (1973). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 5 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Klootwijk et al.
(1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 115 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 95 S <M>, or 58 S <T>. (84) Virions contain 36 %
nucleic acid <B>, or 25 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 64 % protein <B>, or 75 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 9.73 kb.
(92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6 kb <RNA-1>.
(94) The 2nd largest 3.73 kb <RNA-2>. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a VPg
<Daubert and Bruening, 1979>. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12261. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M83309 Em(40)_vi:COMCPSRNA
Gb(84)_vi:CPSRNA2A Cowpea severe mosaic virus RNA-2 region. 7/92 3,732bp
M83830 Em(40)_vi:COMCPSRN1 Gb(84)_vi:CPSRNA1A Cowpea severe mosaic virus
complete RNA1 sequence (isolated from Vigna unguiculata). 4/93 5,9 2
sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132)
Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest> 39000. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 22000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest <c.> 4000. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and unusual in shape. (176)
Vacuolated structures adjacent to the nucleus. (179) Comovirus: Comoviridae.
(180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean
pod mottle virus is related closely; Andean potato mottle, red clover mottle,
pea green mottle and cowpea mosaic viruses are related distantly; radish
mosaic, quail pea mosaic, bean rugose mosaic, pea mild mosaic and broad bean
stain viruses are very distantly related. (187) Agrawal, H.O. (1964). Meded.
Landb. Hoogesch. Wagen. 64: 1. Agrawal, H.O. and Maat, D.Z. (1964). Nature,
Lond. 202: 674. Beier, H., Siler, D.J., Russell, M.L. and Bruening, G. (1977).
Phytopathology 67: 917. Daubert, S. and Bruening, G. (1979). Virology 98: 246.
de Jager, C.P. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 209, 5 pp. Klootwijk,
J., Klein, I., Zabel, P. and van Kammen, A. (1977). Cell 11: 73. Lin, M.T.,

Cowpea stunt (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, and M. Kameya-Iwaki, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.T.DE.2. (8) First reported in Vigna unguiculata and Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis. (9) From Indonesia. (10) By Anon. (1976). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Vigna unguiculata and Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, but not Myzus persicae or Acyrthosiphon
(Aulacorthum) solani. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36)
Studies reported by Tsuchizaki et al. (1986). (39) Spreads in Indonesia and
Thailand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Vigna unguiculata,
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis, Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum
sativum, Psophocarpus tetragonolobus, Vigna radiata small, malformed leaves
and severe stunting. (45) Vigna unguiculata, Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis. (46) Vigna unguiculata (W), Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis (W). (47) Glycine max, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum,
or Psophocarpus tetragonolobus, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna sesquipedalis, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Tsuchizaki et al. (1986). (179) <Possible>
Luteovirus. (187) Anon. (1976). In: Japan-Indonesia Food Crop Research Program

Crimson clover latent nepovirus

      (1) A.J. Cockbain, 1982. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: clover Crimson
latent virus. (3) Standard acronym: CCLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.012.
(8) First reported in Trifolium incarnatum. (9) From Hertfordshire, U.K. (10)
By Kenten et al. (1980). (13) Trifolium incarnatum symptomless. (15) Not
transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <97% in T. incarnatum, 20% in C. quinoa>. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in seed from France, Italy, The Netherlands, U.K.
and the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor systemic mosaic, leaf malformation. C. quinoa chlorotic local
lesions, systemic mosaic, ringspots, leaf malformation. (44) Cucumis sativus,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba, Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Chenopodium album, C.
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Trifolium incarnatum. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Trifolium incarnatum. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/11>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/11>, or
Solanaceae <6/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Kenten et al. (1980). (54)
TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 20-30 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Kenten et al. (1980). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 122 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 101
S <M>, or 52 S <T>. (79) Density 1.5 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.44 g cm3 in CsCl
<M>. (84) Virions contain 41 % nucleic acid <B>, or 34 % nucleic acid <M>, or
0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B>, or 66 % protein <M>, or
100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 12.2 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 7.1 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 5.2 kb. (112) Additional
factor not required for infectivity. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
52000. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, arracacha A, artichoke Italian
latent, lucerne Australian latent, bean leaf roll, bean pod mottle, beet
cryptic, broad bean stain, broad bean mottle, broad bean true mosaic, broad
bean wilt, cherry leaf roll, cherry rasp leaf, cacao necrosis, grapevine
Bulgarian latent, grapevine chrome mosaic, grapevine fanleaf, hibiscus latent
ringspot, mulberry ringspot, myrobalan latent ringspot, pea enation mosaic,
peach rosette mosaic, potato black ringspot, raspberry ringspot, red clover
mottle, red clover necrotic mosaic, southern bean mosaic, strawberry latent
ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and tomato ringspot viruses.

96: 79.


Crinum mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R.D. Pares, 1985. Revised 1990. (3) Standard acronym: CriMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.021. (8) First reported in Crinum spp. (9) From New
South Wales, Australia. (10) By Pares and Bertus (1978). (11) Symptoms
persist. (12) Symptoms longitudinal streaking, yellow mosaic and general
chlorosis. (13) Crinum spp. pale streaking, then mosaic and general chlorosis.
(39) Spreads in Australia and Fiji <Brunt, 1980>. (41) Few (<3) families

Croton yellow vein mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) V. Muniyappa, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CYVMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.0.014. (8) First reported in Croton bonplandianus. (9) From India.
(10) By Varma (1963). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms
vein clearing, vein yellowing, thickening of veins and curling. (13) Croton
bonplandianus vein clearing and yellowing, thickening of veins and leaf
curling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein
clearing, malformation, yellowing and thickening, leaf curling, enations and
dark green veins. (43) Croton bonplandianus yellow vein. Beta vulgaris,
Spinacia oleracea vein thickening. Carica papaya, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Phaseolus vulgaris leaf curling. Raphanus sativus curling and rolling of
leaves. (44) Abelmoschus esculentus, Arachis hypogaea, Cucumis sativus,

physalodes, Nicotiana hybrida, N. tabacum cvs Samsun and Jayasree. (46) Croton

(47) Ageratum conyzoides, or Beta vulgaris, or Carica papaya, or Chenopodium

<11/11>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/2>, or

similarity to African cassava mosaic geminivirus. (187) Harrison, B.D.,
