Cucumber green mottle mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) R.I.B. Francki, 1988. (2) Synonyms: cucumber green mottle mosaic
virus, tobacco mosaic virus watermelon strain W, cucumber virus 3 (Ainsworth,
1935), cucumber virus 4 (Ainsworth, 1935; Hollings et al., 1975), bottlegourd
Indian mosaic virus, cucumis virus 2. (3) Standard acronym: CGMMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 71.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From
Great Britain. (10) By Ainsworth (1935). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis
sativus, Citrullus vulgaris, Lagenaria siceraria (bottlegourd) mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector, or a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Raphidopalpa fevicolis (Rao and Varma, 1984).
(18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in India,
Japan, and the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus,
Citrullus vulgaris systemic mosaic. (44) Datura stramonium, Petunia × hybrida.
(45) Cucumis sativus. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Cucumis sativus (W).
(47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Citrullus lanatus,
or Citrullus vulgaris, or Cucumis sativus, or Lagenaria siceraria, or
Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Petunia × hybrida. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae
<4/4>, or Solanaceae <1/5>. (51) Solanaceae <4/5>. (54) TIP: 80-90 °C. (55)
LIV: <more than> 240 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Tung and Knight (1972); Francki and McLean
(1968). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of <c>
300 nm. (71) Virions <c.> 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic
helix obvious. (84) Virions contain <c.> 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions <c.>
95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size <c.> 6.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 6.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Peden and
Symons (1973). (100) Base composition 23.2 % G <CGMMV-W, 25.8% (CV4), 25.5%
(CV3)>. (101) Base composition 24.6 % A <CGMMV-W, 25.8% (CV4), 25.8% (CV3)>.
(102) Base composition 20.6 % C <CGMMV-W, 19.3% (CV4), 18.3% (CV3)>. (103)
Base composition 31.6 % U <CGMMV-W, 29.5% (CV4), 30.8% (CV3)>. (108)
Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region
absent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (114) Genome has
tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts histidine. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: Meshi et al. (1983). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12235. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): D12505 Em(40)_vi:MCGSHCG Gb(84)_vi:MCGSHCG
Cucumber green mottle mosaic virus (CGMMV) complete genome. 10/92 6,421bp.
J02054 Gb(84)_vi:MCGCPW cucumber green mottle mosaic virus coat protein gene.
9/83 1,071bp. J04322 Em(40)_vi:TOBMCG30 Gb(84)_vi:MCG30KP Cucumber green
mottle mosaic virus 30K protein gene, complete cds, and 180K and coat protein
3 sequences. (119) Features of the genome: the genomic RNA has been sequenced
(Ugaki et al., 1991). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions.
(121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 17261. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Fraenkel-Conrat (1957); Tung and Knight (1972). (146) Amino acid
sequence: Meshi et al. (1983). (147) Amino acid composition: Nozu et al.
(1971); Tung and Knight (1972). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular
parenchyma, xylem, phloem, companion cells and all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: vesiculation of
mitochondria. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: frangipani mosaic, kyuri green mottle mosaic, ribgrass mosaic,
tobacco mosaic, tomato mosaic and tobacco mild green mosaic viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: odontoglossum ringspot,
sunn-hemp mosaic viruses. (184) The host ranges of cucumber green mottle
mosaic virus and kyuri green mottle mosaic virus are similar, and their coat
proteins have greater amino acid sequence similarity than either has to those
of other tobamoviruses, which are serologically more distantly related. (187)
Ainsworth, G.C. (1935). Ann. appl. Biol. 22: 55. Fraenkel-Conrat, H. (1957).
Virology 4: 1. Francki, R.I.B. and McLean, G.D. (1968). Aust. J. biol. Sci.
21: 1311. Francki, R.I.B., Hu, J. and Palukaitis, P. (1986). Intervirology 26:
156. Hollings, M., Komuro, Y. and Tochihara, H. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 154, 4 pp. Meshi, T., Kiyama, R. Ohmi, T. and Okada, Y. (1983).
Virology 127: 54. Nozu, Y., Tochihara, H., Komuro, Y. and Okada, Y. (1971).
Virology 45: 577. Peden, K.W.C. and Symons, R.H. (1973). Virology 53: 487.
Rao, D.C. and Varma, A. (1984). Phytopath. Z. 109: 325. Tung, J.S. and Knight,
C.A. (1972). Virology 48: 574. Ugaki, M., Toriyama, M., Kakutani, T., Hidaka,
S., Kiguchi, T., Nagata, R., Sato, T., Motoyoshi, F. and Nishiguchi, M.
(1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 1487.


Cucumber leaf spot carmovirus

      (1) Sc. H. Kleinhempel and I. Weber, 1987. (2) Synonyms: cucumber fruit
streak virus (Gallitelli et al., 1983; Weber et al., 1986). (3) Standard
acronym: CLSV. (4) Strains: cucumber leaf spot (LS), cucumber fruit streak
(FS). (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.0.006. (8) First reported in Cucumis
sativus. (9) From Germany. (10) By Weber et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms
disappear soon after infection. (13) Cucumis sativus chlorotic spots with
necrotic centres. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus.
(17) Transmitted by Olpidium radicale. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported
by Weber et al. (1982); Gallitelli et al. (1983). (39) Spreads in Germany,
Greece, Jordan, and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Celosia argentea, Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium murale, C. quinoa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Petunia × hybrida necrotic local lesions. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris
var. `Pinto', Avena sativa, Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Nicotiana glutinosa. (45) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana megalosiphon. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Celosia argentea, or Celosia cristata, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,
or Cucurbita pepo, or Gomphrena globosa, or Luffa acutangula, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Apium graveolens, or Avena sativa, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or
Capsicum annuum, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or
Solanum melongena, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae
<3/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/5>,
or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or Solanaceae <3/10>.
(51) Compositae <1/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <7/10>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>.
(53) Weber et al. (1982); Gallitelli et al. (1983). (54) TIP: 80-85 °C. (55)
LIV: 20 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions
<naturally>, or contains many virions <artificially>. (59) Electron
microscopy: ISEM is recommended. (60) Method: Weber et al. (1982). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <c.> 28 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 132 S <FS>. (79) Density 1.342 g
cm3 in CsCl <LS>, or 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl <FS>. (84) Virions contain 20 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.3 kb <LS>, or 4.6 kb
<FS>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 5.3 kb <LS>,
or 4.6 kb <FS>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Leiser et al. (1981).
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 44000 <LS>, or 47000 <FS>. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves,
mesophyll and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: mitochondria maybe
deformed and the Golgi increased to form many small vesicles containing fine
fibrils. (179) Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: carnation mottle, cocksfoot
mild mosaic, cucumber necrosis, melon necrotic spot, narcissus tip necrosis,
tomato bushy stunt, tobacco necrosis (Weber et al., 1982), artichoke mottled
crinkle, cymbidium ringspot, carnation mottle, cucumber necrosis, pelargonium
leaf curl, southern bean mosaic, sowbane mosaic, tobacco necrosis and tomato
bushy stunt viruses (Gallitelli et al., 1983). (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
ELISA. (187) Campbell, R.N., Lecoq, H., Wipf-Scheibel, C. and Sim, S.T.
(1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 3115. Gallitelli, D., Vovlas, C. and Avgelis, A.
(1983). Phytopath. Z. 106: 149. Leiser, R.M., Stanarius, A., and Stanarius,
Th. (1981). Arch. Phytopath. PflSchutz. 17: 299. Weber, I. (1986). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 319, 4 pp. Weber, I., Proll, E., Ostermann, W.D.,
Leiser, R.M., Stanarius, A. and Kegler, H. (1982). Arch. Phytopath. PflSchutz.
18: 137. Weber, I., Stenarius, A. and Kalinina, I. (1986). Arch. Phytopath.
PflSchutz. 22: 169.


Cucumber mosaic cucumovirus

      (1) R.I.B. Francki, 1980; N. Habili, 1987. (2) Synonyms: banana
infectious chlorosis virus, coleus mosaic virus (Creager, 1945; Holcomb and
Valverde, 1991), cowpea banding mosaic virus, cowpea ringspot virus, cucumber
virus 1, lily ringspot virus (Brierley and Travis, 1958), pea top necrosis
virus, peanut yellow mosaic virus, southern celery mosaic virus (Doolittle,
1916; Price, 1935; Wellman, 1934), soybean stunt virus (Hanada and Tochihara,
1982), spinach blight virus, tomato fern leaf virus, pea western ringspot
virus. (3) Standard acronym: CMV. (4) Strains: numerous, the better known
include: ACMV, ECMV, LCMV, NCMV, PCMV, ZCMV and WAI/WAII; there seem to be two
antigenic groups, ToRS and DTL (Devergne, 1975). (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.4.0.001. (8) First reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By Price (1934). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Very many hosts (Kaper and
Waterworth, 1981) including: Cucumis sativus and many other cucurbits mosaics
and stunting, reduced fruit yield. Lycopersicon esculentum mosaic, reduction
of leaf laminae ("fernleaf") and stunting. Spinacia oleracea severe chlorosis
and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by more than 60 spp. including Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis
craccivora and Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <in 19 species, but in variable extents>. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Cucumis sativus
systemic mosaic. Vigna unguiculata necrotic local lesions. Lycopersicon
esculentum, Nicotiana × edwardsonii, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum symptoms depend
on virus strain. (45) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N.
tabacum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Vigna unguiculata
(L). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Atriplex hortensis,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or
Calendula officinalis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum annuum, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cicer arietinum, or Cichorium endiva, or
Citrullus lanatus, or Coriandrum sativum, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or
Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata,
or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura ferox, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Datura tatula, or Daucus carota, or Emilia sagittata, or Fagopyrum esculentum,
or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus
annuus, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Ipomoea nil, or Lens culinaris, or Lotus
corniculatus, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Matthiola incana, or Medicago
sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Phaseolus lunatus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or
Phytolacca americana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Rumex acetosa,
or Senecio vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
nigrum, or Solanum nodiflorum, or Solanum rostratum, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia
faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Celosia argentea, or Citrullus vulgaris,
or Dahlia pinnata, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Petunia × hybrida, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <9/9>, or Compositae <8/11>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <8/8>, or Cucurbitaceae <7/8>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<21/22>, or Malvaceae <2 /2>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <2/2>,
or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <26/28>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/9>, or Compositae <3/11>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/8>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/22>, or Solanaceae
<2/28>. (53) Douine et al. (1979). (54) TIP: 55-70 °C. (55) LIV: 1-10 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment
with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions, or contains many
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: freeze-dry preparations for shadowing, or
fix with aldehyde for negative staining with PTA. (60) Method: Lot et al.
(1972) and modified by Peden and Symons in 1973 (Clark et al., 1974). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 29 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 99 S. (79) Density 1.367 g cm3 in CsCl <after
fixation with formaldehyde>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 5.5 <Q strain>. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.7 <corrected>. (84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 82 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.621 kb. (92) Genome
of three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.389 kb.
(94) The 2nd largest 3.035 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.197 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Gould and Symons (1977). (100) Base composition 24 %
G. (101) Base composition 23 % A. (102) Base composition 23 % C. (103) Base
composition 30 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap.
(108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases, or decreased
when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (114)
Genome has tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts tyrosine. (117) NCBI Taxon
ID: 12305. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00355

Em(44)n:Cmvcpgene Gb(90)_vi:Cmvcpgene Cucumber Mosaic Virus (CMV) RNA for
capsid protein gene. 7/95 880bp. Z12818 Em(40)_vi:CMV3ACP Gb(84)_vi:CMV3ACP

Gb(84)_vi:CM2BPRO RNA 4A. 3/94 682bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in
the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA <of coat protein>, or satellite RNA <in
some isolates>. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (124) Coat
protein mRNA, which is also the encapsidated RNA-4 of 1.027 kb. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24247. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Habili and Francki (1974). (146) Amino acid sequence: Davies and
Symons (1987). (147) Amino acid composition: Mossop (1978). (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins identified by genomic sequence analysis <Clark et al.
(1974); Kumarasamy and Symons (1979); Gill et al. (1981)>. (153) Three
proteins found. (154) Mr <of the largest> 36300 <791 residues>. (155) RNA-1
translation product from Q-CMV, putative viral RNA replicase component
(Rezaian et al., 1985). (156) Mr of 2nd largest 31000 <333 residues; RNA-2
translation product from Q-CMV, putative viral RNA polymerase (Rezaian et al.,
1985)>. (158) Mr of 3rd 9900 <353 residues>. (159) 3a protein, possible
movement protein (Davies and Symons, 1987). (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm <that are often rhomboidal, hexagonal
or roughly spherical and may appear as solid hollow structures>. (177) They
contain virions. (179) Cucumovirus: Bromoviridae <the type species>. (180) :
Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: peanut stunt
and tomato aspermy viruses, but distantly. (184) Sequence homologies indicate
that the virus is distantly related to brome mosaic virus, and also, in
sequences in RNA-1 and RNA-2, to alfalfa mosaic and tobacco mosaic viruses
(Rezaian et al., 1985; Davies and Symons, 1987). (186) Pea western ringspot
virus is probably a mixture of cucumber mosaic and clover yellow vein viruses.

G.L., Peden, K.W.C. and Symons, R.H. (1974). Virology 62: 434. Creager, D.B.

Cucumber necrosis tombusvirus

      (1) D.M. Rochon, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: CNV (CuNV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 74.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From
Harrow, Ontario, Canada. (10) By McKeen (1959). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally.
(12) Symptoms malformed chlorotic or purplish leaves, which dessicate and die.
Fruits mottled. (13) Cucumis sativus malformed chlorotic leaves. (14)
Transmitted by a vector and means not involving a vector <in water and soil>.
(16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Olpidium radicale. (21)
Transmitted by Chytridiales. (22) Principal natural vector(s): Olpidium
radicale. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis gossypii. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Bos et al. (1984). (39) Spreads in Canada <Ontario>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show necrotic local lesions and systemic necrosis. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii
necrotic local lesions, systemic necrosis. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic
necrosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor small necrotic local lesions, no systemic
infection. Vigna unguiculata brown necrotic local lesions, no systemic
infection. Gomphrena globosa grey necrotic local lesions, no systemic
infection. Nicotiana tabacum grey necrotic spots, no systemic infection. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii, Cucumis sativus. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L),
Vigna unguiculata (L), Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Dias and McKeen (1972). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C <10 min>.
(55) LIV: 30 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Tremaine et al. (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 133 S. (79) Density 1.33 g cm3 in CsCl. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 3.9 <pH>. (84) Virions contain 16 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 84 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.701 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Rochon: phenol or chloroform extraction in buffer containing
10 mm EDTA, TrisHCl pH 8.9, 1% SDS. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike
activity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12143. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): M25270 Gb(84)_vi:CNVGENO Cucumber necrosis virus, complete genome.
4/91 4,701bp. S64508 Em(40)_vi:S64508 Gb(84)_vi:S64508 (defective interfering
RNA DI15) cucumber necrosis virus CNV, Genomic RNA, 622 nt. 12/93 62. U16698
Em(43)_vi:Cn16698 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16698 Cucumber necrosis virus defective
interfering RNA isolate C1. 11/94 432bp. U16699 Em(43)_vi:Cn16699
Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16699 Cucumber necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate
C12. 11/94 432bp. U16700 Em(43)_vi:Cn16700 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16700 Cucumber
necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate C2. 11/94 432bp. U16701
Em(43)_vi:Cn16701 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16701 Cucumber necrosis virus defective
interfering RNA isolate C39. 11/94 594bp. U16702 Em(43)_vi:Cn16702
Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16702 Cucumber necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate
C40. 11/94 411bp. U16703 Em(43)_vi:Cn16703 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16703 Cucumber
necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate C46. 11/94 416bp. U16704
Em(43)_vi:Cn16704 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16704 Cucumber necrosis virus defective
interfering RNA isolate C61. 11/94 594bp. U16705 Em(43)_vi:Cn16705
Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16705 Cucumber necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate
C62. 11/94 597bp. U16706 Em(43)_vi:Cn16706 Gb(89)_vi:Cnu16706 Cucumber
necrosis virus defective interfering RNA isolate C66. 11/94 414bp. (119)
Features of the genome: there are 5 ORFs; p33, p92, p41, p21 and p20. p33 and
p92 are translated from the full length genomic RNA. p92 would be translated
if suppression of the amber codon of p33 were to occur. p41, p21 and p20 are
translated from subgenomic RNAs. p41 is coat protein, p92 is possibly a
replicase protein, p33, p21 and p20 functions are unknown. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA and of an unusual
type of structure. (122) Nongenomic nucleic acid defective interfering RNA.
(123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (124) Two subgenomic RNAs found
in infected cells, 2.1 and 0.9 kb, and there are possibly others. (125) 3
virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells <also several minor
ones>. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 4.7 kbp. (127) 2nd largest
2.1 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 0.9 kbp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
41000. (134) Coat protein. (146) Amino acid sequence: Rochon and Tremaine
(1989). (147) Amino acid composition: Rochon and Tremaine (1989). (148) Virion
proteins not glycosylated. (150) Virion proteins not phosphorylated. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies and unusual in shape.
(176) Multivesicular bodies. (177) They do not contain virions. (179)
Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: no serological relationship to several other
tombusviruses. (184) Its possible replicase has similar amino acid sequence to
the replicases of carnation mottle carmovirus, barley yellow dwarf luteovirus,
tobacco necrosis necrovirus, red clover necrotic mosaic dianthovirus, maize
chlorotic mottle machlomovirus and hepatitis C virus. (187) Dias, H.F. and
McKeen, C.D. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 82, 4 pp. Johnston, J.C.
and Rochon, D.M. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 2233. McKeen, C.D. (1959). Can. J.
Bot. 37: 913. Riviere, C.J. and Rochon, D.M. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 1887.
Rochon, D.M. and Tremaine, J.H. (1988). Virology 69: 395. Rochon, D.M. and
Tremaine, J.H. (1989). Virology 169: 251. Rochon, D.M., Johnston, J.C. and
Riviere, C.J. (1991). Can. J. Pl. Pathol. 13: 162.


Cucumber soil-borne carmovirus

      (1) K.M. Makkouk, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: CSBV (CuSBV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 74.0.2.0.005. (8) First reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From
Jieh, south of Beirut, Lebanon. (10) By Koenig et al. (1983). (13) Cucumis
sativus present in roots only, no leaf symptoms. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Lebanon. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C.
amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana glutinosa, Beta
vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata Black eye No. 5 local lesions not systemic. (44)
Physalis floridana, Vicia faba, Spinacia oleracea, Capsicum annuum cv. Yolo
Wonder, Solanum melongena cv. Black Beauty, Vigna unguiculata cv. California
Black Eye No. 5. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L), Datura
stramonium (L), Gomphrena globosa (L), Nicotiana glutinosa (L), Beta vulgaris
(L), Vigna unguiculata cv. Black Eye No. 5 (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus <root
only>, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Vigna unguiculata <cv. Black eye No. 5>. (48) Capsicum annuum <cv. Yolo
Wonder>, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena <cv. Black Beauty>, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata <cv. California Black
Eye No. 5>. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/5>.
(51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae
<3/5>. (53) Koenig et al. (1983). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Koenig et al. (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 31 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile and
angular in profile <occasionally>. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 120 S. (79) Density 1.343 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 5.25 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.75 kb <also a
satellite RNA of 0.5 kb>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Koenig et al.
(1983). (100) Base composition 32 % G. (101) Base composition 23 % A. (102)
Base composition 22 % C. (103) Base composition 23 % U. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 41400. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Koenig
et al. (1983). (168) Acts as helper for a satellite RNA. (171) Virions found
in epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Thin fibrils
about 9 nm thick. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: small vesicles with a single membrane and containing fibrils
resembling nucleic acid. (179) Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (187) Koenig, R., Lesemann, D.-E., Huth, W. and Makkouk, K.M.
(1983). Phytopathology 73: 515.


Cucumber toad-skin (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.DE.02. (8) First
reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From France. (10) By Lecoq (1982). (13)
Cucumis sativus vein-clearing, severe leaf crinkling and stunting (toad skin
disease). (39) Spreads in France and Greece <possibly>. (47) Cucumis sativus.
(50) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>. (179) Unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(187) Katis, N., Avgelis, A. and Lecoq, H. (1995). Proc. 8th Conf. on Virus
Dis. Vegs, p.140 Prague, July, 1995. Lecoq, H. (1982). Rev. Hort. 223: 15.


Cucumber vein yellowing virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and E. Tanne, 1988. (3) Standard acronym: CVYV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 79.0.P.2.001. (8) First reported in Cucumis spp. (9) From Israel.
(10) By Cohen and Nitzany (1960). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis sativus,
Citrullus vulgaris vein clearing, leaf chlorosis and necrosis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (39) Spreads in Israel. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Cucumis sativus, Citrullus vulgaris systemic leaf chlorosis. (44) Cucurbita
moschata, Ecballium elaterium, Nicotiana glutinosa, Pisum sativum, Chenopodium
amaranticolor. (45) Cucumis sativus, Citrullus vulgaris. (46) Cucumis sativus
(W). (47) Citrullus lanatus, or Citrullus vulgaris, or Cucumis sativus. (48)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucurbita moschata, or Ecballium elaterium, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Pisum sativum. (50) Cucurbitaceae <3/5>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 52 °C. (55) LIV: <less than> 1 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (60) Method: Sela et al. (1980). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70)
Virions of 740-800 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 220 S. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 39000. (134)
Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Sela et al. (1980). (179)
(Ungrouped). (187) Cohen, S. and Nitzany, F.E. (1960). Phytopathol. Medit. 1:
44. Cohen, S. and Nitzany, F.E. (1963). Phytopathology 53: 193. Harpaz, I. and
Cohen, S. (1965). Phytopath. Z. 54: 240. Sela, I., Assouline, I., Tanne, E.,
Cohen, S. and Marco, S. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 226.


Cycas necrotic stunt nepovirus

      (1) M. Kusunoki, K. Hanada and M. Kameya, 1987. (3) Standard acronym:
CNSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.013. (8) First reported in Cycas
revoluta. (9) From Chiba Prefecture, Japan. (10) By Kusunoki et al. (1975).
(11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13) Cycas revoluta twisted young
leaves and chlorotic or necrotic spots of mature leaves, stunting. Daphne
odora mild mosaic. Aucuba japonica vein clearing. Gladiolus spp. symptomless.
(14) Transmitted by <possibly> a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<about 30% in Chenopodium amaranticolor and over 80% in C. serotinum>. (39)
Spreads in Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. serotinum chlorotic
local lesions or ringspots, then systemic mottling and necrosis. Celosia
cristata systemic mottling. Gomphrena globosa, Beta vulgaris latent infection.
Spinacia oleracea latent infection. Cycas revoluta chlorotic spotting, then
systemic mottling and necrosis. (44) Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita moschata,
Glycine max, Nicotiana clevelandii, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana
tabacum, N. glutinosa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Catharanthus roseus,
Datura stramonium. (45) Chenopodium serotinum, C. quinoa, C. amaranticolor,
Celosia cristata. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L and W), C. amaranticolor (L) and
then (W), C. murale (L) and then (W), C. serotinum (W), Tetragonia
tetragonioides (L). (47) Aucuba japonica, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia
cristata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Chenopodium serotinum, or Cycas revoluta, or Daphne odora, or
Gladiolus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycium chinense, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis sativus,
or Cucurbita moschata, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus
caryophyllus, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Glycine max, or Helianthus annuus,
or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>,
or Aucubaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Cycadaceae <1/1>, or
Iridaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/9>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Thymelaeaceae <1/1>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or
Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/10>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<8/9>. (53) Kusunoki et al. (1986). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 18-24 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:
Kusunoki et al. (1986). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 112 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 85 S <M>. (79) Density 1.472 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or
1.404 g cm3 in CsCl <M>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.67 <B>, or 1.41 <M>, or 1 <T>.
(84) Virions contain 24 % nucleic acid <B>, or 12 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 %
nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 76 % protein <B>, or 88 % protein <M>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 12.85 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 8.1 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.75 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hanada et al. (1986). (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor
not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest> 71000. (135)
Mr of 2nd largest 65000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 56000. (164) Genome
replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in Golgi
apparatus, and in cell vacuoles. (173) Virions found in in plasmodesmata.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms
<crystalline aggregates of virions and capsid protein>. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: vesicular structures also occur in
cytoplasm. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, cacao necrosis, cherry
leaf roll, crimson clover latent, grapevine chrome mosaic, mulberry ringspot,
myrobalan latent, tobacco ringspot, tomato ringspot and tomato black ring
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: use gel diffusion serology; species
of Fabaceae and Solanaceae not infected despite `nepovirus-like' symptoms in
Chenopodium plants. (187) Hanada, K., Kusunoki, M. and Iwaki, M. (1986). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 422. Kusunoki, M., Nagai, Y., Yamashita, S., Doi, Y.
and Yora, K. (1975). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 41: 285. Kusunoki, M., Hanada,
K., Iwaki, M., Chang, M.U., Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 52: 302.


Cymbidium mosaic potexvirus

      (1) R.I.B. Francki, 1984. (2) Synonyms: orchid mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: CymMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.007. (8) First
reported in Cymbidium spp. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Jensen (1950).
(11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Cymbidium spp. mosaic, necrosis. Cattleya
spp. mosaic, flower necrosis. Phalaenopsis spp. mosaic, water soaked local
lesions. Vanda spp. chlorotic flecks. Epidendrum spp., Laelia spp.,
Laeliocattleya spp., Oncidium spp., Zygopetalum spp., Vanilla fragrans also
naturally infected. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact
between plants. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium
blotchy local lesions developing slowly; not systemic. Cassia occidentalis
small local lesions; not systemic. (44) Beta vulgaris, Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Zea mays. (45) Datura stramonium, Cymbidium sp.
(46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Cassia occidentalis (L), Datura stramonium
(L). (47) Cassia occidentalis, or Cattleya, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or

Cymbidium ringspot tombusvirus

      (1) K. Boswell. 1985. (3) Standard acronym: CyRSV (CymRSV). (4) Strains:
cymbidium and clover. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported
in Cymbidium spp. (9) From Sussex, U.K. (10) By Hollings and Stone (1963).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cymbidium spp. chlorotic ring-mottling, more
intense when mixed with cymbidium mosaic virus. Trifolium repens chlorotic
flecking, mottling. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed <in Trifolium incarnatum,
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. The Prince, Nicotiana clevelandii>. (39) Spreads in the
UK. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
murale, C. quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Emilia
sagittata chlorotic local lesions; systemic yellow spots and rings, leaf
malformation and necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. The Prince whitish necrotic
local lesions with Cymbidium strain, semi-necrotic local lesions with clover
strain; systemic chlorosis and mottling (both strains). Vigna unguiculata cv.
Blackeye necrotic whitish and brown local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana
clevelandii diffuse chlorotic, and some brown local lesions, necrosis spreads
killing leaf; systemic chlorotic and necrotic, speckling, severe puckering,
stunting. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cvs White Burley, Judy's Pride,
Havana 425, Xanthi-nc brown necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii virus is best stored as freeze-dried leaves. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Atriplex hortensis, or Beta
vulgaris, or Capsicum frutescens, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cymbidium, or Datura stramonium, or Emilia sagittata, or Fagopyrum

vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Phytolacca americana,
or Pisum sativum, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Senecio vulgaris, or Solanum
nigrum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia

repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Ageratum conyzoides, or Apium
graveolens, or Avena sativa, or Bellis perennis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea var.
capitata, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chrysanthemum
morifolium, or Citrus limon, or Cucumis melo, or Dactylis glomerata, or

<cv. Scarlett o'Hara>, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phleum pratense, or

Cynara (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: CyV (CraV). (5) ICTV decimal
code 62.U.P.0.015. (8) First reported in Cynara scolymus. (9) From Italy. (10)
By Russo et al. (1975). (13) Cynara scolymus, C. syriaca symptomatology
unknown (virus found only in complex with other viruses). (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy and Spain
<probably>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana
systemic leaf chlorosis. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Nicotiana
benthamiana (W). (47) Cynara scolymus, or Cynara syriaca, or Nicotiana
benthamiana. (50) Compositae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo
or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 260 nm <in vivo>. (71) Virions 73 nm wide <in vivo>.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 20 nm in diameter. (171) Virions
found in leaves, mesophyll and the xylem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(179) <Probably> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(187) Pena-Iglesias, A., Rubio-Huertos, M., Moreno, S. and Martin, R. (1972).
Annl. I.N.I.A. 2: 123. Russo, M., Martelli, G.P. and Rana, G.L. (1975).
Phytopath. Z. 83: 223.

      (1) A.A. Brunt and B.E. Lockhart, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code

Cynosurus mottle (?) sobemovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: lolium mottle virus (A'Brook, 1972).
(3) Standard acronym: CnMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.T.013. (8) First
reported in Cynosurus cristatus, Lolium perenne. (9) From the U.K. (10) By
A'Brook (1972). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Agrostis tenuis, Cynosurus
cristatus severe leaf mottling and necrosis. Agrostis stolonifera dark green
leaf mottling. Lolium perenne, Lolium multiflorum × L. perenne chlorotic leaf
mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Rhopalosiphum padi (New Zealand isolate). (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Germany, New Zealand, and the UK.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Agrostis puchella, Bromus secalinus,
Cynosurus cristatus, Lagurus ovatus, Phleum arenarium, Triticum aestivum
severe systemic leaf mottling and, often, necrosis. Avena fatua, A. sativa,
Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale mild systemic leaf mottling. (44) Elytrigia
repens, Bromus mollis, Dactylis glomerata, Lolium multiflorum, Setaria
italica. (45) Avena sativa, Triticum aestivum. (46) Avena sativa (W),
Cynosurus cristatus (W), Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Agrostis puchella, or
Agrostis stolonifera, or Agrostis tenuis, or Avena fatua, or Avena sativa, or
Bromus secalinus, or Cynosurus cristatus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lagurus
ovatus, or Lolium multiflorum × L. perenne, or Lolium perenne, or Phleum
arenarium, or Poa annua, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Bromus
mollis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Echinochloa colona, or Echinochloa
crus-galli, or Elytrigia repens, or Festuca pratensis, or Lamarckia aurea, or
Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Oryza sativa, or Panicum miliaceum,
or Poa annua, or Setaria italica, or Setaria viridis, or Zea mays. (50)
Gramineae <15/28>. (51) Gramineae <15/28>. (53) Catherall et al. (1977);
Mohamed (1978a). (54) TIP: 75 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 8. (60) Method:
Mohamed (1978b). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
113 S. (79) Density 1.399 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density 1.332 g cm3 in Cs2SO4.
(83) A260/A280 ratio 1.72. (84) Virions contain 22.5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 77.5 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 4.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Mohamed (1978b). (100) Base composition 24.2 % G. (101) Base composition 24.3
% A. (102) Base composition 26.2 % C. (103) Base composition 25.3 % U. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30500. (134) And it is coat protein. (171)
Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) <Possible>
Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cocksfoot
mottle virus. (184) The viral RNA has 58% nucleotide sequence homology with
that of cocksfoot mottle virus. (187) A'Brook, J. (1972). Pl. Path. 32: 118.
Catherall, P.L., Andrews, P.A. and Chamberlain, J.A. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol.
87: 233. Hull, R. (1977). J. gen. Virol. 36: 289. Hull, R. (1988). In: The
Plant Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions with Monopartite RNA Genomes, p.
113; ed. R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York. Huth, W. and Paul, H.L. (1977).
Annls. Phytopath. 9: 293. Mohamed, N.A. (1978a). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 21: 709.
Mohamed, N.A. (1978b). J. gen. Virol. 40: 379. Mohamed, N.A. and Mossop, D.W.
(1981). J. gen. Virol. 55: 63. Paul, H.L., Querfurth, G. and Huth, W. (1980).
J. gen. Virol. 47: 67.


Cypripedium calceolus (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: CypCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.023. (8) First reported in Cypripedium calceolus. (9) From Germany.
(10) By Lesemann and Vetten (1985). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cypripedium
calceolus chlorotic and necrotic streaking and leaf deformation. (39) Spreads
in Germany. (47) Cypripedium calceolus. (50) Cypripediaceae <1/1>. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 774 nm. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic, tobacco etch, tulip
breaking and turnip mosaic viruses. (187) Lesemann, D.-E. and Vetten, H.J.
(1985). Acta Hort. 164: 45.


Dahlia mosaic caulimovirus

      (1) J. Hammond, 1986; A.A. Brunt, 1987. (2) Synonyms: dahlia virus 1.
(3) Standard acronym: DMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 15.0.1.0.005. (8) First
reported in Dahlia pinnata. (9) From Germany. (10) By Brandenburg (1928). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Dahlia pinnata chlorotic vein-banding, mosaic and leaf
malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by 16 species, notably Aphis fabae, Myzus persicae and
Macrosiphum euphorbiae (Heinze, 1951, 1952; Brierley and Smith, 1950). (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner <in an
atypical manner, because the virus can be retained by both feeding and by
starved M. persicae (Brierley and Smith, 1950)>. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Brierley (1933; 1951); Brierley and Smith (1950); Heinze (1951;
1952). Dahlia mosaic is prevalent because it is transmitted effectively by
several aphid species common on dahlias, and cultivars with few or no symptoms
are important reservoirs of infection. (37) Probably distributed worldwide.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Verbesina encelioides chlorotic
local lesions then vein-banding, chlorosis and slight malformation. Dahlia
pinnata systemic chlorotic vein-banding, then chlorosis and stunting. Ageratum
conyzoides cv. Blue Ball chlorotic local lesions, then systemic chlorotic
vein-banding and chlorosis. Zinnia elegans symptomless inoculated leaves, then
slight systemic malformation, with transient chlorosis. Amaranthus caudatus
few chlorotic local lesions, then mild systemic mottle. Chenopodium capitatum
no symptoms in inoculated leaves, then conspicuous systemic chlorotic
vein-banding and chlorosis. (45) Verbesina encelioides and Zinnia elegans.
(46) No reliable local lesion host, but Verbesina encelioides is best for
whole plant assay. (47) Ageratum conyzoides, or Amaranthus caudatus, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Dahlia pinnata, or Verbesina encelioides, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae
<4/4>. (53) Brunt (1971a). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4 days <at 18°C>,
or 16-32 days <at 2°C; Brierley and Smith, 1950; Brunt, 1971>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: use neutral 2%
PTA, in other stains such as UA or UF the virions are swollen or disrupted,
even after fixing. (60) Method: Brunt (1971b). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 48-50 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 254 S. (84) Virions contain 14.5-15 % nucleic acid
<Goméc, 1973>. (85) Virions 85-85.5 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome
size 6.8 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <c.> 6.8 kb <pairs>. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis, xylem, phloem sieve
tubes and enlarged plasmodesmata (Kitajima and Lauritis, 1969). (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm and in the perinuclear space. (173) Virions found in
associated with dictyosomes or Golgi cisternae (Kitajima et al., 1969). (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells <Brunt, 1969; Kitajima and Lauritis,
1969; Kitajima et al., 1969>. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176)
Electron-dense amorphous often vacuolated matrix. (177) They contain virions
<in great numbers and apparently hollow, 40-45 nm in diameter>. (179)
Caulimovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cauliflower
mosaic (Brunt, 1966; 1969) and carnation etched ring viruses (Hollings and
Stone, 1969). (184) Antisera to dahlia mosaic and cauliflower mosaic virus
differ little in homologous and heterologous titres in agar gel (0.8%) double
diffusion tests. However neither virus infects the natural host of the other.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: tobacco streak, tobacco rattle, tomato spotted
wilt and cucumber mosaic viruses also infect dahlia. Unlike dahlia mosaic,
however, each of these viruses is readily isolated and identified
serologically and/or by the reactions of Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor,
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum and Vigna unguiculata. (187) Brandenburg, E.
(1928). Forsch. Geb. Pflkrankh., Berlin 5: 39. Brierley, P. (1933). Contr.
Boyce Thompson Inst. Pl. Res. 5: 235. Brierley, P. (1951). Pl. Dis. Reptr 35:
405. Brierley, P. and Smith, F.F. (1950). Pl. Dis. Reptr 34: 363. Brunt, A.A.
(1966). Virology 28: 778. Brunt, A.A. (1969). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.
1968, 104. Brunt, A.A. (1971a). Ann. appl. Biol. 67: 357. Brunt, A.A. (1971b).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 51, 4 pp. Goméc, B. (1973). Ph.D. Thesis, Univ.
Calif. Davis, California, U.S.A. Heinze, K. (1951). Mitt. biol. BundesAnst.
Land. Forstw. 71, 126 pp. Heinze, K. (1952). Z. PflKrankh. PflPath. PflSchutz.
59: 3. Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1969). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.
for 1968, p. 102. Kitajima, E.W. and Lauritis, J.A. (1969). Virology 37: 681.
Kitajima, E.W., Lauritis, J.A. and Swift, H. (1969). Virology 39: 240.
Richins, R.D. and Shepherd, R.J. (1983). Virology 124: 208.

Dandelion latent carlavirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: DaLV. (4) Strains:

Dandelion yellow mosaic sequivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and L. Bos, 1992. (2) Synonyms: lettuce necrosis virus
(Hein, 1963). (3) Standard acronym: DaYMV (DYMV). (5) ICTV decimal code
65.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Taraxacum officinale. (9) From the U.K.
(10) By Kassanis (1944); Bos (1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
chlorotic rings, interveinal necrosis, distortion and stunting. (13) Lactuca
sativa veinal chlorosis and necrosis, and veinal and interveinal necrotic
etching; leaf narrowing and curling and severe plant stunting. Taraxacum
officinale conspicuous yellow rings and mottling. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
(Aulacorthum) solani, Myzus ornatus, Myzus ascalonicus, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis fabae, Macrosiphum
euphorbiae, Nasonovia ribicola, Aulocorthum circumflexum, Pemphigus bursarius.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by
Kassanis (1947). (39) Spreads in the former Czechoslovakia, Germany, the
Netherlands, Norway, and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, systemic chlorosis, necrosis, leaf curling and stunting or
symptomless infection. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa numerous
small chlorotic local lesions; systemic stippling. Chenopodium murale small
local necrotic lesions. Lactuca sativa chlorotic mosaics, leaf curling and
plant stunting. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic chlorosis (some isolates only).
N. clevelandii systemic chlorotic rings (some isolates only). (44) Pisum
sativum, Sonchus oleraceus, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Chenopodium quinoa,
Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium murale (L), C.
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Gomphrena globosa

quinoa, or Cichorium endiva, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or

benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Pastinaca sativa, or Spinacia oleracea,
or Taraxacum officinale. (48) Apium graveolens, or Calendula officinalis, or
Cheiranthus cheiri, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Senecio
vulgaris, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <5/8>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <5/5>, or Umbelliferae <1/2>. (51) Compositae <3/8>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Umbelliferae <1/2>.
(53) Kassanis (1947); Bos et al. (1983). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: ISEM. (60) Method: Bos et al. (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 159 S. (81) Density 1.42 in
Cs2SO4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.67. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 10
kb. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr 29000, or 32000. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 25000, or 29500. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 24000, or 27000. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) Sequivirus: Sequiviridae. (180) :
Sequiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: parsnip
yellow fleck virus. (187) Blystad, D.-R. (1989). Norw. J. agric. Sci. 3: 373.
Bos, L., Huijberts, N., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D. (1983). Neth. J. Pl. Path.
89: 207. Hein, A. (1963). NachrBl. dtsch. Pflanzenschutzd. Braunschweig 15:
