Daphne S (?) carlavirus

      (1) H.F. Nielson and K.S. Milne, 1991. (2) Synonyms: daphne leaf
distortion S carlavirus. (3) Standard acronym: DVS. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.T.1.013. (8) First reported in Daphne spp. (9) From New Zealand. (10) By
Forster and Milne. (11) Symptoms none. (12) Symptoms sometimes downcurling of
leaf edges. (13) Daphne odora cv. Leucanthe malformation and downcurling of
mature leaves. Daphne odora cvs Leucanthe Variegata, Rubra, Rubra variegata,
D. × burkwoodii cvs Somerset, Variegata, D. cneorum cvs Major, Variegata, D. ×
dauphinii, D. genkwa, D. giraldii, D. laureola, D. × napolitana, D. retusa
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (39) Spreads in New Zealand. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Daphne spp. symptomless. (45) Daphne odora cvs Leucanthe or
Rubra. (47) Daphne, or Daphne cneorum <cvs Major, Variegata>, or Daphne
genkwa, or Daphne giraldii, or Daphne laureola, or Daphne odora <cvs Leucanthe
Variegata, Rubra, Rubra variegata>, or Daphne retusa, or Daphne × burkwoodii
<cvs Somerset, Variegata>, or Daphne × dauphinii, or Daphne × napolitana. (48)
Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,
or Dianthus barbatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Thymelaeaceae <10/10>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/6>. (53) Forster (1974); Forster and Milne (1978).
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: flowers or young
leaves are good sources of virions. (60) Method: Forster and Milne (1978).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight, or usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)
Virions of 720 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74)
Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 174 S <±1>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.35. (125) 1
virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179)
<Possible> Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
carnation latent and potato S viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: flowers
or young leaves are good sources of virions for examination by electron
microscopy. This virus, which has virions 720 nm long, commonly occurs in
mixed infections with daphne Y virus, which has slightly longer (730 nm), less
rigid and narrower virions. If, however, all virions appear the same, have a
length of c.700750 nm and can be mechanically transmitted to C. quinoa
inducing chlorotic local lesions in 46 days, and scattered systemic blotches
in 1028 days then the virus is probably the potyvirus; the carlavirus is not
sap transmissible, and other viruses found in daphne but not readily seen in
the electron microscope give quite different reactions when sap transmitted to
C. quinoa. (187) Forster, R.L.S. (1974). M.Hort.Sci Thesis, Massey University,
New Zealand 137 pp. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1975). N.Z. Jl agric.
Res. 18: 391. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1978). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 21:
131.


Daphne X potexvirus

      (1) R.L.S. Forster, 1986. (2) Synonyms: daphne latent X potexvirus. (3)
Standard acronym: DVX. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.007. (8) First reported
in Daphne cneorum. (9) From New Zealand. (10) By Forster and Milne (1978b).
(11) Symptoms none. (13) Daphne cneorum, D. odora symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (15) Not transmitted between peas
by the aphid Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Forster and Milne
(1976; 1978). In New Zealand, no Daphne cneorum plants have been found free of
daphne X virus out of more than 100 tested. D. cneorum plants imported from
West Germany free of daphne X virus have been propagated and used to replace
infected stock plants in nurseries. (39) Spreads in Australia and New Zealand.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus sunken chlorotic
local lesions; then systemic faint chlorotic spotting, but later leaves are
symptomless. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions, often with red haloes;
not systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic and necrotic local lesions;
systemic chlorotic rings or mottle. Pisum sativum necrotic local lesions; then
systemic chlorotic mottle and sometimes stem blackening. Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica small necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Vicia faba,
Spinacia oleracea. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii inoculated leaves are also good
source for purification. (46) Cucumis sativus (L), Gomphrena globosa (L),
Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica (L). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Daphne cneorum, or Daphne
odora, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Pisum sativum, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (48) Spinacia
oleracea, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>,
or Thymelaeaceae <2/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>. (54) TIP: 80 °C. (55) LIV: 35 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Forster
and Milne (1978c). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 500 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 110 S. (79) Density 1.28 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions
contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
6.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Guilford and Forster (1986).
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110)
Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region at the 3'terminal and 200 bases
long. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (123) Subgenomic
mRNA found in infected cells. (124) Five subgenomic RNAs were detected in
infected tissues (4.9; 4.0; 2.1; 1.4 and 0.8 Kb). The 0.8 Kb subgenomic RNA is
the mRNA for the coat protein (Guilford and Forster, 1986). (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (179) Potexvirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: clover yellow mosaic, narcissus mosaic,
potato X and white clover mosaic viruses, although preliminary tests (Milne
and Forster, 1976) had suggested a distant relationship to white clover mosaic
virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Only two other viruses infecting daphne
have flexuous filamentous virions; daphne S virus has virions c. 720 nm long
(Forster and Milne, 1978a), and daphne Y virus has virions c. 730 nm long
(Forster and Milne, 1976). Unlike daphne X virus, these viruses do not infect
Cucumis sativus or Gomphrena globosa. (187) Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S.
(1976). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 19: 359. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1978a).
N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 21: 131. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1978b). N.Z. Jl
agric. Res. 21: 137. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1978c). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 195, 3 pp. Guilford, P.J. and Forster, R.L.S. (1986). J. gen.
Virol. 67: 83. Milne, K.S. and Forster, R.L.S. (1976). Acta Hort. 59: 95.


Daphne Y potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: daphne chlorotic mosaic Y potyvirus.
(3) Standard acronym: DVY. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.024. (8) First
reported in Daphne odora, D. cneorum, D. retusa. (9) From New Zealand. (10) By
Forster and Milne (1975). (13) Daphne odora, D. cneorum, D. retusa, D.
mezereum leaf chlorosis and distortion, decreased flower quality. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Australia, the Netherlands, New Zealand, and the UK. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, Spinacia
oleracea chlorotic and/or necrotic local lesions; no systemic infection.
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions; systemic chlorotic flecks or
blotches. Nicotiana clevelandii symptomless local infection or etched necrotic
rings; symptomless systemic infection. (44) Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena
globosa, Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Daphne cneorum, or Daphne mezereum, or Daphne odora, or Daphne retusa, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Dianthus barbatus,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Matthiola incana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Solanaceae <1/4>, or Thymelaeaceae <4/4>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3 /4>. (53) Forster and Milne (1976).
(54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 8-10 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (60)
Method: Forster and Milne (1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 733 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 149 S. (171) Virions found in
leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, lettuce
mosaic, maize dwarf mosaic, passionfruit woodiness, potato Y, tobacco etch,
tamarillo mosaic, turnip mosaic and watermelon mosaic 2 viruses. (187) Bos, L.
(1971). Jversl. Inst. PlZt. 1971, p. 84. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S.
(1975). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 18; 391. Forster, R.L.S. and Milne, K.S. (1976).
N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 19: 359. Sutton, J. and Taylor, R.M. (1973). Rep. Vic.
Res. Inst. 19721973, p. 12.


Dasheen bacilliform (?) badnavirus

      (1) R.D. Woods, 1984. (2) Synonyms: colocasia badnavirus, taro
bacilliform virus. (3) Standard acronym: TaBV (CBV). (5) ICTV decimal code
07.0.1.T.003. (8) First reported in Colocasia esculenta. (9) From the Solomon
Islands. (10) By Kenten and Woods (1973). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection. (13) Colocasia esculenta vein clearing and slight leaf
malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Planococcus citri. (18) Transmitted by Pseudococcidae.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(39) Spreads in the Cook Islands, Fiji, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, and
Western Samoa. (43) Colocasia esculenta, Alocasia macrorrhizos, Xanthosoma sp.
transient vein-clearing and slight leaf malformation. (47) Alocasia
macrorrhizos, or Colocasia esculenta, or Xanthosoma. (50) Araceae <3/3>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: James et al. (1973). (61) Virions
bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 125 nm in length. (71)
Virions 28 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 285 S. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant and often in phloem sieve tubes. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm
and in cell vacuoles. (179) <Possible> Badnavirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: cacao swollen shoot badnavirus. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: "Male" taro plants in Papua New Guinea and the Solomon
Islands also containing taro bobone rhabdovirus develop very severe "alomae"
symptoms. (187) Gollifer, D.E., Jackson, G.H.V., Dabek, A.J., Plumb. R.T. and
May, Y.Y. (1977). PANS 23: 171. Jackson, G.H.V. (1980). Diseases and Pests of
Taro South Pacific Commission, Noumea. James, M., Kenten, R.H. and Woods, R.D.
(1973). J. gen. Virol. 21: 145. Kenten, R.H. and Woods, R.D. (1973). PANS 19:
38.


Dasheen mosaic potyvirus

      (1) F.W. Zettler and E. Hiebert, 1986; B. Rodoni, 1986. (3) Standard
acronym: DsMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.023. (8) First reported in
Zantedeschia elliottiana corms imported into the U.S.A. from Holland. (9) From
Alachua County, Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Zettler et al. (1970). (11) Symptoms
vary seasonally. (13) Aglaonema, Alocasia, Amorphophallus, Arisaema, Caladium,
Cyrtosperma spp. mosaic. Cryptocoryne, Dieffenbachia, Philodendron, Richardia,
Zantedeschia spp. mosaic and leaf malformation. Colocasia, Xanthosoma spp.
mosaic, chlorotic feathering. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis craccivora (Morales
and Zettler, 1977) and Aphis gossypii (Gollifer et al., 1977), but apparently
not by Pentalonia nigronervosa (Morales and Zettler, 1977) or Rhopalosiphum
padi (Gollifer et al., 1977). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed <Hartman et al., 1972; Zettler and Abo El-Nil, 1979>. (35)
Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Abo El-Nil and
Zettler (1974); Hartman and Zettler (1972); Debrot and Ordosgoitti (1974);
Alconero and Zettler (1971); Zettler et al. (1970), reported that dasheen
mosaic virus is widespread in Aglaonema, Caladium, Colocasia, Dieffenbachia,
Xanthosoma and Zantedeschia spp. Tissue culture techniques give virus-free
plants of Caladium, Colocasia, Dieffenbachia and Xanthosoma, and these can be
used for propagation (Hartman, 1974b, Zettler et al., 1980). Attempts to
eliminate dasheen mosaic virus from Xanthosoma corms by heat treatment were
unsuccessful (Alconero, 1972). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <especially
in tropical and subtropical regions>. (39) Spreads in China. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Philodendron selloum systemic mosaic, vein
clearing, malformation. Caladium hortulanum, Colocasia spp., Xanthosoma spp.
systemic mosaic. Dieffenbachia spp. systemic mosaic, epinasty, systemic and
local necrosis. Philodendron verrucosum local necrosis; not systemic.
Zantedeschia spp. systemic mosaic, malformation. (44) Nicotiana × edwardsonii,
N. benthamiana, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Philodendron selloum; Caladium
hortulanum (certain cultivars); Xanthosoma spp. (certain cultivars); Colocasia
spp. (certain cultivars); Zantedeschia spp., Richardia spp. (46) Philodendron
verrucosum (L), Philodendron selloum (W) test plant for aphid transmission.
The following species gave local lesions in Italy, but not outside Europe
(Rana et al., 1983): Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. ambrosioides,
Nicotiana benthamiana, Saponaria vaccaria cv. Pink Beauty. (47) Aglaonema, or
Alocasia, or Amorphophallus, or Arisaema, or Caladium hortulanum, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Colocasia esculenta, or Cryptocoryne, or Cyrtosperma, or Dieffenbachia
picta, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Philodendron selloum, or Philodendron
verrucosum, or Richardia, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Spathiphyllum, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Xanthosoma caracu, or Zantedeschia <no species
name provided>, or Zantedeschia elliottiana. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var. acephala, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Capsicum annuum, or Carica papaya, or
Cassia occidentalis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana langsdorffii,
or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Sorghum bicolor, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Araceae <16/16>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or Solanaceae <1/15>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Caricaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Solanaceae <15 /15>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (52)
There are conflicting reports on the susceptibility of non-aroids; in European
studies some are susceptible, but, in tests Florida and Venezuela, non-aroids
were not infected (Zettler and Hartman, 1986). (53) Chase and Zettler (1982);
Debrot and Ordosgoitti (1974); Hartman (1974a); Hartman and Zettler (1972);
Rana et al. (1983); Rodrigues et al. (1984); Shanmuganathan (1980); Tooyama
(1975a; 1975b); Van der Meer (1985); Wisler et al. (1978); Zettler and Hartman
(1986); Zettler et al. (1970). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days <at 26°C
(Alconero, 1972)>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: see Chase and Zettler (1982), p. 892. (60)
Method: Moghal and Francki (1977); Abo El-Nil et al. (1977). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm <approximately>.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.26 g cm3 in CsCl. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 2.38 <specific absorbance at 260 nm>. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 10
kb <similar in size to other potyviral RNAs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 10 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Dougherty and Hiebert (1980). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 29271. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): S66478 Em(40)_vi:S66478 Gb(84)_un:S66478 (3'
region) dasheen mosaic virus DMV, isolate LA, Genomic, 252 nt. 1/94 252bp.
U00122 Em(40)_vi:DPU00122 Gb(84)_vi:DMU00122 Dasheen mosaic potyvirus capsid
protein gene, complete cds, RNA polymerase gene, partial cds. U08124
Em(40)_vi:DM08124 Gb(84)_vi:DMU08124 Dasheen mosaic virus RNA polymerase (NIb)
gene, partial cds, and capsid protein (CP) gene, co 4 sequences. (132) Virion
protein(s) one <; many virion species detected in SDS-PAGE probably due to
proteolysis>. (133) Mr 29000. (134) Capsid protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Morales, Zettler and Hiebert (unpublished); Hiebert et al.
(1984). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins identified by genomic sequence
analysis <Hiebert et al. (1984)>. (153) Four proteins found. (154) Mr <of the
largest> 69000. (155) Cylindrical inclusion protein. (156) Mr of 2nd largest
56000. (157) Nuclear inclusion-like protein, polymerase. (158) Mr of 3rd
47000. (159) Nuclear inclusion-like protein, protease. (160) Mr of 4th 51000.
(161) Helper protein for aphid transmisson. (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and probably
phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions <but
virions may be associated with pinwheel inclusions>. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: blackeye cowpea mosaic, tobacco etch, and araujia mosaic viruses
(Hiebert and Charudattan, 1984; Abo El-Nil et al., 1977). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: potato Y and turnip mosaic viruses. (184) The
cylindrical inclusion protein (pinwheel) of dasheen mosaic virus is
serologically related to that of araujia mosaic virus (Hiebert and
Charudattan, 1984). The helper component protein of tobacco vein mottling
potyvirus is related to in vitro synthesized gene products of dasheen mosaic
virus (Hiebert et al., 1984). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Filamentous
viruses of Anthurium andraeanum in Venezuela (Herold, 1967) and Zantedeschia
aethiopica in the Soviet Union (Kolbasina and Protsenko, 1973) have been
reported, but their relationship to dasheen mosaic virus has not been
determined. Cucumber mosaic virus (Lovisolo and Conti, 1969), tomato spotted
wilt virus (Tomkins and Severin, 1950), and two bacilliform viruses infecting
taro (James et al., 1973) can readily be distinguished from dasheen mosaic
virus by virion morphology, host range, serology and/or mode of transmission.
Banana bunchy top virus in Colocasia (Ram and Summanwar, 1984) and tobacco
necrosis virus in Dieffenbachia (Paludan and Begtrup, 1982) can be similarly
distinguished. (187) Abo El-Nil, M.M. and Zettler, F.W. (1976). Pl. Dis. Reptr
60: 281. Abo El-Nil, M.M., Zettler, F.W. and Hiebert, E. (1977).
Phytopathology 67: 1445. Alconero, R. (1972). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 320.
Alconero, R. and Zettler, F.W. (1971). Pl. Dis. Reptr 55: 506. Chase, A.R. and
Zettler, F.W. (1982). Plant Dis. 66: 891. Christie, R.G. and Edwardson, J.R.
(1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 9, p. 150. Debrot, E.A. and

E. (1980). Virology 101: 466. Gollifer, D.E., Jackson, G.V.H., Dabek, A.J.,

Datura Colombian potyvirus

      (1) R.P. Kahn, 1987. (2) Synonyms: Colombian datura virus. (3) Standard
acronym: CDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.019. (8) First reported in Datura
sanguinea, Datura candida. (9) From Datura cuttings imported from the Sibundoy
Valley, Putumato, Colombia. (10) By Kahn and Bartels (1968). (11) Symptoms
persist, or disappear soon after infection. (13) Datura candida, D. sanguinea
veinbanding, chlorotic flecking followed by mottling. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (39) Spreads in Colombia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Datura metel wilting and death. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Virginia chlorotic and
necrotic spots. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun chlorotic or necrotic spots,
veinal necrosis. Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum `A-6' necrotic spots. Datura
stramonium chlorotic spots, occasionally. Gomphrena globosa var. rubra red
bordered local lesions. (44) Capsicum annuum. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Samsun. (46) Datura metel (W); Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun (W). (47) Datura
candida, or Datura metel, or Datura sanguinea, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Gomphrena globosa var. rubra, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum. (48) Capsicum annuum. (50) Amaranthaceae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <6/7>. (51) Solanaceae <1/7>. (53) Kahn and Bartels
(1968). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 6 days <or more at 20-25°C in crude
sap>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Kahn and Bartels (1968). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of <±28> 721 nm. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: henbane
mosaic and tobacco etch viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: potato A and Y viruses. (187) Kahn, R.P. and Bartels, R. (1968).
Phytopathology 58: 587.


Datura distortion mosaic potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: DDMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.T.026. (8) First reported in Datura metel. (9) From
Maharashtra State, India. (10) By Mali et al. (1985). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Datura metel, D. alba mosaic and blistering of leaves, small fruits, no
spines, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, A. nerii, Dactynotus
sonchi, Myzus persicae, but not Melanaphis sacchari. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Mali et al. (1985); Game (1988). (39) Spreads in
India <Maharashtra State>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Datura
ferox systemic vein clearing, mosaic, leaf malformation and shoe-stringing.
Datura metel veinal necrosis, then systemic mosaic and malformation. D.
stramonium systemic veinal chlorosis. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic local
lesions, then systemic vein clearing, epinasty and leaf malformation. N.
glutinosa, N. sylvestris chlorotic local lesions, then systemic mosaic and
leaf malformation. N. megalosiphon chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottle.
N. tabacum cv. White Burley systemic mottle. N. tabacum cv. Xanthi, Solanum
nigrum systemic mosaic, blistering. Petunia × hybrida, Physalis floridana
systemic vein clearing and mosaic. (44) Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana
rustica, N. tabacum cv. Samsun, Solanum melongena, S. tuberosum, Capsicum
pendulum, Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. murale. (45)
Datura metel, Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. tabacum cv. Xanthi. (46) Datura metel
(W), Nicotiana glutinosa (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Datura alba, or Datura
ferox, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia axillaris, or Petunia
violacea, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis minima, or
Solanum nigrum. (48) Amaranthus tricolor, or Arachis hypogaea, or Bidens
pilosa, or Canavalia ensiformis, or Capsicum pendulum, or Carica papaya, or
Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer
arietinum, or Commelina benghalensis, or Crotalaria juncea, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Luffa acutangula, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Solanum
xanthocarpum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Solanaceae <17/22>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caricaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Commelinaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/9>, or Solanaceae <7 /22>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Mali et al. (1985); Game (1988). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 4
days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Mali et al. (1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of <±11> 770 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial
canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (174) Inclusions <cytoplasmic
cylindrical> present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and
unusual in shape. (176) Scrolls and long straight laminated aggregates. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: henbane mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: potato A, potato Y, bean common mosaic, bean
yellow mosaic, peanut mottle and soybean mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: The virus is a potyvirus and hence distinct from tobacco mosaic
(TMV) (Hotin and Procenko, 1973), potato virus M (PVM) (Habib, 1982), cucumber
mosaic (CMV) (Suteri and Bala, 1982) and tobacco streak (TSV) (Blakeslee,
1921; Edwardson and Purcifull, 1974). Datura species are known to be infected
at least by ten potyviruses such as CDV (Kahn and Bartels, 1968), DNV (Badami
and Kassanis, 1959), DMV (Quereshi and Mahmood, 1968), datura 437 virus
(Damsteegt, 1974), DSV (Giri and Agrawal, 1971), HMV (Bradley, 1952; Lovisolo
and Bartels, 1970), HDMV (Peralta et al., 1981), PMeV (Nelson and Wheeler,
1974), PVY (Blaszczak, 1976; Rao and Yaraguntaiah, 1976) and TEV (Chester,
1937; Klesser, 1966; Zitter, 1971). DDMV differs from DMV, DNV and DSV in
aphid transmissibility. Although DDMV is serologically related to HMV, it
differs in forming type-III CCI inclusions (HMV induces type-II CCI
inclusions), in virion size and host range. HMV has longer virions (800900 nm)
and causes more severe symptoms in Datura stramonium than DDMV. In CCI
morphology, DDMV is also distinct from CDV, HDMV, datura 437 virus, PMeV, PVY
and TEV (Edwardson et al., 1984). DDMV differs from all ten potyviruses in
host range and symptoms. It differs from DSV, PMeV and PVY, in infecting
Datura stramonium and from HMV, TEV, DMV and HDMV in its mild symptoms in
Datura stramonium. It differs from HMV, TEV and PVY, DDMV in not infecting
Chenopodium amaranticolor and Chenopodium quinoa, and is distinct from PMeV in
infecting Datura metel and from HDMV in not infecting Nicotiana rustica and N.
tabacum cv. Samsun. Therefore, DDMV is considered to be a distinct member of
the potyvirus group (Mali, 1985) and in subdivision III of Edwardson (1974).
Few comparisons have been made between DDMV and other similar viruses reported
from India (Capoor and Varma, 1948, 1951; Garga, 1958; Verma and Verma, 1963).
(187) Badami, R.S. and Kassanis, B. (1959). Ann. appl. Biol. 47: 90.
Blakeslee, A.F. (1921). J. Genet. 11: 17. Blaszczak, W. (1976). Rezn. nauk.
roln. seria. E.T. 6, Z 2: 69. Bradley, R.H.E. (1952). Ann. appl. Biol. 39: 78.
Capoor, S.P. and Varma, P.M. (1948). Curr. Sci. 17: 151. Capoor, S.P. and
Varma, P.M. (1951). Indian J. agric. Sci. 22: 303. Chester, K.S. (1937).

50. Edwardson, J.R. (1974). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 4, p. 398.

93: 113. Rao, R.D.V.J.P. and Yaraguntaiah, R.C. (1976). Curr. Sci. 49: 467.
Suteri, B.D. and Bala, S. (1982). Sci. Cult. 48: 384. Varma, G.S. and Verma,
H.N. (1963). Indian Phytopath. 16: 366. Yaraguntaiah, R.C. and Govindu, H.C.
(1972). Mysore J. Agric. Sci. 6: 352. Zitter, T.A. (1973). Pl. Dis. Reptr 57:
991.


Datura innoxia Hungarian mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HDIV. (5) ICTV decimal code

symptoms. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
Hungary <Budapest>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Datura innoxia,
D. stramonium, Petunia × hybrida, Physalis floridana, Nicotiana tabacum
chlorosis of systemically infected leaves which is especially conspicuous in
D. innoxia. (44) Capsicum annuum, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus,
Gomphrena globosa, Solanum melongena. (45) Datura innoxia. (46) Datura innoxia
(W). (47) Datura innoxia, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or

(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)

Datura mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: DTMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.027. (8) First reported in Datura metel. (9) From Aligarh, India.
(10) By Quereshi and Mahmood (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Datura metel
mosaic, blistering and shoe-stringing. (15) Some species of aphid have been
tested and found not to be vectors. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Quereshi and Mahmood (1978). (39) Spreads in India. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Datura innoxia, D. metel necrotic local lesions,
mosaic, blistering, reduced fruits, no spines. D. stramonium necrotic local
lesions, flowering checked, systemic mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa mosaic, leaf
malformation and stunting. N. tabacum mosaic, leaf malformation, flowering
checked. Petunia × hybrida mosaic, leaf reduction and malformation, stunting.
(44) Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum luteum, S. melongena,
S. tuberosum, Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. ambrosioides, C. murale.
(45) Datura metel. (46) Datura metel (L). (47) Datura innoxia, or Datura
metel, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis peruviana,
or Solanum nigrum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Dahlia pinnata, or
Daucus carota, or Dianthus barbatus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Helianthus annuus, or Lablab purpureus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus
sativus, or Solanum luteum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Solanaceae <9/13>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Compositae <5/5>, or
Cruciferae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>,
or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1 /1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <5/13>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Quereshi and Mahmood (1978). (54) TIP: 45-50 °C. (55)
LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (60) Method: Quereshi and Mahmood
(1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 712
nm. (71) Virions 11-13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (179)
<Probably> Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: tobacco etch virus. (184) Datura mosaic virus
is a potyvirus, but its relationships with others are uncertain (Hollings and
Brunt, 1981). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Datura shoestring virus (DSV)
differs from DMV in its failure to infect Datura stramonium, D. innoxia and
Solanum nigrum. Datura distortion mosaic virus (DDMV) differs from DMV in its
failure to induce local lesions in Datura species and in being transmissible
by aphids. Datura species are known to be naturally infected by other
potyviruses such as datura necrosis virus (DNV) (Badami and Kassanis, 1959),
datura Colombian virus (DCV) (Kahn and Bartels, 1968), datura shoestring virus
(DSV) (Giri and Agrawal, 1971) and datura distortion mosaic virus (DDMV) (Mali
et al., 1985). However, they differ in various properties; DNV infects
Lycopersicon esculentum, which is insusceptible to DMV; DCV incites few or no
symptoms in Datura stramonium, D. metel and Nicotiana tabacum var. Samsun, is
transmitted by Myzus persicae, and has a greater LIV; DMV incites severe
symptoms in Datura species, is not transmitted by aphids and has a short LIV;
DMV, unlike DSV, induces local lesions in Datura species; DSV, unlike DMV,
induces lesions in Nicotiana rustica and does not infect Datura stramonium, D.
innoxia and Solanum nigrum. DDMV differs from DMV in being aphid transmitted
and able to infect Capsicum annuum but not cause local lesions in Datura
species (Mali, 1985). The virion morphology of other Indian viruses infecting
Datura (Capoor and Verma, 1948; 1951; Garga, 1958; Verma and Verma, 1963;
Yaraguntaiah and Govindu, 1973) is not known. (187) Badami, R.S. and Kassanis,
B. (1959). Ann. appl. Biol. 47: 90. Capoor, S.P. and Varma, P.M. (1948). Curr.
Sci. 17: 151. Capoor, S.P. and Varma, P.M. (1951). Indian J. agric. Sci. 22:
303. Garga, R.P. (1958). Indian Phytopath. 11: 133. Giri, L. and Agrawal, H.O.
(1971). Phytopath. Z. 70: 81. Hollings, M. and Brunt, A.A. (1981). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 245, 7 pp. Kahn, R.P. and Bartels, R. (1962).
Phytopathology 48: 587. Mali, V.R. (1985). Int. J. Trop. Pl. Dis. 3: 93. Mali,
V.R., Nirmal, D.D., Patel, K.V. and Vyanjane, N.T. (1985). Indian Phytopath.
38: 413. Quereshi, S. and Mahmood, K. (1978). Phytopath. Z. 93: 113. Verma,
G.S. and Verma, H.N. (1963). Indian Phytopath. 16: 366. Yaraguntaiah, R.C. and
Govindu, H.C. (1972). Mysore J. Agric. Sci. 6: 352.


Datura necrosis potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and A. Varma, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: DNV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.T.028. (8) First reported in Solanum jasminoides. (9) From
England from plants imported from India. (10) By Badami and Kassanis (1959).
(13) Solanum jasminoides symptoms unknown all the naturally infected plants
examined also contained potato Y and tobacco wilt viruses. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum vein banding and mosaic.
Nicotiana glutinosa mottling. Datura tatula local lesions and necrosis.
Solanum jasminoides mottling. (44) Solanum tuberosum, Cucumis sativus,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Gomphrena globosa. (45) Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa.
(46) Nicotiana tabacum (W), N. glutinosa (W). (47) Datura tatula, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum jasminoides. (48) Cucumis
sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum tuberosum.
(50) Solanaceae <7/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (54) TIP: 60-65 °C.
(55) LIV: 8-12 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: potato Y and tobacco wilt viruses. (187) Badami, R.S. and Kassanis,
B. (1959). Ann. appl. Biol. 47: 90.


Datura shoestring potyvirus

      (1) M. Weintraub, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: DSTV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.024. (8) First reported in Solanum jasminoides. (9) From Simla,
India. (10) By Giri and Agrawal (1971). (13) Solanum jasminoides mottling and
leaf malformation. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in India. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Datura metel and
Nicotiana glutinosa systemic mosaic, leaf blistering. N. rustica necrotic
local lesions, then vein and stem necrosis, mottling, necrosis and plant
death. N. tabacum cv. White Burley necrotic-chlorotic local lesions, then vein
necrosis and plant death. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium,
D. tatula, Solanum demissum, Physalis floridana. (45) Datura metel, Nicotiana
glutinosa. (46) Datura metel (W), Nicotiana glutinosa (W), N. rustica (W), N.
tabacum cv. White Burley (L, W). (47) Datura metel, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum jasminoides. (48)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum nigrum, or
Solanum nodiflorum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata.
(50) Solanaceae <5/15>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae
<10/15>. (53) Giri and Agrawal (1971). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: 2% PTA-Na, pH 7. (60) Method: Brunt and Stace-Smith (1973). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 720-750 nm.
(71) Virions 16 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix <usually>
obscure <but sometimes visible in thin sections>. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 143 S. (79)
Density 1.33 g cm3 in CsCl. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 36600
<degrades to 27400>. (145) Method of preparation: Agrawal and Tremaine (1972).
(171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in
the cytoplasm, amorphous Xbodies, pinwheels, and unusual in shape. (176)
Tubules in the nucleus. (177) They do not contain virions <although long
helical structures are found near virus aggregates>. (178) Other cellular
changes: drastic reduction of leaf lamina. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180)
: Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: pepper
veinal mottle virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
potato virus Y. (187) Agrawal, H.O. and Tremaine, J.H. (1972). unpublished
data. Brunt, A.A. and Stace-Smith, R. (1973). unpublished data. Giri, L. and
Agrawal, H.O. (1971). Phytopath. Z. 70: 81. Pushkarnath, M.J. (1952). Curr.
Sci. 21: 249. Weintraub, M., Agrawal, H.O. and Ragetli, H.W.J. (1973). Can. J.
Bot. 51: 855.


Datura yellow vein nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) J.E. Thomas, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: DYVV. (4) Strains:
Thunbergia rhabdovirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.0.002. (8) First reported
in Datura stramonium. (9) From south-east Queensland, Australia. (10) By
Thomas and Behncken (1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms vein
yellowing and leaf malformation. (13) Datura stramonium vein yellowing, leaf
and flower bud malformation. Thunbergia alata vein clearing and yellowing,
leaf malformation. Lycopersicon esculentum vein clearing and chlorosis,
mottling and leaf malformation. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae,
Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Aphis gossypii, Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani,
Orosius argentatus, Austroasca alfalfae, Henosepilachna sp. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein yellowing.
(43) Datura stramonium vein yellowing, leaf and flower bud malformation.
Thunbergia alata vein yellowing and leaf malformation. Lycopersicon esculentum
vein clearing and leaf malformation. Solanum melongena vein etching. Nicotiana
glutinosa vein yellowing. Nicotiana tabacum symptomless. (44) Capsicum annuum,
Petunia × hybrida, Nicotiana rustica, N. physalodes, Solanum tuberosum cv.
Sebago. (45) Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum. (46) Datura
stramonium (W). (47) Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum melongena, or Thunbergia
alata. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana physalodes,
or Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum tuberosum. (50)
Solanaceae <5/11>, or Thunbergiaceae <1/1>. (51) Solanaceae <6/11>. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Thomas and Dietzgen (1991). (61)
Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 166 nm. (71)
Virions 77 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obscure. (132) Virion protein(s) four.
(133) Mr <of the largest> 78000. (134) G protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
47000. (136) N protein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 41000. (138) M1 protein. (139)
Mr of 4th largest 36000. (140) M2 protein. (145) Method of preparation: Thomas
and Dietzgen (1991). (148) Virion proteins glycosylated. (149) Are the G
protein is glycosylated and binds to concanavalin A (lectin). (171) Virions
found in leaves. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear space. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae.
(180) : Rhabdoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
sonchus yellow net virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated

maize sterile stunt, cereal chlorotic mottle, digitaria striate, festuca leaf
streak, lettuce necrotic yellows, northern cereal mosaic, maize mosaic and
barley yellow striate mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: virion
shape in negatively stained sap, characteristic symptoms in Datura stramonium,
detection of viral protein from crude sap in Western immunoblots and gel
diffusion serology. (187) Dietzgen, R.G. and Thomas, J.E. (1990). Abstr. 8th
Int. Congr. Virol., Berlin. p. 444. Thomas, J.E. and Behncken, G.M. (1983).
Abstr. 4th Int. Congr. Pl. Path., Melbourne. p. 123. Thomas, J.E. and
Dietzgen, R.G. (1991). Ann. appl. Biol. 118: 339.

Dendrobium vein necrosis (?) closterovirus

      (1) D.E. Lesemann, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: DVNV. (5) ICTV decimal

Germany. (10) By Lesemann (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dendrobium
phalaenopsis vein necrosis in leaves, petals and sepals. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in Germany, but only in two glasshouses. (47)
Dendrobium phalaenopsis. (50) Orchidaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: mount sap in 2% PTA, pH 7. (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)

flowers. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Are bundles of
virions. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: peripheral
vesiculation of mitochondria. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus. (187) Lesemann,
D.-E. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 89: 330.

Digitaria streak monogeminivirus

      (1) P.G. Markham, P.M. Mullineaux, G.P. Accotto, 1991. (3) Standard
acronym: DSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in
Digitaria setigera (syn. D. sanguinalis). (9) From Vanuatu. (10) By Dollet et
al. (1986). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms white or chlorotic streaks or
local lesions. (13) Digitaria setigera narrow white streaks or local lesions,
usually 13 mm long. Longer wider chlorotic often yellow local lesions with
diffuse margins. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Nesoclutha declivata. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae.
(24) Not transmitted by Cicadulina mbila, C. triangula, C. chinai, C.
bipunctella, Nesoclutha pallida. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (27)
Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally
to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Vanuatu. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
narrow, short, white or chlorotic streaks or local lesions with some showing
diffuse edges to local lesions, but most local lesions clearly defined. (43)
Avena sativa, Digitaria setigera, Hordeum vulgare, Zea mays chlorotic streaks
and local lesions, severe deformation of plant. (44) Nicotiana tabacum. (45)
Digitaria setigera. (46) Digitaria setigera (W). (47) Avena sativa, or
Digitaria setigera, or Hordeum vulgare, or Zea mays. (48) Nicotiana tabacum.
(50) Gramineae <4/4>. (51) Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Dollet et al. (1986); Donson
et al. (1988); Pinner and Markham (1990); Creissen et al. (1990). (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM for negative
staining. (60) Method: resuspend virus in 0.01M sodium acetate buffer pH 4.5,
purify through sucrose cushion (30%). (61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 30 nm in length. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.1. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91)
Total genome size 2.701 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 2.701 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Dollet et al.
(1986). (100) Base composition 25.8 % G. (101) Base composition 25.5 % A.
(102) Base composition 23.9 % C. (104) Base composition 24.8 % T. (114) Genome
has no tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Donson et al.
(1987). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10837. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
M23022 Gb(84)_vi:DIGGENOME Digitaria streak virus, complete genome. 3/92
2,701bp. 1 sequence. (119) Features of the genome: 4 ORFs; V1, V2 (coat
protein), C1 and C2. Core promoter sequences located at coordinates 2671
(virion sense) and 2496 (complementary sense). Main stem loop structure in
intergenic region (coordinates 25422581). Polyadenylation sequences at 1064
(virions strand) and 1084 (complementary strand). Transcripts; 2 abundant
virion-sense transcripts (1+, 2+). 1+ 5' end at 27003' end at c. 1060. 2+ 5'
end at 1703' end at c. 1060. 1+ may direct V1 translation, 2+ may direct V2
translation. Rare transcripts on complementary sense. 3 transcripts (1-, 2-
and 4-). 4- is spliced between coordinates 1759 and 1666. Intron sequences
typical for plant leads to fusion of C1:C2 ORF's which synthesise 41kDa
protein. 2- unspliced equivalent would synthesise, C1 product only (30.5kDa).
5' ends 1 2650, 2 2467 and 2476 (2 ends), 4 2467 and 2476 (2 ends). 3' ends
for all transcripts; major end at 1063, minor end at 1067. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
26600. (134) It is ORF V2 and functions as coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Dollet et al. (1986). (146) Amino acid sequence: Donson et al.
(1987). (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (171) Virions found in leaves,
mesophyll, meristems and probably the roots. (172) Virions found in nuclei and
in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are crystals in the nucleus and unusual in shape. (176) Typically in the
formation of large irregular sheets of virions regularly arranged in rows.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: maize
streak, panicum streak and sugarcane streak viruses (Pinner and Markham,
1988). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: chloris striate
mosaic and paspalum striate mosaic viruses. (184) There is 74% homology
between the coat proteins of maize streak and digitaria streak viruses. (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: vector specific transmission; indirect ELISA test on
sap from infected plants, followed by dot-blot nucleic acid hybridization.
(187) Accotto, G.P., Donson, J. and Mullineaux, P.M. (1989). EMBO J. 8: 1033.
Dollet, M., Accotto, G.P., Lisa, V., Menissier, J. and Boccardo, G. (1986). J.
gen. Virol. 67: 933. Donson, J., Accotto, G.P., Boulton, M.I., Mullineaux,
P.M. and Davies, J.W. (1987). Virology 161: 160. Donson, J., Gunn, H.V.,
Woolston, C.J., Pinner, M.S., Boulton, M.I., Mullineaux, P.M. and Davies, J.W.
(1988). Virology 162; 248. Julia, J.F. and Dollet, M. (1989). J. Phytopath.
127: 42. Mullineaux, P.M., Guerineau, F. and Accotto, G.P. (1990). Nucl. Acids
Res. 18: 7259. Pinner, M.S. and Markham, P.G. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 1635.

G-protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions

cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) <Possible>
Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: barley yellow striate mosaic and maize sterile
stunt viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: American
wheat striate mosaic, cereal chlorotic mottle, cynodon rhabdovirus, festuca
rhabdovirus, lettuce necrotic yellows and maize mosaic viruses. (187) Greber,
R.S. (1972). Aust. Pl. Path. Soc. Newsl. 1: 27. Greber, R.S. (1976). Aust. Pl.
Path. Soc. Newsl. 5: 228. Greber, R.S. (1979). Aust. J. agric. Res. 30: 43.
Greber, R.S. (1984). In: Current Topics in Vector Research, Vol. 2, p. 141;

Diodia vein chlorosis (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: DVCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.T.3.04. (8) First reported in Diodia virginiana. (9) From the U.S.A.
(Arkansas). (10) By Larsen et al. (1991). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Diodia
virginiana chlorotic vein-banding and general chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Trialeurodes
abutilonea. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in
the USA <Arkansas>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Diodia virginiana
chlorotic vein-banding. (45) Diodia virginiana. (46) Diodia virginiana (W).
(47) Diodia virginiana. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura
stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Spinacia oleracea. (50) Rubiaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <2/2>. (53) Larsen et al. (1991). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no
clear modal length. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (125) 3 virus specified dsRNA
species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA
4.6 kbp. (127) 2nd largest 4.3 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 1.9 kbp. (171) Virions
found in leaves and vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(178) Other cellular changes: the presence of virions in phloem parenchyma and
sieve elements; virions are associated with membranous vesicles containing
fibrils. Cytoplasm also contains greatly proliferated tubular membranes and
vacuoles have double membrane-bound bodies. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet yellows and lettuce
infectious yellows viruses. (186) A virus with similar virions and
transmissible by Trialeurodes abutilonea occurs in Diodia maritima in
California, U.S.A. (Duffus et al., 1986). Its possible relationship to diodia
vein chlorosis virus has yet to be determined. (187) Duffus, J.E., Larsen,
R.C. and Lui, H.Y. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 97. Larsen, R.C., Kim, K.S. and
Scott, H.A. (1991). Phytopathology 81: 227.

      (1) A. Porth and F. Nienhaus, 1986. (4) Strains: Nigerian yam virus. (5)

From Togo. (10) By Reckhaus (1979, 1980); Reckhaus and Nienhaus (1981). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Dioscorea rotundata chlorotic flecks, greenbanding, and

insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis faba and Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the African region <in the west>.
(39) Spreads in Nigeria and Togo. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic ringspots. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana.
(47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Dioscorea rotundata,

Dioscoreaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/5>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or

filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)

PTANa>, or 769 nm <when stained with UA>. (71) Virions 13-14 nm wide. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient

nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total

Method of preparation: Laemmli and Favre (1973). (171) Virions found in
epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) And
laminated aggregates. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: aggregated mitochondria, deformed chloroplasts and tubular bundles
containing virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: yam mosaic virus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet mosaic and dioscorea
alata ring mottle potyviruses. (187) Hull, R. and Lane, L.C. (1973). Virology

Dioscorea latent (?) potexvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, A.A. Brunt, 1985 and F. Nienhaus, 1987. (3) Standard

Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Dioscoreaceae <1/4>, or Gramineae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2 /4>, or Solanaceae <5/11>. (52) Virus
symptomless in Nicotiana plumbaginifolia and Dioscorea bulbifera, but does not
infect D. alata. (53) Phillips et al. (1986). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C <in Nicotiana
megalosiphon sap>. (55) LIV: 365 days <or more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6 <in
Nicotiana megalosiphon sap>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:

Dioscorea trifida (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: probably dock mosaic virus (Grainger
and Cockerham, 1930); dock mosaic viruses reported in the U.S.A. (Fernow,

DMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.033. (8) First reported in Rumex spp. (9)
From Hungary. (10) By JureticH et al. (1976). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Rumex spp. chlorotic mottling of leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)

conglomeratus, R. obtusifolius, R. patientia, R. pulcher leaf mosaic. (44)

Rumex obtusifolius. (47) Rumex, or Rumex conglomeratus, or Rumex obtusifolius,
or Rumex patientia, or Rumex pulcher. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50)
Polygonaceae <5/5>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (54) TIP:
60 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)

Dodonaea yellows-associated virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.17. (8) First
reported in Dodonaea viscosa. (9) From Hawaii. (10) By Gardner and Kageler
(1984). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dodonaea viscosa pendulous `witches
brooms' formed of abnormally long proliferated branches, the leaves on which
are small and chlorotic. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(39) Spreads in the USA <Hawaii>. (47) Dodonaea viscosa. (50) Sapindaceae
<1/1>. (60) Method: Borth et al. (1990). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 700 nm. (71) Virions 16 nm wide. (125) 1
virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest
virus specified dsRNA 3 kbp. (179) (Ungrouped). (186) The symptoms in Dodonaea
viscosa resemble those induced by mycoplasma-like organisms (MLO) in other
hosts. Although no MLO were detected in affected plants, further work is
necessary to elucidate the etiology of the disease. (187) Borth, W.B.,
Gardener, D.E. and German, T.L. (1990). Plant Dis. 74: 434. Gardener, D.E. and
Kageler, V.A.D. (1984). Hawaii Bot. Soc. Newsl. 23: 7.


Dogwood mosaic (?) nepovirus

      (1) O.W. Barnett, 1991. (2) Synonyms: arabis mosaic virus (first
considered to be a strain of this virus, but now thought to be a separate
viral species; Barnett, 1981; Barnett and Baxter, 1976; Handley and Barnett,
1951; Reddick et al., 1980). (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Cornus florida. (9) From Clemson, South Carolina, U.S.A. (10) By
Barnett and Baxter (1976). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms
mosaic. (13) Cornus florida symptomless or mottling or mosaic. (24) Not
transmitted by Xiphinema diversicaudatum. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by
Barnett et al. (1989). (39) Spreads in the USA <South Carolina>. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
mosaic and/or ringspots. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local
lesions, then systemic chlorotic spots, line patterns, mosaic. C. quinoa
chlorotic local lesions becoming necrotic, then systemic mosaic and tip
necrosis. Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata, Lupinus albus chlorotic
ringspots and systemic mosaic. Pisum sativum chlorotic local lesions, then
systemic mosaic. Torenia fournieri systemic chlorosis and veinal necrosis.
Nicotiana occidentalis local lesions; systemic mosaic. N. tabacum chlorotic
local lesions, then systemic in some cultivars. Petunia × hybrida necrotic
ringspots; systemic necrotic spots. Lactuca sativa systemic mosaic. (44)
Arabis alpina, Fragaria vesca, Phaseolus lunatus, Zinnia elegans, Citrullus
lanatus var. lanatus. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. benthamiana, Chenopodium
quinoa, Gomphrena globosa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L or W), Nicotiana
clevelandii (W). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris,
or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Celosia cristata, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium botrys, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cornus florida, or Cucumis
sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab
purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus hirsutus, or
Lupinus luteus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana longiflora, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana palmeri, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis alkekengi, or Pisum sativum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or
Trifolium pratense, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Anthriscus cerefolium, or Apium
graveolens, or Arabis alpina, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica nigra, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium album, or Citrullus
lanatus, or Citrullus lanatus var. lanatus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Desmodium
tortuosum, or Fragaria vesca, or Ipomoea sloteri, or Lagenaria siceraria, or
Medicago lupulina, or Medicago sativa, or Mirabilis jalapa, or Momordica
balsamina, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pueraria lobata, or
Trifolium pratense, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>,
or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/9>, or Compositae <3/3>, or
Cornaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<12/17>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <2 /2>, or Solanaceae
<13/14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/9>, or Compositae
<1/3>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/6>,
or Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/17>, or Nyctaginaceae
<1/1>, or Rosaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <1/14>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (54)
TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (60) Method: Barnett et
al. (1989). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 125 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 54 S <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.63 <B>, or 1.5 <M>,
or 0.88 <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 12.1 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 8.2 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.9 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Barnett et al. (1989). (112) Additional
factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found
in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 54100. (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and roots.
(179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: arabis mosaic and grapevine fanleaf viruses.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: artichoke Italian
latent, cherry leaf roll, grapevine chrome mosaic, raspberry ringspot,
strawberry latent ringspot, tobacco ringspot and tomato ringspot viruses.
(184) Dogwood mosaic virus is serologically more distant from arabis mosaic
virus than is grapevine fanleaf virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
cucumber mosaic and broad bean wilt viruses are found in Cornus florida in the
USA with the virus. It, unlike cucumber mosaic virus, infects cowpea
systemically and, unlike broad bean wilt, induces local lesions in cucumber.
Serological tests are best for diagnosis. (187) Barnett, O.W. (1981). Abstr.
5th Int. Congr. Virol., Strasbourg, France. Barnett, O.W. and Baxter, L.W.
(1976). Proc. Am. Phytopathol. Soc. 3: 249. Barnett, O.W., Reddick, B.B.,
Burrows, P.M. and Baxter, L.W. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 951. Handley, M.K.
and Barnett, O.W. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 223. Reddick, B.B., Barnett, O.W.
and Baxter, L.W. (1979). Pl. Dis. Reptr 63: 529. Reddick, B.B., Barnett, O.W.
and Baxter, L.W. (1980). Ornamentals South 2: 4.


Dolichos yellow mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) V. Muniyappa, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: DoYMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.0.015. (8) First reported in Lablab purpureus (syn. Dolichos

Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms yellow or green mosaic with pitting. (13)
Lablab purpureus yellow mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by
Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus

transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.

Lablab purpureus. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (61) Virions
geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65)

Dulcamara mottle tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: DuMV. (5) ICTV decimal code

tuberosum several cultivars. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa. (46)

Echinochloa ragged stunt oryzavirus

      (1) C.C. Chen, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ERSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
60.0.9.0.002. (8) First reported in Echinochloa crus-galli var. oryzicola. (9)
From Taiwan. (10) By Chen et al. (1980). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
severe stunting, darker green leaves, serrated margins and veinal swellings.
(13) Echinochloa crus-galli var. oryzicola, Setaria italica, Triticum aestivum
tillering, severe dwarfing, malformation of leaves with serrated margins and
veinal swellings. Plants appear greener and fail to head, or show a delay in
heading time leading to empty grains. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Sogatella vibix, S.
longifurcifera. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (24) Not transmitted by
Nephotettix cincticeps, N. nigropictus, Nilaparvata lugens, Laodelphax
striatellus, Sogatella furcifera, Recilia dorsalis. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus
multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the
progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Taiwan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show severe dwarfing, leaf malformation,
ragged leaf, vein-swelling on abaxial surface of leaf sheaths, and a dark
green plant colour. (43) Alopecurus aequalis, Echinochloa crus-galli var.
formosensis, Eleusine coracana, Lolium multiflorum, Oryza sativa, Setaria
italica, Triticum aestivum excessive tillering, dwarfing and production of
malformed leaves with serrated margins and veinal swellings. Leaves darker
green. Imperata cylindrica var. major leaf yellowing and small vein swellings.
Zea mays milder symptoms and recovery after 23 weeks. (44) Cynodon dactylon,
Eleusine indica, Hordeum vulgare, Leersia hexandra, Sorghum bicolor. (45)
Echinochloa crus-galli, Lolium multiflorum, Setaria italica. (46) Alopecurus
aequalis (W), Echinochloa crus-galli (W), Eleusine coracana (W), Lolium
multiflorum (W), Setaria italica (W). (47) Alopecurus aequalis, or Echinochloa
crus-galli, or Echinochloa crus-galli var. formosensis, or Echinochloa
crus-galli var. oryzicola, or Eleusine coracana, or Imperata cylindrica, or
Imperata cylindrica var. major, or Lolium multiflorum, or Oryza sativa, or
Setaria italica, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Cynodon dactylon, or
Echinochloa colona, or Eleusine indica, or Hordeum vulgare, or Leersia
hexandra, or Sorghum bicolor. (50) Gramineae <12/18>. (51) Gramineae <6/18>.
(53) Chen et al. (1986). (54) TIP: 70-80 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix
with glutaraldehyde. (60) Method: Chen et al. (1988). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 80 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio
1.8. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 26.64 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of 10 parts <named S110>. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.85 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd
largest 3.82 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd largest 3.8 kb <pairs>. (96) The 4th
largest 3.7 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th largest 2.7 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th
largest and other parts 2.6 kb <pairs; also 1.95, 1.85, 1.20 and 1.17 kb
pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Chen et al. (1989). (132) Virion
protein(s) six <4 major, 2 minor>. (133) Mr <of the largest> 127000 <major>.
(135) Mr of 2nd largest 123000 <major>. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 103000

<minor>. (143) Mr of 6th largest and smaller, 34000 <major>. (145) Method of
preparation: Chen et al. (1989). (171) Virions found in leaves and phloem.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Oryzavirus: Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA. (187) Chen, C.C. (1985). Ph.D. Thesis,
150 pp. Grad. Inst. Pl. Path., Nat. Chung-Hsing Univ. Chen, C.C., Chen, M.J.
and Chiu, R.J. (1986). Pl. Prot. Bull. (Taiwan) 28: 371. Chen, C.C., Chen,
M.J., Chiu, R.J. and Hsu, H.T. (1989). Phytopathology 79 ;235. Chen, C.C.,

Intervirology 30: 278. Chen, C.C., Hsu, Y.H., Liu, M.C., Chen, M.J. and Chiu,
R.J. (1988). Pl. Prot. Bull. (Taiwan) 30: 420.


Eggplant green mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, D.E. Lesemann and R. Koenig, 1988. (3) Standard acronym:
EGMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.034. (8) First reported in Solanum
melongena. (9) From southern Nigeria. (10) By Ladipo (1976). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Solanum melongena green mosaic. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Nigeria. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Lycopersicon esculentum mild systemic chlorosis. Nicandra
physalodes necrotic local lesions, then systemic chlorosis and necrotic
spotting. Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. occidentalis, N. rustica, N. sylvestris
necrotic local lesions, then systemic necrotic spotting and veinal necrosis.
N. tabacum cvs White Burley, Xanthi-nc systemic chlorotic spotting and vein
necrosis. N. glutinosa systemic vein clearing and mottling. Petunia × hybrida
chlorotic local lesions, then systemic veinal chlorosis and necrosis. Physalis
peruviana chlorotic rings and lesions, systemic mottling. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena globosa, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana
megalosiphon (L), N. sylvestris (L), N. occidentalis (L), N. rustica (L). (47)
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis
floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum.
(48) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica. (50) Solanaceae <16/19>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/19>. (53) Ladipo (1976);
Ladipo et al. (1988). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days <at 2528°C>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Ladipo et al.
(1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 820
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in
leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: masses of endoplasmic reticulum, microbodies,
lipid droplets, mitochondria and abnormal vesicles in cytoplasm. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: dioscorea green-banding, groundnut eyespot,
zucchini yellow mosaic and an unnamed potyvirus from tomato in Taiwan. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: datura Colombian, henbane
mosaic, pepper mottle, pepper veinal mottle, tomato (Peru), potato A, potato
Y, tobacco etch and wild potato mosaic viruses. (187) Ladipo, J.L. (1976). Pl.
Dis. Reptr 60: 1068. Ladipo, J.L., Lesemann, D.E. and Koenig, R. (1988). J.
Phytopath. 121: 159.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: EMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.T.1.016. (8) First reported in Solanum melongena. (9) From Al-Sharja.
(10) By Khalil and Nelson (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mild
leaf mottling. (13) Solanum melongena mild leaf mottling. (24) Not transmitted
by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
