Eggplant mosaic tymovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: abelia latent virus
(Waterworth et al., 1975). (3) Standard acronym: EMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
77.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Solanum melongena. (9) From Trinidad, West
Indies. (10) By Ferguson (1951); Dale (1954). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Solanum melongena mosaic. Solanum seaforthianum mottle, veinbanding.
Lycopersicon esculentum mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Epitrix sp. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by Gibbs et al. (1966); Debrot et al. (1977). (39)
Spreads in Trinidad and Tobago. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, then
systemic mottle or mosaic. Cucumis sativus symptomless, local infection only.
Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local lesions, then systemic mottling and,
sometimes, necrosis, stunting. Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, then systemic chlorotic or necrotic lesions or flecks and
malformation. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs The Prince, Bountiful, Stringless
Green Pod and Top Crop. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. hybridum (L), Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye
(L). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis
floridana, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum seaforthianum, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Apium graveolens, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <13/16>. (51) Compositae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or
Solanaceae <3/16>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Dale (1954); Debrot et al.
(1977); Gibbs et al. (1966); Gibbs and Harrison (1969). (54) TIP: 80-90 °C.
(55) LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 7. (60) Method: Gibbs and Harrison
(1973). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement <capsid has 32 subunits>. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 111 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 55 S <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH
9.46. (84) Virions contain 36 % nucleic acid <B>. (85) Virions 64 % protein
<B>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.33 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 6.33 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Bercks et al. (1971). Genome sequence reported by Osorio-Keese et al. (1989).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12151. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): J04374

W.T. (1954). Ann. appl. Biol. 41: 240. Debrot, E.A., Lastra, R. and de
Uzcátegui, R.C. (1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61: 628. Dupin, A., Peter, R., Collot,
D., Das, B.C., Peter, C., Bouillon, P. and Duranton, H. (1984). C.R. hebd.
Séanc. Acad. Sci., Paris, Serie III No. 8: 24. Ferguson, I.A.C. (1951). Pl.
Dis. Reptr 35: 102. Gibbs, A.J. and Harrison, B.D. (1969). Ann. appl. Biol.
64: 225. Gibbs, A.J. and Harrison, B.D. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
124, 4 pp. Gibbs, A.J., Hecht-Poinar, E., Woods, R.D. and McKee, R.K. (1966).
J. gen. Microbiol. 44: 177. Osorio-Keese, M., Keese, P. and Gibbs, A.J.
(1989). Virology 172: 547. Waterworth, H.E., Kaper, J.M. and Koenig, R.
(1975). Phytopathology 65: 891.


Eggplant mottled crinkle tombusvirus

      (1) K.M. Makkouk, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: EMCV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 74.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Solanum melongena. (9) From Jieh,
south of Beirut, Lebanon. (10) By Makkouk et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Solanum melongena mottling and crinkling of leaves. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(39) Spreads in Lebanon. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena globosa,
Nicotiana glutinosa, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful local lesions. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L),
Datura stramonium (L), Gomphrena globosa (L), Nicotiana glutinosa (L),
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana,
or Solanum melongena, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <6/6>. (60) Method: Makkouk et al. (1981). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28-30 nm in diameter. (67)
Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 132 S.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41000. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in chloroplasts <but possibly after
chloroplast membranes disintegrate>. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Multivesicular cytoplasmic
inclusions. (178) Other cellular changes: an increase in the volume of
cytoplasm. (179) Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: pelargonium leaf curl, tomato
bushy stunt (strain BS-3) and petunia asteroid mosaic viruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: host range, as a large number of indicator plants produce
local lesions, and serology. (187) Makkouk, K.M., Koenig, R. and Lesemann,
D.-E. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 572.


Eggplant mottled dwarf nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (2) Synonyms: tomato vein chlorosis virus, tomato
yellow vein virus, tomato vein yellowing virus (Adam et al., 1987; Castellano
and Martelli, 1987; El Maataoui et al., 1985), tomato vein clearing virus. (3)
Standard acronym: EMDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.0.003. (8) First reported
in Solanum melongena. (9) From southern Italy. (10) By Martelli (1969). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum melongena mottling, vein clearing and leaf
malformation. Hibiscus rosa-sinensis vein yellowing and leaf malformation.
Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum nigrum yellow vein banding. Solanum sodomaeum
severe leaf chlorosis. Lonicera sp. yellow vein banding. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by the virus is
widespread in some Mediterranean countries, but its vector is unknown. In
Morocco, Solanum sodomaeum is probably an important perennial source of
infection. (39) Spreads in Algeria, Greece, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Tunisia,
and Turkey <and the Canary Islands>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Solanum melongena, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N.
langsdorffii, N. glutinosa, N. megalosiphon, N. rustica, N. tabacum chlorotic
local lesions, then systemic chlorosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Gomphrena globosa local lesions, not systemic. (44) Lactuca sativa, Datura
stramonium, Physalis floridana, Phaseolus vulgaris, Cucumis sativus. (45)
Solanum melongena, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, N. benthamiana, N.
clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (L), N. glutinosa (L). (47) Capsicum
annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, or Lonicera, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana langsdorffii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana
× edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum
melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum sodomaeum. (48) Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Ocimum basilicum,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <20/21>. (51)
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/21>. (52) The Italian
tomato isolate has a narrower host range than the Italian eggplant and
Moroccan tomato isolates and fails also to infect eggplant (Castellano and
Martelli, 1987). El Maataoui et al. (1985) also report that 32 unnamed
dicotyledonous species are insusceptible. (53) Martelli and Rana (1970); El
Maataoui et al. (1985); Castellano and Martelli (1987). (54) TIP: 54 °C. (55)
LIV: 30-44 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap
decreased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: El Maataoui et al. (1985). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped.
(63) Virions enveloped. (70) Virions of 220-230 nm. (71) Virions 80-90 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 18 nm in diameter. (74) Basic
helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.5 nm. (132) Virion protein(s) five.
(133) Mr <of the largest> 100000 <or more>. (134) L protein. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 81000-86000. (136) G protein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 56000-61000.
(138) N protein. (139) Mr of 4th largest 27000-32000. (140) M1 protein. (141)
Mr of 5th largest 21000-25000. (142) M2 protein. (171) Virions found in
leaves, vascular parenchyma, flowers (except stamens) and pericarp. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm <within membranous cisternae attached to the
nuclear membrane>, or in the perinuclear space. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: nuclei which develop uniformly
granular nucleoplasm and loose chromatin. The chloroplasts and mitochondria
are also altered. (179) Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: potato
yellow dwarf (SYDV and CYDV serotypes), broccoli necrotic yellows and sonchus
yellow net viruses. (184) The tomato vein clearing rhabdovirus occurring in
Japan (Kano et al., 1985) shows some similarities to eggplant mottled dwarf
virus, but tests for possible relatedness have yet to be made. The yellow vein
disease of tomatoes in Nigeria (Ladipo, 1977) is induced by an uncharacterised
sap-transmissible virus which also shows some similarities to eggplant mottled
dwarf rhabdovirus. (187) Adam, G., Chagas, C.M. and Lesemann, D.E. (1987).
Phytopathology 120: 31. Castellano, M.A. and Martelli, G.P. (1987).
Phytopathol. Medit. 26: 46. Cherif, C. and Martelli, G.P. (1985). FAO Pl.
Prot. Bull. 33: 166. Dale, J.L. and Peters, D. (1981). Intervirology 16: 86.
El Maataoui, M., Lockhart, B.E.L. and Lesemann, D.E. (1985). Phytopathology
75: 109. Kano, T.S., Namba, S., Yamashita, Y., Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1985).
Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 51: 606. Ladipo, J.L. (1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61:
958. Lockhart, B.E.L. (1987). Plant Dis. 71: 731. Peters, D. (1981). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 244, 4 pp. Plavsic, B., Eric, Z. and MilicHicH, D.
(1984). Phytopathol. Medit. 23: 49. Martelli, G.P. (1969). J. gen. Virol. 5:
319. Martelli, G.P. and Cirulli, M. (1969). Annls. Phytopath. 1: 393.
Martelli, G.P. and Castellano, M.A. (1970). Phytopathol. Medit. 9: 39.
Martelli, G.P. and Rana, G.L. (1970). Phytopathol. Medit. 9: 187. Martelli,
G.P. and Cherif, C. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119: 32. Martelli, G.P. and Hmadi,
A. (1986). Pl. Path. 35: 595. Martelli, G.P., Yilmaz, M.A. and Baloglu, S.
(1984). Phytopathol. Medit. 23: 9. Russo, M. and Martelli, G.P. (1972).
Phytopathol. Medit. 11: 136.


Eggplant severe mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: eggplant severe mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: ESMV. (4) Strains: eggplant and tomato strains. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.T.035. (8) First reported in Solanum melongena. (9) From
Nigeria. (10) By Ladipo et al. (1988). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Lycopersicon esculentum conspicuous leaf mosaic. Solanum melongena severe
mottling, blistering and distortion of leaves, and abnormal serration of leaf
margins (but cv. New York is resistant to infection). (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora,
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Nigeria. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Capsicum annuum,
Datura metel, Nicotiana megalosiphon, Physalis floridana systemic
vein-clearing and/or vein-banding. Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Nicotiana clevelandii, Nicotiana benthamiana systemic leaf mottling. Nicotiana
sylvestris, N. tabacum diffuse local lesions; no systemic infection. Nicotiana
occidentalis local chlorotic spots and rings; systemic leaf mottling. (44)
Arachis hypogaea, Cajanus cajan, Vigna unguiculata, Vigna unguiculata ssp.
cylindrica. (45) Solanum melongena (eggplant strain), Nicotiana megalosiphon,
N. occidentalis (tomato strain). (46) Nicotiana occidentalis (W), Solanum
melongena (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Datura metel,
or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis
peruviana, or Solanum melongena, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea,
or Cajanus cajan, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica.
(50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or Solanaceae <17/17>. (51)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>. (53) Ladipo et al. (1988). (54) TIP: 55-65
°C. (55) LIV: 7-9 days <eggplant strain>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (171)
Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: enlarged, unusually vesiculated
and disrupted mitochondria. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: dioscorea green banding
mosaic, eggplant green mosaic, groundnut eyespot, peanut stripe (mungbean
isolate), pepper veinal mottle and telfairia mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: amaranthus leaf mottle, bean common
mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, beet mosaic, celery mosaic, Colombian datura,
henbane mosaic, pea seed-borne mosaic, pepper mild mottle, pepper mottle, Peru
tomato, potato A, potato Y, soybean mosaic, sugarcane mosaic, sweet potato
feathery mottle, tobacco etch, turnip mosaic, watermelon mosaic 2, wild potato
mosaic and zucchini yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Ladipo, J.L., Lesemann, D.-E.
and Koenig, R. (1988). J. Phytopath. 122: 359.


Elderberry carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: elderberry A virus (Van Lent et al.,
1980). (3) Standard acronym: EV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.009. (8) First
reported in Sambucus canadensis. (9) From Scotland in plants imported from
Canada. (10) By Jones (1970). (13) Sambucus canadensis, S. nigra, S. racemosa
probably symptomless but, when present in complex, it probably intensifies the
symptoms induced by cherry leaf roll nepovirus. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis fabae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Canada, the Netherlands and the U.K. and possibly also
the former Czechoslovakia, U.S.A. and Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Amaranthus caudatus, Vicia faba, Vigna unguiculata cv.
Blackeye local and systemic infection. Arachis hypogaea, Beta vulgaris,
Celosia argentea, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Processor symptomless local
infection. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions in late summer
or early autumn; symptomless systemic infection during other seasons.
Crotalaria juncea chlorotic mottling, veinal necrosis and epinasty of
systemically infected leaves. Gomphrena globosa local lesions, no systemic
infection. (44) Chenopodium album, Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Gomphrena globosa,
Sambucus nigra, S. racemosa. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crotalaria juncea, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Gomphrena globosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Sambucus canadensis, or Sambucus nigra, or Sambucus racemosa, or Solanum
rostratum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Capsicum annuum, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium hybridum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus
albus, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or
Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum,
or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/12>, or Sambucaceae
<3/3>, or Solanaceae <1/16>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/12>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<15/16>. (53) Van Lent et al. (1980). (54) TIP: 75 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days <at
20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Veerisetty and Brakke (1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 678 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.315 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.17.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (134) And it is coat protein.
(171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: carnation latent virus. (186) Carlaviruses
reported to occur in Sambucus spp. in the former Czechoslovakia (BrcHak, 1964;
BrcHak and Polák, 1966), the U.S.A. (Uyemoto and Gilmer, 1971; Uyemoto et al.,
1971) and probably also Japan (Y. Doi, in Hull et al., 1989) might also be
related to elderberry carlavirus, but their affinities have not yet been
reported. (187) BrcHak, J. (1964). Proc. 5th Conf. Czechosl. Pl. Virologists,
Prague 1962, p. 280. BrcHak, J. and Polák, Z. (1966). Meded. Rijksfak. Landb.
Gent 31: 397. Brunt, A.A. and Stace-Smith, R. (1972). Rep. Glasshouse Crops
Res. Inst. 1971, p. 121. Dijkstra, J. and van Lent, J.W.M. (1983). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 263, 4 pp. Hull, R., Brown, F. and Payne, C.C. (1989).
In: Virology: Directory and Dictionary of Animal, Bacterial and Plant Viruses,
p. 325. MacMillan Reference Books, London, U.K. Jones, A.T. (1970). Rep. Scot.
Crops Res. Inst. for 1969, p. 58. Jones, A.T. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 70: 49.
Uyemoto, J.K. and Gilmer, R.M. (1971). Phytopathology 61: 132. Uyemoto, J.K.,
Gilmer, R.M. and Williams, E. (1971). Pl. Dis. Reptr 55: 913. Van Lent,
J.W.M., Wit, A.J. and Dijkstra, J. (1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 117.
Veerisetty, V. and Brakke, M.K. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 59.


Elderberry latent (?) carmovirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1991. (2) Synonyms: pelargonium ringspot virus
(Hollings, 1957; A.T. Jones and A.A. Brunt, unpublished data). (3) Standard
acronym: ELV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.T.016. (8) First reported in
Sambucus canadensis. (9) From Scotland, U.K. (10) By Jones (1972). (11)
Symptoms <usually> none. (12) Symptoms sometimes line patterns. (13) Sambucus
canadensis symptomless. Pelargonium × hortorum occasional line patterns. (15)
Vectorless soil transmission. (24) Not transmitted by Macrosiphum euphorbiae,
Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K. and in Europe, Canada and
the U.S.A. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show symptomless or chlorotic local lesions. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions, sometimes
systemic spots. Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. Xanthi,
Petunia × hybrida symptomless. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (46)
Chenopodium quinoa. (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pelargonium × hortorum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Sambucus canadensis, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Anthriscus
cerefolium, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Daucus carota, or
Pastinaca sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus
sativus. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Sambucaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <9/9>. (51)
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>.
(53) Jones (1972). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (60) Method: Jones (1972). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 112 S
<major, B>. (78) Of the other(s) 48 S <minor, T>. (79) Density 1.36 g cm3 in
CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.8. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.62. (84) Virions
contain 23 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 77 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.7 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Mayo and Jones (1973). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
40000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Mayo and Jones (1973).
(171) Virions found in leaves. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae.
(180) : Tombusviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA, serology. (187)
Ellis, P.J., Converse, R.H. and Stace-Smith, R. (1992). Acta Hort 308: 69.
Hollings, M. (1957). Pl. Path. 6: 17. Jones, A.T. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 70:
49. Jones, A.T. (1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 127, 4 pp. Mayo, M.A.
and Jones, A.T. (1973). J. gen. Virol. 19: 245. Morris, T.J. and Carrington,
J.C. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions with
Monopartite RNA Genomes, p. 73: ed. R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York.


Elm mottle ilarvirus

      (1) A.T. Jones, H. Kleinhempel and K. Kontzog, 1987. (2) Synonyms:
possibly hydrangea mosaic virus (Jones, 1985), lilac streak mosaic virus
(Smolak and Novak, 1950), lilac white mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym:
EMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.02.05. (8) First reported in Ulmus minor.
(9) From Germany. (10) By Schmelzer et al. (1966a). (11) Symptoms persist <but
restricted to a few branches>. (13) Hydrangea macrophylla chlorotic mosaic.
Syringa vulgaris white mosaic. Ulmus minor light green blotches, diffuse
mottling. Ulmus glabra mottling, banded or `oak-leaf` pattern. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <Jones and Mayo 1973>. (36) Studies reported by
Schmelzer et al. (1966); Schmelzer (1969). (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Germany and
Scotland; similar leaf symptoms in elm seen in other countries (Schmelzer et
al., 1966). (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, then systemic mottling and malformation.
Cucumis sativus chlorotic blotches, severe systemic mosaic. Nicotiana
megalosiphon chlorotic or necrotic blotches systemic crinkling. (44) Arachis
hypogaea, Brassica oleracea, Digitalis purpurea, Gypsophila perfoliata, Reseda
alba. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana tabacum for propagation. Petunia ×
hybrida for maintenance. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (L),
Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata (L). (47) Amaranthus retroflexus, or

Chenopodium quinoa local lesions. Cichorium endiva, Lactuca sativa systemic

Epirus cherry ourmiavirus

      (1) A. Avgelis, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: EpCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.4.DE.2. (8) First reported in Prunus avium. (9) From Giannina, Epirus,
Greece. (10) By Avgelis et al. (1988). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
rasp-leaf symptoms. (13) Prunus avium enations on abaxial leaf surfaces,
stunting. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in Epirus, Greece. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions or ringspots, then systemic mottle or chlorotic or
necrotic ringspots. (43) Abelmoschus esculentus chlorotic local lesions, then
systemic yellow ringspots. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions. Datura
stramonium systemic mottle and ringspotting. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local
lesions, then systemic necrotic ring spots and malformation. Nicotiana tabacum
cv. Xanthi-nc local and systemic necrotic ringspots. Petunia × hybrida local
and systemic chlorotic ring spots. Phaseolus vulgaris reddish local lesions.
Vicia faba reddish local lesions, then systemic chlorotic mottle and necrotic
spots. Vigna unguiculata reddish local lesions, then systemic necrotic spots
and tip necrosis. (44) Capsicum annuum, Cucurbita pepo, Nicotiana glutinosa,
Ocimum basilicum, Zinnia elegans. (45) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
benthamiana, Vicia faba. (46) Abelmoschus esculentus (W), Chenopodium

faba (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia cristata,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or

var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum annuum, or

basilicum, or Petroselinum crispum, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum tuberosum, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <1/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/8>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/9>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <10/15>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/3>, or Cruciferae

log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy:

(179) Ourmiavirus. (184) The size and shape of the virions of epirus cherry
and melon Ourmia viruses (Lisa et al., 1988) are like those of alfalfa mosaic
virus. However epirus cherry virus is not an alfamovirus but seems to be
related to cassava Ivorian bacilliform virus (Aiton et al., 1988), olive
latent 2, melon Ourmia and pelargonium zonate spot viruses, but no serological
relationship between their virions has been shown. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: electron microscopy. (187) Avgelis, A., Barba, M. and Rumbos, J.

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ErLV. (5) ICTV decimal code

Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or

Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or

Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: Andean potato

Eucharis mottle (?) nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.DE.2. (8) First
reported in Eucharis candida. (9) From the U.S.A. in plants imported from
Peru. (10) By Kahn et al. (1962). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Eucharis candida
leaf mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Celosia cristata chlorotic local lesions, then systemic
vein-banding and malformation. Chenopodium amaranticolor local and systemic
ringspots. Cucumis sativus chlorotic and necrotic local lesions, then systemic
mottling. Datura stramonium local green rings, becoming systemic. Gomphrena
globosa systemic vein-banding and rings. Nicotiana tabacum mostly symptomless.
Phaseolus vulgaris local lesions then systemic necrosis. Tetragonia
tetragonioides white necrotic rings. Vigna unguiculata necrotic local lesions,
then systemic necrosis. (45) Nicotiana tabacum, Gomphrena globosa. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Vigna unguiculata (L). (47) Celosia cristata,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Datura stramonium, or Eucharis candida, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Kahn et al. (1962). (54) TIP: <in sap of Gomphrena globosa or
tobacco> 65-75 °C. (55) LIV: 6-10 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (60)
Method: Kahn et al. (1962). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: tobacco ringspot virus (several isolates).
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, the beet
ringspot strain of tomato black ring and raspberry ringspot viruses. (184)
Kahn et al. (1962) considered eucharis mottle virus to be a strain of tobacco
ringspot virus. However, as its virions are serologically distinct and the two
viruses fail to cross-protect and are unable to form pseudo-recombinants, it
is considered to be a separate virus species (Gooding, 1970; Salazar and
Harrison, 1978). (187) Gooding, G.V. (1970). Phytopathology 60: 708. Kahn,
R.F., Scott, H.A. and Monroe, R.L. (1962). Phytopathology 52: 1211. Salazar,
L.F. and Harrison, B.D. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 387.


Euonymus fasciation (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: EFV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.017. (8) First reported in Euonymus japonica. (9) From France. (10)
By Codaccioni and Cossard (1975). (13) Euonymus japonica, E. japonica var.
microphylla fasciated stems. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
France. (47) Euonymus japonica, or Euonymus japonica var. microphylla. (50)
Celastraceae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (179) <Possible>
unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (186) It is not known if this
virus is related to a rhabdovirus that occurs in Euonymus japonica with
vein-yellowing and chlorotic leaf spotting, but no fasciation, in the formar
Yugoslavia (PlesHe and EricH, 1980). (187) Codaccioni, M. and Cossard, C.
(1975). C.r. hebd. Seanc. Acad. Sci. 280: 1497. Codaccioni, M. and Cossard, C.
(1977). C.r. hebd. Seanc. Acad. Sci. 284: 701. PlesHe, N. and EricH, Z.
(1980). Acta Phytopath. Acad. Sci. Hung. 15: 291.


Euonymus (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.DE.03. (8) First
reported in Euonymus japonica. (9) From the formar Yugoslavia. (10) By PlesHe
and EricH (1980). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Euonymus japonica, E. japonica
var. microphylla vein-yellowing and chlorotic spotting. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in Yugoslavia. (47) Euonymus japonica, or Euonymus
japonica var. microphylla. (50) Celastraceae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm
<in sections>. (71) Virions 70 nm wide <in sections>. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in the perinuclear space. (179) <Possible> unassigned
rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (186) It is not known whether a
rhabdovirus from fasciated Euonymus japonica in France (Codaccioni and
Cossard, 1975) is related to this virus. (187) Codaccioni, M. and Cossard, C.
(1975). C.r. hebd. Acad. Séanc., Paris 280: 1497. PlesHe, N. and EricH, Z.
(1980). Acta Phytopath. Acad. Sci. Hung. 15: 291.


Euphorbia mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: EuMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.017. (8) First reported in Euphorbia heterophylla. (9) From Sao
Paulo, Brazil. (10) By Costa and Bennett (1950). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Euphorbia heterophylla golden mosaic and leaf malformation. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci

persistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)

Rico, and the USA <Florida>, or Venezuela. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Euphorbia heterophylla chlorosis. Datura stramonium chlorotic local
lesions and systemic chlorosis. Datura metel local and systemic chlorotic
spotting. Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa systemic crinkling. (44)

glutinosa. (46) Datura stramonium (W), Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N. glutinosa

Nicotiana glutinosa. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or

pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana

vulgaris. (50) Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<5/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <6/10>. (53) Costa and Bennett
(1950); Jaramillo and Lastra (1986). (54) TIP: <in Nicotiana benthamiana sap>
44-46 °C. (55) LIV: 6-7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1. (58) Leaf sap contains

only) genome part <the larger> 2.87 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.7 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Jaramillo and Lastra (1986). (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Jaramillo and Lastra (1986). (171) Virions found in leaves,
mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176)
Fibrillar bodies in nuclei. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: unusual for a geminivirus, cytoplasmic inclusions. (179)
Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: bean golden mosaic, African cassava mosaic,
tomato golden mosaic and lima bean golden mosaic geminiviruses. (183) The
Brazilian isolate is more stable than the Venezuelan isolate. (187) Bird, J.
and Maramorosch, K. (1978). Adv. Virus Res. 22: 55. Bird, J., Sanchez, J.,
Rodriguez, R.L. and Julia, F.J. (1975). In: Tropical Diseases of Legumes, p.
325; eds J. Bird and K. Maramorosch. Academic Press, New York. Costa, A.S.
(1965). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 13: 1. Costa, A.S. (1976). Ann. Rev. Phytopath.
16: 429. Costa, A.S. and Bennett, C.W. (1950). Phytopathology 40: 266. Costa,

Faba bean necrotic yellows nanavirus

      (1) K.M. Makkouk, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.1.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Vicia faba. (9) From Lattakia, Syria. (10) By Makkouk et al.
(1991). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms yellowing and stunting. (13)
Cicer arietinum, Lens culinaris yellowing and stunting. Phaseolus vulgaris
stunting, yellowing and rosetting. Vicia faba stunting, yellowing and leaf
necrosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis craccivora, Aphis fabae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Egypt, Ethiopia, Jordan,
Lebanon, Morocco, Syria, and Turkey. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Morocco. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show stunting and yellowing, few pods, rolling of
youngest leaves. (43) Cicer arietinum, Lens culinaris, Phaseolus vulgaris,
Pisum sativum, Vicia faba, V. sativa, V. palaestina leaf yellowing and plant
stunting. Medicago hispida, Trifolium incarnatum leaf yellowing and reddening,

culinaris, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Pisum sativum (W), Vicia sativa
(W). (47) Cicer arietinum, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or
Medicago hispida, or Melilotus officinalis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia palaestina, or Vicia sativa. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris,
or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Crambe
abyssinica, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Glycine max, or

or Vicia villosa, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<12/19>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae
<2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/19>, or

Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM. (60) Method:
Katul et al., 1993. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 18 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in

      (1) T. Lundsgaard, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: FLSV. (5) ICTV decimal

bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)

Lundsgaard (1987). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121)
Is <probably> rRNA. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest>
58000. (134) G protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 49000. (136) N protein. (137)

protein. (171) Virions found in leaves roots, mesophyll and epidermis. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are membranous bodies and viroplasms. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: Northern cereal mosaic, barley yellow
striate mosaic, cereal chlorotic mottle, maize sterile stunt, digitaria
striate and Moroccan wheat viruses (Lundsgaard, 1984; Greber, 1990). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: serology. (187) Greber, R.S. (1990). Ann. appl.
Biol. 116: 259. Lundsgaard, T. (1984). Intervirology 22: 50. Lundsgaard, T.

<1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear modal

(171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in the
perinuclear space. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Govindu, H.C., Yaraguntaiah, R.C. and Keshavamurthy, K.
(1976). Pesticides 10: 21. Maramorosch, K., Govindu, H.C. and Kondo, F.
(1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61: 1029. Rao, D.G., Varma, P.M. and Capoor, S.P.
(1965). Indian Phytopath. 18: 139.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: FoMV. (5) ICTV decimal code

Frangipani mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) A. Varma, 1984. (2) Synonyms: temple tree mosaic virus, champa
mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: FrMV. (4) Strains: Adel (Adelaide), Ald
(Allahabad), Del (Delhi). (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.003. (8) First
reported in Plumeria acutifolia, P. alba. (9) From India and Australia. (10)
By Francki et al. (1971); Varma and Gibbs (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Plumeria acutifolia mosaic, ringspots, vein banding, bronzing. P. alba
ringspots, leaf malformation, necrosis. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Australia, India, and Kenya. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Datura stramonium chlorotic or black necrotic local lesions;
most strains not systemic. Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local lesions, not
systemic. Nicotiana tabacum cvs Samsun, Virginia Gold, White Burley chlorotic
or necrotic ringspots, then systemically when grown at 35°C. Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii faint chlorotic lesions which become necrotic when plants are
grown at 35°C. Not systemic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus,
Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa. (46) Datura stramonium (L). (47)
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or
Plumeria acutifolia, or Plumeria alba. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Apocynaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (52) FMV
requires high temperatures for replication. More species become infected at
temperatures above 25°C than below. Symptoms appear in 36 days at 35°C, but
after 2 weeks or more at 22°C. (53) Varma and Gibbs (1978). (54) TIP: 95 °C.
(55) LIV: 70 days <or more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: Varma et al. (1970). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 297 nm. (71) Virions 17 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 188 S. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome unipartite. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (145) Method of preparation: Francki et al. (1971). (147)
Amino acid composition: Francki et al. (1971). (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cucumber
green mottle mosaic and sunn-hemp mosaic viruses are closely related; tobacco
mosaic virus-type strain, tobacco mild green mosaic (U2), tomato mosaic and
ribgrass mosaic viruses are more distantly related (Francki et al., 1971).
Nucleic hybridization tests have confirmed the relatedness of tomato mosaic
and tobacco mild green mosaic viruses (Palukaitis and Symons, 1980; Palukaitis
et al., 1981). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Sammons'
opuntia virus. (187) Francki, R.I.B., Zaitlin, M. and Grivell, C.J. (1971).
Aust. J. biol. Sci. 24: 815. Varma, A. and Gibbs, A.J. (1978). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 196, 4 pp. Palukaitis, P. and Symons, R.H. (1980). Virology
107: 354. Palukaitis, P., Randles, J.W., Tian, Y.C., Kang, L.Y. and Tien, P.
(1981). Intervirology 16: 136. Varma, A., Gibbs, A.J. and Woods, R.D. (1970).
J. gen. Virol. 8: 21.


Freesia leaf necrosis varicosavirus

      (1) D. Peters, 1991; I. Bouwen, 1994; A.A. Brunt, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.3.DE.2. (8) First reported in Freesia refracta. (9) From the
Netherlands. (10) By Van Dorst (1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
Chlorotic flecks, spots and necrosis. More severe when plants are stressed by
bright light or waterlogging. (13) Freesia spp. chlorotic flecks and spots in
leaves, which become necrotic. Flowers and corms unaffected. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Olpidium
brassicae. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation <with difficulty>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by The virus occurs in soil and is spread by infected
corms, hence it is controlled by soil treatment and corm choice (Hakkaart,
1971, 1975; Van Dorst, 1973, 1975, 1988). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region.
(39) Spreads in Germany, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, and the UK. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor pinpoint
necrotic local lesions with chlorotic halo. Not systemic. Nicotiana hesperis
(Accession 67A) chlorotic local, and sometimes systemic, spots, centres
becoming necrotic and white. Nicotiana occidentalis (Accession P1) chlorotic
spots and rings, sometimes systemic vein chlorosis. (44) Echinops exaltatus,
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cv. White Burley, Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Bataaf, Vicia faba cv. Compacta. (45) Freesia refracta. (46) Freesia refracta
(W), Chenopodium quinoa (L), Nicotiana hesperis (L), N. occidentalis (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Freesia refracta, or
Nicotiana hesperis, or Nicotiana occidentalis. (48) Ageratum conyzoides, or
Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Bellis
perennis, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Echinops
exaltatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Papaver
nudicaule, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cv. Bataaf>, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Salvia
splendens, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Torenia fournieri,
or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/6>, or
Iridaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/12>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/6>, or Compositae <6/6>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae
<2 /2>, or Solanaceae <10/12>. (179) <Possible> varicosavirus. (186) This
virus, together with freesia mosaic potyvirus, causes freesia streak disease
(Brunt, 1974; Van Dorst, 1973). (187) Bellardi, M.G. and Bertaccini, A.
(1989). Adv. Hort. Sci. 3: 29. Bouwen, I. (1994). Acta. Hort. in press. Brunt,
A.A. (1970). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1969, p. 131. Brunt, A.A.
(1974). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1973, p. 117. Caspar, R. and Brunt,
A.A. (1971). Nachbl. PflSchutz., Braunschweig 23: 89. Foxe, M.J. and Wilson,
U.E. (1985). Acta Hort. 164: 291. Hakkaart, F.A. (1971). Proc. 7th Conf.
Czech. Pl. Virol. 1971: 231. Hakkaart, F.A. (1975). Jaarvers. Inst. Pl.
Onderz. 1974, p. 70. Van Dorst, H.J.M. (1973). Neth. J. Pl. Path. :79 130. Van
Dorst, H.J.M. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81 45. Van Dorst, H.J.M. (1988). In:

Freesia mosaic potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1985. (2) Synonyms: freesia streak virus. (3) Standard

Furcraea necrotic streak (?) dianthovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. Revised by F.J. Morales and M. Castâno, 1992. (2)

then necrotic streaks. (15) The virus may have a soil-inhabiting vector. (24)
Not transmitted by Planococcus citri, Saissetia caffea. (31) Virus transmitted

Z. 92: 57. Castâno, J.J. (1990). Fitopatol. Colombiana 14: 24. Gálvez, G.E.,

(1992). J. Phytopath. 134: 247.


Galinsoga mosaic carmovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: GaMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.007. (8) First reported in Galinsoga parviflora. (9) From Queensland,
Australia. (10) By Behncken (1970). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Galinsoga
parviflora mosaic. (15) Without a vector through soil. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
small necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Galinsoga parviflora chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic; leaf malformation. Phaseolus vulgaris
cvs Bountiful, Pinto reddish-brown necrotic lesions; not systemic. Spinacia
oleracea systemic chlorotic spots and vein necrosis, leaves produced later
symptomless. (44) Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Trifolium repens, Vicia faba. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Phaseolus
vulgaris (several cultivars). (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L); Chenopodium
quinoa (L); Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Calendula officinalis, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium
endiva, or Daucus carota, or Emilia sagittata, or Emilia sonchifolia, or
Galinsoga parviflora, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus
annuus, or Lablab purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Melilotus albus, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or

stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Stellaria media, or Trifolium
repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <9/9>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/10>, or Solanaceae <4/6>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>.
(51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/10>, or Solanaceae <2/6>. (53) Behncken (1970).
(54) TIP: 75-80 °C. (55) LIV: 42 days <and longer>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Behncken (1970). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 34 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 118 S. (78) Of the other(s) 48 S <minor component of
some preparations>. (84) Virions contain 22 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 78 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) <Probably> linear. (91) Total genome size 4.4 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.4 kb. (100) Base
composition 24.8 % G. (101) Base composition 28.1 % A. (102) Base composition
21.8 % C. (103) Base composition 25.3 % U. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not
found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 36400. (134) Coat
protein. (145) Method of preparation: Skotnicki and Gibbs (1981). (147) Amino
acid composition: Skotnicki and Gibbs (1981). (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm <but not in the nucleus or perinuclear
space>. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape <multivesicular bodies derived from mitochondria>. (177) They
do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: multivesicular bodies
similar to those found in cells infected with tomato bushy stunt virus. (179)
Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: tomato bushy stunt and glycine mottle
viruses. (187) Behncken, G.M. (1970). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 23: 497. Behncken,
G.M., Francki, R.I.B. and Gibbs, A.J. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
252, 4 pp. Hatta, T. and Francki, R.I.B. (1981). J. Ultrastruct. Res. 74: 116.
Shukla, D.D., Shanks, G.J., Teakle, D.S. and Behncken, G.M. (1979). Aust. J.
biol. Sci. 32: 267. Skotnicki, A. and Gibbs, A.J. (1981). Australas. Pl. Path.
10: 27.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.7.T.DE.1. (8) First

(13) Allium sativum severe dwarfing, leaves dark green with swollen veins and

4th largest 3.25 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th largest 2.7 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th
largest and other parts 2.3 kb <pairs; also 1.60, 1.40 and 1.30 kb pairs>.
(171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (175)
Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible>

Ginger chlorotic fleck (?) sobemovirus

      (1) J.E. Thomas, 1984. Revised 1987. (3) Standard acronym: GCFV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.T.014. (8) First reported in Zingiber officinale. (9)
From New Zealand and Queensland, Australia. (10) By Thomas (1986). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Zingiber officinale chlorotic leaf flecking. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Australia, where it was isolated from ginger imported from India,
Malaysia, Mauritius and Thailand, but all infected material was destroyed and
there was no evidence that it became established in Australia. Its presence
has not yet been confirmed in the countries of origin of the infected ginger.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Zingiber officinale systemic
chlorotic flecking. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis
sativus cv. Supermarket, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful, Zea mays cv.
Iochief. (45) Zingiber officinale. (46) Zingiber officinale (W). No local
lesion host. (47) Zingiber officinale. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Elettaria cardamomum, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Hedychium gardnerianum, or Musa acuminata <cv. Cavendish>, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sorghum bicolor,
or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Zingiberaceae <1/3>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Musaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>, or Zingiberaceae <2/3>. (53) Thomas (1986). (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: virions are unstable in PTA,
but stable in UA and AM. (60) Method: Thomas (1986). (61) Virions isometric.
(64) Virions 28-33 nm in diameter <from side to side, 4 nm less than from
vertex to vertex>. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 111 S <in 10 mM phosphate pH7,
20°C>. (79) Density 1.355 g cm3 in CsCl <fixed>. (81) Density in Cs2SO4 1.297
g cm3 at pH 4.9 and 1.293 g cm3 at pH 6.9. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite <but
with two minor components>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest>
4.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Thomas (1986). (132) Virion
protein(s) two <the smaller probably a degradation product of the larger>.
(133) Mr <of the larger> 29000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 27300. (145) Method of
preparation: Thomas (1986): SDS digestion. (171) Virions found in leaves and
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies. (179) <Possible>
Sobemovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: carnation
mottle, cocksfoot mild mottle (syn. phleum mottle), cocksfoot mottle, cucumber
leaf spot (cucumber fruit streak strain), cucumber mosaic, cymbidium ringspot,
elm latent, galinsoga mosaic, glycine yellow mosaic, hibiscus chlorotic
ringspot, lucerne transient streak, narcissus tip necrosis, pelargonium flower
break, pelargonium line pattern, pelargonium vein netting, red clover necrotic
mosaic, saguaro cactus, solanum nodiflorum mottle, southern bean mosaic,
sowbane mosaic, tobacco necrosis, turnip crinkle, turnip rosette and velvet
tobacco mottle viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: easily diagnosed by
serological methods. (187) Thomas, J.E. (1986). Ann. appl. Biol. 108: 43.
Thomas, J.E. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 328, 4 pp.

Glycine mosaic comovirus

      (1) G.M. Behncken, 1980. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: GMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Glycine clandestina. (9)
From the Blue Mountains, N.S.W., Australia. (10) By Bowyer et al. (1980). (11)
Symptoms vary cyclically over a few weeks and vary seasonally. (13) Glycine
clandestina, G. tabacina green mosaic, leaves malformation. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic
lesions; then systemic mosaic, vein yellowing or netting. Glycine max, G. soja

necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Bountiful, Black Turtle Soup necrotic
lesions; then systemic mottling in cv. Bountiful. Pisum sativum systemic
mosaic. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful, Pisum
sativum cv. Greenfeast. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L),
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful (L). (47) Cajanus cajan, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Glycine
clandestina, or Glycine max, or Glycine soja, or Glycine tabacina, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/20>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<9/20>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (53) Bowyer et al. (1980). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C.
(55) LIV: 7-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Bowyer et al. (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 130 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 60 S <T>, or 103
S <M>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.63 <M>, or 1.75 <B>. (84) Virions contain 38.6 %
nucleic acid <B>, or 26.4 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 63.2 % protein <B>, or 73.6 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (132)
Virion protein(s) two <major and 1 minor>. (133) Mr <of the largest> 42000.
(135) Mr of 2nd largest 21500. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 19000. (145) Method of
preparation: Bowyer et al. (1980). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (176) Large aggregates, often in crystalline array,
associated with amorphous, membrane-bound bodies. (177) They contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: cytoplasmic vesiculation. (179) Comovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: broad bean stain, broad bean true mosaic and squash mosaic viruses to
both strains; cowpea mosaic (Sb and Ark), bean pod mottle and red clover
mottle viruses are related to the GW strain. (187) Bowyer, J.W., Dale, J.L.
and Behncken, G.M. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 95: 385.

      (1) G.M. Behncken, 1981. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: GMoV. (5)

(44) Chenopodium quinoa, Pisum sativum. (45) Glycine soja. (46) Cyamopsis

vulgaris (L). (47) Cassia occidentalis, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine

Nicotiana tabacum, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium

<10/17>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or

(1984). (54) TIP: 80-85 °C. (55) LIV: 60 days <or more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (59) Electron microscopy: use 2% UA for negative staining. (60) Method:

39000 <plus two of 37500 and 31000>. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Dale and Gibbs (1976). (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei <especially
associated with the nucleolus and cytoplasmic invaginations of chloroplasts>.
(178) Other cellular changes: vesicles in peroxisomes closely associated with
chloroplasts. Number of vesicles are variable and are located around
microbodies. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: artichoke
mottled crinkle, carnation Italian ringspot, cymbidium ringspot, galinsoga
mosaic, pelargonium leaf curl, petunia asteroid mosaic, saguaro cactus,
tephrosia symptomless, tomato bushy stunt and turnip crinkle viruses. (187)
Behncken, G.M. and Dale, J.L. (1984). Intervirology 21: 159. Dale, J.L. and
Gibbs, A.J. (1976). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 29: 397.

      (3) Standard acronym: GoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.020. (8) First

(179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(184) This virus is similar to lettuce necrotic yellows rhabdovirus (Kitajima
and Costa, 1966). (187) Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S. (1966). Virology 29:
523.


Grapevine A (?) trichovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: GVA. (5) ICTV decimal code
76.0.1.T.003. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Italy. (10) By
Conti et al. (1980). (13) Vitis vinifera leaf rolling, reddening of leaf
margins and petioles, and localised swelling and cracking of stems (probably
Kober stem grooving disease). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Pseudococcus longispinus, Planococcus citri,
P. ficus. (18) Transmitted by Pseudococcidae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in France,
Italy, Israel, Switzerland, South Africa, Tunisia and Yemen. (43) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii narrow leaflets, vein-banding of systemically
infected leaves, followed by mottling and puckering. Vitis vinifera leaf
rolling and reddening (in autumn). (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Cucurbita pepo, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica, N. tabacum,
N. rustica, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N. clevelandii (W). (47)
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Vitis vinifera. (48)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum. (50) Solanaceae <2/5>, or
Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/5>. (61) Virions
filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 800 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.8
nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35288. (171) Virions found in phloem cells. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (178) Other cellular changes: Rosciglione et al.
(1983). (179) <Possible> Trichovirus. (187) Boscia, D., Aslouj, E., Elicio,
V., Savino, V., Castellano, M.A. and Martelli, G.P. (1992). Arch. Virol. 127:
185. Boccardo, G. and d'Aquilo, M. (1981). J. gen. Virol. 53: 179. Chevalier,
S., Greif, C., Clauzel, J.-M., Walter, B. and Fritsch, C. (1995). J.
Phytopathology 143: 369. Conti, M., Milne, R.G., Luisoni, E. and Boccardo, G.
(1980). Phytopathology 70: 394. Englebrecht, D.J. and Kasdorf, G.G.F. (1985).
Phytopath. medit. 24: 101. Milne, R.G., Conti, M., Lesemann, D.-E., Stellmach,
G., Tanne, E. and Cohen, J. (1984). Phytopath. Z. 110: 360. Minafra, A.,
Saldarelli, F., Grieco, F. and Martelli, G.P. (1994). Arch. Virol. 137: 249.
Rosciglione, B., Castellano, M.A., Martelli, G.P., Savino, V. and Cannizzaro,
G. (1983). Vitis 22: 331.


Grapevine ajinashika disease (?) luteovirus

      (1) S. Holland, 1986. Revised by A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym:
GAV. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.T.006. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera.
(9) From Japan. (10) By Namba et al. (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vitis
vinifera no leaf symptoms, fruit are unpalatable because of small sugar
content. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Vitis
vinifera no leaf symptoms, fruit unpalatable. (45) Vitis vinifera. (47) Vitis
vinifera. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <6/6>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Namba et
al. (1991). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 110 S. (79) Density 1.38 g cm3 in
CsCl. (84) Virions contain 30 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.8 kb. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in
phloem and companion cells in sieve tubes. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm,
in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: necrosis of phloem cells. (179) <Possible>
Luteovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: barley
yellow dwarf and potato leafroll viruses. (187) Namba, S., Yamashita, S., Doi,
Y. and Yora, K. (1979). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 45: 70. Namba, S., Boschia,
D., Yamashita, S., Tsuchizaki, T. and Gonsalves, D. (1991). Plant Dis. 75:
1249.


Grapevine Algerian latent tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: GALV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Algeria. (10) By
Gallitelli et al. (1989). (13) Vitis vinifera no conspicuous symptoms. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (40) Found, but with no evidence
of spread, in Algeria, Germany and Italy. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana
systemic chlorosis and necrosis. (44) Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Vitis vinifera. (48) Nicotiana clevelandii. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <1/2>, or Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51) Solanaceae <1/2>. (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 4.6 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
35900. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178)
Other cellular changes: the virus induces the formation of membrane associated
vesicles at the periphery of peroxisomes which possibly contain dsRNA. It also
sometimes induces the formation of rod-like structures in cytoplasm and in the
stroma of chloroplasts and mitochondria. (179) Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae.
(180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
eggplant mottled crinkle tombusvirus. (184) The viral RNA has some sequence
homology with those of cymbidium ringspot, petunia asteroid mosaic and Sikte
waterborne tombusviruses. (186) The virus has only been found in river water
in Germany and in Sicily. (187) Cannizzaro, G., Rosciglione, B., and
Castellano, M.A. (1990). Inform. Fitopatol. 40: 55. Gallitelli, D., Martelli,
G.P. and di Franco, A. (1989). Phytoparasitica 17: 61. Yi, L., Lesemann,
D.-E., Koenig, R., Rüdel, M. and Pfeilstetter, E. (1992). J. Phytopath. 134:
121.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: GVB. (5) ICTV decimal code
76.0.1.T.004. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Switzerland,
Italy. (10) By Gugerli et al. (1984); Milne et al. (1984). (13) Vitis

Switzerland and, possibly, Israel. (47) Vitis vinifera. (50) Vitidaceae <1/1>.
(61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 1800
nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35289. (179) <Possible> Trichovirus. (187) Conti, M.
