Grapevine Bulgarian latent nepovirus

      (1) S. Holland, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: GBLV. (4) Strains: several
distinct strains are known (Martelli et al., 1978a; Gallitelli et al., 1983).
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.014. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9)
From Bulgaria. (10) By Martelli et al. (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Vitis vinifera symptomless, when infected with European strains (Martelli et
al., 1977). Vitis labrusca cv. Concord delayed budbreak, irregular elongation
of the shoots, pale green foliage and straggly fruit clusters, when infected
with New York strain (Uyemoto et al., 1977). (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <New York strain c. 5% in Vitis
lambrusca and c. 12% in Chenopodium quinoa; Uyemoto et al., 1977>. (36)
Studies reported by Martelli et al. (1978). (40) Found, but with no evidence
of spread, in Bulgaria (Martelli et al., 1977, 1978a), Yugoslavia
(Dimitrijevic, 1985), Portugal (Gallitelli et al., 1983) and the U.S.A.
(Uyemoto et al., 1977). (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, then severe systemic
mottling and necrotic flecking. Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic mottling
and leaf malformation. Gomphrena globosa reddish lesions, then malformation of
upper leaves. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic lesions; then systemic chlorosis
and stunting. Phaseolus vulgaris systemic mottling (Portuguese strain).
Nicotiana megalosiphon local and systemic chlorotic rings (Bulgarian strain).
(44) Datura stramonium, Cucurbita pepo, Pisum sativum, Vigna unguiculata,
Zinnia elegans. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L); Chenopodium amaranticolor (W). (47)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides,
or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vitis labrusca, or
Vitis rupestris, or Vitis vinifera. (48) Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium,
or Pisum sativum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae
<9/9>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or
Solanaceae <5/6>, or Vitidaceae <3/3>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <1/6>. (53) Martelli
et al., 1977; 1978a; Gallitelli et al., 1983. (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV:
15-20 days <at 22°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6 <Martelli et al., 1977;
1987a>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Martelli et al.
(1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 127 S
<B2>. (78) Of the other(s) 120 S <B1>, or 52 S <T>. (79) Density 1.489 g cm3
in CsCl <B2>, or 1.479 g cm3 in CsCl <B1>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.7 <B>, or
0.8 <T); (Martelli et al., 1977; Gallitelli et al., 1983>. (84) Virions
contain 41 % nucleic acid <B2>, or 39 % nucleic acid <B1>, or 0 % nucleic acid
<T; Reichmann, 1965>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B2>, or 61 % protein <B1>, or
100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 12.1 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 6.2 kb <B2>. (94) The 2nd largest 5.9 kb <B1>. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Quacquarelli et al. (1972) freezing and
thawing; Martelli et al. (1977) heating at 68°C for 90 seconds. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
found in the virions <of some isolates>. (121) Is satellite RNA <of c.1.4 kb;
Gallitelli et al. 1983>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 54000 <Martelli
et al., 1977; Gallitelli et al., 1983>. (145) Method of preparation: Agrawal
and Tremaine (1972). (171) Virions found in mesophyll in herbaceous plants and
grapevines. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Membranous bodies
and tubules. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: cell
wall outgrowths centered on plasmodesmata and engulfing virus-containing
tubules (Martelli et al., 1982). (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: blueberry
leaf mottle virus, but distantly (Ramsdell and Stace-Smith, 1982; Gallitelli
et al., 1983). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: many
other nepoviruses. (184) Different strains are serologically distinguishable
from one another in gel diffusion tests (Martelli et al., 1978a; Uyemoto et
al., 1977; Gallitelli et al., 1983). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Grapevine
Bulgarian latent virus, like most other nepoviruses, infects Nicotiana
clevelandii but grapevine fleck virus does not. Grapevine Bulgarian latent is
serologically distinct and also has a much narrower host range than most
nepoviruses. (187) Agrawal, H.D. and Tremaine, J.H. (1972). Virology 47: 8. de
Mendonça, A., de Sequeira, O.A., Mota, M., Pereira, A.N. and Simoes, V.
(1982). Proc. ICVG, Niagara Falls, 1980, p. 245. Gallitelli, D., Savino, V.
and de Sequeira, O.A. (1983). Phytopathol. Medit. 22: 27. Martelli, G.P.,
Gallitelli, D. Abracheva, Savino, V. and Quacquarelli, A. (1978a). Proc. 6th
Meeting ICVG, Cordova 1976, Monogr. INIA 18: 136. Martelli, G.P.,
Quacquarelli, A. and Gallitelli, D. (1978b). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
186, 4 pp. Martelli, G.P., Di Franco, A., Russo, M. and Savino, V. (1982).
Proc. ICVG, Niagara Falls 1980, p. 251. Quacquarelli, A., Piazzolla, P. and
Vovlas, C. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 17: 147. Reichmann, M.E. (1965). Virology
25: 166. Russo, M., Martelli, G.P. and Savino, V. (1982). Proc. 7th Meeting
ICVG. Niagara Falls 1980, p. 251. Uyemoto, J.K., Taschenberg, C.F. and Humer,
D.K. (1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61: 949.


Grapevine chrome mosaic nepovirus

      (1) G.P. Martelli, 1987; S. Holland, 1986. (2) Synonyms: Hungarian
chrome mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: GCMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.0.015. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Hungary. (10) By
Martelli et al. (1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vitis vinifera and
interspecific hybrids green mottling or yellow blotching of leaves, leaf and
cane malformation, stunting, no fruit. Apium graveolens yellow veins. (15)
Virus-infected vines distributed in patches in the field. Reports of
transmission by Xiphinema index (Mali, 1976) are doubtful. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting
<Martelli et al., 1965; Lehoczky and Sarospataki, 1967>. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Hungary. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in Yugoslavia (Saric and Hranuelli, 1979) and
England (Hollings et al., 1969). (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions, systemic mosaic,
stunting; solanaceous plants usually remain symptomless. (43) Chenopodium
quinoa small necrotic lesions; then severe systemic chlorosis, necrotic
speckling, apical necrosis. Gomphrena globosa chlorotic to reddish lesions,
then transient systemic mosaic. Datura stramonium inoculated leaves
symptomless; then systemic transient yellow spots. Phaseolus vulgaris
symptomless inoculated leaves; systemic mosaic, yellow-green rings and specks
with some necrotic blotches. Vitis vinifera cvs Jubileum 75 and Pinot noir
chlorosis and apical necrosis, severe stunting (Lehoczky, 1985). (45)
Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Apium graveolens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vitis vinifera. (48)
Nicotiana megalosiphon. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <6/7>,
or Umbelliferae <1/1>, or Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51) Solanaceae <1/7>. (53)
Martelli (1965); Martelli and Quacquarelli (1972a). (54) TIP: 60-62 °C. (55)
LIV: 7 days <at 22°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4 <Martelli et al., 1965>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: see Martelli (1965);
Martelli and Quacquarelli (1972a). (60) Method: Martelli and Quacquarelli
(1972a): Chloroform-butanol followed by differential and density gradient
centrifugation. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 117 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 92 S <M>. (79)
Density 1.486 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.416 g cm3 in CsCl <M>. (84) Virions
contain 40 % nucleic acid <B>, or 31 % nucleic acid <M>. (85) Virions 60 %
protein <B>, or 69 % protein <M>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.6 kb. (92)
Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.2 kb. (94) The 2nd
largest 4.4 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12273. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): X15163 Em(40)_vi:GCMVRNA2 Gb(84)_vi:GCMVRNA2 Hungarian grapevine
chrome mosaic virus RNA 2. 9/93 4,441bp. X15346 Em(40)_vi:GCMVRNA1
Gb(84)_vi:GCMVRNA1 Hungarian grapevine chrome mosaic nepovirus RNA1 sequence.
9/93 7,212bp. 2 sequences. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cacao necrosis (Kenten,
1972) and tomato black ring viruses (Kerlan et al., 1982), but distantly.
(184) Distorting and chromogenic strains are antigenically close (Martelli et
al., 1965). An isolate of chrome mosaic virus has been associated with celery
yellow vein disease. (187) Brault, V., Hibrand, L., Candresse, T., Le Gall, O.
and Dunez, J. (1989). Nucl. Acid Res. 17: 7809. Le Gall, O., Candresse, T.,
Brault, V. and Dunez, J. (1989). Nucl. Acid Res. 17: 7795. Hollings, M.,
Stone, O.M. and Martelli, G.P. (1969). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1968,
p. 102. Kenten, R.H. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 119. Kerlan, C., Mille, B.,
Dietenne and Dunez, J. (1982). Annls. Virol. Inst. Pasteur 133E: 3. Kolber,
M., Beczner, L., Pacsa, S. and Lehoczky, J. (1985). Phytopathol. Medit. 24:
135. Lehoczky, J. (1985). Phytopathol. Medit. 24: 129. Lehoczky, J. and
Sarospataki (1967). Acta Phytopath. Acad. Sci. Hung. 2: 309. Mali, V.R.
(1976). Indian Phytopath. 26: 363. Martelli, G.P. (1965). Proc. Int. Conf.
Virus Vector Peren. Hosts, Univ. Cal. Agr. Sci., Davis, 402. Martelli, G.P.
and Quacquarelli, A. (1972a). Annls. Phytopath. hors series 1972, 123.
Martelli, G.P. and Quacquarelli, A. (1972b). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
103, 4 pp. Martelli, G.P., Quacquarelli, A. and Lehoczky, J. (1965). Proc.
Int. Conf. Virus Vector Peren. Hosts, Univ. Cal. Agr. Sci., Davis, 389. Russo,
M., Martelli, G.P. and Savino, V. (1982). Proc. 7th Meeting ICVG, Niagara
Falls 1980, 251. Saric, A. and Hranuelli (1979). Proc. Conf. Excoriosis Virus
Dis. Grapevine, Mostar 1977, 149.


Grapevine corky bark-associated (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt (1995). (3) Standard acronym: GCBaV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 17.0.1.T.U.03. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Beukman and Goheen (1996). (13) Vitis vinifera in intolerant
cultivars, delayed bud opening, reduced vigour and yield, swelling of trunk
and, sometimes, thick and rough spongy bark; woody cylinder of rootstock
and/or scion pitted and/or grooved. Some cultivars and rootstocks are tolerant
and produce no symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (18) Transmitted by Psyllidae. (24) Not transmitted by Planococcus
ficus. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (38) Spreads in the African region. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Vitis berlandieri × Conderc 1613 (LN33) swelling of
basal internodes due to proliferation of secondary phloem, and stem grooving.
Vitis berlandieri × V. riparia (Kober SBB) symptomless. Vitis rupestris stem
grooving. (45) Vitis vinifera (LN33) and V. rupestris. (47) Vitis berlandieri
× Conderc 1613, or Vitis berlandieri × V. riparia, or Vitis rupestris, or
Vitis vinifera. (50) Vitidaceae <4/4>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 1400-2000 nm. (179) <Possible>
Closterovirus. (187) Beukman, E.F. and Goheen, A.C. (1966). Proc. Int. Conf.
Virus Vectors Perenn. Hosts and Vitis, Davis 1965, p.164. Candresse, T. and
Martelli, G.P. (1995). Arch. Virol., Suppl. 10: 461. Frison, A.E. and Ikin, R.
(1991). FAO/IBPGR Tech. Guidelines for Safe Mut of Grapevine Germplasm, p.28.
FAO/IBPGR, Rome. Graniti, A. and Martelli, G.P. (1966). Proc. Int. Conf. Virus
Vectors Perenn Hosts and Vitis, Davis 1965, p.168. Namba, S., Boscia, D.,
Azzam, O., Maixner, M., Hu, J.S., Golino, D. and Gonsalves, D. (1991). Proc.
10th Meeting I.C.V.G., Volos 1990, p.10. Savino, D., Boscia, D. and Martelli,
G.P. (1989). Proc. 9th Meeting, I.C.V.G., Kiryat Anavim 1987, p.91. Tanne, E.,
Ben-Dov, Y. and Raccah, B. (1989). Phytoparasitica 17: 55.


Grapevine fanleaf nepovirus

      (1) G.P. Martelli, 1987; S.A. Holland, 1986. (2) Synonyms: grapevine
arricciamento virus, grapevine court noué virus, grapevine infectious
degeneration virus, grapevine Reisigkrankheit virus, grapevine roncet virus,
grapevine urticado virus. (3) Standard acronym: GFLV. (4) Strains: Fanleaf
strain (Hewitt, 1950b); yellow mosaic strain (Hewitt, 1950a) and Dias (1950);
veinbanding strain (Goheen and Hewitt, 1962) and Martelli and Hewitt (1963a).
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.016. (8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9)
From Austria. (10) By Rathay (1883). (11) Symptoms persist and vary
seasonally. (13) Vitis vinifera, V. rupestris and many other Vitis spp. and
interspecific hybrids systemic green or yellow mosaic, ring and line patterns
and flecks, leaf and nodal malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Xiphinema index (Hewitt et al.,
1958) and X. italiae (Cohn et al., 1970). (29) Virus does not require a helper
virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <rarely if ever
transmitted to embryos of Vitis vinifera, virus abundant in endosperm of
infected viruses but not in embryo. Transmitted by seed in Chenopodium
amaranticolor (Dias, 1963), C. quinoa (Brückbauer and Rüdel, 1961a), Glycine
max (Cory and Hewitt, 1968>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen <although
found in pollen of Vitis>. (36) Studies reported by Martelli (1978); Raski et
al. (1983); Esmenjavd (1983). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in all
areas where Vitis vinifera and American hybrid rootstocks are grown>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Vitis spp. green or yellow systemic
mosaic, rings, line patterns and flecks. Chenopodium amaranticolor and C.
quinoa systemic mottling and leaf malformation. Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Bountiful systemic chlorotic or necrotic mosaic, mottling,
flecking or ringspots. Immune to some strains. Gomphrena globosa systemic
chlorotic spots, leaves twisted. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mottling, leaf
malformation, stunting. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mottling and stunting.
(45) Chenopodium amaranticolor; C. quinoa; Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus
vulgaris. Good sources for virus purification are C. quinoa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. benthamiana. G. globosa is good for maintaining cultures. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (W); Gomphrena globosa (W); Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Bountiful (W). No satisfactory local lesion hosts are known. (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna unguiculata, or Vitis, or Vitis labrusca, or Vitis rupestris, or
Vitis vinifera. (48) Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Poncirus trifoliata, or Prunus americana × P. salicina, or Prunus armeniaca,
or Prunus cerasifera, or Prunus domestica, or Prunus mahaleb, or Prunus
persica, or Prunus serrulata, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus occidentalis. (50)
Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <10/10>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <9/9>, or Vitidaceae <4/4>.
(51) Rosaceae <9/9>, or Rutaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/9>. (53) Brückbauer
and Rüdel (1961b); Cadman et al. (1960); Dias (1963); Martelli and Hewitt
(1963a); Taylor and Hewitt (1964); Vuittenez (1963). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55)
LIV: 15-30 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4 <Brückbauer and Rüdel,
1961b; Cadman et al., 1960; Dias, 1963; Taylor and Hewitt, 1964>. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Dias and Harrison (1963); Martelli and
Hewitt (1963b); Taylor and Hewitt (1964). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 120 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 86 S <M>, or 50 S
<T>. (79) Density 1.49 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.41 g cm3 in CsCl <M>, or 1.31 g
cm3 in CsCl <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.67 <B>,
or 1.58 <M>, or 0.73 <T; Quacquarelli et al., 1976>. (84) Virions contain 42 %
nucleic acid <B>, or 30 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 58 % protein <B>, or 70 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 11.116 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
<the larger> 7.342 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.774 kb <Quacquarelli et al.,
1976>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Diener and Schneider (1968);
Quacquarelli et al. (1972; 1976): single-phase phenol/SDS; freezing and
thawing or heating for 90 secs at 66°C. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12274. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D00915 Em(40)_vi:GFLRNA1
Gb(84)_vi:GFLRNA1 Grapevine fanleaf virus (GFLV) RNA1 for polyprotein. 4/94
7,342bp. S38553 Em(40)_vi:S38553 Gb(84)_vi:S38553 RNA1=VPg (253K polyprotein)
grapevine fanleaf nepovirus, Genomic RNA, 84 nt. 1/94 84bp. X16907
Em(40)_vi:NEGFLVR2 Gb(84)_vi:NEGFLVR2 Grapevine Fanleaf virus (GFLV-F13) RNA2
encoding capsid protein. 9/93 3,774bp. X60775 Em(40)_vi:GVFVCP
Gb(84)_vi:GVFVCP Grapevine fanleaf virus genomic RNA for capsid protein. 10/91
2,305bp. U11768 Em(43)_vi:Gf11768 Gb(89)_vi:U11768 Grapevine fanleaf virus
coat protein gene, partial cds. 10/94 1,515bp. U11770 Em(43)_vi:Gf770
Gb(89)_vi:Gfu11770 Grapevine fanleaf virus RNA2, deletion mutant. 10/94 501bp.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 54000 <Quacquarelli et al., 1976>. (145)
Method of preparation: Agrawal and Tremaine (1972): boil in presence of 1%
SDS, 1% 2-mercaptoethanol and 4 M urea. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus <Morris-Krsinich et al., 1983>. (171) Virions found in roots,
mesophyll and vascular parenchyma in herbaceous hosts or grapevines (Gerola et
al., 1969; Saric and Wrischer, 1975; Kalasjan et al., 1979). (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm, or in nuclei <where empty capsids may accumulate (Savina
et al., 1985)>. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are membranous bodies and unusual in shape <crystalline aggregates in the
cytoplasm and tubules>. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: leaf deformations that are open marginal, petiolar sinuses and
prominent marginal teeth. Canes have unevenly spaced or double nodes and are
flat. Cell walls have outgrowths (Saric and Wrischer, 1975; Kalasjan et al.,
1979) and trabeculae in phloem and xylem tissues (Gifford et al., 1956). (179)
Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: different strains of grapevine fanleaf virus
are antigenically close (Cadman et al., 1960; Barabino, 1963; Dias and
Harrison, 1963; Martelli and Hewitt, 1963b; Taylor and Hewitt, 1964), and all
are distantly related to arabis mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: tomato ringspot and tobacco ringspot viruses.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: serology must be used to identify fanleaf
virus. Seedlings or rooted cuttings of V. vinifera and V. rupestris are good
bait plants in studies with nematode vectors. (187) Agrawal, H.D. and
Tremaine, J.H. (1972). Virology 47: 8. Barabino, G. (1963). Hort. Res. 3: 27.
Bercks, R. (1968). Weinb. Kell. 14: 151. Bovey, R., Brugger, J.J. and Gugerli,
P. (1982). Proc. 7th Meeting ICVG, Niagara Falls 1980, p. 251. Brückbauer, H.
and Rüdel, M. (1961a). Wein-Wiss. 16: 177. Brückbauer, H. and Rüdel, M.
(1961b). Wein-Wiss. 16: 197. Cadman, C.H., Dias, H.F. and Harrison, B.D.
(1960). Nature, Lond. 187: 577. Cohn, E., Tanne, E. and Nitzany, F.E. (1970).
Phytopathology 60: 181. Cory, L. and Hewitt, W.B. (1968). Phytopathology 58:

Grapevine fleck virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: grapevine marbrure virus (Vuittenez
et al., 1966), grapevine phloem-limited isometric virus (Boulila et al.,
1990). (3) Standard acronym: GFkV. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.4.005. (8)
First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From France. (10) By Vuittenez et al.
(1966). (13) Vitis vinifera symptomless infection in most European cultivars
and American Vitis species and their hybrids. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in
South Africa. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in European
countries and the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Vitis
rupestris scattered clearing of veinlets and leaf deformation with severe
strains. (45) Vitis rupestris. (47) Vitis rupestris, or Vitis vinifera. (50)
Vitidaceae <2/2>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 30 nm in diameter. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: by grafting to Vitis
vinifera and serological methods (ELISA and ISEM). (187) Boscia, D., Martelli,
G.P., Savino, V. and Castellano, M.A. (1991). Vitis (in press). Boulila, M.,
Boscia, D., di Terlizzi, B., Castellano, M.A., Minafra, A., Savino, V. and
Martelli, G.P. (1990). J. Phytopath. 129: 151. Engelbrecht, D.J. and Kasdorf,
G.G.F. (1990). Phytophylactica 22: 347. Hewitt, W.B., Goheen, A.C., Cory, L.
and Luhn, C. (1972). Annls. Phytopath. 23: 43. Vuittenez, A., Legin, R. and
Kuszala, J. (1966). Annls. Épiphyt. 17: 67.


Grapevine leafroll-associated (?) closteroviruses

      (1) A.A. Brunt 1995. (3) Standard acronym: GLRaV-1, GLRaV-2, GLRaV-3,
GLRaV-4, GLRaV-5. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.U.04. (13) Five viruses,
designated grapevine leafroll-associated 1,2,3,4 and 5 closteroviruses have
been associated with grapevine leafroll disease (Candresse and Martelli,
1995), but none has been fully characterized. Vitis vinifera rolling and
discoloration of leaves (reddish-purple in red-fruited, and yellowish in
white-fruited cultivars), especially conspicuous in mate summer and early
autumn in intolerant cultivars. Symptomless infection in some American Vitis
spp. and hybrids. (17) Transmitted by Pseudococcus longispinus, Planococcus
ficus (GLRaV3). (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (43) Vitis vinifera cvs Cabernet, Pinot Noir, Mission, Gamay
leafrolling and discoloration. (47) Vitis vinifera. (50) Vitidaceae <1/1>.
(61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of
1800-2200 nm. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 38404. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): X75448 Em(40)_vi:GVBMPCP Gb(84)_vi:GVBMPCP Grapevine virus B genomic
RNA for MP and CP genes. 5/94 2,161bp. U22158 Gb(89)_vi:Glu22158 Grapevine
leafroll associated virus type III p20 protein, partial cds. 3/95 1,012bp.
U22170 Em(43)_vi:Gl22170 Gb(89)_vi:Glu22170 Grapevine leafroll associated
virus RNA6 gene, partial cds. 5/95 965bp. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus.
(187) Candresse, T. and Martelli, G.P. (1995). Arch. Virol., Suppl. 10: 461.
Goheen, A.C., Harmon, F.N. and Weinberger, J.H. (1958). Phytopathology 48: 51.
Gugerli, P., Brugger, J.J. and Bovey, R. (1984). Rev. Suisse Vitic. Arb. Hort.
16; 299. Hu, J.S., Gonsalves, D. and Teliz, D. (1990). J. Phytopathology 128:
1. Mossop, D.W., Elliot and Richards (1985). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 28: 419
Rezaian, M.A., Krake, L.R., Canying, Q. and Hazzalin, C.A. (1991). J. Virol.
Methods 31: 325. Rosciglione, B. and Gugerli, P. (1989). Proc. 9th Meeting
I.C.V.G., Kiryat Anavim 1987, p.67. Tanne, E., Ben-Dov, Y. and Raccah, B.
(1989). Proc. 9th Meeting I.C.V.G., Kiryat Anavim 1987, p.71. Teliz, D.,
Tanne, E., Gonsalves, D. and Zee, F. (1987). Plant Dis. 71: 704. Zimmermann,
D., Bass, P., Legin, R. and Walter, B. (1990). Phytopathology 130: 205. Faoro,
F., Tornaghi, R., Cinquanta, S. and Belli, G. (1992). Riv. Pat. Veg. SV 2: 67.


Grapevine line pattern (?) ilarvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.T.DE.4. (8) First
reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Hungary. (10) By Lehoczky et al. (1989).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vitis vinifera chlorotic spots, blotches, rings or
line patterns. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Hungary. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local
lesions, systemic mottle. (45) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa. (46)
Cucumis sativus (W), Nicotiana glutinosa (W). (47) Cucumis sativus, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Vitis vinifera. (50) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>, or Vitidaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 24 nm in diameter. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae

Castellano, M.A., Beczner, L. and Farkas, G. (1989). Proc. 9th Meeting ICVG,

Grapevine stem pitting associated closterovirus

      (1) S. Holland, 1986. (2) Synonyms: grapevine virus A, grapevine corky
bark virus, grapevine stem-pitting virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.DE.3.
(8) First reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Taranto, Italy. (10) By
Ciccarone (1961). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vitis vinifera pits and grooves
in trunk and legno riccio, rugose wood, possibly caused. (14) Transmitted by a
vector <very rarely>. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by
Pseudococcidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <only to
Nicotiana glutinosa>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Rosciglione et
al. (1983). (38) Spreads in the Middle East. (39) Spreads in Italy, South
Africa, and the USA <California>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Vitis rupestris var. rupestris cv. St. George pits and grooves in trunk. (45)
Nicotiana glutinosa. (47) Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Vitis labrusca, or Vitis rupestris, or Vitis rupestris var. rupestris <cv. St.
George>, or Vitis vinifera. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Nicotiana glutinosa. (50) Solanaceae <2/2>, or Vitidaceae <4/4>.
(51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/2>. (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 4-5
days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <when
isolated from Nicotiana clevelandii>. (59) Electron microscopy: when stained
in UA the pitch of the basic helix can be measured. (60) Method: Milne et al.
(1980). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 800
nm. (71) Virions 11-12 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic
helix 3.7 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations <in
CsCl>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Boccardo and D'Aquilo (1981). (100) Base
composition 28.4 % G. (101) Base composition 24.4 % A. (102) Base composition
24.9 % C. (103) Base composition 22.3 % U. (112) Additional factor not
required for infectivity. (145) Method of preparation: Boccardo and D'Aquilo
(1981). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in phloem, but are very difficult to extract from host tissue. (179)
Closterovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: citrus
tristeza virus, but distantly (Conti et al., 1980). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: apple chlorotic leafspot, beet yellows,
carnation yellow fleck, heracleum latent, lilac chlorotic leafspot, apple stem
grooving and potato T viruses. (187) Boccardo and D'Aquilo (1981). J. gen.
Virol. 53: 179. Ciccarone (1961). Hort. Agric. 98: 901. Conti, M. (1980).
Rosciglione, B. (1983). Vitis 22: 331.


Grapevine stunt virus

      (1) S. Yamashita, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.18. (8) First
reported in Vitis vinifera. (9) From Japan, in Okayama Prefecture. (10) By
Namba et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms leaf rolling
and stunting in spring. (13) Vitis vinifera, V. thunbergii leaf rolling and
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector and means not involving a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Arboridia apicalis. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Yamashita: control by vector insect control and use of virus-free
stock for grafting. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show leaf rolling and stunting.
(43) Vitis vinifera cv. Campbell Early, V. thunbergii leaf rolling and
stunting. (45) Vitis vinifera cv. Campbell Early. (47) Vitis thunbergii, or
Vitis vinifera. (48) Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea
var. capitata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum melongena, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Vitidaceae <2/2>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <8/8>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Hatamoto et al. (1982). (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Namba et al. (1981 and 1986). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Are small vesicles containing fibrous material in the cytoplasm and
vacuole. (178) Other cellular changes: phloem necrosis, development of small
vesicles and the accumulation of starch grains in chloroplasts in the
mesophyll cells. (179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: induction
of characteristic symptoms in Vitis vinifera cv. Campbell Early and Vitis
thunbergii and leafhopper transmission. (187) Hatamoto, M., Fujii, S., Namba,
S., Yamashita, S. and Doi, Y. (1982). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 48: 396.
Namba, S. (1983). In: "Handbook of Plant viruses in Japan", p. 344. Eds K.
Yora, Y. Saito, Y. Doi, T. Inouye and K. Tomaru. Asakura Shoten, Japan. Namba,
S., Iwanami, T., Yamashita, S. and Doi, Y. (1986). A.A.T.C. Tech. Bull. 33:
109. Namba, S., Yamashita, S., Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1981). Ann. Phytopath.
Soc. Japan 47: 137.


Groundnut chlorotic spot (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.06. (8) First
reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From Ivory Coast. (10) By Fauquet et al.
(1985). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea chlorotic spotting and
mottling, ring spotting and line patterns in young leaves and green
vein-banding in older leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora and A. spiraecola. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis. (43) Arachis hypogaea.
Chenopodium amaranticolor red necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Physalis
floridana green systemic mosaic. Nicotiana benthamiana leaf malformation.
Nicotiana megalosiphon systemic chlorotic spotting. (45) Arachis hypogaea,
Nicotiana megalosiphon, Physalis floridana. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor
(L). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Physalis floridana. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<3/3>. (53) Fauquet et al. (1985). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 5 days <at
24°C>, or 14 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: Fauquet et al. (1985). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 456 nm <±22>. (71) Virions 13 nm wide
<±1>. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) <Possible>
Potexvirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cactus X,
clover yellow mosaic, cymbidium mosaic, dioscorea latent, narcissus mosaic,
papaya mosaic, potato X and white clover mosaic viruses. (186) The virus
differs from better characterised potexviruses in being transmitted in the
non-persistent manner by aphids. (187) Fauquet, C., Thouvenel, J.-C. and
Fargette, D. (1985). C.r. hebd. Seanc. Acad. Sci., Paris, Serie III No. 17:
773.


Groundnut eyespot potyvirus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: GEV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.027. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea (unnamed cultivar). (9)
From Korhogo, North of the Ivory Coast. (10) By Dubern and Dollet (1978). (13)
Arachis hypogaea dark green spots with chlorotic halos and dark green line
patterns on leaflets. Physalis floridana mild mosaic leaf symptoms. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis craccivora. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (45)
Arachis hypogaea, Physalis floridana. (46) No suitable local lesion host.
Arachis hypogaea cv. Te3 (W) used for in vitro properties and host range
studies. A. hypogaea or Physalis floridana used as source for purification.
(47) Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Cajanus
cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Clitoria ternatea, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Macroptilium
lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Oryza sativa, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum nigrum, or Trifolium repens, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/10>, or
Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/10>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae
<11 /14>. (52) Dioscoraceae and Passifloraceae not susceptible. (53) Dubern
and Dollet (1980). (54) TIP: 44 °C. (55) LIV: 0.125 days <3 hours>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Dubern and
Dollet (1980). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 755 nm. (71) Virions 12.5 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (84) Virions contain 5.5-6.5 % nucleic acid <from
A260/A280 ratio (Layne 1977)>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host
plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: guinea grass mosaic, iris fulva mosaic,
passionfruit ringspot, pepper veinal mottle (Ivory Coast and Ghana strains)
and wisteria vein mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: pepper mottle, bean common mosaic, soybean mosaic, bean yellow
mosaic, bidens mottle, clover yellow vein, Colombian datura virus, blackeye
cowpea mosaic, henbane mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, lettuce mosaic, parsnip
mosaic, pea seed-borne mosaic, peanut mottle, potato A, potato Y, sugarcane
mosaic, ryegrass mosaic, tobacco etch, turnip mosaic and yam mosaic viruses.
(187) Dubern, J. (1981). Phytopath. Z. 100: 237. Dubern, J. and Dollet, M.
(1978). Oleagineux 33: 175. Dubern, J. and Dollet, M. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol.
96: 193. Layne, E. (1977). In: Methods in Enzymology Vol. 3, p. 447; ed. S.P.
Colowick and N.O. Kaplan. Academic Press, New York.


Groundnut ringspot (?) tospovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal code 11.0.5.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From South Africa. (10) By Klesser (1966).
(13) Arachis hypogaea ringspots in leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Frankliniella occidentalis. (18)
Transmitted by Thysanoptera. (39) Spreads in Argentina, Brazil, and South
Africa. (47) Arachis hypogaea. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 12675. (179) <Possible> Tospovirus: Bunyaviridae. (180) :
Bunyaviridae. (187) De Avila, A.C., Huguenot, R., Resende, R. de O., Kitajima,
E.W., Goldbach, R.W. and Peters, D. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 2801. De Avila,
A.C., de Haan, P., Kitajima, E.W., Kormelink, R., Resende, R. de O., Goldbach,
R.W. and Peters, D. (1992). J. Phytopathology 134: 133. De Avila, A.C., de
Haan, P., Kormelink, R., Resende, R. de O., Goldbach, R.W. and Peters, D.
(1993). J. gen. Virol. 74: 153. Dewey, R.A., Semorile, L., Grau, O., de Avila,
A.C. and Kitajima, E.W. (1995). J. Phytopathology 143: in press. Klesser, P.J.
(1966). S. Afr. J. agric. Sci. 9: 711.


Groundnut rosette assistor luteovirus

      (1) R. Hull, 1981. Revised by D.V.R. Reddy in 1989. (3) Standard
acronym: GRAV. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in
Arachis hypogaea (groundnut rosette disease). (9) From Tanzania and later in
Malawi, Zimbabwe and Nigeria. (10) By Zimmerman (1907). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Arachis hypogaea symptomless infection. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A.
gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (29) Virus can help the vector transmission of another virus
<groundnut rosette (?) umbravirus>. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Storey and Bottomley (1928);
Storey and Ryland (1955); Davies (1975); Adams (1967); Gibbons (1977); Reddy
(1984). (38) Spreads in the African region <in those countries south of the
Sahara. It is the most important virus disease of groundnuts in Africa>. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in India and the Phillipines. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Arachis hypogaea latent. (45) Arachis
hypogaea. (46) Arachis hypogaea (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (53) Zimmerman (1907); Hull (1972). (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Rajeshwari and Murant (1988). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (81)
Density in caesium sulphate 1.34. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.9 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.9 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Rajeshwari and Murant (1988). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 33761.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): S54327 Em(40)_un:S54327
Gb(84)_vi:S54327 nucleoprotein (S RNA) groundnut ringspot virus, isolate SA05,
Genomic RNA, 928 nt. 3/93 92 1 sequence. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found
in the virions. (121) Is of an unusual type of structure. (122) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in virions and are groundnut rosette virus nucleic acid and
its satellite RNA. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24000. (148) Virion
proteins not glycosylated. (150) Virion proteins not phosphorylated. (164)
Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in roots and phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bean leaf roll, beet western yellows and potato leafroll viruses.
(184) A MAb for the virions of potato leafroll virus reacted with those of
groundnut rosette assistor virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serology
using luteovirus antisera. (187) Hull, R. (1967). Ann. appl. Biol. 60: 199.
Hull, R. (1968). Ann. appl. Biol. 62: 139. Hull, R. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol.
71: 135. Murant, A.F. (1989). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 345, 4 pp.
Rajeshwari, R. and Murant, A.F. (1988). Ann. appl. Biol. 112: 403. Zimmerman,
A. (1907). Pflanzer 3: 129.


Groundnut rosette umbravirus

      (1) D.V.R. Reddy, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: GRV. (4) Strains:
Different diseases called groundnut chlorotic rosette, groundnut green rosette
and groundnut mosaic rosette caused by complexes of different strains of the
virus, its assistor luteovirus and satellite RNAs. (5) ICTV decimal code
78.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From Tanzania. (10)
By Zimmerman (1907). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea, different
isolates give: chlorotic rosette faint mottling of youngest leaflets, then
yellowing, curling and malformation of leaflets, some veinbanding and
blotching. green rosette mild mottling and flecking, but mostly dark green,
severe stunting. mosaic rosette green blotching and severe chlorosis, but less
severe rosetting than with green rosette. There are three components
associated with all three rosette diseases; 1) Groundnut rosette assistor
virus (GRAV): a luteovirus which gives no overt symptoms in groundnut. 2)
Groundnut rosette virus: a virus with a single-stranded RNA genome, which
becomes packaged in the GRAV virions, and thus depends on GRAV for aphid
transmission, but produces no overt symptoms in groundnut. 3) Groundnut
rosette satellites: satellite RNAs that control the symptoms and cause the
different types of rosette (chlorotic, green and mosaic). (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus requires, for vector
transmission, a helper virus <groundnut rosette assistor luteovirus>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Storey and Bottomley (1928);
Storey and Ryland (1955); Davies (1975); Adams (1967); Gibbons (1977); Reddy
(1984). (38) Spreads in the African region <in all countries south of the
Sahara>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii
necrotic rings, then systemic curling and malformation. Arachis hypogaea see
`Natural host and symptoms`. (44) Cucurbita pepo cv. Eyes, Pisum sativum,
Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Black turtle soup, Bountiful, Great Northern and Pinto,
Vigna unguiculata. (45) Arachis hypogaea, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. murale (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Arachis
hypogaea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Trifolium incarnatum, or
Trifolium repens. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or
Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Calendula officinalis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna
subterranea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<4/12>, or Solanaceae <4/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/12>, or Malvaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <6 /10>, or Umbelliferae <4/4>. (53) Okusanya and Watson (1966);
Dubern (1980); Reddy et al. (1985). (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by
treatment with diethyl ether. (60) Method: Reddy et al. (1985). (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.9 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.05 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Reddy et al. (1985); Murant et al. (1988). (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor
not required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 47740. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): Z29702 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR1 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR1
Groundnut rosette virus Malawi chlorotic (MC3A) satellite RNA. 2/94 901bp.
Z29703 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR2 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR2 Groundnut rosette virus Malawi
chlorotic (MC3B) satellite RNA. 2/94 901bp. Z29704 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR3
Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR3 Groundnut rosette virus Nigerian green (NG3A) satellite
RNA. 2/94 898bp. Z29705 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR4 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR4 Groundnut
rosette virus Nigerian green (NG3B) satellite RNA. 2/94 899bp. Z29706
Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR5 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR5 Groundnut rosette virus Nigerian mild
(NM3A) satellite RNA. 2/94 896bp. Z29707 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR6 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR6
Groundnut rosette virus Nigerian mild (NM3B) satellite RNA. 2/94 896bp. Z29708
Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR7 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR7 Groundnut rosette virus Nigerian mild
(NM3C) satellite RNA. 2/94 895bp. Z29709 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR8 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR8
Groundnut rosette virus Nigerian mild (NM3D) satellite RNA. 2/94 895bp. Z29710
Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR9 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR9 Groundnut rosette virus Yellow blotch
(YB3A) satellite RNA. 2/94 901bp. Z29711 Em(40)_vi:GRVSATR0 Gb(84)_vi:GRVSATR0
Groundnut rosette virus Yellow blotch (YB3B) satellite RNA. 2/94 902bp. 10
sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
satellite RNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (164) Genome
replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication depends on coinfection with a
helper virus. (167) It requires groundnut rosette assistor virus for aphid
transmission, and the satellite RNA determines the symptoms. (168) Acts as
helper for a satellite virus. (169) Acts as a helper for groundnut satellite
RNA, which has regions of homology with the host DNA, and is 2.7kb. (179)
Umbravirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: diagnostic hosts; gel
electrophoresis of double-stranded RNA. (187) Adams, A.N. (1967). J. agric.
Res. 5: 1. Davies, J.C. (1975). Trop. Agric. 52: 359. Dubern, J. (1980).
Phytopath. Z. 99: 318. Gibbons, R.W. (1977). In: Diseases Pests and Weeds in
Tropical Crops, Groundnut rosette virus, p. 19; ed. P. Dorey. Verlag. Murant,
A.F. et al. (1988). J. gen. Virol. 69: 1479. Okusanya, B.A.M. and Watson, M.A.
(1966). Ann. appl. Biol. 58: 377. Reddy, D.V.R. (1984). In: Compendium of
Peanut Diseases. Amer. Phytopath. Soc. Groundnut rosette virus, p. 51. Reddy,
D.V.R., Murant, A.F. and Duncan, G.H. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 107: 57. Reddy,
D.V.R., Raschke, J.H. and Mayo, M.A. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 107: 65. Storey,
H.H. and Bottomley, A.M. (1928). Ann. appl. Biol. 15: 26. Storey, H.H. and
Ryland, A.K. (1955). Ann. appl. Biol. 43: 423. Zimmerman, A. (1907). Pflanzer
3: 129.


Guar symptomless potyvirus

      (1) G.M. Behncken, 1983. (3) Standard acronym: GSLV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.040. (8) First reported in Cyamopsis tetragonoloba. (9) From
seed stocks from India, Pakistan, U.S.A. (10) By Hansen and Lesemann (1978).
(11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba
mild green mottle or symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to
70% in commercial seeds lots>. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Australia, India, Pakistan and the
U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor
necrotic local lesions. C. quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful chlorotic
local lesions. Glycine soja, Macroptilium lathyroides systemic mosaic.
Macrotyloma uniflorum necrotic local lesions and systemic lethal necrosis.
(46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful (L). (47)
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine soja, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Vigna unguiculata. (48) Chenopodium foetidum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pisum sativum, or Vicia faba. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/8>, or
Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Hansen and Lesemann (1978). (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 760 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels <of the scroll-type>. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: cell wall proliferations and enlarged mitochondria. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Hansen, A.J. and Lesemann,
D.E. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 841.


Guar top necrosis virus

      (1) J.P. Varma, 1981. (4) Strains: type and attenuated. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.DE.19. (8) First reported in Cyamopsis tetragonoloba. (9) From
Lucknow, India. (10) By Verma et al. (1962). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba chlorotic leaf mottling and yellowing, chlorotic
depressions then systemic necrosis and bronzing killing plant. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Glycine max systemic necrosis, starting at tips and
margins of leaves and spreading to whole plant. Phaseolus vulgaris systemic
chlorotic mottling and stippling. Vigna radiata systemic leaf curling and tip
necrosis. V. unguiculata chlorotic local lesions. Datura stramonium chlorotic
mottling, leaves leathery and rough. Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley
systemic mosaic. Petunia × hybrida slight mottle. Solanum nigrum systemic
mosaic, mottle. (45) Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley,
Petunia × hybrida, Solanum nigrum. (46) Glycine max (W), Phaseolus vulgaris
(W), Vigna radiata (W), V. unguiculata (L). (47) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum nigrum, or Vigna radiata,
or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Cucumis sativus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Raphanus sativus, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/7>, or Solanaceae <4/7>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/7>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/7>. (53) Verma et al. (1962). (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55)
LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (179) (Ungrouped). (183) The attenuated
strain causes mottling, leaf malformation and stunting. (187) Verma, G.S.,
Varma, J.P. and Saxena, P.N. (1962). Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. India 32B: 287.


Guinea grass mosaic potyvirus

      (1) J.C. Thouvenel, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: GGMV. (4) Strains:
guinea grass mosaic virus strain B (from maize), guinea grass mosaic virus
strain D (from pearl millet), brachiaria strain (Morales et al., 1994). (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.028. (8) First reported in Panicum maximum. (9)
From the Ivory Coast. (10) By Thouvenel et al. (1976). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Panicum maximum, Pennisetum americanum, Zea mays green mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector <both strains B and D>. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Hysteroneura setariae, Rhopalosiphum maidis. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (29)
Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Brazil, Colombia, and Cote d'Ivoire. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Panicum maximum, Bromus macrostachys systemic green mosaic
(strains A and D). Avena fatua, Eleusine coracana systemic green mosaic
(strain B). Setaria italica, Bromus sterilis systemic green mosaic (strains A
and B). Zea mays systemic green mosaic (strains A, B and D). (44) Dactylis
glomerata, Digitaria sanguinalis, Hordeum vulgare, Oryza sativa, Triticum
durum. (45) Panicum maximum (strain A), Pennisetum americanum (strain D), Zea
mays (strain B). (46) Setaria italica (W) for strains A and B. (47) Avena
fatua, or Bromus macrostachys, or Bromus sterilis, or Echinochloa crus-galli,
or Eleusine coracana, or Panicum maximum, or Pennisetum americanum, or Setaria
italica, or Stenotaphrum secundatum, or Zea mays. (48) Avena sativa, or
Dactylis glomerata, or Digitaria sanguinalis, or Eleusine coracana, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Oryza sativa, or Panicum capillare, or Saccharum officinarum, or
Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum. (50) Gramineae <10/19>. (51) Gramineae
<10/19>. (53) Thouvenel et al. (1976); Lamy et al. (1979); Kukla et al.
(1984). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Thouvenel et al. (1976). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous
<virions straighter in 50mM MgCl2>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length.
(70) Virions of 815 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure.
(74) Basic helix obscure. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.7 <strains A and D>, or
5.3 <strain B>. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32500 <strains A and D>, or
34500 <strain B>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: pepper veinal mottle and yam mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: sugarcane mosaic and maize dwarf mosaic
strains A and B. (183) Specific diagnostic hosts for identification of strain
B (maize strain) are Avena fatua, A. paniculata, A. strigosa, Bromus
macrostachys, Eleusine coracana, E. tocusa, Lolium multiflorum, Panicum
capillare, Sorghum vulgare. (187) Kukla, B., Thouvenel, J.C. and Fauquet, C.
(1984). Phytopath. Z. 109: 65. Lamy, D., Thouvenel, J.C. and Fauquet, C.
(1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 93: 37. Morales, F.J., Castano, M., Velasco, A.C. and
Arroyave, J. (1994). Plant Dis. 78: 425. Thouvenel, J.C., Givord, L. and
Pfeiffer, P. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 954. Thouvenel, J.C., Fauquet, C. and
Lamy, D. (1978). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 190, 3 pp.

Helenium S carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HVS. (4) Strains: Helenium
and Impatiens strains. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported
in Helenium amarum. (9) From Germany. (10) By Kuschki et al. (1978). (11)
Symptoms none. (13) Helenium amarum hybrids, Impatiens holstii no conspicuous
symptoms, but the virus is often found in complex with helenium Y potyvirus in
H. amarum plants with leaf chlorosis and flower breaking. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae
(Impatiens isolate). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Germany and the USA. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa
chlorotic local lesions; systemic veinal chlorosis. Gomphrena globosa,
Tetragonia tetragonioides (Impatiens isolates) local lesions; no systemic
infection. Beta vulgaris ssp. cicla, B. patellaris local symptomless
infection; no systemic infection. (44) Cucumis sativus, Glycine max,
Chrysanthemum segetum, Nicotiana clevelandii, Zinnia elegans. (45) Chenopodium
album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (46) Chenopodium album (L,W), C.
amaranticolor (L,W), C. quinoa (L,W). (47) Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris,

Chenopodiaceae <2/8>, or Compositae <9/10>, or Cruciferae <5/5>, or
Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae <3/3>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HVY. (5) ICTV decimal code

Henbane mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R. Plumb, 1991. (2) Synonyms: hyoscyamus virus I, hyoscyamus virus
III, atropa mild mosaic virus (Govier and Woods, 1971; Harrison and Roberts,
1971). (3) Standard acronym: HMV. (4) Strains: alkekengi strain (HMVA). (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.030. (9) From Bedfordshire, U.K. (10) By Hamilton
(1932). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms mosaics and
malformation. (13) Hyoscyamus niger vein clearing, green/yellow mosaic. Datura
stramonium, D. inermis mosaic, malformation. Physalis alkekengi, Atropa
belladonna mild mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, M. ascalonicus, Aulocorthum
circumflexum, Macrosiphum euphorbiae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Myzus persicae. (24) Not transmitted by
Psylloides hyoscyami. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus
<probably> does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Hamilton
(1937). (39) Spreads in Germany, Hungary, Italy, and the UK. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mild to
severe mosaics, some leaf malformation. (43) Datura stramonium severe mosaic.
Hyoscyamus niger mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cvs White Burley and
Samsun, Physalis floridana mild mosaic. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local
lesions and then mosaic. (44) Amaranthus spp., Cucumis sativus, Spinacia
oleracea, Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc. (46) Nicotiana sylvestris (L and W), Datura stramonium
(W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum `A6' (L).
(47) Atropa belladonna, or Capsicum annuum, or Celosia argentea, or Celosia
cristata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura
inermis, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or

hortensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum

quinoa, or Crambe abyssinica, or Cucumis sativus, or Emilia sagittata, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/8>, or
Solanaceae <23/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/24>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (53) Lovisolo and Bartels
(1970); Salamon (1989). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-3 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Govier and Plumb
(1972). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (69) Virions
with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 800-900 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 160 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.1.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base composition 26 %

composition 18 % U. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (168) Acts as helper
for another virus. (170) Acts as a helper by aiding transmission of potato
aucuba mosaic virus; presumably through a helper component. (171) Virions
found in leaves, mesophyll and the epidermis. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm and pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: mitochondrial aggregates found in some plants.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: potato Y, potato A, tobacco etch and tulip
breaking viruses; Columbian datura and pokeweed mosaic viruses are distantly
related. (187) Bartels, R. (1964). Phytopath. Z. 49: 257. Bartels, R. (1971).

Roberts, F.M. (1939). Proc. Royal Soc. London, B 127: 543.


Heracleum latent trichovirus

      (1) F. Bem, 1988. (2) Synonyms: HV2. (3) Standard acronym: HLV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 76.0.1.T.005. (8) First reported in Heracleum sphondylium. (9)
From the U.K. (10) By Murant and Goold (1972). (13) Heracleum sphondylium,
Apiaceae occurs in hogweed causing no symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii, C.
pastinacae, C. theobaldi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27)
Virus does not multiply in the vector. (29) Virus requires, for vector
transmission, a helper virus <carrot yellow leaf (?) closterovirus>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Bem and Murant (1979); Murant
and Duncan (1984). (39) Spreads in the Netherlands and the UK. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa necrotic local lesions, systemic
epinasty and stunting. C. amaranticolor systemic leaf curling and
vein-clearing. Coriandrum sativum systemic interveinal yellowing or
symptomless. (44) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cvs Samsun and White
Burley, Cyamopsis tetragonoloba. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium
murale (L), C. quinoa (W), Coriandrum sativum (W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus,
or Anethum graveolens, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or Apiaceae, or Apium
graveolens, or Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Browallia speciosa, or
Celosia plumosa, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Daucus carota, or Fedia cornucopiae, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Heracleum sphondylium, or Lycopersicon chilense, or Montia perfoliata, or
Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Scandix pecten-veneris, or
Solanum acaule, or Solanum commersonii, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum
melongena, or Solanum spegazzinii, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Valerianella carinata, or Vigna unguiculata,
or Zea mays. (48) Allium porrum, or Amaranthus hypochondriacus, or Anthriscus
sylvestris, or Apium nodiflorum, or Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica perviridis, or
Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura
metel, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Eryngium planum, or
Foeniculum vulgare, or Fragaria vesca, or Hordeum vulgare, or Levisticum
officinale, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Malus sylvestris, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana forgetiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana knightiana, or Nicotiana paniculata,
or Nicotiana repanda, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum

vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Pimpinella anisum,
