Trifolium pratense, or Triticum vulgare, or Urtica pilulifera, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna mungo, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <10/11>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/3>, or Gramineae <1/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/10>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<7/27>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <9/17>, or Valerianaceae
<2/2>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/11>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or Gramineae <4/5>, or Labiatae <1
/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/10>, or Rosaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae
<20/27>, or Umbelliferae <8/17>, or Urticaceae <1/1>. (53) Bem and Murant
(1979). (54) TIP: 40-50 °C <in Chenopodium quinoa sap, clarified with
bentonite>. (55) LIV: 1-2 days <at 22°C, in C. quinoa sap>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4-5 <in C. quinoa sap>. (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment
with diethyl ether <or abolished>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: intact virions are seen when 2% PTA, pH7 is used, but
disrupted ones seen in AM. (60) Method: Bem and Murant (1979). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 730 nm. (71) Virions 12.5
nm wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.8 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
96 S. (81) Density 1.24 in Cs2SO4. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.9
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.9 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Bem and Murant (1979); Murant et al. (1979).
(108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23500. (134)
Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Bem and Murant (1979). (148) Virion
proteins not glycosylated. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, phloem and companion cells. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Trichovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple
chlorotic leafspot, apple stem grooving, beet yellow stunt, carnation necrotic
fleck, citrus tristeza, beet yellows, lilac chlorotic leaf spot, potato T and
wheat yellow leaf viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: gives epinasty and
stunting in Chenopodium quinoa. (187) Bem, F. and Murant, A.F. (1979). Ann.
appl. biol. 92: 243. Bem, F. and Murant, A.F. (1979). J. gen. Virol. 44: 817.
Murant, A.F. (1983). Abstr. 4th Int. Congr. Pl. Path., p. 121. Murant, A.F.
and Duncan, G.H. (1984). Abstr. 6th Int. Congr. Virol. Sendai, Japan, p. 328.
Murant, A.F. and Goold, R.A. (1972). Rep. Scottish Hort. Res. Inst. 1971, p.
63. Murant, A.F., Taylor, M. and Duncan, G.H. (1979). Rep. Scottish Hort. Res.
Inst. 1978, p. 98.


Hibiscus chlorotic ringspot carmovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. Revised by R. Bonfiglioli and K. Gibb, 1991.
(3) Standard acronym: HCRSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.0.008. (8) First
reported in Hibiscus rosa-sinensis. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Waterworth et
al. (1976). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Hibiscus rosa-sinensis mottling or
chlorotic spots, rings or vein-banding. Very variable. Abelmoschus manihot
mosaic. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (15) Is not
transmitted by Myzus persicae, nor by Epilachna varivestis. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Waterworth
(1980). (39) Spreads in Australia, El Salvador, Fiji, the Solomon Islands,
Thailand, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions, not systemic. Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, Gossypium hirsutum, Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica necrotic
local lesions, not systemic. Hibiscus cannabinus (kenaf) ringspots, local
lesions, then systemic mottle. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto small local
lesions, not systemic. (45) Hibiscus cannabinus for purification. Althaea spp.
and Hibiscus rosa-sinensis for maintaining cultures. (46) Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba (L); Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica (L). Hibiscus cannabinus
(L) is the most sensitive host. (47) Abelmoschus manihot, or Althaea, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Gossypium hirsutum, or
Hibiscus cannabinus, or Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Malvaceae <5/5>. (53) Waterworth et al.
(1976). (54) TIP: 72 °C. (55) LIV: 30 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 8.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Waterworth et al. (1976);
Jones and Behncken (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement <negative stain apparently penetrates
about one virion in five Waterworth et al., 1976; Jones and Behncken, 1980>.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 118 S <Jones and Behncken, 1980; Waterworth et al., 1976>. (79)
Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 14 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 86 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.4 kb. (100) Base composition 23.8 % G.
(101) Base composition 25.5 % A. (102) Base composition 26.4 % C. (103) Base
composition 24.3 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 44100. (134) Coat
protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles <of
broken cells>. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Carmovirus:
Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: 45 viruses with isometric virions (Waterworth et al.,
1976), including okra mosaic virus (Givord and Hirth, 1973) and hibiscus
latent ringspot virus (Brunt et al., 1980). Isolates from the U.S.A. and El
Salvador (Waterworth et al., 1976), Australia (Jones and Behncken, 1980), Fiji
(Brunt, 1980) and Thailand (H.C. Phatak, unpublished data) are serologically
indistinguishable. (184) Hibiscus chlorotic ringspot virus may be related to,
or the same, as an agent that induces a mosaic disease of Hibiscus
rosa-sinensis in Hawaii (Hendrix and Murakishi, 1951). (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: hibiscus chlorotic ringspot virus is just one of several viruses
that infect Malvaceae in nature. Others include (1) okra mosaic tymovirus
which causes a mosaic in Abelmoschus esculentus (Givord and Hirth, 1973). (2)
hibiscus latent ringspot nepovirus which sediments as 3 components and causes
leaf chlorosis in Hibiscus rosa-sinensis (Brunt et al., 1980). (3) malva
yellows luteovirus is an aphid-transmitted virus found in many species that
hibiscus chlorotic ringspot does not infect (Costa et al., 1959). (4)
chlorosis in Malvaceae is caused by abutilon mosaic bigeminivirus and is
transmitted by whitefly (Flores and Silberschmidt, 1967; Costa, 1954). (5)
yellow vein mosaic of Abelmoschus esculentus (bhendi) (Capoor and Varma,
1950), of A. esculentus (okra) and of Gossypium hirstutum (cotton) (Santry and
Singh, 1973). (6) hibiscus line pattern which is not transmissible by sap
inoculation (Wolfswinkel, 1966). (7) leaf curl virus which induces different
symptoms (Makherjie and Raychaudhuri, 1964). (187) Brunt, A.A. (1980).
UNDP/FAO Survey of Plant Virus Diseases in Fiji. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J.,
Phillips, S. and Lana, A.O. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 37. Capoor, S.P. and
Varma, P.M. (1950). Ind. J. agric. Sci. 20: 217. Costa, A.S. (1954). Bragantia
13: 23. Costa, A.S., Duffus, J.E. and Bardin, R. (1959). J. Am. Soc. Sug. Beet
Technol. 10: 371. Flores, E. and Silberschmidt, K. (1967). Phytopath. Z. 60:
181. Givord, L. and Hirth, L. (1973). Ann. appl. Biol. 74: 359. Hendrix, J.W.
and Murakishi, H. (1951). Rep. Hawaii Univ. agric. Exp. Stn 1948-1950, p. 123.
Jones, D.R. and Behncken, G.M. (1980). Aust. Plant Path. 9: 4. Lana, A.O.
(1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr 58: 1040. Mukherjee, A.K. and Raychaudhuri, P. (1964).
Indian J. Hort. 21: 176. Sastry, K.S.M. and Singh, S.J. (1973). Indian
Phytopath. 26: 136. Van Velsen, R.J. (1967). Papua New Guin. agric. J. 19: 10.
Waterworth, H.E. (1980). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 227, 4 pp. Waterworth,
H.E., Lawson, R.H. and Monroe, R.L. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 570.
Wolfswinkel, L.D. (1966). S. Afr. J. agric. Sci. 9: 483.


Hibiscus latent ringspot nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: HLRSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.0.018. (8) First reported in Hibiscus rosa-sinensis. (9) From Ibadan,
Nigeria. (10) By Lana (1974). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection.
(13) Hibiscus rosa-sinensis and H. cannabinus leaf chlorosis but usually
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode
<probably>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed <in limited tests with seed from Nicotiana
clevelandii and Chenopodium quinoa>. (39) Spreads in Italy and Nigeria. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa grey necrotic local
lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium murale necrotic lesions, not systemic. C.
quinoa chlorotic local lesions; systemic chlorosis. Trifolium incarnatum
severe systemic chlorosis. Hibiscus cannabinus systemic leaf chlorosis.
Nicotiana clevelandii systemic leaf chlorosis. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris,
Abelmoschus esculentus (okra), Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Physalis floridana. (45) Hibiscus cannabinus, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46)
Chenopodium murale (L), C. quinoa (L,W), Hibiscus cannabinus (W). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Hibiscus cannabinus, or Hibiscus
rosa-sinensis, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
incarnatum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Adansonia digitata, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica oleracea var.
botrytis, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus roseus,
or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucurbita pepo, or Dahlia pinnata,
or Glycine max, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum indicum, or
Solanum demissum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Theobroma cacao,
or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/7>, or Malvaceae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <7/16>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Bombacaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/7>,
or Malvaceae <1/4>, or Pedaliaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <9/16>, or
Sterculiaceae <1/1>. (53) Brunt et al. (1980). (54) TIP: 65 °C <in Nicotiana
clevelandii sap>. (55) LIV: 21-28 days <in N. clevelandii sap>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4-5 <in N. clevelandii sap>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 132 S <B>. (78)
Of the other(s) 114 S <M>, or 51 S <T>. (79) Density 1.52 g cm3 in CsCl <B>,
or 1.49 g cm3 in CsCl, or 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl <M; unfixed>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.85 <B>, or 1.78 <M; corrected for light scattering>. (84) Virions
contain 42 % nucleic acid <B>, or 38 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid
<T>. (85) Virions 58 % protein <B>, or 62 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>.
(86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 13.2 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 7 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 6.2 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Brunt et al. (1980). (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 53600. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, arracacha A,
artichoke Italian latent, cherry leaf roll, cherry rasp leaf, cacao necrosis,
raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black
ring and tomato ringspot viruses. (187) Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J., Phillips,
S. and Lana, A.O. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 37. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J.
and Phillips, S. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 233, 3 pp. Lana, A.O.
(1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr 58: 1040.


Hibiscus yellow mosaic (?) tobamovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Hibiscus sp. (9) From Japan. (10) By Kashiwazaki et al. (1982).
(13) Hibiscus sp. yellow leaf mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Petunia × hybrida local lesions. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Hibiscus, or Petunia ×
hybrida. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>.
(61) Virions rodshaped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (73) Axial canal 2.3 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.3 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 196 S. (171) Virions
found in leaves and mesophyll. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (179) <Possible> Tobamovirus. (187)
Kashiwazaki, S., Yamashita, S. and Doi, Y. (1982). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan
48: 395.


Hippeastrum mosaic potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1985. (2) Synonyms: amaryllis mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: HiMV. (4) Strains: none reported. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.031. (8) First reported in Hippeastrum hybridum. (9) From Baarn, the
Netherlands. (10) By Kunkel (1922); Brants and van den Heuvel (1965). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Hippeastrum hybridum, H. equestre, Eucharis grandiflora
chlorotic streaking of leaves and flower stalks. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis fabae, A. gossypii,
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in the former
Czechoslovakia, Fiji, Japan, the Netherlands, South Africa, the UK, and the
USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Hippeastrum hybridum
irregular green mosaic on leaves and flower stalks. Chenopodium quinoa
necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Hyoscyamus niger numerous chlorotic
lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii white etched rings or chlorotic
lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi white etched rings or
chlorotic lesions; not systemic. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, Hippeastrum
hybridum, Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Hyoscyamus
niger (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L), Hippeastrum hybridum (W). (47) Chenopodium
quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Eucharis grandiflora, or Hippeastrum
equestre, or Hippeastrum hybridum, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida.
(48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum
annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Cichorium endiva, or Citrullus
lanatus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Dahlia pinnata, or Emilia
sagittata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus
annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Momordica balsamina, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum
melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaryllidaceae <3/3>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Solanaceae <6/14>. (51) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Compositae <7/7>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Polemoniaceae <1 /1>, or Polygonaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <8/14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>.
(53) Brants and van den Heuvel (1965); Jayasinghe and Dijkstra (1979). (54)
TIP: 60 °C <in Hippeastrum hybridum sap>. (55) LIV: 2 days <in H. hybridum
sap>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Brunt (1973); Jayasinghe and Dijkstra (1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 782 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 153 S. (79) Density
1.31 g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.21 <corrected for
scattering>. (84) Virions contain 4.5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95.5 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000.
(145) Method of preparation: Brunt et al. (1975). (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <as
membrane-associated aggregates>. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) And bundles near
the nucleus. (178) Other cellular changes: chloroplasts being smaller in
infected cells. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, carnation
vein mottle, clover yellow vein, iris mild mosaic, lettuce mosaic, tobacco
etch, potato Y and turnip mosaic viruses. Reported relationships with other
potyviruses have not been confirmed (Brunt and Phillips, unpublished results).
(186) Gomphrena globosa and Tetragonia tetragonioides have been reported as
local lesion hosts of hippeastrum mosaic virus, but are not, however they are
susceptible to hippeastrum latent virus, a carlavirus which is closely related
to nerine latent and carnation latent viruses, and which frequently occurs,
together with hippeastrum mosaic virus, in hippeastrums. (187) Brants, D.H.
and van den Heuvel, J. (1965). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 71: 145. Brunt, A.A. (1973).
Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1972, p. 103. Brunt, A.A. (1973). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 117, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J., Tremaine, J.H.
and Stace-Smith, R. (1975). J. gen. Virol. 27: 101. Iwaki, M. (1967). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 33: 237. Jayasinghe, U. and Dijkstra, J. (1979). Neth.
J. Pl. Path. 85: 47. Kunkel, L.O. (1922). Science 55: 73.


Holcus lanatus yellowing (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HLYV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.021. (8) First reported in Holcus lanatus. (9) From Italy. (10) By
Amici et al. (1978). (13) Holcus lanatus clear leaf chlorosis. (47) Holcus
lanatus. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (179)
<Possible> unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Amici, A.,
Faoro, F. and Tornaghi, R. (1978). Riv. Patol. Veg. 14: 85.


Holcus streak (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.042. (8) First reported in Holcus mollis and Holcus lanatus. (9) From
Wales, U.K. (10) By Catherall and Chamberlain (1975). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Holcus lanatus, H. mollis yellow streaking of younger leaves and rusty
brown streaks and mottle of flag leaves. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in the UK <Wales>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Holcus lanatus, H. mollis, Avena sativa, A. strigosa, Bromus
mollis, B. macrostachys, Phalaris paradoxa grey or chlorotic leaf streaking.
(45) Holcus lanatus, H. mollis. (46) Holcus lanatus (W), H. mollis (W), Avena
sativa (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Avena strigosa, or Bromus macrostachys, or
Bromus mollis, or Holcus lanatus, or Holcus mollis, or Phalaris paradoxa. (50)
Gramineae <7/7>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Catherall, P.L.
and Chamberlain, J.A. (1975). Pl. Path. 24: 247.


Honeysuckle latent carlavirus

      (1) F.A. van der Meer, 1987. Revised by A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms:
lonicera latent virus (Brunt et al., 1980; Brunt and van der Meer, 1984; Van
der Meer et al., 1980). (3) Standard acronym: HnLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Lonicera japonica, L. periclymenum. (9)
From the U.K. and the Netherlands. (10) By Brunt and Thomas (1976); Van der
Meer et al. (1980). (13) Lonicera americana, L. brownii cvs Dropmore Scarlet,
Fuchsioides and Punica, L. caprifolium, L. heckottii cv. Goldflame, L. henryi,
L. japonica cvs Halliana and Reticulata, L. periclymenum cvs Belgica, Belgica
Elect and Seotina, L. telmanniana symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Hydaphis foeniculi. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <but not between plants of Lonicera species>. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Brunt et al.
(1980) and Van der Meer et al. (1985) showed that honeysuckle plants free of
honeysuckle latent virus can be obtained by rooting small shoots (c. 1 cm
long) from infected plants which have been grown for 68 weeks at alternating
temperatures of 16 hours at 37°C and 8 hours at 26°C (Brunt et al., 1980).
Ecological studies by Van der Meer et al. (1980); (1984). (39) Spreads in the
Netherlands and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show local chlorotic lesions. (43)
Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. occidentalis local lesions and systemic mosaic.
Nicotiana clevelandii faint local lesions and systemic vein chlorosis.
Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local lesions. Gomphrena globosa red local
lesions. Chenopodium quinoa local lesions then systemic mosaic. (44) Nicotiana
tabacum cv. White Burley, N. rustica, Vigna unguiculata, Phaseolus vulgaris.
(45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, N. occidentalis. (46) Chenopodium
murale (L), Nicotiana megalosiphon (L and W), N. occidentalis (L and W). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lonicera americana, or Lonicera
brownii <cvs Dropmore Scarlet, Fuchsioides, Punica>, or Lonicera caprifolium,
or Lonicera heckottii <cv. Goldflame>, or Lonicera henryi, or Lonicera
japonica, or Lonicera periclymenum, or Lonicera telmanniana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
occidentalis, or Petunia × hybrida. (48) Beta macrocarpa, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Calendula officinalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum
demissum × S. tuberosum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caprifoliaceae <8/8>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <5/9>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <4/9>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (52) Sap from infected Lonicera does not infect
Chenopodium quinoa, but that from infected Nicotiana megalosiphon does. In
later serial transfers from C. quinoa to C. quinoa the virus becomes adapted
to C. quinoa and causes local lesions and systemic mosaic (Van der Meer et
al., 1980). (53) Brunt et al. (1980); Van der Meer et al. (1980). (54) TIP:
75-85 °C. (55) LIV: 2-8 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Brunt et al. (1980). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm
wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 157 S. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in CsCl. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.12. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 8 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (134) Coat protein.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (179) Carlavirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: shallot latent, poplar mosaic
and possibly red clover vein mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: carnation latent, chrysanthemum B, cowpea
mild mottle, elderberry A, hippeastrum latent, hop latent, lily symptomless,
nerine latent, narcissus latent, passiflora latent, pea streak, potato M,
potato S and white bryony mosaic viruses. (184) Honeysuckle latent virus does
not infect Vigna unguiculata and Phaseolus vulgaris, whereas poplar mosaic
virus induces local lesions in inoculated leaves of these species (Van der
Meer et al., 1980). Honeysuckle latent virus infects Nicotiana clevelandii
systemically (Van der Meer et al., 1980), whereas shallot latent virus does
not (Bos et al., 1978). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: honeysuckle latent
virus may occur in mixed infections with tobacco leaf curl geminivirus (Osaki
et al., 1977), cucumber mosaic virus (Lihnell, 1951; Brunt and Thomas, 1976;
Van der Meer, 1984) or with an unidentified virus with isometric virions
(Huttinga, 1977); honeysuckle latent virus can be distinguished from these by
the size and shape of its virions. (187) Bos, L., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z.
(1978). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 84: 227. Brunt, A.A. and Thomas, B.J. (1976). Rep.
Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1975, p. 124. Brunt, A.A., Phillips, S. and
Thomas, B.J. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 205. Brunt, A.A. and van der Meer, F.A.
(1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 289, 4 pp. Huttinga, H. (1977). Rep.
Res. Inst. Pl. Prot., Wageningen 1976, p. 31. Lihnell, D. (1951).
Vaxteskyddsnotiser 15: 52. Osaki, T., Kobatake, H. and Inouye, T. (1979). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 45: 62. Van der Meer, F.A. (1985). Rep. Res. Inst. Pl.
Prot. Wageningen 1984, p. 35. Van der Meer, F.A., Maat, D.Z. and Vink, J.
(1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 69.


Hop American latent carlavirus

      (1) A.N. Adams, 1986. (2) Synonyms: American hop latent virus, New
Zealand hop virus. (3) Standard acronym: AHLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Humulus lupulus. (9) From Washington
State, U.S.A. (10) By Probasco and Skotland (1976). (13) Humulus lupulus
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus (Phorodon) humuli experimental vector, no information on
natural spread. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38)
Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in the USA. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in the U.K., Germany and Australia where it has
occurred only in recent imports from the U.S.A. and has probably been
eliminated. Also found in New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic and
chlorotic local lesions, systemic veinbanding and mottle. (43) Datura
stramonium necrotic spots and systemic ringspots. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic
spots, systemic vein-banding and mottle. Humulus lupulus usually symptomless,
may show faint chlorotic ringspots. (44) Nicotiana clevelandii. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Datura stramonium (L). (47) Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Humulus lupulus, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vicia faba. (48) Allium cepa, or Avena
sativa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or
Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens. (50) Cannabidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<5/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>, or Solanaceae <2/9>. (51)
Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/7>, or Solanaceae <8/9>. (53) Adams and Barbara
(1982). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Adams and Barbara
(1982). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight <or slightly flexuous>. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 678 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (84) Virions
contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 8.45 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 8.45 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Adams and Barbara (1982).
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33000. (134) Coat. (145) Method of
preparation: Adams and Barbara (1980). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: nerine latent virus (distantly); hop latent, hop mosaic and
chrysanthemum B viruses (very distantly). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: carnation latent, lily symptomless, potato virus S, poplar
mosaic, helenium S and narcissus latent viruses. (187) Adams, A.N. and
Barbara, D.J. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 201. Adams, A.N. and Barbara, D.J.
(1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 483. Barbara, D.J. and Adams, A.N. (1983).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 262, 3 pp. Probasco, E.G. and Skotland, C.B.
(1976). Proc. Am. Phytopath. Soc. 3: 319.


Hop latent carlavirus

      (1) A.N. Adams, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: HpLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.013. (8) First reported in Humulus japonicus, Humulus lupulus. (9)
From Aschersleben, Germany. (10) By Schmidt et al. (1966). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Humulus lupulus systemic chlorotic flecking, but usually
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus (Phorodon) humuli. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China,
and the USA. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in New Zealand.
Probably occurs worldwide as it is latent and planting material of hops has
been distributed to all parts of the world. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) No reliable diagnostic host is known, as most susceptible
plants show no symptoms. (44) Nicotiana clevelandii, which is however
susceptible to hop mosaic carlavirus but shows no symptoms. (45) Humulus
lupulus. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Kinghorn wax (L) local lesions, but
unreliable. (47) Atriplex hortensis, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Humulus japonicus,
or Humulus lupulus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Allium
cepa, or Apium graveolens, or Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum
annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or
Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum melongena, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium pratense, or Vicia faba. (50) Cannabidaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <5/9>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>. (51) Alliaceae
<1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/9>,
or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/7>, or Solanaceae <12 /12>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Probasco and Skotland (1978); Adams and Barbara
(1982). (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <usually>.
(60) Method: Probasco and Skotland (1978); Adams and Barbara (1982). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight
<or slightly flexuous>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 674 nm. (71) Virions 14.4 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
176 S. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 8.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Adams and
Barbara (1982). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33000. (145) Method of
preparation: Adams and Barbara (1980). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: carnation latent, hop mosaic, lily symptomless, nerine latent and
helenium S viruses are moderately related; American hop latent and potato M
viruses are more distantly related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: potato S and poplar mosaic viruses. (187) Adams, A.N. and
Barbara, D.J. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 201. Adams, A.N. and Barbara, D.J.
(1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 483. Barbara, D.J. and Adams, A.N. (1983).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 261, 4 pp. Probasco, E.G. and Skotland, C.B.
(1978). Phytopathology 68: 277.


Hop mosaic carlavirus

      (1) A.N. Adams, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: HpMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.014. (8) First reported in Humulus lupulus. (9) From England. (10) By
Salmon (1923); see Bock (1967). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Humulus lupulus
mosaic, chlorotic vein-banding; infected plants climb poorly. Many cultivars
are symptomless. Urtica urens no symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus (Phorodon) humuli,
Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China,
and the USA. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in New Zealand. Hop
mosaic virus probably occurs worldwide as it is latent, and planting material
of hops has been distributed worldwide. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Humulus lupulus, Wye Golding varieties only chlorotic
vein-banding and mosaic, tendency to fall from the support. Nicotiana
clevelandii symptomless systemic infection. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46)
Nicotiana clevelandii (W) no symptoms. Humulus lupulus Golding varieties (W).
(47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Humulus lupulus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Urtica urens. (48) Ageratum conyzoides, or
Allium cepa, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Atriplex
hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Cajanus cajan, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota,
or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lupinus albus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus albus, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia
× hybrida, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum nigrum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia
faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Cannabidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/7>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/11>, or Solanaceae <2/12>, or Urticaceae
<1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/7>,
or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/11>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10
/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Bock (1967); Adams
and Barbara (1980). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <when from hop, more
when from Nicotiana clevelandii>. (60) Method: Adams and Barbara (1980). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight
<or slightly flexuous>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 651 nm. (71) Virions 13.8 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (84) Virions contain 6 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.5
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8.5 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Adams and Barbara (1980). (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 34000. (145) Method of preparation: Adams and Barbara
(1980). (147) Amino acid composition: Yu and Liu (1987). (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <the plants examined by Macovei
and Titu (1976) were probably also infected with hop latent virus>. (179)
Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: helenium S,
carnation latent and hop latent viruses, but distantly; American hop latent,
nerine latent, lily symptomless, potato S, potato M and poplar mosaic viruses
are very distantly related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: narcissus latent virus. (187) Adams, A.N. and Barbara, D.J. (1980).
Ann. appl. Biol. 96: 201. Barbara, D.J. and Adams, A.N. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 241, 3 pp. Bock, K.R. (1967). Rep. East Malling Res. Stn.
1966, p. 163. Macovei, A. and Titu, H. (1976). Rev. Roum. Biol. Biol. Veg.
(Bucarest) 21: 71. Salmon, E.S. (1923). J. Minist. Agric. 29: 1. Salmon, E.S.
and Ware, W.M. (1928). Ann. appl. Biol. 15: 342. Thresh, J.M., Adams, A.N.,
Barbara, D.J. and Clark, M.F. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol. 87: 57. Yu, J. and Liu,
Y. (1987). Pl. Path. 36: 38.


Hop trefoil 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) E. Luisoni, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HTCV-1. (5) ICTV decimal
code 49.0.3.0.010. (8) First reported in Medicago lupulina; plants grown from
seeds from Poland and Denmark. (9) From Italy. (10) By Boccardo et al. (1987);
Luisoni et al. (1987). (13) Medicago lupulina symptomless. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39)
Spreads in Italy <plants from seeds from Denmark and Poland and presumed
widespread elsewhere>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Medicago
lupulina symptomless. (45) Medicago lupulina. (47) Medicago lupulina. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (53) Boccardo et al. (1987); Luisoni et al.
(1987). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <very few>. (59) Electron
microscopy: use ISEM; to aid adhesion of negative stain use carbon-coated
Formvar films that have been glow-discharged in air at 0.1 torr. (60) Method:
Luisoni et al. (1987). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (79) Density 1.35-1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 3.7
kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
larger> 1.95 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 1.75 kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Boccardo et al. (1985); Luisoni et al. (1987). (179)
Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: alfalfa 1 alphacryptovirus. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: beet 1 and 2, carnation 1, poinsettia,
radish yellow edge, ryegrass, vicia and white clover 3 cryptoviruses. (184) No
serological cross-reaction between the virions of species of the two
cryptovirus groups. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM and decoration may
distinguish between hop trefoil 2 betacryptovirus and hop trefoil 1 and 3
alphacryptoviruses. The detection, by PAGE, of two dsRNAs similar to those of
the virus can confirm serological results. (187) Boccardo, G., Milne, R.G.,
Luisoni, E., Lisa, V. and Accotto, G.P. (1985). Virology 147: 29. Boccardo,
G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171.
Luisoni, E., Milne, R.G., Accotto, G.P. and Boccardo, G. (1987). Intervirology
28: 144.


Hop trefoil 2 betacryptovirus

      (1) E. Luisoni, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HTCV-2. (5) ICTV decimal
code 49.0.4.0.003. (8) First reported in Medicago lupulina. (9) From Italy, in
plants grown from seeds imported from Poland and Denmark. (10) By Boccardo et
al. (1987); Luisoni et al. (1987). (13) Medicago lupulina symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in in Italy, in plants grown from seeds
from Denmark and Poland, probably widespread elsewhere. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (45) Medicago lupulina. (47) Medicago lupulina. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (53) Boccardo et al. (1987); Luisoni et al.
(1987). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <very few>. (59) Electron
microscopy: use ISEM. To aid negative stain adhesion of purified preparations,
it is best to use carbon-coated Formvar-film that has been treated with
glow-discharge in air at 0.1 torr. (60) Method: Luisoni et al. (1987). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 38 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 5.15 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of three parts <in the
mixture hop trefoil cryptic viruses 2 and 3>. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the largest> 2.05 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 1.65 kb <pairs>. (95)
The 3rd largest 1.45 kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Boccardo et al. (1985); Luisoni et al. (1987). (179) Betacryptovirus:
Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: red clover 2 and white clover 2 betacryptoviruses. (184) No
serological relation to alphacryptoviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
ISEM and decoration may distinguish between hop trefoil 2 betacryptovirus and
hop trefoil 1 and 3 alphacryptoviruses. ELISA may be useful but it does not
distinguish between 1, 2 and 3. The detection by PAGE of dsRNAs similar to
those found for the mixture hop trefoil cryptic viruses 2 and 3 can confirm
serology. (187) Boccardo, G., Milne, R.G., Luisoni, E., Lisa, V. and Accotto,
G.P. (1985). Virology 147: 29. Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne,
R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171. Luisoni, E., Milne, R.G., Accotto, G.P.
and Boccardo, G. (1987). Intervirology 28: 144.


Hop trefoil 3 alphacryptovirus

      (1) E. Luisoni, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HTCV-3. (5) ICTV decimal
code 49.0.3.0.011. (8) First reported in Medicago lupulina; in plants grown
from seeds from Poland and Denmark. (9) From Italy. (10) By Boccardo et al.
(1987); Luisoni et al. (1987). (13) Medicago lupulina symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Italy, but probably widespread
elsewhere. (45) Medicago lupulina. (47) Medicago lupulina. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (53) Boccardo et al. (1987); Luisoni et al.
(1987). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <very few>. (59) Electron
microscopy: use ISEM; to aid negative stain adhesion use carbon-coated Formvar
films treated with glow-discharge in air at 0.1 torr. (60) Method: Luisoni et
al. (1987). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.35-1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.15 kb <pairs>.
(92) Genome of three parts <in the mixture hop trefoil cryptic viruses 2 and
3>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 2.05 kb <pairs>. (94) The
2nd largest 1.65 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd largest 1.45 kb <pairs>. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Boccardo et al. (1985); Luisoni et al.
(1987). (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: vicia cryptic virus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: alfalfa 1, beet 1 and 2,
carnation, poinsettia, radish yellow edge, ryegrass and white clover 3
cryptoviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM and decoration may
distinguish between hop trefoil 2 betacryptovirus and hop trefoil 1 and 3
alphacryptoviruses. The detection, by PAGE, of dsRNAs similar to those found
for the mixture hop trefoil cryptic viruses 2 and 3 can confirm serological
results. (187) Boccardo, G., Milne, R.G., Luisoni, E., Lisa, V. and Accotto,
G.P. (1985). Virology 147: 29. Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne,
R.G. (1987). Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171. Luisoni, E., Milne, R.G., Accotto, G.P.
and Boccardo, G. (1987). Intervirology 28: 144.


Hordeum mosaic rymovirus

      (1) W.G. Langenberg and N.L. Robertson, 1991. (3) Standard acronym:
HoMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.2.0.003. (8) First reported in Hordeum
jubatum. (9) From Alberta, Canada. (10) By Slykhuis and Bell (1966). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mottle. (13) Hordeum jubatum, H. vulgare
mottle. (15) Assumed to be transmitted by eriophyid mites. (24) Not
transmitted by Eriophyes tulipae, Abacarus hystrix, Aculus mckenziei,
Rhopalosiphum padi, R. maidis, Macrosiphum (Sitobion) avenae, Myzus persicae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Canada. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic mottles; streaking; stunting; leaf rolling. (43) Avena sativa,
Echinochloa crus-galli, Elymus canadensis, E. trachycaulus, E. virginicus,
Hordeum jubatum, H. vulgare, Lolium multiflorum, Poa palustris, Secale
cereale, Triticum aestivum, T. durum diffuse chlorotic mottle; streaks at base
of young leaves; moderate stunting and inrolling of leaves only with severe
isolates. (44) Elytrigia repens, Lophopyrum elongatum, Elytrigia intermedia,
Bromus inermis, Lolium perenne. (45) Hordeum jubatum, Lolium multiflorum,
Triticum aestivum. (46) Hordeum jubatum (W), Lolium multiflorum (W), Triticum
aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Elymus
canadensis, or Elymus trachycaulus, or Elymus virginicus, or Hordeum jubatum,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium multiflorum, or Poa palustris, or Secale
cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum. (48) Bromus inermis, or
Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Elytrigia repens, or Lolium
perenne, or Lophopyrum elongatum. (50) Gramineae <12/18>. (51) Gramineae
<6/18>. (53) Slykhuis and Bell (1966). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Slykhuis
and Bell (1966). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 701 nm. (71) Virions 15.5 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 8-10 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8-10
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by (Robertson et al., 1990);
polyadenylated full-length RNA genomes were obtained from partially purified
virions with proteinase K and SDS, phenol/chloroform extraction, ethanol
precipitation, and oligod(T) cellulose chromatography. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a VPg. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region the genome has
a poly A tail of at least 33 residues attached to the 3' non-coding region.
(114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 41764. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Slykhuis and Bell (1966).
(152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Langenberg (1991)>. (153) One
protein found. (154) Mr 68000-72000. (155) Pinwheel inclusion protein. (164)
Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the
cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, epidermis and the meristem. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Rymovirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: agropyron mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: oat necrotic mottle, ryegrass mosaic and wheat streak mosaic viruses.
(184) The genomes of hordeum mosaic and agropyron mosaic viruses are 73%
homologous at their 3' termini. (187) Langenberg, W.G. (1991). J. gen. Virol.
72: 493. Langenberg, W.G. and Schroeder, H.F. (1974). J. gen. Virol. 23: 51.
Robertson, N.L., French, R. and Langenberg, W.G. (1990). Phytopathology 80:
1018. Slykhuis, J.T. and Bell, W. (1966). Can. J. Bot. 44: 1191.

      (1) V. Muniyappa. 1983. Revised 1984. Revised 1989 by D.V.R. Reddy. (3)

reported in Macrotyloma uniflorum. (9) From India. (10) By Muniyappa et al.

hirsuta, Macrotyloma uniflorum, Phaseolus lunatus, P. vulgaris, Vigna mungo,

Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted
by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Glycine max systemic mottle, mosaic, pod and seed malformation. Macrotyloma

max (W), Macrotyloma uniflorum (W), Phaseolus lunatus (W), Phaseolus vulgaris

hirsuta, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Phaseolus

Phytopath. 119: 81.


Horseradish latent caulimovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HRLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Armoracia rusticana. (9) From the U.S.A.,
but in plants from Denmark. (10) By Richins and Shepherd (1986). (13)
Armoracia rusticana no conspicuous symptoms in American cultivars. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Denmark. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa local chlorotic lesions; mild
systemic chlorotic mottling and faint chlorotic banding of main veins.
Matthiola incana mild chlorotic mottling of systemically infected leaves. (44)
Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana tabacum,
Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Brassica campestris cv. Just Right. (46) Brassica
campestris cv. Just Right (W). (47) Armoracia rusticana, or Brassica
campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Malus sylvestris, or
Matthiola incana. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica juncea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Cruciferae <6/7>, or Rosaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae
<2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (53) Richins and
Shepherd (1986). (60) Method: Richins and Shepherd (1986). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 50 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 200 S. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular and linear. (91) Total genome size
8.031 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
8.031 kb <pairs>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 40000. (179)
Caulimovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cauliflower
mosaic virus. (187) Richins, R.D. and Shepherd, R.J. (1986). Phytopathology
76: 749. Shalla, T.A., Shepherd, R.J. and Peterson, L.J. (1980). Virology 102:
381.


Humulus japonicus ilarvirus

      (1) A.N. Adams, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HJV (HjV). (5) ICTV decimal
code 10.0.2.09.01. (8) First reported in Humulus japonicus. (9) From the U.K.
in seedlings grown from seed imported from the Peoples Republic of China. (10)
By Adams et al. (1989). (13) Humulus japonicus, H. lupulus symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Adams et al. (1989). (39) Spreads in China <probably;
it was detected by serology in a few samples from China>. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in samples imported to the U.K., but is now thought to
have been eradicated. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, chlorotic mottle or mosaic
in systemic leaves. (43) Chenopodium quinoa necrotic local lesions, systemic
chlorosis and necrosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor pin-point necrotic local
lesions, systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana clevelandii etched necrotic local
lesions, systemic chlorosis and necrosis. (44) Lactuca sativa, Brassica
oleracea, Vigna unguiculata, Nicotiana glutinosa. (45) Chenopodium quinoa.
(46) Chenopodium quinoa (L) and C. amaranticolor (L). (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia cristata, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Helianthus annuus, or
Humulus japonicus, or Humulus lupulus, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Zinnia elegans.
(48) Allium cepa, or Allium porrum, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica oleracea
var. capitata, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum annuum, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Raphanus
sativus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Cannabidaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or
Compositae <2/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <4/7>. (51) Alliaceae
<2/2>, or Compositae <1/3>, or Cruciferae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/7>. (53) Adams et al. (1989). (55) LIV: <less than>
0.25 days. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Adams et al. (1989).
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 24-33 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) Four sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.364 g cm3 in CsCl <fixed with 2% formaldehyde>.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 9.866
kb. (92) Genome of four parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
largest> 3.393 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.958 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.113
kb. (96) The 4th largest 1.099 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Adams
et al. (1989). (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 26350. (145) Method of
preparation: Adams et al. (1989). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae
<subgroup 9>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: prunus necrotic ringspot virus, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: apple mosaic, prune dwarf, American plum line
pattern, tobacco streak, asparagus 2, citrus leaf rugose, citrus variegation,
elm mottle and lilac ring mottle viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: its
only known natural hosts are species of Humulus. Test plant reactions could be
confused with those of prunus necrotic ringspot virus which is widespread in
hops and hence diagnosis is best confirmed by serology. Clear results obtained
with ISEM and decoration. (187) Adams, A.N., Clark, M.F. and Barbara, D.J.
(1989). Ann. appl. Biol. 114: 497.


Hyacinth mosaic potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: HyaMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.044. (8) First reported in Hyacinthus orientalis. (9) From
Bulgaria and Oregon, U.S.A. (10) By Atanasoff (1928); Smith and Brierley
(1944). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Hyacinthus orientalis leaf chlorosis, stem
spotting, occasional flower break. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Macrosiphum
solanifolii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia,
Bulgaria, the Netherlands, the UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Lilium formosanum, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Phaseolus vulgaris, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Hyacinthus
orientalis. (47) Hyacinthus orientalis. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lilium
formosanum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba. (50) Hyacinthaceae
<1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Phillips: extract from infected hyacinth leaves and flower stems by blending
in 0.4 M Na citrate + 0.2 M urea + 10 mM DIECA + 0.2% (w/v) hemicellulase +
0.1% (v/v) mercapto-acetic acid (pH 6.9) (1 g : 4 ml). Incubate at 37°C for 1
hour. Add Triton X-100 (2% v/v of extractant) and stir for 30 minutes. Leave
at 2°C overnight. Filter through cheesecloth and centrifuge (20 minutes at
12,000 g; 75 minutes at 65,000 g). Resuspend pellets in 0.2 M Nacitrate + 0.1
M urea + 0.1% (v/v) mercapto-acetic acid (pH 6.6, 1 ml/1 g of plant material).
Leave at 2°C overnight. Give a second cycle of differential centrifugation and
resuspend pellets in a 33 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.3). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 740 nm. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: ornithogalum
mosaic, scilla mosaic, freesia mosaic and iris severe mosaic viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic,
hippeastrum mosaic, iris mild mosaic, narcissus yellow stripe, onion yellow
dwarf, potato Y, tulip breaking and turnip mosaic viruses. (187) Atanasoff, D.
(1928). Bull. Soc. Bot. Bulgarie 2: 51. Derks, A.F.L.M. and Vink-van den
Abeele, J.L. (1980). Acta Hort. 109: 495. Smith, F.F. and Brierley, P. (1944).
Phytopathology 34: 497.


Hydrangea latent (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HdLV. (5) ICTV decimal code

Hydrangea mosaic ilarvirus

      (1) B.J. Thomas, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: HdMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.2.08.01. (8) First reported in Hydrangea macrophylla. (9) From West
Sussex, U.K. (10) By Thomas et al. (1983). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12)
Symptoms mottles and mosaic. (13) Hydrangea macrophylla light and dark green
mottle and mosaics on leaves. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in U.K. (West Sussex, Guernsey, the Channel Islands). (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
transitory systemic chlorosis. (43) Chenopodium quinoa diffuse chlorotic local
lesions; transitory systemic chlorotic local lesions. Gomphrena globosa,
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii systemic but symptomless. Chenopodium
amaranticolor small chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Beta vulgaris,
Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, Pisum sativum, Vigna unguiculata. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (W). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hydrangea
macrophylla, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica oleracea var.
botrytis, or Chenopodium murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Hydrangeaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/5>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <3/5>. (53) Thomas et al.
(1983). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 21 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: virions are unstable in
phosphate buffer and must be fixed in aldehyde. UA can be used without fixing
purified preparations. (60) Method: Thomas et al. (1983). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28-30 nm in diameter. (65)
Virions 30-38 nm in length. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with
a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 105 S
<(B)>. (78) Of the other(s) 86 and 97 S <;(T) and (M) respectively>. (79)
Density 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl <necessary to fix with aldehydes>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.32 <±0.44>. (84) Virions contain 24 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 76 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome
size 12.225 kb. (92) Genome of five parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
<the largest> 4.032 kb <RNA-1>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.484 kb <RNA-2>. (95)
The 3rd largest 2.677 kb <RNA-3>. (96) The 4th largest 1.161 kb <RNA-4>. (97)
The 5th largest 0.871 kb <RNA-5>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
methods described by Rogerson (1975); Wilcockson and Hull (1974). (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112)
Additional factor required for infectivity. (113) Additional factor
infectivity depends on RNAs 1-3 (total genome) plus RNA-5 or coat protein.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 42812. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 26400
<±0.4>. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (148)
Virion proteins not glycosylated. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, stamens, gynaecium and petals.
(179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 8>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple mosaic, elm mottle,
prunus necrotic ringspot, asparagus 2, spinach latent and tobacco streak
viruses. Hydrangea mosaic may best be regarded as a strain of elm mottle
ilarvirus (Jones, 1985). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: in Hydrangea, leaf
symptoms differ from the malformations, ringspots or chlorosis caused by
hydrangea ringspot virus, cucumber mosaic, tobacco ringspot, tomato ringspot,
tomato black ring, arabis mosaic or tobacco rattle viruses. Virion
instability, shape and small numbers in leaves is characteristic. (187) Jones,
A.T. (1985). Rep. Scottish Crop Res. Inst. 1984, p.190. Laemmli, U.K. (1970).
Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Rogerson, A.A. (1975). Ann. Biochem. 65: 34. Thomas,
B.J., Barton, R.J. and Tuszynski, A. (1983). Ann. appl. Biol. 103: 261.
Wilcockson, J. and Hull, R. (1974). J. gen. Virol. 23: 107.


Hydrangea ringspot potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: HRSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Hydrangea macrophylla. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Brierley (1954). (13) Hydrangea macrophylla often symptomless, but
leaves sometimes crinkled and distorted, fewer florets, plants stunted. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (38) Spreads in the
Eurasian region, the North American region, and the Pacific region. (39)
Spreads in Belgium, Canada, the former Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France,
Germany, Ireland, Italy, New Zealand, the UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic and necrotic local lesions. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Gomphrena globosa local chlorotic or necrotic lesions, not systemic.
Primula malacoides systemic, but symptomless. (45) Primula malacoides. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L) and Gomphrena globosa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Hydrangea macrophylla, or Primula malacoides. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Hydrangeaceae <1/1>, or Primulaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP:
70-75 °C. (55) LIV: 14-21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Bercks and Brandes, (1961); Koenig, (1973).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 490 nm. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 7 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
22000. (134) Coat. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: cactus X, clover yellow mosaic, potato X and white clover
mosaic potexviruses, distantly. (187) Bercks, R. and Brandes, J. (1961).
Phytopath. Z. 42: 45. Brandes, J. and Bercks, R. (1965). Adv. Virus Res. 11:
1. Brierley, P. (1954). Phytopathology 44: 696. Brierley, P. and Lorentz, P.
(1957). Phytopathology 47: 39. Hollings, M. (1958). J. Hort. Sci. 33: 257.
Koenig, R. (1970). NachrBl. dtsch. PflSchutz. Stuttg. 22: 34. Koenig, R.
(1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 114, 3pp. Sisler, H.D., Chang, S.C.,
Reagan, R.L. and Brierley, P. (1957). Phytopathology 47: 491.


Hypochoeris mosaic (?) furovirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1987. (2) Synonyms: cat's ear yellow spot virus
(Schmidt, 1977; Brunt and Stace-Smith, 1983). (3) Standard acronym: HyMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 27.0.1.T.010. (8) First reported in Hypochoeris radiata
(cat's ear). (9) From Western Canada. (10) By Brunt and Stace-Smith (1978a;
1978b). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally <and they are absent or less conspicuous
at higher temperatures (20-25°C and above)>. (13) Hypochoeris radiata faint
leaf chlorosis. Leontodon autumnalis chlorotic spots in young leaves. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, and Germany
<possibly>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor and C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions and veinal necrosis, then
systemic chlorosis. Chenopodium murale necrotic local lesions. Montia
perfoliata, isolate from western Canada systemic severe chlorosis. Nicotiana
clevelandii local grey necrotic lesions or oakleaf pattern, followed by veinal
necrosis and death, systemic faint chlorosis in abnormally small leaves and
severe stunting. Tetragonia tetragonioides few local chlorotic lesions. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Chenopodium quinoa
(L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hypochoeris radiata, or
Leontodon autumnalis, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>,
or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Brunt and Stace-Smith (1978a);
Singh and McDonald (1980); Greber and Finlay (1981). (54) TIP: 45-50 °C. (55)
LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (60) Method: Brunt and Stace-Smith
(1978a). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
220-240 nm <and 120-140 nm>. (71) Virions 22 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (76) Six sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 173 S. (78) Of
the other(s) 15, 45, 71, 114, and 143 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (133) Mr 24500. (134) Coat protein. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions <cytoplasmic>
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies and unusual
in shape. (176) Crystals. (177) <Occasionally> they contain virions <within
the crystals, but more frequently adjacent to the enclosing membrane (Brunt
and Stace-Smith, 1978b)>. (179) <Possible> Furovirus. (183) An isolate from
Australia, unlike the type isolate, infects Cucumis sativus in which it
induces chlorotic local lesions followed by systemic chlorotic mottling and
leaf malformation. An isolate from eastern Canada differs from the type
isolate in infecting Gomphrena globosa to cause chlorotic local lesions and
veinal necrosis, then systemic chlorotic mottling and leaf malformation. (184)
Hypochoeris mosaic virus has virions of similar morphology, size and
properties to those of broad bean necrosis (Inouye and Asatani, 1968), beet
necrotic yellow vein (Tamada and Baba, 1973), Nicotiana velutina mosaic
(Randles et al., 1976), peanut clump (Thouvenel et al., 1976), potato mop-top
(Harrison and Jones, 1970) and wheat soil-borne mosaic viruses (Brakke et al.,
1965), and to those of defective strains of tobacco mosaic virus (Kassanis and
Woods, 1969). It also resembles some of those viruses in the intracellular
location and appearance of its virions (Brunt and Stace-Smith, 1978b).
Although hypochoeris mosaic virus is apparently serologically distinct, its
similarities to these labile viruses suggests that it too may be a furovirus.
It may also, like these viruses, be transmitted by a root-infecting fungus,
but such transmission tests have not yet been reported. (187) Brakke, M.K.,
Estes, A.P. and Schuster, M.L. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 79. Brunt, A.A. and
Stace-Smith, R. (1978a). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 205. Brunt, A.A. and
Stace-Smith, R. (1978b). J. gen. Virol. 39: 63. Brunt, A.A. and Stace-Smith,
R. (1983). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 273, 4 pp. Greber, R.S. and Finlay,
J.R. (1981). Australas. Pl. Path. 10: 30. Harrison, B.D. and Jones, R.A.C.
(1970). Ann. appl. Biol. 65: 393. Inouye, T. and Asatani, M. (1968). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 34: 317. Kassanis, B. and Woods, R.D. (1969). Ann. appl.
Biol. 64: 213. Randles, J.W., Harrison, B.D. and Roberts, I.M. (1976). Ann.
appl. Biol. 84: 193. Schmidt, H.E. (1977). In: Pflanzliche Virologie, Vol. 4,
p. 517; eds K. Schmelzer and D. Spaar. Berlin, Akademie-Verlag. Singh, R.P.
and McDonald, J.G. (1980). Canad. Pl. Dis. Surv. 60: 4. Tamada, T. and Baba,
T. (1973). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 39: 325. Thouvenel, J.-C., Dollet, M.
and Fauquet, C. (1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 84: 311.

Iris fulva mosaic potyvirus

      (1) O.W. Barnett, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: IFMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.032. (8) First reported in an Apogon iris hybrid (Iris fulva ×
I. brevicaulis). (9) From Massachusetts, U.S.A. (10) By Travis (1957). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms faint mosaic. (13) Iris fulva and hybrids with
Iris fulva faint mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Aphis
fabae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis
craccivora. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show mosaic, necrosis, malformation of leaves and seed pods.

Belamcanda chinensis (W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Belamcanda chinensis,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Iris fulva, or Iris fulva × I. brevicaulis, or Iris
sibirica. (48) Gladiolus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Iris spuria, or Neomarica
gracilis, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Iridaceae
<4/7>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Iridaceae <3/7>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Barnett (1986); Barnett and Alper (1977). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55)
LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Barnett (1986). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)

coefficient 141 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.19. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 9.4 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9.4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Reddick and Barnett (1983). (112) Additional factor not
required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the

preparation: Barnett: heat in phosphate, mercaptoethanol, SDS and
electrophoresis on SDS gels. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
unusual sites. (173) Virions found in aggregate mitochondria. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: mitochondrial aggregates. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: iris virus 1 (Lisa, 1980). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: iris severe mosaic and iris mild mosaic
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serology in EM (decoration). Pinwheel
inclusion morphology easily separates it from iris severe mosaic virus. (187)
Barnett, O.W. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 310, 4 pp. Barnett, O.W. and
Alper, M. (1977). Phytopathology 67: 448. Lisa, V. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 39.
