Iris mild mosaic potyvirus

      (1) C.J. Asjes, 1986. (2) Synonyms: iris mosaic virus, iris latent
mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: IMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.033.
(8) First reported in Iris spp. (9) From Lisse, the Netherlands. (10) By Van
Slogteren (1958); Loebenstein and Alper (1963). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically
over a few weeks. (13) Iris spp.; bulbous irises, Iris xiphoides (English
iris), I. xiphium (Spanish iris), I. tingitana × I. xiphium (Dutch iris), I.
reticulata and I. danfordiae mild mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Macrosiphum
euphorbiae and Myzus persicae, but not by Macrosiphoniella sanborni. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <most
important cultivars are totally infected (Van Slogteren, 1963; Loebenstein and
Alper, 1963; Lawson, 1967; Asjes, 1979)>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Iris spp. green mosaic of leaves, more intense on spathes
(Van Slogteren, 1963; Loebenstein and Alper, 1963; Lawson, 1967; Asjes, 1979).
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana
clevelandii chlorotic lesions. Tetragonia tetragonioides circular chlorotic
local lesions with dark grey necrotic margins, not systemic. Belamcanda
chinensis (Hammond, unpublished data). (45) Iris spp. (46) Tetragonia
tetragonioides (L); Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Belamcanda chinensis, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Iris, or Iris danfordiae,
or Iris reticulata, or Iris tingitana × I. xiphium, or Iris xiphium, or Iris
xiphoides, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Iridaceae <7/7>, or Solanaceae
<2/2>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Asjes (1979). (54) TIP: <probably> 65-70
°C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days <at 20°C and 1632 days at 2°C. Sap lyophilized with
dextrose and peptone remains infective for at least 2 years (Brunt, 1968)>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:
Asjes (1979); Brunt (1973). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious <when stained with UF>. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
142-147 S <but the virions may form faster sedimenting aggregates>. (84)
Virions contain 5-6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0
% lipid. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Primarily pinwheels with laminated
aggregates and the lamellae close to virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean
yellow mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
iris severe mosaic (Van Slogteren, 1963; Lawson, 1967), bearded iris mosaic
(Barnett et al., 1971) and potato Y viruses. (187) Asjes, C.J. (1979). Neth.
J. Pl. Path. 85: 269. Barnett, O.W., de Zoeten, G.A. and Gaard, G. (1971).
Phytopathology 61: 926. Brunt, A.A. (1968). Ann. appl. Biol. 61: 187. Brunt,
A.A. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 116, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A. (1986).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 324, 5 pp. Derks, A.F.L.M., Hollinger, T.C. and
Vink-van den Abeele, J.L. (1985). Acta. Hort. 164: 309. Hammond, J., Brunt,
A.A., Derks, A.F.L.M., Inouye, N., Barnett, O.W., Allen, T.C. and Lawson, R.H.
(1985). Acta Hort. 164: 395. Lawson, R.H. (1967). Pl. Dis. Reptr 51: 952.
Loebenstein, G. and Alper, M. (1963). Phytopathology 53: 349. Van Slogteren,
D.H.M. (1958). Versl. Werkzaamh. Bloemboll. Lisse, 1957. Van Slogteren, D.H.M.
(1963). Versl. Werkzaamh. Bloemboll. Lisse, 1962.


Iris severe mosaic potyvirus

      (1) C.J. Asjes, 1986; J. Hammond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: bearded iris
mosaic virus (Brunt et al., 1988), iris grijs virus, iris stripe virus, iris
yellow mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: ISMV. (4) Strains: type strain,
avirulent strain, virulent strain (Barnett et al., 1986). (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.034. (8) First reported in Iris spp., Crocus vernus cv. King of
the Blues. (9) From the Netherlands. (10) By Atanasoff (1928); Anon. (1961).
(11) Symptoms persist and vary cyclically over a few weeks. (13) Crocus vernus
leaf mosaic; striping of flowers, if not white or yellow. Belamcanda chinensis
severe chlorosis. Iris spp. leaf striping, stunting, flower breaking. Plants
die prematurely. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Macrosiphum euphorbiae and Myzus persicae, but not by
Myzus pelargonii, M. circumflexum or Anuraphis tulipae and Rhopalosiphum
tulipaella (Brierley and McWhorter, 1934; Brierley and Smith, 1948; Travis,
1957; Barnett et al., 1971; Asjes, 1979). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies reported by Deutsch and
Loebenstein (1967); the spread of the virus in bulbous iris can be partially
controlled by spraying crops with mineral oils or pyrethroid and perimicarb
insecticides (Asjes, 1985). (39) Spreads in Australia, the former
Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Japan, the Netherlands, Sweden, the UK, and the USA
<and probably wherever bulbous and rhizomatous irises and crocus are grown>.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Belamcanda chinensis, Iris ×
hollandica. No herbaceous hosts. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, C. foetidum, Freesia
refracta cv. Imperial, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Crocus vernus, Iris sp.
(46) None. (47) Belamcanda chinensis, or Crocus vernus <cv. King of the
Blues>, or Iris, or Iris × hollandica. (48) Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Freesia refracta <cv. Imperial>, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
tabacum. (50) Iridaceae <4/5>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Iridaceae <1/5>,
or Solanaceae <4/4>. (53) Derks et al. (1985), Hammond et al. (1985). (54)
TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days <Barnett et al., 1971>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Asjes (1979). Homogenize
in phosphate buffer, 6.7mM; pH 7.2; (w/v = 1/1) containing 0.1% thioglycollic
acid, or in 0.2 M boric acid plus 0.05 M sodium borate pH 7.2; (w/v = 1/1).
Extract can be frozen (-20°C) or not before the mixing with
n-butanol/chloroform (w/v = 1/1; 30 minutes). The aqueous phase is
differentially centrifuged and the pellet resuspended in phosphate or borate
buffer. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 150 S <Barnett et al., 1986>.
(84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 32620. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X75939
Em(40)_vi:ISMVCP Gb(84)_vi:ISMVCP Iris severe mosaic potyvirus gene for coat
protein. 12/93 2,510bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
33000. (145) Method of preparation: Alper et al. (1985); Hammond and Lawson
(1984). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Alper et al. (1984);
Hammond and Lawson (1985)>. (153) One protein found. (154) Mr 71000. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves
and petals. (172) Virions found <scattered throughout> in cytoplasm <or
sometimes in membrane-enclosed masses>. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Bundles and
laminated aggregates (Barnett et al., 1971; Lisa, 1980). (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: iris mild mosaic, iris fulva
mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, turnip mosaic, freesia mosaic and four other
viruses (Barnett et al., 1971; Brunt, 1975). (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
Rhizomatous irises infected with iris severe mosaic virus in Britain also
contain cucumber mosaic virus (Brunt, 1968; Barnett et al., 1971) or, rarely,
broad bean wilt virus (Bailiss et al., 1975). Tobacco ringspot virus also
occurs occasionally in rhizomatous iris in the U.S.A. and Britain (Travis,
1957; Travis and Brierley, 1957; Brunt, 1972) and in bulbous iris in the
Netherlands (Asjes, 1979). These five viruses may be distinguished from iris
severe mosaic virus (ISMV) by their isometric or rod-shaped virions, their
host ranges or by serological tests. ISMV and three other potyviruses are
known to infect bulbous and rhizomatous irises (Brunt and Phillips, 1980;
Inouye and Mitsuhata, 1978); these three (bean yellow mosaic, iris mild mosaic
and turnip mosaic viruses) are all readily sap-transmitted to dicotyledonous
test plants; moreover, and are serologically distinct from ISMV. Two other
viruses with filamentous virions, narcissus latent carlavirus (Brunt, 1977;
Asjes, 1979) and lilac chlorotic leafspot closterovirus (Lisa, 1980), also
infect irises but are readily distinguished from ISMV. (187) Ainsworth, G.C.
(1936). Rep. exp. Res. Stn Cheshunt 1936, p. 62. Alper, M., Salomon, R. and
Loebenstein, G. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 960. Anon. (1961). Tuinbouwgids, p.
468. Asjes, C.J. (1979). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 85: 269. Atanasoff, D. (1928).
Izv. bul. bot. Druzh. 2: 51. Bailiss, K.W., Brunt, A.A. and Dale, J. (1975).
Pl. Path. 24: 60. Barnett, O.W. and Brunt, A.A. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 147, 4 pp. Barnett, O.W., de Zoeten, G.A. and Gaard, G. (1971).
Phytopathology 61: 926. Brierley, P. and McWhorter, F.P. (1934).
Phytopathology 2: 24. Brierley, P. and McWhorter, F.P. (1936). J. agric. Res.
53: 621. Brierley, P. and Smith, F.E. (1948). Phytopathology 38: 574. Brunt,
A.A. (1975). Acta Hort. 47: 45. Brunt, A.A. (1977). Ann appl. Biol. 87: 355.
Brunt, A.A. and Phillips, S. (1980). Acta Hort. 109: 503. Brunt, A.A., Derks,
A.F.L.M. and Barnett, O.W. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 338, 4 pp. Carne
(1927). J. Proc. R. Soc. West Aust. 14: 23. Derks, A.F.L.N. and Hollinger,
T.C. (1986). Acta Hort. 177: Derks, A.F.L.N., Hollinger, T.C. and Vink-van den
Abeele, J.L. (1985). Acta Hort. 164: 309. Deutsch, M. and Loebenstein, G.
(1967). Pl. Dis. Reptr 51: 318. Fukushi, T. (1932). Trans. Sapporo Nat. Hist.

A.F.L.N., Inouye, T., Barnett, O.W., Allen, T.C. and Lawson, R.H. (1985). Acta

75: 1353. Hsu, H.T., Franssen, J.M., Hammond, J., Dercks, A.F.L.N. and Lawson,
R.H. Phytopathology (1986). 76: 1132. Ingelström (1938). Växts kyddnotiser
Vaxtkyddanst. Stockh. 2: 22. Inouye, T. and Mitsuhata, K. (1978). Nogaku
Kenkyu 57: 1. Lisa, V. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 39. Loebenstein, G. and Alper,
M. (1963). Phytopathology 53: 349. Neergaard (1939). Rep. Phytopath. Lab.
1938-39, p. 16. Travis, R.V. (1957). Phytopathology 47: 454. Travis, R.V. and
Brierley, P. (1957). Pl. Dis. Reptr 41: 524. Van Slogteren, D.H.M. (1958).
Jversl. Lab. Bloemboll. Lisse, 1957, p. 67. Van Slogteren, D.H.M. (1963).
Jversl. Lab. Bloemboll. Lisse, 1963, p. 80.


Isachne mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: IsaMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.046. (8) First reported in Isachne globosa. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Toriyama and Yora (1972). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Isachne globosa leaf
chlorosis. (39) Spreads in Japan. (47) Isachne globosa. (50) Gramineae <1/1>.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels.
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) :
Potyviridae. (187) Toriyama, S. and Yora, K. (1972). In: Virus Diseases of
Wild Grasses and Cereal Crops in Japan. University of Tokyo Press, Tokyo,
Japan.


Ivy vein clearing (?) cytorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: IVCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.023. (8) First reported in Hedera helix. (9) From southern Italy.
(10) By Russo et al. (1979). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Hedera helix
transitory chlorosis of leaf veins, some chlorotic blotching in spring. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
benthamiana chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; transitory systemic vein
clearing. Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. Xanthi systemic ringspots.
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. megalosiphon systemic vein clearing. Datura stramonium
ring-like local lesions; not systemic. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis
sativus, Nicotiana rustica, N. tabacum, Solanum melongena. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L/W), Nicotiana
benthamiana (W), N. clevelandii (W). (47) Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Hedera helix, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum <cv.
Xanthi>. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum melongena. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Araliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/8>. (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 0.25 days
<69 hours>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61)
Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (68) Virions usually straight. (70) Virions of
100-200 nm <in sap>, or 180-320 nm <in vivo>. (71) Virions 60-70 nm wide <in
sap>, or 45-50 nm wide <in vivo>. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, vascular
parenchyma and the phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) <Possible>
Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Castellano, M.A.
and Rana, G.L. (1981). Phytopathol. Medit. 20: 199. Russo, M., Castellano,
M.A. and Martelli, G.P. (1979). Phytopath. Z. 96: 122.


Jatropha mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) K.S. Kim, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: JMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.021. (8) First reported in Jatropha gossypiifolia. (9) From Puerto
Rico. (10) By Bird (1957). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Jatropha gossypiifolia,
J. podagrica, J. multifida, Croton lobatus, Jacquemontia tamnifolia, Phaseolus
vulgaris yellow mosaics. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae.
(25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector
when it moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39)
Spreads in Kenya and Puerto Rico. (47) Croton lobatus, or Jacquemontia
tamnifolia, or Jatropha gossypiifolia, or Jatropha multifida, or Jatropha
podagrica, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae
<4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (61) Virions geminate. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 15-18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 15 and
30 nm in length. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (171) Virions found in
leaves, phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (173)
Virions found in in sieve tubes. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the nucleus, or amorphous Xbodies <in
cytoplasm>, or unusual in shape. (176) Fibrillar bodies. (177) They contain
virions <in the nuclear inclusions>, or they do not contain virions <in the
cytoplasmic inclusions>. (178) Other cellular changes: the nucleolar
segregation of granular and fibrillar components (Kim et al., 1986). (179)
Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (187) Bird, J. (1957). P.
R. Agric. Exp. Stn Tech. Pap., 22. Kim, K.S., Bird, J., Rodriguez, R.L.,
Martin, E.M. and Escudero, J. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 80.


Johnsongrass chlorotic stripe (?) carmovirus

      (1) W. Huth, 1991; K. Izadpanah, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Sorghum halepense (Johnson grass). (9)
From Fars Province, Iran. (10) By Izadpanah (1982). (11) Symptoms persist.
(12) Symptoms stripe mosaic. (13) Sorghum halepense chlorotic leaf stripes,
dwarfing, fewer seeds. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (24)
Not transmitted by Empoasca spp., Laodelphax striatellus, Neoaliturus
haematoceps, Unkanodes tanasijevici, Eriophyes tulipae or Rhopalosiphum spp.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed
<although present in the cotyledon>. (39) Spreads in Iran. (47) Sorghum
halepense. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Izadpanah (1988). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile <with a knobby
surface>. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations <with a minor second
component>. (79) Density 1.359 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.48. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 4.65 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.65
kb. (100) Base composition 27.5 % G. (101) Base composition 23.5 % A. (102)
Base composition 26 % C. (103) Base composition 23 % U. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Izadpanah et al. (1992). (171) Virions found in leaves and
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in chloroplasts, in mitochondria,
and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other
cellular changes: swollen endoplasmic reticulum or nuclear envelope containing
fibrils and vesicles. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (184) No serological relationship to any of 30 isometric
viruses tested. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: JGCSMV and sugarcane mosaic
potyvirus infect Johnson grass in the Fras Province of Iran. JGCSMV induces
more obvious symptoms. (187) Izadpanah, K. (1982). Iran J. Pl. Path. 18: 3-7.
Izadpanah, K. (1988). J. Phytopathology 121: 209. Izadpanah, K., Huth, W.,
Lesemann, D.-E. and Vetten H.J. (1992). J. Phytopathology 137: 105.


Johnsongrass mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (2) Synonyms: maize dwarf mosaic virus strain O
(McDaniel and Gordon, 1985; Shukla et al., 1989), sugarcane mosaic virus
Australian Johnson grass virus (Shukla et al., 1987), maize dwarf mosaic virus
Kansas I strain (McKern et al., 1990). (3) Standard acronym: JGMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.0.035. (8) First reported in Sorghum halepense and Zea
mays. (9) From Australia. (10) By Taylor and Pares (1968). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Sorghum halepense (Johnson grass) systemic mosaic. Zea mays
systemic mosaic. Brachiaria miliiformis, Cenchrus ciliaris, Panicum miliaceum,
Paspalum orbiculare, Pennisetum typhoides, Sorghum × almum, S. laxiflorum, S.
macrospermum, S. miliaceum, S. stipoideum, S. sudanense, S. verticilliflorum,
S. vulgare systemic chlorotic mosaic mottling, necrosis, stunting. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Rhopalosiphum maidis but not Macrosiphum
euphorbiae, M. miscanthi, Rhopalosiphum padi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Australia and the USA.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis. (43) Zea mays
cv. Iochief mosaic. Sorghum vulgare cv. Yates NK22OY necrosis or mosaic. S.
vulgare cv. Atlas mosaic. Avena sativa mosaic. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Bountiful, Chenopodium quinoa, Saccharum officinarum, Nicotiana clevelandii,
Cucumis sativus. (45) Sorghum vulgare, Zea mays cv. Iochief (Sweet corn). (46)
Zea mays cv. Iochief (W), Sorghum verticilliflorum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or
Brachiaria miliiformis, or Cenchrus ciliaris, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or
Eleusine coracana, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or Panicum capillare, or Panicum
miliaceum, or Paspalum orbiculare, or Pennisetum typhoides, or Setaria
italica, or Setaria viridis, or Sorghum bicolor, or Sorghum halepense, or
Sorghum laxiflorum, or Sorghum macrospermum, or Sorghum miliaceum, or Sorghum
stipoideum, or Sorghum sudanense, or Sorghum verticilliflorum, or Sorghum
vulgare, or Sorghum × almum, or Zea mays. (48) Allium cepa, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Bromus inermis, or Bromus secalinus, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer
arietinum, or Cucumis sativus, or Cynodon dactylon, or Dactylis glomerata, or
Datura stramonium, or Elytrigia repens, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium perenne, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Oryzopsis
miliacea, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cv. Bountiful>, or
Phleum pratense, or Pisum sativum, or Poa pratensis, or Saccharum officinarum,
or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50) Gramineae <23/38>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <15/38>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<8/8>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (53) Teakle and Grylls (1973); McDaniel and Gordon
(1985). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Teakle and Grylls (1973); McDaniel and
Gordon (1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 773-778 nm. (72) Axial
canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31742. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): U07217 Em(40)_vi:JM07217 Gb(84)_vi:JMU07217 Johnsongrass
mosaic virus strain Maize dwarf O polyprotein (nuclear inclusion II protein,
coa U07218 Em(40)_vi:JM07218 Gb(84)_vi:JMU07218 Johnsongrass mosaic virus
strain Maize dwarf KS1 polyprotein (nuclear inclusion II protein, c Z26920
Em(40)_vi:JGMVVPS Gb(84)_vi:JGMVVPS Johnson grass mosaic virus gene for
protease 1 and 3, helper component 6K protein, coat prote 3 sequences. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33505. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found
in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177)
They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (184) Virion protein distantly homologous to that of maize dwarf
mosaic potyvirus B and more distantly related to other potyviruses. Using
electro-blot immunoassay with cross-absorbed polyclonal antibodies against the
N-terminus of the virion proteins show that four distinct potyviruses infect
sugarcane, maize and sorghum. Johnson grass mosaic virus (synonyms SCMVJG and
maize dwarf mosaic virus strain O) is one, the others are: 1) Maize dwarf
mosaic potyvirus (syn; MDMVA, MDMVD, MDMVE and MDMVF); 2) Sugarcane mosaic
potyvirus (syn; MDMVB, SCMVA, SCMVB, SCMVD, SCMVE, SCMVSc, SCMVBc and
SCMVSabi); 3) Sorghum mosaic potyvirus (syn; SCMVH, SCMVI and SCMVM). (Shukla
et al., 1989). (187) McDaniel, L.L and Gordon, D.T. (1985). Plant Dis. 69:
602. McKern, N.M, Whittaker, L.A., Strike, P.M., Ford, R.E., Jensen, S.G. and
Shukla, D.D. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 907. Shukla, D.D. and Gough, K.H.
(1984). Plant Dis. 68: 204. Shukla, D.D., Gough, K.H. and Ward, C.M. (1987).
Arch. virol. 96: 59. Shukla, D.D. and Teakle, D.S. (1989). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 340, 5 pp. Shukla, D.D., Tosic, M., Jilka, J., Ford, R.E., Toler,
R.W. and Langham, M.A.C. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 223. Taylor, R.H. and

Kalanchoe isometric virus

      (1) M.L. Izaguirre-Mayoral, 1991. (2) Synonyms: IVLP. (4) Strains:
Venezuelan. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.21. (8) First reported in
Kalanchoe pinnata, K. tubiflora, K. daigremontiana. (9) From Edo Miranda,
Venezuela. (10) By Izaguirre-Mayoral et al. (1990). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (12) Symptoms sunken tissues and necrosis. (13) Kalanchoe pinnata,
K. tubiflora, K. daigremontiana sunken tissues between leaf veins, sometimes
necrosis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
Venezuela. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show chlorotic and necrotic local lesions, chlorotic
rings. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions. Chenopodium
quinoa, Cucumis sativus cv. Palomar necrotic local lesions. Datura stramonium
chlorotic local lesions, chlorotic rings. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic
mosaic. N. tabacum cvs Samsun, White Burley chlorotic rings and systemic
mosaic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top crop systemic mosaic. P. vulgaris cv. Red
Kidney chlorotic local lesions and systemic mosaic. Tetragonia tetragonioides
chlorotic rings. (44) Cucumis melo, C. sativus cv. Ashley, Cucurbita maxima,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Cucumis sativus cv. Palomar (L).
(47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus <cv.
Palomar>, or Datura stramonium, or Kalanchoe daigremontiana, or Kalanchoe
pinnata, or Kalanchoe tubiflora, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
tabacum <cvs Samsun, White Burley>, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus <cv. Ashley>, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Crassulaceae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <3/5>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/5>. (53) Izaguirre-Mayoral
et al. (1990). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 0.2 days <20 hours>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Izaguirre-Mayoral et al. (1990). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 35 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (79)
Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.56. (84) Virions contain
9-10 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 3.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 3.5 kb. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 46000. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes:
severely damaged chloroplasts of different forms, randomly distributed in the
cytoplasm and bigger than those of non-infected leaves. Starch grains occupied
78% of the chloroplast internal volume during the night as well as in the
light period, and the number of thylakoids per grana reduced to 5±2. (179)
(Ungrouped). (187) Izaguirre-Mayoral, M.L., Carballo, O. and Gil, F. (1990).
J. Phytopath. 130: 303.


Kalanchoe latent carlavirus

      (1) S.L. Bhattiprolu, 1992. (2) Synonyms: kalanchoe I virus. (3)
Standard acronym: KLV. (4) Strains: KV1 and KV2. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Kalanchoe blossfeldiana. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Hearon (1981). (13) Kalanchoe blossfeldiana symptomless
infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Paludan (1985). Kalanchoe
latent virus 1 was eliminated from the mother plants by meristem tip culture
combined with previous heat treatment. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. album, C. quinoa local lesions, systemic
yellow vein-banding and leaf distortion with strain KV2). Chenopodium album,
C. murale, Tetragonia tetragonioides local lesions; no systemic infection.

clevelandii, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium

Chenopodium quinoa, or Kalanchoe blossfeldiana, or Tetragonia tetragonioides.

Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cucumis

rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or

<5/7>, or Crassulaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/7>, or Compositae <3/3>,
or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Plantaginaceae <1/1>,

RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
phenol or detergent <KV1>, or lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent

not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and the
vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: fusiform inclusions consisting of
aggregates of parallel virions and pockets of cytoplasmic materials, vesicles,
or microbodies; virions also aggregate along organelle membranes and the
tonoplast. Bands of virions and `fingerprint like' inclusions also in cells
within the local lesions (Hearon, 1982, 1984). (179) Carlavirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: carnation latent, potato S, lily
symptomless and chrysanthemum B carlaviruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: elderberry, potato M and red clover vein
mosaic carlaviruses. (187) Hearon, S.S. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 767.

grafting. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Denmark. (40)

lesions. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic and necrotic
local lesions; not systemic. (44) Beta vulgaris, Brassica campestris ssp.

badnavirus'. (3) Standard acronym: KTSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 07.0.1.0.007.
(8) First reported in Kalanchoe blossfeldiana. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By
Hearon and Locke (1984). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Kalanchoe blossfeldiana
sunken circular yellow spots and occasional leaf deformation in intolerant
cultivars. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Planococcus citri. (18) Transmitted by Pseudococcidae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (39) Spreads in the UK and the
USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Kalanchoe blossfeldiana circular
yellow spots in systemically infected leaves. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis
sativus, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45)
Kalanchoe blossfeldiana. (46) Kalanchoe blossfeldiana (W). (47) Kalanchoe
blossfeldiana. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum.

Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (60) Method: Lockhart
and Ferji (1988). (61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65)
Virions 130 nm in length. (71) Virions 30 nm wide. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 7.35 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.35 kb. (171) Virions
found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179)
Badnavirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: banana
streak, cacao swollen shoot, commelina yellow mottle, dioscorea bacilliform,
rice tungro bacilliform and sugarcane viruses. (184) The viral genome shows
weak homology with those of banana streak and badnaviruses. (187) Hearon, S.S.
and Locke, J.C. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 347. Lockhart, B.E. and Ferji, Z.
(1988). Acta Hort. 234: 73.

Kennedya yellow mosaic tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1981. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: KYMV. (4)
Strains: Port Douglas (Mount Jukes), Jervis Bay, Wapengo; these being the type
members of three geographically separate strains found in north Queensland,
central coast N.S.W. and south coast N.S.W. respectively. (5) ICTV decimal
code 77.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Kennedya rubicunda. (9) From samples
from Murrays Beach, Jervis Bay, Australia. (10) By Dale et al. (1975, 1976);
Gibbs (1978). (11) Symptoms persist <and are often bright>. (13) Kennedya
rubicunda, Desmodium triflorum, D. scorpiurus, Indigofera australis mild
chlorotic local lesions, systemic blotchy yellow mosaic. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia <the eastern coastal region>. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Glycine max blotchy systemic yellow mosaic.
Kennedya rubicunda systemic yellow mosaic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Redland
Pioneer, Pisum sativum chlorotic local lesions; then systemic yellow mosaic.
Vigna radiata necrotic local lesions; systemic leaf malformation. Datura
stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. (44)
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Pisum sativum cv. Early
Massey, Glycine max. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Redland Pioneer (L), Pisum
sativum cv. Massey (W), Vigna radiata (L). (47) Cajanus cajan, or Clitoria

amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena

pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <15/22>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/22>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (53) Dale and Gibbs
(1976); Gibbs (1978) and unpublished data. (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV:
10-100 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Gibbs (1978). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)

A260/A280 ratio 0.81 <T>, or 1.69 <B>. (84) Virions contain 34.1 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 65.9 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size
6.362 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.362 kb.
(100) Base composition 15.1 % G. (101) Base composition 22.5 % A. (102) Base
composition 39.4 % C. (103) Base composition 23 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA
has a methylated nucleotide cap. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor
not required for infectivity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Ding et
al. (1990). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12158. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): D00637 Em(40)_vi:MTYCG01 Gb(84)_vi:KYVCGA Kennedya yellow mosaic
virus genome, complete sequence. 11/90 6,362bp. M15286 Em(40)_vi:TYMTY3KY
Gb(84)_vi:KYV3KYMV Kennedya yellow mosaic virus 3' end which can form a
tRNA-like structure. 11/90 83bp. M58310 Em(40)_vi:KYVRRLT Gb(84)_vi:KYVRRLT
Kennedya yellow mosaic virus 3' terminal tRNA-like structure. 8/91 84bp. 3
sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is of an
unusual type of structure <mRNA like>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
19602. (164) Genome replicates in association with chloroplasts <in the
vesicles>. (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: vesiculation of the
chloroplasts outer membrane. (179) Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: turnip yellow mosaic, clitoria yellow vein and
okra mosaic, closely; desmodium yellow mottle and cacao yellow mosaic viruses
more distantly. (184) CDNA-RNA hybridization tests correlate with the
serological relationships, but also show an unexpected close relationship with
eggplant mosaic tymovirus, which is serologically very distantly related to
kennedya yellow mosaic virus. (187) Blok, J., Gibbs, A.J. and Mackenzie, A.
(1987). Arch. Virol. 96: 225. Dale, J.L., Gardiner, J.E. and Gibbs, A.J.
(1975). Aust. Pl. Path. Soc. Newsl. 4: 13. Dale, J.L. and Gibbs, A.J. (1976).

gen. Virol. 71: 925. Gibbs, A.J. (1978). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 193, 4

Konjak mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: KMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.036. (8) First reported in Amorphophallus konjac. (9) From Gunma
Prefecture, Japan. (10) By Shimoyama et al. (1992a). (13) Amorphophallus
konjac leaf mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads
in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Amorphophallus konjac,
Philodendron oxycardium, P. selloum leaf mosaic. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum. (45) Amorphophallus konjac. (46)
Amorphophallus konjac (W), Philodendron selloum (W). (47) Amorphophallus
konjac, or Philodendron oxycardium, or Philodendron selloum. (48) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris. (50) Araceae <3/3>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (54) TIP: 55-60 °C.
(55) LIV: 2-4 days <at 18C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (60) Method: Shimoyama
et al. (1992b). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 800 nm. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 10.1 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35500. (134)
Coat. (179) <Possible> Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: soybean mosaic and watermelon
mosaic-2 potyviruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
bean yellow mosaic, bean common mosaic (blackeye cowpea mosaic strain),
dasheen mosaic, potato Y, turnip mosaic and zucchini yellow mosaic
potyviruses. (187) Shimoyama, J., Kameya-Iwaki, M., Hanada, K. and Gunyi, T.
(1992a). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 58: 706. Shimoyama, J., Hanada, K., Tsuda,
S., Kameya-Iwaki, M. and Gunyi, T. (1992b). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 58:
713.


Kyuri green mottle mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) R.I.B. Francki, 1988. (2) Synonyms: Japanese CV3, cucumber green
mottle mosaic virus - cucumber strain or strain C (Francki et al., 1986). (3)
Standard acronym: KGMMV. (4) Strains: C and Y isolates or strains. (5) ICTV
decimal code 71.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Cucumis sativus. (9) From
Japan. (10) By Inouye et al. (1967a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis
sativus mosaic, severe fruit mottling and malformation. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Cucumis sativus mottling, and fruit malformation. Datura stramonium,
Petunia × hybrida diffuse chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. (45) Cucumis
sativus. (46) Datura stramonium (L), Cucumis sativus (W). (47) Cucumis melo,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida. (48)
Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or
Solanaceae <3/6>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/6>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Inouye et al. (1967b). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: no special treatments needed. (60) Method: Tung and
Knight (1972); Francki and McLean (1968). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of <c.> 300 nm. (71) Virions <c.> 15 nm wide. (72) Axial
canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (84) Virions contain <c.> 5 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions <c.> 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Peden and Symons (1973). (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor not required
for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
subgenomic mRNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 17000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Fraenkel-Conrat (1957); Tung and Knight (1972). (146) Amino acid
sequence: Nozu et al. (1971); Tung and Knight (1972); Kurachi et al. (1972).
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma, xylem, phloem, companion
cells and all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: vesiculation of mitochondria. (179) Tobamovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cucumber green mottle mosaic
(SDI:6), ribgrass mosaic (SDI:5), frangipani mosaic (SDI:5), odontoglossum
ringspot (SDI:4), tobacco mosaic (SDI:7) and tobacco mild green mosaic (SDI:6)
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: sunn-hemp
mosaic. (184) Biologically kyuri green mottle mosaic and cucumber green mottle
mosaic viruses are similar but have little genomic sequence homology and are
serologically distantly related. (186) Although long considered to be a strain
of cucumber green mottle mosaic tobamovirus, this virus has been shown to be a
distinct tobamovirus (Francki et al., 1986). (187) Fraenkel-Conrat, H. (1957).
Virology 4: 1. Francki, R.I.B. and McLean, G.D. (1968). Aust. J. biol. Sci.
21: 1311. Francki, R.I.B., Hu, J. and Palukaitis, P. (1986). Intervirology 26:
156. Inouye, T., Inouye, N., Asatani, M. and Mitsuhata, K. (1967a). Nogaku
Kenkyu 51: 175. Inouye, T., Inouye, N., Asatani, M. and Mitsuhata, K. (1967b).
Ber. Ohara Inst. landw. Biol. 14: 49. Kurachi, K., Funatsu, G., Funatsu, M.
and Hidaka, S. (1972). Agric. Biol. Chem. 36: 1109. Nozu, Y., Tochihara, H.,
Komuro, Y. and Okada, Y. (1971). Virology 45: 577. Okada, Y. (1986). In: The
Plant Viruses. Vol. 2, The Rod-Shaped Plant Viruses, p. 267; eds M.H.V. van
Regenmortel and H. Fraenkel-Conrat. Plenum Press, New York. Peden, K.W.C. and
Symons, R.H. (1973). Virology 53: 487. Tung, J.S. and Knight, C.A. (1972).
Virology 48: 574.


Laburnum yellow vein (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: laburnum anagyroides virus. (5) ICTV
decimal code 62.0.5.T.D.06. (8) First reported in Laburnum anagyroides. (9)
From the U.K. (10) By Schultz and Harrap (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Laburnum anagyroides chlorotic banding of veins. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian
region. (39) Spreads in the UK <probably>. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (47) Laburnum
anagyroides. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 250 nm. (71) Virions 95 nm wide. (171) Virions found
in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear space. (179)
<Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187)
Schultz, M.G. and Harrap, K.A. (1975). Ann. appl. Biol. 79: 247.


Lamium mild mottle fabavirus

      (1) S. Phillips and O. Lovisolo, 1992. (2) Synonyms: Lamium mild mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: LMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.2.0.003. (8)
First reported in Lamium album and Lamium purpureum. (9) From Cambridge, U.K.
(10) By Lovisolo (1958). (12) Symptoms mild mosaic or symptomless. (13) Lamium
album, L. purpureum, Marrubium peregrinum, M. vulgare mild mosaic or
symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Cryptomyzus alboapicalis, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the UK <Cambridge area>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show chlorotic or necrotic lesions followed by systemic infection, chlorosis
or line patterns. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. Samsun chlorotic or necrotic
local lesions; systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana rustica systemic line patterns.
Vicia faba local lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Capsicum annuum,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. rustica. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Ballota nigra, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lamium album, or Lamium purpureum, or
Marrubium peregrinum, or Marrubium vulgare, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Primula obconica, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba. (48) Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Capsicum annuum, or Coleus blumei, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Pelargonium zonale, or Solanum capsicastrum, or
Solanum melongena, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Labiatae <6/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/3>,
or Primulaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <8/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>, or
Solanaceae <4/12>. (53) Lovisolo (1958; 1960a; 1960b); Lisa et al. (1982).
(60) Method: Lisa et al. (1982). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 25-27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 0.86
<T>, or 1.67 <M>, or 1.76 <B>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lisa et
al. (1982). (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr 45000. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 28500. (145) Method of preparation: Lisa et al. (1982). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) Fabavirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: broad bean
wilt virus serotype I. (184) Not related to six comoviruses. (187) Lisa, V.,
Luisoni, E., Boccardo, G., Milne, R.G. and Lovisolo, O. (1982). Ann. appl.
Biol. 100: 467. Lovisolo, O. (1958). Boll. Staz. Pat. Veg., Roma 15: 89.
Lovisolo, O. (1960a). Boll. Staz. Pat. Veg., Roma 17: 193. Lovisolo, O.
(1960b). Not. Mal. Piante 5354: 233.


Lato River tombusvirus

      (1) C. Vovlas, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LRV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.1.0.009. (9) From water from Lato river, near Apulia, Italy. (10) By
Vovlas (1986). (15) Most probably spread in irrigation water. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
local lesions, systemic mosaic, and death. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Gomphrena
globosa local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii systemic mosaic.
(44) Nicotiana glutinosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Gomphrena globosa
(L), Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N. clevelandii (W). (47) Chenopodium quinoa,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii. (48)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Nicotiana glutinosa. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/3>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Solanaceae <1/3>. (60) Method: Blend infected leaves of Nicotiana benthamiana
in phosphate buffer (pH 7.2). Clarify with magnesium bentonite. (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter <also some 17 nm in diameter>. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (79)
Density 1.28 g cm3 in CsCl, or 1.33 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 18 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 82 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.7 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Vovlas: phenolSDS. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (132) Virion protein(s) one
<plus a fragment>. (133) Mr 38000 <plus 29000>. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (179) Tombusvirus:
Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: Moroccan pepper, artichoke mottled crinkle and Neckar River
tombusviruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cymbidium
ringspot and grapevine Algerian latent viruses. (186) Purified preparations,
after cool storage, contain 30 nm diameter virions and also some about 17 nm
in diameter that contain no RNA. The small virions are formed of the coat
protein of the larger; such virions are not produced by other tombusviruses.
(187) Gallitelli, D., Di Franco, A., Vovlas, C. and Martelli, G.P. (1989). J.
Phytopath. 126: 213. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Vovlas, C.
(1986). Proc. 8th Wksh. Epidem. Pl. Virus Dis., Orlando, Florida, U.S.A. p.
13. Vovlas, C. and Di Franco, A. (1987). Inform. Fitopatol. 3: 55.


Launaea mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.07. (8) First
reported in Launaea naudicaulis. (9) From India. (10) By Padma et al. (1973).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Launaea aspleniifolia, L. naudicaulis leaf
chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in India <New Delhi and Uttar Pradesh>.
(47) Launaea aspleniifolia, or Launaea naudicaulis. (50) Compositae <2/2>.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 812 nm.
(179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Naqvi, S.Q. and
Mahmood, K. (1976). Curr. Sci. 45: 152. Padma, R., Verma, V.S. and Singh, S.
(1973). Z. PflKrankh. PflPath. Pflschutz. 80: 68. Verma, V.S. and Singh, S.
(1974). Biol. Plant. 16: 373. Verma, V.S. and Singh, S. (1975). Zbl. Bakt.
Parasit. Inf. and Hyg. II 130: 121.


Leek yellow stripe potyvirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: LYSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.037. (8) First reported in Allium porrum. (9) From Germany and
several European countries. (10) By Bos et al. (1978). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Allium porrum yellow leaf striping. Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, A. cepa
rarely infected. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted
by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Bos et al. (1975). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39)
Spreads in New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Allium
porrum yellow leaf stripes. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic
local lesions, becoming green rings when leaves senesce. Celosia argentea
brown necrotic local lesions. (44) Allium fistulosum, Cucumis sativus,
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Allium porrum.
(46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L). (47) Allium cepa, or Allium
cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium porrum, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana debneyi. (48) Allium cepa, or
Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium fistulosum, or Apium graveolens, or
Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Silene armeria, or Sinapis alba, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or
Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Alliaceae <3/4>, or Amaranthaceae <1/2>,
or Chenopodiaceae <5/9>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (51) Alliaceae <3/4>, or
Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/9>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <7/8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1
/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Verhoyen and Horvat (1973); Bos et al.
(1978); Graichen (1978). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Huttinga
(1975); Bos et al. (1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 820 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (80) Density
1.326 g cm3 in sucrose. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 42004. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): X89711 Em(44)n:Lyspvpoly Gb(90)n:Lyspvpoly Leek yellow
stripe potyvirus genomic RNA for partial nuclear inclusion protein and coat
protein. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 34000. (134) Coat protein.
(145) Method of preparation: Huttinga (1975). (171) Virions found in leaves.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and
unusual in shape. (176) Large fibrous or granular cytoplasmic inclusion
bodies. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: onion yellow dwarf virus. (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: onions infected by leek yellow stripe virus (LYSV) with
difficulty, and leek is very resistant to onion yellow dwarf virus (OYDV).
Allium fistulosum is immune to LYSV but infected symptomlessly by OYDV. LYSV
gives local lesions in Chenopodium amaranticolor and C. quinoa. LYSV differs
from shallot latent carlavirus in virion size and morphology and in forming
larger and later local lesions on Chenopodium amaranticolor and C. quinoa.
(187) Bos, L. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 240, 4 pp. Bos, L.,
Huijberts, N., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1978). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 84: 185.
Bremer, H. (1937). Phytopath. Z. 10: 79. Graichen, K. (1978). Arch. Phytopath.
PflSchutz. 14: 1. Kupke, F.W. (1957). Rhein. Monatschr. Gem. Obst. Gartenb.
45: 173. Mohamed, N.A. and Young, B.R. (1980). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 23: 129.
Verhoyen, M. and Horvat, F. (1973). Parasitica 29: 16.


Lettuce big-vein varicosavirus

      (1) S. Kuwata, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LBVV. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.3.DE.3. (8) First reported in Lactuca sativa. (9) From Imperial Valley,
California, U.S.A. (10) By Jagger and Chandler (1934). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (12) Symptoms vein yellowing then chlorotic or white vein banding.
(13) Lactuca sativa chlorotic or white vein banding. Sonchus oleraceus
symptomless or vein banding. Sonchus asper yellow vein-banding. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by
Olpidium brassicae. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (24) Not transmitted by
Myzus persicae, Hyperomyzus lactuca, Xiphinema spp., Longidorus spp. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Allen (1948); Tomlinson and Faithfull (1979). (39) Spreads in
Australia, the former Czechoslovakia, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, New
Zealand, the UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic or white vein-banding.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Lactuca
sativa chlorotic or white vein-banding. Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii
symptomless. Nicotiana occidentalis chlorotic local lesions and systemic
chlorosis. Sonchus asper yellow vein-banding. Sonchus oleraceus slight
vein-banding. Tetragonia tetragonioides green rings after leaf senescence.
(44) Chenopodium murale, Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana
occidentalis. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Sonchus asper, or Sonchus
oleraceus, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Chenopodium murale, or Nicotiana
tabacum. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/4>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Solanaceae <1/4>. (53)
Campbell (1965); Huijberts et al. (1990). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 1. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: aldehyde fixation essential. (60) Method: Kuwata et al. (1983).

depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll and
vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Varicosavirus. (184) The virions of this
virus are closely serological related to those of tobacco stunt virus, but as
they differ in host range, they are considered to be separate species, rather
than related strains (Kuwata and Kubo, 1986). (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
soil transmissibility. Serological tests such as ISEM and ELISA. (187) Allen,
M.W. (1948). Phytopathology 38: 616. Campbell, R.N. (1962). Nature, Lond. 195:
675. Campbell, R.N. (1985). Can. J. Bot. 63: 2288. Campbell, R.N. and Grogan,

Lettuce infectious yellows (?) closterovirus

      (1) J.E. Duffus and S. Molyneux, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: LIYV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.3.05. (8) First reported in Lactuca sativa, Beta
vulgaris, Daucus carota. (9) From California and Arizona, U.S.A. (10) By
Duffus et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Lactuca sativa, Citrullus
lanatus, Cucumis melo, Cucurbita pepo, C. maxima, C. moschata, Beta vulgaris,
Daucus carota severe chlorosis and/or reddening, rolling vein-clearing and
brittleness of leaves, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted
by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (27) Virus does
not multiply in the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Duffus et al. (1986). (39) Spreads in
the USA <California and Arizona>. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible <45 spp.
in 15 families>. (43) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa, Lactuca sativa,

sativus, Trifolium subterraneum, Malva parviflora, Nicotiana clevelandii
severe chlorosis, and/or reddening, rolling, vein-clearing and brittleness of
leaves; stunting. (44) Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris,
Vicia faba, Datura stramonium. (45) Lactuca sativa, Malva parviflora,

Lettuce mosaic potyvirus

      (1) J.A. Tomlinson, 1982. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: lactuca virus 1.
(3) Standard acronym: LMV. (4) Strains: three pathotypes of the virus are
recognised. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.038. (8) First reported in Lactuca
sativa. (9) From Florida, U.S.A. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Lactuca spp.,
Senecio vulgaris, Sonchus spp. necrotic or chlorotic local lesions and
streaking, then mosaic, vein yellowing, leaf malformation. Cicer arietinum
leaf chlorosis. Pisum sativum chlorotic mottling. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii,
Macrosiphum euphorbiae, M. gei, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <310%>. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide
<wherever Lactuca sativa is grown>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions; then systemic mosaic,
rugosity. Carthamus tinctorius, Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mosaic. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa, Lactuca sativa. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L), Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Beta vulgaris,

Lettuce necrotic yellows cytorhabdovirus

      (1) J.W. Randles, 1980. Revised 1987. (3) Standard acronym: LNYV. (4)
Strains: severe (SE 3) and mild strains reported. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.4.0.005. (8) First reported in Lactuca sativa. (9) From Victoria,
Australia. (10) By Stubbs et al. (1963). (11) Symptoms persist, or disappear
soon after infection <symptomless>. (13) Lactuca sativa leaves first dull
green, then chlorotic, outer leaves flaccid, bronzed and sometimes necrotic;
plants stunted, and late infected plants have heads with internal necrosis.
Sonchus oleraceus, S. hydrophilus, Reichardia tingitana, Embergeria
megalocarpa symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Hyperomyzus lactucae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Randles (1983). (39) Spreads in Australia. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Lactuca sativa systemic yellowing, leaf malformation. Datura stramonium
faint systemic interveinal chlorosis. Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local
lesions; systemic yellowing, rugosity, leaf malformation. (45) Lactuca sativa,
Nicotiana glutinosa. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa. (47) Datura stramonium, or
Embergeria megalocarpa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Reichardia
tingitana, or Sonchus hydrophilus, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea.
(48) Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <5/6>, or
Solanaceae <6/7>. (51) Compositae <1/6>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <1/7>. (53) Stubbs et al.
(1963). (54) TIP: 52 °C. (55) LIV: 0.3-1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (57)
Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions, or contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
aldehyde fixation necessary. (60) Method: McLean and Francki (1967). (61)
Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 227 nm <in negative stain>, or 360 nm <in
tissue sections>. (71) Virions 52 nm wide <in tissue sections>, or 66 nm wide
<in negative stain>. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obscure. (75)
Pitch of basic helix 4.5 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 940 S. (80) Density 1.19-1.2 g
cm3 in sucrose. (81) Density in Nycodenz, c. 1.135 g cm3. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 12.54 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 12.54 kb. (109) Infectivity
lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 32612.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): L24364 Em(40)_vi:LYLRNAA
Gb(84)_vi:LYLRNAA Lettuce necrotic yellows virus RNA, 3' UTR. 5/94 84bp.

necrotic yellows virus nucleocapsid gene, complete cds. 1/95 1,533bp. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells <Randles et al., 1972)>. (132) Virion
protein(s) five <Laemmli, 1970>. (133) Mr <of the largest> 180000-190000.
(134) L protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 76000. (136) G protein. (137) Mr of
3rd largest 54000. (138) N protein. (139) Mr of 4th largest 38000. (140) NS

Are G protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)

Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)

Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with

P.W.G. and Francki, R.I.B. (1982). Ann appl. Biol. 100: 149. Crowley, N.C.,

Lettuce speckles mottle umbravirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: LSMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
78.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Beta vulgaris, Lactuca sativa, Spinacia
oleracea. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Falk et al. (1978; 1979). (11) Symptoms
vary seasonally. (13) Beta vulgaris, Lactuca sativa, Spinacia oleracea in
mixed infections, the virus enhances the symptoms induced by beet western
yellows luteovirus; the outer leaves of infected plants, especially those of
lettuce, develop numerous angular chlorotic spots to produce the so-called
speckles disease. Symptoms of the complex become less conspicuous as ambient
temperatures rise. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani, Brevicoryne
brassicae, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal
natural vector(s): Myzus persicae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner.
(29) Virus requires, for vector transmission, a helper virus <beet western
yellows luteovirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in the USA <California>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Beta vulgaris, Spinacia oleracea, Nicotiana glutinosa, Physalis floridana no
conspicuous systemic infection. Chenopodium quinoa local lesions. Nicotiana
clevelandii faint interveinal chlorotic spotting of systemically infected
leaves (especially under cool shady conditions). (44) Beta macrocarpa,
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum, Petunia ×
hybrida. (45) Lactuca sativa, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa
(L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris
ssp. napus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca
sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Physalis floridana, or Spinacia oleracea. (48)
Apium graveolens, or Beta macrocarpa, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
or Brassica juncea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cichorium endiva, or
Conium maculatum, or Coriandrum sativum, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus
carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Raphanus sativus,
or Sonchus oleraceus. (50) Chenopodiaceae <5/7>, or Compositae <1/3>, or
Cruciferae <2/5>, or Solanaceae <5/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/7>, or Compositae <2/3>, or Cruciferae <3/5>, or Solanaceae
<5/10>, or Umbelliferae <4/4>. (52) The host range of the virus is wider when
viruliferous aphids are used to infect plants. (53) Falk et al. (1979). (55)
LIV: 2 days <but twice as long in sap from plants also infected with beet
yellows luteovirus>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (179)
Umbravirus. (186) The virus probably lacks a functional coat protein and, in
mixed infections, is probably encapsidated in that of beet western yellow
luteovirus (its helper virus). It thus resembles carrot mottle, groundnut
rosette, tobacco mottle and tobacco yellow vein viruses. (187) Falk, B.W.,
Morris, T.J. and Duffus, J.E. (1978). Proc. Am. Phytopath. Soc. 5: 97. Falk,
B.W., Duffus, J.E. and Morris, T.J. (1977). Phytopathology 69: 612.


Lilac chlorotic leafspot capillovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LCLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
13.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Syringa vulgaris. (9) From south east
England. (10) By Brunt (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Syringa vulgaris
chlorotic local lesions, which may coalesce, enlarge and produce indistinct
line patterns. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Macrosiphoniella
sanborni, Myzus ligustri, M. persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in south east England. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium quinoa
irregular necrotic local lesions, then systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. capitatum, C. murale few necrotic local lesions; not
systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. glutinosa × N. clevelandii,
N. rustica faint systemic leaf chlorosis. Phaseolus vulgaris systemic
chlorotic local lesions. (44) Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Glycine max,
Nicotiana megalosiphon, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
glutinosa, N. rustica, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Beta macrocarpa, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Silene
armeria, or Syringa vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba. (48) Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Citrus

or Malus sylvestris, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Pisum
sativum, or Trifolium repens, or Triticum aestivum, or Tropaeolum majus, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Caryophyllaceae
<1/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/7>, or
Oleaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/10>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/3>, or
Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae
<4/4>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae

Rutaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/10>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (53) Brunt
(1978). (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 8-16 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Brunt (1978). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)

nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix <occasionally> obvious, or
