Density 1.302 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.69. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in
leaves, mesophyll and the vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: enlarged
and sinuous thylakoids in chloroplasts near inclusions. (179) Capillovirus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet yellow stunt, beet
yellows, carnation necrotic fleck and apple chlorotic leafspot viruses. (187)
Brunt, A.A. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 88: 383. Brunt, A.A. and Stace-Smith, R.
(1978). J. gen. Virol. 39: 63.


Lilac mottle carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LiMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.017. (8) First reported in Syringa oblata var. affinis. (9) From the
U.S.A. (in plants from China). (10) By Waterworth (1972). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Syringa oblata var. affinis leaf chlorosis and mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor local lesions; not
systemic. Chenopodium quinoa local lesions; systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana
megalosiphon, Petunia × hybrida, Physalis franchetii systemic chlorosis. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana tabacum,
Glycine max. (45) Petunia × hybrida, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L and W) Petunia × hybrida (W). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Physalis franchetii, or Syringa oblata var. affinis. (48) Capsicum
annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana
tabacum. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Oleaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/6>.
(51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<3/6>. (54) TIP: 67-70 °C. (55) LIV: 0.5-1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Waterworth (1972). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 575-610 nm. (72) Axial
canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: carnation latent, chrysanthemum B and red
clover vein mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: potato S virus. (186) A carlavirus tentatively named lilac ringspot
virus occurs in lilacs in Japan (Y. Doi, in Hull et al., 1989). Its
relationship to lilac mottle and other carlaviruses has not yet been
determined. (187) Hull, R., Brown, F. and Payne, C. (1989). Directory and
Dictionary of Animal, Bacterial and Plant Viruses, p.119. MacMillan Reference
Books, London. Waterworth, H.E. (1972). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 923.


Lilac ring mottle ilarvirus

      (1) F.A. van der Meer, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: LRMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 10.0.2.07.01. (8) First reported in Syringa vulgaris. (9) From
the Netherlands. (10) By Van der Meer (1976). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically
over a few weeks and vary seasonally <infected plants show symptoms in spring;
cvs Mme Florent Stepman and Mme Lemoine show clear symptoms>. (13) Syringa
vulgaris faint rings and line patterns. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <in Chenopodium quinoa,
C. amaranticolor, but not in lilac (Van der Meer, 1976)>. (36) Studies
reported by Van der Meer (1976); Van der Meer et al. (1976). (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in Canada, the Netherlands and the U.K. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa systemic epinasty
and tip necrosis. Celosia plumosa chlorotic flecks, then systemic chlorosis.
Nicotiana megalosiphon necrotic local lesions, then systemic mottling.
Nicotiana tabacum transient wilting of the first leaves to be systemically
infected. (44) Cucumis sativus, Amaranthus caudatus, Capsicum annuum,
Lycopersicon esculentum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (W).
(47) Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Celosia plumosa, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Syringa vulgaris, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus,
or Lycopersicon esculentum. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Oleaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <5/7>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <2/7>. (53) Van der Meer (1976). (54) TIP: 63-65 °C. (55) LIV: 0.2
days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4 <in sap of Chenopodium quinoa>. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix virions with 2%
glutaraldehyde. (60) Method: Van der Meer et al. (1976). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 27 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest (B) component> 98 S. (78) Of the
other(s) 83 S <M>. (79) Density 1.345 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density 1.265 in
Cs2SO4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.43-1.46. (84) Virions contain 13-14 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 86-87 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 9.042 kb. (92) Genome of
three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.324 kb. (94)
The 2nd largest 3.183 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.535 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Huttinga and Mosch (1976). (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor required for
infectivity. (113) Additional factor is coat protein plus RNA 1, 2 and 3.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 37125. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): U17391
Em(43)_vi:Lr17391 Gb(89)_vi:Lru17391 Lilac ring mottle virus RNA 3 movement
protein and coat protein genes, complete cds. 5/95. (120) Nongenomic nucleic
acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA <RNA-4 1.042 kb>. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
27500. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Huttinga and Mosch
(1976). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (179) Ilarvirus:
Bromoviridae <subgroup 7>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: apple mosaic, elm mottle, prunus necrotic
ringspot, spinach latent and tobacco streak viruses. (184) Serological tests
quickly distinguish lilac ring mottle virus from related viruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: ten other sap transmissible viruses are known to infect
lilac (Van der Meer, 1980, 1981; Waterworth, 1972), thus identification of
lilac ring mottle virus by testing in standard indicator plants, like
Chenopodium and Nicotiana species, is unreliable and serological tests are
required. (187) Bos, L., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1980). Neth. J. Pl.
Path. 86: 79. Fulton, R.W. (1983). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 275, 3 pp.
Huttinga, H. and Mosch, W.H.M. (1976). Acta Hort. 59: 113. Huttinga, H., Maat,
D.Z. and van der Meer, F.A. (1976). Acta Bot. neerl. 25: 251. Van der Meer,
F.A. (1976). Acta Hort. 59: 105. Van der Meer, F.A. (1980). Acta Hort. 110:
211. Van der Meer, F.A. and Huttinga, H. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses
No. 201, 4 pp. Van der Meer, F.A., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1976). Neth.
J. Pl. Path. 82: 67. Waterworth, H.E. (1972). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 923.

Lily symptomless carlavirus

      (1) C.J. Asjes, 1986. (2) Synonyms: lily curl stripe virus, lily virus,
lily streak virus. (3) Standard acronym: LSV. (4) Strains: alstroemeria
carlavirus (Brunt and Phillips, 1981; Derks et al., 1991; Phillips and Brunt,
1982). (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.018. (8) First reported in Lilium spp.
(9) From Oregon, U.S.A. (10) By Brierley and Smith (1944). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (13) The only known natural hosts are from the Liliaceae, and all
are infected systemically. Lilium longiflorum curling and striping in cool
conditions. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Lilium longiflorum (Asiatic hybrids) usually symptomless, but chlorotic
striping and leaf curling in cool conditions. (45) Asiatic hybrids of lily.
(46) Lilium longiflorum (W), Tulipa gesneriana cultivars (W). (47)
Alstroemeria, or Lilium longiflorum, or Tulipa gesneriana cultivars. (50)
Alstroemeriaceae <1/1>, or Liliaceae <2/2>. (53) Brierley and Smith (1944);
McWhorter and Allen (1964, 1967); Derks and Asjes (1975). (60) Method:
Civerolo et al. (1968); Derks and Asjes (1975); Derks and Vink-van den Abeele
(1980). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 640 nm. (71) Virions 17-18 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 172 S. (84) Virions contain 8.3 %
nucleic acid <Civerolo et al., 1968>. (91) Total genome size 8 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 8 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12173. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X15343 Em(40)_vi:POLS3TER
Gb(84)_vi:POLS3TER Lily symptomless virus RNA 3-terminal region encoding 25kD,
12kD, 7kD, 16kDa proteins and 32kD. D43801 Em(43)_vi:Llvcp Gb(89)_vi:Llvcp
Lily symptomless virus mRNA for coat protein. 12/94 876bp. (171) Virions found
in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <except
possibly the meristematic region>. (174) Inclusions absent from infected
cells. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
Alstroemeria carlavirus closely, but distinct, also chrysanthemum B, potato M,
potato S, carnation latent and passiflora latent viruses. (186) Lily streak
disease is now known to be caused by tulip breaking potyvirus alone or mixed
with LSV. (187) Allen, T.C. (1971). Lily Yrbk., N. Am. Lily Soc. 24: 29.
Allen, T.C. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 96, 4 pp. Asjes, C.J., de
Vos, N. and van Slogteren, D.H.M. (1973). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 79: 23. Brierley,
P. and Smith, F.F. (1944). Phytopathology 34: 529. Brunt, A.A. and Phillips,
S. (1981). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1979, p. 151. Civerolo, E.L.,
Semancik, J.S. and Weathers, L.G. (1968). Phytopathology 58: 1481. Derks,
A.F.L.M. and Asjes, C.J. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81: 14. Derks, A.F.L.M.,
Lemmers, M.E.C. and Hollinger, Th.C. (1982). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.

Lily X potexvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (2) Synonyms: lily potexvirus. (3) Standard
acronym: LVX. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Lilium
formosanum. (9) From England. (10) By Stone (1976; 1980). (13) Lilium
formosanum symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in the UK. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic
local lesions, becoming green rings. Chenopodium quinoa minute chlorotic local
lesions. C. murale chlorotic local lesions. (44) Trifolium incarnatum,
Nicotiana megalosiphon, Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (46) Tetragonia tetragonioides (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L),
Chenopodium murale (L). (47) Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lilium formosanum, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana debneyi,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/9>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <7/9>. (52)
Some hosts, recorded as insusceptible by Stone (1980), have subsequently been
infected using concentrated purified virion preparations. (53) Stone (1980).
(59) Electron microscopy: usually necessary to use ISEM to detect virions in
sap. (60) Method: Stone (1980). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 470 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12194. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X15342 Em(40)_vi:POLX3TERM
Gb(84)_vi:POLX3TERM Lily virus X RNA 3' terminal region encoding 24kDa and
12KD proteins, 22kDa coat protein. 5/91 1 sequence. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
dioscorea latent (SDI 9) and commelina X (SDI 10) viruses. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: cactus X, cymbidium mosaic, hydrangea
ringspot, narcissus mosaic, nerine X (Agapanthus strain), papaya mosaic
(papaya and ullucus strains), potato aucuba mosaic, potato X and white clover
mosaic viruses. (184) ISEM with `decoration' rapidly distinguishes this virus
from other potexviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM. (186) Stone
(1980) estimated the length of the virions to be about 550 nm, but more recent
estimates are of about 470 nm, which is shorter than that recorded for most
potexviruses (usually 480-580 nm), but is longer than that recorded for
dioscorea latent virus (445 nm), with which this virus shows some serological
affinity. (187) Stone, O.M. (1976). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1975, p.
122. Stone, O.M. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 59.

Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (183) The possible relationship of this virus to those causing
similar diseases in lima beans in India (Capoor and Varma, 1948), Puerto Rico
(Bird et al., 1972), Brazil (Costa, 1965), Colombia (Galvez and Cardenas,
1980) and Costa Rica (Gamez, 1971) has not been determined. (187) Bird, J.,
Perez, J.E., Alconero, R., Vakili, N.G. and Melendez, P.L. (1972). J. Agric.
Univ. P.R. 56: 64. Capoor, S.P. and Varma, P.M. (1948). Curr. Sci. 17: 152.

(1994). Acta Hort. 377: 81.


Lisianthus necrosis (?) necrovirus

      (1) P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LNV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 44.0.1.T.005. (8) First reported in Eustoma russellianum. (9) From Japan.
(10) By Iwaki et al. (1985). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Eustoma russellianum
necrotic lesions and rings, tip necrosis and, in some cultivars, colour
breaking. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17)
Transmitted by Olpidium sp. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic
local lesions. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii local lesions,
systemic necrotic spots and/or general necrosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris,
Sesamum indicum, Vigna unguiculata necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (44)
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Capsicum annuum, Dianthus caryophyllus,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana debneyi. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii,
Eustoma russellianum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris
(L), Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi (L), N. clevelandii (W). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,
or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Eustoma russellianum, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesamum
indicum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (48) Brassica campestris
ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana debneyi. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gentianaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/7>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <3/7>. (53) Iwaki et al. (1987). (54) TIP: 90-95 °C. (55) LIV:
<more than> 63 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 9-10. (60) Method: Iwaki et al.
(1987). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 136 S. (79) Density 1.333 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio
1.61. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size
4.185 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35500. (134) Coat protein.
(179) <Possible> Necrovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: tobacco necrosis, cucumber necrosis and melon necrotic spot viruses.
(187) Iwaki, M., Hanada, K., Maria, E.R.A. and Onogi, S. (1987).
Phytopathology 77: 867. Iwaki, M., Maria, E.R.A., Hanada, K., Onogi, S. and
Zenbayashi, R. (1985). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 355.


Lotus streak (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Yamashita, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.5.T.D.07. (8) First reported in Nelumbo nucifera (East Indian Lotus). (9)
From Okayama, Japan. (10) By Yamashita et al. (1978). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Nelumbo nucifera chlorotic spots or ring spots, streaking of roots. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Rhopalosiphum nymphaeae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (39) Spreads in Japan. (45) Nelumbo nucifera. (47) Nelumbo
nucifera. (50) Nelumbonaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: necessary to prefix with glutaraldehyde or osmium
tetroxide. (60) Method: Yamashita et al. (1985). (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300-340
nm. (71) Virions 90 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.5 nm. (171) Virions found in leaves and
shoots. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms <in the nucleus>.
(177) They contain virions <of nucleoprotein without envelope>. (179)
<Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187)
Yamashita, S., Okamoto, Y., Fujii, S., Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1978). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 44: 61. Yamashita, S., Doi, Y., Yora, K., Okamoto, Y.
and Fujii, S. (1985). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 51: 627.


Lucerne Australian latent nepovirus

      (1) A.T. Jones, 1980. Revised 1987. (2) Synonyms: lucerne latent virus.
(3) Standard acronym: LALV. (4) Strains: lucerne strain, white clover strain.
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.019. (8) First reported in Medicago sativa. (9)
From eastern Victoria, Australia. (10) By Taylor and Smith (1971). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Medicago sativa symptomless. Trifolium repens
chlorotic line patterns or symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <i.e. 1% in C. quinoa and
lucerne>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported
by Jones et al. (1979). (39) Spreads in Australia and New Zealand. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa systemic mottle,
vein yellowing. Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic mottle. C. quinoa necrotic
local lesions; systemic mottling or streaking. Pisum sativum necrotic local
lesions; symptomless systemic infection. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Pisum
sativum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (W), C. quinoa (L,W). (47) Cajanus
cajan, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus
angustifolius, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vigna unguiculata. (48)
Arachis hypogaea, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Glycine max, or Ipomoea setosa, or Lablab purpureus, or Lotus corniculatus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/6>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <14/20>, or Solanaceae <5/9>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/6>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<8/20>, or Solanaceae <4/9>. (53) Blackstock (1978); Jones et al. (1979);
Forster et al. (1985). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Jones et al.
(1979). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 24-27
nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 133 S
<B>. (78) Of the other(s) 128 S <M>, or 56 S <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.71
<unfractionated M and B>. (84) Virions contain 41 % nucleic acid <B>, or 39 %
nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B>, or
61 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 14.7 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7.9 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 6.8
kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 55000. (145) Method of preparation:
Jones et al. (1979). (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (187)
Blackstock, J.M. (1978). Aust. J. agric. Res. 29: 291. Forster, R.L.S. and
Morris-Krsinich, B. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 107: 449. Jones, A.T. and
Forster, R.L.S. (1980). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 225, 4 pp. Jones, A.T.,
Forster, R.L.S. and Mohamed, N.A. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 92: 49. Taylor,
R.H. and Smith, P.R. (1971). Rep. Vic. Pl. Res. Inst. 5: 20.


Lucerne Australian symptomless (?) nepovirus

      (1) A.T. Jones, 1987. (2) Synonyms: lucerne Australian latent virus SM
strain. (3) Standard acronym: LASV. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.004. (8)
First reported in Medicago sativa. (9) From Melbourne, Australia. (10) By
Blackstock (1978). (11) Symptoms none <but infection persists>. (13) Medicago
sativa symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus transmitted by seed <up to 6% in Chenopodium quinoa>. (39) Spreads in
Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor faint systemic mottle. C. murale chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions; then systemic necrotic spots and epinasty of apical leaves. C. quinoa
faint systemic mottle. Gomphrena globosa red rings spots; not systemic.
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N. tabacum cvs White Burley, Samsun NN,
Pisum sativum, Spinacia oleracea symptomless. Nicotiana debneyi and Petunia ×
hybrida local symptomless infection. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, B.
nigra, Catharanthus roseus, Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon
esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica, Phaseolus vulgaris, Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Vicia faba. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa
(L); C. murale (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica nigra, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>, or Solanaceae
<5/9>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>, or Solanaceae <4/9>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: <greater than> 24 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: most
virions are either penetrated by stain or disrupted, when stained with 2% AM,
MT or UA. (60) Method: Remah et al. (1986). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26-28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 130 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 10.9 kb. (92) Genome of two parts <plus
2 minor uncharacterized components of lengths 0.85 kb and 0.56 kb>. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.9 kb.
(99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Remah et al. (1986). (108) Infectivity
lost when deproteinised with proteases. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr
<of the larger> 40000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 26000. (145) Method of
preparation: Remah et al. (1986). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arracacha B (strains O
and T), bean pod mottle, broad bean mottle, broad bean true mosaic, broad bean
stain, broad bean wilt (serotype 1 and 2), cowpea mosaic, crimson clover
latent, cucumber mosaic, lucerne transient streak, rubus Chinese seed-borne,
strawberry latent ringspot and tobacco ringspot viruses. (184) The virus is
similar to strawberry latent ringspot (Murant, 1974) and its relative rubus
Chinese seed-borne virus (Barbara et al., 1985), which are tentative members
of the nepovirus group (Harrison and Murant, 1977; Barbara et al., 1985).
(187) Barbara, D.J., Ashby, S.C. and McNamara, D.G. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol.
107: 45. Blackstock, J.M. (1978). Aust. J. agric. Res. 29: 291. Harrison, B.D.
and Murant, A.F. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 185, 4 pp. Murant,
A.F. (1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 126, 4 pp. Remah, A., Jones, A.T.
and Mitchell, M.J. (1986). Ann. appl. Biol. 109: 307.


Lucerne enation (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) P.A. Signoret, B.C. Alliot, 1981. (3) Standard acronym: LEV. (5)

Transmitted by Aphis craccivora. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in France <the south and the Mediterranean>. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Morocco, Spain, Italy, Yugoslavia, Romania. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Vicia faba stem enations. (47) Medicago
sativa, or Vicia faba. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (70) Virions of 250 nm. (71)
Virions 82-89 nm wide. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in
the perinuclear space. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)

Lucerne transient streak sobemovirus

      (1) R.L.S. Forster, 1982. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: LTSV. (5)

From Victoria, Australia. (10) By Blackstock (1974; 1978). (11) Symptoms
disappear soon after infection. (13) Medicago sativa vein yellowing. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada,
and New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor necrotic local lesions; systemic chlorotic blotching
(Australian, but not Ne Zealand isolates). Chenopodium quinoa necrotic and
chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. Medicago scutellata necrotic local

symptomless (Australian isolates); no systemic infection. Nicotiana
clevelandii chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. (44) Cucumis sativus,
Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana glutinosa, Vigna unguiculata.

or Compositae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/24>, or Solanaceae
<4/13>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Compositae
<2/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <16/24>, or Solanaceae <9/13>. (53) Blackstock
(1978); Forster and Jones (1979). (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: 28 days. (56)

Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 27-28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular

kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.23 kb. (106)

Lupin leaf curl (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LLCV. (5) ICTV decimal code

severe plant stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in India.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Lupinus hartwegii downcurling of
leaves and petioles, thickening of veins and stunting. (46) Lupinus hartwegii
(W). (47) Lupinus hartwegii. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (179)
<Possible> bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (186) This
uncharacterized virus has been included by the ICTV as a possible
bigeminivirus (Francki et al., 1991). (187) Francki, R.I.B., Fauquet, C.M.,

Lychnis (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.009. (8) First

(1985). Acta Hort. 164: 21.


Lychnis ringspot hordeivirus

      (1) A.O. Jackson, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: LRSV. (4) Strains: Salinas
isolate, European isolate (Hungary), Mentha. (5) ICTV decimal code
32.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Lychnis divaricata. (9) From Salinas,
California, U.S.A. in seed imported from Europe. (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms mosaic, ringspot, necrosis. (13) Lychnis divaricata, L. chalcedonica,
L. coronaria, L. haageana systemic ringspots, mosaic and necrosis. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus <probably> transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Hungary. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
ringspots and mosaic. (43) Capsicum frutescens, Chenopodium album, C.
amaranticolor, Nicotiana tabacum chlorotic or necrotic local lesions.
Callistephus chinensis, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, Petunia ×
hybrida, Tetragonia tetragonioides systemic. (44) Centaurea cyanus, Lactuca
sativa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata, Lycopersicon
esculentum. (45) Spinacia oleracea. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47)
Beta patellaris, or Callistephus chinensis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Gypsophila elegans, or
Lychnis chalcedonica, or Lychnis coronaria, or Lychnis divaricata, or Lychnis
haageana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Centaurea cyanus, or
Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Phytolacca americana, or Solanum nigrum, or Theobroma cacao, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. unguiculata. (50) Caryophyllaceae <6/6>, or Chenopodiaceae
<6/6>, or Compositae <1/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/8>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae <2/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/8>, or Sterculiaceae <1/1>.
(60) Method: Hunter et al. (1989). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 100-175 nm. (71) Virions 25 nm wide. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein.
(86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 9 kb. (92) Genome of three parts. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part <the largest> 3.8 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.3 kb. (95)
The 3rd largest 3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hunter et al.
(1989). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 44421. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
23000. (145) Method of preparation: SDS gel electrophoresis. (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (179) Hordeivirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: barley stripe mosaic and poa semilatent
viruses. (184) No detectable cross-hybridization between lychnis ringspot
virus, barley stripe mosaic virus and poa semilatent virus genomes and cDNAs
transcribed from them. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA. (187) Bennett,
C.W. (1959). Phytopathology 49: 708. Beczner, L., Hamilton, R.I. and Rochon,
D.M. (1992). Intervirology 33: 49. Hunter, B.G., Smith, J., Fattouh, F. and
Jackson, A.O. (1989). Intervirology 30: 18. Jackson, A.O. and Lane, L.C.
(1981). In: Handbook of Virus Infections and Comparative Diagnosis, p. 565;
ed. E. Kurstak, Elsevier/North Holland Biomedical Press, Amsterdam.


Maclura mosaic macluravirus

      (1) N. Plese, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: MacMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.U.2.001. (8) First reported in Maclura pomifera. (9) From Zagreb,
Croatia, Yugoslavia. (10) By Plese and MilicHicH (1973). (11) Symptoms persist
and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms mosaic. (13) Maclura pomifera interveinal
mosaic, occasional vein-banding and leaf distortion especially in spring and
autumn (Plese and MilicHicH, 1973; Plese and Stefanac, 1976). (15)
Experimentally transmitted by the aphid Myzus persicae and is non-persistent.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (39) Spreads in the former Yugoslavia. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local mild
symptoms or no symptoms. (43) Amaranthus caudatus, Chenopodium album chlorotic
local lesions. C. amaranticolor circular necrotic local lesions. C. quinoa
latent local infection. Nicotiana clevelandii mild systemic mosaic. N.
megalosiphon latent systemic infection. Tetragonia tetragonioides diffuse
chlorotic local lesions. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Datura
stramonium, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii,
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Amaranthus
caudatus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium
foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Maclura pomifera, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris.
(50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Moraceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/5>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/5>. (53)
Plese and MilicHicH (1973); Plese and Stefanac (1976); Plese et al. (1979).
(54) TIP: 65-67 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Plese et al. (1979). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 672 nm. (71)
Virions 13-16 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 155 S. (79) Density 1.307 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio
1.04. (84) Virions contain 3-4 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 96-97 % protein.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 45000. (145) Method of preparation: Koenig et al. (1970); Koenig
(1972). (171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies
and pinwheels. (179) Macluravirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bean yellow mosaic virus (Plese et al., 1979). Weak reactions were
observed with antisera to poplar mosaic and narcissus latent carlaviruses
(Plese et al., 1979; Mowat et al., 1991). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: bean common mosaic, bidens mottle, clover yellow vein,
gloriosa stripe mosaic, lettuce mosaic, narcissus yellow stripe, pea necrosis,
pea seed borne mosaic, plum pox, potato Y, tobacco etch and turnip mosaic
viruses. (187) Koenig, R. (1972). Virology 50: 263. Koenig, R., Stegemann, H.,
Francksen, H. and Paul, H.L. (1970). Biochim. biophys. Acta 207: 184. Koenig,
R., Lesemann, D.-E. and Plese, N. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 239,
3 pp. Mowat, W.P., Dawson, S., Duncan, G.H. and Robinson, D.J. (1991). Ann.
appl. Biol. 119: 31. Plese, N. and MilicHicH, D. (1973). Phytopath. Z. 77:
178. Plese, N. and Stefanac, Z. (1976). Mitt. Biol. BundesAnst. Land. Forstw.
170: 47. Plese, N. and Wrischer, M. (1978). Acta bot. Croat. 37: 47. Plese,
N., Koenig, R., Lesemann, D.-E. and Bozarth, R.F. (1979). Phytopathology 69:
471.


Maize chlorotic dwarf waikavirus

      (1) R.E. Gingery, 1984. (2) Synonyms: Ohio corn stunt agent. (3)
Standard acronym: MCDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 65.0.2.0.003. (8) First reported
in Zea mays. (9) From Ohio, U.S.A. (10) By Bradfute et al. (1972). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Sorghum halepense mild vein clearing. Zea mays
stunting, reddening and yellowing, tertiary vein banding. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Graminella
nigrifrons most important, but also Graminella sonora and Exitianus exitiosus.
(18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in the USA <the south>.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Digitaria sanguinalis, Panicum
miliaceum, Pennisetum glaucum, Sorghum vulgare var. sudanense symptoms mild or
absent. Setaria faberi, S. lutescens. Sorghum bicolor, S. halepense mild vein
clearing. Triticum aestivum symptomless. Zea mays stunting, yellowing and
reddening, tertiary vein banding. (44) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Oryza
sativa, Saccharum officinarum, Secale cereale. (45) Zea mays. (46) Zea mays
(W). (47) Digitaria sanguinalis, or Panicum miliaceum, or Pennisetum glaucum,
or Setaria faberi, or Setaria halepense, or Setaria lutescens, or Sorghum
bicolor, or Sorghum halepense, or Sorghum vulgare var. sudanense, or Triticum
aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Avena sativa, or Cynodon dactylon, or Dactylis
glomerata, or Elytrigia repens, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or Hordeum vulgare,
or Lolium perenne, or Oryza sativa, or Paspalum dilatatum, or Phleum pratense,
or Saccharum officinarum, or Secale cereale, or Stenotaphrum secundatum, or
Triticum aestivum. (50) Gramineae <11/24>. (51) Gramineae <14/24>. (53) Nault
et al. (1976). (60) Method: Louie et al. (1974); Gingery (1976). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 183 S <± 6 S>. (79) Density 1.507 g cm3 in CsCl
<unfixed>. (84) Virions contain 36 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 64 % protein.
(86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 10.67 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 10.67 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gingery
(1976). (100) Base composition 24 % G. (101) Base composition 30 % A. (102)
Base composition 17 % C. (103) Base composition 29 % U. (132) Virion
protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 30000. (134) Coat protein. (135) Mr
of 2nd largest 18000. (171) Virions found in leaves and phloem but less
frequently in bundle sheath cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms and
unusual in shape. (176) Striated sheets and dense granular bodies. (177) They
contain virions <only in the dense granular inclusions>. (178) Other cellular
changes: numerous cytoplasmic vesicles. (179) Waikavirus: Sequiviridae. (180)
: Sequiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: rice
tungro waikavirus. (187) Bradfute, O.E., Gingery, R.E., Gordon, D.T. and
Nault, L.R. (1972). J. Cell Biol. 55: 25a. Derrick, K.S. and Brlansky, R.H.
(1976). Phytopathology 66: 815. Ge, X., Gordon, D.T. and Gingery, R.E. (1989).

Maize chlorotic mottle machlomovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and D.T. Gordon, 1987. Revised 1991 by A.A. Brunt. (3)
Standard acronym: MCMV. (4) Strains: Kansas serotypes 1 and 2, Peru serotype.
(5) ICTV decimal code 40.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From
Peru. (10) By Hebert and Castillo (1973). (13) Zea mays systemic chlorotic
leaf mottling; in mixtures with any of several potyviruses also causes
necrosis, stunting and death. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Diabrotica spp. and thrips. (18) Transmitted
by Coleoptera, or Thysanoptera. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <detected in 17 of 42000 seedlings from 25 seed lots>. (36) Studies
reported by Nault et al. (1978). (39) Spreads in Argentina, Mexico, Peru, and
the USA <Kansas, Nebraska and Hawaii>. (43) Zea mays systemic chlorotic leaf
mottling. Triticum aestivum systemic chlorotic leaf spotting and mottling.
(44) Sorghum bicolor. (45) Maize hybrids H84, N28 HT, N.28 and Oh 28, maize
hybrid PM 205, Zea mays cv. Aristogold Bantam Evergreen; see Uyemoto et al.
(1980). (46) Maize hybrids H84, N28 HT, N.28 and Oh 28 (W), maize hybrid PM
205 (W), Zea mays cv. Aristogold Bantam Evergreen (W). (47) Bromus inermis, or
Bromus mollis, or Bromus racemosus, or Bromus secalinus, or Bromus tectorum,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Panicum capillare, or Panicum dichotomiflorum, or
Panicum maximum, or Panicum miliaceum, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48)
Sorghum bicolor. (50) Gramineae <12/13>. (51) Gramineae <1/13>. (54) TIP:
80-85 °C <in maize sap>. (55) LIV: 12-33 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-8. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: R.E. Gingery in Gordon et al.
(1984); virions are stabilized by divalent cations. (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <c.> 30 nm in diameter <in PTAK, but
33 nm in UA>. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 109 S. (79) Density 1.365 g cm3
in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 82 % protein.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 4.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
4.4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lommel et al. (1991). (100) Base
composition 22-25 % G. (101) Base composition 24-26 % A. (102) Base
composition 15-16 % C. (103) Base composition 34-37 % U. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap. (110) Poly A region absent. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 12138. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X14736
Em(44)_vi:Mcmvxx Gb(90)_vi:Mcmvxx Maize chlorotic mottle virus genomic RNA.
9/93 4,437bp. (119) Features of the genome: the genome has four ORFs encoding
proteins of 32 kDa, 50 kDa (possibly the polymerase), 9kDa and 25.1 kDa (coat
protein). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
subgenomic mRNA <encodes coat protein>. (125) 2 virus specified dsRNA species
found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 4.4 kbp
<pairs>. (127) 2nd largest 1.1 kbp <pairs>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133)
Mr 25100 <238 amino acid residues>. (134) Coat protein. (179) Machlomovirus <a
monotypic genus>. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: brome
mosaic, cocksfoot mild mottle, cocksfoot mottle, cynosurus mottle, holcus
transitory mottle, maize chlorotic dwarf, maize rayado fino, maize streak,
maize stripe, maize white line, molinia streak, panicum mosaic, phleum mottle,
rice yellow mottle and sowbane mosaic viruses. (184) The virus resembles
carnation mottle and turnip crinkle carmoviruses in the amino acid sequence of
some of its proteins, in its genome organisation and gene expression strategy,
but has an additional ORF and lacks a second sub-genomic RNA. (187) Goldberg,
K.B. and Brakke, M.K. (1987). Phytopath. 77: 162. Gordon, D.T., Bradfute,
O.E., Gingery, R.E., Nault, L.R. and Uyemoto, J.K. (1984). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 284, 5 pp. Hebert, T.T. and Castillo (1973). Abstr. 2nd Int.
Congr. Pl. Path., Minneapolis, No. 72. Jaing, X.Q., Wilkinson, D.R. and Berry,
J.A. (1990). Phytopath. 80: 1060. Jensen, S.G., Wysong, D.S., Ball, E.M. and
Higley, P.M. (1991). Plant Dis. 75: 497. Lommel, S.A., Kendall, T.L., Siu,
N.F. and Nutter, R.C. (1991). Phytopathology 81: 819. Lommel, S.A., Kendall,
T.L., Xiong, Z. and Nutter, R.C. (1991). Virology 181: 382. Nault, L.R.,
Styer, W.E., Coffey, M.E., Gordon, D.T., Negi, L.S. and Niblett, C.L. (1978).
Phytopathology 68: 1071. Nutter, R.C., Sheeks, K., Panganiban, L.C. and
Lommel, S.A. (1989). Nucleic Acids Res. 17: 3163. Uyemoto, J.K., Bockelman,
D.L. and Claflin, L.E. (1980). Plant Dis. 64: 99.


Maize dwarf mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (2) Synonyms: MDMVA, MDMVD, MDMVE, MDMVF. (3)
Standard acronym: MDMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.039. (8) First reported
in Zea mays. (9) From Ohio, U.S.A. (10) By Williams and Alexander, 1965; Dale,
1965. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Sorghum halepense mosaic. Zea mays mosaic,
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by several species. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <maize>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in China, South Africa, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Panicum miliaceum, Zea mays mosaic, reddening and dwarfing.
Sorghum halepense, S. bicolor mosaic. (44) Setaria adhaerans, Hordeum vulgare,
Saccharum officinarum (some cultivars). (45) Zea mays (sweet corn). (46) Zea
mays (sweet corn) (W). (47) Arundo donax, or Bromus mollis, or Bromus
secalinus, or Bromus tectorum, or Chloris gayana, or Cynodon dactylon, or
Echinochloa crus-galli, or Eleusine coracana, or Lagurus ovatus, or Oryza
sativa, or Panicum capillare, or Panicum maximum, or Panicum miliaceum, or
Paspalum dilatatum, or Phalaris paradoxa, or Rottboellia exaltata, or
Saccharum officinarum, or Sacciolepis indica, or Setaria italica, or Setaria
viridis, or Sorghum bicolor, or Sorghum halepense, or Zea mays. (48)
Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Avena sativa, or Dactylis glomerata, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Lolium perenne, or Lolium temulentum, or Poa pratensis, or
Saccharum officinarum, or Secale cereale, or Setaria adhaerans, or Triticum
aestivum. (50) Gramineae <23/33>. (51) Gramineae <11/33>. (52) Differential
hosts for different isolates recorded by Rosenkranz (1987). (53) Rosenkranz
(1987). (54) TIP: 56 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-4. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Shukla et al. (1989a). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 770 nm. (117) NCBI Taxon
ID: 12203. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00949 Em(40)_vi:MDMCP
Gb(84)_vi:MDMCP Maize dwarf mosaic virus gene for coat protein, 3'terminal
region. 2/93 1,377bp. S77088 Gb(90)_un:S77088 polyprotein region (maize dwarf
mosaic virus MDMV, Genomic RNA, 1279 nt). 7/95 1,279bp. U07216
Em(40)_vi:MD07216 Gb(84)_vi:MDU07216 Maize dwarf mosaic virus MDMV-A
polyprotein (nuclear inclusion II protein, coat protein) gene 2 sequences.
(171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Bundles, scrolls
and tubes; type I inclusions (Edwardson, 1974). (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (184) This virus
is one of a complex of potyviruses infecting tropical grasses. These have been
shown by immunoblot and virion protein sequencing to be isolates of four
species; maize dwarf mosaic, sugarcane mosaic, sorghum mosaic and Johnson
grass mosaic. For details check the descriptions of the other three species
(Shukla et al., 1989). (187) Dale, J.L. (1965). Pl. Dis. Reptr 49: 202.
Edwardson, J.R. (1974). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 4. Ford, R.E., Tosic,
M. and Shukla, D.D. (1989). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 341, 5 pp.
Rosenkranz, E. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 1056. Rosenkranz, E. (1987).
Phytopathology 77: 598. Shukla, D.D., Tosic, M., Jilka, J., Ford, R.E., Toler,
R.W. and Langham, M.A.C. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 223. Williams, L.E. and
Alexander, L.J. (1965). Phytopathology 55: 802.


Maize eyespot virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux and C. Fauquet, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.22. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From Ivory Coast. (10) By
Fauquet and Thouvenel (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Zea mays chlorotic
`eyespotting', and chlorosis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Zea mays chlorotic `eyespotting', and chlorosis. Avena
sativa, Bromus sterilis symptomless systemic infection. Hordeum vulgare
systemic chlorotic rings and mosaic. Triticum aestivum, T. durum, Nicotiana
megalosiphon symptomless. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C.
murale, Oryza sativa. (45) Zea mays. (46) Zea mays (W). (47) Avena sativa, or
Bromus sterilis, or Hordeum vulgare, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii,
or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Torenia fournieri, or Triticum aestivum, or
Triticum durum, or Zea mays. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Oryza sativa. (50) Gramineae <6/7>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Gramineae <1/7>. (53) Fauquet and Thouvenel (1982). (54) TIP: 80-85 °C. (55)
LIV: <more than> 20 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 7-8. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Fauquet and Thouvenel (1982). (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (84) Virions contain 26 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 74 % protein. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: rice yellow mottle, tobacco necrosis, maize
stripe, tephrosia latent, southern bean mosaic, broad bean stain, pea enation
mosaic, squash mosaic, cowpea mosaic, tobacco ringspot, tomato ringspot,
cucumber mosaic, peanut stunt, tomato aspermy and red clover mottle viruses.
(187) Fauquet, C. and Thouvenel, J.-C. (1982). C. R. Acad. Sci. Paris 295:
293.


Maize Iranian mosaic (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) K. Izadpanah, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Iranian Shiraz maize mosaic virus.
(5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.T.D.08. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From
Shiraz, Iran. (10) By Izadpanah and Parvin (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms fine chlorotic striping on veins. (13) Echinochloa spp. chlorotic
streaking. Sorghum sudanense reddish striping of leaves. Zea mays fine
chlorotic or necrotic striping on leaf and sheath veins, stunting and ear
abortion wehen infected early. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Unkanodes tanasijevici, Laodelphax
striatellus, Peregrinus maidis. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Unkanodes tanasijevici, Laodelphax striatellus.
(24) Not transmitted by a number of aphid and cicadellid species. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by crops planted
late avoid infection (Izadpanah, 1991). (39) Spreads in Iran. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic leaf streaking, mosaic. (43) Echinochloa sp., Hordeum vulgare,
Sorghum sudanense, Zea mays chlorotic striping. (45) Zea mays. (46) Zea mays
(W). (47) Echinochloa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Sorghum sudanense, or Zea mays.
(50) Gramineae <4/4>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: PTA and UA. (60) Method: Izadpanah (1989). (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (70)
Virions of 180 nm. (71) Virions 80 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (132) Virion protein(s) six.
(134) Proteins G, L, N, NS, M1 and M2 have been reported (Gomez-Luengo and
Gordon, 1987). (148) Virion proteins glycosylated. (171) Virions found in
leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma and phloem (Ammar et al.,
1987). (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in the perinuclear space. (178)
Other cellular changes: enlargement of nucleoli, vesiculation of the
cytoplasm, tubular structures and degeneration of chloroplasts (Ammar et al.,
1987). (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: barley
yellow striate mosaic, cereal chlorotic mottle, cynodon chlorotic streak,
maize mosaic, maize sterile stunt, festuca leaf streak, Moroccan wheat,
northern cereal mosaic, wheat chlorotic streak and wheat rosette stunt
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Iranian maize mosaic (IMMV) and maize
rough dwarf (MRDV) viruses are often found together in the same field and
sometimes the same plant. MRDV induces small galls on the leaf veins, whereas
IMMV induces chlorotic streaks. Also, sugarcane mosaic virus may occur in the
same field but it produces mosaics. (187) Ammar, E.D., Gomez-Luengo, R.G. and
Gordon, D.T. (1987). Phytopathology 77:; 1732. Gomez-Luengo, R.G. and Gordon,
D.T. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 1705. Izadpanah, K. (1989). J. Phytopath. 126:
43. Izadpanah, K. (1991). J. Phytopath. 131: 290. Izadpanah, K. and Parvin, S.
(1979). Iran. J. Pl. Path. 15: 53. Izadpanah, K., Ahmadi, A.A., Parvin, S. and
Jafari, S.A. (1983). J. Phytopath. 107: 283. Milne, R.G., Masenga, V. and
Conti, M. (1986). Intervirology 25: 83. Nault, L.R. and Ammar, E.D. (1989).
Ann. Rev. Ent. 34: 503.


Maize line virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and K. Bock, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.23.
(8) First reported in Zea mays (in complex with maize stripe tenuivirus). (9)
From Tanzania. (10) By Storey (1936). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Zea mays
yellow striping along leaf veins but no apical bending or stunting, like that
caused by maize stripe virus. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Peregrinus maidis. (18) Transmitted by
Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (36) Studies reported by Kulkarni (1973); Smith (1936). (39)
Spreads in Kenya and Tanzania <symptoms are swamped by maize streak virus,
which is widespread, so this virus may occur more commonly (Kulkarni, 1973)>.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Zea mays (hybrid 511, hybrid 613B,
Wisconsin 641AA) small chlorotic spots at leaf bases, followed by vein
chlorosis and mottling. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa,
Glycine max, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Zea mays. (46) Zea
mays (W). (47) Zea mays. (48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Glycine max, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50)
Gramineae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Kulkarni (1973); Storey (1936). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Kulkarni (1973). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 34 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
cucumber mosaic, maize mottle chlorotic stunt and maize streak viruses. (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: Maize line virus sometimes occurs together with
maize streak and/or sugarcane mosaic viruses. (187) Kulkarni, H.Y. (1973).
Ann. appl. Biol. 75: 205. Storey, H.H. (1936). E. Afr. Agric. J. 1: 333.


Maize mosaic nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) R. Lastra, 1985. (2) Synonyms: virus del enanismo rayado maiz, maize
stripe Indian virus (Sharma and Payak, 1983), sorghum chlorosis virus, zea
mays virus. (3) Standard acronym: MMV. (4) Strains: MMV raya fina, MMV raya
gruesa. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.0.004. (8) First reported in Zea mays.
(9) From Colombia. (10) By Lastra and Acosta (1979). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Rottboellia exaltata, Setaria vulpiseta, Zea mays green-yellow spotting,
striping and vein-banding, some apical bending. Sorghum bicolor interveinal
chlorotic streaking, stunting and severe yield loss. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Peregrinus maidis.
(18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in <possibly> Australia, Colombia, Costa
Rica, Fiji, India, Mauritius, Mexico, Peru, Spain, Tanzania, and the USA <and
the Caribbean Islands>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (45) Zea mays.
(46) Zea mays (W). (47) Rottboellia exaltata, or Setaria vulpiseta, or Sorghum
bicolor, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <4/4>. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Lastra and Acosta (1979). (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length.
(70) Virions of 225 nm <242 nm in thin sections>. (71) Virions 90 nm wide <48m
in thin sections>. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 774 S. (80) Density 1.181 g cm3 in sucrose.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 12.54
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 12.54 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Lastra and Acosta (1979). (108) Infectivity
lost when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity lost when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor required for
infectivity. (113) Additional factor probably a polymerase. (122) Nongenomic
nucleic acid N protein. (132) Virion protein(s) five. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
75000. (136) 0 protei. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 50000. (139) Mr of 4th largest
45000. (140) NS protein. (141) Mr of 5th largest 33000. (142) M protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Autrey (1983); Falk and Tsai (1983). (148) Virion
proteins <probably> glycosylated. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (165)
Coat protein mRNA translated in probably in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host
plant. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear space. (173) Virions found in
and the cores bud through the inner nuclear membrane. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Aggregates.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Autrey, L.C. (1983). Proc. Int. Maize Virus Disease
Wksh., 1982, p. 167. Wooster, Ohio, Agric. Res. and Dev. Center. Christie,
R.G. and Edwardson, J.R. (1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 9. Falk, B.W.
and Tsai, J.H. (1983). Phytopathology 73: 1536. Herold, F. (1972). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 94, 4 pp. Herold, F. and Munz, K. (1965). Virology 25:
412. Herold, F. and Munz, K. (1967). J. gen. Virol. 1: 227. Herold, F.,
Bergold, G.H. and Weibel, J. (1960). Virology 12: 335. Kunkel, L.O. (1921).
Bull. Hawaiian Sug. Pltrs. Assoc. Exp. Stn Bot. Ser. 3: 44. Lastra, R.G. and
Acosta, J.M. (1979). Intervirology 11: 215. Lastra, R.G. and Corballo, O.
(1983). Proc. Int. Maize Disease Wksh, 1982, p. 83. Wooster, Ohio, Agric. Res.
and Dev. Center. Naidan, R.A., Harikrishnan, R., Manohar, S.K., Reddy, D.V.R.,
Rakna, A.S., King, S.B. and Bandyopadhyay, R. (1989). Ann. appl. Biol. 114:
301. Sharma, R.C. and Payak, M.M. (1983). Proc. Int. Maize Virus Dis. Colloq.
Wksh., Wooster, Ohio 1982, p. 186. Tsai, J.H. and Falk, B.W. (1988). In:
Advances in Vector Research Vol 5. Springer-Verlag. New York.


Maize mottle/chlorotic stunt virus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (2) Synonyms: maize mottle virus. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.DE.24. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From Tanzania. (10) By
Storey (1937). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Zea mays transient leaf mottling in
young leaves and, in susceptible cultivars, conspicuous chlorosis of older
leaves, stunting of plants and sometimes tassel abortion, loss of seed
production and bending of shoots. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Cicadulina mbila, C. zeae, C.
storeyi and C. triangula. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted
in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies reported by
Storey (1937); Rossel and Thottappilly (1985). (39) Spreads in Nigeria,
Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Tanzania, Togo, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Zea mays transient chlorosis in tip leaves,
then bright chlorosis of mature leaves. (44) Pennisetum typhoides. (45) Zea
mays. (46) Zea mays (W). (47) Zea mays. (48) Pennisetum typhoides. (50)
Gramineae <1/2>. (51) Gramineae <1/2>. (52) Pennisetum typhoides (millet) is
insusceptible and is thus a useful host for rearing non-viruliferous colonies
of the virus vectors. (53) Storey (1937); Rossel and Thottappilly (1985). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 40 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (179) (Ungrouped). (186) The Nigerian virus
may be close to that called maize mottle virus in Tanzania by Storey (1937).
However only modern varieties are available and so this cannot be proven.
Therefore, despite historical precedence, the name maize mottle/chlorotic
stunt virus should be used and "maize mottle virus" recognised as a synonym
(Rossel and Thottappilly, 1985). (187) Rossel, H.W. (1984). Maize Virus
Disease Newsl.. Rossel, H.W. and Thottappilly, G. (1983). In: Proc. Int. Maize
Virus Dis. Coll. and Wksh., pp. 158-160. Wooster, Ohio Agric. Res. and Dev.
Center. Rossel, H.W. and Thottappilly, G. (1985). Virus Diseases of Important
Food Crops in Tropical Africa, pp. 4951. I.I.T.A., Ibadan. Rossel, H.W.,
Buddenhagen, I.W. and Thottappilly, G. (1980). I.I.T.A. Res. Briefs 1: 2.
Storey, H.H. (1937). Ann. appl. Biol. 24: 87.


Maize rayado fino marafivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and R. Gamez, 1988. (3) Standard acronym: MRFV. (4)
Strains: Maize rayado Colombian strain (Martinez-Lopez, 1977), Brazilian corn
streak strain (Gámez, 1980). (5) ICTV decimal code 41.0.1.0.003. (8) First
reported in Zea mays. (9) From El Salvador. (10) By Ancalmo and Davies (1961);
but initially described as a strain of corn stunt, until studied fully by
Gamez (1969). (13) Zea mays ssp. mays (maize), Zea mays ssp. mexicana
(teosinte) chlorotic vein stippling and striping especially in new cultivars.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Dalbulus maidis. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus
multiplies in the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Gamez (1973, 1983); Gamez and Leon (1985, 1988);
Gamez and Saavedra (1986). (39) Spreads in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Costa
Rica, Mexico, Peru, Venezuela, and the USA <in the south>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Zea mays chlorotic spotting of base and veins of
young leaves, then chlorotic striping. Root development poor, yield decreased.
(45) Zea mays (Tico H1 and Tico H4). (46) Zea mays (W). For insect
transmission studies. (47) Zea mays, or Zea mays ssp. mays, or Zea mays ssp.
mexicana. (50) Gramineae <3/3>. (54) TIP: <, determined by feeding vectors in
sap through membranes,> 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days <at 20°C; 4 to 5 days at
3°C>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Gamez et al. (1977);
Leon and Gamez (1981). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 30-33 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67)
Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 120 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 54 S <T>. (79) Density 1.28 g cm3 in
CsCl <T>, or 1.46 g cm3 in CsCl <B>. (81) Density 1.24 (T), 1.37 (B) in Cs2
SO4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 0.87 <T>, or 1.58 <B>. (84) Virions contain 33 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 67 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 6.7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 6.7 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
22000. (134) Coat protein; in virions of some isolates there is a small amount
of a 28kDa protein. (145) Method of preparation: Gamez and Leon (1988). (171)
Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma and phloem.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles <in loose aggregates>.
(173) Virions found in occasionally in sieve tubes in loose aggregates or
large crystalline arrays within the membrane bound vesicles. (179) Marafivirus
<the type species>. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
Bermuda grass etched line and oat blue dwarf viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: This virus is frequently in mixed infections with MLOs and
spiroplasms; these infections induce the corn stunt disease. (187) Ancalmo, O.
and Davies, W.C. (1961). Pl. Dis. Reptr 45: 281. Espinoza, A.M. and Gamez, R.
(1980). Turrialba 30: 413. Falk, B.W. and Tsai, J.H. (1986). Intervirology 25:
111. Gamez, R. (1969). Pl. Dis. Reptr 53: 929. Gamez, R. (1973). Ann. appl.
Biol. 73: 285. Gamez, R. (1980). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 220, 4 pp.
Gamez, R. (1983). In: Plant Virus Epidemiology, p. 267; eds R.T. Plumb and
J.M. Thresh. Blackwell Scientific, Oxford, England. Gamez, R. and Leon, P.
(1985). In: Leafhoppers and Planthoppers, p. 331; eds L.R. Nault and
Rodriguez. J. Wiley and Sons Inc., New York,. Gamez, R. and Saavedra, R.
(1986). In: Plant Virus Epidemics, p. 315; eds G. Maclean, R. Garrett and W.
Ruesnik. Academic Press, Melbourne. Gamez, R., Kosuka, Y. and Fukuoka, T.
(1977). Rev. Biol. Trop. 25: 151. Gamez, R., Kitajima, E.W. and Lin, M.T.
(1979). Pl. Dis. Reptr 63: 830. Gamez, R. and Leon, P. (1986). In: The Plant
Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions with Monopartite RNA Genomes, p. 213; ed.
R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York. Gingery, R.E., Gordon, D.T. and Nault, L.R.
(1982). Phytopathology 72: 1313. Kitajima, E.W. and Gamez, R. (1977).
Turrialba 27: 71. Kitajima, E.W., Yano, T. and Costa, A.S. (1976). Cienc.
Cult., S. Paulo 28: 427. Lastra, R. and de Uscategui, R.C. (1980). Turrialba
30: 405. Leon, P. and Gamez, R. (1986). Rev. Biol. Trop. 34: 111.
Martinez-Lopez, G. (1977). Proc. int. Maize Viruses Diseases Coloq. Wksh., p.
20. Ohio Agric. Res. Dev. Center. Ramirez, P. and Leon, P. (1988). J. gen.
Virol. 69: 757. Rivera, C. and Gamez, R. (1986). Intervirology 25: 76. Tsai,
J.H. (1986). Intervirology 25: 111.


Maize rough dwarf fijivirus

      (1) R.G. Milne, 1984. (2) Synonyms: virus del nanismo ruvido del mais.
(3) Standard acronym: MRDV. (4) Strains: type strain (TS), cereal tillering
disease strain (CTD) (Boccardo and Milne, 1984; Lindsten and Gerhardson,
1971), mal de Rio Cuarto (MR4) (Boccardo and Milne, 1984; Nome et al., 1981).
(5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.7.2.001. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From
Israel. (10) By Harpaz (1959). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena sativa (CTD
strain), Cynodon dactylon, Digitaria sanguinalis, Echinochloa crus-galli,
Hordeum vulgare (CTD strain), Lolium perenne, Setaria verticillata, Triticum
aestivum (CTD strain), Zea mays (dent, not flint cultivars) stunting, dark
green colour, enations on veins of leaves and sheaths, longitudinal splitting
of roots, flowers suppressed. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Delphacodes propinqua, Dicranotropis hamata,
Laodelphax striatellus, Javasella pellucida, Sogatella vibix. (18) Transmitted
by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector <one unconfirmed
report>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <injection; but very
inefficient>. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Argentina, the former
Czechoslovakia, France, Israel, Italy, Norway, Spain, Sweden, and the former
Yugoslavia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Hordeum vulgare cv.
Delesa stunting. Zea mays American yellow dent hybrids; Wisconsin 641 AA
stunting, dark green colour, pale yellow enations on abaxial surface of leaves
and leaf sheaths. (44) Saccharum spp., Sorghum halepense (susceptible to the
Chinese virus), Stipa bromoides, probably all non-Gramineae. (45) Hordeum
vulgare, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays. (46) Hordeum vulgare (W), Triticum
aestivum (W), Zea mays (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Cynodon dactylon, or
Digitaria sanguinalis, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Lolium perenne, or Oryza sativa, or Secale cereale, or Setaria italica, or
Setaria verticillata, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Chloris gayana,
or Saccharum officinarum, or Sorghum halepense, or Stipa bromoides. (50)
Gramineae <12/16>. (51) Gramineae <4/16>. (53) Milne and Lovisolo (1977). (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions, or contains many virions <few virions in whole
leaf sap, many in sap from enations>. (59) Electron microscopy: for whole
virions avoid neutral PTA, use 2% aqueous UA. No special treatment for
subvirions. (60) Method: Milne et al. (1973); Boccardo and Milne (1981). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 70 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile, or angular in profile. (67) Virions with a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations <whole and subvirions>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 400 S <for
subviral non-infectious virions>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 26.169 kb.
(92) Genome of 10 parts <named S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
largest> 3.9 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.2 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd
largest 3.15 kb <pairs>. (96) The 4th largest 3.15 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th
largest 3.1 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 2.293 kb <pairs;
also 2.198, 1.735, 1.728 and 1.715 kb pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Boccardo and Milne (1975). (112) Additional factor required for
infectivity. (113) Additional factor proteins from the virions; isolated
nucleic acid is not infectious. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10989. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X55701 Em(40)_un:MRDVS6 Gb(84)_un:MRDVS6 Maize
rough dwarf virus (MRDV) mRNA for genomic segment S6. 3/91 2,193bp. 1
sequence. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion
protein(s) six. (133) Mr <of the largest> 139000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
125000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 123000. (139) Mr of 4th largest 111000. (141)
Mr of 5th largest 97000. (143) Mr of 6th largest and smaller, 64000. (145)
Method of preparation: Boccardo and Milne (1975). (164) Genome replicates in
cytoplasmic viroplasms. (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
phloem enations. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, or viroplasms
<containing immature virions>, or unusual in shape. (176) Tubular structures
some 100 nm diameter. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: cell wall proliferation and cell enlargement. (179) Fijivirus:
Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: The virus is so closely related to rice black streaked dwarf virus,
that it may be the same species, it is more distantly related to pangola stunt
virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: oat sterile
dwarf, rice ragged stunt and sugarcane Fiji disease viruses. (186) The virus
has been reported from China, but it may be that the virus was incorrectly
identified, and was rice black-streaked dwarf virus, which is common in the
region. (187) Boccardo, G. and Milne, R.G. (1975). Virology 68: 79. Boccardo,
G. and Milne, R.G. (1981). J. virol. Meth. 3: 109. Boccardo, G. and Milne,
R.G. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 294, 7 pp. Conti, M. (1984). In:
Current Topics in Vector Research; ed. K.F. Harris. Praeger Scientific, New
York. Francki, R.I.B. and Boccardo, G. (1983). In: The Reoviridae. p. 155; ed.
K.W. Joklik. Plenum Press, New York. Francki, R.I.B., Milne, R.G. and Hatta,
T. (1984). In: An Atlas of Plant Viruses. Vol. 1. CRC Press, Boca Raton,
