Maize streak dwarf (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.T.D.09. (8) First
reported in Zea mays. (9) From China. (10) By Peng et al. (1979). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Zea mays chlorotic streaking of leaf, husk and sheath.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Laodelphax striatellus (both adults and nymphs). (18) Transmitted by
Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (39) Spreads in China <Gansu Province>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Zea mays chlorotic streaking of leaves and sheaths.
(45) Zea mays. (46) Zea mays (W). (47) Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63)
Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
150-220 nm <and 200-250 nm>. (71) Virions 43-64 nm wide <and 70-80 nm>. (171)
Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear space
<attached to the inner nuclear membrane>. (173) Virions found in the
endoplasmic reticulum. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae.
(180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Peng, C.M., Chen, T.Y., Shen, C.Y., Zhu, F.C. and
Chin, M.C. (1979). Acta Biochim. Biophys. Sin. 11: 187. Tsai, J.H., Zhu, F.C.
and Zhu, X.S. (1984). Maize Virus Dis. Newsl. 1: 21.


Maize streak monogeminivirus

      (1) M.B. von Wechmar, 1985. Revised by P.G. Markham and M.I. Boulton,
1989. (2) Synonyms: bajra streak virus (Seth et al., 1972a & 1972b), cereal
African streak virus, maize streak A virus. (3) Standard acronym: MSV. (4)
Strains: maize strain, Panicum maximum strain, sugarcane strain, Digitaria
setigera strain. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Zea
mays. (9) From South Africa. (10) By Fuller (1901); Bock et al. (1974); Storey
(1925); Rose (1978); Gorter (1953). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena sativa,
Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale, Sorghum bicolor, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays,
Saccharum spp., Panicum maximum, Setaria verticillata, Digitaria abyssinica,
Digitaria velutina, Cenchrus echinatus, Brachiaria reptens, Coix lacryma-jobi,
Chloris gayana, Pennisetum purpureum, Sorghum sudanense, Eleusine africana,
Eleusine indica, Rottboellia exaltata, Setaria homonyma, Setaria pallidifusca,
Urochloa panicoides, Urochloa trichopus chlorotic or white streaking or
lesions. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Cicadulina mbila, C. arachidis, C. bipunctella, C. triangula,
C. bimaculata, C. similis, C. latens, C. ghaurii, C. parazeae. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Rose (1973a; b;
1974; 1978). (38) Spreads in the African region. (39) Spreads in India,
Madagascar, Reunion, and Yemen. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show streaks and spots. (43) Zea mays
systemic chlorotic streaking. (44) Zea perennis, Zea diploperennis, Pennisetum
americanum. (45) Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays. (46) Hordeum
vulgare (W), Triticum aestivum (W), Zea mays cv. Golden Cross Bantam (W). (47)

Maize stripe tenuivirus

      (1) R.E. Gingery, 1984. (2) Synonyms: maize chlorotic stripe virus
(Autrey, 1983; Gingery and Autrey, 1984), maize hoja blanca virus (Gingery et
al., 1979; Trujillo et al., 1974; Lastra and Carballo, 1985), sorghum
chlorosis virus (Mendoza Robles, 1986; Peterschmitt et al., 1991). (3)
Standard acronym: MSpV. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported
in Zea mays. (9) From Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Gingery et al. (1981). (11)
Symptoms persist <chlorosis becomes progressively more severe>. (13)
Rottboellia exaltata, Zea mays stunting, chlorotic leaf striping and apical
bending. Sorghum bicolor chlorotic stripes and bands in leaves, little or no
panicle forms, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Peregrinus maidis. (18) Transmitted by
Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector <via eggs>. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, Botswana, Guadeloupe, India, Kenya,
Mauritius, Nigeria, Peru, the Philippines, Reunion, Sao Tome and Principe, the
USA, and Venezuela. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Rottboellia
exaltata, Zea mays systemic chlorotic striping, apical bending. Sorghum
bicolor variable. (44) Avena sativa, Oryza sativa, Triticum aestivum. (45) Zea
mays. (46) Zea mays (W). (47) Hordeum vulgare, or Rottboellia exaltata, or
Secale cereale, or Sorghum bicolor, or Zea mays. (48) Avena sativa, or Chloris
gayana, or Eleusine coracana, or Oryza sativa, or Saccharum officinarum, or
Triticum aestivum. (50) Gramineae <5/11>. (51) Gramineae <6/11>. (53) Gingery
et al. (1981); Greber (1981). (60) Method: Gingery et al. (1981). (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (62) Virions Virions are flexuous filaments 3-4 nm
wide, or spiral-shaped filaments formed from coils of the 3 nm filaments. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (76) <Usually> four sedimenting components in purified
preparations <sometimes more>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 187 S. (79)
Density 1.28 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5.2 % nucleic acid <±0.3>.
(85) Virions 94.8 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 18.6 kb. (92)
Genome of five parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 9.12
kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.58 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.38 kb. (96) The 4th
largest 2.23 kb. (97) The 5th largest 1.32 kb. (100) Base composition 18.1 %
G. (101) Base composition 26.3 % A. (102) Base composition 17.8 % C. (103)
Base composition 37.8 % U. (112) Additional factor not required for
infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12330. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): L13438 Em(40)_vi:MZSNCPNS4 Gb(84)_vi:MZSNCPNS4P Maize stripe virus
noncapsid protein (NCP); nonstructural protein (NS4) genes. 5/93 2,227bp.
L13446 Em(40)_vi:MZSNSRNA5 Gb(84)_vi:MZSNSRNA5P Maize stripe virus
nonstructural protein RNA5, complete cds. 5/93 1,317bp. M57426
Em(40)_vi:MZSRNA3 Gb(84)_vi:MZSRNA3 Maize stripe virus RNA 3 nonstructural
protein (NS-3) and nucleocapsid protein (N) genes, com M60181
Em(40)_vi:MZSMNCP Gb(84)_vi:MZSMNCP Maize stripe virus major noncapsid protein
mRNA, complete cds. 2/91 720bp. S40180 Em(40)_un:S40180 Gb(84)_vi:S40180 RNA4:
NCP=non-capsid protein, NS4=non-structural protein NS4 maize stripe virus
MStV, Genomi S58504 Em(40)_vi:S58504 Gb(84)_vi:S58504 NS5=44.2 kda protein
(RNA5) maize stripe virus MStV, Genomic RNA, 1317 nt. 1/94 1,317bp. 6
sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32700 <±500>. (152)
Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated. (153) One protein found. (154) Mr
16500 <±300>. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and phloem. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (176) Amorphous, semi-opaque, and filamentous electron dense
laminated aggregates. (177) They do not contain virions <apparently the
filamentous electron dense inclusions contain non-capsid protein. No
nucleoprotein has been shown in either type of inclusion>. (178) Other
cellular changes: induction of smaller vacuoles and increasing amounts of
electron dense cytoplasm after 4-5 weeks apparently due to the large volume of
amorphous semi-opaque inclusions. (179) Tenuivirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: rice stripe virus is closely related; rice
grassy stunt virus is distantly related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: rice hoja blanca and European wheat striate mosaic viruses.
(184) The maize stripe virus reported from India (Raychaudhuri et al., 1977)
is maize mosaic rhabdovirus (Sharma and Payak, 1983). (187) Ammar, E.D.,
Gingery, R.E. and Nault, L.R. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 84. Autrey, L.J.C.
(1983). Proc. Maize Virus Dis. Coll. and Wksh. 1982, p. 167. Capoor, S.P.,
Rao, D.G. and Varma, P.M. (1967). Ind. J. Agric. Sci. 38: 198. Falk, B.W. and
Tsai, J.H. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 909. Gingery, R.E. (1985). CMI/AAB

Maize white line mosaic satellivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 64.0.4.2.001. (8) First
reported in Zea mays. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Gingery and Louie (1984).
(13) Zea mays unknown (found only in complex with maize white line mosaic
virus). (15) Probably in soil. (39) Spreads in France and the USA <Ohio>. (47)
Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (60) Method: Gingery and Louie (1984). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 17 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 47 S. (79) Density 1.355 g cm3 in
CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size
1.168 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 1.168 kb.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31503. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M55012
Em(40)_vi:SVMSECG Gb(84)_vi:SVMSECG Satellite virus of maize white line mosaic
virus ORF, complete cds. 2/91 1,168bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 24700. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and
roots. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected

Maize white line mosaic virus

      (1) R.E. Gingery and R. Louie, 1985. Revised 1989 by R.E. Gingery. (2)
Synonyms: maize dwarf ringspot virus, possibly maize white line virus. (3)
Standard acronym: MWLMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.4.006. (8) First
reported in Zea mays. (9) From Vermont, U.S.A. (10) By Gotlieb and Liese
(1980). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Digitaria sanguinalis, Panicum
dichotomiflorum, Setaria faberi, S. viridis dark green mottle. Zea mays
mottle, mosaic and characteristic chlorotic white lines, small ears with few
or no kernels. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in France, Italy, and
the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Zea mays mottle,
mosaic, discrete chlorotic white lines, stunting. (45) Zea mays. (46) Zea mays
(W). (47) Digitaria sanguinalis, or Panicum dichotomiflorum, or Setaria
faberi, or Setaria viridis, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <5/5>. (53) Louie et
al. (1982). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: de Zoeten et al.
(1980); Louie et al. (1982). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30-35 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile,
or angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 117 S. (79) Density 1.333 g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>, or 1.353 g cm3
in CsCl <when fixed in glutaraldehyde>. (84) Virions contain 20.9 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 79.1 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) <Probably linear>. (91) Total genome size 1.3-1.6 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 1.3-1.6 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by de Zoeten et al. (1980). (100) Base
composition 30 % G. (101) Base composition 19.7 % A. (102) Base composition 26
% C. (103) Base composition 24.3 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
32000-35000. (145) Method of preparation: de Zoeten et al. (1980). (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) (Ungrouped).
(186) Satellite-like virions are associated with this virus. (187) Boothroyd,
C.W. and Israel, H.W. (1980). Plant Dis. 64: 218. de Zoeten, G.A., Arny, D.C.,
Grau, C.R., Saad, S.M. and Gaard, G. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 1019. Gingery,
R.E. and Louie, R. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 808. Gotlieb, A.R. and Liese,
A.L. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 462. Lapierre, H., Moreau, J.C. and Molin, G.
(1976). Poljopr. Znan. Smotra. Agric. Conspect. Sci. 39: 187. Louie, R.,
Gordon, D.T., Knoke, J.K., Gingery, R.E., Bradfute, O.E. and Lipps, P.E.
(1982). Plant Dis. 66: 167. Louie, R., Gordon, D.T., Madden, L.V. and Knoke,
J.K. (1983). Plant Dis. 67: 371.


Maize yellow stripe (?) tenuivirus

      (1) E.D. Ammar, 1989. (2) Synonyms: maize yellow stripe virus, maize
fine stripe virus, maize chlorotic stunt virus. (5) ICTV decimal code
69.0.1.T.DE.2. (8) First reported in Zea mays. (9) From Giza, Egypt. (10) By
Ammar et al. (1984). (11) Symptoms persist, or vary cyclically over a few
weeks. (13) Zea mays, Sorghum vulgare, S. bicolor, Triticum aestivum, Hordeum
vulgare yellow striping or chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Cicadulina chinai. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(36) Studies reported by Ammar et al. (1987); Ammar et al. (1989). (39)
Spreads in Egypt. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics. (43) Zea mays, Sorghum vulgare,
S. bicolor, Triticum aestivum, Hordeum vulgare yellow leaf striping. (45) Zea
mays, Sorghum vulgare, S. bicolor, Triticum aestivum, Hordeum vulgare. (46)
Zea mays (W). (47) Hordeum vulgare, or Sorghum bicolor, or Sorghum vulgare, or
Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <5/5>. (53) Aboul-Ata and Ammar
(1985); Ammar et al. (1987, 1989). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: UA or PTA may be used without fixation. (60) Method:
Ammar et al. (1990). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous.
(71) Virions 5-7 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 87 S. (152)
Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Ammar et al. (1990)>. (153) One
protein found. (154) Mr 13800. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll,
vascular parenchyma, phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
amorphous Xbodies. (177) They contain virions <helical filaments are found>.
(178) Other cellular changes: tubular helical structures which are found
abundantly in cytoplasmic inclusions, sometimes associated with mitochondria.
(179) <Possible> Tenuivirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: maize mottle chlorotic stunt. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: maize stripe, maize chlorotic dwarf, maize chlorotic
mottle, maize dwarf mosaic (A, B or D), maize streak and maize mosaic viruses
(Ammar et al., 1990). (184) Like tenuiviruses it has thin filamentous virions
and similar non-virion proteins, but differs in cytopathology and in being
transmitted by a leafhopper and not a planthopper. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: transmission with Cicadulina chinai (leafhoppers). (187) Aboul-Ata,
A.E. and Ammar, E.D. (1985). Abstr. 4th Int. Conf. Impact of Viral Dis. on the
Devel. of African and Middle East Countries 1419 April 1985, Rabat, Morocco.
Ammar, E.D., Elnager, S., Tolba, A.E. and Aboul-Ata, A.E. (1984). Abstr. 6th
Cong. Medit. Phytopath. Union 16 Oct., 1984, Cairo, Egypt. Ammar, E.D.,
Aboul-Ata, A.E., El-Sheikh, M.A. and Sewify, G.H. (1987). J. Phytopath. 19:
97. Ammar, E.D., Elnager, S., Aboul-Ata, A.E. and Sewify, G.H. (1989). J.
Phytopath. 126: 246. Ammar, E.D., Gingery, R.E., Gordon, D.T. and Aboul-Ata,
A.E. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 303.


Malva vein clearing potyvirus

      (1) G.R. Johnstone, 1987. (2) Synonyms: malva green mosaic virus, malva
yellow vein mosaic virus, malva mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: MVCV. (4)
Strains: Hein (1957) distinguishes two strains, that are the yellow vein
mosaic and green mosaic strains of Costa and Duffus (1957). (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.049. (8) First reported in Malva sylvestris. (9) From Germany.
(10) By Hein (1957). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Malva neglecta, M. nicaensis,
M. parviflora, M. rotundifolia, M. sylvestris, Lavatera assurgentiflora, L.
cretica, L. trimestris vein clearing and yellow mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis umbrella
(syn. Aphis malvae Koch) and Myzus persicae are vectors, whereas Acyrthosiphon
solani, Coloradoa rufomaculata, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus ornatus, M.
ascalonicus and Aulocorthum circumflexum are non-vectors. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia <Tasmania>, or Brazil, or
the former Czechoslovakia, or Germany, or Israel, or Italy, or Portugal, or
the USA <California>, or the former USSR, or the former Yugoslavia. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible <and only some genera of the Malvaceae are
infected>. (43) Malva parviflora, M. neglecta, M. sylvestris, M. rotundifolia,
Lavatera assurgentiflora. (44) Abelmoschus esculentus, Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Gossypium hirsutum. (46)
Malva parviflora (W); M. neglecta (W); M. sylvestris (W); M. rotundifolia (W);
Lavatera assurgentiflora (W). (47) Abutilon indicum, or Abutilon theophrasti,
or Althaea officinalis, or Althaea sinensis, or Anoda cristata, or Anoda
dillerriana, or Anoda lavateroides, or Gossypium barbadense, or Hibiscus
cannabinus, or Hibiscus sabdariffa, or Hibiscus trionum, or Kitaibelia
vitifolia, or Lavatera ambigua, or Lavatera arborea, or Lavatera
assurgentiflora, or Lavatera cretica, or Lavatera trimestris, or Malva alcea,
or Malva crispa, or Malva meluca, or Malva moschata, or Malva neglecta, or
Malva nicaensis, or Malva parviflora, or Malva rotundifolia, or Malva
sylvestris, or Malva verticillata, or Malvastrum capense, or Napaea dioica, or
Sida napaeae, or Sida rhombifolia, or Sidalcea malvaefolia, or Urocarpidium
peruvianum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Althaea rosea, or Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Armeria vulgaris, or Astrocarpa sesmoides, or Beta maritima,
or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Consolida ajacis, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Gossypium hirsutum, or Lamium purpureum, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Melandrium nodiflorum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Salsola kali, or Scabiosa
columbaria, or Schizanthus pinnatus, or Stellaria media. (50) Malvaceae
<33/36>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae
<5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Dipsacaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <3/36>, or Plumbaginaceae <1
/1>, or Ranunculaceae <1/1>, or Resedaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/7>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Hein (1957); Horváth et al. (1979). (54) TIP: 60-65
°C. (55) LIV: 1-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
850-860 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (76) <Presumably> one sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (84) Virions contain <c.> 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions <c.> 95
% protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92)
Genome unipartite <presumably>. (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated.
(153) <Probably> three proteins found. (154) Mr <coding for inclusion protein
and helper component>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, pinwheels, and unusual in
shape. (176) And scrolls. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Costa, A.S. and Duffus, J.E. (1957).
Pl. Dis. Reptr 41: 1006 Hein, A. (1957). Phytopath. Z. 28: 205. Horváth, J.,
Mamula, D., Besada, W.H. and JureticH, N. (1979). Phytopath. Z. 95: 51.


Malva veinal necrosis (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990 and E.W. Kitajima, 1991. (2) Synonyms: malva veinal

Malva spp. veinal necrosis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(39) Spreads in Brazil. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles,

floridana, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae

Malvaceae <2/4>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (54) TIP: 70-75 °C. (56) DEP: log10
minus 6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (68)

Potexvirus. (187) Costa, A.S. and Kitajima, E.W. (1970). Bragantia 29: 51.

      (1) J.L. Dale, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.26. (8) First

Symptoms persist. (13) Malvastrum coromandelianum and Euphorbia peplus leaf

Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor necrotic local lesions, then systemic chlorotic spotting and
malformation. C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions; then systemic chlorosis and
malformation. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic chlorosis. Gomphrena globosa
faint necrotic local lesions; systemic mottling. (45) Chenopodium
amaranticolor. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Gomphrena globosa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Euphorbia peplus, or

<2/3>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a

(179) (Ungrouped).


Maracuja mosaic (?) tobamovirus

      (1) D.-E. Lesemann, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: MarMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 71.0.1T.016. (8) First reported in Passiflora edulis. (9) From Peru. (10)
By Fribourg et al. (1987). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Passiflora edulis
mosaic and leaf crinkling. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by
contact between plants. (36) Studies reported by Fribourg et al. (1987). (39)
Spreads in Peru. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Passiflora edulis
systemic leaf mosaic, crinkle. Nicotiana benthamiana necrotic local lesions;
then systemic line patterns, mosaic. Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor,
Luffa acutangula necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana tabacum
necrotic local lesions, necrotic rings and lines; not systemic. Cucumis
sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Antirrhinum
majus symptomless local infection; not systemic. Datura stramonium chlorotic
local lesions; not systemic. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
Capsicum annuum, Citrullus vulgaris, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Monroe, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Antirrhinum majus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita
moschata, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or
Luffa acutangula, or Lycopersicon chilense, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Passiflora edulis, or Physalis floridana, or Salvia
splendens, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Citrullus
vulgaris, or Clitoria ternatea, or Datura metel, or Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Matthiola incana, or Montia perfoliata, or Phaseolus
acutifolius, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Solanum tuberosum,
or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/5>,
or Labiatae <1/1>, or Passifloraceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <8/13>. (51) Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <5/13>. (53) Fribourg et al. (1987). (54) TIP: 90 °C.
(55) LIV: 90 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 10 <in Chenopodium quinoa sap>. (58)
Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Fribourg et al. (1987); Fribourg
and Nakashima (1984). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 304 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (132) Virion protein(s) two.
(133) Mr <of the larger> 17400. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 15900. (145) Method of
preparation: Fribourg et al. (1987). (171) Virions found in mesophyll,
epidermis, vascular parenchyma and xylem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in
the cytoplasm, amorphous Xbodies, and unusual in shape. (176)
Tonoplast-associated small vesicles. (177) They contain virions <in the
crystals>, or they do not contain virions <in the others>. (179) <Possible>
Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cucumber
green mottle mosaic, frangipani mosaic, odontoglossum ringspot, tobacco mosaic
and ullucus tobamoviruses, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: ribgrass mosaic and Sammons' opuntia tobamoviruses. (187)
Fribourg, C.E., Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 486.
Fribourg, C.E. and Nakashima, J. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1363.


Marigold mottle potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: MaMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.050. (8) First reported in Tagetes erecta. (9) From India. (10) By
Naqvi et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Tagetes erecta severe leaf
mottling, small malformed flowers, stunting and death. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis gossypii,
Brevicoryne brassicae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in India. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (43) Amaranthus caudatus, Calendula officinalis,
Antirrhinum majus, Capsicum annuum, Datura metel, Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
tabacum, Petunia × hybrida chlorosis of systemically infected leaves.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions;
no systemic infection. (44) Chenopodium album, C. murale, Cucumis sativus,
Cucurbita pepo, Physalis peruviana. (45) Datura metel, Nicotiana glutinosa.
(46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Datura metel (W), Nicotiana glutinosa (W),
Tetragonia tetragonioides (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus,
or Beta vulgaris, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia
tora, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Datura

tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum nigrum, or Stellaria media, or

Amaranthus caudatus, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Cajanus cajan, or

murale, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or

barbatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis peruviana, or

oleraceus, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or

or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or

/9>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV:
6 days <at 2025°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)

152 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.28. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: datura mosaic and tobacco etch viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: brinjal mild mosaic and
melilotus mosaic viruses. (187) Naqvi, Q.A., Hadi, S. and Mahmood, K. (1981).
Plant Dis. 65: 271.


Melandrium yellow fleck bromovirus

      (1) J. Horváth, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: MYFV. (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.3.0.006. (8) First reported in Melandrium album. (9) From Hungary. (10)
By Hollings and Stone (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Melandrium album
systemic vein clearing and yellow flecks. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Hungary. (41)
Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Phaseolus vulgaris
necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic/necrotic local
lesions, then systemic mottle. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions, then

Melilotus mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: MeMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.051. (8) First reported in Melilotus indicus. (9) From India
(Aligarh). (10) By Naqvi and Mahmood (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Melilotus indicus leaf mosaic, mottling and stunting. (24) Not transmitted by
Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in India. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Verbena hybrida local lesions. Cajanus cajan, Crotalaria
medicaginea, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petunia ×
hybrida systemic leaf chlorosis, necrosis and distortion. (45) Nicotiana
glutinosa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Cajanus cajan, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Crotalaria medicaginea, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus indicus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Verbena hybrida. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae
<7/7>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Verbenaceae <1/1>. (53) Naqvi and Mahmood
(1978). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days <at 25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4.
(60) Method: Naqvi and Mahmood (1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 600-620 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 118 S. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tobacco etch
virus. (186) Although reported to be serologically related to tobacco etch
virus, the virus has unusually short virions for a potyvirus. (187) Naqvi,
Q.A. and Mahmood, K. (1978). Phytopath. Z. 93: 249.


Melon leaf curl bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux and J.E. Duffus, 1986. (3) Standard acronym:
MLCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.024. (8) First reported in Cucumis melo.
(9) From Imperial Valley, California. (10) By Duffus et al. (1985). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis melo leaf curling and chlorosis. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36)
Studies reported by Duffus et al. (1985). (39) Spreads in the USA
<California>. (43) Cucumis melo, Citrullus lanatus, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita
maxima, Cucurbita moschata, Phaseolus vulgaris chlorosis and leaf
malformation. (45) Cucumis melo, Citrullus lanatus, Cucumis sativus (non hosts
of similar squash leaf curl virus). (46) Cucumis melo (W), Citrullus lanatus
(W), Cucumis sativus (W). (47) Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata, or Phaseolus vulgaris.
(50) Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (61) Virions
geminate. (65) Virions 22 nm in length. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae.
(180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
squash leaf curl virus (by ELISA but not agar gel diffusion tests). (187)
Duffus, J.E., Liu, H.Y. and Johns, M.R. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 1312.


Melon necrotic spot carmovirus

      (1) T. Hibi, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: MNSV. (4) Strains: Japanese
isolate, Californian isolate, European isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.009. (8) First reported in Cucumis melo. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Kishi (1966). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis melo necrotic spotting.
Cucumis sativus chlorotic spotting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Olpidium radicale. (21)
Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <10-40% in melon>. (39) Spreads in Japan, the Netherlands, the UK, and
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis melo necrotic local
lesions then, occasionally, systemic necrosis. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local
lesions then, occasionally, systemic chlorosis or spotting. Citrullus lanatus
local lesions, not systemic. Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis necrotic
spots; not systemic. Cucurbita moschata, Lagenaria siceraria local lesions;
not systemic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
glutinosa. (45) Cucumis melo. (46) Cucumis melo (L) and (W) Cucumis sativus
(L). (47) Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
moschata, or Lagenaria siceraria, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Allium cepa, or Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris,
or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba. (50)
Cucurbitaceae <5/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>. (51) Alliaceae
<1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <1/1>,
or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<5/7>, or Solanaceae <2/2>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Hibi and Furuki
(1985); Furuki (1981). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 9-32 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Hibi and Furuki
(1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 134 S. (79) Density 1.33-1.34 g
cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>. (84) Virions contain 17.8 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions
82.2 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 4.266 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 4.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hibi et al.
(1980). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 11987. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
D00562 Em(40)_vi:MNSCP Gb(84)_vi:MNSCP Melon necrotic spot virus coat protein
gene, complete cds. 3/92 1,173bp. D12536 Em(40)_vi:MNSCG1 Gb(84)_vi:D12536

complete genome. 10/92 4,266bp. D29662 Em(43)_vi:Mnscp1 Gb(89)_vi:Mnscp1 Melon
necrotic spot virus (strain NH) gene for coat protein. 4/95 1,173bp. D29663
Em(43)_vi:Mnscp2 Gb(89)_vi:Mnscp2 Melon necrotic spot virus (strain S) gene
for coat protein. 4/95 1,173bp. (133) Mr 46000. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Bos et al. (1984). (164) Genome replicates in
cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, stems, petioles, fruits and seeds. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: cucumber necrosis, wild cucumber mosaic,
carnation mottle, tobacco necrosis, turnip yellow mosaic, carnation ringspot,
cucumber mosaic, pelargonium leaf curl, squash mosaic, cucumber soil-borne,
cucumber leaf spot and tomato bushy stunt viruses. (187) Bos, L., van Dorst,
H.J.M., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1984). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 90: 55. Furuki,
I. (1981). Tech. Bull. Shizuoka Agric. Exp. Stn 14: 94. Hibi, T., Furuki, I.,
Honda, Y., Saito, Y. and Komuro, Y. (1980). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 46:
419. Hibi, T. and Furuki, I. (1985). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 302, 4 pp.
Kishi, K. (1966). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 32: 138. Riviere, C.J. and
Rochon, D.M. (1990). J. gen. Virol.69: 395. Tomlinson, J.A. and Thomas, B.J.
(1986). Ann. appl. Biol. 108: 71.


Melon Ourmia ourmiavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (2) Synonyms: Ourmia melon virus. (3) Standard
acronym: OuMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.4.008. (8) First reported in
Cucumis melo. (9) From Ourmia, northern Iran. (10) By Lisa et al. (1988). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Cucumis melo chlorotic spots and irregular ringspots,
puckering. (39) Spreads in Iran. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles,
ringspots or necrosis. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Gomphrena globosa necrotic
local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii, N. benthamiana, N. megalosiphon
chlorotic local lesions; systemic necrotic mosaic. Petunia × hybrida,
Callistephus chinensis, Cucumis sativus, Cucumis melo severe systemic
chlorosis. (44) Brassica oleracea, Pisum sativum, Solanum tuberosum, Trifolium

hybrida. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Apium

Cruciferae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Solanaceae <1/10>.
(53) Lisa et al. (1988). (54) TIP: 70-80 °C. (55) LIV: 35 days <more than at

viral genus containing this and the similar, but serologically unrelated,

mottle, dulcamara mottle, Scrophularia mottle and Andean potato latent
viruses, but distantly. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: mechanical inoculation
to watermelon, sweetmelon and squash. (187) Jones, P. (1981). Ann. Rep.
Rothamsted Exp. Stn. Jones, P., Ba Angood S. and Carpenter J.M. (1986). Ann.
appl. Biol. 108: 303.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: MVV. (5) ICTV decimal code

100.


Melothria mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.08. (8) First
reported in Melothria liukiuensis. (9) From Okinawa Prefecture, Japan. (10) By
Yonaha et al. (1993). (13) Melothria liukiuensis faint leaf mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (23) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads
in Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Melothria liukiuensis
systemic leaf mottling. Cucurbita pepo, Nicotiana benthamiana local chlorotic
spotting, systemic vein-clearing and mottling. Bryonopsis laciniosa, Citrullus
lanatus, Cucumis sativus and Cucurbita maxima local necrotic and local and
systemic chlorotic spotting. Sesamum indicum local necrotic spotting, systemic
stem necrosis and wilting. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C. quinoa,
Gomphrena globosa and Spinacia oleracea local necrotic lesions, not systemic.
(44) Datura metel, D. stramonium, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N.
rustica. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L), Nicotiana benthamiana (W). (47) Bryonopsis laciniosa, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,
or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Gomphrena globosa, or Melothria
liukiuensis, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Sesamum indicum, or Spinacia
oleracea. (48) Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <8/8>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <1/6>. (51) Solanaceae <5/6>. (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 8-10 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (60) Method: Yonaha et al. (1993). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 725 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (179) <Possible> unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: papaya ringspot, trichosanthes
mottle, watermelon mosaic-2 and zucchini yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Yonaha,
T., Nagata, M., Kawano, S. and Tamori, M. (1993). Bull. Coll. Agric. Univ.
Ryukus 40: 9-19.

Milk vetch dwarf nanavirus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1981. Revised 1984. (3) Standard acronym: MVDV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 39.0.1.T.007. (8) First reported in Astragalus sinicus. (9) From
Japan. (10) By Ohki (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Astragalus sinicus,
Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba yellow dwarf and
leaf rolling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Acyrthosiphon pisum,
Acyrthosiphon (Aulocorthum) solani. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Spinacia oleracea, Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis leaf
rolling, stunting. Astragalus sinicus, Vicia sativa yellow dwarf. Phaseolus
vulgaris stunting. Pisum sativum, Vicia faba yellow dwarf, leaf roll. Datura
stramonium interveinal yellowing, leaf rolling. Nicotiana rustica leaf
rolling. (45) Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Astragalus sinicus (W), Pisum
sativum (W), Vicia faba (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Astragalus sinicus, or
Cassia tora, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max,
or Lathyrus odoratus, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna
angularis, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis .
(48) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Tetragonia tetragonioides,
or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <17/20>, or Solanaceae <4/6>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/20>, or Solanaceae <2/6>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Inouye et al. (1968). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Ohki et al. (1975). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (171) Virions found
in phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: an
increase of mitochondria. (179) Nanavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: Faba bean necrotic yellows virus, closely (Katul et al.,
1993. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: This virus was
previously considered to be a luteovirus, but is now known to share properties
with subterranean clover stunt and related viruses. Its virions are very
closely serologically related to those of faba bean necrotic yellows virus
(Katul et al., 1993) but, at present, they are listed as separate species,
rather than related strains. (187) Asada, Ohki, S.T., Osaki, T. and Inouye, T.
(1984). Shokubutsu Boeki 38: 184. Katul, L., van Vetten, H.J., Maiss, E.,
Makkouk, K.M., Lesemann, D.-E. and Casper, R. (1993) Ann. appl. Biol. 123:
629. Inouye et al. (1968). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 34: 28. Ohki, S.T.
(1975). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 41: 508.

      (3) Standard acronym: MRLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.T.008. (8)
First reported in Setaria italica. (9) From the Peoples Republic of China.

evidence of spread, in the Peoples Republic of China (Yu et al., 1957; 1958).
(47) Setaria italica. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (184)

isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.39. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80
% protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in

Mirabilis mosaic caulimovirus

      (1) R. Hull, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: MiMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported in Mirabilis nyctaginea. (9) From Illinois,
U.S.A. (10) By Brunt and Kitajima (1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis. (13) Mirabilis nyctaginea
chlorotic vein banding of tip leaves and interveinal chlorosis of older
leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27)

inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus

jalapa, or Mirabilis nyctaginea. (50) Nyctaginaceae <2/2>. (53) Brunt and
Kitajima (1973). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Donson and
Hull (1983); Richins and Shepherd (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 50 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
210-254 S. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 17 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 83 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 7.8 kb
<pairs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.8 kb
<pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Donson and Hull (1983); Richins
and Shepherd (1983). (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region absent, or present. (111) Poly A region present
in full length cRNA. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Brunt and Kitajima (1973). (164) Genome replicates
<presumably> in nuclei and in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on
a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (179) Caulimovirus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: dahlia mosaic,
cauliflower mosaic and carnation etched ring viruses. (187) Brunt, A.A. and
Kitajima, E.W. (1973). Phytopath. Z. 76: 265. Donson, J. and Hull, R. (1983).
J. gen Virol. 64: 2281. Richins, R.D. and Shepherd, R.J. (1983). Virology 124:
208.

Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with

<at room temperature>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Tsuchizaki et al. (1971). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 22-25 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 122 S <B1 and B2>. (78) Of the other(s) 93 S <M>,
or 50 S <T>. (79) Density 1.504 g cm3 in CsCl <B2>, or 1.497 g cm3 in CsCl
<B1>, or 1.413 g cm3 in CsCl <T>. (84) Virions contain 41 % nucleic acid <B2>,
or 40.1 % nucleic acid <B1>, or 29.5 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid
<T>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B2>, or 59.9 % protein <B1>, or 70.5 % protein
<M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.2 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 7.3 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.9
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hibi et al. (1984). (109)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid not found in the virions. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are membranous bodies <with vesicles>. (178) Other cellular
changes: tubules containing a single row of virions in the cytoplasm. (179)
Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, cherry leaf roll, grapevine
chrome mosaic, grapevine fanleaf, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent
ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and tomato ringspot viruses.
(187) Hibi, T., Yagita, H. and Iwaki, M. (1984). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan
50: 445. Tsuchizaki, T. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 142, 3 pp.

      (1) J.P. Varma, 1981. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: MYMV. (5) ICTV

melo leaf chlorosis and vein necrosis. Pisum sativum leaf chlorosis. (14)

protein(s) one. (133) Mr 53000. (134) Capsid protein. (148) Virion proteins
not glycosylated. (150) Virion proteins not phosphorylated. (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and roots.
(179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with

Narcissus latent macluravirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1985. (2) Synonyms: gladiolus latent virus, gladiolus
ringspot virus, iris mild mosaic virus (Derks et al., 1985), iris mild yellow
mosaic virus (Asjes, 1979; Derks et al., 1985), irisbontvirus, narcissus mild
mottle carlavirus. (3) Standard acronym: NLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.U.2.002. (8) First reported in Narcissus pseudonarcissus cv. Golden
Harvest. (9) From Sussex, England. (10) By Brunt and Atkey (1967). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Gladiolus cv. Scarlet Royal and Iris xiphium cv.
praecox × I. tingitana (syn. Iris hollandica) bulbous iris probably
symptomless when present alone. Narcissus pseudonarcissus leaf tip chlorosis
in some cultivars. Nerine sarniensis cv. Rotherside probably symptomless when
present alone. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus persicae, Aphis gossypii. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, the Netherlands, and the UK.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii systemic
chlorotic spotting. Nicotiana benthamiana and N. megalosiphon faint chlorotic
local lesions, then some faint systemic chlorotic vein banding. Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. The Prince small chlorotic local lesions. Tetragonia
tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions, rarely systemic. (44) Chenopodium
quinoa, Dianthus barbatus, Vigna unguiculata, Trifolium incarnatum, Gomphrena
globosa. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. benthamiana, N. megalosiphon. (46)
Nicotiana clevelandii (W), N. megalosiphon (W), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L)
(unreliable), Phaseolus vulgaris (L) (unreliable). (47) Datura metel, or
Datura stramonium, or Gladiolus <cv. Scarlet Royal>, or Iris xiphium <cv.
praecox X I. tingitana>, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nerine sarniensis
<cv. Rotherside>, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Atriplex hortensis, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Beta macrocarpa,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica juncea,
or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Emilia sagittata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Hippeastrum hybridum, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum
sativum, or Silene armeria, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaryllidaceae <2/3>, or Iridaceae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/6>, or Solanaceae <9/16>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Amaryllidaceae <1/3>, or Caryophyllaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5 /6>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/16>. (53) Brunt (1977). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C <in
Nicotiana clevelandii sap>. (55) LIV: 3-4 days <in Nicotiana clevelandii sap>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4 <in Nicotiana clevelandii sap>. (57) Infectivity of
sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Brunt (1977). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 657 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 156-158 S. (79) Density 1.32-1.33
g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.09 <corrected>. (84) Virions
contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 32600. (145) Method of preparation: Brunt et al. (1975). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (179) Macluravirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: lily symptomless virus, but distantly (SDI 6). (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: cactus 2, carnation latent, chrysanthemum B,
cowpea mild mottle, elderberry, hippeastrum latent, hop latent, honeysuckle
latent, passiflora latent, potato M, potato S, red clover vein mosaic and
white bryony mosaic viruses. (186) Formerly assumed to be a carlavirus,
however now known to induce cylindrical inclusions ('pinwheels`) to form
(Mowat et al., 1991; Brunt et al., 1994). Thus the virus shares properties
with maclura mosaic virus which, it is suggested (Mowat et al., 1991), should
form a new genus, that has been tentatively named macluravirus (Shukla et al.,
1994). (187) Asjes, C.J. (1979). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 85: 269. Brunt, A.A.
(1976). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1975, p. 122. Brunt, A.A. (1976).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 170, 4 pp. Brunt, A.A. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol.
87: 355. Brunt, A.A. and Atkey, P.T. (1967). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.
1966, p. 155. Brunt, A.A., Atkey, P.T., Frost, C. and Phillips, S. (1994).
Acta Hort. 377: 275. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J., Tremaine, J.H. and
Stace-Smith, R. (1975). J. gen. Virol. 27: 101. Derks, A.F.L.M., Hollinger,
Th.C. and Vink-van den Abeele, J.L. (1985). Acta Hort. 164: 309. Mowat, W.P.,

Wallingford, U.K.


Narcissus mosaic potexvirus

      (1) W.P. Mowat, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: NMV. (4) Strains: Lychnis
potexvirus (R.I. Hamilton in Koenig, 1985). (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported in Narcissus pseudonarcissus. (9) From the
Netherlands and the U.K. (10) By Van Slogteren and de Bruyn Ouboter (1946);
Brunt (1966). (13) Narcissus pseudonarcissus symptomless infection. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants <between narcissus plants>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide <in all countries which have imported
narcissus and nerine from Europe>. (39) Spreads in <particularly> the
Netherlands and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii
symptomless systemic infection. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions. (44)
Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley, N. glutinosa, Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii (not infected by
some isolates). (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Apium graveolens, or

globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Medicago sativa, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus,
or Nerine bowdenii, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or

Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens. (48) Allium cepa, or Antirrhinum

<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or

<1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1 /1>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/4>,
or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/7>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>,
or Scrophulariaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <5/9>. (53) Brunt (1966). (54) TIP:
75 °C. (55) LIV: 85 days <and more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (57) Infectivity
of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains

Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4
nm. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest, the 550 nm virions> 114 S. (84)
Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 6.955 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)

6,955bp D13747 Em(40)_vi:MNCCGAA Gb(84)_vi:MNCCGAA Narcissus mosaic virus
(NMV), complete genome. 11/92 6,955bp. 2 sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic
acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (123) Subgenomic mRNA
found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24000. (145)
Method of preparation: Robinson et al. (1975). (147) Amino acid composition:

epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles.

Narcissus tip necrosis (?) carmovirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: NTNV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.T.018. (8) First reported in Narcissus pseudonarcissus. (9) From the
Netherlands. (10) By Asjes (1972). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13)
Narcissus pseudonarcissus, N. tazetta, N. poeticus usually symptomless;
sometimes general leaf chlorosis, elongate chlorotic areas near leaf tips,
later becoming brown and necrotic, premature leaf senescence. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting.
(39) Spreads in the Netherlands and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show small chlorotic
local lesions 2mm; no systemic infection. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. murale
chlorotic local lesions; no systemic infection. Tetragonia tetragonioides
chlorotic local lesions or green rings; no systemic infection. Chenopodium
amaranticolor few pin prick chlorotic local lesions. Chenopodium capitatum,
Nicotiana benthamiana symptomless local infection only. (44) Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. tabacum, Belamcanda chinensis. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, C.
capitatum, C. murale, Tetragonia tetragonioides, Narcissus pseudonarcissus cvs
Barrett Browning, Goblet, Redmarley. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Narcissus poeticus, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or
Narcissus tazetta, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Tetragonia tetragonioides.
(48) Avena sativa, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Dahlia pinnata, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia
faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Amaryllidaceae <3/3>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Solanaceae <1/6>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <5/6>. (52) Hosts become
infected only by inoculation with purified virus preparations, never directly
from infected Narcissus sap. (53) S. Phillips and A. Brunt (unpublished data);
Mowat et al. (1977). (54) TIP: 75 °C. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59)
Electron microscopy: ISEM. (60) Method: Mowat et al. (1977). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30.7 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions neither clearly angular or nor rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 123 S. (79) Density
1.356 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.5-1.6. (84) Virions contain 16-20
% nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80-84 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.85 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.85 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Mowat et al. (1977); Murant et al. (1972).
(132) Virion protein(s) one <plus a fragment>. (133) Mr 42000 <plus 39000>.
(134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Mayo et al. (1974); Brunt et
al. (1975). (148) Virion proteins not glycosylated. (150) Virion proteins not
phosphorylated. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis and meristems. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (179) <Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: carnation
mottle, elderberry latent, pelargonium flower break, saguaro cactus and turnip
crinkle viruses. (187) Asjes, C.J. (1972). Jversl. Lab. Bloemboll. Lisse,
1970-1971 p. 45. Asjes, C.J. (1974). Jversl. Lab. Bloemboll., Lisse, 1973, p.
46. Brunt, A.A. (1975). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1974, p. 116. Brunt,
A.A., Barton, R.J., Tremaine., J.H. and Stace-Smith, R. (1975). J. gen. Virol.
27: 101. Mayo, M.A., Robinson, D.J. and Perombelon, M.C.M. (1974). J. gen.
Microbiol. 85: 121. Mowat, W.P. and Hutcheson, A.M. (1974). Rep. Scottish
Hort. Res. Inst. 1973, p. 61. Mowat, W.P., Asjes, C.J. and Brunt, A.A. (1976).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 166, 4 pp. Mowat, W.P., Asjes, C.J. and Brunt,
A.A. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol. 86: 189. Murant, A.F., Mayo, M.A., Harrison,

      (2) Synonyms: narcissus degeneration potyvirus, narcissus yellow streak
virus. (3) Standard acronym: NYSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.041. (13)

Nasturtium mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: NasMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.058. (8) First reported in Tropaeolum majus. (9) From the U.S.A. and
the U.K. (10) By Jensen (1950); Smith (1950). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Tropaeolum majus vein clearing, mottling and slight leaf malformation;
occasionally flower breaking. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis fabae, Dysaphis apifolia, Myzus
persicae, Aulocorthum circumflexum, Rhopalosiphum padi. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Brazil, South Africa, the UK, and
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Tropaeolum majus severe leaf
mosaic. Zinnia elegans mild leaf chlorosis. (45) Tropaeolum majus, Zinnia
elegans. (46) Tropaeolum majus (W). (47) Tropaeolum majus, or Zinnia elegans.
(50) Compositae <1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4
days. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750
nm. (179) <Possible> Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (184)
Although there is no definite evidence, it is thought that the viruses in
Tropaeolum majus in Brazil, South Africa, the U.K. and the U.S.A. are the same
(da Graca and Martin, 1977). (187) Da Graca, J.V. and Budnik (1993). J.
Phytopath.. da Graca, J.V. and Martin, M.M. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 88: 276.
Jensen, D.D. (1950). Phytopathology 40: 967. Silberschmidt, K. (1953).
Phytopathology 43: 304. Smith, K.M. (1950). J. Roy. hort. Soc. 75: 350.


Neckar River tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: NRV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.1.0.010. (9) From water from the River Neckar, Germany. (10) By Koenig
and Lesemann (1985). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Germany. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii conspicuous systemic
leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium quinoa, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena globosa,
Nicotiana tabacum, Petunia × hybrida local lesions; no systemic infection.
(45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<5/5>. (53) Koenig and Lesemann (1985). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions.
(60) Method: Gallitelli et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 133 S. (79) Density 1.357 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 4.7 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 45000. (171)
Virions found in leaves and the mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(178) Other cellular changes: vesicles at the periphery of microbodies. (179)
Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: eggplant mottled crinkle, pelargonium leaf
curl, Moroccan pepper, petunia asteroid mosaic, tomato bushy stunt and
carnation Italian ringspot viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: cymbidium ringspot virus. (184) The viral genome has about
15% nucleotide sequence homology with that of tomato bushy stunt tombusvirus.
(187) Gallitelli, D. and Russo, M. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119: 106. Koenig, R.
and Gibbs, A.J. (1986). J. gen. Virol. 67: 75. Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E.
(1985). Phytopath. Z. 112: 105.

Nerine latent carlavirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (2) Synonyms: hippeastrum latent virus. (3)

tetragonioides. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
glutinosa × N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa, Chenopodium murale and

capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium,

Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Amaryllidaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Solanaceae <3/12>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <5/5>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae
<2/2>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or
Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <9 /12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (53) Brolman-Hupkes (1975); Maat et al. (1978). (54) TIP:
70-80 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM may be necessary to
detect virions in sap. (60) Method: Maat et al. (1978). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)

wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
