Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32600. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Brunt et al. (1975). (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: carnation latent (SDI 3) and chrysanthemum B
(SDI 10) viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: red
clover vein mosaic, cowpea mild mottle, elderberry, honeysuckle latent, lily
symptomless, narcissus latent, potato M and potato S viruses. (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: ISEM with `decoration' best for distinguishing from similar
viruses. NLV together with hippeastrum mosaic potyvirus is common in
Hippeastrum hybridum varieties, but the two viruses can be separated and
identified by inoculation to Gomphrena globosa and Hyoscyamus niger. (187)
Brolman-Hupkes (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81: 226. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J.,
Tremaine, J.H. and Stace-Smith, R. (1975). J. gen. Virol. 27: 101. Brunt,
A.A., Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1970). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.
1969, p. 138. Maat, D.Z., Huttinga, H. and Hakkaart, F.A. (1978). Neth. J. Pl.
Path. 84: 47.


Nerine potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (2) Synonyms: nerine yellow stripe virus. (3)
Standard acronym: NV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.059. (8) First reported
in Nerine sarniensis. (9) From England. (10) By Brunt et al. (1970). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Nerine sarniensis chlorotic streaking. Nerine bowdenii
chlorotic mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted
by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in the Netherlands and the UK. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii systemic
chlorotic vein-banding. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions.
Chenopodium amaranticolor small chlorotic local lesions. Chenopodium murale
diffuse chlorotic local lesions. Hyoscyamus niger chlorotic local lesions.
Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic local lesions, then systemic chlorotic
vein-banding. Tetragonia tetragonioides green chlorotic rings. (44)
Alstroemeria caryophylla, Phaseolus vulgaris, Solanum tuberosum, Belamcanda
chinensis, Trifolium incarnatum. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, Nicotiana
benthamiana. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Nicotiana benthamiana (W),
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Hyoscyamus niger (L).
(47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Nerine bowdenii, or
Nerine sarniensis, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Alstroemeria caryophylla, or
Belamcanda chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Calendula
officinalis, or Cucumis sativus, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura metel, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lilium
formosanum, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum
demissum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaryllidaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Solanaceae <9/13>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Alstroemeriaceae <1/1>, or
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>,
or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/13>. (54) TIP: 65 °C. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM best for finding virions
in sap. (60) Method: Phillips: Homogenise infected leaves in 0.25M phosphate:
0.1M ascorbic acid: 0.14M mercaptoacetic acid (3:9:1 vols/wt; pH7.0), then
ether and finally carbon tetrachloride (1:1 vols). Stir for 15 minutes then
two cycles differential centrifugation. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 780 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: potato Y (SDI 5), henbane mosaic (SDI 8),
clover yellow vein, (SDI 9) and alstroemeria mosaic (SDI 10) viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic (gladiolus
and crocus strains), carnation vein mottle, freesia mosaic, hippeastrum
mosaic, iris mild mosaic, narcissus degeneration, narcissus late season
yellows, pea mosaic, pepper veinal mottle, tobacco severe etch, and watermelon
mosaic viruses. (187) Brunt, A.A., Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1970). Rep.
Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1969, p. 138. Hakkaart, F.A., Maat, D.Z. and Quak
(1975). Acta Hort. 47: 51.


Nerine X potexvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (2) Synonyms: agapanthus X virus. (3) Standard
acronym: NVX. (4) Strains: Agapanthus, nerine. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Nerine sarniensis. (9) From England. (10)
By Brunt et al. (1970). (13) Nerine sarniensis (nerine strain) symptomless.
Agapanthus praecox ssp. orientalis (agapanthus strain) symptomless. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in the Netherlands and the UK. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, then systemic chlorosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C.
capitatum, Gomphrena globosa and Amaranthus retroflexus chlorotic local
lesions, not systemic. Tetragonia tetragonioides etched chlorotic local
lesions, not systemic. All tests done with the agapanthus strain. (44) Lilium
cv. Enchantment, Narcissus pseudonarcissus, Solanum tuberosum, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Hippeastrum hybridum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium
quinoa (L-W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L) and Chenopodium murale (L). (47)
Agapanthus praecox ssp. orientalis, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nerine
sarniensis, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum. (48) Allium cepa, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Belamcanda chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Cajanus cajan, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura stramonium, or Helianthus annuus, or
Hippeastrum hybridum, or Lactuca sativa, or Lilium <cv. Enchantment>, or
Lilium formosanum, or Montia perfoliata, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Alliaceae <1/2>, or Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Amaryllidaceae <1/3>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/5>, or Solanaceae
<3/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <1/2>, or Amaryllidaceae
<2/3>, or Compositae <6/6>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Iridaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/5>, or Liliaceae <2/2>, or
Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <8 /11>. (53) Phillips and Brunt (1980).
(54) TIP: 95-100 °C. (55) LIV: 365 days <at least>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 7
<all tests in Chenopodium quinoa sap; agapanthus strain>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Maat (1976), for nerine strain; Phillips
and Brunt (1980), agapanthus strain. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 540 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 120 S. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in
CsCl <unfixed>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.18-1.4. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Brunt et al. (1980). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 25600. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Brunt et al. (1975). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (179)
Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: commelina X
(SDI 8), hydrangea ringspot (SDI 9), potato X (SDI 5) and viola mottle (SDI 9)
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bamboo mosaic,
cactus X, cymbidium mosaic, lily X, narcissus mosaic, papaya mosaic (type
strain and ullucus strain), potato aucuba mosaic and white clover mosaic
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM with `decoration'. (186) The
type strain from Nerine sarniensis is isolated and maintained in test plants
with difficulty. Most data in this description are from work with the strain
from Agapanthus praecox ssp. orientalis, which is serologically
indistinguishable from the type strain, but is readily isolated, reaches a
high concentration in test plants and is very stable in vitro. (187) Brunt,
A.A., Barton, R.J., Phillips, S. and Lana, A.O. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 96:
37. Brunt, A.A., Barton, R.J., Tremaine, J.H. and Stace-Smith, R. (1975). J.
gen. Virol. 27: 101. Brunt, A.A., Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1970). Rep.
Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1969, p. 138. Maat, D.Z. (1976). Neth. J. Pl.
Path. 82: 95. Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 65.
Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A. (1988). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 336, 3 pp.


Nerine Y (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.09. (8) First
reported in Nerine sarniensis. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Brunt (1976). (13)
Nerine sarniensis severe leaf chlorosis. (39) Spreads in New Zealand and the
UK. (47) Nerine sarniensis. (50) Amaryllidaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions
filamentous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 800 nm.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 10
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 10 kb. (179)
Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (184) A specific cDNA probe to the
NVY genome did not hybridize with the genome of nerine yellow stripe, potato
Y, hippeastrum mosaic and bean yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Balasingam, G.,
Ellison, N., Milne, K.S. and Forster, R.L.S. (1988). Acta Hort. 234: 267.
Brunt, A.A. (1976). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1976, p.123.


Nicotiana velutina mosaic (?) furovirus

      (1) J.W. Randles, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: NVMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 27.0.1.T.DE.2. (8) First reported in Nicotiana velutina. (9) From Lake
Frome, Australia. (10) By Randles et al. (1976). (13) Nicotiana velutina
bright yellow mosaic. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to 72% in Nicotiana glutinosa>.
(39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana glutinosa systemic chlorosis. N. tabacum etched ringspots, then mild
systemic mottling. N. debneyi necrosis; then systemic mosaic and malformation.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions; not systemic.
Beta macrocarpa local lesions; systemic mosaic. Gomphrena globosa necrotic
ringspots; systemic chlorosis. (44) Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Nicotiana
debneyi. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Beta
macrocarpa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana velutina, or Spinacia oleracea.
(48) Cucumis sativus, or Dianthus barbatus, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia faba.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <8/8>. (51)
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60-70 °C.
(55) LIV: 1-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Randles (1978). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 125-150 nm <range 100175 nm>. (71) Virions 18 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix
2.9 nm. (76) Eight sedimenting components in purified preparations <a broad
band (aggregates, not in separate components)>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
<of the fastest> 155 S <and greater>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11 kb. (92) Genome of two
parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 8 kb <RNA 1>. (94) The
2nd largest 3 kb <RNA 2>. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
phenol or detergent. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Randles and Rohde
(1990). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12292. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
D00906 Em(40)_vi:NVMV2 Gb(84)_vi:NVMV2 Nicotiana velutina mosaic virus RNA2.
2/93 2,325bp. 1 sequence. (119) Features of the genome: RNA 2 contains 4
ORF's; ORF 1 = protein 20K, ORF 2 = protein 39K, ORF 3 = protein 13K and one
ORF is incomplete. (133) Mr 21400. (145) Method of preparation: Randles et al.
(1976). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in locally or systemically infected tissue in thin sections. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) <Possible> Furovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: potato mop top, soil-borne
wheat mosaic, tobacco mosaic, beet necrotic yellow vein, barley stripe mosaic
and tobacco rattle viruses viruses. (184) CDNA clones did not hybridize with
tobacco mosaic, frangipani mosaic, odontoglossum ringspot, tomato mosaic,
sunn-hemp mosaic, cucumber green mottle mosaic and Kyuri green mottle mosaic
tobamoviruses or beet necrotic yellow vein and peanut clump furoviruses.
Although the virus has a divided genome with two RNA's of a size comparable to
those of furoviruses, its unique biological properties and lack of serological
relationship with furoviruses suggest that it has no clear relationship to any
recognised taxonomic group of plant viruses. (187) Randles, J.W. (1978).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 189, 4 pp. Randles, J.W. and Rohde, W. (1990).
J. gen. Virol. 71: 1019. Randles, J.W., Harrison, B.D. and Roberts, I.M.
(1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 84: 193.


Nothoscordum mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: NoMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.042. (8) First reported in Nothoscordum
fragrans. (9) From Canary Islands. (10) By McKinney (1929). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Nothoscordum fragrans mosaic mottling. (39) Spreads in the USA
<Louisiana, and the Canary Islands>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum, Avena sativa, Zea mays.
(45) Nothoscordum fragrans (W). (47) Nothoscordum fragrans. (48) Allium cepa,
or Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium,
or Lilium formosanum, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Zea
mays. (50) Alliaceae <1/2>. (51) Alliaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<3/3>. (53) McKinney (1929). (54) TIP: 58-60 °C. (55) LIV: 17-20 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 771 nm. (179) Unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Gold, A.H., Scott, H.A. and McKinney,
H.H. (1957). Pl. Dis. Reptr 41: 250. McKinney, H.H. (1929). J. Agric. Res. 39:
557. McKinney, H.H. (1950). Phytopathology 40: 703.


Oak ringspot virus

      (1) J.P. Fulton, K.S. Kim and O.W. Barnett, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.28. (8) First reported in Quercus marilandica and Q. velutina. (9)
From Northwest Arkansas, U.S.A. (10) By Barnett (1971); Kim and Fulton (1973).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Quercus marilandica, Q. velutina chlorotic
ringspots and mosaic, vein-banding and oak leaf patterns, especially on older
leaves. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Barnett (1971); Kim and
Fulton (1973). (39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Quercus marilandica, Q. velutina. (45) Quercus marilandica, Q. velutina.
(47) Quercus marilandica, or Quercus velutina. (50) Fagaceae <2/2>. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions <none found in extracts>. (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with
no clear modal length. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure.
(171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (177) They contain virions. (178)
Other cellular changes: areas of vesiculation, prominent Golgi and paramural
bodies, and cell wall protrusions. (179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: A virus-like disorder of overcup oak is not graft transmissible
(Gregory and Seliskar, 1970), and no virions could be found (Neinhaus and
Yarwood, 1972). (186) The relationship to viruses of oak in Europe (Blattny
and Prochazkov, 1966; Schmelzer et al., 1966) is not known. (187) Barnett,
O.W. (1971). Pl. Dis. Reptr 55: 411. Blattny, C. and Prochazkova, Z. (1966).
Rev. Roumaine Biol. Ser. Bot. 11(1/3): 39. Gregory, G.F. and Seliskar, C.E.
(1970). Pl. Dis. Reptr 54: 844. Kim, K.S. and Fulton, J.P. (1973). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 57: 1029. Nienhaus, F. and Yarwood, C.E. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 313.
Schmelzer, K., Schmidt, H.E. and Schmidt, H.B. (1966). Arch. Forstw. 15: 107.


Oat blue dwarf marafivirus

      (1) E.E. Banttari, R.J. Zeyen and R.G. Timian, 1991. (2) Synonyms: flax
crinkle virus. (3) Standard acronym: OBDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 41.0.1.0.004.
(8) First reported in Avena sativa. (9) From Minnesota, U.S.A. (10) By Goto
and Moore (1952). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms stunting, enations,
deep blue colour in Avena sp. (13) Avena sativa stunting, short stiffened
leaves, bluish leaves, enations along leaf veins, sterility of florets.
Hordeum vulgare, Chrysanthemum morifolium, Hordeum jubatum, Spinacia oleracea,
Stellaria media, Thlaspi arvense dwarfing and stiffening of leaves, enations.
Linum grandiflorum, L. usitatissimum stunting, prominent enations along leaf
veins. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Macrosteles fascifrons. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (24)
Not transmitted by Macrosiphum avenae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus
not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Banttari and
Zeyen (1976); Long et al. (1975); Timian (1985); Westdal (1968). (39) Spreads
in Canada, Finland, Sweden, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show stunting,
enations along leaf veins, bluish color, sterility of florets. (43) Avena
sativa, Hordeum vulgare enations, blue colour, stunting, sterility, excess
tillering. Chrysanthemum morifolium, Stellaria media enations. Linum
grandiflorum, L. usitatissimum enations, less tillering, dimples on leaves,
stunting. Spinacia oleracea wrinkling and cupping of leaves. Thlaspi arvense
see Westdal (1968). (44) Amaranthus retroflexus, Brassica campestris,
Callistephus chinensis, Cucumis sativus, Zinnia elegans. (45) Avena sativa,
Hordeum vulgare, Linum usitatissimum. (46) Avena sativa (W), Hordeum vulgare
(W), Linum usitatissimum (W). (47) Avena fatua, or Avena sativa, or Centaurea
cyanus, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cichorium endiva, or Daucus carota, or
Gaillardia aristata, or Hordeum jubatum, or Hordeum vulgare, or Linum
grandiflorum, or Linum usitatissimum, or Secale cereale, or Sinapis arvensis,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Thlaspi arvense, or Triticum
aestivum, or Triticum durum. (48) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium graveolens,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus,
or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Calendula officinalis, or Callistephus chinensis, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Carthamus tinctorius, or Chenopodium album, or Cucumis sativus, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus, or Senecio vulgaris, or Setaria viridis, or
Solanum melongena, or Trifolium pratense, or Vicia sativa, or Zea mays, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or
Compositae <4/11>, or Cruciferae <2/7>, or Gramineae <7/9>, or Linaceae <2/2>,
or Umbelliferae <1/4>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Compositae <7/11>, or Cruciferae <5/7>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <2/9>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>,
or Polygonaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <5/5>, or Umbelliferae <3/4>. (53)
Westdal (1968). (54) TIP: 60-70 °C. (55) LIV: 16-32 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5. (60) Method: Banttari and Zeyen (1969). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 28-30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
<probably> rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 119 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.63.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 6.74 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 6.74 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Pring et al. (1973). (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (164) Genome replicates <in
phloem cells>. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in leaves, roots, meristems and phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm, membranous bodies, and viroplasms. (177) They
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: see Banttari and Zeyen (1971);
Zeyen and Banttari (1972). (179) Marafivirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: Bermuda grass etched line viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Maize rayado fino virus. (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: transmission to flax, barley and oats using the
aster leafhopper. Crinkle in flax, leaf enations, serology, blue colour and
dwarfing in leaves. (187) Atcham, T. and Banttari, E.E. (1986). Phytopathology
76: 1062. Azar, M. and Banttari, E.E. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 858.
Banttari, E.E. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 802. Banttari, E.E. (1979).
Phytopathology 69: 1021. Banttari, E.E. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 1242.
Banttari, E.E. and Frederiksen, R.A. (1959). Phytopathology 49: 539. Banttari,
E.E. and Moore, M.B. (1959). Phytopathology 49: 533. Banttari, E.E. and Moore,
M.B. (1962). Phytopathology 52: 897. Banttari, E.E. and Zeyen, R.J. (1968).
Phytopathology 58: 1042. Banttari, E.E. and Zeyen, R.J. (1969). Phytopathology
59: 183. Banttari, E.E. and Zeyen, R.J. (1970). Phytopathology 60: 399.
Banttari, E.E. and Zeyen, R.J. (1971). Phytopathology 61: 1249. Banttari, E.E.

Oat chlorotic stunt (?) tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First
reported in Avena sativa. (9) From Wales. (10) By Catherall (1986). (13) Avena
sativa pale green to bright yellow leaf streaking, then necrosis and severe
stunting, no viable seed produced. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in the UK. (47) Avena sativa. (50) Gramineae <1/1>.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 35 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.114
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Boonham et al. (1995). (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 48200. (134) Coat protein. (179) <Possible>
Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (184) The sequence of the
coat protein places this virus closest to the tombusviruses, but the
polymerase sequence places it outside the Tombusviridae. (187) Boonham, N.,
Henry, C.M. and Wood, K.R. (1995). J. gen. Virol. 76: 2025. Catherall, P.L.
(1980). Rep. Welsh Pl. Breeding Stn. 1985, p. 132.


Oat golden stripe furovirus

      (1) P. Jones, 1990. (2) Synonyms: oat chlorotic stripe virus, oat
tubular virus (Plumb and MacFarlane, 1978), soil-borne oat stripe virus. (3)
Standard acronym: OGSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 27.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported
in Avena sativa. (9) From Devon, England. (10) By Plumb et al. (1977). (11)
Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms yellow striping on tip leaves when
systemically infected. (13) Avena sativa yellow striping on two youngest
leaves. Many plants may have infected roots, but show no systemic symptoms.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus <presumably>. (17)
Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Polymyxa graminis. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(39) Spreads in France, the UK, and the USA <North Carolina>. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
mottling; striping rare in glasshouse plants. (43) Avena sativa yellow
mottling and stripes on leaves; systemic infection. Nicotiana clevelandii,
Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions, sometimes systemic in N.
clevelandii. Nicotiana debneyi chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana.
(44) Triticum sp., Hordeum vulgare, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Avena sp. (47)
Avena sativa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi. (48) Hordeum vulgare, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Triticum aestivum. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <1/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (51) Gramineae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (53) Plumb et al. (1977). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Adams et al. (1988). (61) Virions
rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 150-300 nm. (71) Virions 20
nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 218 S. (78) Of the other(s) 168 S. (79) Density
1.321 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 9.7 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part <the larger> 6.2 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.5 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Jones: proteinase K incubation followed by
phenol/chloroform and precipitation with ethanol. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 45103.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 20000. (171) Virions found in leaves and
roots. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (178) Other cellular changes:
disruption of organelles (Plumb et al., 1977). (179) Furovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: soil borne wheat mosaic virus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet necrotic yellow
vein, hypochoeris mosaic and potato mop top viruses. (184) Very distantly
serologically related to potato M and red clover vein mosaic carlaviruses.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: often found with oat mosaic virus. Distinguish
by virion morphology in EM `dip preparations'. (187) Adams, M.J., Jones, P.
and Swaby, A.G. (1988). Ann. appl. biol. 112: 285. Chen, J. and Adams, M.J.
(1991). Pl. Path. 40: in press. Hariri, D. and Lapierre, H. (1985). Mitt.
Biol. Bund. Land. Forst. Berlin-Dahlem 228: 72. Macfarlane, I., Jenkins, J.E.
and Melville, S.C. (1968). Pl. Path. 17: 167. Plumb, R.T. and Macfarlane, I.
(1977). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn p. 256. Plumb, R.T. and MacFarlane, I.
(1978). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn 1977 p. 212. Plumb, R.T., Catherall, P.L.,
Chamberlain, J. and Macfarlane, I. (1977). Annls. Phytopath. 9: 365.


Oat mosaic bymovirus

      (1) T. Usugi, 1987. (2) Synonyms: soil-borne oat mosaic virus
(Macfarlane et al. 1968). (3) Standard acronym: OMV. (4) Strains: apical
mosaic strain and eyespot strain. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.3.0.004. (8)
First reported in Avena sativa. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Atkinson (1945);
McKinney (1946). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena spp. mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (21) Transmitted by
Plasmodiophorales. (23) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Toler and Hebert (1964); McKinney (1946). (39)
Spreads in the UK and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Avena sativa mottling, especially in the first leaves. (44) Hordeum vulgare,
Zea mays, Lolium spp., Oryza sativa. (45) Avena sativa. (46) Avena sativa (W).
(47) Avena byzantina, or Avena sativa, or Avena strigosa, or Triticum
aestivum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Allium cepa, or Amaranthus caudatus,
or Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or
Capsicum annuum, or Carthamus tinctorius, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cicer
arietinum, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lolium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza
sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or Phaseolus lunatus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis peruviana, or Pisum
sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Secale cereale, or Solanum melongena, or
Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
repens, or Tulipa gesneriana, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans.
(50) Gramineae <4/9>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <5/9>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<12/12>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <2 /2>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10/10>. (53) McKinney (1946); Toler and
Hebert (1963). (54) TIP: 44-46 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
1-2 <using the leaf rubbing method>, or 2-5 <using the air brush method>. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Usugi (1981). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with
no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 600-750 nm. (71) Virions 12-14 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (79) Density 1.3 g cm3 in
CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 12 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 8 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by nucleic acid is extracted by adding 2% SDS to purified
preparation. (110) Poly A region present. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133)
Mr <of the larger> 30000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 26500. (145) Method of
preparation: Usugi (1981). (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179)
Bymovirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
sap inoculation tests; only Avena species are susceptible, and develop
mottling symptoms below 15°C. (187) Atkinson, M. (1945). Pl. Dis. Reptr 29:
86. Hebert, T.T. and Panizo, C.H. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 145,
4 pp. Macfarlane, I., Jenkins, J.E.E. and Melville, S. (1968). Pl. Path. 17:
167. McKinney, H.H. (1946). Phytopathology 36: 359. Panizo, C.H. (1975). Ph.D.
Thesis N. Carolina State University. Toler, R.W. and Hebert, T.T. (1963). Pl.
Dis. Reptr 47: 58. Toler, R.W. and Hebert, T.T. (1964). Phytopathology 54:
428. Usugi, T. (1981). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 47: 581.


Oat necrotic mottle rymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ONMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.2.0.004. (8) First reported in Avena sativa. (9) From Manitoba, Canada.
(10) By Gill and Westdal (1966). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena sativa leaf
chlorosis and, in spring-sown crops, abortion of florets, seed loss and plant
stunting. Poa canadensis, P. pratensis mild leaf chlorosis or symptomless
infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies reported by Gill and
Westdal (1966); Poa pratensis and P. canadensis adjacent to crops are often
infected and may be important sources of infection. (39) Spreads in Canada.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Avena sativa leaf chlorosis, sheath
mottling or necrosis. (44) Elytrigia repens, Dactylis glomerata, Festuca
elatior, F. rubra, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium perenne, Lophopyrum elongatum,
Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays. (45) Avena sativa cv.
Clintland64. (46) Avena sativa cv. Clintland64 (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Poa
canadensis, or Poa pratensis. (48) Agrostis alba, or Agrostis palustris, or
Agrostis tenuis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Elytrigia
repens, or Festuca elatior, or Festuca rubra, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium
perenne, or Lophopyrum elongatum, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or
Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <3/17>. (51) Gramineae <14/17>. (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55)
LIV: 3-7 days <at 23°C>, or 42-56 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (60)
Method: Gill (1971). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 720 nm. (71) Virions
11 nm wide. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.33. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 39800. (134) Coat
protein. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: the occurrence of deposits, sometimes
extensive, on cell walls. (179) Rymovirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: wheat streak mosaic virus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: agropyron mosaic,
hordeum mosaic and ryegrass mosaic viruses. (187) Gill, C.C. (1967).
Phytopathology 57: 302. Gill, C.C. (1971). J. gen. Virol. 12: 259. Gill, C.C.
(1974). Can. J. Bot. 52: 621. Gill, C.C. (1976a). Phytopathology 66: 415.
Gill, C.C. (1976b). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 170, 4 pp. Gill, C.C.
(1980). Can. J. Pl. Path. 2: 86. Gill, C.C. and Westdal, P.H. (1966). Can. Pl.
Dis. Surv. 46: 18.


Oat pseudorosette (?) tenuivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: oat pupation disease virus, oat
Siberian mosaic virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.T.DE.3. (8) First reported
in Avena sativa. (9) From USSR (Siberia). (10) By Sukhov (1940). (13) Avena
sativa light green stripes and spots in leaves and leaf sheaths, proliferic
tillering, severe stunting and, often, sterility. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Laodelphax
striatellus. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the former USSR. (43) Avena sativa leaf
chlorosis, excessive tillering and stunting. (47) Avena sativa. (50) Gramineae
<1/1>. (179) <Possible> Tenuivirus. (186) Symptoms, persistent transmission by
a delphacid planthopper vector and the possible presence of a non-capsid
protein in infected plants suggest that the virus may be a tenuivirus. (187)
Gingery, R.E. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 4, The Filamentous Viruses,
p. 297; ed R.G. Milne, Plenum Press, New York. Sukhov, K.S. and Vovk, A.M.
(1938). C.R. (Dokl.) Acad. Sci., URSS 19: 207. Sukhov, K.S. (1940).
Mikrobiologiya 9: 188. Sukhov, K.S., Vovk, A.M. and Alexeeva, T.S. (1943).
C.R. (Dokl.) Acad. Sci., URSS 41: 344.


Oat sterile dwarf fijivirus

      (1) R.G. Milne, 1991. (2) Synonyms: arrhenatherum blue dwarf virus
(Milne and Lesemann, 1978; Muhle and Kempiak, 1971; Luisoni et al., 1979),
lolium enation virus (Lesemann and Huth, 1975; Milne and Lesemann, 1978). (3)
Standard acronym: OSDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.7.3.001. (8) First reported
in Avena sativa. (9) From the former Czechoslovakia and Sweden. (10) By Prusa
(1958); Lindsten (1959). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms bushy, dwarf,
dark green grass-like appearance; leaf malformation, yellowish or white
enations (small galls) centred on veins or vein swellings on backs of leaves.
(13) Arrhenatherum elatius, Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium multiflorum,
L. perenne dwarfing, excess tillering, flower suppression and retention of
non-maturing juvenile phase; dark green colour of leaves, which may be
notched, ragged or malformed; small enations on abaxial surfaces of leaves,
nodes and spike. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Javesella pellucida, J. dubia, J. discolor, J. obscurella,
Dicranotropis hamata. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (22) Principal natural
vector(s): Javesella pellucida. (24) Not transmitted by Laodelphax
striatellus. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (29) Virus does not
require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Boccardo and Milne (1980); Lindsten (1979); BrcHak (1979).
(39) Spreads in the former Czechoslovakia, Finland, Germany, Norway, Poland,
Sweden, and the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show bushy, dwarf, dark green grass-like appearance;
leaf malformation, yellow or white enations on veins or vein swellings on
backs of leaves. (43) Arrhenatherum elatius, Avena spp., Cynosurus cristatus,
Hordeum spp., Lolium spp., Phalaris canariensis, Poa annua, Secale cereale,
Triticum spp., Zea spp. bushy dwarf dark green grasslike appearance, leaf
malformation, yellow or white enations on veins or vein swellings on backs of
leaves. (44) All species except those from the Gramineae. Insusceptible
Gramineae include Elytrigia repens, Agrostis gigantea, Bromus inermis,
Digitaria sanguinalis, Echinochloa crus-galli. (45) Lolium multiflorum. (46)
Avena sativa (W), Lolium multiflorum (W). (47) Arrhenatherum elatius, or Avena
fatua, or Avena sativa, or Cynosurus cristatus, or Festuca pratensis, or
Holcus lanatus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lagurus ovatus, or Lolium multiflorum,
or Lolium perenne, or Lolium temulentum, or Phalaris canariensis, or Poa
annua, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Agrostis
gigantea, or Alopecurus myosuroides, or Apera spica-venti, or Bromus inermis,
or Digitaria sanguinalis, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Elytrigia repens. (50)
Gramineae <16/23>. (51) Gramineae <7/23>. (53) Milne and Lovisolo (1977). (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: take material from
enations only, or swollen leaf veins; use UA, not PTA, glutaraldehyde causes
damage. (60) Method: Luisoni et al. (1979); Boccardo and Milne (1980). Only
B-spiked subvirions (SVPs) have been purified. Use 0.4M phosphate buffer pH 7,
shake with Freon, recover SVPs in aqueous phase; apply 2 cycles of
differential centrifugation, and a final rate-zonal caesium sulphate density
gradient. (61) Virions isometric. (62) Virions subvirions are commonly seen,
appearing as 50 nm diameter spheres with spikes. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 65-70 nm in diameter <complete virions>. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations to four
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 28.91 kb <pairs>.
(92) Genome of 10 parts <named S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
largest> 4.4 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.9 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd
largest 3.7 kb <pairs>. (96) The 4th largest 3.7 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th
largest 3.3 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 2.9 kb <pairs;
also 1.86, 1.83, 1.82 and 1.5 kb pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Luisoni et al. (1979). (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm <of phloem and
related cells of plants, and in the cytoplasm of many cell types in insects>.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
leaves, roots, phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(173) Virions found in veins of infected plants are swollen or develop
enations consisting of enlarged and proliferated phloem parenchyma. Most
virions are found in these cells, and in the roots. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms and unusual in shape. (176)
Crystalline arrays of complete virions and tubules or scroll-like structures
composed of protein, usually containing virions. (177) They contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: cell proliferation (Milne and Lovisolo, 1977;
Milne, 1980). (179) Fijivirus: Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: sugarcane fiji disease, maize rough
dwarf, rice black-streaked dwarf and pangola stunt viruses. (187) Boccardo, G.
and Milne, R.G. (1980). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 217. Boccardo, G. and
Milne, R.G. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 294, 7pp. BrcHak, J.
(1979). In: Leafhopper Vectors and Plant Disease Agents p. 97; eds K.
Maramorosch and K. Harris. Academic Press, New York. Lesemann, D.-E. and Huth,

Odontoglossum ringspot tobamovirus

      (1) D.-E. Lesemann and P. Beetham, 1986. (2) Synonyms: tobacco mosaic
virus orchid strain (Jensen and Gold, 1951; Kado et al., 1968). (3) Standard
acronym: ORSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in
Odontoglossum grande. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Jensen and Gold (1951). (13)
Odontoglossum grande ringspots. Cymbidium spp. `diamond' mottle. More than 20
genera of orchids are reported to be infected by odontoglossum ringspot virus
and show flower colour-breaking, chlorotic streaking, mosaic or necrosis.
Symptomless in some cultivars. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a
vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc necrotic local lesions in older leaves, ring-like local
lesions in younger leaves. Cassia occidentalis, Chenopodium amaranticolor
pinpoint necrotic spots. The symptoms induced in orchids are not diagnostic.
(45) Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
quinoa (L), Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cymbidium alexanderi, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Odontoglossum grande, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Orchidaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/3>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>.
(53) Paul et al. (1965); Lawson and Ali (1975). (54) TIP: 90 °C. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions rodshaped. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of <mostly> 300 nm <but also shorter, broken
virions>. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the longer virions> 212 S. (78) Of the other(s) 119 S <of the
shorter virions>. (79) Density 1.25 g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 0.99 <for predominantly longer virions>, or 0.63 <for the shorter
virions; both values corrected for scattering>. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12238. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): X55295 Em(40)_vi:TOORCOAT Gb(84)_vi:TOORCOAT Odontoglossum ringspot
virus coat protein gene. 12/91 891bp. X55296 Em(40)_vi:ORVTRANS
Gb(84)_vi:ORVTRANS Odontoglossum ringspot virus cell-to-cell transport gene.
12/90 912bp. X80053 Gb(84)_vi:ORSPVCY Odontoglossum ringspot Virus-Cy RNA.
7/94 1,015bp. X78966 Em(43)_vi:Orsvcp Gb(89)n:Orsvcp Odontoglossum Ringspot
Virus (strain Cy) coat protein mRNA. 5/95 900bp. X82130 Em(43)_vi:Orsvrna
Gb(89)_vi:Orsvrna Odontoglossum ringspot virus RNA for replicase, movement
protein and coat protein genes. 10/9. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
17598. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Paul and Buchta
(1971); Henning (1972). (147) Amino acid composition: Henning (1972). (171)
Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions
found in chloroplasts and in cytoplasm <very occasionally>. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm.
(179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
cucumber green mottle mosaic, ribgrass mosaic, tomato mosaic, tobacco mosaic
and tobacco mild green mosaic tobamoviruses (see Dubs and Regenmortel, 1990).
(183) Local lesions caused by the type strain are larger than those of
Corbett's (1967) isolate TMV-O. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: this virus
differs from all others known to infect orchids by its virion morphology, and
by its ability to induce necrotic local lesions in Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Xanthi. (187) Corbett, M.K. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 164. Dubs, M.C. and van
Regenmortel, M.H.V. (1990). Arch. Virol. 115: 239. Edwardson, J.R. and
Zettler, F.W. (1986). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 2, The Rod-Shaped Plant
Viruses, pp. 233247; eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel and H. Fraenkel-Conrat. Plenum
Press, New York. Hennig, B. (1972). In: Atlas of Protein Sequence and
Structure, Vol. 5, D287; ed. M.O. Dayhoff. National Biomedical Research
Foundation, Washington. Jensen, D.D. and Gold, H.A. (1951). Phytopathology 41:
648. Kado, C.I., van Regenmortel, M.H.V. and Knight, C.A. (1968). Virology 34:
17. Lawson, R.H. and Ali, S. (1975). In: Handbook on Orchid Pests and
Diseases, pp. 62-103. American Orchid Society, Cambridge, Mass., U.S.A. Paul,

Okra leaf-curl bigeminivirus

      (1) L. Givord, 1991. (2) Synonyms: bamia leaf-crinkle virus. (3)
Standard acronym: OLCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.027. (8) First reported
in Abelmoschus esculentus (syn. Hibiscus esculentus). (9) From the Sudan. (10)
By Kirkpatrick (1930). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms vein thickening,
leaf crinkling and curling, vein enations, plants stunted and develop fewer
and smaller pods. (13) Abelmoschus esculentus leaf crinkling, curling, plants
stunted. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by Atiri and Fayoyin (1989). (39) Spreads in Chad,
Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria, and Sudan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show leaf curl. (43) Gossypium hirsutum,
Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Congo Jute, Urena lobata leaf curl. Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Havana 24 faint mottling. (45) Abelmoschus esculentus. (46)
Abelmoschus esculentus (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Urena lobata.
(50) Malvaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (53) Yassin and Nour (1965); Lana
(1976). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: grinding in phosphate
buffer 0.2M pH 7.8, butanol/chloroform clarification, differential
centrifugation, sucrose density gradient, yielding at 15 mg/kg. (61) Virions
geminate. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: African cassava mosaic virus. (187) Ahmed,
A.H. (1978). Acta Hort. 84: 65. Atiri, G.I. and Fayoyin, G.A. (1989). Ann.
appl. Biol. (suppl.) 10: 152. Bink, F.A. (1973). Cot. Fib. Trop. 28: 365.
Fauquet, C. and Thouvenel, J.C. (1987). Initiations Documentations Techniques
No. 46. Kirkpatrick, T.W. (1930). Bull. Ent. Res. 21; 127. Kirkpatrick, T.W.
(1931). Bull. Ent. Res. 22: 323. Lana, A.F. (1976). PANS 22: 474. Yassin, A.M.
and Nour, M.A. (1965). Ann. appl. Biol. 56: 207.


Okra mosaic tymovirus

      (1) L. Givord, 1984. Revised 1991. (2) Synonyms: virus de la mosaique du
Gombo. (3) Standard acronym: OkMV. (4) Strains: VMG-CI (IC. OkMV) from
Abelmoschus esculentus, Côte d'Ivoire; VM-HR, from H. rosa-sinensis, Côte
d'Ivoire; VMG-Nig (N.OkMV) from A. esculentus in Nigeria (Givord, 1977;
Bozarth et al., 1977). (5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported
in Abelmoschus esculentus. (9) From Côte d'Ivoire. (10) By Givord et al.
(1972). (11) Symptoms persist <in all other families except Malvaceae>. (12)
Symptoms mosaic, vein chlorosis and banding in Malvaceae. Other families show
interveinal chlorosis, vein chlorosis and vein banding. In all families plants
are often stunted. (13) Abelmoschus esculentus, Hibiscus rosa-sinensis mosaic
and vein banding. Abutilon hirtum yellow mosaic. Borreria intricans
interveinal mosaic. Corchorus olitorius, Hibiscus sabdariffa vein chlorosis
and vein banding. Malvastrum coromandelianum, Sida acuta, S. rhomboidea yellow
mosaic. Physalis angulata symptomless. Sida linifolia mosaic and vein banding.
Urena lobata some star-shaped light green areas. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Podagrica decolorata in
Côte d'Ivoire (Givord and den Boer, 1980); Podagrica uniforma, P. sjostedti in
Nigeria (Lana and Taylor, 1976; Atiri, 1984). Possibly Bemisia tabaci is a
vector in Nigeria (Lana and Taylor, 1976), but needs confirmation. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (24) Not transmitted by Aphis gossypii,
Chrysolagria cuprina, Lagria villosa, Medythia quaterna, Ootheca mutabilis,
Nisotra dilecta. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by natural and
synthetic chemicals are known for control (Atiri, 1991). Tolerant cultivars;
Perkins Long Pod in Côte d'Ivoire (Givord, 1980), NHAE 621 and NHAE 117 in
Nigeria (Atiri, 1983). (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire and Nigeria. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
regular vein chlorosis, large chlorotic bands along principal veins, spotting
or dotting, chlorotic mosaic, chlorotic local lesions, stunting. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic chlorotic spotting and line patterns.
Cucumis sativus large chlorotic local lesions, then systemic vein chlorosis.
Arachis hypogaea dark and light green mosaic. Vigna unguiculata fine systemic
vein chlorosis and mosaic. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic dark green and
whitish mosaic, dwarfing. (44) Zinnia elegans, Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Cucurbita pepo, Phaseolus vulgaris, Datura stramonium. (45)
Cucumis sativus in temperate regions. Abelmoschus esculentus in tropical
regions. (46) No reliable local lesion host known. Abelmoschus esculentus (W).
(47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Abutilon hirtum, or Adansonia digitata, or
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium graveolens, or Arachis hypogaea, or Borreria
intricans, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Ceiba pentandra, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or

or Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, or Hibiscus sabdariffa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Lavatera trimestris, or Malvastrum coromandelianum, or Matthiola incana, or
Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or

become rounded, clumped, vacuolated and disorganised (Lesemann, 1977). (179)
Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: kennedya yellow

related (Koenig, 1976). (183) VMGCI, VMGNig and VM.HR can be distinguished by

Olive latent ringspot nepovirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: OLRSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.0.022. (8) First reported in Olea europaea. (9) From Lazio,
Central Italy. (10) By Savino et al. (1983). (13) Olea spp. symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (39) Spreads in Italy <Lozio, central Italy>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic, apical necrosis. Gomphrena globosa
red-rimmed local lesions, tip leaves malformed. (44) Nicotiana tabacum cvs
Samsun, White Barley, N. glutinosa, Vigna radiata. (45) Chenopodium quinoa,
Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor
(W), Cucumis sativus cv. Markerer (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Olea europaea, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris.
(48) Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vigna radiata. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Oleaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (51)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/4>. (53) Savino et al.
(1983). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 15 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (60)
Method: Gallitelli: homogenise symptom bearing Chenopodium quinoa leaves in
0.1M neutral phosphate buffer. Clarify the sap with Mg-activated bentonite.
Purify by two cycles of centrifugation. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 132 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 97 S <M>, or 52 S
<T>. (79) Density 1.52 g cm3 in CsCl <B2>, or 1.51 g cm3 in CsCl <B1>, or 1.43
g cm3 in CsCl <M>, or 1.29 g cm3 in CsCl <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.8 <B>, or
1.51 <M>, or 1.03 <T>. (84) Virions contain 45 % nucleic acid <B2>, or 43 %
nucleic acid <B1>, or 32 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 55 % protein <B2>, or 57 % protein <B1>, or 68 % protein <M>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 11.4 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 7.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.9 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Gallitelli; best means by phenol SDS. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor
not required for infectivity. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 58000.
(134) A polymer of a monomeric form of 16kDa. (145) Method of preparation:
Gallitelli; boil for 3 minutes in 125mM Tris-Cl pH 6.8 containing 1% SDS, 2%
beta-mercaptoethanol, 6M urea. (148) Virion proteins not glycosylated. (171)
Virions found in leaves mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and membranous bodies. (177)
They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: clumping of chloroplasts
and finger-like outgrowths of the cell. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis
mosaic, artichoke Italian latent, artichoke yellow ringspot, artichoke vein
banding, cherry leaf roll, cherry rasp leaf, chicory yellow mottle, cacao
necrosis, grapevine Bulgarian latent, grapevine fanleaf, grapevine chrome
mosaic, myrobalan latent ringspot raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent
ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and tomato ringspot viruses.
(187) Gallitelli, D., Martelli, G.P. and Savino, V. (1985). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 301, 4 pp. Savino, V., Gallitelli, D. and Barba, M. (1983). Ann.
appl. Biol. 103: 243.


Olive latent 1 (?) sobemovirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: OLV-1. (5) ICTV decimal
code 67.0.1.T.016. (8) First reported in Olea europaea. (9) From Apulia,
southern Italy. (10) By Gallitelli and Savino (1985). (11) Symptoms none. (13)
Olea europaea symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Apulia, southern Italy. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show local lesions, but no systemic infection, except in Nicotiana
benthamiana. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mosaic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
glutinosa, N. megalosiphon, N. tabacum, Gomphrena globosa necrotic local
lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Datura stramonium, Nicotiana rustica,
Petunia × hybrida. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L),
Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N. clevelandii (L), Cucumis sativus (L), Gomphrena
globosa (L). (47) Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Olea europaea, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (48)
Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida. (50)
Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Oleaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <5/8>. (51)
Solanaceae <3/8>. (53) Gallitelli and Savino (1985). (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: Gallitelli and Savino (1985). (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 111 S. (79) Density 1.314 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.64.
(84) Virions contain <c.> 17 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83 % protein. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.1 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 4.1 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Gallitelli: phenolSDS. (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 47669. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found
in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000. (134) Coat
protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (171) Virions found in
leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and
unusual in shape. (176) Vesiculated bodies and tubules. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: those described by Castellano et al.
(1987). (179) <Possible> Sobemovirus. (187) Castellano, M.A., Di Franco, A.
and Martelli, G.P. (1987). J. Submicrosc. Cytol. 19: 495. Gallitelli, D. and
Savino, V. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 106: 295. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature,
Lond. 227: 680.


Olive latent 2 (?) ourmiavirus

      (1) M. Castellano, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: OLV-2. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.4.007. (8) First reported in Olea europaea. (9) From Apulia,
southern Italy. (10) By Savino et al. (1984). (13) Olea spp. symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence
of spread, in Apulia, southern Italy. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Gomphrena globosa reddish necrotic local lesions then symptomless
systemic infection. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic and necrotic local lesions.
Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. benthamiana mild mottling. Petunia × hybrida,
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. tabacum, Vigna radiata symptomless. (44)
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica, Ocimum basilicum, Datura stramonium, Cucumis
sativus, Cucurbita pepo. (45) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana benthamiana. (47)
Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Olea europaea, or Petunia × hybrida, or Vigna radiata.
(48) Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura
stramonium, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Ocimum basilicum.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Oleaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/9>. (51)
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/9>. (54) TIP: 60 °C.
(55) LIV: <more than> 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: homogenize infected tissues in phosphate buffer
(0.07M, pH 7.0) with 0.01M EDTA and 0.1% Namercaptoacetate, filter and clarify
with 1 vol of 1:1 chloroformbutanol then precipitate with 10% polyethylene
glycol and 1% NaCl. Purify by differential and sucrose gradient
centrifugation. (61) Virions <quasi> bacilliform. (65) Virions 37, 43, 48, and
55 nm in length. (71) Virions 26 nm wide. (76) Two sedimenting components in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 82 S.
(78) Of the other(s) 77 S. (79) Density 1.36 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.58. (84) Virions contain <c.> 19 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 81 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 10.65 kb. (92) Genome of four parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 3.3 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.8 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.45 kb.
(96) The 4th largest 2.1 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 33773. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X76993 Em(40)_vi:OLV212 Gb(84)_vi:OLV212 Olive
latent virus 2 genomic RNA-3. 2/94 2,438bp. X77115 Em(40)_vi:OLV2RNA4
Gb(84)_vi:OLV2RNA4 Olive latent virus 2 genomic RNA-4. 2/94 2,078bp. 2
sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 24000. (134) Coat protein.
(171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes:
major cell organelles, except for nuclei, are affected, there are more
cytoplasmic membranes and tonoplast-associated membranous vesicles. (179)
<Possible> ourmiavirus. (184) Olive latent 2 seems not to be an ilarvirus or
related to alfalfa mosaic virus. It shares most properties with pelargonium
zonate spot, epirus cherry, cassava Ivorian bacilliform and melon Ourmia
viruses, and hence is probably an ourmiavirus. (187) Castellano, M.A., Di
Franco, A. and Martelli, G.P. (1987). J. Submicrosc. Cytol. 19: 495. Grieco,
F., Martelli, G.P., Savino, V. and Piazzolla, P. (1992). Riv. Pat. Veg.,S.V.
2: 125. Savino, V., Piazzolla, P., Di Franco, A. and Martelli, G.P. (1984).
5th Congr. Un. Phytopath. Medit. Cairo, Egypt.


Onion mite-borne latent (?) potexvirus

      (1) P. van Dijk, 1991. (4) Strains: garlic strain. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.D.07. (8) First reported in Allium cepa var. ascalonicum. (9) From
the Netherlands. (10) By Van Dijk et al. (1991). (11) Symptoms persist, or
none. (12) Symptoms slight mottling or diffuse yellow stripes. (13) Allium
cepa, A. cepa var. ascalonicum usually symptomless, sometimes slight mottle.
More virulent isolates induce diffuse yellow striping. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by Aceria tulipae. (19)
Transmitted by Eriophyidae. (24) Not transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus
(Sciamyzus) ascalonicus, M. persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Van
Dijk (1991): vegetative propagation of the most important hosts, latent
infection and omnipresence and abundance of the vector imply that the virus is
readily spread and that it is difficult to control. For information on
abundance of A. tulipae on onion in the former U.S.S.R., see Cheremushkina
(1982). (39) Spreads in France, the Netherlands, Spain, and the former USSR.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show symptomless or show chlorotic local lesions. (43) Allium cepa, A. cepa
var. ascalonicum, A. porrum, A. chinense, A. vineale symptomless systemic
infection. Atriplex hortensis, Chenopodium murale chlorotic local lesions.
Nicotiana occidentalis symptomless systemic infection. (44) Allium fistulosum,
A. schoenoprasum, A. tuberosum, Amaranthus bicolor, Chenopodium quinoa. (45)
Allium cepa, A. cepa var. ascalonicum, A. vineale, Chenopodium murale. (46)
Allium vineale (W), Atriplex hortensis (L), Chenopodium murale (L). (47)
Allium cepa, or Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium chinense, or Allium
porrum, or Allium vineale, or Atriplex hortensis, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
occidentalis. (48) Allium fistulosum, or Allium schoenoprasum, or Allium
tuberosum, or Amaranthus bicolor, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Celosia argentea,
or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chlorophytum comosum, or
Lilium formosanum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana hesperis, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (50) Alliaceae
<5/8>, or Amaranthaceae <1/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Solanaceae <1/3>.
(51) Alliaceae <3/8>, or Amaranthaceae <3/4>, or Anthericaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Liliaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <2/3>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Van Dijk et al. (1991).
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 775 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D11159 Em(40)_vi:GVCCP1
Gb(84)_vi:GVCCP Garlic virus C gene for coat protein, complete cds. 10/92
1,372bp. D49443 Gb(89)_vi:Gmvcp Garlic mite-borne mosaic virus gene for coat
protein. 3/95 2,518bp. L38892 Em(43)_vi:Jgvfra Gb(89)_vi:Jgvfra Mite-Born
Filamentous Virus (UK garlic isolate) genomic RNA, 3' clip. 2/95 2,756bp.
D11157 Em(40)_vi:GVACP1 Gb(84)_vi:GVACP Garlic virus A gene for coat protein,
complete cds. 10/92 2,962bp. D11158 Em(40)_vi:GVBCP1 Gb(84)_vi:GVBCP Garlic
virus B gene for coat protein, complete cds. 10/92 3,047bp. D11160
Em(40)_vi:GVDCP1 Gb(84)_vi:GVDCP Garlic virus D gene for coat protein,
complete cds. 10/92 2,071bp. D28590 Em(43)_vi:Gv2cpa Gb(89)_vi:Gv2cpa Garlic
virus 2 RNA for polyprotein precursor, nuclear inclusion protein b and coat
protein. 1 D28591 Em(43)_vi:Gv1cpb Gb(89)_vi:Gv1cpb Garlic virus 1 RNA for
ORF, coat protein and 3'ORF for a 14.2kDa putative protein. 12/94. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Are granular inclusion bodies
resembling those of potyviruses. (179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: shallot mite-borne latent virus, but
distantly. (183) The garlic strain differs from the type strain by not
infecting onion, shallot and rakkyo, and in infecting garlic and sand leek.
The garlic strain is also found in other countries including Chile, China,
Iran, Japan, Morocco, Phillipines and Syria. Its virion length is 716 nm.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: induction of local lesions in Chenopodium
murale and not in C. quinoa; virions in the electron microscope are clearly
more flexuous than those of poty and carlaviruses; no decoration of virions
with antisera to poty or carlaviruses (if raised to uncontaminated virus
cultures). (186) The onion mosaic virus reported from the former Russia
(Cheremushkina, 1982; Razvjazkina, 1971) was probably a mixture of onion
mite-borne latent virus, shallot mite-borne latent virus and onion yellow
dwarf virus (Van Dijk et al., 1991). Similarly the garlic yellow streak virus
(Mohamed and Young, 1981) of Australasia is also probably a complex of these
viruses. Shallot X virus is probably also one or more components of this
complex (Van Dijk and van der Vlugt, 1994). An antiserum to a German garlic
latent virus contained antibodies to the garlic strain of onion mite-borne
latent virus (Van Dijk et al., 1991). (187) Cheremushkina, N.P. (1982). Trudy
po Selektsii i Semenovodstvu Ovoshchnyak Kultur 15: 74. Mohamed, N.A. and
Young, B.R. (1981). Ann. appl. Biol. 97: 65. Razvjazkina, G.M. (1971). Tag.
Akad. Landw. D.D.R 115: 69. Van Dijk, P. and van der Vlugt, R.A.A. (1994).
Eur. J. Pl. Path. 100: 269. Van Dijk, P., Verbeek, M. and Bos, L. (1991).
Neth. J. Pl. Path. 97: 381.


Onion yellow dwarf potyvirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1985. (2) Synonyms: allium virus 1. (3) Standard acronym:
OYDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.043. (8) First reported in Allium cepa.
(9) From Iowa, U.S.A. and Wageningen, the Netherlands. (10) By Melhus et al.
(1929); Bos et al. (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Allium cepa leaf
striping and curling, stunting ("yellow dwarf"). Allium cepa var. ascalonicum
leaf striping and curling, stunting. Allium (ornamental spp.) symptoms
variable. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae and several other species. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Allium cepa systemic leaf striping and curling. (44) Allium
porrum, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii.
(45) Allium cepa. (46) Allium cepa (W). (47) Allium, or Allium cepa, or Allium
cepa var. ascalonicum. (48) Allium porrum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon. (50)
Alliaceae <3/4>. (51) Alliaceae <1/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae
<2/2>. (52) Earlier reports that onion yellow dwarf virus infects Chinese
sacred lily (Narcissus tazetta) and jonquil (Narcissus jonquilla) (Anon.,
1932; Henderson, 1935) have not been confirmed (Bos, 1982). (53) Bos et al.
(1978). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 2-3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Huttinga (1975). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 772 and 823 nm <Schmidt
and Schmelzer, 1978)>. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 143 S. (79) Density 1.306 g cm3 in CsCl. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
43130. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L28079 Em(40)_vi:PTWPARD
Gb(84)_vi:PTWPARD Shallot potyvirus (probably onion yellow dwarf virus)
protease gene, partial cds, RNA-dep polmerase 1 sequence. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000. (145) Method of preparation: Huttinga and
Mosch (1974). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
amorphous Xbodies <and granular>. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: leek yellow
stripe virus, but distantly. (184) Onion yellow dwarf virus infects poorly, or
with difficulty, Allium porrum (leek); leek yellow stripe virus does not
infect or infects onion (Allium cepa) and shallot (Allium cepa var.
ascalonicum) with difficulty. (187) Anon. (1932). Rep. Iowa Agric. Exp. Stn
1932: 32. Bos, L. (1976). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 158, 4 pp. Bos, L.,
Huijberts, N., Huttinga, H.L. and Maat, D.Z. (1978). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 84:
105. Bos, L. (1982). Acta Hort. 12: 11. Henderson, R.G. (1935). Res. Bull.
Iowa Agric. Exp. Stn 188: 209. Huttinga, H. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81: 81.
Huttinga, H. and Mosch, W.H.M. (1974). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 80: 19. Melhus,
I.E., Reddy, C.S., Henderson, W.J. and Vestal, E.F. (1929). Phytopathology 19:
73. Schmidt, H.E. and Schmelzer, K. (1964). Phytopath. Z. 50: 19.


Ononis yellow mosaic tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1982. Revised 1985. (3) Standard acronym: OYMV. (5) ICTV

U.K. (10) By Gibbs et al. (1966). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Ononis repens

vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not

Solanaceae <3/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or

in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179)

mottle is closely related; belladonna mottle and dulcamara mottle more
