Opuntia Sammons' tobamovirus

      (1) C. Wetter, 1989. (2) Synonyms: Sammons' opuntia virus. (3) Standard
acronym: SOV. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in
Opuntia engelmannii. (9) From Arizona, U.S.A. (10) By Sammons and Chessin
(1961). (13) Opuntia engelmannii and some other species of Opuntia
symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C.
murale, C. amaranticolor local lesions; not systemic. (45) Chenopodium quinoa,
C. murale, C. amaranticolor. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. murale (L), C.
amaranticolor (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Opuntia engelmannii. (50) Cactaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>. (53) Wetter and Paul (1967). (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Wetter: clarify with chloroformbutanol (1:1 v/v),
precipitate with 4% polyethylene glycol and 4% NaCl, resuspend and subject to
several cycles of differential centrifugation. (61) Virions rodshaped. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 317 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 196 S. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.33. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: odontoglossum ringspot, tomato mosaic, tobacco mosaic, ribgrass
mosaic, tobacco mild green mosaic, pepper mild mottle, sunn-hemp mosaic,
frangipani mosaic and cucumber green mottle mosaic viruses. (187) Brandes, J.
and Chessin, M. (1965). Virology 25: 673. Sammons, I.M. and Chessin, M.
(1961). Nature, Lond. 191: 517. Wetter, C. and Paul, H.L. (1967). Phytopath.
Z. 60: 92.


Orchid fleck (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) D.-E. Lesemann, 1986. (2) Synonyms: dendrobium leaf streak virus,
dendrobium virus, probably laelia red leafspot, short orchid rhabdovirus,
orchid rhabdovirus, phalaenopsis chlorotic spot virus, phalaenopsis hybrid
virus, phalaenopsis virus. (3) Standard acronym: OFV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.036. (8) First reported in Cymbidium spp. (9) From Japan. (10) By Doi
et al. (1969); Chang et al. (1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cymbidium
alexanderi chlorotic or necrotic flecks. Phalaenopsis spp. and hybrids
chlorotic flecks. Renanthera spp. chlorotic flecks, then sunken gray necrotic
streaks with sharp margins and of variable size. Coelogyne spp., Dendrobium
spp. (and hybrids), Miltonia spp., Odontoglossum spp., Oncidium spp. and
Paphiopedilum spp. chlorotic areas often with necrotic centres or rings. Vanda
spp. irregular chlorotic areas. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed <some isolates infect better
above 30°C>. (39) Spreads in Australia, Brazil, Germany, Japan, and the USA
<Lesemann and Doraiswamy, 1975; Kitajima et al., 1974>. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in New Zealand. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Dendrobium nobile, Cymbidium alexanderi systemic chlorotic
or necrotic spots or flecks. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cvs Bright
Yellows, White Burley, Xanthi-nc and KY-57 chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, no systemic symptoms. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions.
Vicia faba brown necrotic local lesions. (45) Cymbidium alexanderi. (46)
Nicotiana glutinosa (L), Nicotiana tabacum (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coelogyne, or Cymbidium
alexanderi, or Dendrobium nobile, or Miltonia, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Odontoglossum, or Oncidium, or
Paphiopedilum, or Phalaenopsis, or Renanthera, or Vanda, or Vicia faba. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Orchidaceae
<10/10>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (55) LIV: 1 days <at 6°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions, or contains many virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: for negative staining, mount sap in 2% AM pH 6.5. Virions appear
smaller (32-35 × 100140 nm) in leaf sections. (60) Method: Chang et al.
(1976). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped <or
rarely enveloped>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
105-150 nm. (71) Virions 40-50 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial
canal <c.> 15 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic
helix 4.5 nm <Chang et al., 1976>. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in nuclei <where virions are commonly found to attach by one end
to the inner nuclear membrane (Chang et al., 1976) or endoplasmic reticulum>.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms
and crystals in the nucleus <Chang et al., 1976; Lesemann and Doraiswamy,
1975>. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: virions
attached to the periphery of the nucleus. (179) Unassigned rhabdovirus. (180)
: Rhabdoviridae. (184) The virions of orchid fleck virus resemble those of
plant rhabdoviruses, but are smaller, lack an outer envelope, and are still
infective after treatment with detergents (e.g. Triton X-100), thus they may
be equivalent to the internal component of rhabdovirus virions. In virion
morphology and intracellular effects, orchid fleck virus closely resembles
coffee ringspot (Kitajima and Costa, 1972) and citrus leprosis viruses
(Kitajima et al., 1972). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Electron microscopy
will distinguish orchid fleck virus from cymbidium mosaic, odontoglossum
ringspot and other orchid viruses. (187) Chang, M.U., Arai, K., Doi, Y. and
Yora, K. (1973). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 39: 171. Chang, M.U., Arai, K.,
Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1976). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 42: 156. Doi, Y.,
Chang, M.U. and Yora, K. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 183, 3 pp.
Doi, Y., Toriyama, S., Yora, K. and Asuyama, H. (1969). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 35: 388. Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S. (1972). Cienc. Cult. 24: 542.
Kitajima, E.W., Müller, G.W., Costa, A.S. and Yuki, W. (1972). Virology 50:
254. Kitajima, E.W., Blumenschein, A. and Costa, A.S. (1974). Phytopath. Z.
81: 280. Lesemann, D.-E. and Begtrup, J. (1971). Phytopath. Z. 71: 257.
Lesemann, D.-E. and Doraiswamy, S. (1975). Phytopath. Z. 83: 27. Petzold, H.
(1971). Phytopath. Z. 70: 45.


Ornithogalum mosaic potyvirus

      (1) J.T. Burger, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: OrMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.044. (8) First reported in Ornithogalum thyrsoides. (9) From
Oklahoma, U.S.A. (10) By Smith and Brierley (1944a). (11) Symptoms persist.
(12) Symptoms mottling, mosaic and sunken areas. (13) Ornithogalum spp. and
hybrids mottling of leaves and stems, flowers deformed. Lachenalia spp. and
hybrids mosaic or mottling of leaves and flower stems; flowers deformed. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in the Netherlands, South Africa, and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show mottling, mosaic
and sunken areas in leaves. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Nicotiana clevelandii (Derks et al., 1983). (44) Nicotiana
spp., Pisum sativum, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris, Chenopodium spp.
(45) Ornithogalum spp. and hybrids, Lachenalia spp. and hybrids. (46)
Ornithogalum spp. (W), Lachenalia spp. (W). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or
Lachenalia, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Ornithogalum thyrsoides, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Iris
germanica, or Lilium longiflorum, or Narcissus jonquilla, or Nerine bowdenii,
or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/6>, or Hyacinthaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <1/4>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Amaryllidaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/4>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Derks and Vink-van den Abeele (1980); Dercks et al.
(1983); Burger and Von Wechmar (1989). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(59) Electron microscopy: elimination of mucilage in plant sap before electron
microscopy. (60) Method: Burger and Von Wechmar (1989). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 740 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size <±> 10 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <±> 10 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Burger and Von Wechmar (1989). (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A
region the genome has a polyadenylated 3'terminal tail. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Accession number: D00615. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12204.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00615 Em(40)_vi:OMNIAB
Gb(84)_vi:OMVNIAB Ornithogalum mosaic virus genomic RNA for nuclear inclusion
protein (NIa, NIb) and coat protein 1 sequence. (119) Features of the genome:
single ± 10 kb open reading frame. Sequence of CP, NIb and NIa has been
determined. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000. (134) It is coat
protein and its function is structural. (145) Method of preparation: Burger
and Von Wechmar (1989). (147) Amino acid composition: Burger et al. (1990).
(171) Virions found in leaves and probably all parts of the host plant. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic, potato Y, hyacinth mosaic,
zucchini yellow mosaic and passionfruit woodiness viruses. (184) There are
strong sequence homologies with most sequenced potyviruses (Burger et al.,
1990). (187) Burger, J.T. and Von Wechmar, M.B. (1988). Acta Hort. 234: 31.
Burger, J.T. and Von Wechmar, M.B. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 385. Burger,
J.T., Brand, R.J. and Rybicki, E.P. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 2527. Derks,
A.F.L.M. and Vink-van den Abeele, J.L. (1980). Acta Hort. 109: 495. Derks,
A.F.L.M., Vink-van den Abeele, J.L. and Hollinger Th. C. (1983). Jversl. Lab.
Bloemboll. Lisse, 1982: 61. Smith, F.F. and Brierley, P. (1944a).
Phytopathology 34: 497. Smith, F.F. and Brierley, P. (1944b). Phytopathology
34: 593.


Palm mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Molyneux, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PalMV. (5)

(9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Mayhew and Tidwell (1978). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Washingtonia robusta mosaic, ringspot and line patterns,
stunting. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads
in the USA. (47) Washingtonia robusta. (50) Palmae <1/1>. (61) Virions
filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 686 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain

and Tidwell (1978). Pl. Dis. Reptr 62: 803.


Pangola stunt fijivirus

      (1) R.G. Milne, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: PaSV. (5) ICTV decimal code
60.0.7.2.002. (8) First reported in Digitaria decumbens. (9) From Surinam.
(10) By Dirven and van Hoof (1960). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Digitaria
decumbens chlorosis and reddening, leaves and flower heads malformed, curled
and stunted, small veins swollen. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Sogatella furcifera. (18)
Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Australia, Brazil, Fiji, Guyana, Peru, and Taiwan. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Almost all Digitaria spp. are susceptible. D. decumbens PI
111110, D. longiflora PI 299642, D. pentzii PI 299769, D. setivalvola PI
299795, D. valida PI 299875 stunting, yellowing and twisting of leaves and
inflorescences, small veins swollen, excessive tillering. (45) Digitaria
decumbens and other Digitaria spp. (46) Digitaria decumbens (W). (47)
Digitaria decumbens, or Digitaria longiflora <PI 299642>, or Digitaria pentzii
<PI 299769>, or Digitaria setivalvola <PI 299795>, or Digitaria valida <PI
299875>. (50) Gramineae <5/5>. (53) Hunkar et al. (1974); Milne and Lovisolo
(1977). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <when prepared from whole leaves>,
or contains many virions <when prepared only from enations>. (59) Electron
microscopy: to obtain complete or subvirions with intact spikes, use 2%
aqueous UA not neutral PTA. (60) Method: Boccardo et al. (1979). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <complete virions
including spikes> 70 nm in diameter <when negative stained and in thin
section>. (66) Virions rounded in profile, or angular in profile. (67) Virions
with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in
purified preparations <virions and spiked subvirions>. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 25.188 kb. (92)
Genome of 10 parts <called S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the
largest> 3.405 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.385 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 3.385
kb. (96) The 4th largest 2.6 kb. (97) The 5th largest 2.55 kb. (98) The 6th
largest and other parts 2.49 kb <pairs; also 2.190, 1.735, 1.728 and 1.720 kb
pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Boccardo et al. (1979). (112)
Additional factor required for infectivity <only complete virions are
infective>. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132)
Virion protein(s) <virion proteins probably similar in size to those of maize
rough dwarf virus>. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasmic viroplasms. (165)
Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem and phloem derived
enations. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, viroplasms,
and unusual in shape. (176) Tubular structures 100 nm in diameter. (177) They
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: thickening of cell walls and
cell enlargement. (179) Fijivirus: Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: maize rough dwarf and rice black
streaked dwarf viruses and are closely related. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: oat sterile dwarf, sugarcane Fiji disease,
rice dwarf, rice gall dwarf, rice ragged stunt and clover wound tumor viruses.
(187) Boccardo, G. and Milne, R.G. (1981). J. virol. Meth. 3: 109. Boccardo,
G. and Milne, R.G. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 294, 7 pp. Boccardo,
G., Milne, R.G. and Luisoni, E. (1979). J. gen. Virol. 45: 659. Conti, M.
(1984). Current Topics in Vector Research; ed. K.F. Harris. Praeger
Scientific, New York. Dirven, J.G.P. and van Hoof, E.M. (1960). Tijdsch.
PlZiekt. 66: 344. Giannotti, J. and Milne, R.G. (1977). Virology 80: 347.
Hunkar, A.E.S., Hung, A.T.A., Dulder, I.G., Schank, S.C., Holder, N. and
Edwards, C. (1974). Trop. Agric. 52: 75. Milne, R.G. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 175, 4 pp. Milne, R.G. and Lovisolo, O. (1977). Adv. Virus
Res. 21: 267. Milne, R.G. and Luisoni, E. (1977). Virology 80: 12.

Panicum mosaic (?) sobemovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, A.O. Jackson and C.L. Niblett, 1988, Updated by A.A.
Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: St. Augustine decline virus. (3) Standard acronym:
PMV. (4) Strains: Type strain (TS) and St. Augustine decline virus (SAD),
probably molinia streak virus (Paul et al., 1980; Hull, 1988). (5) ICTV
decimal code 67.0.1.T.017. (8) First reported in Panicum virgatum. (9) From
Kansas, U.S.A. (10) By Sill and Pickett (1957). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Panicum virgatum faint chlorosis. Eremochloa ophiuroides chlorotic leaf spots
and blotches. Muhlenbergia schreberi leaf chlorosis. (15) Transmitted on
cutting shears. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <SAD>, or not transmitted by seed <TS>. (39) Spreads in
Mexico and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Zea mays inbred
lines Ohio 28 and N28 mild systemic mosaic (type strain only). Stenotaphrum
secundatum systemic chlorotic mottling (St. Augustine decline strain only).
Avena sativa, Secale cereale, Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum, Sorghum
bicolor chlorotic local lesions. (44) Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris,
Cucumis sativus, Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Zea mays
inbred line N28 (type strain), Stenotaphrum secundatum (St. Augustine decline
strain). (46) Panicum miliaceum (W), Setaria italica (W). (47) Avena sativa,
or Eremochloa ophiuroides, or Hordeum vulgare, or Muhlenbergia schreberi, or
Panicum dichotomiflorum, or Panicum miliaceum, or Panicum virgatum, or Secale
cereale, or Setaria italica, or Sorghum bicolor, or Stenotaphrum secundatum
<St. Augustine decline strain>, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum, or
Zea mays. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var.
capitata, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or

Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima,

stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago
sativa, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa,
or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or

12 /12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (53) McCoy et al.

one. (133) Mr 29000. (134) Coat protein. (168) Acts as helper for a satellite
virus <with which it is often found. This satellite virus has virions 15-18 nm
in diameter which sediment as one component of 42 S and contain two ssRNAs (14
S and 34 S) and a single polypeptide (Mr 15500)>. (171) Virions found in
leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected

virions. (178) Other cellular changes: disruption of mitochondria and
tonoplast. (179) Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related

Panicum streak monogeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: Panicum strain of maize streak virus

insect_transmissible DNA. 6/92 2,700bp. L39638 Em(43)_vi:Parpakcg

2,705bp. (119) Features of the genome: 5 ORFs. (179) Monogeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: Maize streak and sugarcane streak viruses. (184) The coat
protein has clear sequence homologies (46-82% identity) with those of other
monogeminiviruses. (187) Briddon, R.W., Luness, P. Chamberlin, L.C.L., Pinner,
M.S., Brandish, H. and Markham, P.G. (1992). J. gen. Virol. 73: 1041. Bock,
K.R., Guthrie, E.J. and Woods, R.D. (1974). Ann. appl. Biol. 77: 289. Pinner,

Papaya mosaic potexvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987 and E. Hiebert, 1988. (2) Synonyms: babaco
yellow mosaic virus (Barba and Giordano, 1989), boussingaultia mosaic virus
(Beczner and Vassanyi, 1980; Phillips et al., 1985), papaw mild mosaic virus.
(3) Standard acronym: PapMV. (4) Strains: Argentine plantago virus (Gracia et
al., 1983; Milne, 1988), plantago severe mottle virus (Gracia et al., 1983;
Milne, 1988; Rowhani and Peterson, 1980). (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.013.
(8) First reported in Carica papaya. (10) By Conover (1962; 1964b); de Bokx
(1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Carica papaya mosaic and stunting. Ullucus
tuberosus symptomless infection. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a
vector <Conover, 1964b; Zettler et al., 1968>. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Bolivia, Peru, the USA, and Venezuela. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Carica papaya systemic vein-clearing and downward curling of
leaves, then mottle or mosaic. Gomphrena globosa chlorotic local lesions,
becoming necrotic with red margins; not systemic. Chenopodium amaranticolor
chlorotic local lesions, not systemic. Cassia occidentalis necrotic local
lesions, not systemic. (45) Carica papaya, Antirrhinum majus. (46) Gomphrena
globosa (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Carica papaya, or Cassia occidentalis,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Gomphrena globosa, or Ullucus tuberosus. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Basellaceae <1/1>, or Caricaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>. (53) Conover (1962; 1964b); Cook and Zettler (1970).
(54) TIP: 73-76 °C <in papaya sap; Conover, 1964b>. (55) LIV: 180 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Hiebert
(1970); Koenig et al. (1970). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 530 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 118.7 S. (82) Isoelectric point
pH 5.3. (84) Virions contain 7 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 93 % protein. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 6.656 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
6.656 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Koenig (1971). (100) Base
composition 20.7 % G. (101) Base composition 33.8 % A. (102) Base composition
23.4 % C. (103) Base composition 22.1 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has an
unusual type <Abouhaidar and Bancroft, 1978>. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (111)
Poly A region a poly A tail (Abouhaidar, 1988). (112) Additional factor not
required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12181. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): D00240 Em(40)_vi:PMPCP Gb(84)_vi:PMPCP Papaya mosaic
potexvirus (PMV), capsid protein gene, complete cds. 1/93 900bp. D00580
Em(40)_vi:URNA Papaya mosaic virus genome, complete sequence. 1/93 6,656bp.
D13957 Em(40)_vi:PMPRNA Gb(84)_vi:PMPRNA Papaya mosaic virus genome, complete
sequence. 1/93 6,656bp M35054 Em(40)_vi:PMP5END Gb(84)_vi:PMP5END Papaya
mosaic virus, 5' end. 1/93 139bp. M75794 Em(40)_est:CE02C6 C.elegans cDNA
clone cm02c6 encoding hypothetical 176K protein Papaya mosaic virus homologo 5
sequences. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (124) Coat protein
(Mackie and Bancroft, 1986). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 22930.
(145) Method of preparation: Koenig et al. (1970). (146) Amino acid sequence:
Abouhaidar (1988). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells <Zettler et al., 1968;
Purcifull et al., 1966; Christie and Edwardson, 1977>. (177) <Virions
aggregated in banded inclusion bodies> they contain virions <Christie and
Edwardson, 1977>. (179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: clover yellow mosaic virus, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: potato X virus (Koenig and Lesemann, 1978;
Lesemann and Koenig, 1977). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: several serious
mosaic diseases limit papaya production in various parts of the world,
including India, Puerto Rico, South America, Hawaii and Florida. Some are,
like papaya mosaic, sap-transmissible, but differ in being aphid-borne and
restricted in host range to papaya and cucurbits (Capoor and Varma, 1958;
Conover, 1964a; Ishii and Holtzmann, 1963; Herold and Weibel, 1962); the best
known is papaya ringspot, a typical potyvirus (Purcifull et al., 1984; Zettler
et al., 1968). (187) Abouhaidar, M. (1988). J. gen. Virol. 69: 219.
Abouhaidar, M. and Bancroft, J.B. (1978). J. gen. Virol. 39: 559. Barba, M.
and Giordano, P. (1989). Inform. Fitopatol. 39: 58. Beczner, I. and Vassanyi,
R. (1980). Tag. Ber. Akad. Land. Wiss, DDR, Berlin 184: 65. Brunt, A.A.,
Phillips, S., Jones, R.A.C. and Kenten, R.H. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 65.
Capoor, S.P. and Varma, P.M. (1958). Indian J. agric. Sci. 28: 225. Christie,
R.G. and Edwardson, J.R. (1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 9, 150 pp.
Conover, R.A. (1962). Phytopathology 52: 6. Conover, R.A. (1964a). Proc. Fla

444. Cook, A.A. and Zettler, F.W. (1970). Pl. Dis. Reptr 54: 893. de Bokx,

Papaya ringspot potyvirus

      (1) D.E. Purcifull, J.R. Edwardson, E. Hiebert and D. Gonsalves, 1986.
(2) Synonyms: papaya distortion mosaic virus, papaya leaf distortion virus,
papaw distortion ringspot virus, papaw mosaic virus, watermelon mosaic virus
1. (3) Standard acronym: PRSV. (4) Strains: type P, Guadeloupe papaya
ringspot, papaya ringspot type W has been shown to be watermelon mosaic virus
1 potyvirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.045. (8) First reported in Carica
papaya. (10) By Jensen (1949a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Carica papaya
mottling and malformation of leaves, ringspots and streaking on fruit, stems
and petioles, plants stunted with less fruit (Conover, 1964a; Jensen, 1949a).
Symptoms severe in cool weather (Jensen, 1949a; Conover, 1964a; Lima and
Gomes, 1975). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae (Jensen, 1949b; Conover, 1964a; Zettler et
al., 1968) and Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (30) Amorphous inclusion protein (AI) is required
as the helper component for transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the Middle
East and the South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in China, France,
Germany, India, Italy, Mexico, Taiwan, and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Carica papaya symptoms variable; vein clearing then mottled
and malformed leaves with smaller lobes (Conover, 1964a, 1964b). Cucurbita
pepo some isolates give mosaic and leaf malformation but others induce mild
mottle (Gonsalves and Ishii, 1980). Cucumis metuliferus cv. Accession 2459
systemic mottling or mosaic. (44) Cucumis metuliferus plant introduction PI
292190, Nicotiana benthamiana. (45) Carica papaya, Cucurbita pepo and Cucumis
metuliferus cv. Accession 2459. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L),
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Cucurbita pepo (W). (47) Carica papaya, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis metuliferus
<cv. Accession 2459>, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita
moschata, or Cucurbita pepo. (48) Carica papaya, or Cucumis metuliferus, or
Myosotis sylvatica, or Nicotiana benthamiana. (50) Caricaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <6/6>. (51) Boraginaceae <1/1>, or
Caricaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/6>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Jensen
(1949a); Conover (1964a); Wang et al. (1978); Milne and Grogan (1969);
Purcifull and Hiebert (1979); Yeh et al. (1984). (54) TIP: 54-60 °C. (55) LIV:
0.3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60)
Method: Gonsalves and Ishii (1980), see CMI/AAB description No. 292. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760-800 nm.
(71) Virions 12 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5.5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94.5 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 12 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 12 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Brakke and van Pelt (1970); de Mejia (1984); Hiebert et al.
(1984); de Mejia et al. (1984). (107) 5' terminus of RNA probably a
genome-linked protein (VPg). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12205. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): D00594 Em(40)_vi:PRVW Gb(84)_vi:PAYW Papaya
ringspot virus nuclear inclusion protein (NIb protein) gene, coat protein gene
and 3' D00595 Em(40)_vi:PRVP Gb(84)_vi:PAYP Papaya ringspot virus nuclear
inclusion protein (NIb protein) gene, coat protein gene and 3' S46722

(1980); Baum (1980). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Yeh (1984),
for cylindrical (pinwheel) inclusions (CI) and by de Mejia (1984), for

largest> 69000-70000. (155) CI non virion protein. (156) Mr of 2nd largest
51000. (157) AI, helper protein in aphid transmission. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host
plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies and
pinwheels <i.e. scrolls (Edwardson's type 1 inclusions)>. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: the Guadeloupe isolate of PRV
(Quiot-Douine et al., 1986) is very closely related, but distinct. PRV
antisera react with the D-protein of tobacco etch virus (Shepard et al., 1974)
and the virion proteins and CI proteins of a potyvirus isolate from cucurbits
in Morocco (Fischer and Lockhart, 1974). (183) PRV type P infects papaya and
cucurbits, but watermelon mosaic virus 1 (PRV-W) infects cucurbits, but not
papaya. Analysis of the coat protein genes of isolates from Australia,
Thailand and the U.S.A. indicates that, in each country, papaya ringspot P
isolates have evolved independently from local watermelon mosaic virus 1
isolates (Bateson et al., 1994). (187) Bateson, M.F., Henderson, J.,
Chaleeprom, W., Gibbs, A.J. and Dale, J.L. (1994). J. gen. Virol. 75: 3547.

Purcifull, D.E. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 202. Brakke, M.K. and van Pelt, N.
(1970). Virology 42: 699. Conover, R.A. (1964a). Proc. Fla St. hort. Soc. 77:
440. Conover, R.A. (1964b). Proc. Fla St. hort. Soc. 77: 444. de Mejia, M.V.G.
(1984). Ph.D. Thesis, Univ. of Florida, 52 pp. de Mejia, M.V.G., Hiebert, E.
and Purcifull, D.E. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1015. de Mejia, M.V.G.,
Hiebert, E. and Purcifull, D.E. (1985). Virology 142: 24,34. Edwardson, J.R.

Paprika mild mottle tobamovirus

      (1) J.R. Diaz-Ruiz, I. Garcia Luque and M.T. Serra, 1992. (2) Synonyms:
tobacco mosaic virus P11 pepper isolate. (3) Standard acronym: PaMMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 71.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From the
Netherlands. (10) By Rast (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Capsicum annuum
mild mosaic. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
<possibly> transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39)
Spreads in the Netherlands. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show small chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, mosaic and stunting. (43) Capsicum spp. with either L+L+ or L1L1
genotypes mild mottle or mosaic. Nicotiana benthamiana mosaic, stunting.
Nicotiana clevelandii mosaic, malformation. Solanum pseudocapsicastrum mosaic.
(44) Lycopersicon esculentum. (45) Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana benthamiana and
N. clevelandii. (46) Capsicum annuum (W), C. frutescens (L), Nicotiana
clevelandii (W), N. sylvestris (L), N. tabacum cv Xanthi (L). (47) Capsicum
annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
pseudocapsicastrum, or Trifolium subterraneum. (48) Lycopersicon esculentum.
(50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10/11>. (51) Solanaceae
<1/11>. (53) Tobias et al. (1982). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61)
Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 6.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Alonso et al. (1991). (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35281. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X72586
Gb(84)_vi:PMMVCP Paprika mild mottle virus (Pepper strain P11) coat protein
gene and 3' non-coding region. 7/9. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
17706. (134) Coat protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179)
Tobamovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: tobacco and
tomato mosaic tobamoviruses. (187) Alonso, E., Garcia-Luque, I., de la Cruz,
A., Wicke, B., Avila-Ricón, M.J., Serra, M.T., Castresana, C. and Diaz-Ruiz,
J.R. (1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 2875. Garcia-Luque, I., Serra, M.T., Alonso,
E., Wicke, B., Ferrero, M.L. and Diaz-Ruiz, J.R. (1990). J. Phytopath. 129:1.
Rast, A.Th.B. (1976). Med. Fac. Landb. Rijksuniv. Ghent 44: 616. Tobias, I.,
Rast, A.Th.B. and Maat, D.Z. (1982). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 88: 257.


Parietaria mottle ilarvirus

      (1) P. Caciagli, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.2.10.01. (8) First reported in Parietaria officinalis. (9) From Torino,
Italy. (10) By Caciagli et al. (1989). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12)
Symptoms mosaic or mottling. (13) Parietaria officinalis bright yellow mosaic
or mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local
lesions and then mottle or leafroll in species of the Chenopodiaceae and
necrotic local lesions and necrotic patching in species of Solanaceae. (43)
Chenopodium album local lesions and systemic mottle. Chenopodium amaranticolor
local lesions and systemic leafroll. Chenopodium quinoa, Spinacia oleracea
systemic mottle and leaf malformation. Lycopersicon esculentum mosaic,
necrosis. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorosis, rosetting and mottle. Nicotiana
megalosiphon leaf malformation. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi necrotic etching;
systemic. Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley local lesions. Ocimum basilicum
necrotic etching. Tetragonia tetragonioides latent. (44) Amaranthus caudatus,
Cucumis sativus, Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Momordica balsamina, Nicotiana
glutinosa. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (46) Chenopodium murale
(L), C. quinoa (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (L), Vigna unguiculata cv. Black (W).

1.5 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (59) Electron microscopy: purification.

kb. (96) The 4th largest 1.1 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Boccardo and Milne (1975); Caciagli et al. (1989). (108) Infectivity retained
when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
24300. (145) Method of preparation: Francki et al. (1980). (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (174) Inclusions absent from infected
cells. (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 10>. (180) : Bromoviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple mosaic, hydrangea
mosaic, prune dwarf, spinach latent, tobacco streak and Tulare apple mosaic
viruses. (187) Boccardo, G. and Milne, R.G. (1975). Virology 68: 79. Caciagli,
P., Boccardo, G. and Lovisolo, O. (1989). Pl. Path. 38: 577. Francki, R.I.B.,
Hatta, T., Boccardo, G. and Randles, J.W. (1980). Virology 101: 233.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PaV-5. (5) ICTV decimal code

Parsley green mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.10. (8) First
reported in Petroselinum crispum. (9) From Italy. (10) By Angelis and
Quacquarelli (1974). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Petroselinum crispum green
mottling of leaves; the virus and a strain of chicory yellow mottle nepovirus
in complex together cause parsley bushy stunt disease. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
pisum, Aphis spiraecola, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Apium graveolens cv. Doré Barbier
conspicuous chlorosis in systemically infected leaves (infection is
symptomless in some other cultivars). Ammi majus transient systemic leaf
chlorosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions, general
chlorosis and/or vein yellowing. Petroselinum crispum mosaic, reduced laminae
and distortion of systemicallly infected leaves. Pimpinella anisum symptomless
systemic infection. (44) Beta vulgaris. (45) Petroselinum crispum, Apium
graveolens cv. Doré Barbier. (46) Petroselinum crispum (W), Apium graveolens
(W). (47) Ammi majus, or Apium graveolens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Pimpinella anisum. (48) Beta
vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Umbelliferae <4/4>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>. (54) TIP: 53 °C. (55) LIV: 6 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Angelis and Quacquarelli
(1974). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 758 nm. (71) Virions 12-15 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (179) Unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: celery mosaic potyvirus. (187) Angelis, A. and Quacquarelli, A.
(1974). Phytopath. Medit. 13: 1.

Parsnip leafcurl virus

      (1) P. van Dijk, 1991. (2) Synonyms: hogweed 4 virus (Bem and Murant,
1979; Van Dijk and Bos, 1989). (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.29. (8) First
reported in Heracleum sphondylium. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Bem and Murant
(1979). (12) Symptoms chlorosis and curling of older leaves. (13) Pastinaca
sativa leaf chlorosis and curling. Heracleum sphondylium. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in the Netherlands. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread,
in the U.K. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show chlorotic to necrotic local lesions. (43) Ammi
majus local and systemic necrosis and chlorosis. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic
local lesions; systemic chlorotic spotting and malformation. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Montia
perfoliata, Spinacia oleracea latent. (44) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L and W). (47) Ammi majus, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or
Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Heracleum
sphondylium, or Montia perfoliata, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum
crispum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium
incarnatum. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Vicia faba, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <9/9>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/5>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <7/7>.
(51) Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/5>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<6/6>. (53) Bem and Murant (1979); Van Dijk and Bos (1989). (55) LIV:
0.18-0.75 days <318 hours>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions
isometric. (179) (Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Chenopodium
quinoa infected systemically, C. amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions only,
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba and Nicotiana clevelandii not infected. (187) Bem, F.
and Murant, A.F. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 92: 237. Van Dijk, P. and Bos, L.
(1989). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 95(2): 34.


Parsnip mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ParMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.046. (8) First reported in Pastinaca sativa. (9) From the U.K. in
Scotland. (10) By Murant and Munthe (1967). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection. (13) Pastinaca sativa mild mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Carvariella aegopodii, C.
theobaldi, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in
a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show veinal necrosis and local lesions.
(43) Anthriscus cerefolium, Bupleurum rotundifolium, Coriandrum sativum,
Daucus carota, Thaspium aureum, Trachymene pilosa systemic veinal necrosis.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Gomphrena globosa, Spinacia oleracea
local lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Beta vulgaris, Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, Cucumis melo, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45)
Chenopodium quinoa, Coriandrum sativum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L). (47) Anthriscus cerefolium, or Bupleurum rotundifolium, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Pastinaca sativa, or Spinacia oleracea, or Thaspium aureum, or Trachymene
pilosa. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura

clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida,

Trifolium pratense, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/8>, or Umbelliferae <7/8>. (51)
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/8>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae

55-58 °C. (55) LIV: 7-10 days <at 18°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (61)
Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear

sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
149 S. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, clover yellow vein,
cocksfoot streak, henbane mosaic, iris mild mosaic, lettuce mosaic, pea
mosaic, turnip mosaic, tulip breaking, potato Y and celery mosaic viruses.
(187) Murant, A.F. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 91, 4 pp. Murant,
A.F. and Goold, R.A. (1968). Ann. appl. Biol. 62: 123. Murant, A.F. and

Parsnip yellow fleck sequivirus

      (1) P. Jeyanandarajah, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: PYFV. (4) Strains:
serotypes P121 from Pastinaca sativa and A421 from Anthriscus cerefolium. (5)
ICTV decimal code 65.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Pastinaca sativa. (9)
From the U.K. (10) By Murant and Goold (1968). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms yellow flecks, mosaic, necrosis. (13) Pastinaca sativa, Heracleum
sphondylium chlorotic vein banding, yellow flecks and leaf mosaic. Anthriscus
sylvestris, Apium graveolens no conspicuous symptoms. Aethusa cynapium,
Anethum graveolens, Anthriscus cerefolium, Chaerophyllum temulum, Coriandrum
sativum, Daucus carota, Oenanthe aquatica, Torilis japonica leaf yellowing and
dieback (Anthriscus serotype). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Cavariella aegopodii, C. pastinacae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Cavariella theobaldii. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it
moults. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(29) Virus requires, for vector transmission, a helper virus <anthriscus
yellows waikavirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in Germany and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellow flecks, mosaic, distortion
of leaves, veinal necrosis, local chlorotic or necrotic spots or rings. (43)
Anthriscus cerefolium, Coriandrum sativum, Spinacia oleracea, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Petroselinum crispum, Chenopodium quinoa, Gomphrena globosa,
Montia perfoliata, Chenopodium amaranticolor yellow flecks, necrosis,
chlorotic and necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic local
lesions; systemic vein yellowing, chlorosis and tip necrosis (Anthriscus
serotype). (44) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, Foeniculum vulgare,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Verbesina encelioides, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Spinacia
oleracea and, for some isolates, Anthriscus cerefolium. (46) Anthriscus
cerefolium (W), Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Aethusa cynapium, or Anethum
graveolens, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or Anthriscus sylvestris, or Apium
graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Chaerophyllum temulum, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Heracleum sphondylium, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oenanthe
aquatica, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torilis japonica. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Foeniculum vulgare, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <9/9>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <13/14>.
(51) Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Umbelliferae <1/14>. (53) Murant and Goold (1968); Hemida and Murant
(1989). (54) TIP: 57.5-65 °C. (55) LIV: 4-7 days <at room temperature>. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (60) Method: Hemida and Murant (1989). (61) Virions
isometric. (64) Virions <c.> 31 nm in diameter. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 153 S <B>.
(78) Of the other(s) 60 S <T>. (79) Density 1.297 g cm3 in CsCl <T>, or 1.49 g
cm3 in CsCl <B>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.59 <B>, or 1.46 <T>. (84) Virions
contain 40 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(91) Total genome size 9.871 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 9.871 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12777. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): D14066 Em(40)_vi:PYFPOLYP Gb(84)_vi:PYFPOLYP
Parsnip yellow fleck virus (PYFV) RNA encoding polyprotein, complete cds. 2/93
9,871bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr 30900. (134) It
is coat protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 25500. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 22700.
(171) Virions found in mesophyll. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are membranous bodies. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Sequivirus: Sequiviridae <the type species>. (180) : Sequiviridae. (183)
Differ serologically and in host range. (187) Elnager, S. (1974). Ph. D.
Thesis, 168 pp. University of Dundee, U.K. Elnager, S. and Murant, A.F.

114: 87. Hemida, S.K. and Murant, A.F. (1989). Ann. appl. Biol. 114: 101.
Lennon, A.M. (1984). Ph. D. Thesis, 300 pp. University of Manchester, U.K.

Paspalum striate mosaic monogeminivirus

      (1) R.S. Greber, 1987. (2) Synonyms: paspalum geminivirus. (3) Standard
acronym: PSMV. (4) Strains: Paspalum (P) and Bromus (BC), also bromus striate
virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Paspalum
dilatatum. (10) By Slykhuis (1962). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Paspalum
conjugatum, P. dilatatum striations, then blotchy mottle. P. scrobiculatum
fine striations and notching of leaf margins, then blotchy mottle. Bromus
catharticus fine chlorotic striations. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nesoclutha pallida (obscura).
(18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation <only to the vector>.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in
Australia <New South Wales and Queensland>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Avena sativa striations, stunting, blotchy mottle. Chloris
gayana stunting, leaf margin notching. Dactyloctenium aegyptium striations,
curling. Hordeum vulgare striations, stunting, blotchy mottle. Leptochloa
filiformis severe stunting, curling. Paspalum dilatatum, P. conjugatum, P.
scrobiculatum striations, mottling. Triticum aestivum stunting, leaf notching,
blotchy mottle. Zea mays (sweet corn) pale striations. (44) Bromus
catharticus, Microlaena stipoides. (45) Triticum aestivum cv. Gatcher, for
propagation, Paspalum dilatatum for maintenance. (46) Triticum aestivum cv.
Gatcher (W), Paspalum dilatatum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Bromus catharticus,
or Chloris gayana, or Dactyloctenium aegyptium, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Leptochloa filiformis, or Paspalum conjugatum, or Paspalum dilatatum, or
Paspalum scrobiculatum, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Bromus
catharticus, or Microlaena stipoides. (50) Gramineae <11/12>. (51) Gramineae
<2/12>. (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 30
nm in length. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and vascular
parenchyma. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the nucleus. (177) They
contain virions. (179) Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: chloris striate mosaic,
digitaria streak and maize streak viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
Readily infects Paspalum dilatatum and is vector specific. (187) Francki,
R.I.B., Milne, R.G. and Hatta, T. (1985). In: Atlas of Plant Viruses Vol. I,
222 pp. C.R.C. Press Inc, Boca Raton. Grylls, N.E. (1963). Aust. J. agric.
Res. 14: 143. Grylls, N.E. (1979). In: Leafhopper, Vectors and Plant Disease
Agents, p. 179; ed. K. Maramorosch. Academic Press, New York. Greber, R.S.
(1984). In: Current Topics in Vector Research, Vol. 2, p. 141; ed. K.F.
Harris. Praeger Scientific, New York. Piner, M.S., Markham, P.G., Rybicki, E.
and Greber, R.S. (1992). Plant Path. 41: 618. Slykhuis, J.T. (1962). F.A.O.
Pl. Prot. Bull. 10: 1.

Passiflora ringspot potyvirus

      (1) J.C. Thouvenel, 1984. (2) Synonyms: passionfruit ringspot virus. (3)

minus 3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap increased by treatment with diethyl ether.

Passionfruit Sri Lankan mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) S.L. Bhattiprolu and A.A. Brunt, 1993. (3) Standard acronym: SLPMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.076. (8) First reported in Passiflora edulis
cv. flavicarpa. (9) From Sri Lanka. (10) By Dassanayake and Hicks (1992). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mottling. (13) Passiflora edulis cv.
flavicarpa leaf mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, A. spiraecola.
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus
does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to
the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Sri Lanka. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic/necrotic lesions,
chlorotic mottle/mosaic, leaf distortion, vein yellowing. (43) Cassia
occidentalis systemic chlorotic mottle, mosaic and vein yellowing. Chenopodium
album, C. amaranticolor, C. foetidum chlorotic local lesions only. Chenopodium
murale, C. quinoa chlorotic mottle and mosaic of inoculated leaves only.
Gomphrena globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata necrotic local
lesions only. Passiflora edulis cvs edulis and flavicarpa systemic chlorotic
mottle/mosaic with distortion (vein yellowing also in flavicarpa). P.
mollissima chlorotic mottle/mosaic and flecking, flower break. (44) Datura
stramonium, Glycine max, Nicotiana debneyi, N. tabacum, Passiflora suberosa,
Pisum sativum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Passiflora edulis cv. flavicarpa, P.
foetida. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Passiflora foetida (W). (47)
Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium

or Passiflora foetida, or Passiflora mollissima, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta
vulgaris, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or

Passiflora suberosa, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/7>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/6>, or
Passifloraceae <3/4>, or Solanaceae <2/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/7>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/6>, or Passifloraceae
<1/4>, or Solanaceae <4/6>. (53) Dassanayake and Hicks (1992). (54) TIP: 70-75
°C. (55) LIV: 6-7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Dassanayake and Hicks (1992). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 841 nm <+/- 4.6nm>. (71) Virions 13.1 nm

epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and pinwheels.

(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:

Passionfruit woodiness potyvirus

      (1) J.L. Dale, 1980. (2) Synonyms: passiflora chlorotic spot virus (Van
Velsen, 1961), passiflora mosaic virus, probably passionfruit mosaic virus
(Del Rosario et al., 1964; Martini, 1962; Ong and Ting, 1973). (3) Standard
acronym: PWV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.047. (8) First reported in
Passiflora edulis. (9) From Australia. (10) By Taylor et al. (1964). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Passiflora edulis, P. suberosa, P. subpeltata, P.
aurantia, P. foetida, Arachis hypogaea, Centrosema pubescens, Glycine max,
Macroptilium atropurpureum, Phaseolus vulgaris necrotic and chlorotic local
lesions or streaks, mottling, rugosity. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the South
and Central American region. (39) Spreads in Australia and Brazil. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in New Zealand. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Macrotyloma uniflorum large reddish-brown local lesions;
systemic necrotic spots, vein necrosis in upper leaves, stem and petiole
necrosis, premature death. Macroptilium lathyroides necrotic or chlorotic
local lesions; systemic vein necrosis in upper leaves, leaf fall, bud blight.
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful necrotic or chlorotic local lesions, then
systemic mosaic and necrosis along veins. Passiflora edulis, P. suberosa
systemic vein clearing, rugosity, mottle. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs
Bountiful, Climbing Blue Lake, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Macrotyloma
uniflorum (L), Macroptilium lathyroides (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Bountiful,
Climbing Blue Lake (L), Passiflora edulis (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or
Centrosema pubescens, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab purpureus, or
Lathyrus odoratus, or Macroptilium atropurpureum, or Macroptilium lathyroides,
or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Passiflora aurantia, or Passiflora edulis, or Passiflora foetida, or
Passiflora suberosa, or Passiflora subpeltata, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesbania exaltata, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba. (48) Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Trifolium repens, or Vigna unguiculata.
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/15>, or Passifloraceae <5/5>, or Solanaceae
<3/6>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/15>, or Solanaceae <3/6>. (53)
Teakle and Wildermuth (1967); Edwardson (1974). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV:
3-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Moghal and Francki (1974). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 745 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31732. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33000. (145) Method of preparation: Dale: 1% SDS or
0.1% mercaptoethanol at 100°C for 1 minute. (171) Virions found in mesophyll
and vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: passionflora ringspot, bean
common mosaic and potato Y viruses. (187) Del Rosario et al. (1964). Philipp.
Agric. 48: 95. See Rev. appl. Mycol. 44: 2754. Edwardson, J.R. (1974). Fla
Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 5, p. 75. Martini, C. (1962). Ann. appl. Biol. 50:
163. McKnight, T. (1953). Qld. J. agric. Sci. 10: 4. Moghal, S.M. and Francki,
R.I.B. (1974). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 27: 341. Moghal, S.M. and Francki, R.I.B.
(1976). Virology 73: 350. Ong, C.A. and Ting (1973). MARDI Res. Bull. 1: 33.
See Rev. Pl. Path. 53: 1031. Taylor, R.H. and Greber, R.S. (1973). CMI/AAB

Passionfruit yellow mosaic tymovirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: PFYMV (PaYMV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 77.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported in Passiflora edulis f.
flavicarpa. (9) From Papucaia, Brazil. (10) By Kitajima et al. (1984). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Passiflora edulis f. flavicarpa yellow mosaic, vein
clearing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Diabrotica speciosa (experimental transmission). (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Brazil. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Several Passiflora spp., especially Passiflora
edulis f. flavicarpa. (45) Passiflora edulis f. flavicarpa. (46) Passiflora
edulis f. flavicarpa (W). No local lesion host. (47) Passiflora edulis, or
Passiflora edulis f. flavicarpa. (50) Passifloraceae <2/2>. (52) Limited to
Passiflora spp. (53) Crestani (1984). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 8 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Kitajima,
adapted from Bozarth et al. (1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile, or
angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 125 S. (78) Of the other(s) 62 S. (84) Virions
contain 25 % nucleic acid <or less>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 2 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Aviv and Leder (1972). (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
21000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970). (164)
Genome replicates <perhaps> in association with chloroplasts <in the
peripheral vesicles>. (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm,
possibly. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other
cellular changes: peripheral vesicles in the chloroplasts, which are
characteristic for tymoviruses. (179) Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: okra mosaic, kennedya mosaic, clitoria yellow
mosaic, cocoa yellow mosaic and turnip yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Aviv, H.
and Leder, P. (1972). Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 69: 1408. Bozarth, R.F.,
Lana, A.O., Koenig, R. and Reese, J. (1977). Phytopathology 67: 735. Crestani,
O.A. (1984). M.Sc. Thesis, Univ. Brasilia. Crestani, O.A., Kitajima, E.W.,
Lin, M.T. and Marinho, V.L.A. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 951. Crestani, O.A.,
Kitajima, E.W., Lin, M.T., Marinho, V.L.A. and Pimentel, J.P. (1984).
Fitopatol. Bras. 9: 394. Kitajima, E.W., Ribeiro, R.L.D., Lin, M.T., Ribeiro,
M.I.S.D., Costa C.L. and Pimentel J.P. (1984). Fitopatol. Bras. 9: 607.
Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680.


Patchouli mosaic potyvirus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.08. (8) First
reported in Pogostemon patchouli. (9) From Campinas, S.P. in Brazil. (10) By
Gama (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Pogostemon patchouli. (14)
Transmitted by a vector <probably>. (16) Transmitted by an insect <probably>.
(17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae <probably>.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions, then systemic
chlorotic spots or mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor local lesion with
reddish halo. Zinnia elegans mosaic. Nicotiana tabacum systemic chlorotic
spots. Bidens pilosa, Gomphrena globosa symptomless. (44) Crotalaria juncea,
Capsicum annuum, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus vulgaris, Petunia × hybrida.
(45) Zinnia elegans. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Zinnia elegans,
Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Bidens pilosa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus
annuus, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris,
or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pogostemon patchouli, or Spinacia oleracea, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris,
or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or

Patchouli mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: PatMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.064. (8) First reported in Pogostemon patchouli. (9) From Japan. (10)
By Natsuaki et al., 1994. (13) Pogostemon patchouli symptomless or mild leaf
mottling. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads in India and
Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Gomphrena globosa chlorotic local lesions, not systemic.
Chenopodium quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides local and systemic chlorotic
spotting. Sesamum indicum local and systemic mottle, systemic necrosis. (44)
Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris
and Zinnia elegans. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor
(L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pogostemon patchouli, or Sesamum indicum,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Lactuca sativa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa,
or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/2>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (53) Natsuaki et al.
(1994). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days <at 20oC>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
1. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with
a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760 nm. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels.
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) <Possible> Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
turnip mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
lettuce mosaic, pea seed-borne mosaic, watermelon mosaic-2 and zucchini yellow
mosaic viruses. (186) From its properties Natsuaki et al. (1994) considered
this virus to be a distinct potyvirus, although possibly similar to patchouli
mosaic viruses from India (Rao and Nagar, 1986) and Brazil (Gama, 1979). (187)
Gama, M.I.C.S. (1979). M.S.Thesis. Univ. Brasilia. Natsuaki, K.T., Tomaru, K.,

Pea early browning tobravirus

      (1) B. Gerhardson and K. Ryden, 1982. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: broad
bean yellow band virus (Russo et al., 1984; Robinson and Harrison, 1985). (3)
Standard acronym: PEBV. (5) ICTV decimal code 72.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported
in Pisum sativum. (9) From The Netherlands. (10) By Bos and van der Want
(1962). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Pisum sativum, Phaseolus vulgaris systemic
necrotic spots, streaks and mosaic, leaves malformed, plants stunted. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by
Trichodorus teres, T. pachydermus in The Netherlands; T. anenome, T.
primitivus, T. viruliferus in U.K. (20) Transmitted by Trichodoridae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<37% in Pisum sativum cv. Rondo>. (39) Spreads in Belgium, Italy, Morocco, the
Netherlands, Sweden, and the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Gomphrena globosa small white local lesions, not systemic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor small yellow local lesions, not systemic. C. quinoa necrotic and
chlorotic local lesions, sometimes systemic causing chlorotic spots and
malformation. Cucumis sativus necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Phaseolus
vulgaris necrotic local lesions or rings, then systemic mosaic and leaf
malformation. Pisum sativum diffuse chlorotic local lesions, then systemic
latent infection or necrotic spots on stems and leaf veins. Nicotiana
clevelandii diffuse local lesions, then faint systemic mosaic. N. glutinosa
diffuse local lesions, then occasional systemic mosaic and chlorotic line
patterns. N. tabacum latent systemic infection. Tetragonia tetragonioides
local and systemic necrotic concentric rings. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum
sativum, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Tetragonia tetragonioides. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium hybridum, or Tropaeolum
majus, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Allium cepa, or Avena sativa, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia faba. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/11>, or Solanaceae <5/7>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>,
or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Gramineae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/11>, or Solanaceae <3/7>. (53) Hampton et al.
(1978); Gerhardson et al. (1979). (54) TIP: 74-78 °C. (55) LIV: 183 days <or
more>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Cooper and Mayo (1972); frozen sap. (61) Virions rodshaped. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 215 nm, or 207 nm, or 105 nm. (71) Virions
21 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 4 nm in diameter. (74)
Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.5 nm. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 286 S. (78) Of the other(s) 210 S. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in CsCl.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 12 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 7.9 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.1 kb. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Macfarlanbe et al. (1989). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12294.

sequence, encoding coat protein, 9kDa 5 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 24000. (179) Tobravirus. (183) Broad bean yellow band tobravirus
is a serotype of PEBV (Robinson and Harrison, 1985). It causes yellow vein
banding, ringspotting and line patterns in Vicia faba in southern Italy. Its
RNA-1 has a closely similar sequence to that of PEBV, although their RNA-2s
differ. Pseudo-recombinants of BBYBV and PEBV are viable (B.D. Harrison, pers.

Pea enation mosaic enamovirus

      (1) A.J. Cockbain, 1980. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: enation pea mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: PEMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 24.0.1.0.001. (8)
First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From New York, U.S.A. (10) By Osborn (1935).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cicer arietinum, Lathyrus odoratus, Lens
culinaris, Medicago arabica, Pisum sativum, Trifolium incarnatum, Vicia faba,
Vicia sativa hyaline local lesions with enations, mosaic, puckering and
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus can help the
vector transmission of another virus <bean yellow vein banding umbravirus>.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus <probably>
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Canada, China, Iran, the UK, and the USA.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium album, C.
amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions. Lathyrus odoratus, Medicago arabica,
Pisum sativum, Trifolium incarnatum, Vicia faba systemic mosaic, hyaline
lesions with enations, puckering. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mosaic and
puckering. (45) Pisum sativum and Vicia faba, which is less satisfactory. (46)
Chenopodium album (L), C. amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer
arietinum, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Lespedeza stipulacea,
or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Medicago arabica, or Medicago
sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia
villosa. (48) Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lotus
corniculatus, or Medicago hispida, or Nicotiana rustica, or Sesbania exaltata,
or Trifolium dubium, or Trifolium pratense. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <18/24>, or Solanaceae <1/2>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/24>, or Solanaceae <1/2>. (53) McEwen
and Schroeder (1956); Hagedorn et al. (1964); Thottappilly (1972); Cockbain
and Gibbs (1973); Hampton et al. (1978). (54) TIP: 55-65 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
aldehyde fixation necessary for slower sedimenting virions. (60) Method: Hull
and Lane (1973); Mahmood and Peters (1973). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 and 28 nm in diameter <T and B,
respectively>. (66) Virions rounded in profile, or angular in profile <some
hexagonal, others pentagonal or ovoid>. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 112 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s)
99 S <T>. (79) Density 1.436 g cm3 in CsCl <for B component; top component
degraded in CsCl>. (81) Density 1.36 in D2O and 1.380 in Cs2SO4 for both
components. (82) Isoelectric point pH 5-6. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.63
<unfractionated prparations>. (84) Virions contain 28 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 72 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 9.96 kb. (92) Genome
of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger, RNA-1> 5.71 kb.
(94) The 2nd largest <RNA-2> 4.25 kb <see Taxonomy and Relationships below>.
(100) Base composition 26.6 % G. (101) Base composition 24.1 % A. (102) Base
composition 24.5 % C. (103) Base composition 24.8 % U. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a VPg. (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases. (110)
Poly A region absent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12290. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): L04573 Em(40)_vi:PEQPOLYZ Gb(84)_vi:PEQPOLYZ Pea enation
mosaic virus ORF 1, complete cds; ORF 2, complete cds; ORF 3, 3' end cds; coat
protein gene, complete cds; ORF 5, 3' end cds. U03563 Em(40)_vi:PE03563

complete cds. 6/94 4,253bp. U03564 Em(40)_vi:PE03564 Gb(84)_vi:PEU03564 Pea
enation mosaic virus WSG satellite RNA. 5/94 717bp. Z48507 Em(43)_vi:Pemvcp
Gb(89)_vi:Pemvcp Pea enation mosaic virus RNA for coat protein. 2/95 1,482bp.
(119) Features of the genome: Five ORFs (RNA-1). The coat protein and the
54kDa protein are probably translated from a subgenomic mRNA. RNA-2 also has 5
ORFs. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is satellite
RNA <probably>. (122) Nongenomic nucleic acid of 0.72 kb. (132) Virion
protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest, but minor, protein> 54000. (134)
Facilitates aphid transmission; it comprises the coat protein with a
'read-through' of a 33kDa protein encoded by the 3'terminal gene. (135) Mr of
2nd largest <major> 21000. (136) Coat protein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 17500.
(138) Genome-linked protein (VPg). (171) Virions found in leaves and phloem.
(172) Virions found in nuclei, in cytoplasm, and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Aggregates in the cytoplasm and nucleus. (177) They contain virions.
(178) Other cellular changes: phloem necrosis with dark staining spherical
bodies in sieve tubes. (179) Enamovirus <the type species>. (184) This virus
is probably a complex that has arisen by `symbiogenesis' (Gibbs, 1995). Tests
with transcripts of cDNAs encoding the two genomic components (Demler et al.,
1993, 1994) show that RNA-1 can replicate alone in protoplasts, but not in
intact plants, whereas RNA-2 can replicate alone in both protoplasts and
plants. Thus RNA-2 complements RNA-1 allowing it to be transmitted in sap, and
to spread systemically, whereas RNA-1 directs virion protein synthesis and
assembly into virions. (187) Adam, G., Sander, E. and Shepherd, R.J. (1979).
Virology 92: 1. Clark, R.G. and Bath, J.E. (1977). Phytopathology 67: 1035.
Cockbain, A.J. and Gibbs, A.J. (1973). Ann. appl. Biol. 73: 177. Demler, S.A.
and de Zoeten, G.A. (1989). J. gen. Virol. 70: 1075. Demler, S.A. and de
Zoeten, G.A. (1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 1819. Demler, S.A., Rucker, D.G. and
de Zoeten, G.A. (1993). J. gen. Virol. 74: 1. Demler, S.A., Borkhrenious, O.N.
Rucker, D.G. and de Zoeten, G.A. (1994). J. gen. Virol. 75: 997. De Zoeten,
G.A., Powell, C.A., Gaard, G. and German, T.L. (1976). Virology 70: 459.
Gabriel, C.J. and de Zoeten, G.A. (1984). Virology 139: 223. German, T.L. and

University of Oxford. Gonsalves, D. and Shepherd, R.J. (1972). Virology 48:
709. Harris, K.F., Bath, J.E., Thottapilly, G. and Hooper, G.R. (1975).
Virology 65: 148. Hagedorn, D.J., Layne, R.E.C. and Ruppel, E.G. (1964).
Phytopathology 54: 843. Hampton, R., Beczner, L., Hagedorn, D., Bos, L.,
Inouye, T., Barnett, O., Musil, M. and Meiners, J. (1978). Phytopathology 68:
