Pea mild mosaic comovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PMiMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported in Pisum sativum. (9) From New Zealand. (10)
By Clark (1972). (13) Pisum sativum inconspicuous leaf chlorosis or
symptomless infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in New Zealand. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris small necrotic local lesions in some
cultivars or large chlorotic local lesions; no systemic infection. Cultivar
Pinto is immune. Pisum sativum systemic vein-clearing, vein-etching or
necrosis, leaf-rolling and, sometimes, necrosis after 1015 days; plants then
recover. Vicia faba light green mosaic in systemically infected leaves. (44)
Medicago sativa, Nicotiana tabacum, Trifolium repens, T. pratense, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Bountiful (L), Pisum sativum (W). (47) Cicer arietinum, or Glycine max, or
Lathyrus odoratus, or Medicago hispida, or Melilotus albus, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/14>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/14>, or Solanaceae <4/4>. (53) Clark (1972).
(54) TIP: 68 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 21 days <at 18°C>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Clark (1972). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 27 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 119 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 94
S <M>, or 55 S <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.79 <B>, or 1.67 <M>, or 0.86 <T>.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 13.5
kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger>
8.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 5 kb. (100) Base composition 25 % G. (101) Base
composition 29 % A. (102) Base composition 17 % C. (103) Base composition 29 %
U. (179) Comovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: cowpea severe mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: bean pod mottle, broad bean stain,
cowpea mosaic and red clover mottle viruses. (187) Clark, M.F. (1972). N.Z. Jl
agric. Res. 15: 846.


Pea mosaic potyvirus

      (1) J. Bowyer, 1981. (2) Synonyms: common pea mosaic virus. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Pisum sativum. (9) From
Wisconsin, U.S.A. (10) By Doolittle and Jones (1925). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Pisum sativum, Pisum arvense, Trifolium pratense, Vicia faba, Trifolium
incarnatum, Lathyrus odoratus marble or yellow mosaic, stunting, delayed
unfolding of leaflets. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by 15 spp. including Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide. (39) Spreads in China. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions,
then systemic mosaic, leaf malformation, apical necrosis. C. quinoa chlorotic
local lesions. Lathyrus odoratus, Lupinus angustifolius, Pisum arvense, P.
sativum, Trifolium pratense systemic mosaic. T. subterraneum systemic mosaic,
vein banding, stunting. Vicia faba systemic marble mosaic. (44) Most Phaseolus
vulgaris cvs. (45) Pisum arvense, P. sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus angustifolius,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum arvense, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa. (48) Lactuca sativa, or
Phaseolus vulgaris <most cvs>, or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium repens, or
Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/12>, or Solanaceae <3/3>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/12>. (53) Bos (1970); Bos et al. (1974); Jones
et al. (1978). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Moghal and Francki (1976). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 785-800 nm.
(71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 140 S. (79) Density 1.321 g cm3
in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5.5-6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94-94.5 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome unipartite. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
36398. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): S71232 Gb(84)n:S71232 3'
end: polyprotein pea mosaic potyvirus PMV-I, I, Genomic RNA, 1035 nt. 9/94
1,035bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33000. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and epidermis.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, or crystals in the nucleus
<associated with the nucleolus, 2-3 [Gm]>, or unusual in shape. (176) And
granular bodies, 10-30 [Gm]. (177) They contain virions <in the cytoplasm
only>. (178) Other cellular changes: chloroplast damage. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bean yellow mosaic virus is closely related; bean common mosaic and
clover yellow vein viruses are distantly related. (186) Synonym of bean yellow
mosaic potyvirus. (187) Bos, L. (1970). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 76: 8. Bos, L.
(1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 40, 4 pp. Bos, L., Kowalska, C. and
Maat, D.Z. (1974). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 80: 173. Christie, S.R. and Edwardson,
J.R. (1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 9. Doolittle, S.P. and Jones, F.R.
(1925). Phytopathology 15: 763. Hagedorn, D.J. (1974). Ann. Phytop. Soc.
Monog. No. 9. Huttinga, H. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81: 58. Huttinga, H. and
Mosch, W.H.M. (1974). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 80: 19. Jones et al. (1978).
Phytopathology 68: 831. Moghal, S.M. and Francki, R.I.B. (1976). Virology 73:
350. Randles, J.W., Davies, C., Gibbs, A.J. and Hatta, T. (1980). Aust. J.

50: 337. Taylor, R.H. and Smith, P.R. (1968). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 21: 429.


Pea seed-borne mosaic potyvirus

      (1) P. Fry, 1980. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: pea fizzle top virus, pea
leaf rolling virus, pea leaf roll mosaic virus, pea leaf rolling mosaic virus.
(3) Standard acronym: PSbMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.048. (8) First
reported in Pisum sativum. (10) By Musil (1966). (11) Symptoms disappear soon
after infection. (13) Pisum sativum transitory vein clearing, rosetting of
stem and branches, leaves dark green and leaflets folded adaxially, flowers
malformed and often sterile, pods small, few misshapen seeds. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
pisum, Aphis craccivora, A. fabae, Dactynotus escalanti, Macrosiphum
crataegarius, Rhopalosiphum padi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to 100% in Pisum sativum,
especially when testa is split, but little seed transmission in Vicia faba, V.
narbonensis and V. pannonica>. (38) Spreads in the Central Asian region, the
Eastern Asian region, and the North American region. (39) Spreads in Australia
and the UK. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in New Zealand. (41)
Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local
lesions. C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Pisum sativum systemic stunting,
vein clearing, leaf rolling. Vicia faba systemic vein chlorosis. (45) Lathyrus
odoratus, Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa. (47) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Brassica oleracea var. gemmifera, or
Brassica oleracea var. viridis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucurbita maxima, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Lens culinaris, or Medicago sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or
Senecio vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba, or Vicia
sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Amaranthus retroflexus, or
Arachis hypogaea, or Atriplex hortensis, or Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris
<sugar beet, table beet, ssp. cicla, 4 other cvs>, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Celosia argentea <var. cristata>, or Chenopodium
hybridum, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus
carota, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or Helianthus annuus, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Melilotus albus, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Raphanus sativus, or
Secale cereale, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Triticum
aestivum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/3>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/10>, or Compositae <2/4>, or
Cruciferae <5/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<7/14>, or Solanaceae <1/14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<2/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/10>, or Compositae
<2/4>, or Cruciferae <2/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or Gramineae <5/5>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/14>, or Solanaceae <13 /14>, or Umbelliferae
<1/1>. (53) Hampton (1975). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days <in leaves>, or
4 days <in roots>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix with 3.5% gluraraldehyde. (60) Method:
Knesek et al. (1974). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)
Virions of 770 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74)
Basic helix obscure. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 154 S. (79)
Density 1.329 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5.3 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (100) Base composition 22.8 % G. (101) Base composition
44 % A. (102) Base composition 17.6 % C. (103) Base composition 15.6 % U.

unusual in shape. (176) Aggregates in tonoplasts. (177) They contain virions

Pea stem necrosis virus

      (1) K.T. Natsuaki, 1984. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.30. (8) First
reported in Pisum sativum. (9) From Wakayama, Japan. (10) By Nakano et al.
(1976). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Pisum sativum yellowing, leaf and stem
necrosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17)
Transmitted by Olpidium spp. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Lathyrus odoratus, Phaseolus vulgaris local lesions. Pisum
sativum systemic yellowing, necrosis. Sesamum indicum local lesions. (45)
Pisum sativum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Pisum sativum (W). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum indicum. (48) Lathyrus
odoratus. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>. (51)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>. (53) Nakano et al. (1976). (54) TIP: 70-75
°C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Inouye
et al. (1977). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 34 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 118 S. (84) Virions
contain 15 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 85 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 1.4 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 1.4 kb. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 35000. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: vesicles
in the cytoplasm. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: nepoviruses, tobacco necrosis, cucumber necrosis, satsuma
dwarf and melon necrotic spot viruses. (187) Inouye et al. (1977). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 43: 371. Nakano et al. (1976). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 42: 82. Osaki and Inouye (1982). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 48: 113.


Pea streak carlavirus

      (1) R.O. Hampton, 1981. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: alfalfa latent
virus, Steinklee Virus, Wisconsin pea streak virus, probably pea streak New
Zealand virus (Bos, 1964; Chamberlain, 1954). (3) Standard acronym: PeSV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.023. (8) First reported in Pisum sativum. (9) From
the U.S.A. (10) By Hagedorn and Walker (1949). (11) Symptoms persist, or
disappear soon after infection <in the glasshouse>. (13) Medicago sativa
symptomless. Pisum sativum necrotic lesions or streaks. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
pisum. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region.
(39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Pisum sativum inoculated leaves symptomless, systemic necrosis, vein
banding, reddening. Vicia faba cv. Bell necrotic local lesions, then systemic
necrosis, necrotic spots and streaks. Cassia occidentalis necrotic or
chlorotic local lesions only. (45) Pisum sativum, Vicia faba. (46) Pisum
sativum, Vicia faba. (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Fagopyrum
esculentum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Lens culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Melilotus officinalis,
or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Vigna angularis, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis .
(50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <22/27>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <3 /7>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/27>, or Solanaceae <4/7>. (52) The isolate
orginally described as alfalfa latent virus induces milder symptoms and
infects fewer species. (53) Bos (1973); Edwardson and Christie (1986); Hampton
et al. (1978); Thornberry (1966). (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Veerisetty
and Brakke (1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 630 nm. (71) Virions 13.5 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 160 S. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 7 kb. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) two.
(133) Mr <of the larger> 29000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 24000. (171) Virions
found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Vacuolated,
paracrystalline and banded bodies. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: cells and their organelles deteriorate and endoplasmic
reticulum increases. (179) Carlavirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: red clover vein mosaic, potato M, potato S, hop mosaic, hop
latent and American hop latent viruses. (187) Bos, L. (1964). Neth. J. Pl.
Path. 70: 161. Bos, L. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 112, 4 pp.
Chamberlain, E.E. (1954). N.Z. Dep. Sci. Ind. Res. Bull. 108: 143. Edwardson,
J.R. and Christie, R.G. (1986). Florida Agric. Exp. Sta. Monogr. Series 14.
Hagedorn, D. and Walker, J.C. (1949). Phytopathology 39: 837. Hampton, R.,
Beczner, L., Hagedorn, D., Bos, L., Inouye, T., Barnett, O., Musil, M. and
Meiners, J. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 989. Thornberry, H.H. (1966). In: Index
of Plant Virus Diseases U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 307, p. 272. Veerisetty, V.
and Brakke, M.K. (1977a). Phytopathology 67: 1202. Veerisetty, V. and Brakke,
M.K. (1977b). Virology 83: 226. Veerisetty, V. and Brakke, M.K. (1978).
Phytopathology 68: 59. Veerisetty, V. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
211, 3 pp.


Peach enation (?) nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.DE.3. (8) First
reported in Prunus persica. (9) From Japan. (10) By Kishi et al. (1973). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Prunus persica small enations on abaxial leaf surfaces;
shortening of internodes. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Celosia cristata, Chenopodium quinoa local lesions;
systemic leaf mottling. Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor systemic leaf
mottling. Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. megalosiphon, N. tabacum,
Physalis floridana symptomless systemic infection. Petunia × hybrida local
lesions; symptomless systemic infection. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (45)
Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor, C. quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L),
Petunia × hybrida (L). (47) Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia cristata, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Prunus
persica, or Raphanus sativus, or Sesamum indicum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis
, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>,
or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>,
or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <5/8>, or

(1973). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 40 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter.

Peach rosette mosaic nepovirus

      (1) D.C Ramsdell, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PRMV. (4) Strains: grape
isolate, peach isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.023. (8) First reported
in Prunus persica, Vitis labrusca. (9) From North America. (10) By Catson
(1933). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Prunus persica shoot terminals rosetted,
mosaic, stunting. Vitis spp. short, crooked cane internodes; leaf
malformation, basal stems flat. Rumex crispus, Solanum carolinense, Taraxacum
officinale no symptoms (Ramsdell and Gillet, 1981). (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Xiphinema
americanum, Longidorus diadecturus. (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Ramsdell and Myers (1974);
Ramsdell and Myers (1978); Ramsdell et al. (1983). (39) Spreads in Canada and
the USA <Ontario and Michigan, respectively>. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions, tip necrosis and
epinasty. C. amaranticolor faint systemic mottle. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, C.
amaranticolor. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (W). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or

Peanut chlorotic streak caulimovirus

      (1) D.V.R. Reddy, 1984. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: PCSV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 15.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9)
From Anantapoor, India. (10) By Reddy et al. (1978); Ghanekar et al. (1978).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea chlorotic vein streaking and
stunting. Symptoms slow to appear. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in India. (41)

systemic chlorotic spotting. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba necrotic local lesions;
systemic vein-clearing. Glycine max systemic mosaic. Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Top Crop local lesions, systemic mosaic. Vicia faba chlorotic or necrotic
local lesions; not systemic. Datura stramonium, Nicotiana rustica chlorotic
local lesions; systemic mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa systemic chlorotic spots.
Petunia × hybrida systemic mosaic. Vigna unguiculata chlorotic local lesions
with necrotic centre; not systemic. Spinacia oleracea chlorotic local lesions;
not systemic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Brassica oleracea
var. botrytis, Cassia obtusifolia, Cajanus cajan, Trifolium incarnatum,

Peanut clump furovirus

      (1) J.-C. Thouvenel, 1982. Revised 1984. (3) Standard acronym: PCV. (4)
Strains: Indian peanut clump virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 27.0.1.0.003. (8)
First reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From Upper Volta, West Africa. (10) By
Thouvenel et al. (1974). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea
stunting, mottle, mosaic, chlorotic ringspots. Sorghum arundinaceum, Sorghum
bicolor, Setaria italica symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis. pH of soil
affects transmission by the vector. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <5-11% in Arachis hypogaea and 10% in
Setaria>. (39) Spreads in Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, India, and Senegal.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor
chlorotic local lesions, ringspots and line patterns along veins, not
systemic. Triticum aestivum, Arachis hypogaea systemic mosaic. Phaseolus
vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata, V. mungo, Torenia fournieri systemic ringspots
and/or mosaic. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic ringspots and leaf malformation.
N. glutinosa, Tetragonia tetragonioides systemic ringspots. (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor
(L), Torenia fournieri (L), Nicotiana benthamiana (L) and Triticum aestivum
(W). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or

Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or

Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Setaria italica, or Sorghum arundinaceum, or Sorghum

Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Gramineae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/8>, or Scrophulariaceae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <10/10>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Scrophulariaceae
<1/2>. (53) Thouvenel et al. (1981). (54) TIP: 64 °C. (55) LIV: 28 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Thouvenel et
al. (1978). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 190
and 245 nm. (71) Virions 21 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic
helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.6 nm. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the

Virions 96 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.

detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 28355. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): L07269 Em(40)_vi:PNWRNAII Gb(84)_vi:PNWRNAII Peanut clump virus RNA 2

Peanut green mosaic potyvirus

      (1) N. Iizuka, 1982. (2) Synonyms: peanut chlorotic mottle virus. (5)
ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.09. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9)
From India. (10) By Sreenivasulu et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Arachis hypogaea mosaic, sometimes chlorotic vein banding, ringspots and/or
oak leaf patterns. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in India. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not
systemic. Arachis hypogaea, Cassia occidentalis severe systemic mosaic.
Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Bountiful, Kintoki necrotic local lesions; systemic in
cv. Kintoki. Nicotiana benthamiana, Petunia × hybrida systemic mosaic.
Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Glycine
max, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Top Crop, Pinto, Pisum sativum. (45) Arachis
hypogaea, Cassia occidentalis, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, Petunia
× hybrida. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Cassia obtusifolia (L), Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Indian (L). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Cassia obtusifolia, or
Cassia occidentalis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa,
or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or
Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cvs Top Crop, Pinto>, or Physalis
floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Solanum melongena, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/9>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/12>,
or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/9>, or Solanaceae <10/12>. (53)
Sreenivasulu et al. (1981). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Sreenivasulu
et al. (1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 750 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 171 S. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 10.8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 10.8 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 34500. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
unusual in shape. (176) Cylindrical. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: clover
yellow vein, soybean mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, blackeye cowpea mosaic and
peanut mottle viruses. (187) Iizuka, N. (1979). Proc. Symp. Legumes in Tropics
Univ. Agric. Malaysia. Sreenivasulu, P., Iizuka, N., Rajeshwari, R., Reddy,
D.V.R. and Nayudu, M.V. (1981). Ann. appl. Biol. 98: 255.


Peanut mottle potyvirus

      (1) K. Bock, 1980. Revised 1987 by J.R. Edwardson. Updated 1991 by A.A.
Brunt. (2) Synonyms: groundnut mottle virus, peanut mild mosaic virus, peanut
severe mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: PeMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.049. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea and Glycine max. (9) From
Georgia, U.S.A.; Queensland, Australia; west Kenya and Uganda. (10) By Kuhn
(1965); Behncken (1970). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea East
African isolates, often symptomless or mild mottle. Strains in the USA cause
mottling with necrosis and mosaic. Arachis pintoi chlorotic ringspots in
leaves. Cassia bicapsularis (east Africa) and C. leptocarpa, C. occidentalis,
C. tora (U.S.A.) mild dark green mottling. Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris,
Pisum sativum leaf mottling and necrosis. Stylosanthes sp. mild leaf chlorosis
and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Hyperomyzus lactucae, Myzus
persicae, Rhopalosiphum padi. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner <A. craccivora can remain infective for 2 hours and
M. persicae for 12 hours after acquisition (Paguio and Kuhn, 1974)>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<0.022% in Arachis hypogaea; to 1% in Phaseolus vulgaris and to 0.008% in
Vigna unguiculata (Demski et al., 1983), but not in Glycine max, Pisum
sativum, Cassia obtusifolia>. (36) Studies reported by Paguio and Kuhn (1974);
Kuhn and Demski (1975; 1977); Boerma and Kuhn (1976); Shipe et al. (1979).
(38) Spreads in the African region, the Eastern Asian region, and the South
and Central American region. (39) Spreads in Australia <the north east>, or
Colombia, or India <possibly>, or Japan, or Malaysia, or the Philippines, or
Taiwan, or the USA <in the south east>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Arachis hypogaea necrotic local lesions, then systemic mottling, mosaic,
necrosis. Cassia occidentalis systemic mosaic; not infected by severe strain.
Glycine max systemic dark green mottling, crinkling, blistering and
malformation. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local lesions; only some strains
systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mottling. (45) Pisum sativum, Vigna
unguiculata, Nicotiana clevelandii (Phaseolus lunatus strain only). (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (Cassia and Vigna isolates only), Phaseolus vulgaris
(L most isolates). (47) Arachis hypogaea <cvs Natal Common, Argentine>, or
Arachis pintoi, or Cassia bicapsularis <host adapted strain in Africa>, or
Cassia leptocarpa, or Cassia obtusifolia, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia
tora, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis sativus,
or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Glycine tabacina, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus albus, or Macroptilium lathyroides,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum
indicum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stylosanthes, or Trifolium incarnatum, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna subterranea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Carica papaya, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Catharanthus roseus,
or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Citrullus lanatus, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyphomandra betacea, or Datura stramonium, or
Fagopyrum esculentum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Lens culinaris, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Melilotus officinalis,
or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Passiflora edulis, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
acutifolius, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phytolacca
americana, or Raphanus sativus, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia villosa, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <5/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <17/31>, or
Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/11>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caricaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae
<2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <18 /31>, or
Passifloraceae <1/1>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <10/11>. (53) Bock (1973); Bock et al. (1975, 1978); Choopanya
(1983); Demski et al. (1983); Inouye (1969); Roechan et al. (1978). (54) TIP:
54-65 °C <but varies with isolates, and host adapted variants>. (55) LIV:
0.5-6 days, or 8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not
changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions
<probably>. (60) Method: Sun et al. (1972); Bock et al. (1975, 1978). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 740-750 nm
<but may range between 704-984 nm>. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 151 S <Rajeshwari et al., 1983>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 2.6 <specific absorbance at 260 nm>. (84) Virions contain <c.> 6 %

ID: 33763. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L32956

Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in

crystals in the nucleus <Xu, 1984>, or unusual in shape. (176) However, most
isolates induce pinwheels, bundles, laminated aggregates and scrolls (Christie
and Edwardson, 1977; Inouye, 1973; Herold and Munz, 1969; Choopanya, 1983).
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :

Peanut stunt cucumovirus

      (1) G.I. Mink, 1980. Revised by P.L. Guy, 1990. (2) Synonyms: robinia
mosaic virus (Richter et al., 1979; Schmelzer, 1971; Zheng and Kung, 1984),
black locust true mosaic virus, clover blotch virus (Richter et al., 1979).
(3) Standard acronym: PSV. (4) Strains: peanut common mosaic virus. (5) ICTV
decimal code 10.0.4.0.002. (8) First reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From
Virginia, U.S.A. (10) By Miller et al. (1966). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Robinia pseudoacacia mosaic and leaf malformation. Trifolium repens, T.
pratense, T. vesiculosum, T. incarnatum, T. subterraneum, Medicago sativa
chlorotic mottling. Phaseolus spp. chlorotic local lesions and mottling, then
mosaic, elongated misshapen trifoliate leaves in cv. Bountiful. Arachis
hypogaea stunting, mild mottle, pod malformation. Vicia sp. systemic chlorotic
mottle. Glycine max, Pisum sativum, Vigna angularis, Coronilla varia,
Tephrosia sp., Nicotiana tabacum, Apium graveolens, Lupinus luteus leaf
chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. spiraecola and Myzus persicae, but not
Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34)
Virus transmitted by seed <0.1% in Arachis hypogaea>. (39) Spreads in France,
Japan, Korea D.P.R. (North), Korea Republic, Morocco, Poland, Spain, and the
USA. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa chlorotic local lesions; systemic spotting. Spinacia oleracea,
Tetragonia tetragonioides systemic mottling. Glycine max systemic chlorotic
mottling. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, systemic
chlorotic mottling or mosaic. P. vulgaris cv. Bountiful elongated mis-shapen
trifoliate leaves. Pisum sativum systemic chlorotic mottling, stunting. Vigna
unguiculata chlorotic local lesions; systemic vein clearing and severe
epinasty. Datura stramonium systemic chlorotic mottle with islands of green
tissue. Nicotiana tabacum light green and yellow rings, then systemic
chlorotic areas. Tetragonia tetragonioides systemic mottle. (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Pisum sativum, Vigna unguiculata, Nicotiana tabacum. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L), Vigna unguiculata (L, W),
Datura stramonium (W), Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Apium graveolens, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer
arietinum, or Citrullus lanatus, or Coronilla varia, or Crotalaria
spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura
metel, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lens culinaris, or Lespedeza
stipulacea, or Lobelia erinus, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or
Lupinus luteus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus
albus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica,
or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
acutifolius, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis

or Sesamum indicum, or Sesbania exaltata, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tephrosia vogelii, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia
fournieri, or Trifolium dubium, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium
subterraneum, or Trifolium vesiculosum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or
Vicia villosa, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (48) Antirrhinum
majus, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Glycine max, or Helianthus annuus, or
Momordica balsamina, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <6/7>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1

Scrophulariaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <13/14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/7>, or Compositae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/34>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/2>, or Solanaceae <1/14>. (53) Mink et al. (1969); Waterworth et al.
(1973); Milbrath and Tolin (1977). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days <and
several days for P strain>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: aldehyde fixation necessary. (60)
Method: Mink et al. (1969); Waterworth et al. (1973). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.

Peanut top paralysis (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.11. (8) First
reported in Arachis hypogaea (wild hybrid). (9) From Oklahoma, U.S.A. (10) By
Wagih et al. (1994). (12) Symptoms Arachis hypogaea (wild hybrid) few
chlorotic rings, green blotching, smaller leaf laminae. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Oklahoma, U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Arachis hypogaea cvs
Pronto and Tamnut 74 severe leaf chlorosis and distortion, plants stunted.
Glycine max systemic leaf chlorosis (some cultivars). Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Top Crop, Chenopodium amaranticolor local necrotic lesions. (44) Cucumis
sativus, Datura stramonium, Petunia × hybrida and Vigna unguiculata. (45)
Arachis hypogaea cv. Tamnut 74. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop (W),
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Glycine max, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (48) Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Petunia × hybrida, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>. (51) Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (54) TIP:
55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 6 days <at 23oC>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (60) Method:
Wagih et al. (1994). (61) Virions filamentous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 750-850 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000. (134) Coat protein. (179) <Possible>
unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, bean common mosaic (peanut stripe
strain), potato Y, papaya ringspot, watermelon mosaic 2 and zucchini yellow
mosaic potyviruses. (187) Wagih, E.E., Melouk, H.A. and Sherwood, J.L. (1994).
J. Phytopathology 141: 302.


Peanut veinal chlorosis (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.DE.07. (8) First
reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From India. (10) By Anon. (1986). (13)
Arachis hypogaea veinal chlorosis. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread,
in India. (47) Arachis hypogaea. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (179)
Unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Anon. (1986). Rep.
ICRISAT 1985, p. 226. Naidu, A., Manohar, S.K., Reddy, D.V.R. and Reddy, A.S.
(1989). Pl. Path. 38: 623.


Peanut yellow spot tospovirus

      (1) D.V.R. Reddy, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code 11.0.5.DE.01. (8) First
reported in Arachis hypogaea. (9) From India. (10) By Anon. (1980). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Arachis hypogaea small chlorotic local lesions, which
coalesce then become necrotic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Scirtothrips dorsalis. (18) Transmitted by
Thysanoptera. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in India and Thailand. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Vigna unguiculata large chlorotic
local lesions becoming necrotic. Petunia × hybrida necrotic local lesions.
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Datura stramonium chlorotic local
lesions with necrotic rings. (44) Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicandra
physalodes. (45) Arachis hypogaea, Vigna mungo. (46) Vigna unguiculata (L),
Petunia × hybrida (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L), Datura stramonium (L). (47)
Arachis hypogaea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana rustica. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/7>, or Solanaceae <3/6>. (51) Solanaceae <3/6>.
(54) TIP: 40-45 °C. (55) LIV: <less than> 1 days <c. 4 hours at 2530°C>. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 2. (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
fix in 1.5% glutaraldehyde. (60) Method: Reddy: from Arachis hypogaea tissue;
grind in 20mM phosphate buffer, pH 7.5, clarify. Add NaCl (0.2 M), PEG (2.1);
centrifuge 10000 G for 15 minutes; resuspend in 10mM phosphate (pH 7.5) and
centrifuge in sucrose gradients. (61) Virions unusually shaped. (62) Virions
quasi-isometric. (63) Virions enveloped. (64) Virions 70-90 nm in diameter.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 17.6 kb. (92) Genome of
three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 8.8 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 5.4 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 3.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Reddy; extract twice in phenol-cresol chloroform mixture. (108)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity lost
when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112) Additional factor not
required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (132) Virion protein(s) four. (133) Mr <of the largest> 72000. (135)
Mr of 2nd largest 64000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 62000. (139) Mr of 4th
largest 31000. (148) Virion proteins glycosylated. (150) Virion proteins
phosphorylated. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (173) Virions found in associated with
endoplasmic reticulum. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Tospovirus: Bunyaviridae. (180) : Bunyaviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: tomato spotted wilt virus. (187) Anon.
(1980). Rep. ICRISAT for 1979. Anon. (1985). Rep. ICRISAT 1984. Anon. (1986).
Rep. ICRISAT 1985, p. 226. Anon. (1987). Rep. ICRISAT 1986, p. 227. Anon.
(1988). Rep. ICRISAT 1987, p. 235. Reddy, D.V.R., Sudarshana, M.R., Ratna,
A.S., Reddy, A.S., Kiran-Kumar, I. and Murthy, A.K. (1991). Proc. Tomato
Spotted Wilt Virus Wksh. 1719 April 1991, Beltsville, Maryland, U.S.A., p. 77.
Wongkaew, S. (1983). Groundnut Improvement Project, Khon Kaen University,
Progress Report 1983.


Pecteilis mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt. (3) Standard acronym: PcMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.067. (8) First reported in Pecteilis sp. (9) From Japan. (10) By Yora
et al. (1983). (47) Pecteilis. (50) Orchidaceae <1/1>. (179) <Possible>
unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Yora, K., Saito, Y., Doi, Y.,
Inouye, T. and Tomaru, K. (1983). In: Handbook of Plant Viruses. Asakura
Shoten, Tokyo.


Pelargonium flower break carmovirus

      (1) I. Bouwen, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PFBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.010. (8) First reported in Pelargonium zonale. (9) From the U.K. (10)
By Stone and Hollings (1971; 1973a and b). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally, or
none. (13) Pelargonium peltatum symptomless. P. zonale usually symptomless.
Some cultivars show white flower streaking, chlorotic spotting of young leaves
and stunting. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (15)
Vegetative propagation and mechanical transmission. (24) Not transmitted by
Cuscuta campestris, Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus <probably>
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Hollings and Stone (1974), Pelargonium can be freed
from pelargonium flower break virus by growing for 4 weeks at 3035°C or 48
weeks at 3437°C (16 hours) and 2025°C (8 hours) then rooting small cuttings
from the stem tips, but few plants survive. (39) Spreads in Denmark, Germany,
the Netherlands, and the UK. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
the U.S.A. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show no symptoms, but some Pelargonium zonale cultivars
show flower breaking. (43) Chenopodium quinoa numerous chlorotic and necrotic
local lesions; occasional systemic infection, with leaf mottling. Gomphrena
globosa few, brown necrotic local lesions (or symptomless if inoculum is
dilute), not systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii diffuse chlorotic, occasionally
necrotic, local lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana megalosiphon local and
systemic symptomless infection. Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local
lesions not systemic. (44) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
megalosiphon. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Atriplex hortensis, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Ocimum basilicum, or Pelargonium
peltatum, or Pelargonium zonale, or Saponaria vaccaria, or Silene armeria, or

or Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Arachis

or Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Geraniaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or

Hollings and Stone (1974); Stone and Hollings (1973a). (54) TIP: 85-90 °C <in

tetragonioides>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions isometric.

preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 125 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.64.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4 kb.

Taxon ID: 35291. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L34289
Gb(84)_vi:CVIRDRP Pelargonium flower-break carmovirus (clone pPFB26) RNA
polymerase (RdRp) mRNA fragment. 7/94. Z28395 Em(43)_vi:Pfbvrdrp

Morris and Carrington, 1988; Stone and Hollings, 1973a; Hollings and Stone,
1974>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (174) Inclusions
absent from infected cells. (179) Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean mild
mosaic, blackgram mottle, carnation mottle, cowpea mottle, cucumber leaf spot,
cucumber necrosis, cucumber soil-borne, elderberry latent, galinsoga mosaic,
glycine mottle, hibiscus chlorotic ringspot, melon necrotic spot, narcissus
tip necrosis, pelargonium line pattern, plantain 6, saguaro cactus, tephrosia
symptomless and turnip crinkle viruses. (184) No serological relationship
found to any of 42 other isometric viruses. (187) Anon. (1988). In: Tips on
Growing Zonal Geraniums, p 43; ed. H.K. Tayama, OCES, Ohio State University,
Bulletin FP765 Agdex 281/15. Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1974). CMI/AAB

Pelargonium leaf curl tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: geranium crinkle virus (Pethybridge
and Smith, 1952), tomato bushy stunt virus pelargonium strain (Martelli et
al., 1971). (3) Standard acronym: PLCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.0.011.
(8) First reported in Pelargonium zonale. (9) From Germany. (10) By Pape
(1927). (13) Pelargonium zonale pale chlorotic spots, which later become
stellate and necrotic, leaf crinkling and plant degeneration. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Hollings (1962);
Hollings and Stone (1965). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region, the
Mediterranean region, and the North American region. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic and/or necrotic
local lesions; systemic chlorosis and necrosis. Nicotiana clevelandii local
chlorotic lesions and rings; severe systemic chlorotic and semi-necrotic spots
and rings. (45) Datura stramonium, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Datura stramonium (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Pelargonium zonale, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>.
(54) TIP: 90 °C. (55) LIV: 21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (60) Method:
Gallitelli et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 136 S. (79) Density 1.34 g cm3 in
CsCl. (84) Virions contain 17 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83 % protein. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 4.7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 4.7 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35280. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 41000. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in
nuclei, in nucleoli, in the perinuclear space, in chloroplasts, and in cell
vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: nucleoli enlarged, chromatin depleted. (179) Tombusvirus:
Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: carnation Italian ringspot and tomato bushy stunt viruses.
(184) The genome of the virus has 24% sequence identity with that of tomato
bushy stunt virus. (187) Gallitelli, D., Hull, R. and Koenig, R. (1985). J.
gen. Virol. 66: 1523. Hollings, M. (1962). Ann. appl. Biol. 50: 189. Hollings,
M. and Stone, O.M. (1965). Ann. appl. Biol. 56: 87. Koenig, R. and Gibbs, A.J.
(1986). J. gen. Virol. 67: 75. Martelli, G.P. and Castellano, M.A. (1969).
Virology 39: 610. Martelli, G.P. and Russo, M. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 15: 193.
Martelli, G.P., Gallitelli, D. and Russo, M. (1988). In The Plant Viruses; 3,
Polyhedral Virions with Monopartite Genomes, pp. 13-72. Plenum Press, New
York. Martelli, G.P., Quacquarelli, A. and Russo, M. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 69, 4 pp. Pape, H. (1927). Gartenwelt 31: 329. Pethybridge,
G.H. and Smith, K.M. (1932). Gard. Chron. 92: 378. Wetter, C. and Luisoni, E.
(1969). Phytopath. Z. 65: 231.


Pelargonium line pattern (?) carmovirus

      (1) I. Bouwen and D.Z. Maat, 1991. (2) Synonyms: pelargonium ring
pattern virus. (3) Standard acronym: PLPV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.T.DE.2. (8) First reported in Pelargonium zonale. (9) From Great
Britain. (10) By Stone and Hollings (1971 and 1976). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally, or none. (13) Pelargonium zonale mainly symptomless but, during
winter, may have yellow/green spots and line patterns. Pelargonium peltatum no
symptoms. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Belgium, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, the UK, and the
former Yugoslavia. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A.
and Germany. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show symptoms 18 months after inoculation and usually
during winter, in Pelargonium zonale, as veinal flecks and line pattern. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor small chlorotic local lesions with whitish necrotic
centres, not systemic. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic spots, most becoming
necrotic, occasional systemic chlorotic spots. Nicotiana clevelandii faint
diffuse spots, occasionally symptomless, systemic mild chlorotic mottle, vein
clearing and mild rugosity or symptomless. Pisum sativum grey-brown necrotic
spots, not systemic. Vicia faba dark green local lesions with necrotic centre,
chlorosis, usually symptomless systemic infection. (44) Amaranthus caudatus,
Chrysanthemum sp., Cucumis sativus, Dianthus caryophyllus. (45) Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Vicia
faba (L). (47) Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Pelargonium
peltatum, or Pelargonium zonale, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Silene armeria, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum,
or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cucumis
sativus, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa. (50) Amaranthaceae
<2/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/3>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or Geraniaceae
<2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/7>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13/13>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <2/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>. (53) Plese and Stefanac (1980); Stone (1974); Stone and
Hollings (1971 and 1977); Welvaert et al. (1982). (54) TIP: 85 °C. (55) LIV:
18-23 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions.
(60) Method: Maat: harvest leaves of Nicotiana clevelandii 10 days after
inoculation. Homogenize leaves at 4°C with 2 ml/g of 20mM sodium phosphate,
(pH 6), 20mM sodium thioglycolate and 20mM sodium diethyldithiocarbamate, then
with 0.16 vol of 50:50 diethyl ether: carbon tetrachloride. Homogenate is
clarified, then differentially centrifuged (85,600 g for 2 hours and 810000g
for 10 minutes) in 20mM sodium phosphate buffer, and 2 cycles of
sucrose-gradient centrifugation. (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions <c.> 30
nm in diameter. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): S58174
Em(40)_vi:S58174 Gb(84)_vi:S58174 putative RNA polymerase, coat protein
pelargonium leaf curl virus PLCV, Genomic RNA, 1787 nt 1 sequence. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41400. (134) Capsid polypeptide. (171) Virions
found in leaves, mesophyll and the epidermis. In Pelargonium peltatum the
virus has been found in the leaves, petioles, stem, nodes and complete
flowers. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) In Chenopodium quinoa and Vicia faba the inclusions are described as
delicate granular cytoplasmic bodies of characteristic star-like or amoeboid
appearance. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: are
described by Stefanac et al. (1981 and 1982). (179) <Possible> Carmovirus:
Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: carnation mottle, bean mild mosaic, blackgram mottle,
cowpea mottle, cucumber leaf spot, cucumber necrosis, cucumber soil-borne,
elderberry latent, galinsoga mosaic, glycine mottle, hibiscus chlorotic
ringspot, melon necrotic spot, narcissus tip necrosis, pelargonium flower
break, plantain 6, saguaro cactus, tephrosia symptomless and turnip crinkle
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: pelargonium line pattern virus is
often associated with pelargonium flower break virus. It can be distinguished
by ELISA or by mechanical inoculation on Vicia faba. Pelargonium line pattern
virus produces brown local lesions on inoculated leaves and pelargonium flower
break does not infect. (187) Anon. (1988). In: Tips on Growing Zonal
Geraniums, pp. 4345; ed. H.K. Tayama, OCES, Ohio State University, Bulletin
FP765 Agdex 281/15. Hoof, H.A., van Maat, D.Z. and Vink, J. (1973). Vakblad
voor de Bloemisterij 28: 9. Morris, T.J. and Carrington, J.C. (1988). In: The
Plant Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions with Monopartite RNA Genomes, p. 73;
ed. R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York. Paludan, N. and Begtrup, J. (1987).
Tidsskr. PlAvl. 91: 183. Plese, N. and Stefanac, Z. (1980). Acta Hort. 110:
183. Stefanac, Z., Plese, N. and Wrischer, M. (1981). Abstr. 5th Int. Congr.
Virol., Strasbourg, p. 239. Stefanac, Z., Plese, N. and Wrischer, M. (1982).
Phytopath. Z. 105: 288. Stone, O.M. (1974). Acta Hort. 36: 113. Stone, O.M.
(1980). Acta Hort. 110: 177. Stone, O.M. and Hollings, M. (1971). Rep.
Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1970, p. 153. Stone, O.M. and Hollings, M. (1976).
Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1975, p. 119. Stone, O.M. and Hollings, M.
(1977). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1976, p. 121. Welvaert, W. and Samyn,
G. (1985). Acta Hort 164: 341. Welvaert, W. and Samyn, G. (1988). Acta Hort.
234: 165. Welvaert, W., Samyn, G. and De Simpelaere, P. (1982). Med. Fac.
Landb. Rijksuniv. Gent. 47: 1033.


Pelargonium vein clearing (?) cytorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PVCV (PelVCV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 62.U.P.0.038. (8) First reported in Pelargonium peltatum. (9)
From southern Italy. (10) By Russo et al. (1979). (13) Pelargonium peltatum,
P. zonale mild vein clearing. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. rustica, N. tabacum,
N. debneyi, N. megalosiphon, Capsicum annuum, Petunia × hybrida chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions in older plants, but systemic vein clearing, chlorotic
vein banding and leaf malformation of seedlings inoculated 4 leaf-stage.
Gomphrena globosa small red local lesions; not systemic. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Beta vulgaris.
(45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N.
glutinosa (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Pelargonium peltatum, or Pelargonium zonale, or Petunia × hybrida.
(48) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Geraniaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <9/9>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60 °C.
(55) LIV: 2 days <at 2224°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (70) Virions of 250 nm <in sections>, or 175 nm <purified
virions>. (71) Virions 70 nm wide <in sections>, or 90 nm wide <purified
virions>. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 30-35 nm in diameter.
(74) Basic helix obvious. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, vascular
parenchyma and the phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in the
perinuclear space. (179) <Possible> Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Di Franco, A., Russo, M. and Martelli, G.P. (1979).
Phytopathol. Medit. 18: 41. Quacquarelli, A. and Gallitelli, D. (1979).
Phytopathol. Medit. 18: 61. Russo, M., Castellano, M.A. and Martelli, G.P.
(1979). Phytopath. Z. 96: 122.


Pelargonium zonate spot ourmiavirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PZSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 79.0.P.4.009. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From
Apulia, Southern Italy. (10) By Martelli and Cirulli (1969). (11) Symptoms
disappear soon after infection. (13) Lycopersicon esculentum concentric yellow
bands, then necrotic stunting. Cynara scolymus foliar malformations.
Chrysanthemum segetum yellow mottling. Diplotaxis erucoides symptomless.
Pelargonium zonale concentric yellow bands. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36)
Studies reported by Gallitelli (1982); Quacquarelli et al. (1969); Vovlas et
al. (1986). (39) Spreads in Italy <Apulia>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana glutinosa
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic and marginal necrosis.
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi chlorotic rings, systemic mottling. Cucurbita
pepo chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, death. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic
or necrotic local lesions. Lycopersicon esculentum concentric yellow bands,
then necrosis. (44) Callistephus chinensis, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
benthamiana, Ocimum basilicum, Pisum sativum. (45) Cucumis sativus,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cv. Xanthi. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L), Cucumis sativus (W), Nicotiana
glutinosa (W), Vigna radiata (L). (47) Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chrysanthemum segetum, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cynara scolymus, or Diplotaxis erucoides, or
Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pelargonium
zonale, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Callistephus chinensis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Datura
stramonium, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Ocimum basilicum, or Pisum sativum,
or Solanum melongena, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <2/4>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<5/6>, or Solanaceae <4/7>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/4>, or
Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/6>, or Solanaceae <3/7>. (53)
Quacquarelli et al. (1979); Gallitelli (1982); Vovlas et al. (1986). (54) TIP:
40 °C. (55) LIV: 0.3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix with formaldehyde before mounting
in KPT. (60) Method: Gallitelli; homogenise Nicotiana glutinosa leaves in 20mM
sodium phosphate containing 20 mM sodium thioglycollate and 20 mM DIECA,
clarify by adjusting pH to 4.8, and precipitate virions with PEG. (61) Virions
bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 35 nm in length. (71)
Virions 25 nm wide. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 118 S <BV, which
is probably an aggregate of TV>. (78) Of the other(s) 80 S <TV>, or 90 S <MV>.
(79) Density 1.286 g cm3 in CsCl <Cs2SO4>, or 1.346 g cm3 in CsCl <CsCl;
formaldehyde-stabilised virions>. (84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid <TV>,
or 18 % nucleic acid <MV>, or 18 % nucleic acid <BV>. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 7.7 kb. (92) Genome of two
parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 4.4 kb. (94) The 2nd
largest 3.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli; use
phenol-SDS. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is of unknown origin and
function. (122) Nongenomic nucleic acid perhaps a satellite-like RNA is
associated with some strains. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000.
(145) Method of preparation: Gallitelli (1982). (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis
and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in nucleoli.
(178) Other cellular changes: damage of chloroplasts and vesicles containing
fibrillar material. (179) <Possible> ourmiavirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: alfalfa mosaic, apple mosaic, arabis mosaic,
artichoke Italian latent, artichoke mottled crinkle, artichoke vein banding,
broad bean wilt, brome mosaic, carnation ringspot, cherry leaf roll, cherry
rasp leaf, chicory yellow mottle, cacao necrosis, cucumber mosaic, grapevine
Bulgarian latent, grapevine chrome mosaic, grapevine fanleaf, myrobalan latent
ringspot, pelargonium leaf curl, prune dwarf, prunus necrotic ringspot, radish
mosaic, raspberry bushy dwarf, raspberry ringspot, southern bean mosaic,
sowbane mosaic, tobacco necrosis, tobacco ringspot, tobacco streak, tomato
black ring, tomato ringspot, Tulare apple mosaic and turnip yellow mosaic
viruses. (184) The virus shares properties with epirus cherry, cassava Ivorian
bacilliform, olive latent 2 and melon Ourmia viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: serology and host range. (187) Castellano, M.A. and Martelli, G.P.
(1981). Phytopathol. Medit. 20: 64. Gallitelli, D. (1982). Ann. appl. biol.
100: 457. Gallitelli, D., Martelli, G.P. and Quacquarelli, A. (1983). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 272, 4 pp. Martelli, G.P. and Cirulli, M. (1969).
Phytopathol. Medit. 8: 154. Quacquarelli, A. and Gallitelli, D. (1979).
Phytopathol. Medit. 18: 61. Vovlas, C., Gallitelli, D. and Difranco, A.
(1986). Inform. Fitopatol. 36: 9.


Pepino mosaic potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: PepMV. (5) ICTV decimal code

(39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana

Pepper Indian mottle potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1990. (2) Synonyms: chilli mottle virus, Indian pepper
mottle virus. (3) Standard acronym: IPMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.045.
(8) First reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From the Punjab, India. (10) By
Sandhu and Chohan (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Capsicum annuum systemic
mottling and leaf malformation, including narrowing and split tips. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae, Aphis gossypii, A. craccivora. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies
reported by Sandhu and Chohan (1979). (39) Spreads in India. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis showing first on youngest
leaves usually as vein clearing. (43) Capsicum annuum systemic mottle.
Capsicum frutescens cv. Tabasco necrotic local lesions, then systemic
necrosis. Physalis floridana systemic mottle. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum
cv. Turkish systemic mottle. Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions.
(44) Chenopodium album, Gomphrena globosa, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
rustica, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Cucurbita pepo. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor. (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Cucurbita pepo, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum nigrum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Antirrhinum majus, or
Benincasa hispida, or Chenopodium album, or Citrullus lanatus, or Citrullus
vulgaris var. fistulosis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis melo var. momordica, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lagenaria cineraria, or
Luffa acutangula, or Luffa cylindrica, or Momordica charantia, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or
Pisum sativum, or Triticum aestivum, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna radiata, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/12>, or Solanaceae <8/11>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<1/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <11/12>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>,
or Scrophulariaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <3/11>. (53) Sandhu and Chonan
(1979). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: pepper mottle and potato Y viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: tobacco mosaic, tobacco etch,
potato X and cucumber mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Indian
pepper mottle virus (PeMV-I) can be distinguished from tobacco mosaic (TMV),
cucumber mosaic (CMV) and potato X virus (PVX) viruses which naturally infect
chilli (Capsicum annuum) in India by host range, serology and virion
morphology. In India chilli (Capsicum annuum) is also infected by potyviruses
such as potato Y virus (PVY; Jayarajan and Ramakrishna, 1969; Joshi and
Bhargava, 1962; Khatri and Sekhon, 1984) and pepper veinal mottle (PVMV;
Bidhari and Reddy, 1981; Prasadrao, 1976). PeMV-I, as reported by Sandhu and
Chohan (1979) from the Punjab, can be distinguished from the potyviruses by
the reactions of six pepper cultivars (Avelar, Agronomico-S, Yolo Y, Early
Calwonder, Fla-23-1-7 and Tabasco) as recommended by Zitter (1973); its host
range is similar to that reported by Purcifull et al. (1975). (187) Bidhari
and Reddy (1981). 3rd Int. Symp. Pl. Path. New Delhi session XXII, p. 129.
Jayarajan and Ramakrishna (1969). Madras Agric. J. 56: 761. Joshi, B.S. and
Bhargava, K.S. (1962). Indian J. Microbiol. 2: 29. Khatri and Sekhon (1984).
Indian J. Mycol. Pl. Path. 4: 121. Nelson, M.R., Wheeler, R.E. and Zitter,
T.A. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 253, 4 pp. Prasadrao, R.D.V.
(1976). Ph.D. Thesis, U.A.S., Hebbal, Bangalore, India. Purcifull, D.E.,
Zitter, T.A. and Hiebert, E. (1975). Phytopathology 65: 559. Sandhu, K.S. and
Chohan, J.S. (1979). Indian J. Mycol. Pl. Path. 9: 177. Zitter, T.A. (1973).
Pl. Dis. Reptr 57: 991.


Pepper mild mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: PMMsV (PMMV). (5) ICTV

Venezuela. (10) By Debrot et al. (1980). (13) Capsicum annuum chlorotic

Venezuela. (43) Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum systemic leaf
chlorosis. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa (W) (Ladera et al., 1982). (47) Capsicum

in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Unassigned potyvirus.
