Pepper mild mottle tobamovirus

      (1) C. Wetter, 1987. (2) Synonyms: Samsun latent strain of tobacco
mosaic virus, pepper mosaic virus (Cohen and Ben-Josef, 1989; Tanzi et al.,
1988). (3) Standard acronym: PMMoV (PMMV). (4) Strains: capsicum mosaic virus;
Samsun latent virus, pepper unusual strain, also isolate P8 of tobacco mosaic
virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Capsicum
annuum. (9) From South Carolina, U.S.A. (10) By McKinney (1952). (11) Symptoms
persist, or vary seasonally. (13) Capsicum spp. mild chlorosis and stunting,
especially if plants infected when young. Fruits are small, malformed, mottled
and some have necrotic depressions. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a
vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in Argentina, Australia, Denmark, France, Hungary, Iceland, Italy,
Japan, the Netherlands, Spain, the UK, and the USA. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Datura metel local necrosis and abscission. Datura
stramonium small necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Capsicum
chacoense, C. praetermissum severe systemic necrosis. Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
sylvestris, N. tabacum cvs White Burley and Xanthi-nc small necrotic local
lesions; not systemic. (44) Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana
rustica. Many other species in the Solanaceae are susceptible, but not
Lycopersicon esculentum or Nicotiana glauca. (45) Capsicum frutescens and
cultivars of Capsicum annuum that are immune to tobacco mosaic virus. (46)
Nicotiana glutinosa (L), N. sylvestris (L), Datura stramonium (L), Chenopodium
quinoa (L), C. amaranticolor (L). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum baccatum,
or Capsicum cardenasii, or Capsicum chacoense, or Capsicum chinense, or
Capsicum eximium, or Capsicum frutescens, or Capsicum microcarpum, or Capsicum
praetermissum, or Capsicum pubescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Physalis floridana. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glauca, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <19/22>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/22>. (53) Wetter et al.
(1984); Wetter and Conti (1987). (54) TIP: 95 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 30
days <i.e several months>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-8 <Wetter and Conti, 1984>.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Wetter et al. (1984). (61) Virions
<rigid> rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 312 nm. (71) Virions
18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 4 nm in diameter. (74)
Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix <c.> 2.3 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (82) Isoelectric point pH
3.38-3.71. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12239. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): M81413 Em(40)_vi:PPPSLF Gb(84)_vi:PPPSLF Nucleotide sequence of the
genomic RNA of the tobamovirus Pepper mild mottle virus, strain S, 1 sequence.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (145) Method of preparation: Fraenkel-Conrat
(1957). (147) Amino acid composition: Wetter et al. (1984); Creaser et al.
(1989). (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and phloem. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and unusual in shape. (176)
Aggregates layered in angles. (177) They contain virions. (179) Tobamovirus.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tobacco mosaic, tobacco
mild green mosaic, tomato mosaic, odontoglossum ringspot, ribgrass mosaic,
sunn-hemp mosaic and cucumber green mottle viruses. (187) Cohen, S. and
Ben-Josef, R. (1989). Hassadeh 70: 394. Creaser, W., Gibbs, A.J. and Pares,
R.D. (1987). Australas. Pl. Path. 16: 85. Marte, M. and Wetter, C. (1986). Z.
PflKrankh. PflPath. PflSchutz. 93: 37. McKinney, H.H. (1952). Pl. Dis. Reptr
36: 184. Paludan, N. (1982). Acta Hort. 127: 65. Pares, R.D. (1985). Ann.
appl. Biol. 106: 469. Tanzi, M., Betti, L., Bertaccini, A. and Canova, A.
(1988). Phytopath. Medit. 27: 28. Tobias, J., Rast, A.Th.B. and Maat, D.Z.
(1982). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 88: 257. Wetter, C. (1984). Plant Dis. 68: 597.
Wetter, C. and Conti, M. (1987). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 330. Wetter, C.,
Conti, M., Altschuh, D., Tabillion, R. and van Regenmortel, M.H.V. (1984).
Phytopathology 74: 405.


Pepper mild tigré (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) J.K. Brown, 1989. (2) Synonyms: tigre disease geminivirus. (3)
Standard acronym: PepMTV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.029. (8) First
reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From Mexico. (10) By Brown et al. (1989).
(11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (13) Capsicum annuum cvs Jalapeno
and Serrano mild yellow leaf curling and mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18)
Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Mexico and the USA <Texas>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Capsicum annuum cvs Anahiem, Serrano and Tabasco
systemic yellow leaf curling. Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Pole Boy systemic
yellow mosaic or leaf curling. (44) Cucumis melo cv. Topmark, C. sativus cv.
Straight eight, Gossypium hirsutum cv. DP90, Malva parviflora, Glycine max cv.
Frost beater. (45) Lycopersicon esculentum, Capsicum annuum. (46) Capsicum
annuum (W), Lycopersicon esculentum (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Lycopersicon esculentum. (48) Cassia obtusifolia, or
Chenopodium album, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus,
or Cucurbita maxima, or Glycine max, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus
annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Malva parviflora, or Solanum melongena, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Solanaceae <3/4>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/1>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or
Malvaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/4>. (53) Brown et al. (1989). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix with buffered (pH 7.0)
0.25% glutaraldehyde. (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter.
(65) Virions <dimers> 30 nm in length. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): L27270 Em(40)_vi:GEPEMAC1A
Gb(84)_vi:PEMAC1A Pepper geminivirus replication-associated protein (AC1)
gene, 3' end. 1/94 299bp L27271 Em(40)_vi:GEPEMBC1A Gb(84)_vi:PEMBC1A Pepper
geminivirus movement protein (BC1) gene, partial cds. 1/94 222bp. 2 sequences.
(179) <Possible> bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (186)
Alone, the virus induces mild leaf symptoms in pepper, but peppers also
containing chino del tomaté virus and another uncharacterised whitefly
transmitted virus have the tigré disease. (187) Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R.
(1989). Phytopathology 79: 908. Brown, J.K., Campodonico O.P. and Nelson, M.R.
(1989). Plant Dis. 73: 610.


Pepper Moroccan tombusvirus

      (1) D. Gallitelli, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Moroccan pepper virus. (3)
Standard acronym: MPV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported
in Capsicum annuum. (9) From Morocco. (10) By Fischer and Lockhart (1977).
(11) Symptoms persist and vary cyclically over a few weeks. (12) Symptoms
stunting, leaf malformations, lethal systemic necrosis. (13) Capsicum annuum
stunting, deformation, leaf and flower abscission, lethal systemic necrosis.
Lycopersicon esculentum leaf mottling and malformation, stunting. Pelargonium
zonale leaf malformation, stunting. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a
vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Morocco. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Germany. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic local lesions, systemic
necrosis, stunting. (43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. murale, Cucumis sativus,
Cucurbita pepo, Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Vicia faba necrotic local lesions. Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii, Spinacia oleracea necrotic local lesions;
systemic necrosis. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Capsicum
annuum (W), Datura stramonium (L), Nicotiana benthamiana (W), Nicotiana
glutinosa (L), Spinacia oleracea (W). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Capsicum
annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or
Pelargonium zonale, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13
/13>. (53) Fischer and Lockhart (1977); Vetten and Koenig (1983). (54) TIP:
80-85 °C. (55) LIV: 49-56 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Gallitelli and Russo (1987). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions neither clearly angular or nor rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 140 S. (79) Density 1.36
g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 82 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 4.7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli and Russo
(1987). (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor not required
for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 43000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Laemmli (1970). (171) Virions found in leaves, roots and
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies.
(177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: see Martelli
et al. (1988). (179) Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: artichoke mottled crinkle,
eggplant mottled crinkle, grapevine Algerian latent, pelargonium leaf curl,
petunia asteroid mosaic and tomato bushy stunt viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: carnation Italian ringspot, cymbidium
ringspot and Neckar River tombusviruses. (184) Dot blot hybridization tests
indicate that the virus has 10% nucleotide homology with tomato bushy stunt
tombusvirus. (187) Fischer, H.V. and Lockhart, B.E. (1977). Phytopathology 67:
1352. Gallitelli, D. and Russo, M. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119: 106. Laemmli,
U.K. (1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Martelli, G.P., Gallitelli, D. and Russo,
M. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions with Monopartite
RNA Genomes, p. 13; ed. R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York. Martelli, G.P.,
Russo, M. and Gallitelli, D. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 352. 8pp.
Vetten, H.J. and Koenig, R. (1985). Phytopath. Z. 108: 215.


Pepper mottle potyvirus

      (1) T.A. Zitter and V.R. Mali, 1987. (2) Synonyms: chilli mottle virus.
(3) Standard acronym: PepMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.050. (8) First
reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From Palm Beach County, Delray Beach,
Florida, U.S.A. (10) By Zitter (1972a and b). (11) Symptoms persist and vary
seasonally. (13) Capsicum annuum mottling and malformed leaves. Datura
meteloides mild mottle. Solanum sp. systemic mild mottle. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii,
A. craccivora, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by
Sandhu and Chohan (1979); Zitter (1972a); Zitter and Cook (1973); Purcifull et
al. (1975); Zitter and Ozaki (1978a and b). (39) Spreads in El Salvador,
India, and the USA <Florida, New Mexico, Texas, Arizona and California>. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Capsicum annuum severe systemic leaf
mottling in all susceptible cultivars. Capsicum frutescens necrotic local
lesions; systemic leaf necrosis and death of young Tabasco plants. Datura
meteloides, Lycopersicon esculentum mild systemic mottling. Nicotiana
glutinosa, N. tabacum, Physalis floridana systemic leaf mottling. Chenopodium
amaranticolor necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Capsicum frutescens
cv. Greenleaf Tabasco, Datura metel, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum cv.
`V-20', Solanum tuberosum cv. `Russet Burbank', Nicotiana rustica, Petunia ×
hybrida, Chenopodium album, Gomphrena globosa. (45) Capsicum annuum cv. Early
Calwonder, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa, N. glutinosa × N. clevelandii,
N. tabacum cvs Turkish NN, Havana 425, Xanthi-nc, White Burley, Cucurbita
pepo. (46) Capsicum annuum (W), C. frutescens Tabasco (L) and systemic mottle
and death of young seedlings (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Capsicum
annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura meteloides, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii,
or Physalis floridana, or Solanum nigrum. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or
Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
or Capsicum frutescens <cv. Greenleaf Tabasco>, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium
album, or Cichorium endiva, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Luffa acutangula, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum <cv. V-20>, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Phytolacca americana, or Pisum
sativum, or Solanum tuberosum <cv. Russet Burbank>, or Triticum aestivum, or
Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/3>,
or Cucurbitaceae <1/6>, or Solanaceae <12/17>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <6/6>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or
Phytolaccaceae <1 /1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <7/17>. (53) Nelson and Wheeler (1978); Nelson et al. (1982);
Purcifull et al. (1975); Sandhu and Chohan (1979). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55)
LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: Purcifull et al. (1975). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 737 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(92) Genome unipartite. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12209. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): M11598 Em(40)_vi:PMV38KPA Gb(84)_vi:PMV38KPA Pepper mottle

mottle virus (Italian strain) coat protein gene and 3' non-coding region. 7/94

Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves
and epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176)
With striated lamellae. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: potato Y, tobacco etch and
pepper veinal mottle viruses, but distantly. Peptide analyses show that the
virus has close affinities with potato Y virus (D. Shukla, unpublished
information). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bidens
mottle, lettuce mosaic and turnip mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: see Nelson et al. (1982). (187) Hiebert, E. and McDonald, J.G.
(1973). Virology 56: 349. Nelson, M.R. and Wheeler, R.E. (1978).

Reptr 56: 586. Zitter, T.A. (1972b). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 731. Zitter, T.A.

Pepper ringspot tobravirus

      (1) D.J. Robinson, 1987. (2) Synonyms: artichoke yellow band virus
(Chagas, Flores and Caner, 1970; Harrison and Robinson, 1986), tobacco rattle
virus CAM, tobacco rattle virus serotype III. (3) Standard acronym: PepRSV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 72.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon
esculentum. (9) From Brazil. (10) By Silberschmidt (1962-63). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Capsicum annuum ringspots. Cynara scolymus yellow banding.
Lycopersicon esculentum ringspots and yellow banding. Bidens pilosa. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies
reported by reviewed by Harrison (1977). (38) Spreads in the South and Central
American region. (39) Spreads in Brazil. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Cucumis
sativus chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana tabacum
cv. Samsun NN necrotic rings and lines, systemic. N. tabacum cv. White Burley
symptomless, systemic. Phaseolus vulgaris pinpoint necrotic local lesions, not
systemic. Pisum sativum and Vicia faba small necrotic local lesions, not
systemic. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. White Burley. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Bidens pilosa, or Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cynara scolymus, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum
basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <11/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1
/1>. (54) TIP: 80-85 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 42 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: preservation in
uranyl formate/NaOH. Fine detail in UA. (60) Method: Harrison and Nixon
(1959). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 52
and 197 nm. (71) Virions 22 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial
canal 4 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix
2.5 nm. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest (long) virions> 305 S. (78) Of the
other(s) 163 S <short virions>. (79) Density 1.306 g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>.
(80) Density 1.27 g cm3 in sucrose. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.15. (84) Virions
contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 9.6 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 7.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.1 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Harrison and Nixon (1959); Darby and Minson, (1972); Cooper
and Mayo, (1972). (100) Base composition 25.5 % G <RNA-1>, or 24.3 % G
<RNA-2>. (101) Base composition 29.5 % A <RNA-1>, or 26.1 % A <RNA-2>. (102)
Base composition 16.5 % C <RNA-1>, or 17.6 % C <RNA-2>. (103) Base composition
28.5 % U <RNA-1>, or 32 % U <RNA-2>. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated
nucleotide cap <reported only on RNA-1, but probably on both>. (108)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region
absent. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (114) Genome has
no tRNAlike activity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Bergh et al.
(1985). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31750. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
L23972 Em(40)_vi:PPNRNA Gb(84)_vi:PPNRNA Pepper ringspot viral 12k, 29k 136k
and 195k protein RNA, complete cds. 11/93 6,828bp. 1 sequence. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
22000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Semancik (1970);
Ghabrial and Lister (1973). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins identified by
genomic sequence analysis <Bergh et al. (1985)>. (153) Three proteins found.
(154) Mr <of the largest> 170000. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 140000. (158) Mr of
3rd 30000. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (165) Coat protein mRNA
translated in the cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant, except xylem. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm <mostly near mitochondria, but not in them>. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells <by NM forms>. (175) Inclusions are
amorphous Xbodies. (179) Tobravirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: tobacco rattle and pea early-browning viruses, but distantly.
(184) Although there is distant sequence homology with other tobraviruses,
these are not usually detected in hybridization tests. (186) For many years
pepper ringspot virus was thought to be a serotype of tobacco rattle virus,
and some research work did not distinguish between them. (187) Bergh, S.T.,
Koziel, M.G., Huang, S.C., Thomas, R.A., Gilley, D.P. and Siegel, A. (1985).
Nucl. Acids Res. 13: 8507. Chagas, C.M., Flores, E. and Caner, J. (1970).
Biologico 35: 271.Cooper, J.I. and Mayo, M.A. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 16: 285.
Darby, G. and Minson, A.C. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 14: 199. Ghabrial, S.A. and
Lister, R.M. (1973). Virology 52: 1. Harrison, B.D. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 12, 4 pp. Harrison, B.D. (1977). Ann. Rev. Phytopath. 15: 331.
Harrison, B.D. and Nixon, H.L. (1959). J. gen. Microbiol. 21: 591. Harrison,
B.D. and Robinson, D.J. (1986). In: The Plant Viruses Vol 2, The Rod-Shaped
Viruses, p. 339; eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel and H. Fraenkel-Conrat. Plenum
Press, New York. Robinson, D.J. and Harrison, B.D. (1989). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 347, 4 pp. Semancik, J.S. (1970). Virology 40: 618. Silberschmidt,
K. (1962-63). Phytopath. Z. 46: 209.


Pepper severe mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: PeSMV. (4) Strains:
PSMV/type, PSMV20, PSMV127 and PSMV151. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.051.
(8) First reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From San Juan, Argentina. (10) By
Feldman and Gracia (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Capsicum annuum
necrotic spots and streaks in leaves and stems, leaf abscission, then
chlorotic leaves. Fruit yield greatly decreased. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora,
Macrosiphum euphorbiae and, except for type strain, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (36) Studies reported by Feldman and Gracia (1977). (39) Spreads in
Argentina. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions; not systemic. Nicandra physalodes,
Nicotiana debneyi, N. rustica, N. tabacum local lesions, followed by systemic
vein-clearing mosaic and/or chlorotic rings. Capsicum annuum, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. sylvestris systemic leaf mottling and
malformation. (44) Datura stramonium, Solanum tuberosum, Gomphrena globosa,
Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana tabacum, N. sylvestris.
(46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L), Nicotiana tabacum
(L,W), Nicotiana debneyi (L,W), Nicandra physalodes (W). (47) Capsicum annuum,
or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Datura metel, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium,
or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis
peruviana, or Solanum nigrum. (48) Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <16/18>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<5/5>, or Solanaceae <2/18>. (53) Feldman and Gracia (1977). (54) TIP: 85-90
°C. (55) LIV: 32-64 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7 <values for type strain,
but some strains less stable>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Feldman and Gracia (1977). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 761 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12210. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X66027 Em(40)_vi:PSMVCP Gb(84)_vi:PSMVCP Pepper
Severe Mosaic Virus genomic RNA for coat protein. 6/92 1,329bp. 1 sequence.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels.
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tobacco etch
and potato Y viruses, but very distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: pepper mottle, pepper veinal mottle and turnip mosaic
viruses. (187) Feldman, J.M. and Gracia, O. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 89: 146.


Pepper Texas bigeminivirus

      (1) D.C. Stenger, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Texas pepper virus. (3) Standard
acronym: TPV. (4) Strains: distortion strain, yellow mosaic strain. (5) ICTV
decimal code 29.0.3.0.036. (8) First reported in Capsicum annuum. (9) From
Texas, U.S.A. (10) By Stenger et al. (1990). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms leaf curl, malformation and stunting or mosaic. (13) Capsicum annuum
leaf curling, malformation, vein clearing and stunting (distortion strain);
mosaic, vein clearing and stunting (mosaic strain). (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci.
(18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Mexico and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show leaf curl, malformation, stunting, vein
malformation, mosaic. (43) Capsicum annuum leaf curl, malformation, stunting,
vein malformation. Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum mosaic, vein
clearing, stunting. Nicotiana benthamiana mosaic, vein clearing, leaf curl,
stunting. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis melo, Malva parviflora, Phaseolus
vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), Capsicum
annuum (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus,
or Cucumis melo, or Cucurbita maxima, or Gomphrena globosa, or Malva
parviflora, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50) Solanaceae <7/7>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/1>. (52) Restricted to
Solanaceae. (53) Stenger et al. (1990). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(59) Electron microscopy: stain with UA. (60) Method: Stein et al. (1983);
Stenger et al. (1990). (61) Virions geminate <isometric virions also present>.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions
<dimers> 40 nm in length. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 88 S. (78) Of the other(s) 50 S.
(88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total
genome size 5.2 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 2.6 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.6 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by : extracting in phenol/ chloroform, precipitate with ethanol.
(112) Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic
acid not found in the virions. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves
and roots. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae.
(180) : Geminiviridae. (184) Texas pepper geminivirus DNA A has homology with
tomato golden mosaic virus DNA A. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: DNA A cross
hybridizes with the A DNAs of other bipartite geminiviruses. DNA B does not
hybridize with other geminivirus DNAs. (187) Stenger, D.C., Duffus, J.E. and
Villalon, B. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 704. Stein, V.E., Coutts, R.H.A. and
Buck, K.W. (1983). J. gen. Virol. 64: 2493.


Pepper veinal mottle potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: PVMV. (4) Strains: isolates
differ in host range and pathogenicity. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.052.
(8) First reported in Capsicum annuum, C. frutescens, Petunia × hybrida. (9)
From Tafo, Ghana. (10) By Brunt and Kenten (1971). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Capsicum annuum, C. frutescens mottle, leaf shape malformation. Datura
stramonium mosaic, fruit malformation, with spine suppression. Lycopersicon
esculentum mosaic and necrotic or chlorotic spots and streaks. Petunia ×
hybrida mottle and mosaic. Datura metel, Nicotiana tabacum, Solanum
integrifolium, S. melongena, S. nigrum mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, A.
spiraecola, Myzus persicae, Toxoptera citricidus. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana,
Kenya, Nigeria, and South Africa. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. foetidum local chlorotic or necrotic
ringspots. Capsicum annuum, C. frutescens systemic mosaic, mottle and leaf
shape malformation. Nicotiana clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, N. occidentalis,
Physalis angulata, P. floridana systemic mosaic. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Dutch A
local necrotic or chlorotic ringspots. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Beta vulgaris,
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana sylvestris.
(45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N. megalosiphon, N. occidentalis,
Petunia × hybrida. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), C.
foetidum (L) at 20-24°C. (47) Ageratum conyzoides, or Allium cepa, or Brassica

capitata, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum

Perilla mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PerMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.069. (8) First reported in Perilla frutescens. (10) By Lee et al.
(1980). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Perilla frutescens leaf mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions. Perilla frutescens systemic leaf
mottling. (44) Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Perilla frutescens. (46)

Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Perilla frutescens, or Vicia faba. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or

angularis, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae

Petunia asteroid mosaic tombusvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: tomato bushy stunt virus petunia
strain (Martelli et al., 1971). (3) Standard acronym: PeAMV (PAMV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 74.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Petunia × hybrida. (9) From
Italy. (10) By Lovisolo (1957). (13) Petunia × hybrida yellow stellate spots
in leaves, leaf distortion and flower colour breaking. Humulus lupulus yellow
mottling and leaf distortion. Ligustrum vulgare, Cornus sanguinea chlorotic
leaf spotting. Prunus avium leaf veinal necrosis and distortion, leaves
bunched, shoots stunted with bark splitting, fruits with sunken pits. Prunus
domestica pox-like markings on fruits. Spinacia oleracea Vein clearing, leaf
mottling and distortion and stunting. Vitis vinifera symptoms unknown as the
virus only found in mixtures with others. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (15) Probably abiotically in soil. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (38) Spreads in
the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Canada, the former Czechoslovakia,
Germany, Switzerland, the UK, and the former Yugoslavia. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local
lesions or necrotic lesions. (47) Cornus sanguinea, or Humulus lupulus, or
Ligustrum vulgare, or Petunia × hybrida, or Prunus avium, or Prunus domestica,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Vitis vinifera. (50) Cannabidaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cornaceae <1/1>, or Oleaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>, or Vitidaceae <1/1>. (60) Method: Ambrosino et al.
(1967). (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
134 S. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl <unfixed>. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated
by Ambrosino et al. (1967). (100) Base composition 28 % G. (101) Base
composition 27 % A. (102) Base composition 22 % C. (103) Base composition 23 %
U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41000. (134) Coat protein. (179)
Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: Tomato bushy stunt, carnation Italian ringspot,
pelargonium leaf curl viruses. (186) The virus was previously identified in
some European countries and Canada as tomato bushy stunt virus. (187)
Albrechtova, L., Chod, J. and Zimandl, B. (1975). Phytopath. Z. 82: 25. Allen,
W.R. (1968). Can. J. Bot. 45: 229. Allen, W.R. and Davidson, T.R. (1967). Can.
J. Bot. 45: 2375. Ambrosino, C., Appiano, A., Rialda, G., Papa, G., Redolfi,
P. and Carrara, M. (1967). Alti Acc. Sci. Torino 101: 301. Eric, Z., Stefanac,

Petunia vein clearing (?) caulimovirus

      (1) D.-E. Lesemann, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PVCV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 15.0.1.T.004. (8) First reported in Petunia × hybrida hort. cv.
Himmelsroeschen. (9) From Germany. (10) By Lesemann and Casper (1973). (11)
Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms chlorotic vein clearing,
leaf malformation. (13) Petunia × hybrida hort. cv. Himmelsroeschen chlorotic
clearing and banding of leaf veins, leaf malformation, stunting of sprouts.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted
by grafting. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Germany. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
vein clearing, leaf malformation. (43) Petunia spp. vein clearing, chlorotic
vein banding and leaf distortion. (45) Petunia spp. (47) Petunia × hybrida.
(50) Solanaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 43-46 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular
parenchyma, phloem and the companion cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm
and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are viroplasms and unusual in shape. (176) Proliferation of endoplasmic
reticulum. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes:
proliferation of endoplasmic reticulum into multilayers, surrounding the
virion-containing regions which also contain the dark staining, viroplasm like
rounded and vacuolated inclusions. (179) <Tentatively> Caulimovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cauliflower mosaic and dahlia
mosaic viruses. (187) Casper, R., Lesemann, D.-E. and Fischer, D. (1973).
Proc. 7th Conf. Czechoslovak Pl. Virologists, High Tatras 1971, Slovak Acad.
Sci., Bratislava, p. 247. Lesemann, D.-E. and Casper, R. (1973).
Phytopathology 63: 1118.


Phleum green stripe (?) tenuivirus

      (1) K. Bremer, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.T.DE.4. (8) First
reported in Phleum sp. (9) From Finland. (10) By Heikinheimo and Raatikainen
(1976). (13) Phleum spp. green stripes in leaves. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Megadelphax
sordidula, Dicranotropis hamata. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Megadelphax sordidula. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (36) Studies reported by Heikinheimo and Raatikainen (1976):
crop rotation and plough early in autumn. (39) Spreads in Finland. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show light green or yellow leaf stripes,
seed wrinkling and stunting. (43) Phleum pratense, Avena sativa, Triticum
aestivum, Hordeum vulgare light green or yellow leaf stripes, seed wrinkling
and stunting. (44) Dactylis glomerata, Festuca pratensis, F. rubra, Lolium
multiflorum. (45) Phleum pratense, Avena spp. (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Phleum, or Phleum pratense, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Dactylis
glomerata, or Festuca pratensis, or Festuca rubra, or Lolium multiflorum. (50)
Gramineae <5/9>. (51) Gramineae <4/9>. (179) <Possible> Tenuivirus. (187)
Gingery, R.E. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 4, The Filamentous Viruses,
p.303. ed. R.G. Milne. Plenum Press, New York. Heikinheimo, O. and
Raatikainen, M. (1976). Ann. Agric. Fenn. 15: 34.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: turnip latent virus disease complex

vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon
(Aulocorthum) solani, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not
transmitted by Aphis nasturtii, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus (Sciamyzus)
ascalonicus. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (39) Spreads in Canada.

chlorosis; conspicuous chlorotic vein-netting leaf symptoms when present in

vulgaris, Spinacia oleracea, Brassica campestris ssp. napus, B. campestris
ssp. rapa, Datura bernhardii symptomless systemic infection. (44) Chenopodium
album, Capsicum annuum, Datura metel, D. stramonium, Petunia × hybrida and
Solanum tuberosum. (46) Physalis floridana (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Datura
bernhardii, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicandra physalodes, or Physalis
floridana, or Raphanus sativus, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Capsicum annuum, or
Chenopodium album, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/3>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or
Solanaceae <5/8>. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (184) Physalis mild chlorosis
(?) luteovirus is possibly a strain of beet western yellows luteovirus. (187)
MacKinnon, J.P. (1956). Can. J. Bot. 34: 131. MacKinnon, J.P. (1965). Can. J.

faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/6>, or Compositae <2/4>, or Gramineae <1/3>, or Solanaceae
<19/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/6>, or Compositae <2/4>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or

changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions.

one. (133) Mr 20000. (134) Coat protein. (146) Amino acid sequence: Jacob et
al. (1991). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (179) Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: belladonna mottle and dulcamara mottle viruses.
(183) Most of the plant species inoculated with physalis mosaic virus or with
belladonna mottle virus (I) isolate reacted similarly however Chenopodium
quinoa and Solanum nigrum were infected by the latter and not the former.
(184) Slight cross protection with Andean potato latent and dulcamara mottle
viruses. (187) Jacob, A.N.K., Murthy, M.R.N. and Savithri, H.S. (1991). J.

Physalis vein blotch (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: turnip latent virus disease complex
(part; MacKinnon, 1956). (3) Standard acronym: PhyVBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.T.010. (8) First reported in Physalis floridana. (9) From Canada. (10)
By MacKinnon and Lawson (1966). (13) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa symptomless
infection, even in complex with physalis mild chlorosis virus. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Physalis floridana
usually symptomless but co-infection with this virus and physalis mild
chlorosis (?) luteovirus induce chlorotic vein-netting. (44) Chenopodium
album, Capsicum annuum, Datura metel, D. stramonium, Petunia × hybrida and
Solanum tuberosum. (46) Physalis floridana (W). (47) Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Physalis floridana. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium album, or
Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum
tuberosum. (50) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <5/6>. (179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (187) MacKinnon, J.P.
(1956). Can. J. Bot. 34: 131. MacKinnon, J.P. (1965). Can. J. Bot. 43: 509.
MacKinnon, J.P. and Lawson, F.L. (1966). Can. J. Bot. 44: 795. Waterhouse,
P.M., Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 339,
9 pp.


Pigeonpea proliferation (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) Y.L. Nene, 1981. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: pigeonpea witches'
broom virus, pigeonpea rosette virus. (3) Standard acronym: PPPV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 62.U.P.0.039. (8) First reported in Cajanus cajan. (9) From
Dominican Republic. (10) By Hirumi et al. (1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Cajanus cajan stunting, bushiness, although leaf size normal, base of midrib
of young leaflets chlorotic, rough brown surface of branches. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by possibly the
leafhopper, Empoasca papayae. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in the Dominican Republic, Haiti, Jamaica, Papua New
Guinea, Puerto Rico, Taiwan, and Trinidad and Tobago. (47) Cajanus cajan. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped <MLOs
also found>. (179) <Possible> unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(187) Hirumi, H., Maramorosch, K. and Hichez, E. (1973). Phytopathology 63:
202. Maramorosch, K., Hirumi, H. and Kimura, M. (1974a). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull.
22: 32. Maramorosch, K., Hirumi, H., Kimura, M., Bird, J. and Vakili, N.G.
(1974b). Phytopathology 64: 582. Maramorosch, K., Kimura, M. and Nene, Y.L.
(1976). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 24: 33.


Pigeonpea sterility mosaic (?) virus

      (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.31. (13) Cajanus cajan. (47) Cajanus
cajan. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (179) (Ungrouped). (186) The
pathogen causing the sterility mosaic disease of pigeonpea Cajanus cajan in
India is transmissible by mites (Aceria cajani) and by grafting, and has long
been considered to be virus-induced (Capoor, 1952). However, as no virus has
been isolated from, or detected in, affected plants during recent intensive
investigations, the pathogen is still unknown (Wendy Sachs, personal
communication). (187) Capoor, S.P. (1952). Ind. J. agric. Sci. 22: 274.

(61) Virions bacilliform, or rhabdo or bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear

Pineapple wilt-associated (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and U.B. Gunasinghe, 1988. Updated 1991. (2) Synonyms:
pineapple mealybug wilt-associated (?) closterovirus (Gunasinghe et al., 1989;
Ullman et al., 1989). (3) Standard acronym: PMWaV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.T.2.02. (8) First reported in Ananas comosus cv. Smooth Cayenne. (9)
From Hawaii. (10) By Carter (1933). (11) Symptoms persist, vary seasonally,
and disappear soon after infection. (13) Ananas comosus yellowing and
flaccidity of young leaves, necrosis of leaf tips; plants wilt and may die.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Pseudococcus brevipes. (18) Transmitted by Pseudococcidae. (25) Transmitted
in a semipersistent manner <possibly>. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Gunasinghe and German (1986;
1988). (39) Spreads in the USA <Hawaii>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Ananas comosus young leaves become yellow and flacid with brown and
necrotic tips. Plants wilt. (45) Ananas comosus. (46) Ananas comosus (W). (47)
Ananas comosus <cv. Smooth Cayenne>. (50) Bromeliaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Gunasinghe and German (1977). Extract
tissue in 0.5M Tris, followed by PEG precipitation and differential
centrifugation. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 1200-1500 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (81) Density 1.2 g cm3 in
caesium sulphate. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.1 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 7.1 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000.
(171) Virions found in leaves and phloem. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: detection of dsRNA can be used for diagnosis
(Gunasinghe and German, 1986; 1988). (186) The virus can be eliminated from
planting stock by hot water treatment of "crowns" for up to 120 minutes at
50°C. (187) Carter, W.C. (1933). Phytopathology 23: 207. Gunasinghe, U.B. and
German, T. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 1073. Gunasinghe, U.B. and German, T.
(1987). Phytopathology 77: 1776. Gunasinghe, U.B. and German, T. (1988).
Phytopathology 78: 1584. Gunasinghe, U.B. and German, T.L. (1989).
Phytopathology 79: 1337. Ullman, D.E., German, T.L., Gunasinghe, U.B. and
Ebesu, R.H. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 1341. Ullman, D.E., German, T.L.,
McIntosh, C.E. and Williams, D.D.F. (1991). Plant Dis. 75: 859.

Pittosporum vein yellowing nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and G.L. Rana, 1991. (2) Synonyms: pittosporum vein
clearing virus (Plásic et al., 1976, 1978; Rana and Di Franco, 1979, 1980),
tomato vein yellowing virus, eggplant mottled dwarf virus. (3) Standard
acronym: PVYV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.0.003. (8) First reported in
Pittosporum tobira. (9) From Liguria, Italy. (10) By Corte (1957). (11)
Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms stunting, bushy
appearance, vein yellowing and mottling, fruit malformation and size
reduction. (13) Pittosporum tobira clearing and chlorotic banding of major
leaf veins. Lycopersicon esculentum stunting, vein yellowing and curling of
leaves, yellow spots on fruit. Solanum melongena stunting, vein yellowing,
leaf mottling and crinkling, fruit malformation and size reductions. Hibiscus
rosa-sinensis, Lonicera sp. vein yellowing. Solanum sodomaeum severe mosaic.
(24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae, Aphis fabae, Aphis spiraecola,
Toxoptera aurantium, Aphis gossypii, Macrosiphum spp. (Rana and Di Franco,
1979; El Maataoui et al., 1985). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the seed. (39) Spreads in Italy. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in Yugoslavia and Libya. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local
lesions, followed by systemic vein-clearing, leaf curling, veinal necrosis,
leaf blade, malformation, mottle, top necrosis. (43) Capsicum annuum systemic
vein-clearing and leaf curling. Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic vein
clearing and leaf malformations. Gomphrena globosa, Datura stramonium
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana spp. chlorotic
local lesions; systemic vein-clearing and often veinal necrosis and death of
plants. Lycopersicon esculentum systemic vein clearing and leaf curling. (44)
Anagyris foetida, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo, Celosia cristata, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Solanum tuberosum, Vigna radiata. (45) Lycopersicon esculentum,
Nicotiana alata, N. benthamiana, N. clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. glutinosa, N.
rustica, N. tabacum cv. White Burley. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L), Nicotiana
glutinosa (L and W), Nicotiana benthamiana (L and W), N. rustica (L and W), N.
alata (W), N. clevelandii (W), Solanum melongena (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, or Lonicera, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicotiana alata,
or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana cavicola, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glauca, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
langsdorffii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis
floridana, or Physalis ixocarpa, or Pittosporum tobira, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum sodomaeum. (48) Anagyris foetida, or Celosia
cristata, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Solanum tuberosum, or Vigna radiata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or
Pittosporaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <23/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae
<1/24>. (53) Rana and Di Franco (1979); El Maataoui et al. (1985); Camele et
al. (1991). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 0.12 days <2 hours at about 18°C>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: at
present, no good purification method is known. However, good results were
obtained for the TVYV and EMDV isolates using the procedures described by El
Maataoui et al. (1985). and Adam et al. (1987). (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 95-310 nm. (71) Virions
80-96 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 30 nm in diameter.
(74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4-5 nm. (132) Virion
protein(s) four. (134) G protein. (136) N protein. (138) M1 protein. (140) M2
protein. (145) Method of preparation: Laemmli (1970); Adam et al. (1987).
(146) Amino acid sequence: Adam et al. (1987). (148) Virion proteins
glycosylated. (149) Are and it is the G protein. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, vascular parenchyma
and flowers of the eggplant isolate (Russo and Martelli, 1972). (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm and in the perinuclear space. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: less dense nuclei and nucleoli.
Perinuclear gaps between the lamellae of the nuclear envelope. Cell wall
protrusions contain unusually long rhabdovirus virions. (179)
Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: tomato vein yellowing and eggplant mottled
dwarf viruses (Adam et al., 1987; Martelli and Cherif, 1987; Camele et al.,
1991). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cynara
rhabdovirus. (184) Pittosporum vein clearing rhabdovirus is very closely
related, if not identical, to a Moroccan isolate of TVYV (=EMDV) (Camele et
al., 1991). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: 1) sap inoculation of Nicotiana
benthamiana using fresh young infected leaves of Pittosporum tobira as
inoculum (Rana and Di Franco, 1979). 2) Inoculate Cucurbita pepo to
distinguish from cucumber mosaic virus which also infects Pittosporum (Rana,
1980). 3) Gel diffusion tests using sap of infected Nicotiana benthamiana
(Camele et al., 1991; Adam et al., 1987). (187) Adam, G., Gnagas, C.M. and
Lesemann, D.-E. (1987). Phytopathology 120: 31. Camele, I., Nuzzaci, M., Rana,
G.L., Lafortezza, R., De Stradis, A., Pace, G. and Palumbo, M. (1991). Inform.
Pat. Agrario. Corte, A. (1957). Riv. Ortoflorofruitticol. Ital. 41: 97. Di
Franco, A., Russo, M. and Martelli, G.P. (1980). J. gen. Virol. 49: 209. El
Maataoui, M. and Lockhart, B.E.L. (1982). Phytopathology 72: 478. El Maataoui,
M., Lockhart, B.E.L. and Lesemann, D.-E. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 109.
Horvath, J. (1973). Acta bot. Croat. 32: 25. Laemmli, U.K. (1970). Nature,
Lond. 227: 680. Lockhart, B.E.L. (1987). Plant Dis. 71: 731. Martelli, G.P.
and Cirulli, M. (1969). Annls. Phytopath. 1: 393. Martelli, G.P. and Cherif,
C. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119: 32. MilicHicH, D. (1977). Proc. 8th Conf. Czech.
Pl. Virol., Bratislava. Plavsic, B., Corte, A. and MilicHicH, D. (1976).
Phytopathol. Medit. 15: 115. Plavsic, B., MilicHicH, D. and Eric, Z. (1976).
Phytopath. Z. 86: 225. Plavsic, B., MilicHicH, D. and Eric, Z. (1978).
Phytopath. Z. 91: 67. Rana, G.L. (1980). Inf. tore Fitopatol. 30(4): 7. Rana,
G.L. and Di Franco, A. (1979). Phytopathol. Medit. 18: 48. Rana, G.L. and Di
Franco, A. (1980). Acta Hort. 110: 191. Russo, M. and Martelli, G.P. (1972).
Phytopathol. Medit. 11: 136.

Plantain 7 (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PlV-7. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.070. (8) First reported in Plantago lanceolata. (9) From U.K. (10) By
Hammond (1981). (13) Plantago lanceolata symptomatology not described (virus
found only in complex with others). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus sp. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K.
(Cambridge). (43) Nicotiana benthamiana faint leaf chlorosis. (47) Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Plantago lanceolata. (50) Plantaginaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions
of 720-750 nm. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Hammond,
J. (1981). Pl. Path. 30: 237.


Plantain 8 (?) carlavirus

      (1) J. Hammond, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PlV-8. (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.T.1.026. (8) First reported in Plantago lanceolata. (9) From the U.K.
(10) By Hammond (1981). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Plantago lanceolata occurs
only with other viruses, but alone possibly causes no conspicuous symptoms.
(15) Presumably transmitted by aphids. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in the UK. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in England (Cambridge). (43) Cucumis sativus, Plantago lanceolata
symptomless. (47) Cucumis sativus, or Plantago lanceolata. (50) Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Plantaginaceae <1/1>. (53) Hammond (1980). (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 600-640 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus. (187) Hammond, J. (1980). Ph.D.
Thesis, University East Anglia, U.K.. Hammond, J. (1981). Pl. Path. 30: 237.


Plantain mottle (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: plantain mottle virus (Smith, 1972).
(3) Standard acronym: PlMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.042. (8) First
reported in Plantago lanceolata. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Hitchborn et al.
(1966). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Plantago lanceolata mottling of younger
leaves and necrotic spotting of older leaves. (39) Spreads in the UK. (47)
Plantago lanceolata. (50) Plantaginaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or
bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 330 nm
<in sap>. (71) Virions 63 nm wide <in sap>. (179) <Possible> unassigned
rhabdovirus. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Hitchborn, J.H., Hills, G.J. and
Hull, R. (1966). Virology 28: 768. Smith, K.M. (1972). In: A Textbook of Plant
Viruses, p.388, 3rd edition. London, Longman.


Plantain X potexvirus

      (1) J. Hammond, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PlVX. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Plantago lanceolata. (9) From Great
Britain. (10) By Hammond and Hull (1981). (13) Plantago lanceolata no obvious
symptoms. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies
reported by Hammond (1982). (39) Spreads in the UK. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii systemic necrotic flecking
when grown in bright light. N. × edwardsonii necrotic flecking of inoculated
and systemically infected leaves (white ringspots at 32°C). Plantago rugelii
spreading local and systemic necrotic spots. (44) Tetragonia tetragonioides,
Montia perfoliata, Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena
globosa. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. × edwardsonii. (46) Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii (W) and Plantago rugelii (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Plantago lanceolata, or Plantago rugelii, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Momordica
balsamina, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Pisum sativum, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/4>, or Plantaginaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <10/11>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Hammond and Hull (1981). (54) TIP: 60-70
°C. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fixation
not necessary. Best detail with UA and UF. (60) Method: Hammond and Hull
(1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (62) Virions sometimes have a loose external
helical structure in negatively stained epidermal dips (Hammond and Hull,
1981). (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 570-580 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious <in UA or UF>. (75)
Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 119 S. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in
CsCl. (81) Density 1.259 in Cs2SO4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.19 <partially
corrected>. (85) Virions 94-95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.5
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.5 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Wilcockson and Hull; the SDS sodium
perchlorate method; or the phenol-chloroform method is probably equally as
efficient. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 26000. (134) Coat protein.
(145) Method of preparation: Francki and McLean (1968). (147) Amino acid
composition: Hammond and Hull (1981). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Whorl-like arrays. (177) They contain
virions. (179) Potexvirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: cactus X, clover yellow mosaic, cymbidium mosaic, narcissus mosaic,
papaya mosaic (plantago severe mottle strain), potato X and white clover
mosaic viruses. (184) No significant sequence homologies were found between
plantago X, potato X and papaya mosaic viruses by cDNA/RNA hybridization.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: Plantain X virus does not infect Gomphrena
globosa, whereas the plantago severe mottle strain of papaya mosaic virus
does. The latter also does not infect Plantago lanceolata and Nicotiana spp.
(187) Gracia, O., Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E. (1983). Phytopathology 73:
1488. Hammond, J. (1977). Rep. John Innes Inst. 1976, p.109. Hammond, J.
(1983). Adv. Virus Res. 27: 103. Hammond, J. and Hull, R. (1981). J. gen.
Virol. 54: 75. Hammond, J. and Hull, R. (1983). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
266, 4 pp. Rowhani, A. and Petersen, J.F. (1980). Can. J. Pl. Path. 2: 12.
Wilcockson, J. and Hull, R. (1974). J. gen. Virol. 23: 107.

Plum American line pattern ilarvirus

      (1) R.W. Fulton, 1985. (2) Synonyms: plum line pattern virus, peach line
pattern virosis virus, prunus virus 10, American plum line pattern virus. (3)
Standard acronym: APLPV. (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.05.01. (8) First
reported in Prunus americana × P. salicina (Shiro plum). (9) From Wenatchee,
Washington, U.S.A. (10) By Kirkpatrick et al. (1964). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (13) Prunus domestica, P. serrulata, P. cerasus, P. cerasifera, P.
americana × P. salicina, P. persica line patterns and chlorotic rings. (38)
Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in Canada and the USA
<CABI/EPPO data>. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; systemic
veinbanding, mottles, ringspots. (43) Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica tiny
red local lesions; systemic red vein necrosis. Cucumis sativus, Chenopodium
quinoa small local lesions, not systemic. Nicotiana megalosiphon, N.
occidentalis chlorotic or diffuse necrotic local lesions, systemic ringspots
or mottles. Physalis floridana inconspicuous chlorotic local lesions, systemic
chlorotic veinbanding ringspots, or oak-leaf. Petunia × hybrida chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions, systemic necrosis. Most species of the Leguminosae
show local necrosis, but many are not very susceptible. Some isolates infect
Gomphrena globosa and Lactuca sativa. (44) Antirrhinum majus, Gomphrena
globosa, Lactuca sativa, Torenia fournieri, Tithonia speciosa. (45) Nicotiana
megalosiphon, N. occidentalis, Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, Catharanthus
roseus, Prunus domestica. (46) Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica (L),
Nicotiana megalosiphon (W). (47) Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lactuca sativa, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Prunus
americana × P. salicina, or Prunus cerasifera, or Prunus cerasus, or Prunus
domestica, or Prunus persica, or Prunus serrulata, or Sesbania exaltata, or
Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Zinnia elegans.
(48) Antirrhinum majus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa,
or Momordica balsamina, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or
Physalis peruviana, or Phytolacca americana, or Tithonia speciosa, or Torenia
fournieri. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/3>, or Compositae <2/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/6>, or Rosaceae <6/6>, or Solanaceae <12/13>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <3/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/6>, or Phytolaccaceae
<1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2
/13>. (53) Paulsen and Fulton (1968); Kirkpatrick et al. (1964). (54) TIP: 66
°C. (55) LIV: 0.2 days <4 hours in sap stabilized with 2-mercaptoethanol. In
undiluted sap, infectivity is lost within seconds>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7.
(59) Electron microscopy: treatment with 1% glutaraldehyde of virions
suspended in 0.03 M EDTA. (60) Method: Fulton (1982); Paulson and Fulton
(1969). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26,
28, 31, and 33 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Four sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 125
S. (78) Of the other(s) 95, 100, and 114 S <all four are needed for
infection>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.67 <unseparated components>. (84) Virions
contain 14 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 86 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome <probably> consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome
<probably> of three parts. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (179) Ilarvirus:
Bromoviridae <subgroup 5>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: prunus necrotic ringspot, prune dwarf,
tobacco streak, asparagus 2, citrus leaf rugose, citrus variegation, elm
mottle, Tulare apple mosaic, apple mosaic, lilac ring mottle and spinach
latent viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: American plum line pattern
virus is one of three different viruses that may cause line pattern symptoms
in plum and other Prunus spp. The other two are apple mosaic virus and some
strains of prunus necrotic ringspot virus, which cause line pattern symptoms
worldwide. Serological tests are required for unequivocal identification.
(187) Cation, D. (1941). Phytopathology 31: 1004. Fulton, R.W. (1982).
Phytopathology 72: 1345. Fulton, R.W. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
280, 4 pp. Kirkpatrick, H.C., Cheney, P.W. and Linder, R.C. (1964). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 48: 616. Kirkpatrick, H.C. and Fulton, R.W. (1976). In: Virus Diseases
and Non Infectious Disorders of Stone Fruits in North America. U.S. Dep.

Phytopathology 58: 766. Paulsen, A.Q. and Fulton, R.W. (1969). Ann. appl.
Biol. 63: 233.


Plum pox potyvirus

      (1) H. Kegler and D. Sutic', 1991. (2) Synonyms: prunus virus 7,
Scharka-Virus, Sarka virus. (3) Standard acronym: PPV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.054. (8) First reported in Prunus domestica. (9) From Bulgaria. (10)
By Atanasoff (1932). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms leaf mottling and
fruit malformation. (13) Prunus armeniaca fruits pale rings and deformation;
stones pale rings. P. cerasifera latent, occasional mild pale green mottling.
P. domestica pale green mottling, light green or yellow rings, spots or lines,
some brown necrotic spots; fruits blue, shallow depressions or ringlike
discolouration, deeply engraved rings and spots of the skin, flesh turns brown
and gum like, fruit drop; shoots split and die back. P. glandulosa, P. persica
vein clearing, chlorotic blotching and malformation of leaves; fruits develop
pale rings and diffuse bands on the skin, some malformation. P. insititia, P.
spinosa, P. salicina symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. spiraecola,
Brachycaudus helichrysi, B. cardui, Myzus persicae, M. varians, Myzus
(Phorodon) humuli. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal natural
vector(s): Brachycaudus helichrysi, Myzus persicae, Myzus (Phorodon) humuli.
(24) Not transmitted by Aphophora alni, Edwardsonia plebeja, Hyalopterus
pruni, Lecanium corni, Lygus pratensis, Macrosteles laevis, Myzus cerasi,
Olianus quinquecostatus, Paratetranychus pilosus, Typhlocyba rosae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <in apricots (Nemet and
Kolber, 1983)>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by
Resistant cultivars: Prunus domestica Abundance, Anna Spáth, bessarabische
Zwetsche, Bluefre, Büler Frühzwetsche, Burbank, C'canska lepotica, C'ac'anska
najbolja, C'ac'anska, Carpatin Czar, Czernowitzer, Chrudimer, Ersinger,
Fecunda, Graf Althans, Grose Grüne Reneklode (distinct sources), Herman
Jalomita, Kirkes Pflaume, Montfort, Nancymirabelle, Ontariopflaume, Opal,
Oullins, Pamjatj vavilova, Pitestean, President, Ruth Gerstetter, Schöne von
Löwen, Stanley, St. Hubertus, Tuleu gras, Valor, Valjevka, Vengerka posdnjaja,
Zucker pflaume. Prunus armeniaca Stella, Early Orange, Harcot, Nanno, Badami.
Prunus persica var. nectarina Crimson gold, Fanthasia, May Grand. Prunus
persica TS1TS10, Andross, Coronado, June Berta, Ranger, Rio Oso Gem. Krczal
and Kunze (1976); Marenaud et al. (1976); Jordovic' (1967); Minoiu (1973);
Verderevskaja et al. (1983). (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (38) Spreads
in the African region, the Eurasian region, and the Mediterranean region. (39)
Spreads in Albania, or Austria, or Bulgaria, or Cyprus, or the former
Czechoslovakia, or Egypt, or France, or Germany, or Greece, or Hungary, or
Italy, or Luxembourg, or Poland, or Portugal, or Romania, or Spain, or Syria,
or Turkey, or the UK, or the former USSR, or the former Yugoslavia. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions, mild pale green leaf mottling and leaf
malformation. (43) Chenopodium foetidum yellow spots, some with necrotic
centres or necrotic spots; not systemic. Nicandra physalodes black-brown
necrotic local lesions. Prunus domestica cvs Italian Prune and Poz'egac'a
chlorotic rings, bands and spots. P. japonica diffused chlorotic spots. P.
maritima chlorotic spots, vein necrosis. P. sibirica green spots and faint
line pattern. P. tomentosa epinasty and malformation of young leaves,
chlorotic spots, necrotic spots of older leaves. Sorbus domestica yellow
spots, leaf chlorosis. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Crataegus monogyna,
Malus domestica, Prunus avium, Pyrus communis. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
clevelandii, N. occidentalis, Stellaria media. (46) Chenopodium foetidum (L),
Nicandra physalodes (L), Nicotiana acuminata (W), N. benthamiana (W), N.
clevelandii (W), Ranunculus arvensis (L). (47) Capsella bursa-pastoris, or
Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Emilia sagittata, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Humulus lupulus, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lupinus albus,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Melilotus albus, or Melilotus officinalis, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana acuminata, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or

5/95 411bp. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr <of the largest> 43500.
(135) Mr of 2nd largest 29000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 27000. (146) Amino acid
sequence: Kerlan and Dunez (1976); Rankovic' (1976). (164) Genome replicates
<probably> in cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, xylem, flowers, buds, fruits,
bark and young shoots. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies, pinwheels,
and unusual in shape. (176) Needle shaped (Ples'e et al., 1969) and are
protein paracrystals (Bovey, 1971). (177) They do not contain virions. (178)
Other cellular changes: firstly paracrystals appear, then they become
surrounded polysomal membranes. Evaginations of external nuclear envelope
(Bovey, 1971). Chloroplasts may become invaginated. Increased nucleoprotein
synthesis and numbers of ribosomes (Rankovic', 1974). (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: potato Y virus, but distantly (Grüntzig and Fuchs, 1979). (183)
Various strains have been distinguished by symptoms in Chenopodium foetidum:
yellow strain, intermediate strain, necrotic strain (Sutic' et al., 1971).
Pathotypes are distinguished by their ability to infect systemically resistant
genotype K4: CG strain, D1 strain (Kegler et al., 1991). In France, the
south-western ecotype is more virulent than the south-eastern one (Marenaud et
al., 1976). Two serotypes closely related have been reported (Kerlan and
Dunez, 1979). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serological tests, local lesion
hosts and Petri dish test. Plums are commonly also infected with prunus
necrotic ringspot (PNRV), prune dwarf (PDV), apple chlorotic leaf spot (ACLSV)
and plum line pattern virus (PLPV). The following differential host reactions
allow the mixtures to be sorted: + = symptoms appear = latent 0 = no
infectable host Chenopodium foetidum: PPV +, PNRV 0, PDV 0, ACLSV +, PLPV - C.
quinoa: PPV 0, PNRV +, PDV 0, ACLSV +, PLPV + Celosia argentea: PPV 0, PNRV 0,
PDV 0, ACLSV +, PLPV 0 Cucumis sativus: PPV 0, PNRV +, PDV +, ACLSV 0, PLPV +
Sesbania exaltata: PPV 0, PNRV -, PDV +, PLPV Prunus serrulata: PPV 0, PNRV +,
PDV +, ACLSV -, PLPV . (187) Adams, A.N. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 125.
Atanasoff, D. (1932). Jahrb. Univ. Sofia Agr. Fak. 11: 49. Baumann, G. (1968).
Tagungsber. DAL DDR, Berlin 97: 211. Bovey, R. (1971). Annls. Phytopath. 225.
Bovey, R. (1973). Plant Virology, Prague 91, p. 125. Casper, R. (1975). Acta
Hort. 44: 171. Casper, R. and Meyer, S. (1981). Nach. dtsch. Pflanzenschutzd.
