Poa semilatent hordeivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: PSLV. (4) Strains: mild and
severe strains. (5) ICTV decimal code 32.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in
Elymus trachycaulus, Poa palustris. (9) From Canada. (10) By Slykhuis (1972).
(11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Elymus trachycaulus, Poa
palustris probably symptomless infection or faint transient leaf chlorosis
(but often occurs together with hordeum mosaic and/or oat necrotic mottle
viruses in plants with conspicuous leaf chlorosis). (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Canada <Alberta>. (43) Avena sativa, Triticum aestivum chlorotic leaf mottling
and plant death. (44) Elytrigia repens, Agrostis palustris, Bromus inermis,
Lolium perenne. (45) Avena sativa, Poa palustris. (46) Avena sativa (W),
Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Elymus trachycaulus, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Lolium multiflorum, or Phleum pratense, or Poa compressa, or Poa
palustris, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum, or Zea
mays. (48) Agrostis alba, or Agrostis palustris, or Agrostis tenuis, or Bromus
inermis, or Elytrigia intermedia, or Elytrigia repens, or Lolium perenne. (50)
Gramineae <11/18>. (51) Gramineae <7/18>. (53) Slykhuis (1972). (54) TIP: 67
°C. (55) LIV: 120 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Lane (1974). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 162 nm. (71) Virions 25 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 15.6 kb. (92) Genome of four parts.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4 kb. (95) The
3rd largest 3.6 kb. (96) The 4th largest 3.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Lane (1974). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12328. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): M81486 Em(40)_vi:PSZBETACD Gb(84)_vi:PSZBETACD Poa
semilatent virus beta genomic segment, 3' proximal end. 12/92 795bp. M81487
Em(40)_vi:PSZGAMRNA Gb(84)_vi:PSZGAMRNAP Poa semilatent virus gamma genomic
segment, 3' terminal end. 12/92 1,519bp. 2 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 23000. (134) And it is coat protein. (179) Hordeivirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: barley stripe mosaic and lychnis
ringspot viruses. (183) Several that differ in pathogenicity have been
described. (184) The genome of the virus does not cross-hybridize with those
of barley stripe mosaic or lychnis ringspot viruses using cDNAs transcribed
from them. (187) Carroll, T.W. (1986). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 2, The
Rod-Shaped Plant Viruses, p. 388; eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel and H.
Fraenkel-Conrat. Plenum Press, New York. Hunter, B.G., Heaton, L.A., Bracker,
C.E. and Jackson, A.O. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 322. Hunter, B.G., Smith,
J., Fattouh, F. and Jackson, A.O. (1989). Intervirology 30: 18. Jackson, A.O.,
Hunter, B.G. and Gustafson, G.D. (1989). Ann. Rev. Phytopath. 27: 95. Lane,
L.C. (1974). Virology 58: 323. Pólak, Z. and Slykhuis, J. (1972). Can. J. Bot.
50: 263. Slykhuis, J. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 508.


Poinsettia (?) alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: PnCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
49.0.3.T.006. (8) First reported in Euphorbia pulcherrima. (9) From Germany.
(10) By Koenig and Lesemann (1980). (13) Euphorbia pulcherrima no symptoms.
(36) Studies reported by Preil et al. (1982); Paludan et al. (1982). (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Germany. (47) Euphorbia pulcherrima.
(50) Euphorbiaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 28 nm in diameter <may be of two sizes 26 nm and 31 nm diameter>.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 120 S. (179) <Possible> Alphacryptovirus:
Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (184) As plants may be freed of virus
by meristem or cell culture, it may not be a typical cryptovirus (Boccardo et
al., 1987). (187) Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1987).
Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171. Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E. (1980). Plant Dis. 64:
782. Paludan, N. and Begtrup, J. (1986). Tidsskr. PlAvl. 86: 283. Preil, W.,

193.


Poinsettia mosaic (?) tymovirus

      (1) P.L. Guy, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: PnMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
77.0.1.T.019. (8) First reported in Euphorbia pulcherrima. (9) From Wisconsin,
U.S.A. (10) By Fulton and Fulton (1980). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally, or
disappear soon after infection. (13) Euphorbia pulcherrima, E. fulgens
systemic mosaic and malformation. Bracteoles malformed and may not develop
their full cream or red colouration. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, Germany, the UK, and
the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Euphorbia cyathophora (syn.
E. heterophylla) systemic leaf mosaic. Nicotiana benthamiana patches of
irregular chlorosis in systemically infected leaves. (44) Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Gomphrena
globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, Euphorbia
cyathophora. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), Euphorbia cyathophora (W). (47)
Datura stramonium, or Euphorbia cyathophora, or Euphorbia fulgens, or
Euphorbia marginata, or Euphorbia pulcherrima, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta patellaris, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Dahlia pinnata, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Lactuca sativa, or Lilium
formosanum, or Linum usitatissimum, or Momordica balsamina, or Papaver
nudicaule, or Pastinaca sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or
Ricinus communis, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium repens, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Euphorbiaceae <4/5>, or Solanaceae <6/6>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/6>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/5>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or
Liliaceae <1 /1>, or Linaceae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Papaveraceae
<1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (53) Fulton and Fulton (1980); Lesemann et al.
(1983); Meyer et al. (1986); Paludan and Begtrup (1986). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C.
(55) LIV: 8-10 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4 <and greater>. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Lesemann et al. (1983); Koenig et al.
(1986). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26-29
nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 112-117 S. (78)
Of the other(s) 50-55 S. (79) Density 1.41 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.29 g cm3 in
CsCl <T; when fixed in 9% formaldehyde>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 7. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.8 <B>, or 1 <T>. (84) Virions contain 37 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 63 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 2-2.3 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 2-2.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Pfannenstiel et al. (1982); Lesemann et al. (1983). (100) Base composition
20.5 % G. (101) Base composition 24.1 % A. (102) Base composition 31.3 % C.
(103) Base composition 24.1 % U. (133) Mr 21700. (145) Method of preparation:
Pfannenstiel et al. (1982); Lesemann et al. (1983). (147) Amino acid
composition: Pfannenstiel et al. (1982). (164) Genome replicates <probably> in
association with chloroplasts <in vesicles>. (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm, in nucleoli, and in chloroplasts. (173) Virions
found in the vacuole. However, only empty components (T) are found in the
nucleus. (178) Other cellular changes: vesicle formation by invagination of
the inner chloroplast membrane only (in contrast to definitive tymoviruses in
which the invaginations have a double membrane). (179) <Possible> Tymovirus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: 11 tymoviruses. (187)
Fulton, R.W. and Fulton, J.L. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 321. Koenig, R. and
Lesemann, D.-E. (1980). Plant Dis. 65: 781. Koenig, R., Lesemann, D.-E. and
Fulton, R.W. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 311, 4 pp. Lesemann, D.-E.,
Koenig, R., Huth, W., Brunt, A.A., Phillips, S. and Barton, R.J. (1983).
Phytopath. Z. 107: 250. Meyer, S., Lesemann, D.-E. and Koenig, R. (1986).
NachrBl. dtsch. PflSchutz., Stuttg. 38: 163. Paludan, N. and Begtrup, J.
(1986). Tidsskr. PlAvl 90: 283. Pfannenstiel, M.A., Mintz, K.P. and Fulton,
R.W. (1982). Phytopathology 72: 252.


Pokeweed mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PkMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.055. (8) First reported in Phytolacca
americana. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Woods (1902). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Phytolacca americana chlorotic leaf mottling. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the USA
<central, southern and eastern states>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Phytolacca americana systemic chlorotic mottling and malformation.
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Gomphrena globosa
chlorosis and necrotic spotting of systemically infected leaves. (45)
Phytolacca americana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Phytolacca americana. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Dahlia pinnata,
or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or
Phytolaccaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or
Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<7/7>. (54) TIP: 70-75 °C. (55) LIV: 10 days <at 25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 776
nm. (71) Virions 12-13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
henbane mosaic, potato Y and tobacco etch viruses. (187) Shepherd, R.J.,
Fulton, J.P. and Wakeman, R.J. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 219. Woods, A.F.
(1902). Bull. Bur. Pl. Ind. US Dep. Agric. 18: 24.


Poplar decline (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: poplar potyvirus, populus virus. (3)
Standard acronym: PV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.072. (8) First reported
in Populus × canadensis, P. tremuloides. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Martin et
al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Populus × canadensis, P. grandidenta,
P. tremuloides chlorotic and/or necrotic leafspots in spring, bronzing and
necrosis of leaves later and, ultimately, death of branches and then trees.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris, P. lunatus, Vigna
unguiculata local chlorotic or necrotic spots; systemic mottling and necrosis.
Nicotiana clevelandii mild systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium quinoa
chloroitc local lesions; no systemic infection. (44) Cucumis sativus,
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Pisum sativum. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii, Phaseolus vulgaris, P. lunatus, Vigna unguiculata. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (W), Vigna unguiculata (W). (47)
Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus lunatus, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Populus grandidenta, or Populus tremuloides, or Populus
× canadensis, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo,
or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum
sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or Salicaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <1/9>.
(51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>,
or Solanaceae <8/9>. (53) Martin et al. (1982). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 1.2
days <at 22°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 805 nm. (71)
Virions 12.6 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Martin, R.R.,
Berbee, J.G. and Omuema, J.O. (1982). Phytopathology 72: 1158.


Poplar mosaic carlavirus

      (1) F.A. van der Meer; J.I. Cooper, 1987. (2) Synonyms: Canadian poplar
mosaic virus (Atanasoff, 1935), poplar latent virus (Matthews, 1979). (3)
Standard acronym: PopMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.024. (8) First
reported in Populus balsamifera. (9) From Bulgaria. (10) By Atanasoff (1935).
(11) Symptoms persist <but the virus is often irregularly distributed in
trees; Van der Meer et al., 1980; Cooper and Edwards, 1981>. (13) Populus
maximowiczii no symptoms (Cooper et al., 1986). P. balsamifera, P. nigra, P.
deltoides subspecies angulata, monilifera and missouriensis, P. trichocarpa,
P. candicans, P. × canadensis; Berg, 1964), P. × interamericana (= P.
trichocarpa × P. deltoides; Van der Meer, 1981) yellow asteroid spotting of
the smaller leaf veins. Very sensitive cultivars may develop necrosis in bark,
petioles and leaf veins, growth of poplars may be severely decreased (Berg,
1964; Castellani, 1966; Biddle and Tinsley, 1971; Van der Meer, 1981) but more
than one virus may be involved. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <Berg, 1962>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting <Corte, 1959;
Blattny et al., 1962>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed <Cooper and Edwards,
1981>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant <Cooper,
1976>. (36) Studies reported by Cooper (1969); Cooper and Edwards (1981); Van
der Meer (1979; 1981); Van der Meer et al. (1980a). Poplar can be freed from
PMV by heat treatment; after 4-10 weeks at 3739°C (Sweet, 1976; Van der Meer,
1981), one cm long tip cuttings are usually virus-free. (39) Spreads in the
Netherlands and the UK <Van der Meer, 1979 and 1981; Cooper and Edwards,
1981>. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Bulgaria (Atanasoff,
1935), Canada (Navratil and Boyer, 1968), China (Xiung Yuying et al., 1984),
former Czechoslovakia (Blattny et al., 1962), Denmark (Kristensen, 1960),
Poland (Benben, 1957), Italy (Corte, 1959), Georgia CIS (Navratil, 1965),
Germany (Brandes, 1963; Schmelzer, 1964), Korea (Yong Jooh et al., 1980), U.K
(Biddle and Tinsley, 1971a) and former Yugoslavia (Perisic, 1951). Also in
Austria, Australia, Belgium, France, Hungary, Ireland, Japan, Luxembourg,
Spain, Switzerland, Turkey, Tanzania, the U.S.A. and Venezuela. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana megalosiphon chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions and systemic mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic local lesions and
systemic vein chlorosis. Vigna unguiculata red or brown local lesions.
Phaseolus vulgaris necrotic local lesions (Van der Meer et al., 1980; 1980a).
(44) Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley, Gomphrena globosa (Luisoni et al.,
1976). (45) Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana
megalosiphon (L and W) (Van der Meer et al., 1980a). (47) Antirrhinum majus,
or Arachis hypogaea, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Daucus
carota, or Glycine max, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lavatera trimestris, or
Lonicera periclymenum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or
Pisum sativum, or Populus balsamifera, or Populus candicans, or Populus
deltoides subspecies angulata, monilifera, missouriensis, or Populus
maximowiczii, or Populus nigra, or Populus trichocarpa, or Populus ×
canadensis, or Populus × interamericana <= P. trichocarpa X P. deltoides>, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or
Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum annuum, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foliosum, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Dianthus barbatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Helianthus annuus, or Lupinus albus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
tabacum <cv. White Burley>, or Senecio vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Trifolium repens, or Verbesina encelioides. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/8>, or Compositae <1/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/10>,
or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1 /1>, or Salicaceae <8/8>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13/15>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/8>, or Compositae <3/4>, or
Cruciferae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/10>, or Solanaceae <3/15>.
(52) Infectious inoculum from poplar does not induce symptoms in Chenopodium
quinoa. However, after passage in Nicotiana megalosiphon, the virus causes
lesions in Chenopodium quinoa and becomes adapted to Chenopodium quinoa and
then induces numerous local lesions and systemic mosaic in it. (53) Berg
(1964); Schmelzer (1966); Luisoni et al. (1976); Van der Meer et al. (1980);
Xiang Yuying et al. (1984). There is some discrepancy between the results in
these five references. (54) TIP: 74 °C <with sap from Nicotiana megalosiphon>.
(55) LIV: 2 days. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Van der
Meer et al. (1980; 1980a). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous <but only slightly>. (69) Virions
with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 675 nm <Biddle and Tinsley, 1971>.
(71) Virions 13 nm wide <Biddle and Tinsley, 1976>. (72) Axial canal obvious
<but only partially and is inconsistent (Boccardo and Milne, 1976)>. (73)
Axial canal <c.> 2 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious, or obscure. (75)
Pitch of basic helix 3.5 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 165 S <Berg, 1964>. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 6.48 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.48 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Boccardo and Milne (1976). (109) Infectivity retained
when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12166. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D13364 Em(40)_vi:MVWTGBCPG
Gb(84)_vi:MVWTGBCPG Poplar mosaic virus (PMV) genes for coat protein, helicase
and other proteins, complete cds. X65102 Em(40)_vi:PMVCOATP Gb(84)_vi:PMVCOATP
Poplar mosaic Virus genomic RNA for coat protein and putative 14 kDa protein.
7/93 1,328bp. 2 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one <plus a fragment>.
(133) Mr 40000 <plus 30000>. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation:
Boccardo and Milne (1976). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll, vascular parenchyma and palisade
cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (173) Virions found in plasmodesmata
occasionally, but were virion-like particles. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells <Boccardo and Milne, 1976; Atkinson and Cooper, 1976; Brunt et
al., 1976>. (178) Other cellular changes: cell wall overgrowths in poplar
caused by poplar mosaic virus (Atkinson and Cooper, 1976), whereas cell wall
structure in Nicotiana megalosiphon was not altered by the virus (Boccardo and
Milne, 1976). Accumulation of endoplasmic reticulum occured in both infected
hosts. Loose wefts of virions have been noted (Atkinson and Cooper, 1976).
(179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
honeysuckle latent virus (Van der Meer et al., 1980; Brunt et al., 1980).
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: pea streak,
chrysanthemum B, potato S, red clover vein mosaic (Berg, 1964), carnation
latent (Berg, 1964; Luisoni et al., 1976), potato M (Berg, 1964; Luisoni et
al., 1976) and shallot latent (Bos et al., 1978) viruses. (184) Poplar mosaic
virus induces necrotic local lesions in inoculated leaves of Phaseolus
vulgaris and Vigna unguiculata, but neither are susceptible to the
serologically related honeysuckle latent virus (Van der Meer et al., 1980).
Although poplar mosaic virus is a carlavirus, its vector is unknown (Berg,
1964; Schmelzer, 1966; Boccardo et al., 1973; Cooper and Edwards, 1981). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: poplar mosaic virus usually occurs alone in poplars.
Potyvirus-like virions have been found in poplars in the U.S.A. (Martin et
al., 1982), that can be distinguished by virion morphology and by serological
tests. (187) Atanasoff, D. (1935). Phytopath. Z. 8: 197. Atkinson, M.A. and
Cooper, J.I. (1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 83: 395. Benben (1957). Roczn. Nauk les.
19: 63 (as cited by Cooper, 1969). Berg, T.M. (1962). Nature, Lond. 194: 1302.

Poplar vein yellowing (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.T.D.11. (8) First
reported in Populus balsamifera. (9) From Canada. (10) By Navratil (1981).
(13) Populus balsamifera clearing and yellowing of leaf veins. (39) Spreads in
Canada. (47) Populus balsamifera. (50) Salicaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo
or bulletshaped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 286
nm <in vivo>, or 290 nm <in sap>. (71) Virions 60 nm wide <in vivo>, or 77 nm
wide <in sap>. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in the
perinuclear space. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Navratil, S. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 245.


Potato 14R (?) tobamovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Molyneux, 1986. (5) ICTV decimal code
71.0.1.T.DE.2. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena × S.
tuberosum ssp. tuberosum. (9) From Peru. (10) By Salazar (1977). (13) Solanum
tuberosum ssp. andigena × S. tuberosum ssp. tuberosum yellowish mosaic on
leaves. (39) Spreads in Peru. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
systemic necrotic rings and line patterns. Chenopodium ambrosioides faint
systemic mosaic. Nicotiana debneyi, N. tabacum cv. Turkish necrotic rings.
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa, N. occidentalis necrotic local lesions.
(44) Trifolium incarnatum, Capsicum annuum, Ocimum basilicum. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana glutinosa (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium capitatum, or

sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon chilense, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis

Solanum tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena × S. tuberosum ssp.
tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum,

repens, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or

<6/10>, or Solanaceae <16/17>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae <1/1>,
or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/10>,
or Solanaceae <1/17>. (53) Salazar (1977). (54) TIP: 95 °C. (55) LIV: <more
than> 64 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (60) Method: Salazar (1978). (61)

Potato A potyvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: potato mild mosaic virus,
potato virus P, Solanum virus 3. (3) Standard acronym: PVA. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.056. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From Eire.
(10) By Murphy and McKay (1932). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum
mild mosaic, leaf surface rough with wavy margins, or symptomless. Potatoes
infected with potato virus A in combination with potato virus X and Y show
crinkle symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Aphis frangulae, A. nasturtii, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (29)
Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission and can help the
vector transmission of another virus <potato aucuba mosaic potexvirus; Clinch
et al., 1936>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in most potato
growing areas>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Samsun systemic vein-clearing and diffuse mottling. N. tabacum cv. White
Burley systemic vein-clearing and dark green vein-banding. Nicandra physalodes
systemic slight vein-clearing and mottle to severe necrosis, rugosity and
stunting. Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium systemic necrosis and death.
(MacLachlan et al., 1953). Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum cv. Aquila (=A6
hybrid) and S. demissum SdA many local lesions. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Samsun. (46) Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum cv. Aquila (L) (Köhler, 1953;
Bartels, 1970), Solanum demissum SdA (L), Nicandra physalodes (W) is useful
for aphid transmission tests with Myzus persicae. (47) Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum
demissum, or Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum. (50)
Solanaceae <6/6>. (54) TIP: 44-52 °C. (55) LIV: 0.5-0.75 days <1218 hours
MacLachlan et al., 1953>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1. (60) Method: Bartels
(1971). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 730
nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide <Brandes and Paul, 1957>. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12215. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): S51667 Em(40)_un:S51667 Gb(84)_vi:S51667 polyprotein potato
virus A PVA, Genomic RNA, 2597 nt. 3/93 2,597bp. X59985 Em(40)_vi:PVACOATM
Gb(84)_vi:PVACOATM Potato virus A RNA 3'-terminal for coat protein and
polymerase. 6/93 1,383bp Z21670 Em(40)_vi:PVCGA Gb(84)_vi:PVCGA Potato virus A
complete genome. 2/94 9,585bp. Z49087 Em(43)_vi:Pvaunibcp Gb(89)_vi:Pvaunibcp
Potato virus A (USA) mRNA for nuclear inclusion b (partial) and coat protein.
4/95 1,108bp. Z49088 Em(43)_vi:Pvamnibcp Gb(89)_vi:Pvamnibcp Potato virus A
(Maine) mRNA for nuclear inclusion b (partial) and coat protein. 4/95 1,110bp.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: potato Y
(common and tobacco veinal necrosis strain), henbane mosaic and tobacco etch
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Potato may be infected by potato A,
potato Y and other potyviruses. They are more easily distinguished
serologically although only potato virus A induces local lesions in Solanum
demissum SdA. (187) Bartels, R. (1970). Potato Res. 13: 119. Bartels, R.
(1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 54, 4 pp. Brandes, J. and Paul, H.L.
(1957). Arch. Microbiol. 26: 358. Clinch, P., Loughnane, J.B. and Murphy, D.A.
(1936). Scient. Proc. R. Dubl. Soc. 21: 431. Köhler, E. (1953). Züchter 23:
173. MacLachlan, D.S., Larson, R.H. and Walker, J.C. (1953). Res. Bull. agric.
Exp. Stn Univ. Wis., 180, 36 pp. Murphy, P.A. and McKay, R. (1932). Scient.
Proc. R. Dubl. Soc. 20: 347.


Potato Andean latent tymovirus

      (1) R. Koenig, 1985. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: Andean potato latent
virus. (3) Standard acronym: APLV. (4) Strains: isolates differ in serological
and electrophoretic properties and symptoms induced (Koenig et al., 1979). (5)
ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum
(groups Phureja, Chaucha and Andigena). (9) From material collected in
tropical Andes. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum symptomless or
sometimes mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector and means not involving a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Epithrix sp. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <less than 1% in Solanum tuberosum>. (38) Spreads in the
South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in Bolivia, Chile, Colombia,
Ecuador, and Peru <CABI/EPPO data>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium quinoa necrotic spots; systemic chlorosis with some strains.
Nicotiana bigelovii, N. clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. megalosiphon severe
mosaic. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana bigelovii,
N. clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana bigelovii (W), N. clevelandii (W). (47)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hyoscyamus
niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or

Potato Andean mottle comovirus

      (1) R. Koenig, 1984. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: Andean potato mottle
virus. (3) Standard acronym: APMoV. (4) Strains: three recognised (Avila et
al., 1984). (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Solanum
tuberosum. (9) From La Molina, Peru. (10) By Fribourg et al. (1975). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum (unknown cultivar) yellow local

transmitted by Epitrix sp. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.

Potato aucuba mosaic potexvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond and D.A. Govier, 1987. (2) Synonyms: potato G
virus, potato virus F, tuber blotch virus. (3) Standard acronym: PAMV. (4)
Strains: potato virus F, synonym of tuber blotch virus (Clinch et al., 1936).
(5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.017. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum.
(9) From the Netherlands and U.K. (10) By Quanjer (1921); Clinch et al.
(1936). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum chlorotic local lesions
on older leaves, necrotic on younger, systemic (top) necrosis (Clinch, 1941).
Stored tubers develop necrosis in the cortex and pith with irregular brown or
sunken patches on the surface. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus requires,
for vector transmission, a helper virus <any potyvirus, such as potato viruses
A and Y; Kassanis and Govier, 1971a;b>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <but uncommon>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Capsicum annuum, C. frutescens necrotic local
lesions then epinasty, systemic mosaic or necrosis, young plants killed.
Nicotiana glutinosa light green mottle with dark green vein-banding.
Lycopersicon esculentum small chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana tabacum cvs
White Burley and Xanthi-nc, Datura stramonium and Petunia sp. systemic
infection but usually symptomless. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc. (46)
Capsicum annuum cv. Long Red (L/W), C. frutescens cv. Early Calwonder (L/W).
(47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Tinantia erecta. (50) Solanaceae
<8/8>. (51) Commelinaceae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 30-60 days <at
18-20°C; Kollmer and Larson, 1960>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (60) Method:
Govier and Kassanis (1972). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 580 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 130 S. (84)
Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base
composition 25 % G. (101) Base composition 30 % A. (102) Base composition 24 %
C. (103) Base composition 21 % U. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12182. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): S73580 Gb(89)_un:S73580 putative polymerase.
capsid protein potato aucuba mosaic potexvirus PAMV. Genomic RNA Complete.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 26000. (171) Virions found in all parts
of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <sometimes in dense
aggregates>. (179) Potexvirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: The symptoms in
potato resemble those of potato mop-top virus (PMTV); both cause necrosis on
the tuber surface, but those of PAMV are less clearly patterned than the
raised necrotic rings caused by first-year infection with PMTV; however, PAMV
sometimes causes necrotic rings. PAMV, but not PMTV, infects Capsicum annuum
systemically, they have virions of different sizes (Harrison and Jones, 1970).
(187) Clinch, P.J. (1941). Scient. Proc. R. Dubl. Soc. N. S. 22: 435. Clinch,
P.J., Loughnane, J.B. and Murphy, P.A. (1936). Scient. Proc. R. Dubl. Sco. N.
S. 21: 431. Harrison, B.D. and Jones, R.A.C. (1970). Ann. appl. Biol. 65: 393.
Kassanis, B. and Govier, D.A. (1971a). J. gen. Virol. 10: 99. Kassanis, B. and
Govier, D.A. (1971b). J. gen. Virol. 13: 221013. Kassanis, B. and Govier, D.A.
(1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 98, 4 pp. Kollmer, G.F. and Larson,
R.H. (1960). Res. Bull. agric. Exp. Stn Univ. Wis. 223. Quanjer, H.M. (1921).
R. hort. Soc., Lond. Rep. int. Potato Conf. 127.


Potato black ringspot nepovirus

      (1) L.F. Salazar, 1987. (2) Synonyms: potato calico strain of tobacco
ringspot virus (Salazar and Harrison, 1978), Andean potato calico strain of
tobacco ringspot virus (Fribourg, 1977). (3) Standard acronym: PBRSV. (4)
Strains: potato calico strain. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.024. (8) First
reported in Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena × S. tuberosum ssp. tuberosum. (9)
From potatoes from Huasa Huasi, Peru. (10) By Salazar and Harrison (1977).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum necrotic ringspots. Potato
calico strain causes general leaf chlorosis in some cultivars, especially cv.
Ticahuasi. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in the South and Central
American region. (39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible.
(43) Beta vulgaris necrotic spots and rings; systemic chlorotic or necrotic
rings. Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Kondine Red systemic necrotic rings spots
and/or line patterns. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba general systemic necrosis.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions; systemic
necrosis. Nicotiana tabacum systemic necrotic ringspots and line patterns.
Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum necrotic spots; systemic necrotic ringspots.
Catharanthus roseus chlorotic spots; systemic necrosis. (45) Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. Samsun, N. benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Chenopodium quinoa (L) and Nicotiana clevelandii (S). (47)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba,
or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Daucus carota, or Dianthus
barbatus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena × S. tuberosum ssp. tuberosum,
or Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>,
or Solanaceae <17/17>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (51)
Gramineae <1/1>. (53) Salazar and Harrison (1978). (54) TIP: 58-60 °C <in
Nicotiana clevelandii sap>. (55) LIV: 9-10 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: it is better to mount virions
in 1% UA. (60) Method: Salazar and Harrison (1978). (61) Virions isometric.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 117 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 84 S <M>, or 49 S
<T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.97 <B>, or 1.78 <M>, or 1.03 <T>. (84) Virions
contain 41 % nucleic acid <B>, or 28 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid
<T>. (85) Virions 59 % protein <B>, or 72 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 11.2
kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger>
7 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Salazar and Harrison (1978). (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 59000. (145) Method of preparation: Salazar
and Harrison (1978). (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Nepovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: tobacco ringspot and eucharis mottle viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, artichoke Italian latent,
cacao necrosis, cherry leaf roll, grapevine fanleaf, myrobalan latent
ringspot, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot, tomato black ring
and tomato ringspot viruses. Although the virus is serologically distantly
related to tobacco ringspot and eucharis mottle viruses, the viruses do not
cross-protect in plants and do not form recombinants; potato black ringspot
virus is, therefore, considered to be a distinct virus. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: serology is the only way to distinguish this virus from others with
which it is often naturally associated. (187) Fribourg, C.E. (1977).
Phytopathology 67: 174. Salazar, L.F. and Harrison, B.D. (1977). Nature, Lond
265: 337. Salazar, L.F. and Harrison, B.D. (1978b). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 387.
Salazar, L.F. and Harrison, B.D. (1978). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 375. Salazar,
L.F. and Harrison, B.D. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 206, 4 pp.


Potato leafroll luteovirus

      (1) J.E. Thomas, 1987. (2) Synonyms: potato phloem necrosis virus
(Quanjer, 1913). (3) Standard acronym: PLRV. (4) Strains: tobacco yellow top
virus, tomato yellow top strain (Sutton, 1955; Thomas, 1984), capsicum yellows
virus (Gunn and Pares, 1990). (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.012. (8) First
reported in Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum. (9) From the Netherlands. (10)
By Quanjer et al. (1916); see Peters (1967). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum pallor or reddening of the tip leaves, which
roll and become erect. Plants grown from infected tubers are stunted, leaflets
upwardly rolled, oldest leaves first. Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena in South
America stunting and marginal yellowing of tip leaves (Rodriguez and Jones,
1978). Lycopersicon esculentum stunting of plants, marginal yellowing and
curling of leaflets, and death of flower buds (Braithwaite and Blake, 1961).
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Myzus persicae is the most efficient and important; Macrosiphum euphorbiae
transmits potato strains less effectively but is a good vector of Australian
tomato yellow top isolates. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in
a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus
does not multiply in the vector <although Weidemann (1982) found that virion
antigen accumulates in the nuclei of cells of the midgut and principal
salivary glands of Myzus persicae 1-2 days after virus acquisition and
suggested that the virus multiplies in these cells>. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide <in potato growing areas. Tomato yellow top
diseases are reported from North America (Alstatt and Ivanoff, 1945), South
America (Costa, 1949) and Australasia (Sutton, 1955), but not all have been
shown to be caused by strains of potato leafroll virus>. (39) Spreads in
China. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Datura stramonium
systemic interveinal yellowing. Physalis floridana systemic interveinal
chlorosis, older leaves slightly rolled, plant stunted. Solanum tuberosum ssp.
tuberosum stunted and leaves rolled. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
Raphanus sativus, Vicia faba. (45) Physalis floridana, Solanum tuberosum. (46)
Physalis floridana (W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris,
or Celosia argentea, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Physalis floridana, or Solanum tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum ssp. andigena,
or Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis,
or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or
Senecio vulgaris, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae
<1/4>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/7>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <3/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (53) Natti et al.
(1953); Thomas (1984); Tamada et al. (1984). (54) TIP: 70-80 °C <in Physalis
floridana sap>. (55) LIV: 5-10 days <Murayama and Kojima, 1965>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Takanami and Kubo
(1979a). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 24
nm in diameter <Peters, 1967; Takanami and Kubo, 1979a>. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
115 S. (79) Density 1.39 g cm3 in CsCl <Rowhani and Stace-Smith, 1979>. (81)
Density 1.34 g/cm3 in Cs2SO4 (Thomas, 1984). (84) Virions contain 30 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 70 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.88-5.99 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 5.88-5.99 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Rowhani and Stace-Smith (1979); Takanami and
Kubo (1979b). (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases.
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110)
Poly A region absent <Mayo et al., 1982>. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12045. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): A07935 Em(40)_vi:07935 Gb(84)_pat:A07935

4/95 1,779bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
subgenomic mRNA <2.66 kb; Barker et al., 1984>. (132) Virion protein(s) two.
(133) Mr <of the larger> 26000. (134) Coat protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
7000. (136) A genome-linked protein (VPg). (145) Method of preparation:
Rowhani and Stace-Smith (1979). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated
<Mayo et al. (1982); Mayo and Barker (1984)>. (153) Three proteins found.
(154) Mr <of the largest> 125000 <Mayo et al., 1982>. (156) Mr of 2nd largest
71000 <Mayo et al., 1982>. (158) Mr of 3rd 29000 <Mayo and Barker, 1984>.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell
vacuoles. (173) Virions found in (Arai et al., 1969; Kojima et al., 1969).
Vesicles occur in the cytoplasm attached to the nucleus and fused with the
nuclear envelope (Shepardson et al., 1980). (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: thickening of walls in primary
phloem cells of stems and petioles, and callose accumulated in some sieve
tubes of tubers. The presence of callose is the basis of various staining
tests (e.g. with 1% Resorcin Blue), used before serological methods were
developed (de Bokx, 1967). (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: tobacco necrotic dwarf (SDI 1), beet western
yellows/beet mild yellowing (SDI 2-4), bean leafroll, subterranean clover red
leaf and barley yellow dwarf viruses (Kubo and Takanami, 1978; Roberts et al.,
1980; Kubo, 1981; Tamada et al., 1984; Thomas, 1984). (187) Altstatt, G.E. and
Ivanoff, S.S. (1945). Pl. Dis. Reptr 29: 29. Arai, K., Doi, Y., Yora, K. and

Potato M carlavirus

      (1) J.A. de Bokx, 1987. (2) Synonyms: Kartoffel-K-Virus,
Kartoffel-Rollmosaik-Virus, potato paracrinkle virus (Bagnall et al., 1959;
Kassanis, 1961; 1963; Salaman and Le Pelly, 1930), potato virus E. (3)
Standard acronym: PVM. (4) Strains: potato leafrolling mosaic virus, potato
American interveinal mosaic virus (Schultz and Folsom, 1923; Bagnall et al.,
1956); Dutch isolates (Rozendaal and van Slogteren, 1958); D1102 and Fortuna
isolates (Köhler, 1953; Wetter and Brandes, 1956). (5) ICTV decimal code
14.0.1.0.025. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Schultz and Folsom (1923); Bagnall et al. (1956). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum symptoms range from very slight (e.g. in cv.
King Edward) to severe (e.g. in cv. Arran Victory). Causes mottles, mosaic,
crinkling and abaxial rolling of leaves, and stunting of shoots. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae (Wetter and Völk, 1960) but less efficiently by Aphis
frangulae, A. nasturtii and Macrosiphum euphorbiae (Bode and Weidemann, 1970);
some isolates not aphid-transmitted (Kassanis, 1961). (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Kassanis (1957). King Edward potato has been freed from potato M,
S and other viruses by apical meristem culture. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide <in potato cultivars>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Datura metel chlorotic or necrotic local lesions then systemic rugose
chlorotic mottle, leaves abscissed, plants stunted and may die. Gomphrena
globosa chlorotic spots with reddish borders; not systemic. Lycopersicon
esculentum symptomless systemic infection. Nicotiana debneyi irregular brown
necrotic ring-like local lesions; not systemic. Solanum rostratum systemic
necrotic streaking of stem, petioles and leaf-veins. (44) Tinantia erecta.
(45) Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum tuberosum cv. Saco. (46) Datura metel
(L), Gomphrena globosa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red Kidney bean (L)
(Hiruki, 1970). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura
metel, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Dianthus caryophyllus,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum
demissum × S. tuberosum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum rostratum, or
Solanum tuberosum, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Tinantia erecta. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <10/10>. (51) Commelinaceae
<1/1>. (53) De Bokx (1984); Vulich and Hunnius (1967); Kowalska and Wás
(1976). (54) TIP: 65-71 °C. (55) LIV: 5-7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3.
(60) Method: Wetter (1960); Proll and Richter (1979). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight <to
slightly curved>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650
nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide <Brandes et al., 1959>. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
8.535 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Proll et al. (1981); Tavantzis
(1984). (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Rupasov (1989). (117) NCBI Taxon
ID: 12167. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00515 Em(40)_vi:PVM3TR
Potato virus M genomic RNA, 3'-terminal region. 2/93 3,164bp. D14449
Em(40)_vi:PTMPVMCG Gb(84)_vi:PTMPVMCG Potato virus M genomic RNA, complete
sequence. 2/93 8,535bp. X53062 Em(40)_vi:POPVMCG Gb(84)_vi:POPVMCG Potato
virus M complete genome. 9/93 8,535bp. X57440 Em(40)_vi:PVMCP Gb(84)_vi:PVMCP
Potato Virus M genes for capsid protein CP and 12 kDa protein. 6/92 1,400bp. 4
sequences. (119) Features of the genome: the sequence of the 3' proximal 2630
nucleotides of the genomic RNA has been determined; five ORF's have been
recognised which encode polypeptides of c. 11000, 34000, 25000, 12000 and
7000. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found
in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies.
(179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
carnation latent, potato S, chrysanthemum B, passiflora latent, cactus 2 and
red clover vein mosaic viruses, but distantly. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
potatoes are often infected with both potato viruses M and S; PVM can be freed
from PVS by inoculating tomato, which is immune to potato virus S, or the
potato cultivar Saco, which is very resistant to potato virus S and X. (187)
Bagnall, R.H., Larson R.H. and Walker, J.C. (1956). Res. Bull. agric. Exp.
Stn. Univ. Wis. 198, 45 pp. Bagnall, R.H., Wetter, C. and Larson, R.H. (1959).
Phytopathology 49: 435. Bode, O. and Weidemann, H.L. (1970). Proc. 4th trienn.
Conf. Eur. Ass. Potato Res. Brest 1969, p. 224. Brandes, J., Wetter, C.,
Bagnall, R.H. and Larson, R.H. (1959). Phytopathology 49: 443. de Bokx, J.A.
(1984). Potato Res. 27: 99. de Bokx, J.A., Piron, P.J.M. and Cother, E.
(1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 285. Hiruki, C. (1970). Phytopathology 60: 739.
Kassanis, B. (1957). Ann. appl. Biol. 45: 422. Kassanis, B. (1960). Nature,
Lond. 188: 688. Kassanis, B. (1961). Eur. Potato J. 4: 13. Köhler, E. (1953).

J. 3: 158.


Potato mop-top furovirus

      (1) J.I. Cooper, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PMTV. (5) ICTV decimal code
27.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From Northern
Ireland, U.K. (10) By Calvert and Harrison (1966). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (13) Solanum tuberosum dwarfing (mopping); chlorotic and necrotic
chevrons and blotching, tuber cracking and necrotic conchoidal layers in
tubers especially in cool weather (15°C). Chenopodiaceae, Solanaceae weeds
species are susceptible and commonly infected in the Andean region of South
America, but not elsewhere. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
a fungus. (17) Transmitted by potato powdery scab fungus Spongospora
subterranea. Virus is retained in spore balls, but virus-free Spongospora has
not been experimentally infected; Jones, 1988. (21) Transmitted by
Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Cooper et al. (1973);
Cooper et al. (1976); Harrison et al. (1970); Jones (1981); Jones et al.
(1972). Virus does not spread to all tubers of infected plants, thus the virus
is maintained by the vector. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the South
and Central American region <in the Andean region>. (39) Spreads in Israel,
Japan, and the UK. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Chile and
Taiwan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana debneyi
systemic necrotic oak leaf patterns. Chenopodium amaranticolor concentric
brown local lesions. (44) Lycium barbarum, Chenopodium capitatum, Solanum
dulcamara. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana debneyi, Nicotiana
clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana debneyi (W), N.
benthamiana (W). (47) Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum
annuum, or Chenopodiaceae, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura ferox, or Datura
stramonium, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or
Solanaceae, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Celosia
argentea, or Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Dianthus
caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gypsophila elegans, or Lobelia erinus,
or Lycium barbarum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Primula malacoides, or Solanum
dulcamara, or Torenia fournieri, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50) Chenopodiaceae <6/7>,
or Solanaceae <17/19>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <4/4>, or
Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/7>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Primulaceae <1/1>,
or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2 /19>. (53) Jones et al. (1972);
Harrison et al. (1970). (54) TIP: 75-80 °C. (55) LIV: <up to> 200 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Kassanis
et al. (1972); Koenig et al. (1984). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 100-150 nm, or 250-300 nm. (71) Virions 18-20 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious <at the ends>. (76)
<Possibly> three sedimenting components in purified preparations <broadbands>.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 236 S <longest most specific infectivity>. (78)
Of the other(s) 126 S, or 171 S. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 37128. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): D16193 Em(44)n:Pxm67kp Gb(90)n:Pxm67kp Potato
mop-top virus RNA 3 for coat protein and 67K readthrough protein, complete
cds. 8/95 2. D30753 Em(43)_vi:Pxmtodd Gb(89)_vi:Pxmtodd Potato mop-top virus
triple gene for 51K protein, 13K protein, 21K protein and 8K protein. 1.
S75140 Em(44)n:S75140 Gb(90)_un:S75140 20 kda coat protein (RNA3) (potato
mop-top furovirus PMTV, isolate T, Genomic RNA, 2315 nt). (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 18500-20000. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are viroplasms and unusual in shape. (176) And small loose sheafs.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: necrosis in arcs or
lines in potato tubers. (179) Furovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: soil borne wheat mosaic virus, and also tobacco mosaic virus,
but very distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
peanut clump, sugarbeet necrotic yellow vein, hypochoeris mosaic and oat
golden stripe viruses. (184) There is no homology (using cDNA or RNA
hybridization) between potato mop top and peanut clump, soil borne wheat
mosaic and beet necrotic yellow vein viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
virion shape and size. Symptoms in Chenopodium amaranticolor, inoculated
leaves. (187) Calvert, E.L. and Harrison, B.D. (1966). Pl. Path. 15: 134.
Cooper, J.I. and Harrison, B.D. (1973). Pl. Path. 22: 73. Cooper, J.I., Jones,
R.A.C. and Harrison, B.D. (1976). Ann. appl. Biol. 83: 215. Harrison, B.D. and
Jones, R.A.C. (1970). Ann. appl. Biol. 65: 395. Harrison, B.D. and Jones,
R.A.C. (1970). Ann. appl. Biol. 67: 377. Jones, R.A.C. (1981). In: Pests,
Pathogens and Vegetation p. 89; ed. J.M. Thresh. Pitman, London. Jones, R.A.C.
(1988). In: Viruses with Fungal Vectors p. 255; eds J.I. Cooper and M. Asher.
Association of Applied Biologists, Wellesbourne, U.K. Jones, R.A.C. and
Harrison, B.D. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 47. Kassanis, B., Woods, R.D. and
White, R.F. (1972). J. gen. Virol. 14: 123. Koenig, R., Lesemann, D.E. and
Burgermeister, W. (1984). Phytopath. Z. 111: 244.


Potato S carlavirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: pepino latent virus (Dolby and
Jones, 1988; Jones et al., 1980). (3) Standard acronym: PVS. (5) ICTV decimal
code 14.0.1.0.026. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the
Netherlands. (10) By de Bruyn Ouboter (1952); Rozendaal (1952). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum causes few or no symptoms, but decreases yield
of potato tubers by up to 20%. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. Isolates differ in their
transmissibility by Myzus persicae (Bode and Weidemann, 1970); an isolate from
the U.S. seedling 41956 could not be transmitted under conditions in which the
related potato virus M was transmitted (Wetter and Völker, 1960). (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by Kassanis (1957). Infected potato, cv. King
Edward has been freed from potato M, S and other viruses by apical meristem
culture. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in cultivated varieties of
potato>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. quinoa, C. album chlorotic local lesions which, in older leaves, may
develop a green halo; not systemic. Solanum rostratum small necrotic local
lesions, systemic necrotic spots. Nicotiana debneyi symptomless in inoculated
leaves; systemic veinclearing and mottling and necrosis. Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba small brown necrotic local lesions in cotyledons, not systemic.
(44) Tinantia erecta. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L); Chenopodium quinoa (L); Chenopodium album (L). (47)
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or

DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (60) Method: Wetter (1960). (61) Virions filamentous.

(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (179) Carlavirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: carnation latent, potato M,
chrysanthemum B, passiflora latent, cactus 2 and red clover vein mosaic
viruses, but distantly. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: In some potato
cultivars potato S virus is found with the related potato M carlavirus. Potato
S virus may be obtained from the mixture by inoculating Nicotiana debneyi
which is systemically infected by potato S virus, but only locally by potato M
virus. (187) Bode, O. and Weidemann, H.L. (1970). Proc. 4th Trienn. Conf. Eur.

Potato T trichovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and L.F. Salazar, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PVT. (5)
ICTV decimal code 76.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9)
From Peru. (10) By Salazar and Harrison (1977). (11) Symptoms disappear soon
after infection. (13) Solanum tuberosum usually symptomless but occasionally
induces mild leaf mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <10-72% in solanaceous hosts>.
(35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by Salazar
and Harrison (1978a). (38) Spreads in the South and Central American region.
(39) Spreads in Bolivia and Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor systemic leaf necrosis. C. quinoa systemic leaf
mosaic and tip necrosis. Datura stramonium mild systemic leaf chlorosis.
Nicotiana debneyi leaf mottling and systemic necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris
necrotic local lesions and systemic necrosis. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46)
Phaseolus vulgaris (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon chilense, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum rostratum, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Apium
graveolens, or Brassica campestris, or Cucumis sativus, or Dianthus barbatus,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Petunia
× hybrida, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium pratense, or Triticum
aestivum, or Zea mays. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <9/9>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<6/7>, or Solanaceae <14/16>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Caryophyllaceae
<1/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/7>, or Solanaceae <2/16>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Salazar and Harrison
(1978a). (54) TIP: 65 °C <in Chenopodium quinoa sap>. (55) LIV: 2-4 days <at
20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Salazar and Harrison (1978b). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 637 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious <when virions mounted in UA>. (75) Pitch of
basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations.
(77) Sedimentation coefficient 99 S. (84) Virions contain 95 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 5 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 7.5 kb. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly
A region at the 3'terminus. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 36403. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): D10172 Gb(84)n:PVTGR Potato virus T genomic RNA,
3'-terminal region. 8/94 2,392bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27000.
(134) Coat protein. (179) Trichovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: apple chlorotic leafspot, potato M, potato S, potato X and

and Tsuchizaki, T. (1992). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 58: 416. Salazar, L.F.

Potato U nepovirus

      (1) R.A.C. Jones, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: PVU. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.0.025. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the Comas
Valley, central Peru, at an altitude of 3600 metres. (10) By Jones et al.
(1983). (13) Solanum tuberosum yellow leaf markings (calico); it is difficult
to infect potato, even by grafting, so it may normally infect another
unidentified plant species, or may mostly infect potato roots and rarely
infect systemically. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a
nematode. (17) Transmitted by Longidorus sp. (P. Jatala and C.E. Fribourg,
unpublished). (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <in
Nicotiana debneyi, N. tabacum, Chenopodium amaranticolor and C. quinoa. It is
readily seed borne in some test plant species and, therefore, seed
transmission may be important for natural spread>. (36) Studies reported by
Jones et al. (1983). (39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic or necrotic spots, then
systemic chlorotic mottle, leaf malformation and necrosis. C. murale necrotic
spots, systemic necrosis. C. amaranticolor chlorotic and necrotic spots,
systemic mottle and leaf malformation, later recovery. Nicotiana tabacum
systemic chlorotic ringspots and line patterns, recovery. Beta vulgaris (red
beet) red ringspots, then systemic red vein banding, plus red rings, spots and
blotches. Cucumis sativus chlorotic blotches, systemic vein clearing,
chlorotic blotching and mosaic, later recovery. (44) Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Phaseolus vulgaris, Capsicum sinensis. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii,
N. tabacum. (46) Chenopodium murale (L and W), C. amaranticolor (W), C. quinoa
(W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium berthaultii, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium
ficifolium, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium glaucum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lycopersicon
chilense, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or
Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia
× hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum chacoense,
or Solanum chancayense, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum demissum × S.
tuberosum, or Solanum goniocalyx, or Solanum megistacrolobum, or Solanum
microdontum, or Solanum mochiquense, or Solanum stoloniferum, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Solanum villosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica.
(48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Capsicum sinensis, or Phaseolus
vulgaris. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <11/11>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/3>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <28/29>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/3>, or Solanaceae <1/29>. (53) Jones et al.
(1983). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 7-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Jones et al. (1983); Fribourg
et al. (1978). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions <c.> 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Four sedimenting components
in purified preparations <three major but one subdivides into two>. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 135 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 117
S <M>, or 55 S <Tb>, or 40 S <Ta>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
58000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Koenig et al. (1970).
(179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: arracacha A, arabis mosaic, artichoke Italian
latent, artichoke vein banding, grapevine chrome mosaic, grapevine fan leaf,
hibiscus latent ringspot, myrobalan latent ringspot, olive ringspot, potato
black ringspot, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot, tobacco
ringspot (eucharis mottle strain), tomato black ring (beet, bouquet and potato
pseudo aucuba strains) and tomato ringspot viruses. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: to distinguish from other potato viruses use gel diffusion and
ISEM. (187) Fribourg, C.E., Jones, R.A.C. and Koenig, R. (1978).
Phytopathology 67: 969. Jones, R.A.C., Fribourg, C.E. and Koenig, R. (1983).
Phytopathology 73: 195. Koenig, R., Stegemann, H., Francksen, H. and Paul,
H.L. (1970). Biochim. biophys. Acta 207: 184.


Potato V potyvirus

      (1) C.E. Fribourg, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: PVV. (4) Strains: PVY-C
Gl (Rozendaal et al., 1971), PVY-C AB (Calvert et al., 1980), UF (Fribourg and
Nakashima, 1983). (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.057. (8) First reported in
Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the Netherlands. (10) By Rozendaal et al. (1971).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum mild or severe mosaic, premature
senescence of lower leaves, green spots or rings, partial vein necrosis of
leaf undersides. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Brachycaudus helichrysi, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in France, Ireland, the
Netherlands, Peru, and the UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana glutinosa and N. occidentalis systemic mosaic and chlorotic vein
banding. N. debneyi local and systemic chlorotic spotting. Solanum demissum PI
230579 necrotic spots; systemic veinal necrosis. S. tuberosum clone `A6'
systemic veinal necrosis. (44) Capsicum annuum, Solanum stoloniferum PI
230557, S. demissum PI 175404. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N.
occidentalis. (46) Nicotiana occidentalis (W), Solanum demissum PI 230579 (L).
(47) Datura metel, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or
Solanum demissum, or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Cajanus
cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Clitoria ternatea, or Cucumis melo, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Matthiola incana, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum
demissum × S. tuberosum, or Solanum stoloniferum <PI 230557>, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica. (50) Solanaceae <11/16>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Pedaliaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/16>. (53) Calvert et al. (1980); Fribourg and
Nakashima (1984). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Fribourg and Nakashima
(1984). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 40640. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X61279 Gb(89)n:Pvvcp Potato Virus V gene for coat
protein. 6/95 2,500bp. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
potato A and wild potato mosaic viruses; potato virus Y (strains O, N and C)
is very distantly related. (187) Calvert, E.L., Cooper, P. and McClure, J.
(1980). Rec. Agric. Res. 28: 63. Fribourg, C.E. and Nakashima, J. (1983). In:
Research for the Potato in the Year 2000; ed. W.J. Hooker. CIP, Peru.
Fribourg, C.E. and Nakashima, J. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1363. Gugerli, P.

Potato X potexvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: potato latent virus, potato
mild mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: PVX. (4) Strains: Indian turnip
strain; Samad et al., 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.018. (8) First
reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Smith (1931). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum symptoms vary, some strains
symptomless, others induce necrotic streaks. Brassica campestris ssp. rapa
mild mosaic mottling and distortion of leaves, plant stunting. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34)
Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide <in potato growing areas>. (39) Spreads in
India. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Datura stramonium systemic
chlorotic rings, then mosaic and mottling. Nicotiana tabacum systemic ringspot
or mottle. Some strains symptomless at high glasshouse temperatures. (45)
Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L). (47) Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <3/3>. (54) TIP: 68-76 °C. (55) LIV: 40-60 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Francki and
McLean (1968). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 515 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide <Brandes, 1964>. (72) Axial canal obscure.
(73) Axial canal 3.4 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of

Base composition 22 % G. (101) Base composition 32 % A. (102) Base composition

fragment, encoding a partial ORF. 1/95 502bp. U19790 Gb(89)n:Pvu19790 Potato
virus X coat protein mRNA, complete cds. 6/95 789bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic

(134) Coat protein. (147) Amino acid composition: Shaw and Larson (1962); Shaw
et al. (1962); Miki and Knight (1968). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and less frequently in the
epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions <mainly near the
nucleus> present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies
<Kozar and Sheludko, 1969>. (177) They contain virions. (179) Potexvirus.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: white clover mosaic,
hydrangea ringspot, cactus X and clover yellow mosaic viruses, but distantly.
(187) Bercks, R, (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 4, 4 pp. Brandes, J.
