Potato Y potyvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond, 1987. (2) Synonyms: brinjal mosaic virus (Sastry,
1982; Varma, 1988), datura 437 virus, potato acropetal necrosis virus, potato
severe mosaic virus, tobacco vein-banding virus (Fang et al., 1985). (3)
Standard acronym: PVY. (4) Strains: potato C virus, tobacco veinal necrosis
virus potato virus Yo group (common strain), potato virus YN group (tobacco
veinal necrosis strain), potato virus YC group (stipple streak strain,
including potato virus C). (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.058. (8) First
reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Smith (1931). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum tuberosum mild to severe leaf mottling, or
streak or `leaf-drop streak' with vein necrosis (`stipple-streak') (Beemster
and Rozendaal, 1972). Capsicum spp. mild leaf mottling, but severe in complex
with other viruses. Nicotiana spp. mild mottle or veinal necrosis.
Lycopersicon esculentum mild leaf mottling but severe in mixed infections
(Edwardson, 1974a). The differences between the primary and secondary symptoms
induced by potato virus Y are often uncertain because of the diversity of
potato cultivars and virus strains, and effect of climatic conditions (de Bokx
and Pirone, 1977). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae is the most efficient vector;
others are Aphis fabae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Myzus (Nectarosiphon) certus,
Myzus (Phorodon) humuli and Rhopalosiphum insertum (Kennedy et al., 1962; Van
Hoof, 1980). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector
transmission and can help the vector transmission of another virus <potato
aucuba mosaic potexvirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Bartels (1970),
in certification schemes. In temperate areas, perennials rarely act as virus
reservoirs in nature. Potato plants as "ground-keepers" are a reservoir host
(Thresh, 1980). In tropical and subtropical areas, weeds such as Solanum
atropurpureum (Chagas et al., 1977) and other Solanum spp. (Edwardson, 1974a)
may act as important virus sources. Use of insecticides to control virus
spread through vectors have been ineffective. The main control methods are (1)
avoidance of infection, i.e. growing crops when vectors are absent or numbers
are low; (2) not growing crops near established crops of the same species; (3)
destroying haulms of seed-potato crops before maturity to restrict virus
spread at the end of the growing season; (4) spraying with mineral oils to
reduce frequency of transmission (Bradley, Moore and Pond, 1966; Vanderveken,
1977); (5) breeding for resistance, if sources of durable resistance can be
obtained; (6) use of reflective surface and sticky yellow sheets which can
reduce virus spread (Loebenstein and Raccah, 1980). (37) Probably distributed
worldwide <in potato growing areas and in outdoor crops of pepper, tobacco and
tomato in warmer countries. Yo strains are spread worldwide; YN strains occur
in Europe including the U.S.S.R., parts of Africa and South America; YC
strains including potato virus C, are probably present in Australia, India and
in some parts of the U.K. and continental Europe>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Nicotiana glutinosa mild to severe systemic mottling. N.
tabacum systemic vein-clearing and leaf mottling. Solanum tuberosum YC strain
local lesions in cv. Duke of York (Eersteling); YN and Yo strains no local
lesions. Tinantia erecta severe systemic mottling. (44) Datura stramonium,
Solanum demissum `A'. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun NN. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L); C. quinoa (L); Physalis floridana (L); Solanum tuberosum
cvs Duke of York, Saco (L); Lycium spp. (L); Solanum chacoense (TE1) (L), S.
demissum `Y' (L); S. demissum × S. tuberosum `A6' (L). (47) Capsicum annuum,
or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Lycium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum chacoense, or Solanum demissum, or
Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Tinantia erecta.
(48) Datura stramonium, or Solanum demissum. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Commelinaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <11/12>. (51) Solanaceae <2/12>. (53)
Edwardson (1974b); Horváth (1979). (54) TIP: 50-62 °C. (55) LIV: 7-50 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 2-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment
with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Damirdagh
and Shepherd (1970); Huttinga (1973); McDonald et al. (1976); Moghal and
Francki (1976); Leiser and Richter (1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 684 nm <from purified preparations
(Delgado-Sanchez and Grogan, 1966)>, or 730 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (73) Axial canal 2-3 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.3 nm <Varma et al., 1968>. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
145 S <Huttinga, 1975>. (79) Density 1.323 g cm3 in CsCl <strain Yo>, or 1.326
g cm3 in CsCl <strain YN (Huttinga, 1975)>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 2.3
<corrected for light-scattering (Leiser and Richter, 1978)>, or 2.9
<uncorrected (Stace-Smith and Tremaine, 1970; Leiser and Richter, 1978)>. (84)
Virions contain 5.4-6.4 % nucleic acid <Stace-Smith and Tremaine, 1970; Leiser
and Richter, 1978>. (85) Virions 93.6-94.6 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 10.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 10.4 kb <Makkouk and Gumpf, 1974; Hinostroza-Orihuela, 1975>. (106) 5'
terminus of RNA has a VPg. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region at 3'
end, but not essential for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12216. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): A08776 Em(40)_vi:A08776 Gb(84)_pat:A08776

PVY-ONAT). 7/95 1,443bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the

(145) Method of preparation: Hiebert and McDonald (1973); Huttinga and Mosch
(1974); Moghal and Francki (1976). (147) Amino acid composition: Stace-Smith
and Tremaine (1970); Miki and Oshima (1972); Makkouk and Gumpf (1975); Moghal
and Francki (1976). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated <Hiebert and
McDonald (1973)>. (153) One protein found. (154) Mr 67000. (155) Cylindrical
inclusion protein (Purcifull et al., 1973). (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in epidermis. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the nucleus <when infected by certain strains
(Kitajima et al., 1968)>, or pinwheels <especially in epidermal tissue in the
cytoplasm (Christie and Edwardson, 1977)>. (178) Other cellular changes:
mitochondria often being surrounded by filaments with a diameter of 9-10 nm
but of indeterminate length (Borges and David Ferreira, 1968) when infected
with strain YN in Datura metel. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tobacco etch,
henbane mosaic, potato A, pepper veinal mottle and bidens mottle viruses, but
distantly (Bartels, 1964; Brunt et al., 1978; Purcifull, 1976). (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: Tinantia erecta is immune to potato aucuba mosaic, potato
M and S viruses and hence may be used to separate potato Y virus from these
viruses (Horváth, 1979). most strains of potato virus Y induce no local
lesions in Solanum demissum `A', which gives necrotic local lesions with
potato virus A (Cockerham, 1958). Potato cultivars resistant to potato X virus
(e.g. cv. Saco), can be used to separate potato Y virus from potato X virus.
Detached leaves of Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum `A6' are commonly used to
detect potato Y virus, but this host does not distinguish between several
viruses which infect it (Bartels, 1970). (187) Bartels, R. (1964). Phytopath.

Potato yellow dwarf nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) G. Adam, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: PYDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.5.0.005. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Barrus and Chupp (1922). (13) Chrysanthemum leucanthemum, Solanum
tuberosum, Trifolium incarnatum. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Agallia constricta, A.
quadripunctata, Aceratagallia sanguinolenta. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae.
(25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in
the North American region. (39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
vein clearing, stunting, leaf malformation, mosaic, chlorotic local lesions.
(43) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica chlorotic local lesions, vein clearing,
leaf malformation, mosaic. Trifolium incarnatum vein clearing, death. (44)
Medicago sativa cv. Grimm. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica. (46)
Nicotiana rustica (L). (47) Chrysanthemum leucanthemum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium incarnatum. (48) Medicago
sativa <cv. Grimm>. (50) Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/2>, or Solanaceae <5/5>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>. (53)
Younkin (1942). (54) TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 0.25 days <few hours>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 3. (57) Infectivity of sap decreased by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: use
ammonium molybdate as the stain. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63)
Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear
modal length. (70) Virions of 380 nm. (71) Virions 75 nm wide. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
800 S. (80) Density 1.2 g cm3 in sucrose. (84) Virions contain 2 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 78 % protein. (86) Virions 20 % lipid. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 12.6 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 12.6 kb. (108)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity lost

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PYMV. (5) ICTV decimal code

hybrida systemic leaf chlorosis. (47) Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana,

Primula mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and P. Jeyanandarajah, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: PrMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.073. (8) First reported in Primula obconica.
(9) From Italy. (10) By Lisa and Lovisolo (1976). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Primula obconica leaf chlorosis and flower breaking. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Italy. (41)
Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Apium graveolens, Coriandrum sativum,
Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii, Trigonella foenum-graecum, Zinnia
elegans chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. murale, C. quinoa, Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic local lesions; no
systemic infection. (44) Amaranthus caudatus, Beta vulgaris, Datura
stramonium, Nicotiana rustica, Spinacia oleracea. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii.
(46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. murale (L), C. quinoa (L), Nicotiana
clevelandii (W). (47) Apium graveolens, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Chenopodium album, or

foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum,
or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or

Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Primula
obconica, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, or

4. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with

with serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic and lettuce mosaic

mosaic, carnation vein mottle, henbane mosaic and potato Y viruses. (186) It
is not known whether a primula mosaic virus in the U.S.A. (Tompkins and
Middleton, 1941) has any relationship to that described here. The closeness of
the serological relationship between primula mosaic and lettuce mosaic viruses
(SDI 23) suggests that the former could be regarded as a strain of lettuce

Primula mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: PrMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code

mild mosaic of green and chlorotic areas, flower colour breaking and stunting.

by Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)

inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Singh et al. (1970); Mali (1985). (39)

rustica, N. tabacum, Petunia alba systemic mild mottle, vein-clearing. (44)

amaranticolor (L), C. album (L). (47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium

Primula malacoides. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or

Prune dwarf ilarvirus

      (1) R.W. Fulton, 1985. (2) Synonyms: cherry chlorotic ringspot virus,

From the U.S.A. (10) By Thomas and Hildebrand (1936). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Prunus domestica leathery, strap-like leaves. Prunus cerasus leaf

plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <to 10% in Prunus cerasus>. (35) Virus

Prunus necrotic ringspot ilarvirus

      (1) R.W. Fulton, 1985. (2) Synonyms: European plum line pattern virus,
hop B virus, hop C virus, peach ringspot virus, plum line pattern virus,
prunus ringspot virus, red currant necrotic ringspot virus, rose chlorotic
mottle virus, rose line pattern virus, rose vein banding virus, rose yellow
vein mosaic virus (Sastry, 1966), sour cherry necrotic ringspot virus. (3)
Standard acronym: PNRSV. (4) Strains: cherry rugose mosaic virus, Danish plum
line pattern virus and North American plum line pattern ilarvirus. (5) ICTV
decimal code 10.0.2.03.02. (8) First reported in Prunus persica. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Cochran and Hutchins (1941). (11) Symptoms persist <in some
hosts>, or disappear soon after infection <in some hosts>. (13) Prunus cerasus
dark necrotic lines and rings, shotholes, recovery. Prunus persica brown lines
and rings, recovery. Rosa (rose) chlorotic lines and rings, oak leaf patterns,
no recovery. Prunus (plum) chlorotic lines and rings only some strains. Prunus
(almond) bright mosaic. Humulus (hops) no symptoms. Cucumis sativus chlorotic
local lesions, systemic necrosis and severe stunting. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <to over 80% in Prunus
pennsylvanica but much less in peach>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the
seed and transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis
sativus large yellow chlorotic local lesions in cotyledons, growing point
stunted. Momordica balsamina necrotic local lesions. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba
dark necrotic local lesions. Chenopodium quinoa systemic mottle. Prunus
serrulata local necrosis and gumming at site of grafts. Lupinus albus systemic
mottle. Helianthus annuus systemic chlorotic lines and rings. Cassia tora
local and systemic ringspotting. (44) Tithonia speciosa, Lagenaria siceraria,
Nepeta cataria, Crotalaria spectabilis, Plantago virginica. (45) Cucumis
sativus, Catharanthus roseus. (46) Momordica balsamina (L), Cucumis sativus
(W), Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Cassia tora, or

Helianthus annuus, or Humulus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lupinus albus, or

Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Lagenaria siceraria, or Nepeta

<2/3>. (51) Compositae <1/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/7>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or

Fulton (1957). (54) TIP: 55-62 °C. (55) LIV: 0.4-0.75 days <6-18 hours>. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 2-3 <in presence of antioxidant>. (59) Electron microscopy:
fix in 1% glutaraldehyde. (60) Method: Fulton (1968). (61) Virions isometric.

citrus leaf rugose, citrus variegation, elm mottle, Tulare apple mosaic and
prune dwarf viruses. (187) Barbara, D.J., Clark, M.F., Thresh, J.M. and
Casper, R. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 90: 395. Cation, D. (1949). Phytopathology
39: 37. Cochran, L.C. and Hutchins, L.M. (1941). Phytopathology 31B 860.
Cropley, R., Gilmer, R.M. and Posnette, A.F. (1964). Ann. appl. Biol. 53: 325.
Fulton, R.W. (1957). Phytopathology 47: 215. Fulton, R.W. (1957).
Phytopathology 47: 683. Fulton, R.W. (1958). Virology 6: 499. Fulton, R.W.
(1968). Phytopathology 58: 635. Fulton, R.W. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.

Prunus S (?) carlavirus

      (3) Standard acronym: PruVS. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.T.1.027. (8)

Hull, R., Brown, F. and Payne, C. (1989). Directory and Dictionary of Animal,

Purple granadilla mosaic virus

      (1) E.W. Kitajima, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.32. (8) First
reported in Passiflora edulis cv. Sims. (9) From Cotia, SP, Brazil. (11)
Symptoms vary cyclically over a few weeks. (13) Passiflora edulis cv. Sims.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Diabrotica speciosa Germ. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted
in a semipersistent manner. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Brazil. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Passiflora serrato-digitata, P. caerulea, P.
maliformis, P. gibertii, P. alata, P. edulis f. flavicarpa. (44) Gomphrena
globosa, Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana tabacum, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus
vulgaris `marteiga'. (45) Passiflora edulis cv. Sims. (46) Passiflora edulis
cv. Sims. (W). (47) Passiflora alata, or Passiflora caerulea, or Passiflora
edulis <cv. Sims>, or Passiflora edulis f. flavicarpa, or Passiflora gibertii,
or Passiflora maliformis, or Passiflora serrato-digitata. (48) Abelmoschus
esculentus, or Ageratum conyzoides, or Allium cepa, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea
var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum annuum, or
Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Cichorium endiva, or
Citrullus lanatus, or Citrus limon, or Coriandrum sativum, or Crotalaria
spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota,
or Desmodium tortuosum, or Dianthus caryophyllus, or Emilia sagittata, or
Eucalyptus marginata, or Euphorbia marginata, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Ipomoea setosa, or
Lablab purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Myosotis sylvatica, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Passiflora edulis, or Petroselinum crispum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox
drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or
Saccharum officinarum, or Secale cereale, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Triticum
aestivum, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Passifloraceae
<7/7>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Boraginaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <9/9>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1 /1>, or Gramineae <5/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/9>,
or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Myrtaceae <1/1>, or Passifloraceae <1/7>, or
Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Rutaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <12/12>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>. (53) Chagas et al. (1984);
Oliveira (1986). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
129 S. (84) Virions contain 15 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 35500. (134) Coat
protein. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected
cells. (178) Other cellular changes: filamentous material within the cristae
of mitochondria. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: tymoviruses, comoviruses, cucumoviruses, sobemoviruses,
ilarviruses, mimosa mosaic virus and maize rayado fino virus. (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: serology, symptoms in Passiflora spp. and host range. (N.B. CMV
infects species outside Passifloraceae). Passionfruit yellow mosaic tymovirus
produces bright yellow mosaic in most Passiflora spp., but is not
serologically related. (187) Chagas, C.M., Joazeiro, P.P., Kudamatsu, M. and
Vega, J. (1984). Fitopatol. Bras. 9: 241. Oliveira, C.R.B. (1986). M.Sc.
Thesis, Univ. Brasilia.


Quail pea mosaic comovirus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. (2) Synonyms: bean curly dwarf mosaic virus (Moore
and Scott, 1981). (3) Standard acronym: QPMV. (4) Strains: type, bean curly
dwarf mosaic. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in
Strophostyles helvula. (9) From Arkansas, U.S.A. (10) By Moore (1973). (13)
Strophostyles helvula, Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Ceratoma trifurcata. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed <type strain not
transmitted through seed of Phaseolus vulgaris or P. acutifolius; Meiners et
al., 1977>. (39) Spreads in Costa Rica and El Salvador <in Phaseolus
vulgaris>, or the USA <in Strophostyles helvula in Arkansas>. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa not infected by type strain;
systemic chlorosis (bean curly dwarf strain). Ipomoea nil cv.-Scarlet O'Hara
necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Vigna unguiculata cv. Monarch chlorotic
local lesions but not systemic. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Black Valentine,
Cherokee Wax, Glycine max cv. Kanrich. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Pinto (L).
Glycine max cv. Lee (W) for vector transmission. (47) Cajanus cajan, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Ipomoea nil, or
Lablab purpureus, or Lens culinaris, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesbania exaltata, or
Strophostyles helvula, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata.
(48) Arachis hypogaea, or Cicer arietinum, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab
purpureus, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Tephrosia
vogelii, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<1/1>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/17>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/17>. (53) Meiners et al.
(1977). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 5-6 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(60) Method: Moore and Scott (1981). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (76) Three sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 112
S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 93 S <M>, or 57 S <T>. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome of two parts. (132) Virion protein(s)
two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 40000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 22000. (179)
Comovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: members of each of the other four serogroups
(Fulton and Scott, 1979). (183) The bean curly dwarf strain differs from the
type strain in several respects. It is transmitted by Diabrotica
undecimpunctata, Epilachna varivestis, infects Gomphrena globosa systemically,
induces chlorotic local lesions in Lablab purpureus, and diffuse local lesions
in Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Pinto, Top Crop. Its best local lesion host is
Lablab purpureus. (187) Fulton, J.P. and Scott, H.A. (1979). Phytopathology
69: 305. Meiners, J.P., Waterworth, H.E., Lawson, R.H. and Smith, F.F. (1977).
Phytopathology 67: 163. Moore, B.J. (1973). Pl. Dis. Reptr 57: 311. Moore,
B.J. and Scott, H.A. (1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 238, 4 pp.


Radish mosaic comovirus

      (1) R.N. Campbell, 1988. (2) Synonyms: radish enation mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: RaMV. (4) Strains: type (North American), European (HZ),
Japanese. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.1.0.013. (8) First reported in Raphanus
sativus. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Tompkins (1939); Severin and
Tompkins (1950); Campbell (1964). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Brassica
campestris line and ring patterns, mosaic, necrosis of veins and petioles,
rosetting of leaves. B. campestris ssp. napus mild mosaic, and leaf
deformation. B. oleracea variable; from symptomless to severe systemic
chlorosis and necrosis. Raphanus sativus mosaic, occasionally enations. Eruca
sativa severe crinkle, chlorosis, stunting, some necrosis. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Phyllotreta spp.,
Epitrix hirtipennis and Diabrotica undecimpunctata. (18) Transmitted by
Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Mamula and Juretic (1985); Koenig and Fischer (1981). (39) Spreads
in Austria, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Japan, Morocco, the USA, the former USSR,
and the former Yugoslavia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Brassica campestris (tendergreen mustard) necrotic local lesions; systemic
mottling. B. campestris (turnip) chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; systemic
mosaic or line patterns. Chenopodium amaranticolor and other Chenopodium spp.
local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Turkish necrotic rings; not
systemic. (44) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cv. Havana 425. (45) Brassica
campestris. (46) Brassica campestris (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L), C. murale (L), Raphanus sativus (W). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica
campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Chenopodium
album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium
foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Datura stramonium, or Eruca sativa, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Raphanus sativus, or Sinapis alba, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Beta vulgaris,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca
sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<8/8>, or Cruciferae <12/12>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or Solanaceae <4/6>.
(51) Chenopodiaceae <1/8>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <4/6>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Campbell (1964); Stefanac and Mamula (1972). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C.
(55) LIV: 14-21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Stefanac and Mamula (1972). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <about> 30 nm in diameter <28 nm
side-to-side, 33 nm corner-to-corner; Milne et al., 1980>. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 128 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 103 S <M>, or 57
S <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.3 <fast>, or 5.3 <slow>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.65 <M>, or 1.78 <B>. (84) Virions contain 35 % nucleic acid <B>, or 26
% nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 65 % protein <B>, or
74 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (86) Virions 0 % lipid <all
components>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 9.8 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 6.2 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.6 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Fukunaga and Furusawa (1981). (100) Base composition 22 % G
<M>, or 25 % G <B>. (101) Base composition 29 % A <M>, or 30 % A <B>. (102)
Base composition 19 % C <M>, or 18 % C <B>. (103) Base composition 30 % U <M>,
or 27 % U <B>. (132) Virion protein(s) two <plus one or more hydrolysis
products, in some isolates>. (133) Mr <of the larger> 40000. (135) Mr of 2nd
largest 22000-24000. (145) Method of preparation: Koenig and Fischer (1981).
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell
vacuoles. (173) Virions found in in membrane bound layers considered to be
tonoplastic channels (Honda and Matsui, 1972). (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Vesiculated
inclusion bodies (Milne et al., 1980; Stefanac and Ljubesic, 1971). (177) They
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: enations on chronically
infected radish (Chinese white winter types). (179) Comovirus: Comoviridae.
(180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
cowpea severe mosaic, bean pod mottle, squash mosaic and broad bean stain
viruses. (183) Radish mosaic virus has 2 serological subgroups: i). isolates
from California and Japan; ii). European isolates including the HZ
(Yugoslavian strain). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serological testing by
gel diffusion is most reliable. (186) An aphid-borne virus designated radish
mosaic virus in India (Naqvi et al., 1986; Ahlawat and Chenulu, 1982) differs
from radish mosaic comovirus. (187) Ahlawat, Y.S. and Chenulu, V.V. (1982).
Indian Phytopath. 35: 633. Campbell, R.N. (1964). Phytopathology 54: 1418.
Campbell, R.N. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 121, 4 pp. Fukunaga, K.
and Furusawa, I. (1981). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 47: 534. Honda, Y. and
Matsui, C. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 448. Koenig, R. and Fischer, H.U.
(1981). Plant Dis. 65: 758. Mamula, D. and JureticH, N. (1985). Phyton (Houn,
Austria) 25: 241. Milne, R.G., Masenga, V., Lenzi, R. and Lovisolo, O. (1980).
Phytopathol. Medit. 19: 145. Naqvi, Q.A., Khan, J.A. and Mahmood, K. (1986).
J. Indian Bot. Soc. 65: 136. Severin, H.H.P. and Tompkins, C.M. (1950).
Hilgardia 20: 191. Stefanac, Z. and Mamula, D. (1972). Ann appl. Biol. 69:
229. Stefanac, Z. and Ljubesic, N. (1971). J. gen. Virol. 13: 51. Tompkins,
C.M. (1939). J. Agric. Res. 58: 119.


Radish yellow edge alphacryptovirus

      (1) T. Natsuaki, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: RYEV. (5) ICTV decimal code
49.0.3.0.012. (8) First reported in Raphanus sativus. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Natsuaki et al. (1979). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13)
Raphanus sativus usually no symptoms, but rarely with yellowed leaf margins.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed.
(36) Studies reported by Natsuaki et al. (1979, 1983). (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Australia, China, Italy, the U.K. and the U.S.A. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Nicotiana
tabacum, Cucumis sativus, Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis and Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa. (45) Raphanus sativus. (47) Raphanus sativus. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis
sativus, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50)
Cruciferae <1/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>.
(53) Natsuaki et al. (1979); Natsuaki (1985). (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Natsuaki (1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
118 S. (79) Density 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 3.76 kb. (92) Genome of
three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 1.3 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 1.25 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 1.21 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Natsuaki et al. (1983). (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of
the larger> 63000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 61000. (145) Method of preparation:
Natsuaki et al. (1983). (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are viroplasms <but are rarely observed>. (177) They contain
virions. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: all other alphacryptovirus
species tested. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: This virus is readily
distinguished from other viruses infecting crucifers by its possession of
dsRNA. ISEM and extracting dsRNA directly from leaves are used for diagnosis.
(187) Natsuaki, T., Yamashita, S., Doi, Y. and Yora, K. (1979). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 45: 313. Natsuaki, T., Okuda, S., Teranaka, M.,
Yamashita, S. and Doi, Y. (1983). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 49: 593.


Ranunculus mottle potyvirus

      (1) P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (2) Synonyms: ranunculus mosaic virus
(Raabe and Gold, 1957). (3) Standard acronym: RanMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.075. (8) First reported in Ranunculus asiaticus. (9) From the U.S.A.

asiaticus foliar mottling and distortion. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Consolida
ajacis conspicuous foliar mosaic. (44) Anemone coronaria, Aquilegia coerulea,
Clematis occidentalis, Thalictrum dipterocarpum. (47) Consolida ajacis, or
Ranunculus asiaticus. (48) Anemone coronaria, or Aquilegia coerulea, or
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or

Matthiola incana, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or

melongena, or Thalictrum dipterocarpum. (50) Ranunculaceae <2/6>. (51)
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>,
or Ranunculaceae <4/6>, or Solanaceae <7/7>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 707 nm. (171) Virions found in
leaves. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: watermelon mosaic 2 virus. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, bidens mottle,
blackeye cowpea mosaic, clover yellow vein, dasheen mosaic, papaya ringspot,
peanut mottle, peanut stripe, pepper mottle, potato Y, tobacco etch, turnip
mosaic and zucchini yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Elliott, M.S., Zettler, F.W.,
Gallegati, M. and Ko, N.J. (1988). Acta Hort. 234: 39. Laird, E.F. and
Dickson, R.C. (1965). Pl. Dis. Reptr 49: 449. Laird, E.F. and Dickson, R.C.
(1967). J. econ. Ent. 60: 10. Raabe, R.D. and Gold, A.H. (1957).
Phytopathology 47: 28.

Raphanus (?) cytorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: RaV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.044. (8) First reported in Raphanus sp. (9) From Brazil. (10) By
Kitajima and Costa (1979). (13) Raphanus sp. no conspicuous symptoms. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Brazil. (47)
Raphanus. (50) Cruciferae <1/1>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63)
Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
250-300 nm <in sections>. (71) Virions 50-70 nm wide <in sections>. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (179) <Possible> Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Kitajima, E.W. and Costa, A.S. (1979). Fitopatol. Bras.
4: 55.


Raspberry bushy dwarf idaeovirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond and A.F. Murant, 1987. (2) Synonyms: loganberry
degeneration virus (Barnett and Murant, 1970; Legg, 1960), raspberry yellows
virus (Cadman, 1952; Jones et al., 1982), possibly raspberry line-pattern
virus (Basak, 1971; Jones and Murant, 1972). (3) Standard acronym: RBDV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 34.0.1.0.001. (8) First reported in Rubus idaeus. (9) From
Scotland. (10) By Cadman (1961). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Rubus idaeus
(raspberry) cvs Lloyd George, Canby, Carnival, Creston, Newburgh and Norfolk
Giant symptomless, but may have high proportion of aborted drupelets. R.
loganobaccus (loganberry), R. ursinus (boysenberry), R. occidentalis (black
raspberry) cvs Munger, New Logan and Plum Farmer symptoms uncertain. This is
desirable because, although the virus causes mild symptoms, it may affect
fruit quality, especially in mixed infections. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector <none of the insects common on raspberry in Scotland
transmitted the virus (Cadman, 1970)>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <up to 77%; Cadman, 1965; Converse, 1973; Murant et al., 1974>. (35)
Virus <possibly> transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant, or transmitted
by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by Murant et al. (1974) and
Converse (1973). The virus may be eliminated from stocks of Rubus idaeus
(Murant et al., 1974) and from R. occidentalis (Converse, 1973) by heat
therapy. Immune cultivars are not infected via pollen. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide <and probably occurs wherever susceptible Rubus
cultivars are grown>. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the North
American region. (39) Spreads in Australia, New Zealand, and the former USSR.
(41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor transient
chlorotic local lesions, systemic chlorotic rings and line patterns.
Chenopodium murale sunken necrotic rings; not systemic. Chenopodium quinoa
transient local lesions, systemic chlorotic spots and then mosaic and ring
patterns. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. The Prince small brown local lesions in
winter; no systemic infection. Nicotiana clevelandii infected systemically
without symptoms. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. The
Prince (L), Chenopodium murale (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Fragaria vesca, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus loganobaccus, or
Rubus occidentalis, or Rubus ursinus. (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53)
Barnett and Murant, 1970; 1971. (54) TIP: 65 °C. (55) LIV: 4 days <at 20°C>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4 <an isolate from Rubus occidentalis had a dilution
end-point of only 102 in Chenopodium quinoa sap and lost infectivity after 2-3
hours at room temperature; Jones and Murant, 1972a; Murant and Jones, 1976>.
(59) Electron microscopy: virions disrupt in PTA but not in UA or UF (Barnett
and Murant, 1970). (60) Method: Murant (1976). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations, or three sedimenting
components in purified preparations <in a rather broad zone>. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (79) Density 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl <fixed in
formaldehyde>. (84) Virions contain 24 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 76 %
protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 8.6 kb. (92) Genome of three parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the largest> 5.4 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.2 kb. (95) The 3rd
largest 1 kb. (110) Poly A region absent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12451. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D01052 Em(40)_vi:RUDMRCP
Gb(84)_vi:RUDMRCP Raspberry bushy dwarf virus (RBDV) mRNA for coat protein.
11/92 946bp. S51557 Em(40)_un:S51557 Gb(84)_vi:S51557 RNA-1 segment:
non-structural polyprotein raspberry bushy dwarf virus RBDV, R15, Genomic RNA
2 sequences. (119) Features of the genome: RNA-1 has one ORF, that encodes a
protein of Mr 188000, and is probably a polymerase. RNA-2 has 2 ORFs, one
encodes a protein of Mr 39000, that is probably a movement protein, the other
the coat protein. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
subgenomic mRNA <RNA-3>. (132) Virion protein(s) one <probably>. (133) Mr
29000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Murant (1975). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (179) Idaeovirus <the type, and
only, species of the genus>. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: twenty-four isometric viruses, including seven ilarviruses (Barnett
and Murant, 1970). (184) Earlier reports (Cadman, 1963; 1970) that raspberry
bushy dwarf virus is related to apple chlorotic leaf spot trichovirus have not
been confirmed (Murant, 1976). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Raspberry bushy
dwarf virus (RBDV) is one of several viruses isolated from Lloyd George
raspberry with `bushy dwarf' (Cadman and Harris, 1951) or `symptomless
decline' (Cadman, 1952). Plants infected with RBDV alone produce few, stunted
canes and are late fruiting (Barnett and Murant, 1970), but so do plants
infected with mixtures of RBDV and aphid-borne black raspberry necrosis virus
(Jones, 1976). RBDV is readily distinguished from most nepoviruses from Rubus,
except strawberry latent ringspot virus, by the symptoms it induces in
Chenopodium quinoa; and their virions differ. The symptoms caused in C. quinoa
also distinguish it from black raspberry necrosis virus (Jones and Murant,
1972b); which is transmitted by sap inoculation with difficulty, has isometric
virions, but occurs in very small concentrations in sap. The black raspberry
latent strain of tobacco streak virus (Lister and Converse, 1972) has virions
like those of RBDV and is transmitted by pollen but causes severe systemic
necrosis in C. quinoa and Phaseolus vulgaris. (187) Barnett, O.W. and Murant,
A.F. (1970). Ann. appl. Biol. 65: 435. Basak, W. (1971). Bull. Acad. Polmarse
Sci., Serie sci. biol. C.I.V. 19: 681. Cadman, C.H. (1952). Ann. appl. Biol.
39: 495. Cadman, C.H. (1961). Hort. Res. 1: 47. Cadman, C.H. (1963). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 47: 459. Cadman, C.H. (1965). Pl. Dis. Reptr 49: 230. Cadman, C.H.
(1970). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruit and Grapevines, p. 149. University
of California Press, Berkeley. Cadman, C.H. and Harris, R.V. (1951). Rep. E.
Malling Res. Stn. 1950, p.127. Converse, R.H. (1973). Phytopathology 63: 780.
Jones, A.T. (1976). Rep. Scottish Hort. Res. Inst. 1975, p. 73. Jones, A.T.
and Murant, A.F. (1972a). Rep. Scottish Hort. Res. Inst. 1971, p. 60. Jones,
A.T. and Murant, A.F. (1972b). Pl. Path. 21: 166. Jones, A.T., Murant, A.F.,
Jennings, D.L. and Wood, G.A. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 100: 135. Legg, J.T.
(1960). Rep. E. Malling Res. Stn. 1959, 102. Lister, R.M. and Converse, R.H.
(1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.166, 4 pp. Mayo, M.A., Jolly, C.A.,

Raspberry leaf curl (?) luteovirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: RLCV. (4) Strains:
alpha, beta. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.T.011. (8) First reported in Rubus
idaeus. (9) From Ontario, Canada and New York, U.S.A. (10) By Rankin and
Hockey (1922). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms leaf curling, shoot
proliferation, stunting, fruits are small and crumbly. (13) Rubus idaeus, R.
occidentalis, R. fruticosus, R. × neglectus leaf curling, proliferation of
shoots and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis rubicola. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(24) Not transmitted by Amphorophora agathonica. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Stace-Smith (1962). (38) Spreads in the North American region.
(39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show downcurling of leaves, yellowing
and stunting. (43) Rubus idaeus, R. albescens, R. henryi, Fragaria vesca
downcurling of leaves and leaf yellowing. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
tabacum, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata. (45) Rubus idaeus. (46) Rubus idaeus (W), R. henryi (W), R.
phoenicolasius (W). (47) Fragaria vesca, or Rubus albescens, or Rubus
fruticosus, or Rubus henryi, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus occidentalis, or Rubus

(179) <Possible> Luteovirus. (187) Rankin, W.H. and Hockey, J.F. (1922).

Raspberry ringspot nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: raspberry Scottish leaf curl virus,
red currant ringspot virus. (3) Standard acronym: RpRSV. (4) Strains: type
strain, Lloyd George yellow blotch strain, English strain. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.0.026. (8) First reported in Rubus idaeus. (9) From Scotland. (10)
By Cadman (1956). (13) Rubus idaeus cv. Norfolk Giant leaf curling, dieback
and death (cv. Lloyd George is immune), but less conspicuous symptoms in other
cultivars. Fragaria vesca dwarfing and eventually death. Narcissus
pseudonarcissus symptomless infection. The virus may infect species of wild
and cultivated dicotyledonous and monocotyledonous plants. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Longidorus
elongatus, L. macrosoma. (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35)
Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by Cadman
(1956); Murant et al. (1968); Kleinhempel (1970); Murant (1970); Bovey et al.
(1972); Jennings (1964). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the
Mediterranean region. (39) Spreads in Austria, or Belgium, or Bulgaria, or the
former Czechoslovakia, or Finland, or France, or Germany, or Greece, or
Hungary, or Ireland, or Luxembourg, or the Netherlands, or Norway, or Poland,
or Spain, or Switzerland, or Turkey, or the UK, or the USA, or the former
USSR, or the former Yugoslavia. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Denmark. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; no systemic infection. C. quinoa
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; systemic mottling and apical necrosis.
Nicotiana rustica local lesions or rings; systemic ring and line patterns but
systemic infection later often symptomless. Phaseolus vulgaris necrotic local
lesions (in winter) and chlorotic local lesions (in summer); systemic
mottling, distortion and necrosis. Petunia × hybrida local chlorotic lesions;
systemic chlorosis, line patterns and/or necrosis. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii,
N. rustica, Petunia × hybrida. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa
(L/W), Spinacia oleracea (W, especially useful as a bait plant for vector
transmission tests). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Fragaria
vesca, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Rubus idaeus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Rosaceae <2/2>,
or Solanaceae <6/6>. (54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: 21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
4. (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 125 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s)
91 S <M>, or 50 S <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.78 <B>, or 1.62 <M>. (84)
Virions contain 43 % nucleic acid <B>, or 29 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 %
nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 57 % protein <B>, or 71 % protein <M>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 12.727 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 8.485 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.242 kb. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: Mayo et al. (1992). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12809. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): S46011 Em(40)_un:S46011 Gb(84)_vi:S46011
polyprotein raspberry ringspot virus RRV, Genomic RNA Complete, 3928 nt. 2/93
3,928bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 54000. (134) Coat
protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (179) Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic, strawberry latent
ringspot, sweet potato ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and
tomato ringspot viruses. (183) Many variants occur. Cultivars differ in
susceptibility; Norfolk Giant is very susceptible to the type strain, but
Lloyd George is immune to it. (187) Bovey, R. et al. (1972). In: La Défense
des Plantes Cultivées 6th Edition. Payot, Switzerland. Cadman, C.H. (1956). J.

Red clover mottle comovirus

nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 64 % protein <B>, or 75 % protein <M>, or 100 %

Red clover necrotic mosaic dianthovirus

      (1) M. Hollings, 1980. (2) Synonyms: clover primary leaf necrosis virus
(Ragetli and Elder, 1977), clover red necrotic mosaic virus. (3) Standard
acronym: RCNMV. (4) Strains: isolates differing in their serological types
reported from England, Scotland, Sweden and the former Czechoslovakia. (5)
ICTV decimal code 23.0.1.0.002. (8) First reported in Trifolium pratense. (9)
From the former Czechoslovakia. (10) By Musil (1969a); Musil et al. (1967);
Gould et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium pratense necrotic
local lesions, mosaics, leaf deformation. Medicago sativa, Melilotus
officinalis, Trifolium repens. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (15)
Experimentally transmitted by the chytrid Olpidium radicale. (29) Virus does
not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
the former Czechoslovakia, Sweden, and the UK. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Australia, Poland, Canada and New Zealand. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (43) Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions, not
systemic. Chenopodium capitatum necrotic local lesions, systemic chlorosis,
mottle, rosetting, stunting and leaf deformation. Chenopodium quinoa, Ocimum
basilicum necrotic local lesions, not systemic. Cucumis sativus cv. Butcher's
Disease Resistor necrotic local lesions in cotyledons; not systemic. Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Prince chlorotic/necrotic local lesions, systemic necrotic
streaks, stunting, leaf deformation. Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye necrotic
local lesions, systemic mottle. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local lesions,
systemic chlorotic rings, mottle, stunting, severe puckering and leaf
deformation. N. tabacum cv. White Burley chlorotic or necrotic local lesions;
not systemic. Tetragonia tetragonioides necrotic local lesions, not systemic.
(45) Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Cucumis sativus (L),
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Ocimum basilicum (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L,W), Vigna
unguiculata (L,W), Nicotiana clevelandii (L,W). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or

Red clover vein mosaic carlavirus

      (1) D.J. Hagedorn, 1981. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: pea stunt virus,
vein mosaic virus of red clover. (3) Standard acronym: RCVMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 14.0.1.0.027. (8) First reported in Trifolium pratense. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Osborne (1937). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium pratense
mosaic, vein yellowing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus persicae, Therioaphis
(Pterocallidium) maculatus, Cavariella aegopodii, C. theobaldi. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<in Trifolium pratense and Vicia faba>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen.
(38) Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in Germany and the
Netherlands. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K., Sweden
and Switzerland. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Medicago
sativa, Melilotus albus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum cv. Perfection,
Trifolium incarnatum, T. pratense, T. repens, Vicia sativa systemic mosaic,
yellowing and leaf deformation. (44) Medicago sativa. (45) Melilotus albus,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum cv. Perfection, Trifolium incarnatum, T.
pratense. (46) Melilotus albus (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (W), Pisum sativum cv.
Perfection (W), Trifolium incarnatum (W), T. pratense (W). (47) Antirrhinum
majus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia sativa. (48) Capsicum frutescens, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lotus corniculatus, or
Lupinus angustifolius, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/17>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/17>, or Solanaceae
<7/8>. (53) Hagedorn and Hanson (1951); Sander (1959); Thornberry (1966);
Varma (1970); Hampton et al. (1978). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-3 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Varma et
al. (1970). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of
600-700 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial
canal 3.5 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix
3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 160 S. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.5. (84) Virions
contain 6.25 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 93.75 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome
size 7.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.5
kb. (100) Base composition 31 % G. (101) Base composition 24 % A. (102) Base
composition 23 % C. (103) Base composition 22 % U. (171) Virions found in
leaves. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells <Pisum sativum and in leaf
hairs of Trifolium pratense>. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies and
unusual in shape. (176) And crystalline; bundles of virions and rings of
coiled virions in ultrathin sections. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: pea streak
virus. (187) Hagedorn, D.J. (1958). Tijdschr. PlZiekt. 64: 263. Hagedorn, D.J.
(1974). Ann. Phytop. Soc. Monog. No. 9. Hagedorn, D.J. and Hanson (1951).

(1986). Phytopathology 76: 1073.


Ribgrass mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) N. Oshima, 1986. (2) Synonyms: Holmes' ribgrass virus, plantago
mosaic virus, ribgrass strain of tobacco mosaic virus, rai mosaic virus,
youcai mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: RMV. (4) Strains: primula isolate,
RMV-K, TMV-C, Wasabi isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.008. (8) First
reported in Plantago lanceolata. (9) From New Jersey, U.S.A. (10) By Holmes
(1941). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Plantago lanceolata, P. major chlorotic
mottling and rings. Digitalis lanata mosaic. Rorippa amphibia mild mottling
and necrotic lines. Rorippa sylvestris symptomless carrier. Eutrema wasabi
mottling. Sisymbrium loeselii yellow leaf edges and vein clearing. Melandrium
album chlorotic ringspots and lines. Nicotiana tabacum stunting and necrosis.
(14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus
transmitted by contact between plants. (37) Probably distributed worldwide.
(41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc
brown necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Samsun
necrotic concentric rings and line patterns. Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
sylvestris, Petunia × hybrida brown necrotic local lesions; not systemic.
Chenopodium amaranticolor small necrotic local lesions, occasional systemic
necrotic spotting. Cyphomandra betacea chlorotic local lesions; systemic
mosaic and deformation. Momordica charantia necrotic local lesions; not
systemic. Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, B. nigra systemic mosaic symptoms or
symptomless carrier. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cv.
Samsun. (46) Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc (L); N. glutinosa (L); N.
sylvestris (L); N. tabacum cv. Samsun (W); Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica
nigra, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata,
or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium endiva, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cyphomandra betacea, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Datura tatula, or Digitalis lanata, or Eutrema wasabi, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lupinus albus,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Melandrium
album, or Momordica charantia, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phlox drummondii, or
Physalis peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Plantago lanceolata, or Plantago
major, or Raphanus sativus, or Rorippa amphibia, or Rorippa sylvestris, or
Sisymbrium loeselii, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Triticum
aestivum, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (48) Cucumis melo, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Vicia sativa. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <13/13>, or
Cucurbitaceae <3/4>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4 /6>, or Plantaginaceae <2/2>, or Polemoniaceae
<1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <21/21>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/6>. (53) Oshima et al., (1974); Schumann (1963);
Kovachevsky (1963); Fujisawa et al. (1982). (54) TIP: 93 °C. (55) LIV: 160
days <or more at 20-25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap contains
many virions. (60) Method: Siegel and Wildman (1954). (61) Virions rodshaped.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal <c.> 4 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.3 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 180-200 S. (79) Density
<c.> 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.49. (84) Virions contain
5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.5
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Fraenkel-Conrat et al. (1961). (100)
Base composition 25.8 % G. (101) Base composition 29.3 % A. (102) Base
composition 18 % C. (103) Base composition 27 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA
has a methylated nucleotide cap <m7GpppX>. (108) Infectivity decreased when
deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA <possibly> found in infected cells. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 17500. (145) Method of preparation:
Fraenkel-Conrat (1957). (165) Coat protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm,
possibly. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are crystals in the cytoplasm and amorphous Xbodies. (177) They contain
virions. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: all tobamoviruses to a greater or lesser extent, and this is
correlated with their virion protein sequence similarities (Gibbs, 1986).
Distant serological relationship with broad bean necrosis, potato moptop and
soilborne wheat mosaic (Van Regenmortel, 1982). (187) Chessin, M., Zaitlin, M.
and Solberg, R.A. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 452. Fraenkel-Conrat, H. (1957).
Virology 4: 1. Fraenkel-Conrat, H., Singer, B. and Tsugita, A. (1961).
Virology 14: 54. Fujisawa, K., Tsuchizaki, T. and Iizuka, N. (1982). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 48: 592. Gibbs, A.J. (1986). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol.
2, The Rod-Shaped Plant Viruses, p. 167; eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel and H.
Fraenkel-Conrat. Plenum Press, New York. Goto, T. and Oshima, N. (1962). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 27: 109. Holmes, F.O. (1941). Phytopathology 31: 1089.
JureticH, N., MilicHicH, D. and Mamula, D. (1973). Acta bot. Croat. 32: 29.
Kovachevsky, I.C. (1963). Phytopath. Z. 49: 127. Kovachevsky, I.C. (1969).
Proc. 7th Conf. Czechoslov. Pl. Virol., Olomouc, 1967, p. 250. Oshima, N. and
Harrison, B.D. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 152, 4 pp. Oshima, N.,
Ohashi, Y. and Ume K. (1974). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 40: 241. Polak, Z.
(1962). Proc. 5th Conf. Czechoslov. Pl. Virol., Prague, 1962, p. 168.
Schumann, K. (1963). Phytopath. Z. 48: 1. Siegel, A. and Wildmann, S.G.
(1954). Phytopathology 54: 277. Tochihara, H., Komuro, Y. and Kobari, Y.
(1964). Proc. Kanto Pl. Prot. Soc. 11: 46. Van Regenmortel, M.H.V. (1982). In:
Serology and Immunochemistry of Plant Viruses, p. 147 and p. 166. Academic
Press, New York. Zhu, P.K., Lu, M.K., Wang, M.Q., Xia, Y.N., Sun, X.G., Jin,
C.X. and Shen, Q. (1984). Acta phytopath. Sin. 14: 59.


Rice black-streaked dwarf fijivirus

      (1) E. Shikata, 1987; Li Jing, 1987. (2) Synonyms: rice black streak
virus. (3) Standard acronym: RBSDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.7.2.003. (8)
First reported in Oryza sativa var. japonica. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Kuribayashi and Shinkai (1952). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza sativa, Zea
mays, Triticum sativum, Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare stunted, deformed leaves
with white waxy or black-streaked swellings along the veins. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Laodelphax
striatellus (Kuribayashi and Shinkai, 1952; Shinkai, 1962), Unkanodes
sapporona (Shinkai, 1966) and U. albifascia (Shinkai, 1967). (18) Transmitted
by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in China, Japan, Korea D.P.R. (North), and Korea Republic. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Oryza sativa var. japonica stunting,
darkening of leaves, twisting of tips of young leaves, white waxy swellings
along veins on the abaxial leaf surface, later becoming brown and forming
black-streaked tumours. Zea mays dwarfening, darkening of leaves, white
streaks along the veins and white waxy swollen veins on the abaxial surface of
leaves. Triticum sativum, Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare severe stunting,
twisting of leaves, sometimes with waxy swollen veins on the abaxial surface
of leaves and culms. (45) Oryza sativa, Triticum sativum, Avena sativa and
Hordeum vulgare. (46) Zea mays cv. Golden Cross Bantam (W) (Zea mays useless
as a virus source for insect transmission). (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Oryza sativa, or Oryza sativa var. japonica, or Triticum aestivum,
or Triticum sativum, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <7/7>. (53) Shinkai (1962);
Morinaka and Sakurai (1968). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 6 days, or 7 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 5 <in rice plants>, or 6 <in insects>. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: leaves fixed in 2% osmium
tetroxide or 2% paraformaldehyde before extraction yield the large virions of
75-80 nm with the outer projections attached. (60) Method: Kitagawa and
Shikata (1969); Kawano et al. (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 75-80 nm in diameter <in cells of infected plants and
insects>, or 55 nm in diameter <B-spiked subvirions>, or 70 nm in diameter
<intact virions>. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Doublestranded. (91) Total genome size 23.898 kb. (92) Genome of 10 parts
<named S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 3.998 kb. (94) The 2nd
largest 3.385 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 3.31 kb. (96) The 4th largest 3.31 kb.
(97) The 5th largest 3.1 kb. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 2.45 kb
<pairs; also 2.198, 1.830, 1.826 and 1.810 kb pairs>. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10990. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00606 Em(40)_vi:RBDSEG10
Gb(84)_vi:RBDSEG10 Rice black-streaked dwarf virus genome segment 10. 11/90
1,801bp. L36524 Gb(84)n:RBDGS3A Rice black-streaked dwarf virus genome segment
3 fragment. 10/94 939bp. S63914 Em(40)_vi:S63914 Gb(84)_vi:S63914 orf (segment
8) rice black-streaked dwarf virus RBSDV, Genomic RNA, 1927 nt. 1/94 1,927bp.
S63917 Em(40)_vi:S63917 Gb(84)_vi:S63917 orf1, orf2 (segment 7) rice
black-streaked dwarf virus RBSDV, Genomic RNA, 2193 nt. 1/94 2. (171) Virions
found in phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms, or crystals in the nucleus.
(177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: hyperplasia and
hypertrophy of phloem cells. (179) Fijivirus: Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae.
(184) Reported to be serologically closely related to maize rough dwarf
fijivirus (Luisoni et al., 1973); their relationship is so close that they may
be the same species. (187) Kashiwagi, Y. (1966). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan
32: 168. Kawano, S., Uyeda, I. and Shikata, E. (1984). J. Fac. Agric. Hokkaido
Univ. 61: 408. Kitagawa, Y. and Shikata, E. (1969). Mem. Fac. Agric. Hokkaido
Univ. 6: 446. Kuribayashi, K. and Shinkai, A. (1952). Ann. Phytopath. Soc.
Japan 16: 41. Luisoni, E., Lovisolo, O., Kitagawa, Y. and Shikata, E. (1973).
Virology 52: 281. Morinaka, T. and Sakurai, Y. (1968). Bull. Chugoku agric.
exp. Stn. Ser. E 2: 1. Shikata, E. (1974). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 135,
4 pp. Shinkai, A. (1962). Bull. nat. Inst. agric. Sci., Tokyo Ser. C., p. 223.
Shinkai, A. (1966). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 32: 317. Shinkai, A. (1967).
Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 35: 318.


Rice bunchy stunt (?) phytoreovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and H. Hibino, 1988. (5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.8.T.DE.1.
(8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From southern China. (10) By Chen et
al. (1978). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza sativa most cultivars have short
narrow mottled leaves, are severely stunted with increased tillering;
intolerant cultivars also produce nodal branches and bunches of short narrow
leaves which have the appearance of birds nests. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nephotettix virescens, N.
cincticeps. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Chen et al.
(1978); Xie et al. (1979, 1980); Xie and Lin (1980, 1982). The virus occurs
sporadically in rice fields; average incidence differs according to year,
location and cultivar, it was less than 1% in 1974, 1975, 1980 and 1981, over
3% from 1976-1979 and highest (3.2%) in 1977, but has declined since 1981.
Infected rice plants can over-winter and produce new leaves from which
non-viruliferous leafhoppers can acquire virus. Viruliferous nymph and adult
leafhoppers can also over-winter. (39) Spreads in China. (43) Oryza sativa
symptoms as in naturally infected plants. (45) Oryza sativa. (46) Oryza sativa
(W). (47) Oryza sativa. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 60 °C <in rice sap;
determined by micro injection of vectors>. (55) LIV: 4 days <at 2°C>. (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <about> 60 nm in
diameter. (171) Virions found in cells of leaves and roots. (179) <Possible>
Phytoreovirus: Reoviridae. (180) : Reoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: rice dwarf virus. (184) No cross protection
in rice plants previously infected with rice dwarf or rice ragged stunt
viruses. (187) Chen, S.H., Lin, H.Y., Xi, L.H. and Hu, F.P. (1978). Scientia
Agric. Sinica 3: 79. Xie, L.H., Chen, Z.X. and Lin, Q.Y. (1979). Acta
Phytopath. Sin. 9: 93. Xie, L.H. and Lin, J.Y. (1980). Kexue Tongbao 25: 786.
Xie, L.H. and Lin, J.Y. (1982). Int. Rice Res. Newsl. 7: 6. Xie, L.H. and Lin,
H.Y. (1983). Acta Phytopath. Sin. 13: 15. Xie, L.H., Lin, Q.Y. and Zhu, Q.L.
(1982). Acta Phytopath. Sinica 12: 16.


Rice dwarf phytoreovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990; H. Hibino, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: RDV. (4)
Strains: severe strain and a vector non-transmissible strain. (5) ICTV decimal
code 60.0.8.0.002. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Shiga, Japan.
(10) By Takada (1895 and 1896). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms stunting,
fine chlorotic specks on leaves. (13) Echinochloa crus-galli, Paspalum
thumbergii, Oryza sativa, Alopecurus aequalis stunting, white chlorotic specks
on leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Nephotettix cincticeps, N. apicalis, N. nigropictus, N.
virescens, Recilia dorsalis. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (22) Principal
natural vector(s): Nephotettix cincticeps. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (28) Virus transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Miyai et al.
(1986). (39) Spreads in China, Japan, Korea D.P.R. (North), Korea Republic,
and Nepal. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show stunting, white specks on leaves, darker leaf colour. (43)
Alopecurus japonicus, A. aequalis, Avena sativa, Echinochloa crus-galli,
Hordeum sativum, Oryza cubensis, O. sativa, Panicum miliaceum, Poa annua,
Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum stunting and systemic chlorotic specks. (44)
Andropogon sorghum, Setaria italica, Zea mays. (45) Alopecurus japonicus,
Oryza sativa. (46) Oryza sativa (W). (47) Alopecurus aequalis, or Alopecurus
japonicus, or Avena sativa, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Hordeum sativum, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Oryza cubensis, or Oryza sativa, or Panicum miliaceum, or
Paspalum thumbergii, or Poa annua, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum.
(48) Andropogon sorghum, or Setaria italica, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae
<13/16>. (51) Gramineae <3/16>. (53) Fukushi (1934); Shinkai (1962). (54) TIP:
45-50 °C. (55) LIV: 10 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4 <in sap from
rice leaves>. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Iida et al. (1972).
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 70 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 510 S. (79) Density 1.26 g cm3 in
CsCl <T>, or 1.38 g cm3 in CsCl <M1>, or 1.43 g cm3 in CsCl <M2>, or 1.46 g
cm3 in CsCl <B>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.4. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 25.13 kb <pairs>. (92)
Genome of 12 parts <named S110>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.354 kb
<pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.385 kb <pairs>. (95) The 3rd largest 3.195 kb
<pairs>. (96) The 4th largest 2.468 kb <pairs>. (97) The 5th largest 2.57 kb
<pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 1.699 kb <pairs; also 1.696,
1.424, 1.305, 1.319, 0.887 and 0.828 kb pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Kimura et al. (1987). (100) Base composition 21.8-22.8 % G. (101)
Base composition 27.8-28.4 % A. (102) Base composition 21.4-21.6 % C. (103)
Base composition 28-28.2 % U. (105) Base composition of ds genome 42.3-48.1 %
(G + C). (106) 5' terminus of RNA has an unusual type. (107) 5' terminus of
RNA shows the sequence of GGCA or GGUA. (109) Infectivity lost when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 10991. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00241

Rice gall dwarf phytoreovirus

      (1) T. Omura, 1984. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: RGDV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 60.0.8.0.003. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From
Thailand. (10) By Omura et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza
sativa stunting, gall formation and dark green leaves. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nephotettix
nigropictus, N. cincticeps, N. malayanus, N. virescens, Recilia dorsalis. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector.
(28) Virus transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in China. (40) Found, but with no evidence
of spread, in Malaysia and Thailand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Lolium multiflorum, Secale cereale, Triticum
aestivum stunting, gall formation and leaf discoloration. (45) Oryza sativa.
(46) Avena sativa (W), Hordeum vulgare (W), Oryza sativa (W), Secale cereale
(W), Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium
multiflorum, or Oryza sativa, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum. (48)
Secale cereale. (50) Gramineae <6/6>. (51) Gramineae <1/6>. (53) Putta et al.
(1982). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Omura et al. (1982).
(61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 65 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.406 g cm3 in
CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.42 <uncorrected for scattering>. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (91) Total genome size 25.191 kb
<pairs>. (92) Genome of 12 parts <named S112>. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the largest> 4.423 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 3.385 kb <pairs>.
(95) The 3rd largest 3.205 kb <pairs>. (96) The 4th largest 2.5 kb <pairs>.
(97) The 5th largest 2.47 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts
1.72 kb <pairs; also 1.720, 1.578, 1.202, 1.198, 1.190 and 0.600 kb pairs>.

peptide component of rice gall dwarf virus when tested by immunoblotting.
