Rice grassy stunt tenuivirus

      (1) H. Hibino, 1985. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: rice rosette
Philippines virus, probably rice rosette virus (Bergonia et al., 1966;
Gingery, 1988; Ling, 1972). (3) Standard acronym: RGSV. (4) Strains: GSV1 and
GSV2 in the Philippines, wilted stunt virus (GSW), grassy stunt B (GSV),
grassy stunt Y (GSY) in Taiwan. GSV 2-like strains in India, Indonesia and
Thailand. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Oryza
sativa. (9) From the Philippines. (10) By Ribera et al. (1966). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Oryza sativa severe stunting, excessive tillering, erect growth
habit, short, narrow pale green leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nilaparvata bakeri, N. lugens,
N. muiri. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Khush and Ling
(1974); Ling et al. (1976); Chen (1984). (39) Spreads in China, India,
Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, and Thailand.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Oryza sativa cv. Shan San Sa San
striping of leaves. Oryza sativa cv. Taichung Native 1 excess tillering,
short, narrow pale green leaves. (45) Oryza sativa. (46) Oryza sativa (W).
(47) Cynodon dactylon, or Cyperus rotundus, or Echinochloa colona, or Leersia
hexandra, or Monochoria vaginalis, or Oryza punctata, or Oryza sativa. (50)
Cyperaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <5/5>, or Pontederiaceae <1/1>. (53) Ling
(1979); Anjaneyulu et al. (1988). (55) LIV: 0.5 days <12 hours>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 2. (59) Electron microscopy: virions difficult to detect in sap.
(60) Method: Hibino et al. (1985a; 1985b). (61) Virions filamentous <often
circular>. (63) Virions not enveloped. (70) Virions of 950-1350 nm. (71)
Virions 6 nm wide. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 15.46 kb. (92) Genome of four parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 4.39 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.94 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 3.64 kb. (96)
The 4th largest 3.49 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (145)
Method of preparation: Hibino et al. (1985a). (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, crystals in
the nucleus, and unusual in shape. (176) Bundles of fibrillar structures.
(178) Other cellular changes: occurrence of small spherical virions in sieve
tubes and phloem cells (Pellegrini and Bassi, 1978, Shikata et al., 1980).
(179) Tenuivirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: rice
stripe virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: maize
stripe and rice hoja blanca viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: use
combination of symptomatology, transmission tests using Nilaparvata lugens and
serology. (187) Anjaneyulu, A., Daquioag, R.D., Mesina, M. E., Hibino, H.,
Lubigan. R.T. and Moody, K. (1988). Int. Rice Res. Newsl. 13: 37. Bergonia,
Capule, Novera and Calica (1966). Philipp. J. Pl. Ind. 31: 47. Chen, C.C.
(1984). Plant Prot. Bull. Taiwan 26: 315. Chen, C.C. and Chiu, R.J. (1982).
Plant Dis. 66: 15. Gingery, R.E. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses Vol. 4, The
Filamentous Plant Viruses, p. 302; ed. R.G. Milne. Plenum Press, New York.
Hibino, H. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 320, 5 pp. Hibino, H., Iwasaki,
M. and Izumi, K. (1982). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 48: 388. Hibino, H.,
Usugi, T. and Tsuchizaki, T. (1983a). Int. Rice Res. Newsl. 8: 11. Hibino, H.,
Usugi, T., Omura, T. and Shohara, K. (1983b). Int. Rice Res. Newsl. 8: 9.
Hibino, H., Cabauatan, P.Q., Omura, T. and Tsuchizaki, T. (1985a). Plant Dis.
69: 538. Hibino, H., Usugi, T., Omura, T., Tsuchizaki, T., Shohara, K. and
Iwasaki, M. (1985b). Phytopathology 75: 894. Khush, G.S. and Ling, K.C.
(1974). J. Hered. 65: 134. Ling, K.C. (1972). Rice Virus Diseases. Los Banos,
Philippines, Int. Rice Res. Inst. Ling, K.C. (1979). Int. Rice Res. Inst., Los

B: 89. Toriyama, S. (1985). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 51: 59.


Rice hoja blanca tenuivirus

      (1) F.J. Morales, 1984. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: echinochloa hoja
blanca virus (Falk et al., 1987). (3) Standard acronym: RHBV. (4) Strains:
echinochloa strain (Morales and Niessen, 1985). (5) ICTV decimal code
69.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Colombia. (10) By
Garcés (1940); Morales and Niessen (1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza
sativa, wild Oryza spp. systemic necrosis, systemic chlorotic striping in
early infections. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Sogatodes orizicola. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Everett and Lamey
(1969); Lamey (1967). (38) Spreads in the South and Central American region.
(39) Spreads in Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador,
El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, and Venezuela <and elsewhere
in the Caribbean>. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Avena sativa, Digitaria spp., Hordeum
vulgare, Leptochloa spp., Oryza sativa cv. Bluebonnet-50, Secale cereale,
Triticum aestivum chlorotic stripes. (44) Host range restricted to Gramineae.
(45) Purified from susceptible Oryza sativa cultivars only. (46) Susceptible
Oryza sativa cultivars (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Digitaria, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Leptochloa, or Oryza sativa, or Secale cereale, or Triticum
aestivum. (50) Gramineae <7/7>. (53) Lamey et al. (1964). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Morales and Niessen (1983). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (71) Virions 3 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations to two sedimenting components in purified preparations <in
caesium salts>, or one sedimenting component in purified preparations to three
sedimenting components in purified preparations <in sucrose>. (79) Density
1.288 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.5. (84) Virions contain 12 %
nucleic acid <determined from A260/280>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 17.59 kb. (92) Genome of
four parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9.8 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
3.5 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.3 kb. (96) The 4th largest 1.99 kb. (117) NCBI

Rice necrosis mosaic bymovirus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: RNMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.3.0.005. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Okayama, Japan.

susceptible. (43) Oryza sativa spindle shaped yellow flecks and streaks. (44)

7-14 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)

Rice ragged stunt oryzavirus

      (1) G. Boccardo, 1984. (2) Synonyms: rice infectious gall virus. (3)
Standard acronym: RRSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 60.0.9.0.003. (8) First reported
in Oryza sativa. (9) From Indonesia and the Philippines. (10) By Hibino et al.
(1977); Ling (1977); Shikata et al. (1977). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza
latifolia, O. nivara, O. sativa stunting, enations on veins of leaves and leaf
sheaths, ragged leaves, flower suppression. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Nilaparvata lugens. (18)
Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29)
Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (39) Spreads in Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Japan,
Malaysia, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, and Thailand. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Oryza sativa cv. Taichung Native (TN-1) pale
spindle-shaped enations on abaxial surfaces of leaves and leaf sheaths,
twisted and ragged leaves, dark green colour, suppressed flowering, infected
plants remain green and appear grassy after healthy plants have senesced. (44)
Triticum aestivum, Saccharum spp. (45) Oryza sativa cv. Taichung Native
(TN-1). (46) Oryza sativa (W). (47) Hordeum vulgare, or Oryza latifolia, or

(1979); Shikata et al. (1979). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <whole leaf

protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm. (166) Replication does not depend on
a helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem enations. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are

Rice stripe necrosis (?) furovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987 and C. Fauquet, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: RSNV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 27.0.1.T.011. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9)
From Ivory Coast. (10) By Louvel and Bidaux (1977). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Oryza sativa chlorotic striping and necrosis of leaves, stunting and
reduced tillering. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus.
(17) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Cote

chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana benthamiana necrotic ringspots. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Oryza sativa. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Fauquet and Thouvenel (1983). (54) TIP: <more than>
50 °C. (60) Method: Fauquet and Thouvenel (1983). (61) Virions rodshaped. (69)

preparations. (179) <Possible> Furovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically

Rice stripe tenuivirus

      (1) S. Toriyama, 1984. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: ine shima-ha gare
uirusu. (3) Standard acronym: RSV. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.0.005. (8)
First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Japan. (10) By Koganezawa et al.,
1975. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena sativa, Digitaria adscendens, D.
violascens, Eragrostis multiflorum, Hordeum vulgare, Oryza sativa, Setaria
italica, S. viridis, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays systemic necrotic or
chlorotic spots and streaking. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Laodelphax striatellus, Terthron
albovittatum, Unkanodes sapporona, U. albifascia. (18) Transmitted by
Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation <but only with great difficulty>. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads in China, Japan,
Taiwan, and the former USSR. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Oryza
sativa (Japonica type), Triticum aestivum, Zea mays chlorotic stripe and pale
streaking. (44) Anthoxanthum odoratum, Elymus tsukushiensis var. transiens,
Festuca arundinacea, Phalaris arundinacea, Poa pratensis. (45) Oryza sativa
Japonica type varieties, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays. (46) Oryza sativa
japonica type cvs Norin 8, Kinmaze, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays cv. Golden
Cross Bantam, all (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Cynodon dactylon, or Dactylis
glomerata, or Digitaria adscendens, or Digitaria violascens, or Eragrostis

sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Toriyama (1982a). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (71)

Virions contain 12 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 88 % protein. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome of four parts.

Rice transitory yellowing (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) E. Shikata, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: RTYV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.047. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Taiwan. (10) By
Chiu et al. (1965). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Oryza
sativa japonica types are more susceptible than indica types. Yellow or
orange-buff colouring of oldest leaves, some rusty flecking. No systemic
symptoms. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Nephotettix nigropictus, N. cincticeps, N. impictus. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Taiwan. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Okinawa, Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Oryza sativa japonica type yellow or orange-buff colouring of oldest
leaves. (45) Oryza sativa japonica type. (46) Oryza sativa japonica type (W).
(47) Oryza sativa, or Oryza sativa var. japonica. (48) Echinochloa colona, or
Echinochloa crus-galli. (50) Gramineae <2/4>. (51) Gramineae <2/4>. (53) Chiu
et al. (1968). (55) LIV: 11 days <at 0°C to 2°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5.
(60) Method: Inoue et al. (1986). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (70)
Virions of 129 nm <120140 nm>. (71) Virions 96 nm wide. (171) Virions found in
leaves, phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear
space. (179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Chiu, R.J., Jean, J.H., Chen, M.H. and Lo, T.C. (1968).
Phytopathology 58: 740. Chiu, R.J., Lo, T.C., Pi, C.L. and Chen, M.H. (1965).
Bot. Bull. Acad. Sin., Taipei 6: 1. Inoue et al. (1986). Tech. Bull. Trop.
Agr. Res. Center, Japan 21: 65. Shikata, E. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses
No. 100, 3 pp.


Rice tungro bacilliform badnavirus

      (1) H. Hibino, 1987. Updated by A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: rice
yellow orange leaf virus. (3) Standard acronym: RTBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
07.0.1.0.009. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From Indonesia. (10) By
Rivera and Ou (1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza sativa leaves
yellow-orange, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by especially Nephotettix virescens, but also N.
nigropictus, N. cincticeps, N. malayanus, N. parvus, Recilia dorsalis. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26)
Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(29) Virus requires, for vector transmission, a helper virus <rice tungro
spherical waikavirus>. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Cabunagan et al. (1987); Hibino et al. (1987); Hibino et al.
(1988); Tiongco et al. (1988); Khan et al. (1991). (38) Spreads in the Eastern
Asian region. (39) Spreads in China. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Oryza sativa leaves yellow-orange, stunting. (45) Oryza sativa. (46) Oryza
sativa (W), Oryza australiensis (W), Oryza longistaminata (W), Oryza barthii
(W), Oryza latifolia (W), Oryza nivara (W), Oryza glaberrima (W), Oryza
perennis (W), Eleusine indica (W), Cyperus rotundus (W), Fimbristylis miliacea
(W), Leersia hexandra (W), Monochoria vaginalis (W). (47) Cyperus rotundus, or
Eleusine indica, or Fimbristylis miliacea, or Leersia hexandra, or Monochoria
vaginalis, or Oryza australiensis, or Oryza barthii, or Oryza glaberrima, or
Oryza latifolia, or Oryza longistaminata, or Oryza nivara, or Oryza perennis,
or Oryza sativa. (50) Cyperaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <10/10>, or
Pontederiaceae <1/1>. (53) Anjaneyulu et al. (1988). (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: use PTA or UA, fixation not required.
(60) Method: Omura et al. (1983); Cabauatan and Hibino (1988). (61) Virions
bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 110-400 nm in length.
(71) Virions 30-35 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.312 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of DNA.
(89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 8.3 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hibino et al.
(1991). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10654. (118) Sequence database accession code(s):
D10774 Em(40)_vi:RTBWG Gb(84)_vi:RTBWG Rice tungro bacilliform virus whole
genome. 9/92 8,002bp. M65026 Em(40)_vi:LERTUORFS Gb(84)_vi:RTUORFS Rice tungro
bacilliform open reading frames 1, 2, 3, and 4 genomic RNA. 12/92 8,000bp.
M95497 Em(40)_vi:LERTUPOLY Gb(84)_vi:RTUPOLYP Rice tungro virus polyprotein
gene, complete cds. 1/93 12,484bp. X57924 Em(40)_vi:RTBVPHIL
Gb(84)_vi:RTBVPHIL Rice tungro bacilliform virus (infectious clone) ORF's P24,
P12, P194 & P46. 6/91 8,002bp. 4 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133)
Mr 32000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, vascular
parenchyma and phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: starch accumulation.
(179) Badnavirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA or latex serology,
transmission test using Nephotettix virescens, symptomatology. (186) Rice
"tungro" disease is caused by a complex of rice tungro badnavirus and rice
tungro spherical waikavirus; the badnavirus depends on the waikavirus for its
transmission by leafhoppers, and causes the tungro symptoms, whereas the
waikavirus alone causes mild stunting and enhances the tungro symptoms. (187)

Rice tungro spherical waikavirus

      (1) H. Hibino, 1987. Updated by A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: rice
leaf yellowing virus, rice penyakit habeng virus, rice penyakit mentek virus,
rice waika virus, rice yellow leaf virus. (3) Standard acronym: RTSV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 65.0.2.0.004. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From the
Philippines. (10) By Gálvez (1968). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Oryza sativa
slight stunting (but when in complex exacerbates the symptoms induced by rice
tungro badnavirus). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by especially Nephotettix virescens. (18) Transmitted
by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost
by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28)
Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus
can help the vector transmission of another virus <rice tungro bacilliform
badnavirus>. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus
not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Furuta (1977);
Bajet et al. (1986); Hibino et al. (1987); Khan et al. (1991). (38) Spreads in
the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads in China and Japan. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Oryza sativa mild stunting, grain discoloration.
(45) Oryza sativa. (46) Oryza sativa (W). (47) Axonopus compressus, or
Brachiaria mutica, or Cynodon dactylon, or Cyperus brevifolius, or Cyperus
difformis, or Cyperus rotundus, or Digitaria ciliaris, or Echinochloa colona,
or Eleusine indica, or Eragrostis tenella, or Fimbristylis miliacea, or
Imperata cylindrica, or Leersia hexandra, or Monochoria vaginalis, or Oryza
australiensis, or Oryza barthii, or Oryza glaberrima, or Oryza latifolia, or
Oryza longistaminata, or Oryza nivara, or Oryza perennis, or Oryza sativa.
(50) Cyperaceae <4/4>, or Gramineae <17/17>, or Pontederiaceae <1/1>. (53)
Anjaneyulu et al. (1988). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: use PTA or UA. (60) Method: Omura et al. (1983); Cabauatan and
Hibino (1988). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with
a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 175 S <±5>. (79) Density
1.551 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 10.422 kb. (99) Genomic
nucleic acid isolated by Hibino et al. (1991). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35287.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): S65252 Em(40)_vi:S65252
Gb(84)_vi:S65252 polyprotein rice tungro spherical virus RTSV, Genomic RNA,
2823 nt. 1/94 2,823bp. 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
23000. (134) And it is coat protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 24000. (136) Coat
protein. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, vascular parenchyma and phloem.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies, viroplasms, and unusual in shape.
(176) Lattice or tubular structures. (177) They contain virions <in
viroplasms>, or they do not contain virions <in lattice structures>. (178)
Other cellular changes: some starch accumulation. (179) Waikavirus:
Sequiviridae <the type species>. (180) : Sequiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: maize chlorotic dwarf virus. (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: use electron microscopy, ELISA or latex agglutination serology.
(186) Rice tungro disease is caused by a complex of rice tungro badnavirus and
rice tungro spherical waikavirus; the badnavirus depends on the waikavirus for
its transmission by leafhoppers, and causes the tungro symptoms, whereas the
waikavirus alone causes mild stunting and enhances the tungro symptoms. (187)
Anjaneyulu, A., Daquioag, R.D., Mesina, Ma.E., Hibino, H., Lubigan, R.T. and
Moody, K. (1988). Int. Rice Res. Newsl. 13: 30. Bajet, N.B., Daquioag, R.D.
and Hibino, H. (1985). J. Pl. Prot. Tropics 2: 125. Bajet, N.B., Aguiero,
V.M., Daquioag, R.D., Jonson, G.B., Cabunagan, R.C., Mesina, E.M. and Hibino,
H. (1986). Plant Dis. 70: 971. Cabauatan, P.Q. and Hibino, H. (1985). Philipp.

Rice yellow mottle sobemovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and W. Bakker, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: RYMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 67.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Oryza sativa. (9) From
Kisumu, Western Kenya. (10) By Bakker (1970). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Oryza sativa yellow or orange leaves, stunting, reduced tillering and
sterility. Oryza longistaminata chlorosis and mottling. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Sesselia pusilla,
Chaetocnema pulla, Trichispa serica and Dicladispa viridicyanea. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26)
Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(36) Studies reported by Bakker (1970, 1971, 1974); Fauquet and Thouvenel
(1977); Rossel et al. (1982); John et al. (1984). (39) Spreads in Burkina
Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Kenya, Liberia, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, and
Tanzania <and, possibly, Zanzibar>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Oryza sativa chlorotic dotting of leaf bases, elongating parallel to veins to
produce mottling, stunting. Oryza barthii yellow spots and vein streaking.
Oryza punctata systemic chlorotic dots. Dinebra retroflexa mild systemic
mottling. Phleum arenarium systemic mottling and leaf death. (45) Oryza sativa
cv. Sindano. (46) Oryza sativa cvs Sindano and IR 20 (W). (47) Dinebra
retroflexa, or Oryza barthii, or Oryza longistaminata, or Oryza punctata, or
Oryza sativa, or Phleum arenarium. (50) Gramineae <6/6>. (53) Bakker (1970,
1974). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C <in sap from infected rice>. (55) LIV: 99 days <at
20°C>, or 260 days <at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-9. (57) Infectivity of
sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Bakker (1975); Fauquet and Thouvenel (1977). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 116 S. (79) Density 1.359 g cm3 in CsCl. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 6. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.46-1.54. (84) Virions contain
23 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 77 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.2 kb.
(92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (100) Base
composition 29 % G. (101) Base composition 21 % A. (102) Base composition 25 %
C. (103) Base composition 25 % U. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31744. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): L20893 Em(40)_vi:RYVCGEN Gb(84)_vi:RYVCGEN Rice
yellow mottle virus complete genome. 2/94 4,450bp. U23142 Em(43)_vi:Ry23142
Gb(89)_vi:Ryu23142 Rice yellow mottle virus from Nigeria, complete genome.
4/95 4,451bp. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Sobemovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cocksfoot
mottle and cocksfoot mild mosaic (syn. phleum mottle) viruses. (187) Bakker,
W. (1970). Neth. J. Pl. Path 76: 53. Bakker, W. (1971). Neth J. Pl. Path. 77:
201. Bakker, W. (1974). Agric. Res. Reports 829: 152 pp. Bakker, W. (1975).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 149, 4pp. Fauquet, C. and Thouvenel, J.C.
(1977). Pl. Dis. Reptr 61: 443. John, V.T., Thottappilly, G. and Awoderu, V.A.
(1984). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 32: 86. Rossel, H.W., Thottappilly, G. and
Buddenhagen, I.W. (1982). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 30: 137.


Rice yellow stunt virus

      (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.33. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31720. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): X75534 Em(40)_vi:RYSVNP Gb(84)_vi:RYSVNP
Rice yellow stunt virus mRNA for nucleocapsid protein. 11/93 1,920bp. 1
sequence. (179) (Ungrouped).


Rose (?) tobamovirus

      (1) R.G.T. Hicks, 1991. (2) Synonyms: rose colour break virus (Hunter,
1966; Farrar and Frost, 1972). (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.T.DE.3. (8) First
reported in Rosa spp. (9) From Essex, U.K. (10) By Hicks and Frost (1984).
(11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms flower break. (13) Rosa spp. deformed
flecked and streaked petals, but roses infected with this tobamovirus, by sap
or grafting, show no flower symptoms so the cause of the flower break disease
is unknown. (15) Disseminated by vegetative propagation. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting
<with difficulty>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the UK.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show local lesions, usually necrotic; systemic mosaics or mottles, or
symptomless. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions; systemic
chlorotic lines and spots. Cucumis sativus cvs Lemon, BDR starch lesions in
cotyledons; not systemic. Datura stramonium chocolate local lesions; not
systemic. Nicotiana debneyi chlorotic mottle; systemic necrotic local lesions
or mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa necrotic local lesions; systemic mosaic and
leaf deformation. Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. tabacum cv. White Burley necrotic
local lesions; symptomless systemic. Petunia × hybrida cv. Rose of Heaven
necrotic local lesions; systemic mottle or flower break or symptomless. (44)
Pisum sativum cv. Onward, Vicia faba, Catharanthus roseus cv. Little Pinkie.
(45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. White Burley, Petunia × hybrida cv.
Rose of Heaven. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Cucumis sativus (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum <cv. White Burley>, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Rosa, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata. (48)
Catharanthus roseus <cv. Little Pinkie>, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Pisum sativum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/4>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <9/10>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>, or Solanaceae
<1/10>. (53) Hicks (1979); Hicks and Frost (1984). (54) TIP: 95 °C. (55) LIV:
730 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Hicks and Frost (1984). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with no clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 310-320 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obvious. (73) Axial canal 2.5 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix obscure. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.2. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (171) Virions found in leaves. (179) <Possible> Tobamovirus.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: the ash isolate of tobacco
mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: sunn-hemp
mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Nicotiana tabacum produces no
systemic symptoms. Petunia × hybrida shows flower break at 14 or 17°C, but not
22°C or higher. (187) Farrar, E.H. and Frost, R.R. (1972). Pl. Path. 21: 97.
Hicks, R.G.T. (1979). Ph.D. Thesis University of Manchester, U.K. Hicks,
R.G.T. and Frost, R.R. (1984). Pl. Path. 33: 581. Hunter, J.A. (1966). N.Z. Jl
agric. Res. 9: 1070.


Rottboellia yellow mottle sobemovirus

      (1) S.L. Bhattiprolu, 1993. (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.DE.01. (8)
First reported in Rottboellia cochinchinensis syn. R. exaltata. (9) From
Nigeria. (10) By Thottapilly et al. (1992). (11) Symptoms persist. (12)
Symptoms chlorotic mottling and severe stunting. (13) Rottboellia
cochinchinensis chlorotic leaf mottling. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Nigeria. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic chlorotic mottle and
stunting. (43) Rottboellia cochinchinensis systemic chlorotic mottle. Zea mays
chlorotic spots, systemic mottle and stunting. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
Datura stramonium, Glycine max, Oryza sativa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Triticum
aestivum. (45) Rottboellia cochinchinensis. (46) Rottboellia cochinchinensis
(W), Zea mays (W). (47) Rottboellia cochinchinensis <syn. R. exaltata>, or Zea
mays. (48) Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or Bromus commutatus, or Bromus
sterilis, or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus,
or Hordeum vulgare, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza
sativa, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phalaris arundinacea, or Phaseolus lunatus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phleum pratense, or Pisum sativum, or Secale
cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum durum, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Gramineae <2/12>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Gramineae <10/12>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Solanaceae <9/9>. (53) Thottapilly et al.
(1992). (60) Method: Thottapilly et al., 1992. (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 29 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 114 S <decreasing to c. 87S after EDTA treatment>.
(79) Density 1.379 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density two components in caesium
sulphate; 1.29-1.31 and 1.32-1.33 g cm3. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.51. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 4.4 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.4
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Thottapilly et al., 1992. (108)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases. (112) Additional factor
required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27000. (134) Coat. (145) Method
of preparation: Thottapilly et al., 1992. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm <virion
aggregates>. (177) They contain virions. (179) Sobemovirus. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: cocksfoot mild mosaic, cocksfoot mottle,
cynosurus mottle, lucerne transient streak, panicum mosaic, rice yellow mottle
and sowbane mosaic viruses. (187) Thottapilly, G., van Lent, J.W.M., Rossel,
H.W. and Sehgal, O.P. (1992). Ann. appl. Biol. 120: 405.


Rubus Chinese seed-borne (?) nepovirus

      (1) D.J. Barbara, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: RCSV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.T.005. (8) First reported in Rubus spp. (9) From the U.K. (in seed
imported from China). (10) By Barbara et al. (1985). (13) Rubus spp. infected
seedlings show no symptoms. (15) As the virus is probably a nepovirus, it is
likely to have a nematode vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in China. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K. from seed imported from
China. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa
chlorotic local lesions, systemic chlorosis, deformation, necrotic flecking.
Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions, systemic chlorotic flecking or
chlorosis. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium
quinoa (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
bernhardii, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or
Rubus. (48) Aubrieta deltoidea, or Aurinia saxatilis, or Brassica oleracea
var. botrytis, or Cucurbita pepo, or Helianthus annuus, or Lupinus
polyphyllus, or Medicago sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus,
or Rubus idaeus, or Solanum melongena, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Compositae <1/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/9>, or Rosaceae <1/2>, or Scrophulariaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <11/12>. (51) Compositae <1/2>, or Cruciferae <4/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/9>, or Rosaceae <1/2>,
or Solanaceae <1/12>. (53) Barbara et al. (1985). (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: stable in 2% Na-PTA, pH 6.5, partially disrupted in 2% UA. (60)
Method: Barbara et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter <some virions are penetrated by
negative stain and these are 8-10% smaller in some preparations>. (66) Virions
angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations <in sucrose density
gradients>, or three sedimenting components in purified preparations <in
CsCl>. (79) Density 1.461 g cm3 in CsCl, or 1.452 g cm3 in CsCl <not fixed
with aldehydes>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.71 <B>, or 0.87 <T>. (84) Virions
contain 37 % nucleic acid <B>, or 36 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid
<T>. (85) Virions 63 % protein <B>, or 64 % protein <T>, or 100 % protein <T>.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) <Possibly> linear. (92)
Genome of two parts. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Barbara et al.
(1985). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion
protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 47000. (134) Probably structural
protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 25200. (136) Structural protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Barbara et al. (1985). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and epidermis (so far only
these have been tested). (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies and unusual
in shape. (176) And tubular structures within the outer membrane. (177) They
contain virions. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: strawberry latent ringspot
virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis mosaic,
cherry leaf roll, elm mosaic, myrobalan latent ringspot, satsuma dwarf,
tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring, and tomato ringspot viruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: use serology ELISA. (187) Barbara, D.J., Ashby, S.C. and
McNamara, D.G. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 107: 45.


Rubus yellow net (?) badnavirus

      (1) A.T. Jones, 1987. Checked 1989. (2) Synonyms: probably raspberry
yellow mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: RYNV. (5) ICTV decimal code
07.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Rubus procerus. (9) From Canada. (10) By
Stace-Smith (1955). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Rubus strigosus (red
raspberry) chlorotic netting of leaf veins. R. procerus (Himalayan blackberry)
chlorotic netting or yellow chlorosis, or no symptoms. R. occidentalis (black
raspberry) chlorotic netting of leaf veins. N.B. the virus usually occurs
mixed with other aphid-borne viruses, and these induce mosaic diseases of red
and black raspberry. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent
manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Stace-Smith and Jones (1978).
(38) Spreads in the Eurasian region and the North American region. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Rubus idaeus, R. occidentalis, R. procerus
vein netting. Fragaria vesca downcurling of leaves, then necrosis of petiole,
wilting and plant death. Rubus macraei vein netting. (45) Rubus macraei, R.
idaeus, R. occidentalis. (47) Fragaria vesca, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus
macraei, or Rubus occidentalis, or Rubus procerus, or Rubus strigosus. (50)
Rosaceae <6/6>. (53) Stace-Smith and Jones (1978); Jones and Badenoch (1982).
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: 2% AM (pH 6.5).
(61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 80-150 nm
in length. (71) Virions 25-31 nm wide. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis and vascular
parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: cell wall outgrowths and
parallel arrangements of long tubules. (179) <Probably> Badnavirus. (187)
Stace-Smith, R. (1955). Can J. Bot. 33: 269. Stace-Smith, R. and Jones, A.T.
(1978). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 188, 4 pp. Jones, A.T. and Badenoch, J.
(1982). Acta Hort. 129: 49.


Ryegrass alphacryptovirus

      (1) P.L. Guy, 1987. (2) Synonyms: ryegrass spherical cryptic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: RGCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.013. (8) First reported
in Lolium multiflorum, (unknown cultivar) which may have also contained
ryegrass mosaic virus. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Plumb (1973). (13) Lolium
perenne, Lolium multiflorum, Lolium multiflorum × L. perenne symptomless but
may enhance symptoms of ryegrass mosaic virus in some cultivars. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus transmitted
by pollen to the seed. (39) Spreads in Australia, Germany, Italy, and the UK.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (47) Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium
multiflorum × L. perenne, or Lolium perenne. (50) Gramineae <3/3>. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions <or very few virions; more virions in plants also
infected with ryegrass mosaic virus>. (59) Electron microscopy: repeated
testing with ISEM necessary to ensure that preparation is free of other
viruses. (60) Method: extract sap in distilled water, heat 40°C for 10
minutes, then purify through differential centrifugation. (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 29-30 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (171) Virions
found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (179)
Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) : Partitiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: beet cryptic and carnation cryptic viruses.
(187) Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1980). Proc. 3rd Conf. on Virus Diseases of
Gramineae in Europe, p. 73. Plumb, R.T. and Lennon, A.M. (1980). Proc. 3rd
Conf. on Virus Diseases of Gramineae in Europe, p. 75.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Lolium ryegrass virus. (3) Standard
acronym: LoRV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.027. (8) First reported in
Lolium perenne, L. multiflorum × L. perenne. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Plumb
and James (1975). (13) Lolium spp. probably symptomless, but may intensify the
symptoms of ryegrass mosaic rymovirus. (47) Lolium multiflorum × L. perenne,
or Lolium perenne. (50) Gramineae <2/2>. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped.
(70) Virions of 288 nm <in vivo>, or 210 nm <for damaged virions found in
negatively stained sap>. (71) Virions 68 nm wide. (171) Virions found in
mesophyll within membrane bound vesicles. (172) Virions found in the

Rhabdoviridae. (187) Plumb, R.T. and James, M. (1975). Ann. appl. Biol. 80:
181.


Ryegrass mosaic rymovirus

      (1) R.T. Plumb, 1980. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: ryegrass streak mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: RGMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.2.0.005. (8)
First reported in Lolium multiflorum. (9) From Washington state U.S.A. (10) By
Bruehl et al. (1957). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Lolium spp. in Europe,
Lolium spp. and Dactylis glomerata in North America chlorotic flecking,
mosaic, necrosis with some isolates, stunting and fewer tillers. Symptoms
usually more obvious in L. multiflorum and L. multiflorum × L. perenne than in
L. perenne. Necrosis rare in L. perenne. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by Abacarus hystrix. (19) Transmitted
by Eriophyidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in
the Eurasian region and the North American region. (39) Spreads in Australia.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Avena sativa, Lolium multiflorum
systemic mosaic, necrotic flecking and striping. L. perenne systemic mosaic.
(47) Avena sativa, or Bromus mollis, or Dactylis glomerata, or Festuca
pratensis, or Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium multiflorum × L. perenne, or
Lolium perenne, or Oryza sativa, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Avena sativa. (50)
Gramineae <9/9>. (51) Gramineae <1/9>. (53) Mulligan (1960). (54) TIP: 60 °C.
(55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: Paliwal et al. (1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 700 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 166 S. (79) Density 1.325 g cm3
in CsCl <at 25°C>, or 1.3049 g cm3 in CsCl <when fixed with glutaraldehyde>.
(84) Virions contain 5.3 % nucleic acid. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 9-10 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9-10 kb. (100) Base
composition 31 % G. (101) Base composition 23 % A. (102) Base composition 24 %
C. (103) Base composition 22 % U. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 40666. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 29200. (145) Method of preparation: Paliwal et
al. (1976). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176)
And cylindrical structures. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: vacuolation of cytoplasm. (179) Rymovirus: Potyviridae <the
type species>. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: isolates of the virus from Europe and North America are closely
related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: agropyron
mosaic, spartina mottle, hordeum mosaic, wheat streak mosaic and oat necrotic
mottle viruses. (187) Bruehl, G.W., Toko, H. and McKinney, H.H. (1957).
Phytopathology 47: 517. Gibson, R.W. and Heard, A.J. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol.
91: 101. Mulligan, T.E. (1960). Ann. appl. Biol. 48: 575. Paliwal, Y.C. and
Tremaine, J.H. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 406. Plumb, R.T. and James, M.
(1973). J. gen. Virol. 18: 409. Slykhuis, J.T. (1958). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 6:
129. Slykhuis, J.T. and Paliwal, Y.C. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
86, 4 pp. Slykhuis, J.T., Watson, M.A. and Mulligan, T.E. (1956). Rep.
Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1956, p. 104.

Saguaro cactus (?) carmovirus

      (1) J.H. Tremaine, 1988. (2) Synonyms: cactus Saguaro virus. (3)
Standard acronym: SCV. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.2.0.011. (8) First reported
in Carnegiea gigantea. (9) From Arizona, U.S.A. (10) By Milbrath and Nelson
(1972). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Carnegiea gigantea, Chamaecereus sylvestrii

with no evidence of spread, in Arizona, U.S.A. or Germany. (43) Chenopodium
capitatum systemic vein-clearing and necrosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa local lesions, not systemic. Gomphrena globosa local lesions, systemic
spots. (45) Chenopodium capitatum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L). (47) Carnegiea gigantea, or Chamaecereus sylvestrii, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Cactaceae <2/2>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>. (54) TIP: 55-65 °C. (55) LIV: 34 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Nelson and Tremaine
(1975). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 32 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 118 S. (79) Density 1.33 g cm3 in
CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 3.5, 5, and 5.5. (84) Virions contain 17 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.2
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (100)
Base composition 29 % G. (101) Base composition 24 % A. (102) Base composition
21 % C. (103) Base composition 27 % U. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in
the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (132) Virion protein(s) one <and
degraded protein and dimers 5%>. (133) Mr 38900. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Nelson and Tremaine (1975). (147) Amino acid
composition: Nelson and Tremaine (1975). (166) Replication does not depend on
a helper virus. (171) Virions found in cactus buds, flowers and fruit. (179)
<Possible> Carmovirus: Tombusviridae. (180) : Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: carnation mottle and turnip crinkle
viruses. (184) Like carmoviruses it produces dsRNAs, and of a similar size
(1.7 and 1.5 kbp) (Morris and Carrington, 1985). (187) Morris, T.J. and
Carrington, J.C. (1985). In: The Plant Viruses, Vol. 3, Polyhedral Virions
with Monopartite RNA Genomes, p. 73 ed. R. Koenig. Plenum Press, New York.
Milbrath, G.M. and Nelson, M.R. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 739. Nelson, M.R.
and Tremaine, J.H. (1975). Virology 65: 309. Nelson, M.R., Yoshimura, M.A. and
Tremaine, J.H. (1975). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 148, 4 pp.

Satsuma dwarf (?) nepovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and Y. Saito, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: SDV. (4)
Strains: citrus mosaic, natsudaidai dwarf and navel orange infectious
mottling. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.006. (8) First reported in Citrus
unshiu (Satsuma). (9) From Japan. (10) By Yamada (1950). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Citrus unshiu stunting, leaf malformation and rosetting. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <8.6% transmission in Phaseolus vulgaris>. (36) Studies
reported by Usugi and Saito (1979). (39) Spreads in Japan and Turkey. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic and
necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Physalis floridana systemic mottling and
leaf malformation. Sesamum indicum local lesions; systemic vein clearing,
necrosis and leaf deformation. Vigna unguiculata local lesions; vein clearing
and mottling, necrotic streaking of petioles and stems. (45) Physalis
floridana. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrus
unshiu, or Physalis floridana, or Sesamum indicum, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Pedaliaceae
<1/1>, or Rutaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Tanaka and Nakanishi
(1972); Usugi and Saito (1977). (54) TIP: 50-55 °C <in Physalis floridana
sap>. (55) LIV: 8-12 days <at room temperature>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Usugi and Saito (1979). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 129 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 119
S <M>. (79) Density 1.46 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.43 g cm3 in CsCl <M>. (84)
Virions contain 37 % nucleic acid <B>, or 33 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 %
nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 63 % protein <B>, or 67 % protein <M>, or 100 %
protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total
genome size 10.1 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part <the larger> 5.3 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.8 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
47416. (132) Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 42000. (134) Coat
protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 21000. (136) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Usugi and Saito (1979). (171) Virions found in mesophyll and
epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous bodies <vesicular>. (178)
Other cellular changes: tubular outgrowths of cell walls containing a single
row of virions. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cherry leaf roll, citrus
leaf rugose, grapevine Bulgarian latent, mulberry ringspot, raspberry
ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot, tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and
tomato ringspot viruses. (187) Tanaka and Nakanishi (1972). Ann. Phytopath.
Soc. Japan 38: 212. Usugi, T. and Saito, Y. (1977). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan
43: 137. Usugi, T. and Saito, Y. (1979). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 208, 4
pp. Yamada, M. (1950). Bull. Hort. Div. Tokai-Kirki Agric. Exp. Stn 1: 61.


Schefflera ringspot badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: SRV. (5) ICTV decimal code
07.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Brassica actinophylla. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Lockhart. (13) Brassica actinophylla spreading chlorotic ringspots.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (47) Brassica actinophylla. (50) Cruciferae <1/1>.
(61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 120-150 nm
in length. (71) Virions 25-30 nm wide. (179) Badnavirus. (187) Lockhart, B.E.
and Hull, R. (1991). In: Classification and Nomenclature of Viruses; Report of
the ICTV. Eds R.I.B. Francki, C.M. Fauquet, D.L. Knudson and F. Brown. Arch.
Virol., Suppl. 2, p. 153.


Scrophularia mottle tymovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1991. (2) Synonyms: scrophularia-Scheckungsvirus. (3)
Standard acronym: ScrMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.015. (8) First
reported in Scrophularia nodosa. (9) From Germany. (10) By Hein (1959). (11)
Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms mottling. (13) Scrophularia nodosa mottling
and vein clearing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Cionus tuberculosis, C. scrophularia, C.
hortulanus, C. alauda. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Germany. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local
lesions, systemic mottle or mosaic. (43) Antirrhinum majus systemic green
spots. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. Datura
stramonium yellow spreading local lesions, systemic spotting and mosaic. Vicia
faba chlorotic local lesions. (44) Arachis hypogaea, Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Cucumis sativus, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Antirrhinum majus, Datura
stramonium. (46) Vicia faba (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Catalpa
bignonioides, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura
stramonium, or Pisum sativum, or Scrophularia nodosa, or Valerianella, or
Vicia faba. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Bellis perennis, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Cassia artemisioides, or Cucumis
sativus, or Daucus carota, or Delphinium hybridum, or Eucalyptus cloeziana, or
Euphorbia marginata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or Fragaria vesca, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Gypsophila elegans, or Helianthus annuus, or Ipomoea purpurea, or
Lactuca sativa, or Leptosiphon, or Lobelia erinus, or Myosotis sylvatica, or
Papaver nudicaule, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Podolepis robusta, or Salvia splendens, or Sinningia speciosa, or
Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna radiata, or Viola cornuta. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Bignoniaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/4>, or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/2>, or Valerianaceae <1/1>.
(51) Boraginaceae <1/1>, or Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or
Gesneriaceae <1 /1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/4>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Myrtaceae <1/1>,
or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or
Ranunculaceae <1 /1>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/2>, or Tropaeolaceae
<1/1>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>, or Violaceae <1/1>. (53) Bercks (1973); Hein
(1959); Guy et al. (1984). (54) TIP: 90 °C. (55) LIV: 30 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5-6. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Bercks (1973). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 116 S. (78) Of the other(s) 54 S.
(79) Density 1.351 and 1.449 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 7. (84)
Virions contain 37 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 63 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 6 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome
part 6 kb. (100) Base composition 15.9 % G. (101) Base composition 21.3 % A.
(102) Base composition 33.7 % C. (103) Base composition 29.3 % U. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 21600. (134) Coat protein. (147) Amino acid
composition: Bercks (1973). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (179) Tymovirus.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: ononis yellow mosaic virus
is the closest related, but also Andean potato latent, belladonna mottle,
dulcamara mottle, eggplant mosaic and turnip yellow mosaic viruses. A virus
from Anagyris foetida in Italy is closely related (Rana et al., 1988). (185)
Best tests for diagnosis: virions serologically close to ononis yellow mosaic
virus but the virions of ononis yellow mosaic virus have a lesser IEP. (187)
Bercks, R. (1973). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 113. Bercks, R., Huth, W.,
Koenig, R., Lesemann, D.-E., Paul, H.L. and Querfurth, G. (1971). Phytopath.
Z. 71: 341. Guy, P.L., Dale, J.L., Adena, M.A. and Gibbs, A.J. (1984). Pl.
Path. 33: 337. Hein, A. (1959). Phytopath. Z. 36: 290. Rana, G.L., Castellano,
M.A. and Koenig, R. (1988). J. Phytopath. 121: 239.


Serrano golden mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) J.K. Brown, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SGMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.033. (8) First reported in Capsicum annuum cv. Serrano. (9) From
Sinaloa, Mexico. (10) By Brown and Poulos (1990). (11) Symptoms vary
cyclically over a few weeks. (12) Symptoms golden mosaic. (13) Capsicum annuum
cvs Serrano, Bell, Anaheim golden mosaic; green mosaic, stunting and fruit
deformation. Lycopersicon esculentum interveinal chlorosis; sometimes necrosis
of blossom end of fruit and deformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted
by Aleyrodidae. (24) Not transmitted by Trialeurodes vaporariorum. (25)
Transmitted in a semipersistent manner, or in a persistent manner. (26) Virus
lost by the vector when it moults. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <with difficulty>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus
not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in Mexico <Sinaloa and, possibly, Sonora>, or the USA <in
greenhouse grown tomatoes in Arizona>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show golden mosaic. (43) Capsicum
frutescens, C. annuum golden mosaic. Lycopersicon esculentum, Datura
stramonium yellow mosaic. (44) Cucumis melo, Cucurbita maxima, C. pepo,
Lactuca sativa, Gossypium hirsutum. (45) Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon
esculentum. (46) Capsicum annuum (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum. (48) Cucumis
melo, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Gossypium hirsutum, or
Lactuca sativa. (50) Solanaceae <4/4>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae
<3/3>, or Malvaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
similar to that for other geminiviruses, but variable concentrations in pepper
add difficulty. (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65)
Virions <dimers> 30 nm in length. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.37. (84) Virions
contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 5.2 kb. (92)
Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.6 kb. (94) The 2nd
largest 2.6 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Brown: incubate 1% SDS
at 42°C; extract with phenol chloroform, ethanol precipitate. (108)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (179) Bigeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
distinguish by transmission with Bemisia tabaci to susceptible pepper. (187)
Brown, J.K. and Poulos, B.T. (1990). Plant Dis. 74: 720.


Shallot latent carlavirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1987. (2) Synonyms: garlic laent virus (Van Dijk, 1993). (3)
Standard acronym: SLV. (4) Strains: type, garlic and Asian shallot strains
recognized (Van Dijk, 1993). (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.1.0.028. (8) First
reported in Allium cepa var. ascalonicum. (9) From the Netherlands. (10) By
Bos (1972). (13) Allium porrum mild chlorotic streaking. Allium cepa var.
cepa, A. sativum, A. cepa var. ascalonicum symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus (Sciamyzus)
ascolonicus and, perhaps, Aphis fabae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Bos et al. (1978); Paludan (1980). (37)
Probably distributed worldwide <all shallots tested have been found to be
infected>. (39) Spreads in Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Japan, and the
UK. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium album, C.
amaranticolor, C. quinoa small dry local lesions in yellowing leaves, often
developing green rings. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii, N.
tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (45) Allium
porrum, A. fistulosum (`filter host' to separate the leek yellow stripe
virus). (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Allium cepa,
or Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium cepa var. cepa, or Allium
fistulosum, or Allium porrum, or Allium sativum, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa. (48) Chrysanthemum, or
Cichorium endiva, or Crotalaria, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lilium formosanum,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Tulipa, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays.
(50) Alliaceae <6/6>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Liliaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <5/5>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Bos et al. (1978). (54) TIP: <about> 80 °C. (55)
LIV: 8-11 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: virions best seen in PTA, often aggregated
end-to-end. (60) Method: Bos et al. (1978); molecular sieving through Sephadex
G-200, then equilibrium density gradient centrifuging in CsCl (Bos et al.,
1978). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight <or slightly curved>. (69) Virions with a clear modal length.
(70) Virions of 650 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 147.5 S. (79) Density 1.313 g cm3 in CsCl. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12172. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23200. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Huttinga (1975). (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm <Paludan, 1980>. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: narcissus latent and lonicera latent viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: chrysanthemum B, nerine latent, pea streak,
poplar mosaic, potato S, potato M, red clover vein mosaic, lily symptomless
and carnation latent viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM with
antiserum or shallot latent virus, rapid formation of local lesions on
Chenopodium amaranticolor and C. quinoa and local lesions more numerous and
smaller than those of leek yellow stripe virus. (187) Bos, L. (1972).
Gewasbesch. 3:81. Bos, L. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 250, 4 pp.
Bos, L., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 84: 227.
Huttinga, H. (1975). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 81: 81. Paludan, N. (1980). Tidsskr.
PlAvl. 84: 371. Van Dijk, P. (1993). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 99: 233.


Shallot mite-borne latent (?) potexvirus

      (1) P. van Dijk, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.09. (8) First
reported in Allium cepa var. ascalonicum. (9) From the Netherlands (in
shallots imported from Asia). (10) By Van Dijk et al. (1991). (11) Symptoms
none. (13) Allium cepa var. ascalonicum symptomless infection or sometimes
slight mottle. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a mite. (17)
Transmitted by Aceria tulipae. (19) Transmitted by Eriophyidae. (24) Not
transmitted by aphids; Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus (Sciamyzus) ascolonicus.
(29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Van Dijk et
al. (1991): vegetative propagation, latent infection, omnipresence and
abundance of the vector imply that the virus can be readily spread and is
difficult to control. (39) Spreads in China, the Netherlands, Thailand, and
the former USSR. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show mostly symptomless or show chlorotic local
lesions. (43) Allium cepa, A. cepa var. ascalonicum, A. vineale symptomless
infection or slight mottle. (44) Allium porrum, A. sativum, A. fistulosum,
Chenopodium murale. (45) Allium cepa, A. cepa var. ascalonicum. (46) Allium
cepa, A. cepa var. ascalonicum (W). (47) Allium cepa, or Allium cepa var.
ascalonicum, or Allium vineale. (48) Allium fistulosum, or Allium porrum, or
Allium sativum, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chlorophytum comosum, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana hesperis, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or
Vicia faba. (50) Alliaceae <3/6>. (51) Alliaceae <3/6>, or Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Anthericaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Van Dijk et al.
(1991). (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 767 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): M97264 Em(40)_vi:SLVRNAGEN
Gb(84)_vi:SLVRNAGENM Shallot virus X DNA sequence, open reading frames 1 ( RNA
replicase) through 5 (coat protein) 1 sequence. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in
shape. (179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: onion mite-borne latent virus is distantly related to shallot
mite-borne latent virus, but distantly. Shallot virus X is probably onion
mite-borne latent virus, and/or shallot mite-borne latent virus (Van Dijk and
van der Vlugt, 1994). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: no
serological relationship with potyviruses, when tested in ISEM with polyclonal
antibodies raised against whole potyvirus virions. (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: no local lesions in Chenopodium spp., especially Chenopodium
murale; virions in the electron microscope are clearly more flexuous than
those of poty and carlaviruses; no decoration of virions with antisera to poty
or carlaviruses (if raised to uncontaminated virus cultures). (186) The onion
mosaic virus reported from the former U.S.S.R. (Cheremushkina, 1982;
Razvjaskina, 1971), was probably a mixture of onion mite-borne latent, shallot
mite-borne latent and onion yellow dwarf viruses (Van Dijk et al., 1991).
(187) Cheremushkina, N.P. (1982). Trudy po Selektsii i Semenovodstvu
Ovoshchnyak Kultur 15: 74. Razvjazkina, G.M. (1971). Tag. Akad. Landw. D.D.R.
115: 69. Van Dijk, P. and van der Vlugt, R.A.A. (1994). Eur. J. Pl. Path. 100:
269. Van Dijk, P., Verbeek, M. and Bos, L. (1991). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 97: 381.


Shallot yellow stripe (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (4) Strains: Common and virulent (Van Dijk, 1993).
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.12. (8) First reported in Allium cepa var.
ascalonicum (shallot). (9) From the Netherlands from bulbs from Asia. (10) By
Van Dijk (1993). (13) Allium cepa var. ascalonicum mild striping of young
leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon pisum, Myzus cymbalariae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
China, Indonesia, and Thailand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Allium cepa var. cepa cv. Stuttgarter Riesen systemic leaf chlorosis, necrosis
and malformation, plant stunting and, occasionally, death (virulent strain),
or systemic chlorotic striping (common strain). Allium sativum, Lilium
formosanum systemic yellow leaf striping and etching (virulent strain). (44)
Allium porrum (leek), A. fistulosum (Welsh onion), Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. murale, C. quinoa, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. occidentalis, Vicia faba. (45)
Allium cepa var. cepa. (46) Allium cepa var. cepa (W). (47) Allium cepa, or
Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium cepa var. cepa <cv. Stuttgarter
Riesen>, or Allium sativum, or Lilium formosanum. (48) Allium fistulosum, or
Allium porrum, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana occidentalis, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba. (50) Alliaceae
<4/6>, or Liliaceae <1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <2/6>, or Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<2/2>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions
of 750 nm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
viroplasms. (179) <Possible> Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: leek yellow stripe and
onion yellow dwarf viruses. (187) Van Dijk, P. (1993). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 99:
Suppl.2, 48pp.


Shamrock chlorotic ringspot (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.13. (8) First
reported in Oxalis regnellii. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Coyier (1981). (13)
Oxalis regnellii chlorotic ringspots in leaves, subsequent decline and death
of plants. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Aulocorthum circumflexum. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA. (47)
Oxalis regnellii. (50) Oxalidaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 850 nm. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Coyier, D.L.
(1981). Plant Dis. 65: 275.


Sieg River (?) potexvirus

      (1) R. Koenig, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.10. (8) First
reported in river water. (9) From the river Sieg, Germany. (10) By Koenig and
Lesemann (1985). (15) Probably spread by water. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Germany. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mottle.
(43) Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor, C. capitatum, C. foliosum, C.
murale, C. schraderianum systemic mottle. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local
lesions. (44) Nicotiana spp., Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Vicia faba,
Antirrhinum majus. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Gomphrena globosa (L),
Chenopodium quinoa (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Chenopodium schraderianum, or Gomphrena globosa. (48) Antirrhinum
majus, or Capsicum annuum, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/6>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <10/10>. (60) Method: Koenig
and Lesemann (1983 and 1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 466 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome unipartite. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 22800. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and the
epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and unusual in
shape. (176) Paracrystalline aggregates. (177) They contain virions. (179)
<Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
plantago severe mosaic and viola mottle viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: potato X, cactus X, cymbidium mosaic, papaya
mosaic and white clover mosaic viruses. (187) Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E.
(1983). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 265. Koenig, R. and Lesemann, D.-E.
(1985). Phytopath. Z. 112: 105.


Silene X (?) potexvirus

      (1) R.I. Hamilton, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.11. (8) First
reported in Silene latifolia ssp. alba. (9) From British Colombia, Canada.
(10) By Hamilton (1984). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Silene latifolia ssp.
alba usually symptomless, sometimes a slight mosaic, stunting. (15) Infected
plants occur in orchards and on roadsides which are frequently mown. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (39) Spreads in Canada. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show usually symptomless or systemic
mosaic. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions;
systemic mosaic. Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii necrotic local lesions;
systemic mosaic. Vigna unguiculata chlorotic rings; systemic mosaic. (44)
Narcissus spp., Solanum tuberosum (5 cultivars). (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (W), C. quinoa (W), Gomphrena globosa (L), Phaseolus
vulgaris (L), Pisum sativum (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Dianthus barbatus, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Silene latifolia ssp.
alba, or Spergula arvensis, or Stellaria media, or Vigna unguiculata. (48)
Narcissus, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae
<4/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/4>. (51) Amaryllidaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/4>. (53) Wakarchuk and Hamilton (1989). (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: aldehyde fixation. (60)
Method: Brunt (1966). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)
Virions of 546 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74)
Basic helix obscure. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl <±0.3>. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.18. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear.
(91) Total genome size 6.9 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 6.9 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hamilton: phenol
extraction of purified virus in 100 mm NH4CO3 (pH 9.0), 10 mm EDTA and 1% SDS;
precipitation of RNA in EtOH. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (112) Additional factor
not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the
virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (125) 4 virus specified dsRNA species found
in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 17.1 kbp. (127)
2nd largest 7 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 5.7 kbp. (129) 4th largest 4.6 kbp. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 29000. (134) Capsid protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Laemmli (1970). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells.
(179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: Argentine plantago, clover yellow mosaic, cymbidium mosaic, daphne X,
hydrangea ringspot, narcissus mosaic, viola mottle and white clover mosaic
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: silene X virus often occurs mixed
with ribgrass mosaic virus in Silene latifolia ssp. alba. It rapidly infects
Chenopodium quinoa systemically, whereas ribgrass mosaic virus does it more
slowly. (187) Brunt, A.A. (1966). Ann. appl. Biol. 58: 13. Laemmli, U.K.
(1970). Nature, Lond. 227: 680. Wakarchuk, D.A. and Hamilton, R.I. (1989).
Intervirology 30: 330.


Sint-Jan's onion latent (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: Welsh onion latent virus (Van Dijk
and Sutarya, 1992; Van Dijk, 1993). (3) Standard acronym: SJOLV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 14.0.1.0.029. (8) First reported in Allium sp. (unidentified).
(9) From the Netherlands. (10) By Van Dijk (1993). (13) Allium sp. unident.
(Sint-Jan's onion), A. ampeloprasum var. sectivum (pearl onion), A. cepa var.
ascalonicum (shallot), A. cepa var. perutile (ever-ready onion), A. chinense
(rakkyo), A. fistulosum (Welsh onion) symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus (Sciamyzus)
ascalonicus. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Indonesia, The Netherlands. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show No symptoms. (43) Allium cepa var.
cepa, A. vineale (crow garlic), A. cepa var. ascalonicum, A. fistulosum (Welsh
onion) symptomless infection. (44) Allium sativum, Chlorophytum comosum,
Lilium formosanum. (45) Allium cepa var. cepa, A. vineale. (46) Allium cepa
var. cepa (W). (47) Allium ampeloprasum var. sectivum, or Allium cepa, or
Allium cepa var. ascalonicum, or Allium cepa var. cepa, or Allium cepa var.
perutile, or Allium chinense, or Allium fistulosum, or Allium vineale. (48)
