related virions: Shallot latent and garlic common latent carlaviruses. (186)
The virus is also considered to be a serological variant of shallot latent
virus (Barg et al. 1995). (187) Barg, E., Lesemann, D.-E., Vetten, H.J. and
Maiss, E. (1995). Proc. 8th Conf. Virus Dis. Vegetables, p.26. Van Dijk, P.
(1993). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 93: 233. Van Dijk, P. and Sutarya, R. (1992).
Internal Doc. DLO, Wageningen, pp.70.


Sitke waterborne (?) tombusvirus

      (1) A.A.Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: SWBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.1.0.013. (8) First reported in water from River Sitke. (9) From Germany.
(10) By Yi et al. (1992). (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
plants in Germany (River Sitke at Braunschweig and Neustadt). (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (47) Chenopodium

clevelandii. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (60) Method:
Gallitelli et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped.
(64) Virions 33 nm in diameter. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 4.8 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
35800. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (178) Other
cellular changes: few peroxisomal vesicles induced; endoplasmic reticulum
adjacent to peroxisomes. (179) <Possible> Tombusvirus: Tombusviridae. (180) :
Tombusviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Artichoke
mottled crinkle, carnation Italian ringspot, cymbidium ringspot, cucumber
necrosis, eggplant mottled crinkle, grapevine Algerian latent, Lato River,
pepper Moroccan, Neckar River, petunia asteroid mosaic, pelargonium leaf curl
and tomato bushy stunt tombusviruses, and 15 carmoviruses. (184) In Northern
blot hybridization tests, the genomic RNA showed some homology with the
genomic RNAs of grapevine Algerian latent, petunia asteroid mosaic and
cymbidium ringspot tombusviruses. (187) Gallitelli, D., Hull, R. and Koenig,
R. (1985). J. gen Virol. 66: 1523. Yi, L., Lesemann, D.-E., Koenig, R., Rüdel,
M. and Pfeilstetter, E. (1992). J. Phytopathology 134: 121.

Solanum apical leaf curling (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) L.F. Salazar, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SALCV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.T.057. (8) First reported in Solanum tuberosum. (9) From San
Ramon, Junin, Peru. (10) By Hooker and Salazar (1983). (11) Symptoms persist.
(12) Symptoms curling, dwarfing and chlorosis of tip leaves. (13) Solanum
tuberosum upward rolling, narrowing and dwarfing of tip leaflets. Red or
purple discoloured leaflet bases. Tubers do not sprout or produce short, thin
sprouts. Solanum basendopogon, S. basendopogon f. obtusum mild chlorosis of
apical leaves. Nicandra physalodes chlorosis. Physalis peruviana stunting and
chlorosis with green leaf veins. Datura tatula vein yellowing, tip leaves
curled downward and dwarfed. Severe chlorosis in older infections. (15)
Probably transmitted by leafhoppers. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted
by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Peru. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show curling, dwarfing and chlorosis. (43) Datura tatula, D.
stramonium, Nicotiana benthamiana curling, dwarfing and chlorosis of apical
leaves. Solanum nigrum chlorosis. Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicandra physalodes
symptomless. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, Datura tatula, D. stramonium,
Lycopersicon esculentum. (46) Datura tatula (W), Datura stramonium (W). (47)
Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum
basendopogon, or Solanum basendopogon f. obtusum, or Solanum nigrum, or
Solanum tuberosum. (50) Solanaceae <10/10>. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Hooker and Salazar (1983). (61) Virions geminate, or
unusually shaped. (62) Virions trisegmented virions. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 17 nm in diameter. (65) Virions <up to> 52 nm in
length. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations <usually, but 1 or 2
components seen in some preparations>. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (171) Virions found in leaves, phloem and
companion cells. (179) <Possible> bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serology (ELISA). (187) Hooker,
W.J. and Salazar, L.F. (1983). Ann. appl. Biol. 103: 449. Hooker, W.J.,
Salazar, L.F. and Brown, C.R. (1985). Am. Potato J. 62: 263.


Solanum nodiflorum mottle sobemovirus

      (1) R.S. Greber and J.W. Randles, 1986. (2) Synonyms: solanum nigrum
mosaic virus, solanum nodiflorum virus. (3) Standard acronym: SNMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 67.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Solanum nodiflorum, an
endemic species (Henderson, 1974). (9) From eastern Australia. (10) By Greber
(1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum nodiflorum, S. nitidibaccatum, S.
nigrum leaf mottling and rugosity. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Epilachna vigintioctopunctata
pardalis (syn. E. sparsa), E. vigintisexpunctata vigintisexpunctata (syn. E.
doryca australica) and E. guttatopustulata. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Australia <the east>. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Solanum nodiflorum systemic leaf mottling
and puckering. Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic local lesions; systemic vein
chlorosis, mottling and puckering. Nicotiana debneyi necrotic local lesions
and small chlorotic ring local lesions; not systemic. (45) Nicotiana
clevelandii for purification. Solanum nodiflorum for culture and vector
maintenance. (46) Nicotiana debneyi (L). (47) Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum nitidibaccatum, or Solanum nodiflorum, or
Solanum rostratum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13/13>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53)
Greber (1981); Jones and Mayo (1984). (54) TIP: 90 °C. (55) LIV: 365 days <at
2°C and 7 years at -20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (57) Infectivity of sap
not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Greber (1981); Hollings et al. (1979); Kiberstis and
Zimmern (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 28-30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
114 S <Hollings et al., 1979>. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 4.2
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (99)
Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gould and Hatta (1981). (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12471. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): J02386 Em(40)_vi:NOR2
Gb(84)_vi:MSNR2 solanum nodiflorum mottle virus (circular viroid-like) RNA2.
4/90 377bp. 1 sequence. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions.
(121) Is satellite RNA <of 2 species, (RNA-2 and RNA-3), which are similar in
size (c. 0.37 kb) but one is circular (RNA-2) the other linear (Gould et al.,
1981; Jones and Mayo, 1984)>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000.
(134) Coat protein (Hollings et al., 1979; Greber, 1981; Chu and Francki,
1983). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (168) Acts as
helper for a satellite RNA <Some of the isolates of the virus have no
satellite RNA; Jones and Mayo, 1984>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in nuclei. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm,
membranous bodies, and unusual in shape. (176) Long tubules or rod structures.
(179) Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: velvet
tobacco mottle virus (Randles et al., 1981; Chu and Francki, 1983). (184) No
serological relationship was found to 53 other viruses with isometric virions
(Hollings et al., 1979). (187) Chu, P. and Francki, R.I.B. (1983). Virology
129: 350. Gould, A.R. and Hatta, T. (1981). Virology 109: 137. Gould, A.R.,
Francki, R.I.B. and Randles, J.W. (1981). Virology 110: 420. Greber, R.S.
(1965). Aust. Plant Dis. Rec. 17: 18. Greber, R.S. (1973). Aust. Pl. Path.
Soc. Newsl. 2: 3. Greber, R.S. (1981). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 34: 369. Greber,
R.S. and Randles, J.W. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 318, 5 pp.
Henderson, J. (1974). Qld. Herb. Contrib. 16: 78 pp. Hollings, M., Stone,
O.M., Barton, R.J. and Greber, R.S. (1979). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst.
1978, p. 150. Jones, A.T. and Mayo, M.A. (1984). J. gen. Virol. 65: 1713.
Kiberstis, P.A., Haseloff, J. and Zimmern, D. (1985). EMBO J. 4: 1984.
Kiberstis, P.A. and Zimmern, D. (1984). Nucl. Acids Res. 12: 933. Randles,
J.W., Davis, C., Hatta, T., Gould, A.R. and Francki, R.I.B. (1981). Virology
108: 111.

TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 0.33 days <at c. 18°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63)

Sonchus yellow net nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) J.D. Wagner, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SYNV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.5.0.006. (8) First reported in Sonchus oleraceus. (9) From Florida,
U.S.A. (10) By Christie et al. (1974). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
vein clearing, yellow netting, stunting. (13) Bidens pilosa symptomless; mixed
infection with bidens mottle gives necrotic etching. Lactuca sativa bright
yellow interveinal spotting of older leaves. Sonchus oleraceus chlorotic local
lesions, vein clearing, yellow patches between veins. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis coreopsidis.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Dactynotus sp.,
Hyperomyzus lactucae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (27) Virus
multiplies in the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein clearing, chlorotic local
lesions, malformation or cupping, symptoms often disappear after 46 weeks.
(43) Bidens pilosa symptomless; mixed infection with bidens mottle gives
necrotic etching. Chenopodium quinoa local chlorotic local lesions, not
systemic. Lactuca sativa bright yellow interveinal spotting of older leaves.
Nicotiana benthamiana severe systemic vein clearing. N. clevelandii, N.
debneyi, N. × edwardsonii, N. glutinosa yellow netting, leaf cupping. Sonchus
oleraceus chlorotic local lesions, vein clearing, yellow patches between
veins. Zinnia elegans transient systemic vein clearing. (44) Capsicum
frutescens, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena globosa,
Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Nicotiana × edwardsonii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L).
(47) Bidens pilosa, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum nigrum, or Vigna radiata. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <5/10>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/10>. (53) Christie et al. (1974); Jackson and Christie
(1974); Falk et al. (1986). (55) LIV: 0.33 days <less than 8 hours at 20°C>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: Christie et al. (1974) Jackson and Christie (1974). (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.

Sorghum mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: SrMV. (4) Strains: SCMVH
(Florida) (Abbot and Tibbet, 1966), SCMVI, SCMVM (Koike and Gillespie, 1976),
sorghum mosaic virus H (Florida), sugarcane mosaic virus I, sugarcane mosaic
virus M. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.060. (8) First reported in Saccharum
officinarum. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Abbott and Tippet (1966). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Saccharum officinarum mosaic. Sorghum bicolor mosaic,
red-leaf. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (47) Saccharum officinarum, or Sorghum bicolor.
(50) Gramineae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)

code(s): U07219 Em(40)_vi:SM07219 Gb(84)_vi:SMU07219 Sorghum mosaic virus
strain Sugarcane mosaic virus H polyprotein (nuclear inclusion II protei 1
sequence). (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Bundles, scrolls, tubes
and laminated aggregates; group I inclusions (Edwardson, 1974). (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (184) This virus is one of a
complex of potyviruses infecting tropical grasses. These have been shown by
immunoblot and virion protein sequencing to fall into four species; maize
dwarf mosaic, sugarcane mosaic, sorghum mosaic and Johnson grass mosaic. For
details also check descriptions of the other three species. (187) Abbot, E.V.
and Tippet, R.L. (1966). U.S. Dep. Agric. Res. Serv. Tech. Bull. 1340. Koike,
H. and Gillespie, A.G. (1976). Pl. Dis. Reptr 60: 50. Edwardson, J.R. (1974).

Toler, R.W. and Langham, M.A.C. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 223.


Sorghum stunt mosaic (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and D.E. Mayhew, 1988. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.5.T.D.12. (8) First reported in Sorghum vulgare. (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Mayhew and Flock (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Sorghum
vulgare chlorotic and necrotic mottling and streaking, severe stunting and
fewer seeds. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Graminella sonora. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by there may
be different optimum temperatures for virus transmission and symptom
expression. Temperatures above 38°C kill viruliferous leafhoppers, but induce
severe symptoms. Below 27°C, the vector thrives, but no virus can be detected
in the hosts (Mayhew and Flock, 1981). (39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Sorghum vulgare, Zea mays, Triticum aestivum
systemic chlorotic and necrotic mottling and streaking, severe stunting and
fewer seeds. (44) Hordeum vulgare, Avena sativa. (45) Sorghum vulgare, Zea
mays. (46) Sorghum vulgare (W), Zea mays (W). (47) Sorghum vulgare, or
Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (48) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare. (50)
Gramineae <3/5>. (51) Gramineae <2/5>. (53) Mayhew and Flock (1981). (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions
enveloped. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 220 nm.
(71) Virions 68 nm wide <in sections>. (74) Basic helix obvious. (171) Virions
found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in the perinuclear space.
(179) <Possible> Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: maize mosaic

Sowbane mosaic sobemovirus

      (1) D.S. Teakle, 1985. (2) Synonyms: apple latent virus 2 (Bancroft and
Tolin, 1967; Kirkpatrick et al., 1965), chenopodium mosaic virus (Bennett and
Costa, 1961; Dias and Waterworth, 1967; Silva et al., 1958; Vuittenez, 1962),
chenopodium seed-borne mosaic virus (Dias and Waterworth, 1967), chenopodium
star mottle virus (Bancroft and Tolin, 1967). (3) Standard acronym: SoMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.0.008. (8) First reported in Chenopodium murale. (9)
From Riverside, California, U.S.A. (10) By Bennett and Costa (1961). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Chenopodium spp. systemic chlorotic mottling. Vitis
sp., Prunus domestica latent infection, but rarely infected. Atriplex
suberecta stunting and leaf deformation. Chenopodium murale symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by <probably> a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Circulifer tenellus, Liriomyza langei, Halticus
citri (Bennett and Costa, 1961). Probably none of these transmit frequently or
specifically. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae, or Cicadellidae, or Coleoptera
<and Diptera>. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae; Dias and Waterworth
(1967). (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner <Bennett and Costa, 1961>.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <up to 60% in Chenopodium quinoa;
Dias and Waterworth, 1967, and 2070% in Chenopodium murale; Bennett and Costa,
1961>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed and transmitted by pollen
to the pollinated plant <pollen contains much virus, Francki and Miles, 1985>.
(38) Spreads in the South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in
Australia, Bulgaria, Canada, the former Czechoslovakia, Italy, Japan, the USA,
and the former Yugoslavia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. murale chlorotic local lesions,
systemic yellow flecking, star shaped patterns, leaf deformation. Beta
vulgaris mild systemic mosaic. Only species of Chenopodiaceae show symptoms,
but the virus locally infects plant species of several families including
Solanaceae and Fabaceae (Dias and Waterworth, 1967). (45) Chenopodium
amaranticolor; C. quinoa; C. murale for maintenance. Spinacia oleracea for
purification. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L); C. quinoa (L). (47) Atriplex
hortensis, or Atriplex suberecta, or Beta macrocarpa, or Beta vulgaris, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Fabaceae, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus lunatus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Prunus domestica, or Solanaceae, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vitis. (48) Nicotiana glutinosa. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <10/10>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/5>, or
Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51) Solanaceae <1/5>. (54) TIP: <usually> 86-96 °C <Dias
and Waterworth, 1967; Kado, 1971>. (55) LIV: 60 days <at 23°C; Kado, 1971>.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 7-9 <or more; Kado, 1971; Teakle, 1968>. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions <Teakle, 1968>. (59) Electron microscopy: virions of
some isolates may be more stable in PTA at pH 4 than at pH 7 (Finlay and
Teakle, 1969; Guy, 1982). (60) Method: Steere (1956); Kado (1967); Guy (1982)
used the method of Steere (1956), but resuspended virions in 10 mM sodium
acetate, 1 mM magnesium acetate, pH 6. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 26-28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile, or angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 104-107 S <Kado, 1971; Guy, 1982>. (82) Isoelectric
point pH 4.4 <Kado, 1971>. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 80 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated
by Tremaine and Ronald (1977). (100) Base composition 26 % G. (101) Base
composition 23.2 % A. (102) Base composition 27.2 % C. (103) Base composition
23.2 % U. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent <but infectivity is reduced; Saksena and Mink, 1970>. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000 <Kado, 1967>, or 32000 <Guy, 1982>. (147) Amino
acid composition: Kado, 1967. (171) Virions found in mesophyll and xylem, but
never in phloem (Lombardo et al., 1971). (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and
in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other
cellular changes: proliferation of tonoplasts with concentric membranes
bulging into the vacuole (Lombardo et al., 1971). (179) Sobemovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cocksfoot mottle, lucerne
transient streak, rice yellow mottle, southern bean mosaic and turnip rosette
viruses. (187) Bancroft, J.B. and Tolin, S.A. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 639.
Bennett, C.W. and Costa, A.S. (1961). Phytopathology 51: 546. Dias, H.J. and
Waterworth, H.E. (1967). Can. J. Bot. 45: 1285. Finlay, J.R. and Teakle, D.S.
(1969). J. gen. Virol. 5: 93. Francki, R.I.B. and Miles, R. (1985). Pl. Path.
34: 11. Guy, P. (1982). Australas. Pl. Path. 11: 51. Kado, C.J. (1967).
Virology 31: 217. Kado, C.I. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 64, 4 pp.
Kirkpatrick, H.C., Mink, G.I. and Lindner, R.C. (1965). Phytopathology 55:

Sowthistle yellow vein nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) D.C. Stenger, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SYVV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 62.0.5.0.007. (8) First reported in Sonchus oleraceus. (9) From the
U.S.A. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Hyperomyzus lactucae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22)
Principal natural vector(s): Hyperomyzus lactucae. (24) Not transmitted by
Chaetosiphon jacobi. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus
retained when the vector moults. (28) Virus transmitted congenitally to the
progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus <probably> transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (47) Lactuca
sativa, or Sonchus oleraceus. (50) Compositae <2/2>. (53) Peters (1971). (59)
Electron microscopy: to retain membrane, fix with glutaraldehyde and stain
with neutral PTA, otherwise `bullets' are found. (60) Method: Jackson and
Christie (1977). (61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped.
(68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70)
Virions of 230 nm. (71) Virions 100 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74)
Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 4.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 1000 S.
(80) Density <c.> 1.18 g cm3 in sucrose. (84) Virions contain 1 % nucleic
acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (86) Virions 19 % lipid <probably>. (88)
Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome
size 13-14 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
13-14 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Stenger et al. (1988). (108)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases <probably>. (109)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent <probably>. (119)
Features of the genome: genome encodes at least 4 size classes of
polyadenylated mRNA species. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the
virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion
protein(s) five. (133) Mr <of the largest> 200. (134) L and it is
transcriptase. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 78. (136) G and appear as spikes. (137)
Mr of 3rd largest 56. (138) N, nucleocapsid. (139) Mr of 4th largest 44. (140)
M1. (141) Mr of 5th largest 37. (142) M2. (145) Method of preparation: Dale
and Peters (1981). (148) Virion proteins glycosylated. (149) Are and it is the
G protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in leaves, roots, phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in the perinuclear space. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms and unusual in shape. (176)
And many bacilliform virions found in the perinuclear space. (177) They
contain virions. (179) Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: sonchus
yellow net virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: 32p probes using cloned DNA
fragments in Northern or dot blots. Bacilliform virions in Sonchus oleraceus
transmitted persistently with a long latent period by Hyperomyzus lactucae.
(187) Dale, L.J. and Peters, D. (1981). Intervirology 16: 86. Jackson, A.O.,
Francki, R.I.B. and Zuideman, D. (1987). In: The Rhabdoviruses; ed. R.R.
Wagner. Plenum Press, New York. Peters, D. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses
No. 62, 3 pp. Stenger, D.C., Richardson, J., Sylvester, E.S., Jackson, A.O.
and Morris, T.J. (1988). Phytopathology 78: 1473.


Soybean chlorotic mottle caulimovirus

      (1) Mitsuro Kameya-Iwaki, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: SbCMV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 15.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Glycine max. (9) From Aichi
Prefecture, Japan. (10) By Iwaki et al. (1984). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Glycine max systemic mosaic, stunting. Lablab purpureus systemic
vein-clearing. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local lesions. systemic vein
clearing, mottling, leaf curling. Vigna unguiculata systemic infection, no
symptoms. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Glycine max systemic vein-clearing, followed by leaf
mottling and stunting. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local lesions; systemic
vein-clearing, mottling and leaf curling. Lablab purpureus systemic
vein-clearing. Vigna unguiculata cv. Blackeye symptomless systemic infection.
(44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Nicotiana tabacum, Vicia faba, Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis. (45) Glycine max, Phaseolus vulgaris. (46)
Glycine max (W); Phaseolus vulgaris (L, W). (47) Glycine max, or Lablab
purpureus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Abelmoschus
esculentus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum
annuum, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus
caryophyllus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or
Sesamum indicum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna angularis, or
Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans.
(50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/13>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <9/13>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or
Pedaliaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <8/8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Iwaki
et al. (1984). (54) TIP: 85-90 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Iwaki et al. (1984).
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 50 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Circular.
(91) Total genome size 8.175 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 8.175 kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Hibi et al. (1986). (105) Base composition of ds genome 28 % (G + C). (108)
Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Verver et al. (1986). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10651. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): X15828 Em(40)_vi:CASCMVX
Gb(84)_vi:CASCMVX Soybean chlorotic mottle virus complete genomic sequence.
9/93 8,175bp. 1 sequence. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Caulimovirus. (187) Hibi, T. and Kameya-Iwaki, M. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 331, 4 pp. Iwaki, M., Isogawa, Y., Tsuzuki, H. and Honda, Y.
(1984). Plant Dis. 68: 1009. Hibi, T., Iwaki, M., Saito, Y., Verver, J. and
Goldbach, R. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52 (5): 785. Verver, J.,
Schijns, P., Hibi, T. and Goldbach, R. (1986). J. gen. Virol. 68: 159.


Soybean crinkle leaf (?) bigeminivirus

      (1) M. Iwaki, 1984. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: soybean crinkle virus.
(3) Standard acronym: SCLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.T.058. (8) First
reported in Glycine max. (9) From Phitsanulok, Thailand. (10) By Iwaki et al.
(1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Glycine max leaf deformation and leaf vein
enations. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (39) Spreads in Thailand. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show vein-clearing, leaf mottling,
vein-enations. (43) Cassia tora, Datura stramonium, Glycine max, Lycopersicon
esculentum, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum,
Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop, Zinnia elegans systemic
vein-clearing followed by leaf curling and crinkling. (44) Arachis hypogaea,
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus
lunatus, Vigna unguiculata, V. unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis. (45) Glycine
max. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (W), Lycopersicon esculentum (W), Petunia ×
hybrida (W), Datura stramonium (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (W). (47) Cassia tora,
or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Abelmoschus esculentus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
or Cajanus cajan, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Lablab purpureus, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Sesamum indicum, or Solanum melongena, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Compositae <1/1>,
or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/11>,
or Solanaceae <7/9>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<10/11>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/9>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>. (53) Iwaki et al. (1983). (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (61) Virions <possibly> geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (171)
Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the nucleus and
amorphous Xbodies. (177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible> bigeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (187) Iwaki, M., Thongmeearkom, P.,
Honda, Y. and Deema, N (1983). Plant Dis. 67: 546. Iwaki, M., Thongmeearkom,
P., Honda, Y., Sarindu, N., Deema, N. and Surin, P. (1986). Tech. Bull. Trop.
Agric. Res. Center, Japan, p. 132.


Soybean dwarf luteovirus

      (1) T. Tamada, 1980. Revised by G.R. Johnstone, R.R. Martin and P.
Waterhouse, 1989. (2) Synonyms: subterranean clover red leaf luteovirus. (3)
Standard acronym: SbDV. (4) Strains: soybean dwarf virus dwarfing strain
(SDVD), soybean dwarf leaf yellowing strain (SDVY). (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.0.015. (8) First reported in Glycine max. (9) From Hokkaido, Japan.
(10) By Tamada et al. (1969); Tamada (1970). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Glycine max, Trifolium pratense puckering, rugosity and yellowing, stunting.
Pisum sativum mild yellowing of older leaves. Phaseolus vulgaris yellowing of
leaves and stunting. Gomphrena globosa, Erodium moschatum, Trifolium
subterraneum, Vicia sativa, Calandrinia caulescens leaf reddening. Beta
vulgaris, Lupinus albus, Lupinus angustifolius, Medicago polymorpha leaf
yellowing. Trifolium repens, T. pratense no symptoms. Vicia faba, Vicia
articulata leaf yellowing, rolling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum)
solani (some isolates also by Acyrthosiphon pisum). (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when
the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus does not
require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Ashby et al.
(1979); Johnstone (1978); Tamada (1975). (39) Spreads in Australia, Japan, New
Zealand, and the USA <in California>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Astragalus sinicus systemic leaf yellowing or reddening. Glycine max
systemic puckering, rugosity and yellowing of leaves, stunting. Trifolium
incarnatum, T. subterraneum systemic leaf reddening. Vicia faba systemic
chlorosis and yellowing. (45) Glycine max, Pisum sativum. (46) Glycine max
(W), Pisum sativum (W), Trifolium subterraneum (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or
Astragalus sinicus, or Beta vulgaris, or Calandrinia caulescens, or Erodium
moschatum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens
culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Lupinus cosentinii,
or Medicago hispida, or Medicago polymorpha, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium dubium, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens,
or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia articulata, or Vicia faba, or Vicia
sativa. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or
Cicer arietinum, or Datura stramonium, or Lablab purpureus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Linum usitatissimum, or Lotus corniculatus, or Medicago sativa,
or Melilotus albus, or Stellaria media, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna angularis,
or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <20/31>,
or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>,
or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/31>, or Linaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Tamada (1973, 1975); Johnstone et al. (1984). (54)
TIP: 45-50 °C <when tested by insect injection or membrane feeding>. (55) LIV:
<more than> 14 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (57) Infectivity of sap
decreased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(59) Electron microscopy: not necessary to fix the virions. (60) Method:
Tamada et al. (1969); Kojima and Tamada (1976); Tamada (1973); Ashby and
Kyriakou (1982); Johnstone et al. (1982); Waterhouse and Helms (1985). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25-27 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 114 S. (84) Virions contain 30 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 70 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size
5.861 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 5.861 kb.
(99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Waterhouse et al. (1987). (110) Poly A
region absent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12049. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): L20835 Em(40)_vi:SDVCOATX Gb(84)_vi:SDVCOATX Soybean dwarf virus coat
protein gene and 21 kDa ORF, complete cds. 3/94 612bp. L24049
Em(40)_vi:SDVRNAP Gb(84)_vi:SDVRNAP Soybean dwarf virus RNA-dependent RNA
polymerase, coat protein, genome-linked protein genes, X15502
Em(40)_vi:LUSDPRM Gb(84)_vi:LUSDPRM Soybean dwarf virus genomic RNA for
potential promoter. 3/92 122bp. 3 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) two.
(133) Mr <of the major> 24000. (134) Coat protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
55000. (136) Possibly a read through protein from the coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Ashby and Kyriakou (1982). (171) Virions found in
phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: phloem
necrosis, starch accumulates in chloroplasts of epidermis and mesophyll cells.
(179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: beet
western yellows, barley yellow dwarf (strains RPV and MAV), bean leaf roll,
potato leafroll and tobacco necrotic dwarf viruses. Subterranean clover red
leaf virus is so closely related that it is often considered to be the same
species. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ELISA tests using monoclonal
antibodies. (186) A severe stunting disease of soybean (Glycine max), African
soybean dwarf, was first noted in 1975 in Nigeria (Rossel and Thottappilly,
1983). The causal virus was transmitted in the persistent manner by Bemisia
tabaci. It resembles that caused by soybean dwarf luteovirus, which is
aphid-borne. Some soybean genotypes (e.g. cvs Improved Pelican, Indo 100 and
Bossier) are very resistant to the Nigerian virus (Rossel and Thottappilly,
1985). (187) Ashby, J.W. and Kyriakou, A. (1982). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 25: 607.
Ashby, J.W., Teh, P.B. and Close, R.C. (1979). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 22: 361.
D'Arcy, C.J., Torrance, L. and Martin, R.R. (1989). Phytopathology 79: 869.
Johnstone, G.R. (1978). Aust. J. agric. Res. 29: 1003. Johnstone, G.R.,
Duffus, J.E., Munro, D. and Ashby, J.W. (1982). Aust. J. agric. Res. 33: 697.
Johnstone, G.R., Ashby, J.W., Gibbs, A.J., Duffus, J.E., Thottappilly, G. and
Fletcher, J.D. (1984). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 90: 225. Kojima, M. and Tamada, T.
(1976). Phytopath. Z. 85(3): 347. Rathjen, J.P., Karageorgos, L.E., Habili,
N., Waterhouse, P.M. and Symons, R.H. (1994). Virology 198: 671. Rossel, H.W.
and Thottappilly, G. (1983). I.I.T.A. Res. Briefs 3: 3. Rossel, H.W. and
Thottappilly, G. (1985). Virus Diseases of Important Food Crops in Tropical
Africa. Ibadan: I.I.T.A. Tamada, T. (1970). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 36:
266. Tamada, T. (1973). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 39: 27. Tamada, T. (1975).
Rep. Hokkaido Pref. Agric. Exp. Stn 24. Tamada, T. (1975). Rep. Hok. Pref.
Agric. Exp. Stn 25: pp.144. Tamada, T. and Kojima, M. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 179, 4 pp. Tamada, T., Goto, T., Chiba, I. and Suwa, T.
(1969). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 35: 282.


Soybean Indonesian dwarf luteovirus

      (1) M. Iwaki, 1983. (2) Synonyms: Indonesian soybean dwarf virus. (3)
Standard acronym: ISDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported
in Glycine max. (9) From Bogor, Indonesia. (10) By Iwaki et al. (1980). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Glycine max stunting, mottling and leaf malformation.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Aphis glycines. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does
not multiply in the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Indonesia and Thailand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Glycine max
stunting, mottling, leaf shape malformation. (45) Glycine max. (46) Glycine
max (W). (47) Glycine max. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Astragalus sinicus, or
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum
indicum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/14>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae
<1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/14>, or
Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (53) Iwaki et al. (1980). (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Takanami and Kubo (1979). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (171)
Virions found in phloem. (179) Luteovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: soybean dwarf and beet western yellows luteoviruses (Ashby
and Johnstone, 1985). (187) Ashby, J.W. and Johnstone, G.R. (1985). Australas.
Pl. Path. 14: 2. Iwaki, M., Roechan, M., Hibino, H., Tochihara, H. and
Tantera, D.M. (1980). Plant Dis. 64: 1027. Takanami, Y. and Kubo, S. (1979).
J. gen. Virol. 44: 153.


Soybean mild mosaic virus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1981. Revised 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.34.
(8) First reported in Glycine max. (9) From Japan. (10) By Takahashi et al.
(1974). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Glycine max chlorotic spots, mild
mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <22-70% in Glycine max cultivars>. (39) Spreads
in Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. Spinacia oleracea
necrotic and chlorotic local lesions; systemic chlorotic spotting and
vein-clearing. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions or latent. Glycine max,
Pisum sativum systemic mosaic. Vigna radiata, V. unguiculata necrotic local
lesions; systemic vein-clearing and necrotic spotting. Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
tabacum systemic mosaic. (44) Astragalus sinicus, Datura stramonium,
Tetragonia tetragonioides. (45) Spinacia oleracea, Glycine max, Lupinus albus,
Macroptilium lathyroides, Vigna unguiculata. (46) Phaseolus lunatus cv.
Henderson Bush (L), P. vulgaris cv. Top Crop (L), Vigna radiata (L). (47)
Antirrhinum majus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Glycine
max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lupinus albus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Macrotyloma
uniflorum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Sesamum indicum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vicia villosa, or Vigna radiata,
or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48) Apium
graveolens, or Astragalus sinicus, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Cucurbita maxima, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Ipomoea nil, or Lablab purpureus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna
angularis, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <15/18>, or
Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/8>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/18>, or Solanaceae <3/8>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1 /1>. (53) Takahashi et al. (1974, 1980); Hampton et
al. (1978). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 3-4 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5.
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26-27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (171) Virions found
in leaves. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) (Ungrouped).
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: soybean stunt, alfalfa
mosaic, cucumber mosaic, mulberry ringspot, broad bean mottle and tomato black
ring viruses. (187) Hampton, R., Beczner, L., Hagedorn, D., Bos, L., Inouye,
T., Barnett, O.W., Musil, M. and Meiners, J. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 989.
Kolte, S.J. and Nene, Y.L. (1972). Indian Phytopath. 25: 401. Takahashi, K.,
Tanaka, T. and Tsuda, Y. (1974). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 40: 103.
Takahashi, K., Tanaka, T., Iida, W. and Tsuda, Y. (1980). Tohoku Agric. Exp.
Stn Bull. 62: 1.


Soybean mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R. Goodman, 1980. Revised 1987 by J.R. Edwardson and L. Bos. (3)
Standard acronym: SMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.061. (8) First reported
in Glycine max. (9) From Connecticut, U.S.A. (10) By Clinton (1915); Gardener
and Kendrick (1921). (11) Symptoms persist, or disappear soon after infection
<especially at high temperatures>. (13) Glycine max Rugosity, dark green vein
banding and light green interveinal areas, stunting, leaf curling and seed
coat mottling, male sterility, flower deformation, less pubescent, necrosis,
sometimes necrotic local lesions, systemic necrosis and bud blight. (14)
Transmitted by <normally> a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by 16 species, including Acyrthosiphon pisum, Aphis fabae, Myzus
persicae (Edwardson and Christie, 1986). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus does not require a helper
virus for vector transmission <One strain is not aphid transmitted (Ross,
1975; Cho and Goodman, 1981)>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus <up to 30% or higher> transmitted by seed <not in
Glycine max cvs Kawanggyo, Hill or Bienville (Cho et al., 1977; Ross, 1968;
Porto and Hagedorn, 1975)>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed, or
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (36) Studies reported by Ross
(1968, 1977); Quiniones et al. (1971); Sun et al. (1977); Cho and Goodman
(1979); Kiihl and Hartwig (1979); Dhingra and Chenulu (1980); Kwon and Oh
(1980); Irwin and Schultz (1981); Polsten and Goodman (1981). (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
album, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions. Lablab purpureus necrotic local
lesion. Macroptilium lathyroides systemic mosaic. Phaseolus vulgaris systemic
mosaic with some strains in some cultivars, but often latent or no infection.
P. vulgaris cv. Top Crop necrotic local lesions at 30°C in detached leaves.
(44) Cucumis sativus, Vicia faba, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Glycine max. (46)
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L), Lablab purpureus (L), Macrotyloma uniflorum (W),

occidentalis, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crotalaria

Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are <cylindrical>
pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) , Bundles, scrolls and laminated
aggregates and are pinwheels, bundles, scrolls and short curved laminated
aggregates. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes:
the production of fewer starch grains, but more vesicles in chloroplasts.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic, bean common mosaic, clover
yellow vein and watermelon mosaic II viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic strains 240-1 and OH-S,
blackeye cowpea mosaic, gloriosa stripe and peanut mottle viruses. (184)
Peptide analysis and immunoblot tests show that this virus is very closely
related to blackeye cowpea mosaic potyvirus (D. Shukla, personal
communication). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Soybean mosaic virus (SMV)
does not infect Phaseolus vulgaris systemically, except cv. Double White
Princess. Bean common mosaic (BCMV) and bean yellow mosaic (BYMV) viruses
infect Phaseolus vulgaris systemically. BCMV does not infect Glycine max
systemically and BYMV infects Vicia faba systemically. (187) Bos, L. (1972).

Spinach latent ilarvirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1987. (2) Synonyms: GE 36 virus (Van der Meer, 1968; Maat
and Vink, 1971). (3) Standard acronym: SpLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.2.06.01. (8) First reported in Spinacia oleracea. (9) From plants grown
from seed of spinach (Spinacia oleracea) from several countries. (10) By Bos
et al. (1980). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Spinacia
oleracea symptomless or transient faint mosaic and vein clearing. (14)
Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus transmitted
by pollen to the seed and transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant
<S"tefanac and Wrischer, 1983>. (36) Studies reported by Bos et al. (1980).
(39) Spreads in the Netherlands, the USA, and the former Yugoslavia. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (43) Beta vulgaris small chlorotic or etched rings.
Celosia cristata symptomless. Chenopodium amaranticolor pin-point desiccated
chlorotic local lesions. Chenopodium quinoa diffuse chlorotic local lesions
then systemic leaf rolling, chlorotic vein banding, mottling, stunting and tip
blight. Cucumis sativus cv. Gele Tros transient chlorotic local lesions.
Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bataaf necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana clevelandii,
N. rustica, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum, Tetragonia tetragonioides, Gomphrena
globosa symptomless systemic infection. (44) Apium graveolens, Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, Datura stramonium, Lactuca sativa, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Pisum sativum. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana spp. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L) and (W), Phaseolus vulgaris (L). (47)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Beta macrocarpa, or Beta
vulgaris, or Celosia argentea, or Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Apium graveolens, or
Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago
sativa, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petroselinum crispum, or Physalis floridana,
or Pisum sativum, or Sinapis alba, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <4/4>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/9>, or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/9>, or Solanaceae <4/11>, or
Umbelliferae <2/2>. (52) Infection in most species is symptomless. (53) Bos et
al. (1980). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 6-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4.
(59) Electron microscopy: virions are labile and difficult to locate without
fixation. (60) Method: Bos et al. (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 27 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 103 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 87 and 98 S <T
and (M), respectively>. (81) Density 1.269 in Cs2SO4. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.295 kb. (92)
Genome of five parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.662
kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.324 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.563 kb. (96) The 4th
largest 0.986 kb. (97) The 5th largest 0.76 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by Bos et al. (1980). (112) Additional factor required for
infectivity. (113) Additional factor one or two of the two smallest RNA
segments or coat protein required for infectivity of the three largest
segments. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 42680. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
20000. (145) Method of preparation: Bos et al. (1980). (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll.
(174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes:
groups of vesicles surrounded by a unit membrane in cytoplasm and small
vacuoles of leaf parenchyma cells (Stefanac and Wrischer, 1983). (179)
Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 6>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: apple mosaic, elm mottle, lilac ring
mottle, prunus necrotic ringspot and tobacco streak viruses (but ilarviruses
are poorly immunogenic). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Cucumber mosaic virus
induces characteristic local lesions in Chenopodium quinoa and infects
cucumber and Nicotiana spp. systemically. Cucumber mosaic virus and tobacco
rattle virus rarely infect Chenopodium quinoa systemically. Spinach latent
virus induces characteristic local and systemic reactions in Chenopodium
quinoa. (187) Bos, L. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 281, 4 pp. Bos,
L., Huttinga, H. and Maat, D.Z. (1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 79. Maat, D.Z.
and Vink, J. (1971). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 77: 93. S"tefanac, Z. (1978). Acta
bot. Croat. 37: 39. S"tefanac, Z. and Wrischer, M. (1983). Acta bot. Croat.
42: 1. Van der Meer, F.A. (1968). TagBer. dt. Akad. Landw. Berlin 97: 27.


Spinach temperate alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SpTV. (5) ICTV decimal code
49.0.3.0.014. (8) First reported in Spinacia oleracea. (9) From Japan. (10) By
Natsuaki et al. (1983). (13) Spinacia oleracea symptomless infection. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Japan. (47) Spinacia
oleracea. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.

Spring beauty latent bromovirus

      (1) R.A. Valverde, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SBLV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 10.0.3.0.007. (8) First reported in Claytonia virginica. (9) From
Arkansas, U.S.A. (10) By Valverde (1985). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Claytonia
virginica symptomless. (15) Possibly on lawn mowers and tractors in lawns and
public areas. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus <possibly> transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the USA. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show necrotic local lesions, systemic mottle and necrosis. (43) Chenopodium
quinoa, C. album, C. amaranticolor, Cucurbita pepo cv. Small Sugar, Datura
stramonium, Glycine max cvs Lee and Bragg, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Pinto,
Bountiful, Black Valentine, Vigna radiata, V. unguiculata ssp. unguiculata cv.
Monarch necrotic local lesions. Cucumis sativus cv. Model chlorotic local
lesions. Commelina diffusa systemic mottle. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local
lesions, systemic mottle and necrosis. Nicotiana megalosiphon, N. clevelandii
necrotic local lesions, systemic necrosis. Nicotiana debneyi necrotic local
lesions, systemic mottle. Pisum sativum cv. little Marvel systemic mottle and
necrosis. Vicia faba systemic necrosis. Catharanthus roseus systemic necrosis
and mottle. (44) Avena sativa, Capsicum annuum, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Havana 38, Zea mays. (45) Commelina diffusa, Gomphrena
globosa, Nicotiana clevelandii, Pisum sativum, Catharanthus roseus. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Datura stramonium (L), Gomphrena globosa (L and W),
Pisum sativum (W), Vicia faba (W). (47) Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium

Squash leaf curl bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux and S. Cohen, 1986. (2) Synonyms: probably
muskmelon necrotic mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: SLCV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.0.035. (8) First reported in Cucurbita maxima, Cucurbita moschata,
Cucurbita pepo, Phaseolus vulgaris. (9) From the south western U.S.A. (10) By
Cohen et al. (1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucurbita pepo severe
stunting and leaf curl. Cucurbita moschata, C. pepo, Phaseolus vulgaris. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36)
Studies reported by Cohen et al. (1983). (39) Spreads in the USA <California>.
(43) Cucurbita pepo, Cucurbita maxima, Cucurbita moschata severe stunting and
leaf curling. Phaseolus vulgaris green mosaic leaf symptoms and deformation.

Umbelliferae <1/1>. (60) Method: Cohen et al. (1983). (61) Virions geminate.

Squash mosaic comovirus

      (1) R.N. Campbell, 1985. (2) Synonyms: cucurbit ring mosaic virus,
muskmelon mosaic virus, pumpkin mosaic virus (Stoner, 1963). (3) Standard
acronym: SqMV. (4) Strains: Arizona watermelon stunt virus; 2 serological
groups, named I and II, have been recognized. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.015. (8) First reported in Cucurbita pepo. (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Freitag (1956). (13) Cucumis melo, C. sativus, Cucurbita pepo,
C. moschata, C. maxima systemic mosaic, ringspots and leaf deformation.
Ecballium elaterium mild yellow mosaic (reported from Israel). Citrullus
lanatus infected by some isolates. Chenopodium album one report from Morocco.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Acalymma trivittata; A. thiemei thiemei; Diabrotica undecimpunctata
undecimpunctata; D. bivittula; Epilachna chrysomelina; E. paenulata. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus transmitted by seed
<c. 10% in Cucumis melo and up to 35% in Cucurbita pepo>. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen <Alvarez and Campbell, 1978; Nolan and Campbell, 1984>.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide <presumably via imported seeds>. (39)
Spreads in China. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in New Zealand.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis melo, Cucurbita pepo systemic
mosaic, often with ringspots, leaf deformation. Cucumis metuliferus chlorotic
local lesions. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
glutinosa, N. tabacum cvs Turkish, Havana, Citrullus lanatus (resistant to all
but the watermelon strain of SqMV). (45) Cucurbita pepo, Cucumis melo. (46)
Cucurbita pepo (W), Cucumis metuliferus some collections e.g. P.I. 202681 or
P.I. 292190 (L). (47) Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium quinoa <in Morocco
(Lockhart, 1982)>, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
metuliferus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata,
or Cucurbita pepo, or Ecballium elaterium, or Pisum sativum <in Morocco
(Lockhart, 1982)>. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or
Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris
<Lockhart (1982) found Beta vulgaris susceptible in Morocco>, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea
var. capitata, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum frutescens, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Citrullus lanatus <when infected with Arizona
strain>, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Delphinium hybridum, or
Dianthus caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus
annuus, or Ipomoea nil, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Matthiola incana, or Medicago hispida, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phlox drummondii, or Pisum sativum, or
Raphanus sativus, or Ricinus communis, or Rumex acetosa, or Solanum tuberosum,
or Spinacia oleracea, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or
Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or
Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <8/8>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/14>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/5>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>,
or Cruciferae <6/6>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/8>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <1 /1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <14/14>, or Malvaceae <2/2>,
or Polemoniaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Ranunculaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <8/8>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae < 4 /4>. (53) Freitag (1956); Lockhart (1982). (54) TIP: 70-80
°C. (55) LIV: 30 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-6. (60) Method: Alvarez and
Campbell (1978). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components
in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 118
S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 95 S <M>, or 57 S <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH
4.56 <Rice et al., 1955>. (84) Virions contain 35 % nucleic acid <B>, or 27 %
nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 65 % protein <B>, or
73 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.2 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.8 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 4.5 kb <Mazzone et al., 1962>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated
by Hiebert and Purcifull (1981). (100) Base composition 22.5 % G. (101) Base
composition 31.6 % A. (102) Base composition 16.2 % C. (103) Base composition

Taxon ID: 12263. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M96148

protein and 22 kDa capsid protein. 7/93 2,536bp. 1 sequence. (120) Nongenomic

depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(179) Comovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with

Statice Y potyvirus

      (1) D.-E. Lesemann, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SVY. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.017. (8) First reported in Limonium sinuatum. (9) From southern
Germany. (10) By Lesemann et al. (1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
light green mosaic, stunting, narrow leaves, deformation of leaves. (13)
Limonium sinuatum. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40)
Found, but with no evidence of spread, in southern Germany. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show local
lesions, mosaic. (43) Chenopodium quinoa systemic, chlorotic, later necrotic
spots. C. amaranticolor, C. murale, C. foliosum local lesions. Gomphrena
globosa, Amaranthus retroflexus symptomless. Lathyrus odoratus light mosaic.
Nicotiana clevelandii faint mottle. Phaseolus vulgaris yellow mosaic. Vicia
faba mosaic. (44) Beta vulgaris, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum cv. Samsun,
Pisum sativum cv. Kelvex, Zinnia elegans. (45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (W), C. amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (W). (47)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
ambrosioides, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Limonium sinuatum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta
vulgaris, or Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Sinapis alba, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/8>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/4>, or Plumbaginaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/4>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/8>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/4>, or Solanaceae <3/4>,
or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 54-56 °C. (55) LIV: 15 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
glutaraldehyde fixation reduces virion breakage. (60) Method: Lesemann et al.
(1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 748
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
12198. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Lesemann et al. (1979): SDS polyacrylamide
electrophoresis. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and the epidermis.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, crystals in the nucleus, and
pinwheels. (176) And are hypertrophied mitochondria. (177) They do not contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: pinwheels of laminated aggregate type,
small electron dense crystals in nucleolus and cytoplasm and hypertrophied
mitochondria (Lesemann et al., 1979). (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean yellow
mosaic, bean common mosaic, clover yellow vein, gloriosa stripe, pea seed
borne mosaic and potato Y viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: lettuce mosaic virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis:
Systemically infects Chenopodium quinoa and fails to infect Pisum sativum
unlike bean yellow mosaic virus. Little or no reaction with antisera to clover
yellow virus (CYVV) and fails to produce local lesions on cucumber like CYVV.
(187) Lesemann, D.-E., Koenig, R. and Hein, H. (1979). Phytopath. Z. 95: 128.


Strawberry crinkle cytorhabdovirus

      (1) R.H. Converse, 1985 and J.A. Cooper, 1985. (3) Standard acronym:
SCrV (SCV). (4) Strains: strawberry latent A (mild form); strawberry latent A
and latent B; strawberry vein chlorosis. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.0.4.0.008.
(8) First reported in Fragaria vesca cv. Marshall. (9) From Oregon, U.S.A.
(10) By Zeller and Vaughan (1932). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Fragaria vesca
chlorotic and necrotic spotting of veins, epinasty, deformation, local lesions
in petioles and stolons, streaking and deformation of petals. Fragaria
virginiana leaflets malformed, vigour reduced. Fragaria chiloensis, F. ×
ananassa (cultivated strawberry) usually symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Chaetosiphon
jacobi, Chaetosiphon fragaraefolii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation <by injection of haemolymph from aphid to aphid>. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (38) Spreads in the African region, the Eurasian region, the North
American region, and the South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in
Australia, or Belgium, or Bulgaria, or Canada, or Chile, or China, or the
former Czechoslovakia, or France, or Germany, or Israel, or Italy, or Japan,
or the Netherlands, or New Zealand, or Poland, or South Africa, or the UK, or
the USA, or the former Yugoslavia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Fragaria vesca chlorotic and necrotic spotting of veins, epinasty,
deformation, local lesions in petioles and stolons, streaking and deformation
of petals. Fragaria virginiana leaflets malformed, vigour reduced. (45)
Fragaria chiloensis, F. × ananassa, F. vesca, F. virginiana. (46) Fragaria
vesca var. semperflorens (W). (47) Fragaria chiloensis, or Fragaria vesca, or
Fragaria vesca var. semperflorens, or Fragaria virginiana, or Fragaria ×
ananassa, or Sanguisorba minor. (50) Rosaceae <6/6>. (55) LIV: 0.1-0.2 days
<the virus remains infectious for at least 1 hour in refrigerated extracts
made of infective aphids. Infectious virus can be recovered from aphids frozen
at -54°C for two years>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped <ranging between 190-380 nm>. (63) Virions enveloped
<less than 80 nm and uncoated>. (69) Virions with no clear modal length. (71)
Virions 42 nm wide <±3 nm>. (171) Virions found in epidermis and in parenchyma
cells near vascular bundles and sieve tubes. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(173) Virions found in sometimes enclosed in membrane bound cisternae. (179)
Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Frazier, N.W. and
Mellor, F.C. (1970). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits and Grapevines, pp.
18-23; ed. Frazier, N.W.. Univ. Calif., Div. Agric. Sci., Berkeley. Frazier,
N.W., Sylvester, E.S. and Richardson, J. (1987). In: Virus Diseases of Small
Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse. U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 631, p. 20. Richardson,
J., Frazier, N.W. and Sylvester, E.S. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 491.
Sylvester, E.S., Frazier, N.W. and Richardson, J. (1976). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 163, 4 pp. Zeller, S.M. and Vaughan, E.K. (1932). Phytopathology
22: 709.


Strawberry latent C (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1993. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.DE.09. (8) First
reported in Fragaria spp. (9) From Japan and North America. (10) By Yoshikawa
et al. (1986). (13) Fragaria spp. most cultivars symptomless. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Chaetosiphon
fragaefolii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region and the North American
region. (39) Spreads in Canada, Japan, and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Fragaria vesca symptomless in fection of clones UC4. Severe
leaf epinasty of young leaves of clone UC5, mottling and distortion of leaves
produced subsequently, plants stunted. (45) Fragaria vesca clone UC5. (46)
Fragaria vesca clone UC5 (W). (47) Fragaria vesca. (50) Rosaceae <1/1>. (61)
Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (70) Virions of
190-380 nm. (71) Virions 68 nm wide <from sap>. (179) Unassigned rhabdovirus.
(180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Yoshikawa, N., Inouye, T. and Converse, R.H.
(1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 437.


Strawberry latent ringspot (?) nepovirus

      (1) J. Cooper, 1986. (2) Synonyms: aesculus line pattern virus
(Schmelzer and Schmidt, 1968), rhubarb virus 5. (3) Standard acronym: SLRSV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.T.007. (8) First reported in Fragaria vesca and
Rubus idaeus. (9) From Dundee, Scotland. (10) By Lister (1964). (13) Fragaria
vesca (strawberry) mottle and death. Apium graveolens strap leaf. Robinia
pseudoacacia mosaic. Rosa spp. chlorotic ringspots and stunting. Euonymus
europaeus yellow mottle. Aesculus carnea line pattern. Rubus idaeus stunting.
Other natural hosts include: Rubus fruticosus. Ribes nigrum. Ribes rubrum.
Asparagus officinalis. Vitis vinifera. Capsella bursa-pastoris, Delphinium
spp., Lamium amplexicaule, Narcissus spp., Prunus domestica, P. persica, Rheum
rhaponticum, Sambucus nigra, Senecio vulgaris, Stellaria media, Taraxacum
officinale, Trifolium repens and Urtica dioica. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Xiphinema diversicaudatum.
(20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <often more than 70% in Capsella bursa-pastoris, Mentha arvensis, Lamium
amplexicaule, Rubus idaeus, Senecio vulgaris, Stellaria media, Chenopodium
quinoa, Pastinaca sativa, Petroselinum crispum and Apium graveolens>. (39)
Spreads in Australia, or Belgium, or Canada, or Finland, or France, or
Germany, or Ireland, or Israel, or Italy, or Luxembourg, or the Netherlands,
or New Zealand, or Poland, or Portugal, or Romania, or Spain, or Switzerland,
or Turkey, or the UK, or the USA, or the former Yugoslavia. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in Canada and New Zealand. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C. quinoa chlorotic or
necrotic local lesions, systemic chlorosis and deformation, necrosis or faint
chlorotic mottle. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions or none; systemic
interveinal chlorosis or necrosis; recovery in summer, in winter symptoms may
persist. Some isolates induce enations. (44) Nicotiana rustica, Nicotiana
tabacum, Petunia × hybrida. (45) Cucumis sativus. (46) Chenopodium murale (L),
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Aesculus carnea, or Allium porrum, or
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Arachis
