Strawberry mild yellow edge-associated (?) potexvirus

      (1) W. Jelkmann, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SMYEaV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 56.0.1.T.019. (8) First reported in Fragaria vesca. (9) From California,
U.S.A. (10) By Horne (1922). (13) Fragaria vesca chlorotic flecks in young
leaves, gradual loss of vigour, chlorotic mottling, interveinal necrosis of
older leaves. Rubus rosifolius, Chenopodium quinoa symptomless. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Chaetosiphon fragaraefolii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in
a nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus <possibly> requires, for vector
transmission, a helper virus <strawberry mild yellow edge luteovirus>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (36) Studies reported by Converse et al. (1987). (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (39) Spreads in Australia, or Belgium, or Bulgaria, or
Canada, or Chile, or China, or the former Czechoslovakia, or France, or
Germany, or Ireland, or Israel, or Italy, or Japan, or Luxembourg, or New
Zealand, or Paraguay, or South Africa, or Switzerland, or the UK, or the USA.
(46) Fragaria vesca UC4 (W), UC5 (W), EMC (W), F. vesca var. semperfloreus
`Alpine' (W). (47) Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Fragaria
vesca, or Rubus rosifolius. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Rosaceae <2/2>. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 482 nm. (71)
Virions 13 nm wide. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.966 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 5.966 kb. (110) Poly A region present. (116) Nucleotide
sequence references: Jelkmann et al. (1991). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12187. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): D12515 Em(40)_vi:SYVCPH Gb(84)_vi:SYVCPH
Strawberry mild yellow edge-associated virus (SMYEAV), 3'terminus of the viral
genome encodin D12517 Em(40)_vi:SYVCPE Gb(84)_vi:SYVCPE Strawberry mild yellow
edge-associated virus (SMYEAV) genomic RNA encoding coat protein and 5 2
sequences. (125) 4 virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells.
(126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 6 kbp. (127) 2nd largest 4.2 kbp.
(128) 3rd largest 1.7 kbp. (129) 4th largest 0.5 kbp. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 25714. (145) Method of preparation: Jelkmann et al. (1990).
(146) Amino acid sequence: Jelkmann et al. (1991). (147) Amino acid
composition: Jelkmann et al. (1991). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins
identified by genomic sequence analysis. (153) Five proteins found <ORFs in
genome in addition to coat protein>. (154) Mr <of the largest> 149423. (155)
Probably replicase. (156) Mr of 2nd largest 25344. (158) Mr of 3rd 11576.
(160) Mr of 4th 11216. (162) Mr of 5th and smaller 8079. (171) Virions found
in the companion cells. (179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: chicory X, cassava Colombian common mosaic,
papaya mosaic, Sieg river potexviruses and, but distantly, wineberry latent
virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: plantago
Argentinian, cactus X, cassava common mosaic (WF), clover yellow mosaic,
cymbidium mosaic, daphne X, hydrangea ringspot, lily X, lychnis potex,
narcissus mosaic, pepino mosaic, plantago X, potato aucuba mosaic, potato X,
Tamus potex, tulip X, viola mottle and white clover mosaic viruses. (184) The
sequence of the coat protein of SMYEAV, like that of other potexviruses, has
significant homologies with the protein sequences of carlaviruses. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: ISEM useful, antisera prepared from coat protein
expressed as a fusion protein in E. coli. (187) Converse, R.H., Martin, R.R.
and Spiegel, S. (1987). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse.
U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 631, p. 25. Horne, W.T. (1922). Rep. Cal. Exp. Stn.
19211922, p. 122. Jelkmann, W., Maiss, E. and Martin, R.R. (1990). Abstr. 8th
Int. Congr. Virol., p. 1445. Jelkmann, W., Maiss, E. and Martin, R.R. (1991).
J. gen. Virol. submitted. Jelkmann, W., Martin, R.R. and Maiss, E. (1989).
Phytopathology 79: 1250. Jelkmann, W., Martin, R.R., Lesemann, D.-E., Vetten,
H.J. and Skelton, F. (1990). J. gen. Virol. 71: 1251. Martin, R.R., Jelkmann,
W., Spiegel, S. and Converse, R.H. (1989). Acta Hort. 236: 111.


Strawberry mild yellow edge luteovirus

      (1) R.H. Converse, 1985 and J.A. Cooper, 1985. (2) Synonyms: soybean
dwarf luteovirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.0.015. (8) First reported in
Fragaria vesca. (9) From California, U.S.A. and England. (10) By Horne (1922);
Harris (1933). (13) Fragaria chiloensis, F. × ananassa usually symptomless. F.
vesca leaflets cupped, chlorotic margins, vigour reduced. An isolate from the
Pacific Coast of North America causes chlorotic vein netting and necrosis of
youngest leaves. F. virginiana leaflets cupped, vigour reduced. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Chaetosiphon fragaraefolii, C. thomasi, C. thomasi jacobi. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (29) Virus can help the
vector transmission of another virus <strawberry mild yellow edge-associated
potexvirus>. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants
<of Fragaria vesca clone UC6>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus
not transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (38) Spreads
in the Eastern Asian region, the Eurasian region, the Mediterranean region,
the North American region, and the Pacific region. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Fragaria vesca leaflets cupped, chlorotic margins, vigour
reduced; chlorotic vein netting and necrosis of young leaves with Pacific
coast strain. F. virginiana leaflets cupped, vigour reduced. F. ovalis
symptomless carrier. (44) Fragaria vesca strain UC6 is insusceptible or only
very mildly infected when graft inoculated. (45) Fragaria chiloensis, F. ×
ananassa, F. vesca, F. virginiana. (46) Fragaria vesca (W). (47) Citrus
aurantium, or Duchesnea indica, or Fragaria chiloensis, or Fragaria ovalis, or
Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria virginiana, or Fragaria × ananassa, or Sanguisorba
minor. (48) Fragaria vesca <strain UC-6 is insusceptible or only very mildly
infected when graft inoculated>. (50) Rosaceae <7/7>, or Rutaceae <1/1>. (51)
Rosaceae <1/7>. (54) TIP: <cannot be directly measured but is> 45-50 °C <for
aphid acquisition from living leaves>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: Martin and Converse (1982; 1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 23-28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular
in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12049.
(171) Virions found in roots (Yosuikewa, 1985). (179) Luteovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: soybean dwarf virus, closely;
beet western yellows virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: potato leafroll, bean leaf roll and tobacco necrotic dwarf viruses.
The relationship to soybean dwarf virus is so close that they are probably the
same species. (187) Converse, R.H., Martin, R.R. and Spiegel, S. (1987). In:
Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse. U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No.
631, p. 25. Harris, R.V. (1933). J. Pomol. 11: 56. Harris, R.V. and King, M.E.
(1940). Rep. East Malling Res. Stn. 1939, p. 66. Horne, W.T. (1922). Rep.
Calif. Agric. Exp. Stn. 1921-1922, p. 122. Martin, R.R. and Converse, R.H.
(1982). Acta Hort. 129: 75. Martin, R.R. and Converse, R.H. (1985). Phytopath.
Z. 114: 21. Mellor, F.C. and Frazier, N.W. (1970). In: Virus Diseases of Small
Fruits and Grapevines, p. 14; ed. N.W. Frazier. Univ. Calif. Div. Agric. Sci.,
Berkeley. Yankulova, M. and Schmelzer, K. (1974). Virusni bolesti po
rastenyala, pp.33-42. Yoshikawa, N., Ohki, S.T., Kobatake, H., Osaki, T. and
Inouye, T. (1984). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 50: 659. Yoshikawa, N. and
Inouye, T. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 643.


Strawberry mottle virus

      (1) N. Yoshikawa, 1991. (2) Synonyms: strawberry mild crinkle virus. (4)
Strains: many strains of differing severity have been described. (5) ICTV
decimal code 79.0.P.DE.37. (8) First reported in Fragaria × ananassa. (9) From
England. (10) By Harris (1938). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally, or none
<reduced vigour and yield>. (13) Fragaria × ananassa. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Chaetosiphon
fragaraefolii, C. thomasi, C. minor, C. jacobi, Aphis gossypii. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (26)
Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide <where strawberries
are grown>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show Fragaria vesca shows vein clearing, mottling and
dwarfing. (43) Fragaria × ananassa, Gomphrena globosa, Potentilla canadensis,
P. sterilis symptomless. Fragaria virginiana dwarfing of leaves. F. vesca
mottle, vein clearing and stunting. Potentilla adscherica vein chlorosis.
Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions and systemic mottling. C.
amaranticolor vein clearing and necrotic spots. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba
chlorotic local lesions, systemic vein clearing. (45) Fragaria × ananassa, F.
virginiana. (46) Fragaria vesca (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Fragaria chiloensis, or
Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria virginiana, or Fragaria × ananassa, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Potentilla adscherica, or Potentilla canadensis, or Potentilla
sterilis. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <7/7>. (53) Frazier (1968);
Converse (1987). (60) Method: Yoshikawa and Converse (1991). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 37 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (79)
Density 1.42 g cm3 in CsCl. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded
<possibly>. (91) Total genome size 6.6 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part 6.6 kb. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
26000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis
and the phloem. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (179) (Ungrouped). (187) Frazier, N.W. (1968). Pl. Dis. Reptr
52: 64. Frazier, N.W. (1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr 58: 28. Frazier, N.W. and
Sylvester, E.S. (1960). Virology 12: 233. Kitajima, E.W., Betti, J.A. and
Costa, A.S. (1971). Cienc. Cult. 23: 649. Mellor, F.C. and Krczal, H. (1987).
In: Viruses Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse. U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk
No. 631, p, 10. Yoshikawa, N. and Converse, R.H. (1991). Ann. appl. Biol.


Strawberry pallidosis (?) virus

      (1) N. Yoshikawa, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.38. (8) First
reported in Fragaria × ananassa. (9) From the U.S.A and Australia. (10) By
Frazier and Stubbs (1957). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Fragaria × ananassa. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies
reported by Mullin et al. (1975). (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, and the
USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants
mostly show leaf deformation and chlorosis and dwarfing of the plant. (43)
Fragaria × ananassa, F. vesca symptomless. Fragaria virginiana leaf
deformation, chlorosis and dwarfing. (45) Fragaria × ananassa, F. vesca. (46)
Fragaria virginiana. (47) Fragaria chiloensis, or Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria
virginiana, or Fragaria × ananassa. (50) Rosaceae <4/4>. (125) 3-14 virus
specified dsRNA species found in infected cells <depending on isolates>. (126)
Size of largest virus specified dsRNA 4.3-5.2 kbp. (179) (Ungrouped). (187)
Frazier, N.W. and Stubbs, L.L. (1969). Pl. Dis. Reptr 53: 524. Mullin, R.H.,
Frazier, N.W. and Schlegel, D.E. (1975). Pl. Dis. Reptr 59: 268. Yoshikawa, N.
and Converse, R.H. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 543.


Strawberry pseudo mild yellow edge carlavirus

      (1) N. Yoshikawa, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SPMYEV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 14.0.1.0.030. (8) First reported in Fragaria virginiana. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Frazier (1966). (11) Symptoms none. (13) Fragaria virginiana,
F. × ananassa symptomless. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Chaetosiphon thomasi jacobi, C. fragaraefolii,
Aphis gossypii. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (22) Principal natural
vector(s): Chaetosiphon fragaraefolii, Aphis gossypii. (25) Transmitted in a
semipersistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27)
Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally
to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Japan and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show yellow to reddish colouration on lower leaves,
followed by necrosis and leaf roll. (43) Fragaria × ananassa symptomless.
Fragaria vesca chlorotic mottle and reddening on older leaves, then necrosis
and leaf fall. Fragaria virginiana yellow to red colouration of old leaves.
(45) Fragaria × ananassa, F. virginiana, F. vesca. (46) Fragaria vesca (W).
(47) Fragaria chiloensis, or Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria virginiana, or
Fragaria × ananassa. (50) Rosaceae <4/4>. (53) Frazier (1966); Yoshikawa and
Inouye (1986). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Yoshikawa and
Inouye (1986). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 625 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (79) Density
1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.19. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear
<possibly>. (91) Total genome size 8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 8 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Yoshikawa
and Inouye (1986). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 33500. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions
found in leaves, mesophyll, epidermis, vascular parenchyma and companion
cells. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected
cells. (179) Carlavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
carnation latent virus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: dot immunobinding
assay. (187) Frazier, N.W. (1966). Phytopathology 56: 571. Yoshikawa, N. and
Inouye, T. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 643. Yoshikawa, N., Poolpol.
P. and Inouye, T. (1986). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 52: 728.


Strawberry vein banding (?) caulimovirus

      (1) T.J. Morris and J.A. Cooper, 1985. (2) Synonyms: yellow vein banding
virus, chiloensis vein banding virus, Eastern veinbanding virus. (3) Standard
acronym: SVBV. (4) Strains: possibly Erdbeer-Nekrose virus (Schöniger, 1958;
Domes, 1957). (5) ICTV decimal code 15.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported in
Fragaria vesca. (9) From Great Britain from plants of cv. `Fairfax' imported
from the U.S.A. and from Brazil. (10) By Prentice (1952); Kitajima et al.
(1973). (11) Symptoms persist <but symptoms fluctuate in severity>. (13)
Fragaria vesca, F. virginiana, F. chiloensis and F. × ananassa yellow vein
banding, discontinuous banding, streaking and spotting of older leaves,
twisting of leaflets. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Chaetosiphon jacobi, C. fragaraefolii, C. thomasi.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (38) Spreads in the African region. (39)
Spreads in Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, the former Czechoslovakia,
Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Japan, the USA, and the former USSR
<Schöniger, 1958>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Fragaria vesca, F.
virginiana, F. chiloensis and F. × ananassa yellow vein banding, discontinuous
banding, streaking and spotting of older leaves, twisting of leaflets. (45)
Most species and clones of Fragaria vesca, F. virginiana, F. chiloensis and F.
× ananassa. (46) Fragaria vesca (W), F. virginiana (W). (47) Fragaria
chiloensis, or Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria virginiana, or Fragaria × ananassa,
or Sanguisorba minor. (50) Rosaceae <5/5>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(59) Electron microscopy: purification, 1% formaldehyde treatment, stain with
UA. For ISEM use cauliflower mosaic virus antiserum to trap virions. (60)
Method: Morris et al. (1980). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 43 nm in diameter <± 4nm>. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 200 S <±10>. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Doublestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 7.8 kb <pairs>. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.8 kb <pairs>. (164)
Genome replicates <in cytoplasmic inclusions>. (171) Virions found in leaves,
mesophyll, epidermis and vascular parenchyma particularly in adjoining xylem
vessels. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm <where unique spike structures are
observed when stained with UA>. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are viroplasms. (177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible>
Caulimovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cauliflower
mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: carnation
etched ring virus. (184) The strawberry vein-banding virus genome has no
significant homology in hybridization tests with that of cauliflower mosaic
virus. (187) Domes, R. (1957). Phytopath. Z. 31: 113. Frazier, N.W. and
Converse, R.H. (1980). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 219, 4 pp. Frazier, N.W.
and Morris, T.J. (1985). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H.
Converse. U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk No. 631, p. 16. Kitajima, E.W., Betti, J.A.
and Costa, A.S. (1973). J. gen. Virol. 20: 117. Miller, P.W. and Frazier, N.W.
(1970). In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits and Grapevines pp. 8-10; ed.
Frazier. Univ. Calif. Div. Agric. Sci., Berkeley. Morris, T.J., Mullin, R.H.,
Schlegel, D.E., Cole, A. and Alosi, M.C. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 156.
Prentice, I.W. (1952). Ann. appl. Biol. 39: 487. Schöniger, G. (1958).
Phytopath. Z. 32: 325.


Subterranean clover mottle sobemovirus

      (1) R.I.B. Francki, 1983. Revised 1987. (2) Synonyms: subterranean
clover virus. (3) Standard acronym: SCMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.0.009.
(8) First reported in Trifolium subterraneum. (9) From Perth, Australia. (10)
By Francki et al. (1983). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Trifolium subterraneum
systemic mosaic, stunting. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Pisum sativum necrotic local lesions; No systemic
infection. Trifolium subterraneum systemic mosaic, stunting. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Trifolium subterraneum.
(46) Pisum sativum (L). (47) Pisum sativum, or Trifolium subterraneum. (48)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii.
(50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Francki et al. (1983). (60) Method: Francki et al.
(1983). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (84) Virions contain <c.>
20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions <c.> 80 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.2
kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 12472. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M33000
Em(40)_vi:SUVSATA Gb(84)_vi:SUVSATA Subterranean clover mottle virus satellite
RNA (virusoid) sequence. 7/90 332bp. M33001 Em(40)_vi:SUVSATB

sequence. 7/90 388bp. 2 sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the
virions. (121) Is of an unusual type of structure. (122) Nongenomic nucleic
acid satellite RNA. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 29000. (134) Coat
protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Aggregates. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: lucerne
transient streak virus, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: velvet tobacco mottle, solanum nodiflorum mottle, southern
bean mosaic and sowbane mosaic viruses. (187) Francki, R.I.B., Randles, J.W.
and Graddon, D. (1987). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 329. Francki, R.I.B.,
Randles, J.W., Hatta, T., Davies, C., Chu, P.W.G. and McLean, G.D. (1983). Pl.
Path. 32: 47. Graddon, D. and Randles, J.W. (1986). J. virol. Meth. 13: 63.


Subterranean clover red leaf luteovirus

      (1) G.R. Johnstone, P.M. Waterhouse, 1980; J.W. Ashby 1980. Revised
1984. (2) Synonyms: clover subterranean red leaf virus, soybean dwarf
luteovirus (Ashby and Kyriakou, 1982; Johnstone and McLean, 1987). (5) ICTV
decimal code 39.0.1.0.015. (8) First reported in Trifolium subterraneum. (9)
From Northern Victoria, Australia. (10) By Anon. (1968). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Erodium moschatum, Trifolium repens, T. subterraneum, Pisum
sativum, Vicia faba, Lupinus spp., Glycine max, Lens culinaris mild yellowing,
stunting and reddening. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani, Neomyzus
circumflexus, Acyrthosiphon pisum, Macrosiphum euphorbiae (in New Zealand).
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in Australia, New Zealand,
and the USA <in California>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Gomphrena globosa slight leaf reddening. Beta vulgaris systemic yellowing.
Erodium cicutarium systemic reddening. Glycine max cv. Shirotsuronoko
interveinal yellowing, leaves rolled down. Lupinus cosentinii systemic
yellowing and reddening. Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Galatin 50, Tendergreen, Top
Crop interveinal chlorosis, leaf puckering, leaves rolled down. Pisum sativum
cvs Laxton superb, Onyx, Puget general yellowing, leaves brittle, leaves
rolled. Trifolium hybridum and T. repens systemic infection but few or no
symptoms. T. subterraneum leaf reddening. (44) Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
Capsella bursa-pastoris, Arachis hypogaea, Lathyrus odoratus, Trifolium
pratense. (45) Pisum sativum cvs Onyx, Puget. (46) Pisum sativum cvs Onyx,
Puget, Trifolium subterraneum cvs Bacchus Marsh, Geraldton, Mt Barker (W).
(47) Astragalus sinicus, or Beta vulgaris, or Erodium cicutarium, or Erodium
moschatum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens
culinaris, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus cosentinii, or Medicago hispida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Senecio vulgaris, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia sativa, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica campestris
ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or
Lathyrus odoratus, or Linum usitatissimum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus
albus, or Stellaria media, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or
Trifolium pratense, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Geraniaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/21>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or Cruciferae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<9/21>, or Linaceae <1/1>. (53) Kellock (1971); Kellock (unpublished data).
(54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 14 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Waterhouse and Helms (1984); Ashby and
Kyriakou (1982). Add 1-1.5% cellulase when using standard luteovirus
purification method. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 27 nm in diameter, or 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations <dimers often found>. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 114 S. (79) Density 1.39 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions
contain 28-30 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 70-72 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 5.86 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 5.86 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12049. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 22600, or 25000. (145) Method of preparation: Ashby and Kyriakou
(1982). (147) Amino acid composition: Waterhouse and Kortt in Waterhouse et
al. (1987). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in phloem and companion cells in transfer cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: small vesicles with stranded
material. (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: soybean dwarf virus, so closely that it is probably the same species;
bean leaf roll, beet western yellows and potato leafroll more distantly. (187)
Anon. (1968). J. Dep. Agric. Vic. 66: 182. Ashby, J.W. and Kyriakou, A.
(1982). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 25: 607. Ashby, J.W., Teh, P.B. and Close, R.C.
(1979). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 22: 361. Jayasena, K.W., Hatta, T., Francki,
R.I.B. and Randles, J.W. (1981). J. gen. Virol. 57: 205. Johnstone, G.R.
(1978). Aust. J. agric. Res. 29: 1003. Johnstone, G.R., Duffus, J.E., Munro,
D. and Ashby, J.W. (1982). Aust. J. agric. Res. 33: 697. Johnstone, G.R. and
McLean, G.D. (1987). Ann. appl. Biol. 110: 421. Johnstone, G.R. and Rapley,
P.E.L. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 91: 345. Kellock, A.W. (1971). Aust. J. agric.
Res. 22: 615. Waterhouse, P.M. and Helms, K. (1984). J. Virol. Meth. 8: 321.
Waterhouse, P.M., Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1987). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 339. Wilson, J. and Close, R.C. (1973). N.Z. Jl agric. Res. 16:
305.


Subterranean clover stunt nanavirus

      (1) G.R. Johnstone, 1983. Revised by P.W.G. Chu, 1987. (2) Synonyms:
clover stunt virus, clover subterranean stunt virus. (3) Standard acronym:
SCSV. (4) Strains: Dickson isolate; Clandulla isolate; Ginnindera isolate a
severe strain and Wattamondara isolate. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.1.003.
(8) First reported in Trifolium subterraneum. (9) From New South Wales,
Australia. (10) By Grylls and Butler (1956). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Trifolium subterraneum, T. cernuum mild or severe stunting, marginal chlorosis
and puckering or cupping of leaflets, older leaves purple or crimson. Medicago
lupulina, M. hispida var. denticulata, M. minima, Trifolium repens, T.
glomeratum, Wisteria sinensis typical stunting, shortening of petioles and
internodes; chlorosis of young leaves. Phaseolus vulgaris severe epinasty and
leaves thickened, smaller and chlorotic; severe stunting and terminal
necrosis, few or no seeds. Pisum sativum, Vicia faba leaf size reduced,
petioles and internodes shortened, leaf chlorosis and rolling. Trifolium
dubium, T. pratense, Medicago arabica typical stunting and yellowing on new
growths. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Myzus persicae, Macrosiphum
euphorbiae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (36) Studies reported by Grylls and Butler (1956; 1959); O'Loughlin
(1958); Grylls and Peak (1960; 1969); Peak et al. (1963); Gutierrez et al.
(1971). (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Trifolium subterraneum cv. Mt Barker severe stunting, rosetting, puckering and
marginal chlorosis, reddening of older leaves. Medicago hispida var.
denticulata severe stunting, rosetting, puckering and marginal chlorosis,
reddening of older leaves. Macroptilium lathyroides severe stunting and small
leaves, then marginal chlorosis and puckering of terminal leaves. Trigonella
procumbens extreme stunting and puckering of leaflets. Astragalus sinicus
stunting, leaf yellowing, size reduction and rolling down. (44) Gomphrena
globosa, Capsella bursa-pastoris, Erodium moschatum. (45) Trifolium
subterraneum cv. Mt Baker, Pisum sativum cv. Greenfeast propagation only. (46)
Trifolium subterraneum (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Astragalus sinicus, or
Crotalaria intermedia, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Desmodium intortum, or
Lablab purpureus, or Lens culinaris, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or
Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Medicago, or Medicago arabica, or Medicago hispida,
or Medicago hispida var. denticulata, or Medicago lupulina, or Medicago
minima, or Medicago orbicularis, or Medicago polymorpha, or Medicago sativa,
or Medicago scutellata, or Melilotus albus, or Melilotus indicus, or
Onobrychis biebersteinii, or Onobrychis viciifolia, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum, or Trifolium, or Trifolium cernuum, or Trifolium dubium, or
Trifolium glomeratum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pannonicum, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Trifolium subterraneum, or
Trigonella procumbens, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or Vigna unguiculata,
or Wisteria sinensis. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris ssp. napus, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Cicer arietinum, or
Datura stramonium, or Erodium moschatum, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Linum usitatissimum, or Lupinus
albus, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Senecio vulgaris, or
Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium hybridum, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vitis rupestris. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <39/44>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <2/2>, or Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <10/44>,
or Linaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1 /1>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Vitidaceae <1/1>. (52) Host range data variable, probably resulting from
strain differences or contaminants. All varieties of Trifolium subterraneum
appear to be susceptible as well as all varieties of Phaseolus vulgaris. Many
species of Medicago and Trifolium are susceptible. (53) Grylls and Butler
(1959); O'Loughlin (1958); Gutierrez et al. (1971); Smith (1966). (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions <when tested by ISEM>. (59) Electron microscopy:
virus preparations are stable in AM, pH 6.5. (60) Method: Chu and Helms
(1987). Use of cellulases helps purify virions. (61) Virions isometric. (63)

Sugarcane bacilliform badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and B.E.L. Lockhart, 1988. (3) Standard acronym: SCBV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 07.0.1.0.011. (8) First reported in Saccharum
officinarum. (9) From north west Morocco. (10) By Lockhart and Autry (1988).
(13) Saccharum officinarum no conspicuous symptoms. (39) Spreads in Cuba,
Morocco, and the USA <Florida and Hawaii>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Saccharum officinarum (clone CP 44-101) symptomless systemic infection.
(44) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana benthamiana, N. glutinosa, Sorghum
halepense, Zea mays. (45) Saccharum officinarum. (46) Saccharum officinarum
(clone CP 44-101) (W). (47) Saccharum officinarum. (48) Avena sativa, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Sorghum halepense, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays. (50)
Gramineae <1/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <5/6>, or Solanaceae
<2/2>. (53) Lockhart and Autry (1988). (60) Method: Lockhart and Autry (1988).
(61) Virions bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 131 nm in

sequence. (179) Badnavirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related

kalanchoe top spotting, yam bacilliform, rice tungro and canna yellow mottle

related to banana streak badnavirus, but is probably distinct. (187) Bouhida,

Sugarcane Fiji disease fijivirus

      (1) T. Hatta, 1980. (3) Standard acronym: FDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
60.0.7.1.001. (8) First reported in Saccharum spp. (9) From Australia and the
Philippines. (10) By Anon. (1886); North (1915); Ocfemia (1923); Bell (1933).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Saccharum spp. leaf deformation and leaf galls.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Perkinsiella saccharicida, P. vitiensis and P. vastatrix. (18) Transmitted
by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained
when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus
transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (38) Spreads in the African region and
the Pacific region <New Britain and the New Hebrides>. (39) Spreads in
Australia, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Thailand, and Western
Samoa. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Saccharum spp., Sorghum spp., Zea mays enations on
deformed leaves and leaf sheaths. (47) Saccharum officinarum, or Sorghum
bicolor, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <3/3>. (53) Hutchinson et al. (1972).
(58) Leaf sap <galls> contains many virions, or contains few virions <in
leaves>. (59) Electron microscopy: stain with UA. (60) Method: Van der Lubbe
et al. (1979). (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 71 nm in diameter <intact

(97) The 5th largest 3.1 kb <pairs>. (98) The 6th largest and other parts 2.5
kb <pairs; also 2.190, 1.732, 1.724 and 1.720 kb pairs>. (132) Virion
protein(s) <at least> three <in the core>. (133) Mr 145000-150000. (135) Mr of
2nd largest 125000-129000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 36000-39000. (145) Method
of preparation: Van der Lubbe et al. (1979). (171) Virions found in gall
tissue. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Round, containing strands and amorphous material. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: proliferations in both phloem and
xylem. (179) Fijivirus: Reoviridae <the type species>. (180) : Reoviridae.

Sugarcane mosaic potyvirus

      (1) D.M. Persley, 1980. (2) Synonyms: grass mosaic virus, maize dwarf
mosaic virus strain B (MacKenzie et al., 1966; Louie and Knoke, 1975; Shukla
et al., 1989), sorghum red stripe virus. (3) Standard acronym: SCMV. (4)
Strains: European maize dwarf virus, MDMVB, SCMVA, SCMVB, SCMVD, SCMVE,
SCMVSC, SCMVSabi, sorghum concentric ringspot virus, possibly also abaca
mosaic potyvirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.062. (8) First reported in
Saccharum spp. (10) By Brandes (1919); Gold and Martin (1955). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Saccharum spp., Sorghum bicolor, Panicum spp., Eleusine spp.,
Setaria spp., Zea mays mosaic and/or ringspots, stunting. Sorghum halepense
(particular strains) mosaic and/or necrosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Dactynotus ambrosiae,
Hysteroneura setariae, Rhopalosiphum maidis, Toxoptera graminum. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Saccharum sp. systemic mosaic.
Sorghum bicolor necrotic local lesion, then systemic mosaic, necrosis. S.
halepense systemic mosaic. Zea mays systemic mosaic, ringspots. Most
dicotyledonous plants. (45) Zea mays (sweet corn). (46) Sorghum genotypes
(L,W). (47) Anthoxanthum odoratum, or Arundinaria amabilis, or Arundo donax,
or Cynodon dactylon, or Digitaria decumbens, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or
Eleusine coracana, or Elytrigia repens, or Eragrostis cilianensis, or Hordeum
vulgare, or Imperata cylindrica, or Lolium perenne, or Oplismenus compositus,
or Oryza sativa, or Panicum capillare, or Paspalum dilatatum, or Phalaris
paradoxa, or Phaseolus vulgaris <symptomless local infection on cv. Bountiful
with some strains>, or Phragmites australis, or Saccharum officinarum, or
Sacciolepis indica, or Setaria italica, or Setaria viridis, or Sorghum
bicolor, or Sorghum genotypes, or Sorghum halepense, or Zea mays. (48)
Agrostis tenuis, or Avena sativa, or Bromus mollis, or Cortaderia selloana, or
Dactylis glomerata, or Festuca pratensis, or Isachne globosa, or Lolium
temulentum, or Phleum pratense, or Poa pratensis, or Secale cereale, or
Triticum aestivum. (50) Gramineae <26/38>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>. (51) Gramineae <12/38>. (53) Ford et al. (1972); Tosic et al. (1972);
Penrose (1974); Rosenkranz (1978; 1987). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-4
days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by
treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Moghal and Francki (1976); Shukla et al. (1989a); Bond and Pirone (1971). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 730-755 nm.
(71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.

Sugarcane streak monogeminivirus

      (1) F. Hughes, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: SSV. (4) Strains: Natal
(type) and Mauritius. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported
in Saccharum officinarum. (9) From Natal, South Africa. (10) By Storey (1925).
(11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms chlorotic spots and narrow chlorotic
streaks. (13) Cenchrus echinatus, Saccharum officinarum narrow, elongated
chlorotic spots and streaks. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Cicadulina mbila, C. bipunctata bipunctata. C.
bipunctella-zeae. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (22) Principal natural
vector(s): Cicadulina mbila, C. bipunctata bipunctata, C. bipunctella-zeae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner, or in a semipersistent manner.
(26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in
the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the
vector. (29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in Benin, Cape Verde, Cote d'Ivoire, Egypt, India, Kenya, Malawi,
Mauritius, Mozambique, Pakistan, Reunion, Sudan, Uganda, and Zimbabwe. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show mild chlorotic streaks and spots. (43) Saccharum officinarum yellow and
white streaks. Cenchrus echinatus. Eleusine indica mild permanent leaf
streaks. Zea mays mild, short, pale streaks. (44) Digitaria horizontalis. (45)
Saccharum officinarum, Zea mays. (47) Cenchrus echinatus, or Eleusine indica,
or Saccharum officinarum, or Zea mays. (48) Digitaria horizontalis. (50)
Gramineae <4/5>. (51) Gramineae <1/5>. (53) McClean (1947); Pinner et al.
(1988). (55) LIV: 7 days. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method:
Bock and Bailey (1989); Pinner et al. (1988). (61) Virions geminate. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 30 nm in
length. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 76 S. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88)
Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome
size 2.76 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.76
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hayes et al. (1988). (100) Base
composition 27.7 % G. (101) Base composition 21.8 % A. (102) Base composition
23.1 % C. (104) Base composition 28.1 % T. (116) Nucleotide sequence
references: GENBANK database accession number M33829. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10836. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00597 Em(40)_vi:SSVL1
Gb(84)_vi:SSVL1 Sugarcane streak virus, L1'' gene encoding replication
associated protein. 3/91 254bp. M82918 Em(40)_vi:GESSV4ORF Gb(84)_vi:SSV4ORFS
Sugarcane streak virus (strain Natal) DNA. 2/94 2,758bp. S64567
Em(40)_vi:S64567 Gb(84)_un:S64567 11.16 kda orf(V1)...34.9 kda orf(C1)
sugarcane streak virus SSV, Genomic Complete, 4 genes, 3 sequences. (119)
Features of the genome: 2 virion sense ORFs encoding proteins of 11,000 and
27,000 Mr; the smaller ORF has homology with V1 of MSV (transport protein),
and the larger with V2 of MSV (capsid protein). There are two ORFs in the
complementary strand; C1 encoding a protein of 34,940 Mr and C2 of 17,000 Mr,
these, like other monogeminiviruses, may be spliced to give c', which encodes
the replicase protein of 41,000 Mr. There is a TATA box upstream of V1 and
upstream of C1, and a AATAA consensus polyadenylation signal downstream of C2
and of V2. Sequence with homology to the core upstream activator sequence of
MSV is upstream of C1. There are two intergenic regions. The large one is
between the starts of C1 and V1 and contains promoter sequences and a
conserved stem and loop structure with the TAATATTAC sequence common to all
geminivirus genomes. The small intergenic region lies between the termini of
V2 and C2 and contains AATAA sequences and a possible binding site of about 72
nucleotides in the genomic strand for an endogenous DNA primer molecule. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 28000. (134) Capsid protein. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves,
mesophyll, meristem and phloem. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Non-crystalline. (179) Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: digitaria
streak and maize streak viruses. (183) The Mauritius strain is milder and
induces finer streak symptoms. (184) Until recently sugarcane streak
geminivirus was considered to be a strain of maize streak virus. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: serology (Pinner and Markham, 1990; Peterschmitt et al.,
1991), transmission to maize and sugarcane and symptoms (Bock and Bailey,
1989). (187) Bock, K.R. and Bailey, R.A. (1989). In: Diseases of Sugarcane;
Major Diseases, p. 322; eds C. Ricaud, B.T. Egan, A.G. Gillespie Jr. and G.C.
Hughes. Elsevier/North Holland, Amsterdam, Oxford, New York, Tokyo. Hatta, T.
and Francki, R.I.B. (1979). Virology 92: 428. Hayes, R.J., MacDonald, H.,
Coutts, R.H.A. and Buck, K.W. (1988). J. gen. Virol. 69: 1345. Hughes, F.L.,
Rybicki, E.P., Kirby, R. and Von Wechmar, M.B. (1990). Intervirology 32: 19.
McClean, A.P.D. (1947). S.A. Dep. Agric. Sci. Bull. 265: 33 pp. Peterschmitt,
M., Reynaud, B., Sommermeyer, G. and Baudin, P. (1991). Plant Dis. 75: 27.
Pinner, M.S., Markham, P.G., Markham, R.H. and Dekker, E.L. (1988). Pl. Path.
37: 74. Storey, H.H (1925). S. Afr. Sugar Technol. Assoc. 4: 69.

(39) Spreads in Kenya and Tanzania. (47) Helianthus annuus. (50) Compositae

Sunflower mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1988. (2) Synonyms: helianthus mosaic virus, sunflower
potyvirus. (3) Standard acronym: SuMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.077. (8)
First reported in Helianthus annuus. (9) From Texas, U.S.A. (10) By Arnott and
Smith (1967). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Helianthus annuus mild systemic
mosaic and mottling, mosaic then severe necrosis of leaves and stems. (39)
Spreads in China and the USA <Texas>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Helianthus annuus systemic leaf mottling. (45) Helianthus annuus. (47)
Helianthus annuus. (50) Compositae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (171) Virions found in
leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187)
Arnott, H.J. and Smith, K.M. (1967). J. Ultrastruct. Res. 19: 173.

Sunn-hemp mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1983. Revised 1985. (2) Synonyms: bean strain of tobacco
mosaic virus, cowpea strain of tobacco mosaic virus, cowpea chlorotic spot
virus (Sharma and Varma, 1975; Varma, 1986), cowpea mosaic virus (Lister and
Thresh, 1955; Kassanis and Varma, 1975), cowpea yellow mosaic virus,
Crotalaria mucronata mosaic virus, dolichos enation mosaic virus (Capoor and
Varma, 1948; Kassanis and Varma, 1975), sunn-hemp rosette virus (Varma, 1986;
Verma and Awasthi, 1976; 1978). (3) Standard acronym: SHMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 71.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Crotalaria juncea. (9) From India.
(10) By Capoor and Varma (1948). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Crotalaria
juncea, Lablab purpureus, Vigna unguiculata, Mucuna aterrima systemic mosaic,
mottling, stunting. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus <probably> transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in <in the tropics>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Cajanus cajan systemic leaf mosaic and mottling.
Crotalaria juncea systemic vein yellowing, mosaic, mottling and stunting.
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba necrotic local lesions. Phaseolus vulgaris necrotic or
chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic and vein yellowing. Vigna unguiculata
systemic mosaic, mottling and vein yellowing. Nicotiana glutinosa necrotic
local lesions; not systemic. Petunia × hybrida, Solanum melongena, Tropaeolum
majus few or no systemic symptoms. (44) Catharanthus roseus, Cucumis sativus,
Lablab purpureus, Vicia faba (with most, but not all, isolates). (45)
Phaseolus vulgaris. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa (L), N. tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc
(L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L), most cultivars. (47) Beta vulgaris, or Cajanus
cajan, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia tora, or Crotalaria juncea, or
Crotalaria retusa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab
purpureus, or Mucuna aterrima, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana glutinosa,
or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
peruviana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (48)
Abelmoschus esculentus, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cucumis sativus, or Lablab
purpureus, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Rumex acetosa, or Vicia faba, or
Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/15>, or
Solanaceae <12/12>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/15>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>. (53) Capoor (1962). (54)
TIP: 90-95 °C. (55) LIV: 3000 days <or longer>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7.
(57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Kassanis and Varma (1975). (61)
Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm <also c. 25
nm>. (71) Virions 17 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (73) Axial canal 4 nm
in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.3 nm. (76)
Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 187 S. (78) Of the other(s) 35 S, or 75 S. (79)
Density 1.318 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.5 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.5 kb. (106) 5' terminus of
RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap. (108) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (114) Genome has
tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts valine. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12240.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): Em_vi:TOC30KCP 30k and coat protein
genes, 1,800bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions <short

(133) Mr 18062. (147) Amino acid composition: Rees and Short (1975). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: most tobamoviruses. (187) Capoor, S.P. and
Varma, S.P. (1948). Curr. Sci. 17: 57. Capoor, S.P. (1962). Phytopathology 52:
393. Kassanis, B. and McCarthy, D. (1967). J. gen. Virol. 1: 425. Kassanis, B.

Sweet clover latent (?) nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) G.M. Milbrath, 1982. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: melilotus latent
virus. (3) Standard acronym: MeLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.033. (8)
First reported in Melilotus albus, M. officinalis. (9) From Chicago, U.S.A.
(10) By Kitajima et al. (1969). (13) Melilotus albus, M. officinalis no
distinct symptoms, but often present with bean yellow mosaic potyvirus in
plants with leaf chlorosis. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads
in the USA. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Spain, the
Netherlands and the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Melilotus
albus, M. officinalis symptomless infection. (45) Melilotus albus, M.
officinalis. (46) Melilotus albus (W). (47) Melilotus albus, or Melilotus
officinalis. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains few

vascular parenchyma in sieve tubes and young tracheids. (172) Virions found in

Sweet clover necrotic mosaic dianthovirus

      (1) K. Boswell, 1985. (2) Synonyms: clover sweet necrotic mosaic virus.

officinalis chlorotic ringspots, then mottle, mosaic, leaf malformation,
veinal necrosis especially during winter. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Canada. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible.
(43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Gomphrena globosa, Vicia faba

systemic mosaic. (44) Petunia × hybrida. (45) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red
Kidney. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Red Kidney

Sweet potato caulimovirus

      (1) A.A Brunt, 1986; F. Nienhaus, 1987. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.T.DE.1. (8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From the U.K., in
plants imported from Puerto Rico. (10) By Atkey and Brunt (1987). (13) Ipomoea
batatas no conspicuous symptoms. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but
with no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A., Puerto Rico, New Zealand, Kenya,
Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Australia, Tonga and Madeira. (43) Ipomoea
setosa chlorotic veinal flecks and/or circular interveinal chlorotic spots.
(44) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. benthamiana, Chenopodium quinoa, Gomphrena
globosa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Ipomoea setosa. (47) Ipomoea batatas, or
Ipomoea setosa. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus vulgaris. (50)
Convolvulaceae <2/2>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 50 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Doublestranded. (132) Virion
protein(s) one <major>. (133) Mr 42000-44000. (171) Virions found in vascular
parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Ovoid and up to 4
[Gm]m in diameter with a large central lacuna and usually several smaller
peripheral lacunae. (177) They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: vascular parenchyma cells, which protrude into and sometimes
completely occlude, adjacent xylem vessels. (179) <Probable> Caulimovirus.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cauliflower mosaic,
dahlia mosaic, carnation etched ring and soybean chlorotic mottle viruses.
(187) Atkey, P.T. and Brunt, A.A. (1987). J. Phytopath. 118: 370.


Sweet potato feathery mottle potyvirus

      (1) R.N. Campbell, 1984; F. Nienhaus, 1987. Revised 1989 by J.W. Moyer.
(2) Synonyms: sweet potato chlorotic leaf spot virus, sweet potato internal
cork virus, sweet potato russet crack virus, sweet potato virus A (Hollings et
al., 1976; Sheffield, 1957). (3) Standard acronym: SPFMV. (4) Strains: russet
crack strain and sweet potato vein-clearing virus. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.064. (8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Beltsville,
Maryland, U.S.A. (10) By Doolittle and Harter (1945). (11) Symptoms disappear
soon after infection <except for russet crack strain symptoms which persist on
roots>. (13) Ipomoea spp. vein clearing, vein feathering, chlorotic spots, in
cv. Jersey also causes root necrosis if infected by russet crack strain. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Aphis gossypii, A. craccivora, Lipaphis erysimi, Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably
distributed worldwide. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Louisiana, U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Ipomoea incarnata,
I. nil systemic vein clearing, vein banding, ringspots. I. setosa vein
clearing followed by remission. (45) Ipomoea batatas, I. incarnata, I. nil, I.
purpurea, I. setosa, Nicotiana benthamiana (some strains). (46) Ipomoea setosa
(W), I. nil (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L) for some isolates in certain
environments. (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Ipomoea batatas, or Ipomoea
incarnata, or Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea purpurea, or Ipomoea setosa, or
Nicotiana benthamiana. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica
juncea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Convolvulaceae <5/5>, or Solanaceae
<1/5>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cruciferae <3/3>,
or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae
<4/5>. (53) Campbell et al. (1974); Moyer and Kennedy (1978). (54) TIP: 60-65
°C. (55) LIV: 0.3-0.5 days <7-12 hours>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Moyer and Kennedy (1978); Cali and
Moyer (1981); Cadena-Hinojosa and Campbell (1981a); Loebenstein et al. (1988).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 830-850 nm.
(72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.6 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 11.6 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Moyer and Cali (1985). (110) Poly A region present. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12844.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): D16664 Em(40)_vi:SPFNIBCP

      (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.10. (8) First reported in Ipomoea

Sweet potato latent (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux, 1986, F. Nienhaus, 1987. (2) Synonyms:
sweet potato virus N. (3) Standard acronym: SwPLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.078. (8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas cv. Tainung 63. (9) From
Taiwan. (10) By Liao et al. (1979). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection. (13) Ipomoea batatas most cultivars infected symptomlessly. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Liao et al. (1979); Liao et al.
(1982). (39) Spreads in Taiwan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mosaic and stunting. Chenopodium quinoa, C.
amaranticolor brown necrotic local lesions; no systemic infection. Ipomoea nil
systemic mottle on c. 6-8 leaves but symptomless on subsequent leaves.
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Dutch `A' chlorotic rings. Nicotiana megalosiphon
systemic deformation and mottling. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic pin-prick
chlorotic local lesions. (44) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. debneyi, Chenopodium
murale, C. capitatum. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana benthamiana
(W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Ipomoea batatas <cv. Tainung 63>, or Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea
setosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Avena
byzantina, or Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or

sap>. (55) LIV: 0.6-1 days <at 25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Liao et al. (1979). (61) Virions
filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 700-750 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31743. (118) Sequence database accession

coat protein (Taiwan). 1/95 1,076bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
36000. (145) Method of preparation: Brunt: proteins identified by SDS
polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
nucleus and pinwheels. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: sweet potato feathery mottle
virus and several other potyviruses. (187) Liao, C.H., Chien, K., Chung, M.L.,
Chiu, R.J. and Han, Y.H. (1979). J. agric. Res. China 28: 127. Liao, C.H.,
Tsay, H.S. and Lu, Y.C. (1982). J. agric. Res. China 31: 239.


Sweet potato leaf curl (?) badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Green, 1988. (5) ICTV decimal code 07.0.1.T.DE.2.
(8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Taiwan. (10) By Liao et al.
(1979). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Ipomoea batatas upward curling of
leaves and vein swelling on young plants, but later few or no symptoms. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Japan and Taiwan.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Ipomoea batatas cv. Tainung 63,
Ipomoea nil curling of young leaves. (47) Ipomoea batatas, or Ipomoea nil.
(50) Convolvulaceae <2/2>. (53) Chung et al. (1985). (61) Virions bacilliform.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (179) <Possible> Badnavirus. (187) Chung, M.L., Liao, C.H.,
Chen, M.J. and Chiu, R.J. (1985). Pl. Prot. Bull., Taiwan 27: 333. Liao, C.H.,
Chien, I.C., Chung, M.L., Chiu, R.J. and Han, Y.H. (1979). J. agric. Res.

Soc. Japan. 50: 438.


Sweet potato mild mottle ipomovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, S. Molyneux, 1986; F. Nienhaus, 1987. (2) Synonyms:
sweet potato T virus, sweet potato B virus (Hollings et al., 1976a; Sheffield,
1957). (3) Standard acronym: SPMMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.U.1.001. (8)
First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania. (10)
By Sheffield, 1957; Hollings et al. (1971). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Ipomoea batatas mild leaf mottling and stunting in intolerant cultivars, but
symptomless infection in others. Some cultivars are immune. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia
tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Hollings et al.
(1976a); Wambugu (1990). (39) Spreads in Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda.
(41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum vein
clearing, leaf curling and deformation. Chenopodium quinoa local lesions; not
systemic. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa, N. clevelandii, N. tabacum. (46)
Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Atriplex hortensis, or Beta vulgaris, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Ipomoea batatas, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or
Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia
× hybrida, or Phlox drummondii, or Primula malacoides, or Saponaria vaccaria,

tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Zinnia

from plants from Thailand. (47) Ipomoea aquatica, or Ipomoea setosa. (50)
Convolvulaceae <2/2>. (179) <Possible> Phytoreovirus: Reoviridae. (180) :
