Sweet potato ringspot (?) nepovirus

      (1) J.D. Brown and A.A. Brunt, 1988. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.T.DE.4. (8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas cv. Wanmun. (9) From the
U.K. in a sweet potato imported from Papua New Guinea. (10) By Brown et al.
(1988). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Ipomoea batatas
occasional chlorotic ringspots, then symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (39)
Spreads in Papua New Guinea. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Ipomoea batatas cvs Jasper and Rose Centennial chlorotic ringspots (after
graft inoculation), then symptomless. Ipomoea setosa faint systemic chlorotic
leaf mottling. Nicotiana megalosiphon necrotic rings, systemic leaf mottling.
Nicotiana benthamiana systemic leaf deformation. Glycine max systemic leaf
chlorosis and stunting. Chenopodium quinoa, C. murale transient systemic
chlorosis. (44) Nicotiana debneyi, Trifolium incarnatum, Vicia faba, Pisum
sativum, Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis. (45) Nicotiana megalosiphon, N.
benthamiana, Ipomoea setosa. (46) Nicotiana megalosiphon (W), Chenopodium
murale (W), C. quinoa (W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Capsicum annuum, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Ipomoea batatas <cv. Wanmun>, or Ipomoea nil, or
Ipomoea setosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Pisum sativum,
or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Convolvulaceae <3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/6>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/8>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<3/6>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (53) Brunt and Brown (unpublished information).
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Brunt and Brown (unpublished
information). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 130 S <B>.
(78) Of the other(s) 87 S <M>, or 47 S <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 15.1 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 8.4 kb. (94) The
2nd largest 6.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Brunt et al. (1989).
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 56500. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method
of preparation: Brunt: dissociation in 0.625 M Tris-HCl pH 6.8 containing 2%
SDS and 5% 2-mercaptoethanol for 3 minutes at 100°C. (171) Virions found in
leaves and roots. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus: Comoviridae. (180) :
Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: arabis
mosaic, cassava green mottle, crimson clover latent, hibiscus latent ringspot,
cacao necrosis, grapevine chrome mosaic, cherry leaf roll, peach rosette
mosaic, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot, tomato black ring,
tomato ringspot and tobacco ringspot viruses. (187) Brown, J.D., Brunt, A.A.
and Hugo, S.A. (1988). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. for 1986-1987, p. 104.


Sweet potato sunken vein (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and G. Loebenstein, 1995. (2) Synonyms: possibly sweet
potato whitefly transmitted agent (Schaefers and Terry, 1976; Rossel and
Thottapilly, 1985). (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.DE.5. (8) First reported in
Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Israel. (10) By Cohen et al. (1992). (13) Ipomoea
batatas symptomless or mild vein yellowing, some sunken secondary veins on
adaxial leaf surfaces and swollen veins on abaxial surfaces. Very severe
diseases occur when the virus is in mixed infections with sweet potato
feathery mottle virus. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae.
(25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Israel and Nigeria
<possibly>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Ipomoea hederacea, I.
setosa, I. trichocarpa, I. trifida leaf rolling and cupping. (44) Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, Chenopodium murale, C. quinoa, Cucumis sativus,
Datura stramonium, Petunia × hybrida, Physalis floridana. (47) Ipomoea
batatas, or Ipomoea hederacea, or Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea setosa, or Ipomoea
trichocarpa, or Ipomoea trifida, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium murale,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Daucus
carota, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Raphanus sativus, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Convolvulaceae <6/6>, or Solanaceae <2/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <4/6>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (60) Method: Cohen et al. (1992).
(61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (70) Virions of 850
nm. (71) Virions 12 nm wide. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 39721. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X80995 Em(43)_vi:Spsvvcp Gb(89)_vi:Spsvvcp Sweet
potato sunken vein virus genomic RNA for coat protein. 4/95 1,182bp. (125) 3
virus specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest
virus specified dsRNA 10.5 kbp. (127) 2nd largest 7 kbp. (128) 3rd largest 5
kbp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 34000. (134) Coat protein. (178)
Other cellular changes: phloem cells have fibril-containing vesicles. (179)
<Possible> Closterovirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: lettuce infectious yellows virus. (186) The whitefly-transmitted
component of the sweet potato virus disease complex occurring in Nigeria has
properties very similar to those of sweet potato sunken vein virus; the genome
of the former has also been shown to be of 9 kb. (187) Cohen, J. and
Loebenstein, G. (1991) Plant Dis. 75: 291. Cohen, J., Frank, A., Vetten, H.J.,
Lesemann, D.-E. and Loebenstein, G. (1992). Ann. appl. Biol. 121: 257. Rossel,
H.W. and Thottappilly, G. (1985). Virus Diseases of Important Food Crops in
Tropical Africa, pp. 10-13. IITA, Ibadan, Nigeria. Schaefers, G.A. and Terry,
E.R. (1976). Phytopathology 66: 642. Winter, S., Purac, A., Leggett, F.,
Frison, E.A., Rossel, H.W. and Hamilton, R.I. (1992). Phytopathology 82: 869.


Sweet potato vein mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) F. Nienhaus, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: SPVMV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.T.079. (8) First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Argentina.
(10) By Nome (1973). (13) Ipomoea batatas vein-clearing, mosaic, twisting of
leaves and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in Argentina. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Ipomoea batatas and other Ipomoea spp. systemic
vein-clearing and mosaic. (47) Ipomoea batatas, or Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea
setosa. (50) Convolvulaceae <3/3>. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 761 nm. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host
plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Scrolls and
laminated aggregates. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) <Probably>
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Nome, S.F. (1973).
Phytopath. Z. 77: 44. Nome, S.F., Shalla, T.A. and Petersen, L.J. (1974).
Phytopath. Z. 79: 169.


Sweet potato yellow dwarf (?) ipomovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1988. (2) Synonyms: whitefly transmissible sweet potato
virus. (3) Standard acronym: SPYDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.U.1.002. (8)
First reported in Ipomoea batatas. (9) From Taiwan. (10) By Liao et al.
(1979). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Ipomoea batatas stunting, chlorosis
(chlorophyll content decreased by 50%), poor roots and tubers. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Taiwan. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Ipomoea batatas cv. Tainung 63 severe systemic leaf
chlorosis and stunting. Chenopodium spp., Gomphrena globosa, Datura
stramonium, Cassia occidentalis, Sesamum indicum. (47) Cassia occidentalis, or
Chenopodium, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Ipomoea batatas,
or Sesamum indicum. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Pedaliaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53) Chung et al. (1986). (54) TIP: 85-90 °C <in
sweet potato sap>. (55) LIV: <more than> 7 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 33000. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) <Possible> ipomovirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (187) Chung, M.L., Hsu, Y.H., Chen, M.J. and Chiu, R.J. (1986).
In: Pl. Virus Diseases of Hort. Crops in the Tropics and Sub-tropics, No. 33,
p. 84. FFTC Book Series. Liao, C.H., Chien, I.C., Chung, M.L., Chin, R.J. and
Han, Y.H. (1979). J. agric. Res. China 28: 121.


Swordbean distortion mosaic potyvirus

      (1) V.R. Mali, 1987. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: swordbean mosaic virus.
(3) Standard acronym: SBDMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.080. (8) First
reported in Canavalia ensiformis. (9) From Parbhani, Maharashtra State, India.
(10) By Mali (1979). (13) Canavalia ensiformis, C. virosa, C. ensiformis × C.
virosa mosaic, leaf deformation, shoe-stringing, small deformed pods,
stunting. Canavalia gladiata mosaic, mottling and slight leaf deformation.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Aphis gossypii, Dactynotus sonchi, Myzus persicae, Rhopalosiphum maidis.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (36) Studies reported by Mali (1979, 1985); Mali et al.
(1983); Raut (1981). (39) Spreads in India <Maharashtra and Karnataka States>.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Canavalia gladiata veinal
necrosis; systemic mosaic, mottling, veinal necrosis and slight leaf
deformation. Canavalia virosa veinal chlorosis; mosaic and systemic leaf
deformation. Phaseolus vulgaris, Glycine max chlorotic or necrotic local
lesions, veinal necrosis; systemic mosaic mottling and slight puckering. Cicer
arietinum, Trigonella foenum-graecum systemic mosaic and leaf deformation.
Vigna unguiculata systemic mosaic. Chenopodium album faint chlorotic local
lesions; not systemic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Arachis
hypogaea, Nicotiana glutinosa, Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Top Crop, Solanum
nigrum. (45) Canavalia ensiformis, Phaseolus vulgaris, Cicer arietinum. (46)
Phaseolus vulgaris (W), Cicer arietinum (W). (47) Cajanus cajan, or Canavalia
ensiformis, or Canavalia ensiformis × C. virosa, or Canavalia gladiata, or
Canavalia virosa, or Chenopodium album, or Cicer arietinum, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Glycine max, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis . (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum,
or Carthamus tinctorius, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale,
or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Helianthus annuus, or Lablab
purpureus, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens culinaris, or Lycopersicon esculentum,
or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris <cv.
Top Crop>, or Sesamum indicum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Vicia faba. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/6>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <16/21>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <5/6>, or Compositae
<3/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/21>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <8/8>.
(53) Mali (1979, 1985); Mali et al. (1985); Raut (1981). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C.
(55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Mali (1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 790 nm. (71) Virions 11 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (174) Inclusions <cytoplasmic cylindrical> present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are pinwheels and unusual in shape. (176) Scrolls, resembling
those of sub-division I type (Edwardson, 1974). (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: bean
common mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, peanut mottle, soybean mosaic and wisteria
vein mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
blackeye cowpea mosaic, celery mosaic, datura distortion mosaic, henbane
mosaic, papaya ringspot, potato Y and watermelon mosaic 2 viruses. (184)
Although serologically related to five potyviruses, swordbean distortion
mosaic virus is distinguished from them by its host range and symptomatology.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: insusceptibility of Chenopodium amaranticolor
and C. quinoa aids the distinction of the swordbean distortion mosaic virus
from a similar virus (probably caused by a strain of bean yellow mosaic virus)
infecting Canavalia ensiformis in India. (187) Edwardson, J.R. (1974). Fla
Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 4, p. 1. Hollings, M. and Brunt, A.A. (1981).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 245, 7 pp. Mali, V.R. (1979). Curr. Sci. 48:
162. Mali, V.R. (1985). Int. J. Trop. Pl. Dis. 3: 93. Mali, V.R., Nirmal,
D.D., Mundhe, G.E., Vyanjane, N.T. and Raut, K.G. (1983). Abstr. Papers Virol.
Conf. Publ. HAU, Hissar p. 41. Raut, K.G. (1981). M.Sc. Thesis, M.A.U.,
Parbhani, M.S., India. Rodriguez, R.L., Bird, J., Monllor, A.C., Waterworth,
H.E., Kimura, M. and Maramorosch, K. (1975). In: Tropical Diseases of Legumes
p. 91; eds J. Bird and K. Maramorosch. Academic Press, New York.
Silberschmidt, K. and Nobrega, N.R. (1943). O. Biologica 8: 129.


Tamarillo mosaic potyvirus

      (1) D.W. Mossop, 1988. (2) Synonyms: tomato tree virus, Cyphomandra
virus. (3) Standard acronym: TamMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.065. (8)
First reported in Cyphomandra betacea. (9) From New Zealand. (10) By
Chamberlain (1954). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13) Cyphomandra betacea
vein-banding and mosaic, fruit blotching. Solanum nigrum usually symptomless,
sometimes leaf blotching. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Mossop (1977).
(39) Spreads in New Zealand. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana glutinosa systemic necrosis and, usually, plant death. N.
clevelandii, N. rustica and N. tabacum systemic vein-clearing and mosaic. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa (W). (47)
Cyphomandra betacea, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana
× edwardsonii, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum nigrum. (48) Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsicum
annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Ipomoea setosa, or Lactuca sativa, or
Lupinus angustifolius, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans.
(50) Solanaceae <9/14>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <3/3>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <5/14>.
(53) Mossop (1977). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Mossop (1977).
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 745 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 148 S <±3>. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid <based on
A260/A280 values>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (92) Genome unipartite. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised
with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region
probably at the 3' end. (112) Additional factor not required for infectivity.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12226. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): X54804
Em(40)_vi:TAMVCPG Gb(84)_vi:TAMVCPG Tamarillo mosaic virus gene for the coat
protein. 4/91 1,066bp 1 sequence. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 30000.
(134) Coat protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
potato Y, turnip mosaic, bean yellow mosaic, lettuce mosaic, passionfruit
woodiness and tobacco etch viruses. (184) Originally incorrectly identified as
potato virus Y in tree tomato, furthermore PVY does not protect tamarillo
against tamarillo mosaic potyvirus. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: tamarillo
mosaic virus is often in mixed infections with potato aucuba mosaic virus,
which depends on TaMV for aphid transmission. PaMV causes severe necrosis of
Capsicum frutescens, but no host species is known that separates them. (187)
Chamberlain, E.E. (1954). Plant Viruses in New Zealand. Bulletin DSIR, No.108,
p.129. Mossop, D.W. (1977). N. Z. Jl agric. Res. 20: 535. McLean, G.D. and
Mossop, D.W. (1988). In: The Plant Viruses; Vol. 4, The Filamentous Viruses,
p. 401; ed R.G. Milne. Plenum Press, New York.


Tamus latent (?) potexvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and D.-E. Lesemann, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.T.D.12. (8) First reported in Tamus communis. (9) From south west
England. (10) By Vetten et al. (1987). (13) Tamus communis symptomless. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with no evidence
of spread, in the U.K. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show local lesions, then systemic vein
chlorosis or necrosis. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. megalosiphon systemic
chlorotic and necrotic vein banding. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C.
quinoa, Gomphrena globosa, Tetragonia tetragonioides local chlorotic or
necrotic lesions. Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana
clevelandii symptomless systemic infection. (44) Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana
tabacum, Petunia × hybrida, Phaseolus vulgaris, Physalis floridana. (45)
Nicotiana benthamiana, N. megalosiphon. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C.
quinoa (L). (47) Antirrhinum majus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Solanum demissum, or Tamus communis,
or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Cucumis sativus, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Dioscoreaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <9/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<3/12>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Vetten et al.
(1987). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 553
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (83) A260/A280 ratio
1.26. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27700. (134) And it is coat
protein. (145) Method of preparation: Vetten et al. (1987). (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll
and all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Cytoplasmic masses of filamentous virions mainly parallel or in whorls.
(177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible> Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: papaya mosaic (Argentine plantago and
boussingaultia mosaic strains), hydrangea ringspot and potato X viruses. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Brazilian cassava common
mosaic, cymbidium mosaic, dioscorea latent, lily X, narcissus mosaic, potato
aucuba mosaic, potato X and white clover mosaic potexviruses. (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: In Tamus communis in England, potyviruses related to yam mosaic
virus are common, but may be distinguished from this virus by serology and
virion morphology. (187) Vetten, H.J., Lesemann, D.-E. and Allen, D.J. (1987).
Pl. Path. 36: 492.


Teasel mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: TeaMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.081. (8) First reported in Dipsacus fullonum.
(9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By Stoner (1951). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Dipsacus fullonum vein clearing, chlorotic mottling and malformed filiform
leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Macrosiphum rosae, Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Rhopalosiphum padi, Macrosiphum avenae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the USA <California>. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show leaf
mottling and malformation. (43) Dipsacus fullonum, Scabiosa atropurpurea
systemic vein clearing, then mottling and malformed leaves. (44) Cucurbita
pepo, Beta vulgaris, Nicotiana tabacum, Cucumis sativus. (45) Dipsacus
fullonum, Scabiosa atropurpurea. (46) Dipsacus fullonum (W). (47) Dipsacus
fullonum, or Scabiosa atropurpurea. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris,
or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50) Dipsacaceae
<2/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>,
or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Stoner (1951). (61) Virions <possibly>
filamentous. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (179) Unassigned potyvirus. (180) :
Potyviridae. (187) Stoner, W.N. (1951). Phytopathology 41: 91.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TeMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.066. (8) First reported in Telfairia occidentalis. (9) From Nigeria.
(10) By Nwauzo and Brown (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Telfairia
occidentalis stunting, chlorosis of leaves, malformation of fruits. (14)

Aphis spiraecola. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <Anno-Nyako, 1988>. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Atiri and Varma (1983). (39)
Spreads in Nigeria. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Citrullus
vulgaris, Cucumis melo, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo systemic leaf
chlorosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, C. murale, Phaseolus vulgaris
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
clevelandii systemic chlorosis. (44) Nicotiana rustica, N. glutinosa, Datura
metel, Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, Ocimum basilicum. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Phaseolus vulgaris
(L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Citrullus vulgaris, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or

or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana

Datura metel, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Ocimum
basilicum, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Chenopodiaceae

Solanaceae <8/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/6>, or Solanaceae <3/11>. (54) TIP:
65-70 °C <in Telfairia occidentalis sap>. (55) LIV: 1 days <or less at about
25°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (60) Method: Shoyinka et al. (1987). (61)
Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear
modal length. (70) Virions of 806 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (74) Basic
helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 145 S. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions
contain <c.> 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists
of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32000.
(134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and roots. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are pinwheels <often seen as scrolls>. (177) They do not contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: hypertrophy of elements of endoplasmic
reticulum with vesicles containing finely stranded material. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bean yellow mosaic, watermelon mosaic 2 and zucchini yellow mosaic
viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: alstroemeria
mosaic, arracacha Y, bean common mosaic, bidens mottle, blackeye cowpea
mosaic, commelina mosaic, clover yellow vein, datura shoestring, freesia
mosaic, henbane mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, iris mild mosaic, iris severe
mosaic, lettuce mosaic, nerine yellow stripe, papaya ringspot, passiflora
woodiness, peanut mottle, pepper veinal mottle, potato Y, sugarbeet mosaic,
sweet potato feathery mottle, tobacco etch, turnip mosaic and ullucus mosaic
viruses. (187) Anno-Nyako, F.O. (1988). J. Phytopath. 121: 85. Atiri, G.I. and
Varma, A. (1983). Trop. Agric., Trin. 60: 95. Nwauzo, E.E. and Brown, W.M.

Lesemann, D.-E., Thottappilly, G. and Lastra, R. (1987). J. Phytopath. 119:
13.


Tephrosia symptomless (?) carmovirus

      (1) K.R. Bock, 1982. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: TeSV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 74.0.2.T.010. (8) First reported in Tephrosia villosa. (9) From
Mombasa, Kenya. (10) By Bock et al. (1981). (13) Tephrosia noctiflora, T.
villosa symptomless. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in Kenya. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Canavalia
ensiformis necrotic local lesions; systemic mosaic. Glycine max systemic
mosaic. Phaseolus acutifolius, P. vulgaris necrotic or chlorotic local
lesions; not systemic. (44) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (45) Glycine max. (46) Glycine max
(W). (47) Canavalia ensiformis, or Glycine max, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tephrosia noctiflora, or Tephrosia villosa. (48)
Amaranthus caudatus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Atriplex hortensis, or Bauhinia
purpurea, or Beta vulgaris, or Cajanus cajan, or Calendula officinalis, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or Citrullus lanatus, or Clitoria
ternatea, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura ferox, or Datura metel,
or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lablab purpureus, or
Macroptilium lathyroides, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or
Solanum nigrum, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium subterraneum, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna angularis, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/19>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae
<4/4>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <5/5>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/19>, or
Solanaceae <11/11>, or Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>. (53) Bock et al. (1981). (54)
TIP: 85-90 °C. (55) LIV: 23 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6-7. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Bock et al. (1981). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 126-127 S. (79) Density 1.361 g cm3 in CsCl. (84)
Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid <estimated from bouyant density in CsCl and
A260/A280>. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)

Thimbleberry ringspot virus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.39. (8) First
reported in Rubus parviflorus. (9) From British Columbia, Canada. (10) By
Stace-Smith (1958). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Rubus parviflorus irregular
leaf ringspotting and oak leaf patterns. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Macrosiphum (Oestlundia)
davidsonii, M.(O.) maxima and Amphorophora parviflori. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (24) Not transmitted by Amphorophora agathonica. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Canada. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show ringspots and oak leaf markings. (43) Rubus parviflorus
ringspot and oak leaf markings. Rubus idaeus faint chlorotic markings. R.
occidentalis diffuse mottle. R. henryi chlorotic leaf spots. (44) All
herbaceous hosts tested were insusceptible including Chenopodium quinoa,
Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana tabacum, Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata,
Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Rubus parviflorus. (46) Rubus parviflorus (W), Rubus
occidentalis (W). (47) Rubus henryi, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus occidentalis,
or Rubus parviflorus. (48) Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata. (50) Rosaceae <4/4>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (53)
Stace-Smith (1958). (61) Virions isometric. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (179) (Ungrouped).
(187) Stace-Smith, R. (1958). Can. J. Bot. 36: 385. Stace-Smith, R. (1987).
In: Virus Diseases of Small Fruits; ed. R.H. Converse, U.S. Dep. Agric. Hdbk
No.631, p. 277.


Thistle mottle caulimovirus

      (1) R. Hull, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: ThMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
15.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Cirsium arvense. (9) From Norwich, U.K.

kb <pairs>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Donson and Hull (1983).
(120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (164) Genome
replicates <presumably> in nuclei and in cytoplasm <DNA to RNA in the former,
RNA to DNA in the latter>. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper
virus. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are viroplasms.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Caulimovirus. (187) Donson, J. and Hull, R.
(1983). J. gen. Virol. 64: 2281.

Tobacco etch potyvirus

      (1) D.E. Purcifull, 1981. (2) Synonyms: datura Z virus, tobacco severe
etch virus, tomato etch virus. (3) Standard acronym: TEV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.1.0.067. (8) First reported in Datura spp. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By Blakeslee (1921). (11) Symptoms persist <may be strain-dependant>. (13)
Cassia obtusifolia leaf mottling, malformation and necrosis, stunting and
reduced seed yield. Capsicum annuum mottling, mosaic and leaf malformation,
fruit malformation, stunting. Datura stramonium leaf mottling, vein banding
and malformation, suppression of fruit spines. Lycopersicon esculentum leaf
mottling and distortion, severe yield reductions. Nicotiana tabacum mottling
and necrotic leaf etching. Physalis spp. leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by more than 10 spp.,
especially Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in
a nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector
transmission <Simons, 1976; Pirone, 1979>. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (38) Spreads in
the Eastern Asian region and the South and Central American region. (39)
Spreads in Canada, China, Mexico, Puerto Rico, Venezuela, and the USA. (41)
Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Cassia obtusifolia necrotic local
lesions; systemic mosaic and leaf malformation. Capsicum annuum systemic
mosaic, rugosity and leaf malformation. C. frutescens root necrosis, wilting
and death. Chenopodium album, C. amaranticolor and C. quinoa local chlorotic
or necrotic lesions; not systemic. Datura stramonium systemic mosaic,
ringspots, rugosity and leaf malformation. Nicotiana tabacum chlorotic local
lesions; systemic mosaic, ringspots, leaf malformation and necrotic etching.
(45) Capsicum annuum, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Chenopodium

Tobacco leaf curl bigeminivirus

      (1) T. Osaki, 1984. Revised 1989. (2) Synonyms: eggplant yellow mosaic
virus, eupatorium yellow vein virus, honeysuckle yellow vein mosaic virus
(Osaki et al., 1979), tobacco cabbaging virus, tobacco curly leaf virus,
tobacco frenching virus, tobacco leaf curl virus 1, tomato yellow dwarf virus,

29.0.3.0.037. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Amani,
Tanzania. (10) By Storey (1931). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Ageratum
conyzoides, Zinnia elegans, Capsicum annuum, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
tabacum leaf curling. Lycopersicon esculentum leaf curling, yellow dwarfing.

Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted
by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus lost by
the vector when it moults. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the
progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide <in tropical and subtropal regions>. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa systemic leaf
curling. Lonicera japonica systemic vein yellowing. Lycopersicon esculentum

Tobacco mild green mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1988. (2) Synonyms: green-tomato atypical mosaic virus
(Wetter, 1984; 1986), mild strain of tobacco mosaic virus (Johnson, 1947;
Wetter, 1984), paratobacco mosaic virus (Köhler and Panjan, 1943; Wetter,
1984), tobacco mosaic virus South Carolina mild mottling strain (McKinney,
1952; Wetter, 1984), tobacco mosaic virus strain U2 (Johnson, 1947; Siegel and
Wildman, 1954; Wetter, 1984), tobacco mosaic virus strain U5, tomato atypical
mosaic green mottling strain (Knight et al., 1962; Miller and Thornberry,
1958). (3) Standard acronym: TMGMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.011. (8)
First reported in Nicotiana glauca. (9) From the Canary islands. (10) By
McKinney (1929). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Nicotiana glauca bright yellow
mosaic, mottling, ringspots and cupping; stunting. N. tabacum cv. Samsun mild
green mosaic. Capsicum annuum severe necrotic mosaic; plants often killed.
Eryngium aquaticum, E. planum systemic yellow flecking. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by McKinney (1929); Randles et al. (1981); Wetter
(1980). (37) Probably distributed worldwide <in Nicotiana glauca in
Mediterranean climatic regions>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. sylvestris, N. tabacum cvs Xanthi-nc, White Burley
systemic yellow mosaic, ringspots. Datura stramonium, Chenopodium
amaranticolor local lesions; not systemic. Eryngium aquaticum, E. planum
systemic yellow flecks. Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Rutgers yellow mosaic with
Australian isolate. (44) Lycopersicon esculentum, Canary Island and American
cvs to Canary Island isolates (McKinney, 1929) L. esculentum cv. Marmande
(Wetter et al., 1984). (45) Nicotiana glauca, N. tabacum cv. Samsun, Eryngium
aquaticum (maintenance), Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa (L),
Datura stramonium (L). (47) Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura stramonium, or Eryngium aquaticum, or Eryngium
planum, or Lycopersicon esculentum <cv. Rutgers>, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana glauca, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N.

basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida. (48) Lycopersicon esculentum <cv. Marmande>.

Umbelliferae <2/2>. (51) Solanaceae <1/10>. (53) Wetter (1980; 1984); Wetter
et al. (1984). (54) TIP: 85-90 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 35000 days <i.e. more

(1958). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 308

RNA. 8/94 414bp. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (146) Amino acid sequence: Altschuh et al. (1981). (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant (Solberg and Bald, 1963). (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in chloroplasts. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and unusual in
shape. (176) Angled-layer aggregates and paracrystals. (177) They contain
virions. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: tobacco mosaic, tomato mosaic and odontoglossum ringspot viruses are
closely related and cucumber green mottle mosaic and sunn-hemp mosaic
tobamoviruses are distantly related. (184) The virion protein of tobacco mild
green mosaic virus has 67-68% amino acid homology with those of tobacco mosaic
and tomato mosaic, 60% with odontoglossum ringspot and less than 45% with
those of other tobamoviruses; thus it is most closely related to other
`solanaceous tobamoviruses' (Gibbs, 1986). Nucleic acid hybridization tests
confirm these results (Palukaitis and Symons, 1980). (185) Best tests for
diagnosis: tobacco mild green mosaic virus infects Eryngium aquaticum and E.
planum systemically, whereas tobacco mosaic and pepper mild mottle viruses
infect only inoculated leaves. (187) Bald, J.G. and Goodchild, D.J. (1960).
Phytopathology 50: 497. Boedtker, H. and Simmons, N.S. (1958). J. Am. chem.
Soc. 80: 2550. Gibbs, A.J. (1986). In: The Plant Viruses; Vol. 2, The
Rod-Shaped Plant Viruses; eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel and H. Fraenkel-Conrat.
Plenum Press, New York. Johnson, J. (1947). Phytopathology 37: 822. Knight,
C.A., Silva, D.M., Dahl, D. and Tsugita, A. (1962). Virology 16: 236. Köhler,
E. and Panjan, M. (1943). Ber. Deutsch. bot. Ges. 61: 175. McKinney, H.H.
(1929). J. Agric. Res. 39: 557. McKinney, H.H. (1952). Pl. Dis. Reptr 36: 184.
Miller, P.M. and Thornberry, H.H. (1958). Phytopathology 48: 665. Palukaitis,
P. and Symons, R.H. (1980). Virology 107: 354. Randles, J., Palukaitis, P. and
Davies, C. (1981). Ann. appl. Biol. 98: 109. Solis, I. and Garcia-Arenal, F.
(1990). Virology 177: 553. Siegel, A. and Wildman, S.G. (1954). Phytopathology
44: 277. Van de Walle, M.J. and Siegel, A. (1982). Phytopathology 72: 390.
Wetter, C. (1980). Z. PflKrankh. PflPath. PflSchutz. 87: 150. Wetter, C.

Tobacco mosaic satellivirus

      (1) G. Kurath and J.A. Dodds, 1992. (2) Synonyms: satellite tobacco
mosaic virus. (4) Strains: known to exist but none yet described in the
literature. (5) ICTV decimal code 64.0.4.2.003. (8) First reported in
Nicotiana glauca. (9) From southern California, U.S.A. (10) By Valverde and
Dodds (1986). (13) Nicotiana glauca symptomless; symptoms may be caused by
mixed infection with cucumber mosaic virus or potyviruses. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana tabacum, N. glauca, N. benthamiana, N. rustica, N. sylvestris,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Physalis floridana, Datura meteloides, Catharanthus
roseus symptoms of the helper virus are unaltered. Capsicum annuum modifies
helper virus symptoms by increased chlorosis and transient amelioration of
leaf blister. (44) Only those that do not support the helper virus. (45)
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi for systemic infections, N. tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc
for local lesions passage. (46) Capsicum annuum (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucurbita pepo, or Datura metel, or Datura meteloides, or Datura stramonium,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glauca, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis
floridana. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13/13>. (53) Valverde and Dodds
(1986); Valverde et al. (1991). (60) Method: Valverde et al. (1991). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <less than> 17 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions neither clearly angular or nor rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 42 S. (84)
Virions contain 25 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 75 % protein. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size
1.059 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 1.059 kb.
(99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by proteinase K treatment and
phenol:chloroform extraction. (100) Base composition 24.4 % G. (101) Base
composition 26.1 % A. (102) Base composition 21.3 % C. (103) Base composition
28.2 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has an unusual type. (107) 5' terminus of
RNA is non-phosphorylated. (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (112) Additional factor not required
for infectivity. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Mirkov et al. (1989).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12254. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): Genbank
M25782. (119) Features of the genome: ORF 1, nt 53229, encodes a 6.8kDa
protein of unknown function. This ORF has been translated in vitro but its
role in vivo has not been ascertained. ORF 2, nt 163642, encodes the virion
coat protein both in vitro and in vivo. The 3' terminal 240 nt share 65%
overall sequence similarity with the 3' terminus of TMVU1. This includes two
regions of near identity which are 40 and 50 nt long. The sequence of tobacco
mosaic satellite virus genomic RNA indicates that, probably, much of it is
base paired. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (125) 1 virus specified dsRNA
species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus specified dsRNA
1.1 kbp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 17500. (134) Coat protein.
(145) Method of preparation: Valverde and Dodds (1987). (152) Viruscoded
nonvirion proteins isolated <Mirkov et al. (1989)>. (153) One protein found
<in vitro>. (154) Mr 68000. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasmic viroplasms.
(166) Replication depends on coinfection with a helper virus. (167) But the
specific basis of dependence is not known. (171) Virions found in leaves,
roots, mesophyll and epidermis. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm, viroplasms, and unusual in shape. (176) Unit membranes with
vesicles containing fibrillar material surround viral crystals; proteinaceous
bodies are contained within this inclusion. (177) They contain virions. (179)
Satellivirus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: tobacco
necrosis satellite, panicum mosaic satellite, and maize white line mosaic
satellite viruses. (184) This satellite virus is found naturally associated
with tobacco mild green mosaic tobamovirus, but can be experimentally coinfect
with any of tobamoviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: tobacco mosaic
satellite virus causes no symptom modification in any host plants except
Capsicum annuum. Therefore the quickest way to identify it is by Ouchterlony
diffusion tests with tobacco mosaic satellite virus specific antiserum
available from J.A. Dodds. (186) Tobacco mosaic satellite virus crystallizes
very readily (Koszelak et al., 1989). The virion structure has recently been
resolved to the 0.3nm level (A. McPherson, personal communication). (187)
Dodds, J.A. (1991). Can. J. Pl. Pathol. 13: 192. Kim, K.S., Valverde, R.A. and
Dodds, J.A. (1989). J. Ultrastruct. Mol. Struct. Res. 102: 196. Koszelak, S.,
Dodds, J.A. and McPherson, A. (1989). J. mol. Biol. 209: 323. Mirkov, T.E.,
Kurath, G., Mathews, D.M., Elliot, K., Dodds, J.A. and Fitzmaurice, L. (1990).
Virology 179: 395. Mirkov, T.E., Mathews, D.M., DuPlessis, D.H. and Dodds,
J.A. (1989). Virology 170: 139. Valverde, R.A. and Dodds, J.A. (1986). J. gen.
Virol. 67: 1875. Valverde, R.A. and Dodds, J.A. (1987). J. gen. Virol. 68:
965. Valverde, R.A., Heick, J.A. and Dodds, J.A. (1991). Phytopathology 81:
99.


Tobacco mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) M. Zaitlin, 1984. (2) Synonyms: virus mosaique de tabac, tobacco
mosaic virus U1, tobacco mosaic virus type, tobacco mosaic virus vulgare,
tobacco mosaic virus common strain. (3) Standard acronym: TMV. (4) Strains:
Japanese common strain, masked strain M and many others. (5) ICTV decimal code
71.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Russia and the
U.S.A. (10) By Mayer (1886); Iwanowski (1892); Allard (1914); Stanley (1935).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Nicotiana tabacum leaf mosaic, severe crop losses.
Also found in many other plant species. (14) Transmitted by means not
involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <occasionally transmitted through the
testa, but not through the embryo>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana tabacum (various cultivars) systemic mosaic. Chenopodium quinoa,
Nicotiana glutinosa and N. tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc local lesions. (45) Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Turkish Samsun. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Nicotiana glutinosa
(L), N. tabacum cvs Samsun NN or Xanthi-nc (L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Datura stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Papaver nudicaule, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana,
or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Apium graveolens, or Avena
sativa, or Bellis perennis, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chrysanthemum morifolium,
or Dahlia pinnata, or Daucus carota, or Dianthus barbatus, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Ipomoea nil, or Ipomoea
setosa, or Matthiola incana, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Pastinaca sativa,
or Petroselinum crispum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus
sativus, or Salvia splendens, or Secale cereale, or Sinningia speciosa, or
Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria
media, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Compositae <1/6>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Papaveraceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<15/19>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Compositae
<5/6>, or Convolvulaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <5/5>, or Gesneriaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <5/5>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or
Malvaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae <4/19>, or Umbelliferae <4/4>. (53) Holmes
(1946); Cheo and Gerard (1971). (55) LIV: 3000 days. (57) Infectivity of sap
not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Gooding and Hebert (1967); Asselin and Zaitlin (1978).
(61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm. (71)
Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 2 nm in
diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.3 nm. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations <the main component is of
intact virions, but shorter rods are found, and two of these contain
encapsidated sub-genomic RNAs>. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 194 S. (79)
Density 1.325 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 3.5. (84) Virions
contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(87) Also include a trace amount of metal ions. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.395 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.395 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Mandeles and Bruening (1968). (100) Base composition 25.3 %
G. (101) Base composition 29.8 % A. (102) Base composition 18.5 % C. (103)
Base composition 26.3 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated
nucleotide cap. (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases.
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110)
Poly A region absent <at 3' terminus>. (112) Additional factor not required
for infectivity. (114) Genome has tRNAlike activity. (115) Genome accepts
histidine. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Goelet et al., (1982). (117)
NCBI Taxon ID: 12242. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D13367

disrupted in systemic infections. (179) Tobamovirus <the type species>. (181)

Tobacco mottle umbravirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
78.0.1.0.006. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Zimbabwe. (10)
By Smith (1946a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Nicotiana tabacum vein clearing
and dark green leaf mottling. Mixed infections with tobacco vein distorting
luteovirus give the rosette disease. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Acyrthosiphon
(Aulacorthum) solani. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (29) Virus requires, for
vector transmission, a helper virus <tobacco vein-distorting luteovirus>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Smith
(1946a,b). (39) Spreads in Zimbabwe. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa dark green leaf mottling. Lycopersicon
esculentum systemic transient leaf mottling. Datura stramonium systemic leaf
mottling and malformation. (45) Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa, Lycopersicon
esculentum. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50)
Solanaceae <4/4>. (54) TIP: 55 °C <in tobacco sap>. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (179) Umbravirus. (186) Tobacco mottle was probably the
first virus found to require an assistor virus (tobacco vein distorting
luteovirus) for its transmission by aphids (Smith 1946a,b). Few properties of
the virus are known, but it may resemble groundnut rosette and carrot mottle
`umbraviruses'. (187) Smith, K.M. (1946a). Parasitol. 37: 21. Smith, K.M.
(1946b). Parasitol. 37: 131.


Tobacco necrosis necrovirus

      (1) D.S. Teakle, 1982. Revised 1985. Updated 1990 by A.A. Brunt. (2)
Synonyms: tulip Augusta disease virus, bean stipple streak virus, chenopodium
necrosis necrovirus (Tomlinson et al., 1983), cucumber systemic necrosis
virus, strawberry necrotic rosette virus (Faccioli, 1970; 1974). (3) Standard
acronym: TNV. (4) Strains: many reported, including A, B, C, D E, and S (Babos
and Kassanis, 1963), cucumber necrosis (Van Koot and van Dorst, 1955), stipple
streak (Van der Want, 1948), Ac 36, Ac 38 and Ac 43 (Uyemoto et al., 1968),
Urbana (Lesnaw and Reichmann, 1969), chenopodium necrosis (Tomlinson et al.,
1983). (5) ICTV decimal code 44.0.1.0.003. (8) First reported in Nicotiana
tabacum. (9) From Cambridge, U.K. (10) By Smith and Bald (1935). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local lesions (some
strains), systemic necrosis (Chenopodium necrosis strain only). Cucumis
sativus systemic necrosis of leaves and stems (cucumber necrosis strain only).
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum necrotic local lesions. Phaseolus vulgaris
discrete local lesions only (D strains), local lesions that spread along minor
veins (A strains), systemic infection (stipple streak strain only). Tulipa
gesneriana necrosis of leaves and stems (Augusta disease). (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Olpidium
brassicae. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not
transmitted by pollen. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Lactuca
sativa, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna radiata, V. unguiculata,
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum necrotic local lesions, usually no systemic
spread (except the bean stipple streak strain in P. vulgaris). (45) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Vigna unguiculata, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L), Vigna radiata (L), V.
unguiculata (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum frutescens, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cichorium endiva, or Clarkia amoena, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba,
or Datura stramonium, or Fragaria vesca, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Gypsophila elegans, or Helianthus annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Hyoscyamus
niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Ricinus communis, or Sinningia speciosa, or
Solanum nodiflorum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium
repens, or Triticum aestivum, or Tulipa gesneriana, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Calendula officinalis, or
Daucus carota, or Dianthus barbatus, or Euphorbia marginata, or Ipomoea
setosa, or Medicago sativa, or Myosotis sylvatica, or Physalis peruviana, or
Raphanus sativus, or Secale cereale, or Solanum melongena, or Tropaeolum
majus, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <5/6>, or
Cruciferae <2/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/2>, or
Gesneriaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <4 /5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<11/13>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Onagraceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <11/13>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Boraginaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <1/6>, or
Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/3>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/2>, or
Gramineae <1/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/13>, or Solanaceae <2 /13>,
or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Price (1940); Thornberry
(1966). (54) TIP: 85-95 °C. (55) LIV: 7-28 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: aldehyde fixation
necessary for some strains (Finlay and Teakle, 1969). (60) Method: Finlay and
Teakle (1969); Kassanis (1970). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 118 S. (79)
Density 1.399 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.5 <B strain>. (84)
Virions contain 19 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 81 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 3.759 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 3.759 kb. (100) Base composition 24 % G. (101) Base composition
27.5 % A. (102) Base composition 22.5 % C. (103) Base composition 25.5 % U.
(106) 5' terminus of RNA has an unusual type <uncapped>. (109) Infectivity
retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A region <at
3' terminus> absent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12054. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): D00942 Em(40)_vi:TNCDNSC Gb(84)_vi:TNCDNSC Tobacco necrosis
virus genome, complete sequence. 1/94 3,759bp. L04261 Em(40)_vi:TNCPOLCOA
Gb(84)_vi:TNCPOLCOAT Tobacco necrosis virus (Nebraska) RNA-dependent RNA
polymerase gene, 3' end p10.7, p6.2 and c M33002 Em(40)_vi:TNCPOLY
Gb(84)_vi:TNCPOLY Tobacco necrosis virus RNA dependent RNA polymerase and coat
protein genes, complete cds. 7/9 X58455 Gb(84)_vi:TNVARNA Tobacco necrosis
virus type A RNA. 6/94 2,236bp. (119) Features of the genome: 5 ORFs encoding
proteins of 23, 82, 7.9, 6.2 and 30 kDa with a sixth encoding a 6.7 kDa
protein found only in strain A. The 82 kDa protein is probably a polymerase,
and the 30 kDa the coat protein. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in
the virions. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in infected cells. (124) Two
subgenomic RNAs (1.6 and 1.3 kb); the smaller encodes the coat protein, and
the larger the proteins of ORF 3 and, possibly, ORF 4. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 30000 <268-275 amino acid residues>. (134) Coat protein. (145)
Method of preparation: Lesnaw and Reichmann (1969); Uyemoto and Grogan (1969).
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
roots. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, or unusual in shape.
(176) String-like arrays and aggregates in the nucleus. (177) They contain
virions <Edwardson and Christie, 1986>. (179) Necrovirus <the type species>.

Tobacco necrosis satellivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: satellite virus. (3) Standard
acronym: STNV. (4) Strains: SV1, SV2 and SV3 (England) and SVA, SVB and SVC
(U.S.A.). (5) ICTV decimal code 64.0.4.2.004. (8) First reported in Nicotiana
tabacum. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Kassanis and Nixon, 1960. (13) Phaseolus
vulgaris, Tulipa gesneriana symptoms unknown. It only infects when with its
natural helper, tobacco necrosis necrovirus, and makes its lesions smaller.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted
by Olpidium brassicae. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(38) Spreads in the Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (43)
Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana tabacum inocula containing both tobacco necrosis
and its satellite virus induce smaller local lesions than the former alone.
(45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris (but dependent upon
strain of tobacco necrosis virus in inoculum). (46) Phaseolus vulgaris (L),
Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Tulipa gesneriana. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>. (54) TIP: 95 °C. (60) Method:
Kassanis (1970). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 17 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions with
a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 50 S. (82) Isoelectric
point pH 7. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.65. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 80 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(91) Total genome size 1.239 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part 1.239 kb. (100) Base composition 22-24 % G. (101) Base
composition 28-29 % A. (102) Base composition 20-22 % C. (103) Base
composition 25-29 % U. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12881. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): J02399 Gb(84)_vi:TNSCG Satellite tobacco necrosis virus,
complete genome. 3/89 1,239bp L06057 Em(40)_vi:TNSUTR Gb(84)_vi:TNSUTR

Em(40)_sy:CVGNL1 Gb(84)_sy:SYNTNSGNL1 Satellite tobacco necrosis virus genome

plasmid linker pSTNV-403. 7/89 64bp. M20900 Em(40)_vi:TNSFRNA

with an unidentified ORF, 5' end. 7 M64479 Em(40)_vi:TNSCP Gb(84)_vi:TNSCP

virus genome including reading frame for the viral coat protein. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 23000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Rees et al. (1970); Uyemoto and Grogan (1969). (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Satellivirus <type species>.
(186) Type strain of above group. (187) Kassanis, B. (1962). J. gen.
Microbiol. 27: 477. Kassanis, B. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 15, 4
pp. Kassanis, B. and Kleczkowski, A. (1965). Nature, Lond. 205: 310. Kassanis,
B. and MacFarlane, I. (1968). J. gen. Virol. 3: 277. Kassanis, B. and Nixon,

Tobacco necrotic dwarf luteovirus

      (1) S. Kubo, 1984. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: TNDV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 39.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From
Tochigi Prefecture, Japan. (10) By Kubo and Takanami (1977). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Spinacia oleracea leaf vein yellowing. Nicotiana tabacum
interveinal leaf chlorosis, veinal necrosis, severe stunting. Capsella
bursa-pastoris interveinal reddening, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus
retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector.
(28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by
pollen. (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Capsella bursa-pastoris, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana sylvestris, N. tabacum
systemic interveinal chlorosis, veinal necrosis, stunting. Physalis floridana
systemic interveinal chlorosis, leaf rolling. Montia perfoliata mild systemic
interveinal chlorosis. (44) Beta vulgaris, Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
Astragalus sinicus, Pisum sativum, Lactuca sativa. (45) Physalis floridana.
(46) Nicotiana sylvestris (W). (47) Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Datura metel,
or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Montia perfoliata, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis
floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum nodiflorum, or
Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea. (48) Astragalus sinicus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Lactuca sativa, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Senecio vulgaris,
or Solanum melongena, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Cruciferae <1/5>, or
Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <13/15>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <4/5>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae
<2/15>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Kubo (1981). (54) TIP: 80 °C <assayed
using protoplasts>. (55) LIV: <more than 6 months at 4°C>. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Takanami and Kubo (1979). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (79) Density <virions disrupted in caesium
salts>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 5.3. (84) Virions contain 30 % nucleic acid.
(85) Virions 70 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.1 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.1 kb. (120) Nongenomic
nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is satellite RNA. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 25700. (134) Coat protein. (147) Amino acid
composition: Kubo (1981). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in phloem and companion cells. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: a fibrous appearance in
cytoplasm. (179) Luteovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: potato leafroll virus is closely related, but distinct; carrot red
leaf and soybean dwarf viruses are distantly related. (187) Kubo, S. and
Takanami, Y. (1977). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 43: 76. Kubo, S. (1981).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 234, 4 pp. Takanami, Y. and Kubo, S. (1979). J.
gen. Virol. 44: 153. Takanami, Y. and Kubo, S. (1979). J. gen. Virol. 44: 853.


Tobacco rattle tobravirus

      (1) B.D. Harrison and D.J. Robinson, 1984. (2) Synonyms: aster ringspot
virus, belladonna mosaic virus, paeony mosaic virus (Brierley, 1944), paeony
ringspot virus (Chang et al., 1976; Jones and Young, 1978; Martin, 1929),
potato corky ringspot virus, potato stem mottle virus, stengelbonk virus
(Rozendaal and van der Want, 1948), ratel virus, Tabakmauche Virus,
Tabakstreifen- und Kraüselkrankheit Virus, spinach yellow mottle virus, tulip
white streak virus (Smith, 1950). (3) Standard acronym: TRV. (4) Strains:
fraxinus tobravirus (Cooper et al., 1983), Oregon yellow virus, PRN (Scottish
type strain), spinach yellow mottle. NM isolates, which lack the smaller part
of the genome and do not produce nucleoprotein, can be prepared from all
strains. (5) ICTV decimal code 72.0.1.0.004. (8) First reported in Nicotiana
tabacum. (9) From Germany. (10) By Böning (1931). (11) Symptoms persist <some
strains>, or vary seasonally, or disappear soon after infection. (13)
Stellaria media, Viola arvensis few symptoms, mottling. Beta vulgaris,
Spinacia oleracea chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; systemic mottle.
Capsicum annuum ringspots or line patterns. Solanum tuberosum necrotic local
lesions; systemic chlorotic or necrotic spots and streaks. Nicotiana tabacum
necrotic local lesions, necrotic or chlorotic ringspots; systemic necrosis,
ringspots or line patterns, mottling. Narcissus pseudonarcissus, Tulipa sp.,
Hyacinthus sp. mottling. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a
nematode. (17) Transmitted by Paratrichodorus allius, P. anemones, P.
christiei, P. nanus, P. pachydermus, P. teres, Trichodorus minor, T.
primitivus, T. viruliferus. (20) Transmitted by Trichodoridae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted
by seed <up to 40% in Viola arvensis or only to 1% in Capsella
bursa-pastoris>. (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region, the North American
region, and the South and Central American region. (39) Spreads in China,
Japan, and the former USSR. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in New
Zealand and Australia. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Cucumis sativus necrotic and chlorotic local
lesions; no systemic infection. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. The Prince, Pisum
sativum, Vicia faba necrotic local lesions; no systemic infection. Nicotiana
clevelandii necrotic and chlorotic local lesions; few systemic symptoms,
mottle, necrosis. N. tabacum cv. Samsun NN necrotic local lesions and
ringspots; systemic necrosis, ringspots, mottle. (44) Probably Hordeum
vulgare. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Phaseolus vulgaris (L), Nicotiana tabacum for some strains
(L). (47) Allium cepa, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or
Antirrhinum majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Avena sativa, or Bellis perennis,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus,
or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica juncea, or Calendula
officinalis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus
roseus, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum
sativum, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Gypsophila elegans, or Helianthus annuus, or Hyacinthus, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Linum
usitatissimum, or Lobelia erinus, or Lupinus mutabilis, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Melilotus albus, or Momordica

Tobacco ringspot nepovirus

      (1) P.G.W. Chu, 1980. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: anemone necrosis virus
(Hollings and Stone, 1963; Hollings, 1965), blueberry necrotic ringspot virus
(Lister et al., 1963; Varney and Raniere, 1960), tobacco ringspot virus 1. (3)
Standard acronym: TRSV. (4) Strains: anemone necrosis strain, gladiolus
strain, North American strains WS, ST, NC39 (these contain satellite RNA),
tobacco green ringspot strain, tobacco yellow ringspot strain; possibly potato
black ringspot virus (Salazar and Harrison, 1977; 1978a and b; 1979) and also
ash ringspot virus (Hibben and Bozarth, 1972). (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.3.0.027. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (10) By Fromme et al.
(1927). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Cucumis sativus,
Glycine max, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana tabacum necrotic spots,
mottling, chlorotic ringspots and vein banding. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by a nematode <and also, non-specifically by insects and
mites Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae, Melanopus sp. Epitrix hirtipennis,
Thrips tabaci (possibly nymphs) and Tetranychus sp.>. (17) Transmitted by
Xiphinema americanum. (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (26) Virus lost by the
vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus
not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus does not
require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed.
(38) Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in China. (40) Found,
but with no evidence of spread, in Australia, the U.K., Germany and New
Zealand. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. quinoa necrotic or chlorotic local lesions. Cucumis sativus chlorotic local
lesions; then systemic ringspots, and leaves malformed. Phaseolus vulgaris
necrotic local lesions; systemic ringspots. Nicotiana clevelandii, Vigna
unguiculata necrotic local lesions; systemic leaf shape malformation. N.
glutinosa, N. tabacum necrotic local lesions; systemic ringspots. (44)
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, Abelmoschus manihot, Reseda odorata, Asperula
odorata, Secale cereale. (45) Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana
tabacum. (46) Cassia occidentalis (L), Vigna unguiculata (L), Nicotiana
clevelandii (L), N. tabacum (L,W). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Ageratum
conyzoides, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens,
or Apium graveolens var. dulce, or Atriplex hortensis, or Bellis perennis, or
Beta vulgaris, or Beta vulgaris ssp. cicla, or Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis <cv. Wong Bok>, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia argentea, or Cheiranthus cheiri, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cichorium endiva, or Clarkia amoena, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus <cv. Davis Perfect>, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo <and vars. medullosa, melopepo,
orifera>, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium,
or Daucus carota <unconfirmed>, or Dianthus barbatus <latent>, or Fagopyrum

Lactuca sativa, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lilium longiflorum, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus
albus, or Myosotis sylvatica, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana bigelovii,
