Tobacco streak ilarvirus

      (1) R.W. Fulton, 1984. (2) Synonyms: asparagus stunt virus (Brunt and
Paludan, 1970; Paludan, 1964), datura quercina virus, strawberry necrotic
shock virus (Frazier et al., 1962; Stace-Smith and Frazier, 1971). (3)
Standard acronym: TSV. (4) Strains: bean red node strain (Scott et al., 1961;
Thomas and Zaumeyer, 1950; Virgin, 1943), black raspberry latent strain (Brunt
and Stace-Smith, 1976; Converse and Lister, 1969; Jones and Mayo, 1975). (5)
ICTV decimal code 10.0.2.01.01. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9)
From Wisconsin, U.S.A. (10) By Johnson (1936). (11) Symptoms persist <most
hosts do not recover>. (13) Dahlia spp. leaf mottling or symptomless.
Gossypium herbaceum, Melilotus albus, Trifolium pratense leaf mottling.
Phaseolus vulgaris reddening of nodes. Glycine max systemic necrosis, bud
blight. Rosa setigera leaf vein yellowing. Nicotiana tabacum systemic
necrosis, with recovery. Asparagus officinalis stunting. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Frankliniella
occidentalis and Thrips tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Thysanoptera <possibly by
allowing virus from the surface of infected pollen to enter through feeding
wounds; Sdoodee and Teakle, 1987>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <in Chenopodium quinoa,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Datura stramonium to different extents>. (35) Virus
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (38) Spreads in the North American region and the Pacific region.
(39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, Peru, and the USA <CABI/EPPO data for black
raspberry latent strain>. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Beta
patellaris necrotic local lesions. Cyamopsis tetragonoloba small dark local
lesions. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Manteiga necrotic local lesions. Vigna
unguiculata chlorotic or necrotic local lesions. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Turkish
upper leaves become toothed. (45) Catharanthus roseus, Cucumis sativus, Datura
stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Beta patellaris (L), Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba (L), Macrotyloma uniflorum (L), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Manteiga
(L), Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, (L) for most strains. (47) Abelmoschus
esculentus, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Antirrhinum
majus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Asparagus officinalis, or Beta macrocarpa, or
Beta patellaris, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris, or Capsicum annuum,
or Capsicum frutescens, or Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or
Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or
Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata,
or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Dahlia pinnata, or Datura
stramonium, or Fragaria vesca, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Gossypium herbaceum, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens culinaris, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or
Matthiola incana, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Momordica
balsamina, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Nicotiana ×
edwardsonii, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Phlox drummondii, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Pisum
sativum, or Rosa setigera, or Salvia splendens, or Solanum demissum, or
Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or
Solanum nodiflorum, or Solanum rostratum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tithonia speciosa, or Torenia fournieri, or
Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia
faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zea mays, or Zinnia
elegans. (48) Brassica juncea, or Citrullus lanatus, or Datura ferox, or
Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lupinus albus, or
Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Sesamum indicum, or Sesbania
exaltata, or Tropaeolum majus. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Asparagaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <11/11>, or
Compositae <5/5>, or Cruciferae <2/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <6/7>, or Gramineae <1
/1>, or Labiatae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <18/20>, or Malvaceae <3/3>, or Polemoniaceae
<1/1>, or Rosaceae <2/2>, or Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <25/30>.
(51) Cruciferae <1/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/7>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/20>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/30>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>.
(53) Berkeley and Phillips (1943); Fulton (1948); Kaiser et al. (1982). (54)
TIP: 64 °C <in sap diluted in buffer containing anti-oxidant>. (55) LIV: 1.5
days <most infectivity lost within 5 min. in crude sap>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
1-4 <but varies over a wide range depending on host species, antioxidants
used, etc.>. (59) Electron microscopy: fixation with 1% glutaraldehyde
essential. (60) Method: Fulton (1967). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 27, 30, and 35 nm in diameter. (66) Virions
rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement.
(76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 113 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 90 S <T>, or 98 S
<M>. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.6. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.56. (84) Virions contain 14 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 86
% protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 7.915 kb. (92) Genome of three parts.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 2.94 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
2.77 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.205 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by
Van Vloten-Doting (1975). (100) Base composition 25 % G. (101) Base
composition 25 % A. (102) Base composition 20 % C. (103) Base composition 30 %
U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a methylated nucleotide cap <Van
Vloten-Doting, 1981>. (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with phenol or detergent.
(110) Poly A region present <Van Vloten-Doting, 1981>. (112) Additional factor
required for infectivity. (114) Genome has no tRNAlike activity. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 12317. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): J02416
Gb(84)_vi:TSVRNA2 tobacco streak virus rna 2: 3' end. 9/83 180bp J02417

9/93 2,205bp. 5 sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions.
(121) Is subgenomic mRNA. (122) Nongenomic nucleic acid of 0.881 kb. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 28500-30000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Van
Vloten-Doting (1975). (147) Amino acid composition: Ghabrial and Lister
(1974). (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and in
nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells <epidermal or guard cells>.
(175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Irregularly shaped. (177) They do
not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: fibrils in the cytoplasm
and nucleus that are associated with virion aggregates and masses of fibrils
in the cytoplasm that are not associated with virions (Edwardson and Christie,
1986). (179) Ilarvirus: Bromoviridae <subgroup 1 and the type species>. (180)
: Bromoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: apple
mosaic, American plum line pattern, asparagus C, citrus leaf rugose, citrus
variegation, elm mottle, lilac ring mottle, prune dwarf, prunus necrotic
ringspot, spinach latent, Tulare apple mosaic viruses. (187) Berkeley, G.H.
and Phillips, J.H.H. (1943). Can. J. Res. 21: 181. Brunt, A.A. and Paludan, N.
(1970). Phytopath. Z. 69: 277. Brunt, A.A. and Stace-Smith, R. (1976). Acta

Tobacco stunt varicosavirus

      (1) S. Kuwata, 1985. Revised 1989. (3) Standard acronym: TStV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 79.0.P.3.001. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From
Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan. (10) By Hidaka (1950). (11) Symptoms vary
seasonally. (13) Nicotiana tabacum stunting, vein necrosis, necrotic leaf
spotting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17)
Transmitted by Olpidium brassicae. (21) Transmitted by Chytridiales. (29)
Virus does not require a helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in
Japan. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Nicotiana tabacum cv. Burley 21
necrotic leaf spotting. Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc faint leaf spotting.
Tetragonia tetragonioides yellow leaf spotting; not systemic. (44) Brassica
oleracea, Lactuca sativa, Capsicum annuum. (45) Nicotiana tabacum cvs Burley
21, Bright Yellow. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Cyamopsis tetragonoloba
(L), Nicotiana glutinosa (L,W), N. tabacum (L,W), Tetragonia tetragonioides
(L). (47) Beta vulgaris, or Catharanthus roseus, or Chenopodium album, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Dianthus
caryophyllus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana,
or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Arachis
hypogaea, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Calendula
officinalis, or Capsicum annuum, or Celosia argentea, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Daucus carota, or Lactuca sativa, or Medicago
sativa, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Petroselinum
crispum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Phytolacca americana, or Raphanus sativus,
or Solanum demissum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium pratense, or Triticum
aestivum, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/9>, or
Solanaceae <13/17>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or
Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <5/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/2>, or Gramineae
<2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/9>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <4 /17>, or Umbelliferae <3/3>. (53)
Hiruki (1975). (54) TIP: 40-50 °C <sap transmissible only after addition of
reducing agents such as 0.01M Na2SO3>. (55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fixation
with glutaraldehyde necessary. (60) Method: Kuwata and Kubo (1981). (61)
Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 and 340 nm. (71)
Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 3.5 nm in
diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 5 nm. (81)
Density 1.27 in Cs2SO4. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.98 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts.
(93) Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 6.35 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd
largest 5.63 kb <pairs>. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 48000. (134)
Coat protein. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Varicosavirus.
(184) Virions of the virus are closely serologically related to those of
lettuce big vein virus, but as the two differ in host range, they are
considered as distinct species, rather than related strains (Kuwata and Kubo,
1986). (187) Hidaka, Z. (1950). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 15: 40. Hidaka, Z.,
Hiruki, C., Nakano, K., Shimizu, T. and Uozumi, T. (1956). Bull. Hatano
Tobacco Exp. Stn 40: 1. Hiruki, C. (1965). Virology 25: 288. Hiruki, C.
(1975). Can. J. Bot. 53: 2425. Kuwata, S. and Kubo, S. (1981). Ann. Phytopath.
Soc. Japan 47: 264. Kuwata, S. and Kubo, S. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
313, 4 pp.

Tobacco vein-distorting (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TVDV. (5) ICTV decimal code
39.0.1.T.012. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Zimbabwe. (10)
By Smith (1946a). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Nicotiana tabacum malformation
of leaf veins. Tobacco vein-distorting and tobacco mottle viruses together
causes tobacco rosette disease. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum)
solani. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (29) Virus can help the vector transmission of another virus <tobacco
mottle (?) umbravirus>. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (36) Studies reported by Smith (1946a,b). (39) Spreads in
Zimbabwe. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum, N.
glutinosa, N. sylvestris, Lycopersicon esculentum, Datura stramonium leaf vein
malformation. (45) Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa, N. sylvestris. (46)
Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50)
Solanaceae <5/5>. (53) Smith (1946a). (179) <Probably> Luteovirus. (184) Few
of the properties of this virus are known, but some indicate that it is
probably a luteovirus (Waterhouse et al., 1988). (186) This virus was probably
the first to be shown to assist the aphid transmission of another virus,
tobacco mottle umbravirus (Smith, 1946 a and b). (187) Smith, K.M. (1946a).
Parasitol. 37: 21. Smith, K.M. (1946b). Parasitol. 37: 131. Waterhouse, P.M.,
Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses, No.339, 9 pp.


Tobacco vein mottling potyvirus

      (1) M.K. Sun, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: TVMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.068. (8) First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By Gooding and Sun (1972). (11) Symptoms vary cyclically over a few
weeks. (13) Rumex sp., Nicotiana tabacum, Solanum carolinense chlorotic vein
banding of leaves. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus
transmitted by contact between plants. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen.
(38) Spreads in the North American region. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum chlorotic vein
banding. (45) Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Datura
metel, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Rumex, or Solanum carolinense. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<5/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Solanaceae <5/10>. (53) Sun et
al. (1974). (54) TIP: 60-70 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Sun et al. (1974). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 765 nm. (71)
Virions 13 nm wide. (74) Basic helix obvious. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12228. (118) Sequence database
accession code(s): K02991 Em(40)_vi:TVMURF Gb(84)_vi:TVMURF Tobacco vein
mottling virus helper component-related P75 gene, partial cds. 4/90 420bp
S68375 Em(40)_vi:S68375 Gb(84)_vi:S68375 coat protein (3' UTR region, direct
repeats) tobacco vein mottling virus (TVMV), variant pXB X04083
Em(40)_vi:POTTVMVX Gb(84)_vi:POTTVMVX Tobacco vein mottling virus (TVMV) RNA
genome. 9/93 9,472bp. 3 sequences. (164) Genome replicates in cytoplasm. (171)
Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
bean common mosaic, iris severe mosaic, clover yellow vein, henbane mosaic,
peanut mottle, potato Y, soybean mosaic and tobacco etch viruses. (187)
Gooding, G.V. and Sun, M. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 803. Sun, M.K.C.,
Gooding, G.V., Pirone, T.P. and Tolin, S.A. (1974). Phytopathology 64: 1133.


Tobacco wilt potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and A. Varma, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TWV. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.T.083. (8) First reported in Solanum jasminoides. (9) From
England from infected plants imported from India. (10) By Badami and Kassanis
(1959). (13) Solanum jasminoides symptoms unknown; naturally infected plants
are also infected with datura necrosis virus. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in India. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum chlorotic local
lesions; systemic veinal necrosis. Nicotiana glutinosa, Datura tatula,
Hyoscyamus niger systemic vein banding, mottling, severe malformation. Solanum
jasminoides necrotic local lesions; systemic veinal necrotic spotting. (44)
Solanum tuberosum, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana
glutinosa, Datura tatula, Hyoscyamus niger. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (W), N.
glutinosa (W). (47) Datura tatula, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum jasminoides. (48) Cucumis sativus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum tuberosum. (50) Solanaceae <5/6>. (51)
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/6>.
(54) TIP: 60-65 °C <in Nicotiana glutinosa sap>. (55) LIV: 4-8 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)

Tobacco yellow dwarf monogeminivirus

      (1) J.E. Thomas, 1980. Revised 1984. (2) Synonyms: bean summer death
virus. (3) Standard acronym: TYDV. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.011. (8)
First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Myrtleford District, Victoria,
Australia. (10) By Hill (1937). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Nicotiana tabacum
downcurling of tips and margins of younger leaves, general chlorosis. Datura
stramonium, D. tatula, Lycopersicon esculentum symptomless. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Orosius
argentatus. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (31) Virus not transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting <between
solanaceous hosts>. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in
Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. Spartan Arrow, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum systemic leaf
yellowing. (45) Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum cv. Grosse Lisse,
Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Spartan Arrow (W). (47) Beta
vulgaris, or Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lycopersicon esculentum,
or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum nigrum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or
Trifolium repens. (48) Cucumis sativus, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vigna radiata. (50) Chenopodiaceae
<1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or Solanaceae
<7/9>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or
Solanaceae <2/9>. (53) Hill (1950); Helson (1950); Hill and Mandryk (1954);
Thornberry (1966); Bowyer and Atherton (1972). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C <determined
by feeding leafhoppers through membranes on virus-containing extracts>. (55)
LIV: 26 days <in bean tissue stored at 18°C and in purified preparations
stored at 4°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-4. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(60) Method: Thomas and Bowyer (1980). (61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 35 nm in length. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 76 S. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Circular. (91) Total genome size 2.8 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 2.8 kb. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10830. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): M81103 Em(40)_vi:GETYDMONO Gb(84)_vi:TYDMONOCOT
Tobacco yellow dwarf virus gene, complete cds. 2/94 2,580bp. 1 sequence. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27500. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Thomas and Bowyer (1980). (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem. (174) Inclusions absent from
infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes: necrosis of phloem, especially
in sieve tubes. (179) Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae.

Tobacco yellow net (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: TYNV. (5) ICTV decimal code

Tobacco yellow vein assistor (?) luteovirus

      (1) A.N. Adams, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TYVAV. (4) Strains: virulent
and mild (Adams and Hull, 1972). (5) ICTV decimal code 39.0.1.T.014. (8) First
reported in Nicotiana rustica. (9) From Malawi. (10) By Adams and Hull (1972).
(13) Nicotiana rustica only found in natural infections with tobacco yellow
vein virus; which together cause tobacco yellow vein disease. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (29) Virus can help the
vector transmission of another virus <tobacco yellow vein umbravirus>. (31)
Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by
Adams and Hull (1972). (39) Spreads in Malawi. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum, N. clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. rustica
systemic veinal chlorosis and mottling. Lycopersicon esculentum mottling and
rugosity (virulent strain only). (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Cucumis sativus, Datura stramonium, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vicia faba. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii (W), N. tabacum (W). (47) Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vicia faba. (50) Solanaceae <5/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <1/6>.
(53) Adams and Hull (1972). (179) <Probably> Luteovirus. (184) Few of the
properties of this virus are known; it is probably a luteovirus (Waterhouse et
al., 1988). (187) Adams, A.N. and Hull, R. (1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 135.
Waterhouse, P.M., Gildow, F.E. and Johnstone, G.R. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 339, 9pp.


Tobacco yellow vein (?) umbravirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and A.N. Adams, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: TYVV. (4)
Strains: mild and virulent strains. (5) ICTV decimal code 78.0.1.T.010. (8)
First reported in Nicotiana tabacum. (9) From Malawi. (10) By Adams and Hull
(1972). (13) Nicotiana rustica, Nicotiana tabacum chlorotic vein-banding and
leaf malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (29) Virus requires, for vector transmission, a helper virus <tobacco
yellow vein assistor (?) luteovirus>. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Adams and Hull (1972). (39) Spreads in
Malawi. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum, N.
clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. rustica systemic chlorotic vein-banding; severe
isolates also cause malformation. Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicandra
physalodes, Petunia × hybrida light and dark green systemic leaf mottling.
Arachis hypogaea systemic pale green rings and pale green areas along midribs.
Glycine max mild systemic leaf mottling. (44) Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Datura
stramonium. (45) Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Nicotiana tabacum (W), N. rustica
(W), N. clevelandii (W), N. glutinosa (W). (47) Arachis hypogaea, or Glycine
max, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or
Datura stramonium, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Raphanus sativus, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/5>, or Solanaceae
<7/8>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/5>, or Solanaceae <1/8>. (53) Adams and Hull
(1972). (179) <Possible> Umbravirus. (184) Does not cross-protect against
tobacco mottle and groundnut rosette viruses. (187) Adams, A.N. and Hull, R.
(1972). Ann. appl. Biol. 71: 135.


Tomato aspermy cucumovirus

      (1) J. Hammond and J.M. Kaper, 1986; N. Habili, 1987. (2) Synonyms:
chrysanthemum mild mottle virus, chrysanthemum mosaic virus, chrysanthemum
aspermy virus. (3) Standard acronym: TAV. (4) Strains: type strain, TAV-Can
(Blencowe and Caldwell, 1949; Hollings and Stone, 1969) and TAV-V (Habili and
Francki, 1974a,b). (5) ICTV decimal code 10.0.4.0.003. (8) First reported in
Chrysanthemum morifolium. (9) From England. (10) By Ainsworth (1939); Blencowe
and Caldwell (1949). (11) Symptoms persist <but vary from plant to plant>.
(13) Chrysanthemum morifolium severe flower-breaking, dwarfing and
malformation. Lycopersicon esculentum severe leaf malformation and seedless
fruit. Canna spp., Lilium spp. mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae and many other
species. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae <Kennedy et al., 1962>. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by
contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <transmitted in seeds
of Stellaria media; Noordam et al., 1965>. (36) Studies reported by Hollings
and Kassanis (1957); Brierley and Lorentz (1980); most strains of the virus
can be eliminated from Chrysanthemum after c. 4 weeks at 37°C; or by
meristem-tip culture (Dunez and Monsion, 1968). A few heat-tolerant isolates
have been found in Britain, able to persist at 37°C, but their other
properties were similar to those of typical strains. (38) Spreads in the
Eurasian region. (39) Spreads in Australia, Canada, India, Japan, New Zealand,
the USA, and the former USSR. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43)
Nicotiana glutinosa chlorotic or ring local lesions, severe blister-mottle
with malformation and dwarfing. Leaves become tendril-like and enations form
on abaxial leaf surfaces. Nicotiana tabacum severe mottle, dwarfing and
malformation; symptoms less diagnostic than in N. glutinosa. Nicotiana
clevelandii severe mottling, dwarfing and malformation. Cucumis sativus small
local chlorotic spots in cotyledons only; type strain does not infect.
Lycopersicon esculentum leaf mottling, malformation, dwarfing, fruits dwarfed,
malformed and seedless. Phaseolus vulgaris small pale necrotic local lesions
in winter, not infected by type strain. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
numerous chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Vigna unguiculata
necrotic local lesions; not infected by type strain. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa
maintenance. Nicotiana clevelandii purification. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L); Chenopodium quinoa (L); Vigna unguiculata (L). (47) Canna,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chrysanthemum
morifolium, or Cucumis sativus, or Lilium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Stellaria media, or Vigna unguiculata. (48) Cucumis
sativus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Cannaceae <1/1>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Liliaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <4/4>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>. (53) Brierley (1955); Govier (1957); Hollings (1955); Hollings et al.
(1968); Noordam (1952); Oertel (1967). (54) TIP: 50-60 °C. (55) LIV: 2-6 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 4-6. (59) Electron microscopy: best to fix the virions
with formaldehyde. Few virions are found in dips, and they are difficult to
distinguish from normal cell components. Strains vary in stability in PTA; UA
is better. (60) Method: Marani (1969), a variant of Steere's method), Grogan
et al. (1963), Hollings et al. (1968), Habili and Francki (1974b), Lot et al.
(1972). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 29 nm
in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile, or angular in profile
<V-strain>. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
98-100 S. (79) Density 1.367 g cm3 in CsCl <labile in CsCl unless fixed;
Habili and Francki, 1974a>. (81) Density 1.304 g/cm3 in Cs2SO4 (Hull, 1976).
(82) Isoelectric point pH 5.6. (84) Virions contain 21.2 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 78.8 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.698 kb. (92) Genome
of three parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part <the largest> 3.41 kb. (94)
The 2nd largest 3.074 kb. (95) The 3rd largest 2.214 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Habili and Francki (1974a). (100) Base composition 23.1 % G
<TAV-Can>, or 23.9 % G <TAV-V>. (101) Base composition 24.6 % A <TAV-V>, or
26.2 % A <TAV-Can>. (102) Base composition 21.4 % C <TAV-V>, or 21.6 % C
<TAV-Can>. (103) Base composition 29 % U <TAV-Can>, or 30.1 % U <TAV-V;
Stace-Smith and Tremaine, 1973; Habili and Francki, 1974a>. (106) 5' terminus
of RNA has a VPg. (108) Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region absent. (114) Genome has tRNAlike activity.
(115) Genome accepts tyrosine. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Wilson
and Symons (1981); 189 residues from 3' ends of RNAs of two Australian TAV
isolates. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12315. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): D01015 Em(40)_vi:TOARNA3 Gb(84)_vi:TOARNA3 Tomato aspermy virus, RNA3
genome segment, complete sequence. 8/92 2,214bp. D10044 Em(40)_vi:TOAVRNA1
Gb(84)_vi:TOAVRNA1 Tomato aspermy virus (V-TAV) RNA1. 2/92 3,410bp. D10663
Em(40)_vi:TOARNA2 Gb(84)_vi:TOARNA2 Tomato aspermy virus (TAV) RNA 2, complete
sequence. 7/92 3,074bp. L15335 Em(40)_vi:TOA3APCOA Gb(84)_vi:TOA3APCOAT Tomato
aspermy virus 3A protein and coat protein mRNA (RNA3), complete cds. 5/93
2,222bp. M10342 Em(40)_vi:CUTOARN Gb(84)_vi:TOARNAV4 Tomato aspermy virus
(V-TAV) RNA 4, 3' end. 7/89 188bp. M10343 Em(40)_vi:CUTOARN2
Gb(84)_vi:TOARNAV3 Tomato aspermy virus (V-TAV) RNA 3, 3' end. 7/89 188bp
M10344 Em(40)_vi:CUTOARN3 Gb(84)_vi:TOARNAV1 Tomato aspermy virus (V-TAV) RNA
1, 3' end. 7/89 189bp. M10345 Em(40)_vi:CUTOARN4 Gb(84)_vi:TOARNAN3 Tomato
aspermy virus (N-TAV) RNA 3, 3' end. 7/89 189bp. M10346 Em(40)_vi:CUTOARNA
Gb(84)_vi:TOARNAN1 Tomato aspermy virus (N-TAV) RNA 1, 3' end. 7/89 189bp.
S72468 Gb(89)_un:S72468 capsid protein (RNA 3) (tomato aspermy virus TAV-B,
Blencowe, Genomic RNA, 2213 nt). 1/95 2,2. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found
in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA, or satellite RNA. (122) Nongenomic
nucleic acid the former encodes the coat protein and is called RNA-4 and is of
1.303 kb. (133) Mr 24500. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation:
Habili and Francki (1974a). (147) Amino acid composition: Habili and Francki
(1974a). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion proteins isolated. (153) One protein
found. (154) Mr 30000. (155) Non structural protein. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host
plant and particularly in the mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm and
in cell vacuoles. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions
are crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (179) Cucumovirus:
Bromoviridae. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: cucumber mosaic and peanut stunt viruses (Waterworth et al., 1973).
(184) Tomato aspermy and cucumber mosaic virus are similar; some isolates of
each have serologically related virions and cross-protect plants against each
other. Most strains of tomato aspermy virus differ from most of cucumber
mosaic virus in that they (1) infect only the cotyledons of cucumber; (2)
induce seedlessness of tomato fruit; (3) induce enations to form on the
abaxial surfaces of leaves of several Nicotiana species; and (4) infect
Chrysanthemum morifolium. (187) Ainsworth, G.C. (1939). Rep. Exp. Res. Stn
Cheshunt, 1938, p. 60. Bernal, J.J., Moriones, E. and Garcia-Arenal, F.
(1991). J. gen. Virol. 72: 2191. Blencowe, J.W. and Caldwell, J. (1949). Ann.
appl. Biol. 36: 320. Brierley, P. (1955). Phytopathology 45: 2. Brierley, P.
and Lorentz, P. (1960). Phytopathology 50: 404. Christie, R.G. and Edwardson,
J.R. (1977). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog. No. 9, p.89. Dunez, J. and Monsion, M.
(1968). Annls. Épiphyt. 19: 165. Govier, D.A. (1957). Ann. appl. Biol. 45: 62.
Grogan, R.G., Uyemoto, J.K. and Kimble, K.A. (1963). Virology 21: 36. Habili,
N. and Francki, R.I.B. (1974a). Virology 57: 392. Habili, N. and Francki,
R.I.B. (1974b). Virology 60: 29. Hollings, M. (1955). Ann. appl. Biol. 43: 86.
Hollings, M. and Kassanis, B. (1957). J. R. hort. Soc. 82: 339. Hollings, M.
and Stone, O.M. (1969). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1967, p. 95.

Tomato Australian leafcurl bigeminivirus

      (1) B.D. Conde and J.E. Thomas, 1987. (2) Synonyms: tomato transmissible
leafroll virus. (3) Standard acronym: ToLCV-Au. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.3.0.039. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From Darwin,
Australia. (10) By Aldrick (1971). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Lycopersicon
esculentum chlorosis and upward curling of leaflet margins, dark stunting.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by <possible> an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (31) Virus not
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible <and limited to
graft transmission tests until vector transmission is obtained>. (43)
Lycopersicon esculentum chlorosis and upward curling of leaflet margins,
stunting. Datura stramonium downward curling of leaf margins, interveinal
chlorosis, and chlorosis of minor veins. Nicotiana benthamiana leaf
malformation, vein chlorosis, prominent veins on abaxial leaf and sepal
surfaces. Nicotiana tabacum stunting, chlorosis and upward cupping of leaves.
(44) Capsicum annuum, Physalis minima, Physalis peruviana. (45) Lycopersicon
esculentum, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Datura stramonium
(W); Nicotiana benthamiana (W). (47) Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Nicotiana rustica, or Physalis
minima, or Physalis peruviana. (50) Solanaceae <9/13>. (51) Solanaceae <4/13>.
(53) B.D. Conde and J.E. Thomas (unpublished data). (61) Virions geminate.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (88) Genome <probably> consists of DNA. (117) NCBI
Taxon ID: 28350. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L11746

Tomato black ring nepovirus

      (1) B.D. Harrison, 1982. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: bean ringspot
virus, beet ringspot virus (Harrison, 1958), celery yellow vein virus
(Hollings, 1960; 1965), lettuce ringspot virus (Hollings, 1965), potato
bouquet virus, potato pseudo-aucuba virus. (3) Standard acronym: TBRV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.028. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum.
(9) From the U.K. (10) By Smith (1946). (11) Symptoms disappear soon after
infection. (13) Allium porrum, Beta vulgaris, Lactuca sativa, Phaseolus
vulgaris, Robinia pseudoacacia, Fraxinus sp., Rubus sp., Lycopersicon
esculentum, Solanum tuberosum, Apium graveolens, Narcissus pseudonarcissus,
Tulipa sp., Vitis sp., and many weed and endemic species. necrotic rings,
spots and flecks, systemic chlorotic ringspots, mottle, stunting, leaf
malformation, vein yellowing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Longidorus elongatus, L. attenuatus. (20)
Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <10-100%
depending on host>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed, or
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (39) Spreads in Brazil, or
Canada, or the former Czechoslovakia, or Denmark, or Finland, or France, or
Germany, or Greece, or Hungary, or India, or Ireland, or Italy, or Japan, or
Kenya, or the Netherlands, or Norway, or Poland, or Romania, or Sweden, or
Turkey, or the UK, or the USA, or the former USSR, or the former Yugoslavia.
(40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in Japan. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Beta vulgaris, Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa necrotic
local lesions, systemic chlorotic mottling, necrosis. Cucumis sativus necrotic
local lesions, systemic mottling, necrosis. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local
lesions, systemic chlorotic mottling, necrosis, malformation. Lycopersicon
esculentum necrotic local lesions, systemic necrotic spotting, streaking,
mottling and malformation. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local lesions,
systemic necrotic streaking, mottling and stunting. N. rustica, N. tabacum cvs
White Burley, Xanthi-nc necrotic and chlorotic local lesions, systemic
necrotic spotting and streaking, mottling. Petunia × hybrida chlorotic local
lesions, systemic veinal necrosis or chlorosis. (45) Cucumis sativus,
Nicotiana clevelandii, N. tabacum. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Nicotiana tabacum. (47) Allium porrum, or Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Antirrhinum majus, or Apium graveolens, or Atriplex hortensis,
or Bellis perennis, or Beta vulgaris, or Calendula officinalis, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Celosia argentea, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo <var. medullosa>, or Datura
stramonium, or Daucus carota, or Emilia sagittata, or Fagopyrum esculentum, or
Fraxinus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Lactuca sativa, or Lens culinaris, or Lobelia erinus, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Matthiola incana, or Myosotis sylvatica, or
Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Phytolacca
americana, or Pisum sativum, or Robinia pseudoacacia, or Rubus, or Salvia
splendens, or Senecio vulgaris, or Solanum tuberosum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Stellaria media, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Tulipa, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vitis, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Ageratum
conyzoides, or Avena sativa, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Capsicum frutescens, or Cheiranthus cheiri,
or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chloris gayana, or
Chrysanthemum morifolium, or Dahlia pinnata, or Dianthus barbatus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus
albus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Pastinaca sativa, or Petroselinum crispum,
or Petunia × hybrida, or Trifolium pratense. (50) Alliaceae <1/1>, or
Amaranthaceae <4/4>, or Amaryllidaceae <1/1>, or Boraginaceae <1/1>, or
Campanulaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or
Compositae <8/11>, or Cruciferae <2/5>, or Cucurbitaceae <3 /3>, or Labiatae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <8/12>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or Oleaceae
<1/1>, or Phytolaccaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <11 /14>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or
Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <3/5>, or Vitidaceae <1/1>. (51)
Caryophyllaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/7>, or Compositae <3/11>, or
Cruciferae <3/5>, or Gramineae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/12>, or
Solanaceae <4/14>, or Umbelliferae <2/5>. (53) Schmelzer (1963); Hollings
(1965); Thornberry (1966). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 14-21 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Mayo et al. (1979).
(61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in
diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 121 S <B>. (79)
Density 1.5 g cm3 in CsCl <B>, or 1.44 g cm3 in CsCl <M>, or 1.285 g cm3 in
CsCl <T>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.78 <B>, or 1.62 <M>. (84) Virions contain 44
% nucleic acid <B>, or 32 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 56 % protein <B>, or 68 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90)
Linear. (91) Total genome size 13 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part <the larger> 8.2 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.8 kb. (106)
5' terminus of RNA has a VPg. (108) Infectivity lost when deproteinised with
proteases. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (110) Poly A region present. (111) Poly A region at 3' end and 100
adjacent nucleotides of RNA2. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Harrison
(unpublished). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12275. (118) Sequence database accession

Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all

in cytoplasm and in cell vacuoles. (173) Virions found in tubules extending
through plasmodesmata, which is possibly a sign of degenerating nuclei. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Vesicles. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes:
virions in single files and tubules which are surrounded by a single membrane.

Tomato bushy stunt tombusvirus

      (1) G.P. Martelli, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: TBSV. (4) Strains: type,
BS-3 and others. (5) ICTV decimal code 74.0.1.0.014. (8) First reported in
Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From England. (10) By Smith, 1935. (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Lycopersicon esculentum bushy growth, fewer smaller fruits with
chlorotic blotching, rings and line pattern. Capsicum annuum stunting,
mottling, deformation of the leaves, no fruit. Solanum melongena stunting,
leaf mottling and crinkling; few spotted and deformed fruit. Tulipa spp. leaf
and petal necrosis. Tolmiea menziesii stunting and leaf mottling. Malus spp.,
Pyrus spp. no symptoms. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus
transmitted by seed <at a low rate>. (35) Virus <possibly> transmitted by
pollen to the seed. (36) Studies reported by Cherif and Spire (1983); Kegler
and Kegler (1981); Tomlinson and Faithfull (1984). (39) Spreads in Argentina,
Morocco, Tunisia, the UK, and the USA <in California>. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in Portugal, France, Italy, Germany and Canada. (41) Many
(>9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
systemic mosaics and mottles. (43) Gomphrena globosa necrotic reddish local
lesions, some isolates infect systemically. Ocimum basilicum necrotic black
local lesions with lighter centre; not systemic. Chenopodium amaranticolor
whitish necrotic dots with chlorotic haloes; rarely systemic. Chenopodium
quinoa chlorotic local lesions; rarely systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii
chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; systemic mottle and necrosis. Nicotiana
glutinosa brown necrotic local lesions. (45) Datura stramonium, Nicotiana
clevelandii, Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa.
(46) Gomphrena globosa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana glutinosa
(L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Datura stramonium (W). (47) Antirrhinum majus,
or Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Celosia argentea, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Gypsophila elegans, or Hyoscyamus niger, or Lavatera trimestris, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Malus, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana, or Pyrus, or
Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Tolmiea menziesii, or Tulipa, or
Vicia faba, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (48)
Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Caryophyllaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>,
or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Liliaceae <1/1>, or
Malvaceae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <2 /2>, or Saxifragaceae <1/1>, or
Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <17/18>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Solanaceae <1/18>. (52) Most hosts are only infected locally. (53) Schmelzer
(1958); Cherif and Spire (1983). (54) TIP: 80-90 °C. (55) LIV: 130-150 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus <often above> 6. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions.
(60) Method: Gallitelli et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
130 S. (79) Density 1.35 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.1. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.64. (84) Virions contain 17 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83
% protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91)

genome part 4.7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gallitelli et al.

Tombusviridae <the type species>. (180) : Tombusviridae. (181) Virus(es) with

curl and petunia asteroid mosaic viruses are closely related; Moroccan pepper
virus is distantly related; eggplant mottled crinkle, carnation Italian
ringspot, Lato River and Neckar River viruses are very distantly related.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cymbidium ringspot,
cucumber necrosis and grapevine Algerian latent viruses. (184) Sequences
homologous with those of other species of genus (especially in certain ORFs).
The coat protein gene is, unusually, located upstream of a 3' terminal ORF
coding for a non-virion protein. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: mechanically
inoculated plants of Gomphrena globosa produce characteristic local lesions
within 2436 hours and those of Ocimum basilicum in less than a week. (187)

Tomato golden mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) K.W. Buck, 1987. (2) Synonyms: virus do mosaico dourado do
tomateiro, possibly tomato yellow mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: TGMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.038. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon
esculentum. (9) From Brazil. (10) By Costa et al. (1975). (13) Lycopersicon
esculentum stunting and severely deformed young leaves and shoots; bright
yellow mosaic. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (36) Studies reported by Costa et al. (1976). (39) Spreads in
Brazil. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana faint chlorotic systemic mottling then
golden yellow mosaic, curling and malformation. Datura stramonium yellow local
lesions, then a systemic golden yellow mosaic especially around veins. (44)
Virus only known to infect Solanaceae; few other species tested. (45)
Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc. (47) Datura
stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum pennellii.
(48) Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum nigrum, or Solanum tuberosum. (50)
Solanaceae <10/12>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<2/12>. (52) Species listed as insusceptible have been tested by mechanical
inoculation or grafting; infection by whitefly has not been tested. (53) Costa
et al. (1975); Costa (1976); Hamilton et al. (1981); Matyis et al. (1975).
(58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Stein et al. (1983). (61)
Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (81) Density 1.34 in
Cs2SO4; (unstable in CsCl). (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 5.1 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93)
Largest (or only) genome part <the larger> 2.59 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.51
kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hamilton et al. (1981). (100) Base
composition 23.4 % G <DNA A>, or 21.5 % G <DNA B>. (101) Base composition 26 %
A <DNA A>, or 29 % A <DNA B>. (102) Base composition 19.8 % C <DNA A>, or 18.7
% C <DNA B>. (104) Base composition 30.8 % T <DNA A>, or 30.8 % T <DNA B>.
(108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (110) Poly A
region absent. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Hamilton et al. (1984).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 10831. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): K02029

Gb(84)_vi:GETGMVS1 Tomato golden mosaic virus subgenomic DNA derived from DNA
B cccds = covalently closed circul 9 sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
found in the virions. (121) Is of an unusual type of structure. (122)
Nongenomic nucleic acid subgenomic DNA; single stranded DNA circles, formed by
specific deletions in DNA B (Macdowell et al., 1986). (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 28500. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Stein
(1985). (146) Amino acid sequence: Stein (1985) and Hamilton et al. (1984).

helper virus <DNA A will replicate alone and form virions in petunia plants
transformed with dimers of DNA A using a Ti plasmid vector without causing

phloem. (172) Virions found in nuclei. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae.
(180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
African cassava mosaic, bean golden mosaic, euphorbia mosaic and squash leaf
curl viruses, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: wheat dwarf, chloris striate mosaic, maize streak and tobacco yellow
dwarf viruses. (184) Does not form pseudo-recombinants with African cassava
mosaic virus. No host shared with bean golden mosaic virus. The DNAs of tomato
golden mosaic and euphorbia mosaic viruses will hybridize. Nucleotide sequence
of DNA A related to those of wheat dwarf, maize streak and beet curly top
viruses (Macdowell et al., 1985; Mullineaux et al., 1985; Stanley et al.,
1986). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: monoclonal antibodies may be useful for
diagnosis, see Thomas et al. (1986). (187) Bisaro, O.M., Hamilton, W.D.O.,
Coutts, R.H.A. and Buck, K.W. (1982). Nucl. Acids Res. 10: 4913. Buck, K.W.
and Coutts, R.H.A. (1985). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 303, 6 pp. Costa,

Tomato infectious chlorosis (?) closterovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (5) ICTV decimal code 17.0.1.T.DE.6. (8) First

and severe yield loss. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (23) Transmitted by Trialeurodes vaporariorum (but not Bemisia spp.).
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in
<possibly> Italy and the USA. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43)
Lycopersicon esculentum interveinal yellowing, necrosis and stunting. (47)
Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Compositae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (60)
Method: Duffus (1995). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 850-900 nm.
(71) Virions 12 nm wide. (179) <Possible> Closterovirus. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: Beet pseudo yellows, lettuce infectious
yellows and cucurbit yellow stunt (?) closteroviruses. (187) Dellavalle, G.,

Tomato mild mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.D.15. (8) First reported
in Datura stramonium, Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum nigrum. (9) From Yemen
Republic. (10) By Walkey et al. (1994). (12) Symptoms Datura stramonium,
Lycopersicon esculentum, Solanum nigrum faint leaf mottling and plant
stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(38) Spreads in the Middle East. (39) Spreads in Yemen. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum cv. White
Burley necrotic local lesions, systemic veinal chlorosis. Nicotiana tabacum
cv. Xanthi chlorotic local lesions, systemic mottling. Datura metel, Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. occidentalis systemic veinal chlorosis or necrosis.
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana rustica systemic mottling. (44) Capsicum
annuum, C. frutescens, Chenopodium quinoa, Cucumis sativus, Petunia × hybrida,
Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana glutinosa. (46) Lycopersicon esculentum
(W), Nicotiana glutinosa (W). (47) Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Solanum nigrum. (48) Capsicum annuum, or Capsicum
frutescens, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Petunia × hybrida,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Sonchus oleraceus. (50) Solanaceae <10/13>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/13>. (54) TIP: 70-75 °C.
(55) LIV: 8-16 days <at 2oC and 18oC>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (61) Virions
filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 719 nm. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 41500.
(134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present
in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) <Possible> unassigned
potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: Chilli veinal mottle, datura shoestring, pepper mottle, pepper veinal
mottle, potato Y and tobacco etch potyviruses. (187) Walkey, D.G.A., Spence,
N.J., Clay, C.M. and Miller, A. (1994). Pl. Path. 43: 931.


Tomato mosaic tobamovirus

      (1) H. Huttinga and A.Th.B. Rast, 1985. (3) Standard acronym: ToMV. (4)
Strains: tomato aucuba mosaic, tomato enation mottle, dahlemense and other
strains (Hollings and Huttinga, 1976). (5) ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.013. (8)
First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From Connecticut, U.S.A. (10)
By Clinton (1909). (13) Lycopersicon esculentum mosaic with leaf narrowing in
winter. (14) Transmitted by means not involving a vector. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <up to 94% in tomato. The virus is found on the outside of the seed,
sometimes in the endosperm, but not in the embryo; infection occurs during
transplanting>. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Solanum giganteum systemic leaf mosaic. Nicotiana tabacum
cv. White Burley (necrosis line or Dutch A) local lesions; not systemic.
Nicotiana rustica, Petunia × hybrida local lesions; not systemic. (44) Cucumis
sativus, Cyphomandra betacea (tree tomato), Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Nicotiana
tabacum cv. Samsun, Lycopersicon esculentum. (46) Nicotiana glutinosa (L), N.
tabacum cvs Xanthi-nc and Samsun NN (L), N. clevelandii (W). (47) Capsicum
annuum, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or
Physalis peruviana, or Solanum giganteum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
nigrum. (48) Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Cyphomandra betacea, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna
unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae
<17/18>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or
Solanaceae <1/18>. (54) TIP: 85-90 °C. (55) LIV: 500 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5-7. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl
ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Gooding and Hebert
(1967). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300
nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 4 nm
in diameter. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.3 nm. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 190 S. (79) Density 1.33 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH
4.5-4.64 <depending on strain>. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85)
Virions 95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA.
(89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 6.384 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.384 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Mandeles and Bruening (1968). (100) Base composition 23 % G.
(101) Base composition 28 % A. (102) Base composition 19 % C. (103) Base
composition 30 % U. (108) Infectivity decreased when deproteinised with
proteases <due to action of RNases at the site of infection>. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12253.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): Em_vi:TOTMV7 strain L. 5'-terminal
region, 278bp; Em_vi:TOTMV8 strain L genome, 6,384bp. (132) Virion protein(s)
one. (133) Mr 17600. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation:
Fraenkel-Conrat (1957). (146) Amino acid sequence: Wittmann-Liebold and
Wittmann (1967). (164) Genome replicates <probably> in cytoplasm. (165) Coat
protein mRNA translated in the cytoplasm, probably. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and amorphous Xbodies. (177)
They contain virions. (179) Tobamovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: other tobamoviruses (Van Regenmortel, 1975). (187) Broadbent,
L. (1976). Ann. Rev. Phytopath. 14: 75. Brunt, A.A. (1986). in The Plant
Viruses; Vol.2, The Rod-Shaped Viruses, p.181; eds Van Regenmortel, M.H.V. and

156, 6 pp. Mandeles, S. and Bruening, G. (1968). Biochem. Prep. 12: 111.
Mosch, W.H.M., Huttinga, H. and Rast, A.Th.B. (1977). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 79:
104. Ohno, T., Aoyagi, M., Yamanashi, Y., Saito, H., Ikawa, S., Neshi, T. and

Tomato mottle bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: ToMoV (TMoV). (5) ICTV
decimal code 29.0.3.0.041. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9)
From Florida, U.S.A. (10) By J.K. Brown (in Polston et al., 1993). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Lycopersicon esculentum chlorotic mottling of younger
leaves, curling and chlorosis of older leaves; plants stunted, especially
those infected when young. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by
an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by
Aleyrodidae. (22) Principal natural vector(s): B. tabaci biotype B. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus <Kring et al. (1991)>. (38)
Spreads in the North American region. (39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, Nicotiana
benthamiana systemic mottling and leaf curling; plants stunted. Lycopersicon
hirsutum, L. peruvianum systemic yellow mosaic. Physalis ixocarpa systemic
yellow mosaic, leaf curling; plants stunted. Phaseolus vulgaris symptomless
systemic infection. (44) Brassica oleracea, Capsicum annuum, Cucurbita pepo,
Datura stramonium. (45) Lycopersicon esculentum. (46) Lycopersicon esculentum
(W). (47) Lycopersicon chilense, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon
hirsutum, or Lycopersicon peruvianum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or

Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis ixocarpa. (48) Arachis
hypogaea, or Brassica oleracea, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or

Gossypium hirsutum, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Medicago sativa, or

18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions <dimers> 30 nm in length. (88) Genome consists
of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome of two parts. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10835. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L02618 Em(40)_vi:GETMWBR1

indicate that the virus is distinct from other New World geminiviruses. (187)
Abouzid, A., Polston, J.E. and Hiebert, E. (1992). J. gen. Virol. 73: 3225.
Kring, J.B., Shuster, D.J., Price, J.F. and Simone, G.W. (1991). Plant Dis.
75: 1186. Polston, J.E., Hiebert, E., McGovern, R.J., Stansly, P.A. and
Schuster, D.J. (1993). Plant Dis. 77: 1181. Simone, G.W., Brown, J.K.,
Hiebert, E. and Cullen, R.E. (1990). Phytopathology 80: 1063.


Tomato Peru potyvirus

      (1) E.N. Fernandez-Northcote, 1985. (2) Synonyms: Peru tomato mosaic
virus, Peru tomato virus, Peruvian tomato virus, virus Peruano del tomate. (3)
Standard acronym: PTV. (4) Strains: M; N; Oc; Om; Os. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.053. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From
Trujillo, Peru. (10) By Raymer et al. (1972). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Capsicum annuum, C. baccatum var. pendulum, C. chinense, Physalis peruviana
mosaic, green vein banding. Lycopersicon esculentum vein clearing, twisting,
mosaic, stem and leaf necrosis by some strains, fruit mottling. Solanum
nigrum, Nicandra physalodes leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Peru. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic
local lesions; not systemic. Lycopersicon esculentum systemic leaf chlorosis
and/or necrosis, epinasty, apical necrosis and stunting. Nicotiana
occidentalis systemic chlorotic blotching and leaf malformation. Nicotiana
debneyi systemic chlorotic rings and spots. N. glutinosa systemic mosaic. (44)
Gomphrena globosa, Capsicum annuum cv. Agronomico 8, Datura stramonium,
Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum cv. A6, S. tuberosum cv. Katahdin. (45)
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. occidentalis, N. tabacum cvs
Burley 21, White Burley. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana
occidentalis (W), N. tabacum cv. Burley 21 (W). (47) Capsicum annuum, or
Capsicum baccatum var. pendulum, or Capsicum chinense, or Capsicum frutescens,
or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura metel, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra
physalodes, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana,
or Solanum nigrum. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta patellaris, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Capsicum annuum <cv.
Agronomico 8>, or Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium,
or Dianthus barbatus, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium
hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Momordica balsamina, or
Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum
sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Ricinus communis, or Sesamum indicum, or
Sesbania exaltata, or Solanum demissum × S. tuberosum <cv. A6>, or Solanum
tuberosum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vicia faba, or
Vigna angularis, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans.
(50) Chenopodiaceae <2/5>, or Solanaceae <21/24>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or
Compositae <4/4>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <6/6>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1
/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <13/13>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Pedaliaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <4/24>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Fernandez-Northcote
(1978); Fribourg (1979); Fernandez-Northcote and Fulton (1980). (54) TIP:
55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 10-21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Fernandez-Northcote and Fulton (1980). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 741-746 nm.
(71) Virions 11-13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (84) Virions
contain 7 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 93 % protein. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177)
They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) :
Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: potato Y,
pepper mottle, tobacco etch and bidens mottle viruses. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: bean yellow mosaic, lettuce mosaic, pepper
veinal mottle, pepper severe mosaic, potato A, tobacco vein mottling, turnip
mosaic and wild potato mosaic viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: check
for pinwheel inclusions to differentiate from tobacco mosaic virus. (187)
Christie, R.G. (1967). Virology 31: 268. Raymer, W.B., Kahn, R.P., Hikida,
H.R. and Waterworth, H.E. (1972). Phytopathology 62: 784. Fernandez-Northcote,

Tomato pseudo curly top (?) hybrigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: TPCTV. (5) ICTV decimal code
29.0.2.T.003. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By Giddings et al. (1951). (13) Lycopersicon esculentum chlorosis
(especially at leaf edges), vein-clearing, leaf curling and cupping and shoot
proliferation. Plants often severely stunted and set few fruit. Ambrosia sp.,
Solanum nigrum vein-clearing and leaf rolling. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Micrutalis malleifera. (18)
Transmitted by Membracidae. (24) Not transmitted by Acutalis sp., Micrutalis
clava, Spissistilus festinus. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Tsai and Brown (1991). (39) Spreads in the USA <Florida>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Ambrosia sp., Datura stramonium,
Lactuca sativa, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. ×
edwardsonii, Solanum melongena, Solanum nigrum systemic vein-clearing,
chlorosis, leaf rolling or cupping and plant stunting. (44) Beta vulgaris,
Capsicum annuum, Cucumis sativus, Nicotiana tabacum, Solanum melongena. (45)
Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana × edwardsonii, Solanum nigrum. (46)
Lycopersicon esculentum (W), Solanum nigrum (W). (47) Ambrosia, or Datura
stramonium, or Lactuca sativa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana × edwardsonii, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
nigrum. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Chenopodium ambrosioides, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Solanum melongena, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Compositae
<2/3>, or Solanaceae <6/10>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>,
or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <1/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <5/10>. (53) Simons (1962a).
(61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are viroplasms and unusual in shape. (176) Fibrillar rings in
nuclei. (177) They contain virions. (179) <Possible> hybrigeminivirus:
Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: beet curly top hybrigeminivirus. (184) Reported to have
virions that are serologically related to those of beet curly top
hybrigeminivirus, however this virus is transmitted by the treehopper
Micrutalis malleifera (Hemiptera: Membracidae) and fails to infect Beta
vulgaris, whereas beet curly top hybrigeminivirus is transmitted by the
leafhopper Circulifer tenellus (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae). (187) Bennett, C.W.
(1971). Am. Phytopathol. Soc. Monog. 7, 81 pp. Christie, R.G., Ko, N.-J.,
Flak, B.W., Hiebert, E., Lastra, R., Bird, J. and Kim, K.S. (1986).
Phytopathology 76: 124. Giddings, N.J., Bennett, C.W. and Harrison, A.L.
(1951). Phytopathology 41: 415. McDaniel, L.L. and Tsai, J.H. (1990). Plant
Dis. 74: 17. Simons, J.N. (1962a). J. econ. Ent. 55: 358. Simons, J.N.
(1962b). J. econ. Ent. 55: 363. Simons, J.N. and Coe, D.M. (1958). Virology 6:
43. Tsai, J.H. and Brown, L.G. (1991). Fla Dep. Agric. and Consumer Serv.,
Plant Path. Circ. No. 344, 2 pp. Zitter, T.A. and Tsai, J.H. (1981). Plant
Dis. 65: 787.


Tomato ringspot nepovirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1981. Revised 1987. (2) Synonyms: blackberry
Himalaya mosaic virus, euonymus ringspot virus (Puffinberger and Corbett,
1985), grape yellow vein virus, grapevine yellow vein virus (Gooding et al.,
1967), peach yellow bud mosaic virus (Cadman and Lister, 1961; Thomas and
Rawlins, 1950), prune brown line virus, prunus stem-pitting virus, red currant
mosaic virus (Hildebrand, 1942), tobacco ringspot virus 2, winter peach mosaic
virus. (3) Standard acronym: ToRSV. (4) Strains: tobacco strain, grape yellow
vein strain, apple union necrosis nepovirus, euonymus chlorotic ringspot
virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 18.0.3.0.029. (8) First reported in Nicotiana
tabacum. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Price (1936). (11) Symptoms disappear
soon after infection. (13) Pelargonium spp., Rubus spp. and a very wide range
of other species mosaic or ringspot. Prunus spp. rasp leaf, yellow bud or
yellow vein. Nicotiana tabacum ringspots and chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by a nematode. (17) Transmitted by Xiphinema
americanum (sensu lato). (20) Transmitted by Dorylamidae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <of Rubus idaeus, Nicotiana tabacum, Glycine
max, Fragaria × ananassa>. (35) Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed, or
transmitted by pollen to the pollinated plant. (36) Studies reported by
Stace-Smith and Ramsdell (1987). (38) Spreads in the North American region.
(39) Spreads in Australia, or Bulgaria, or Canada, or Chile, or China, or
Cyprus, or Germany, or Italy, or Japan, or Korea Republic, or New Zealand, or
Peru, or Puerto Rico, or Turkey, or the USA, or the former USSR, or the former
Yugoslavia. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
amaranticolor and C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions, systemic apical necrosis.
Cucumis sativus necrotic or chlorotic local lesions; systemic mottle.
Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic local lesions; systemic rugosity, tip necrosis.
Vigna unguiculata necrotic or chlorotic local lesions; systemic tip necrosis.
Lycopersicon esculentum necrotic flecking; systemic mottle, necrosis.
Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic local lesions; systemic chlorosis, necrosis. N.
tabacum necrotic local lesions or ringspot markings; systemic ring or line
patterns. Petunia × hybrida necrotic local lesions; tip necrosis. (45) Cucumis
sativus, Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana tabacum, Petunia × hybrida. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L), Vigna unguiculata (L), Nicotiana
clevelandii (L), N. tabacum (L). (47) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium
graveolens, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium foetidum, or
Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Fragaria chiloensis, or
Fragaria vesca, or Fragaria virginiana, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Malus
sylvestris, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Pelargonium, or Petunia × hybrida, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Prunus persica, or Rubus idaeus, or Rubus occidentalis,
or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or Stellaria media, or Trifolium
hybridum, or Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vigna unguiculata.
(48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Catharanthus roseus, or Daucus carota, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Tropaeolum majus, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or
Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <7/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Geraniaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Rosaceae <7/7>, or
Solanaceae <17/19>, or Umbelliferae <1 /2>. (51) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Compositae <1/1>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/19>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/2>. (52) In nature, the
virus occurs mainly in ornamentals and woody or semi-woody plants. (53)
Stace-Smith (1962); Thornberry (1966); Najarian et al. (1980). (54) TIP: 58
°C. (55) LIV: 21 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains many
virions. (60) Method: Stace-Smith (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 25 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 127 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 119 S <M>, or 53
S <T>. (79) Density 1.49 and 1.5 g cm3 in CsCl. (82) Isoelectric point pH 5.1.
(83) A260/A280 ratio 1.8 <M and B>, or 0.9 <T>. (84) Virions contain 44 %
nucleic acid <B>, or 41 % nucleic acid <M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85)
Virions 56 % protein <B>, or 59 % protein <M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (86)
Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 15.8 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 8.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 7.3 kb. (100) Base
composition 26 % G. (101) Base composition 23 % A. (102) Base composition 22 %
C. (103) Base composition 29 % U. (109) Infectivity retained when
deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (116) Nucleotide sequence references:
RNA 2 has been sequenced (Rott et al., 1991). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12280.
(118) Sequence database accession code(s): D12477 Em(40)_vi:TOSRNA2
