Gb(84)_vi:TOSNC1 Tomato ringspot virus genomic RNA-1 3' non-coding region.
2/90 1,546bp. M73822 Em(40)_vi:TOSRNA1A Gb(84)_vi:TOSRNA1A Tomato ringspot
virus RNA1 gene, 5' end. 12/91 1,140bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
58000. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of preparation: Allen et al. (1977).
(171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (173)
Virions found in plasmodesmata. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells.
(175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Large vacuoles in the cytoplasm
(Smith and McWhorter, 1957) or crystals consisting of nucleoprotein
(Gordejchuk et al., 1977). (178) Other cellular changes: general tissue
disintegration in florets of Pelargonium × hortorum. (179) Nepovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: cherry leaf roll virus, and many other members of the nepovirus
group. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: serological tests are the only reliable
ones because symptoms resemble those caused by other nepoviruses. (187) Allen,
W.R. and Dias, H.F. (1977). Can. J. Bot. 55: 1028. Cadman, C.H. and Lister,
R.M. (1961). Phytopathology 51: 29. Capoor, S.P. (1952). Indian J. agric. Sci.
22: 274. Forer, L.B. and Stouffer, R.F. (1982). Plant Dis. 66: 735. Gooding,
G.V., Hewitt, W.B. and Cory, L. (1967). Phytopathology 57: 236. Gordejchuk,

Hoy, J.W., Mircetich, S.M. and Lownsbery, B.F. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 332.
Mayo, M.A., Barker, H. and Harrison, B.D. (1982). J. gen Virol. 59: 149.

Tomato spotted wilt tospovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1983. Revised 1985; 1990. (2) Synonyms: dahlia oakleaf
virus, dahlia ringspot virus, dahlia yellow ringspot virus (Brunt, 1959),
groundnut ringspot virus (Klesser, 1966), mung bean leaf curl virus, pineapple
yellow spot virus, watermelon silver mottle virus. (3) Standard acronym: TSWV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 11.0.5.0.003. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon
esculentum. (10) By Brittlebank (1919); Samuel et al. (1930). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Ananas comosus, Bidens pilosa, Capsicum annuum, Datura
stramonium, Helianthus annuus, Ipomoea congesta, Lactuca sativa, Malva
parviflora, Nicandra physalodes, Phaseolus vulgaris, Physalis peruviana,
Zinnia elegans, Arachis hypogaea, Canavalia gladiata, C. obtusifolia, C.
occidentalis, Crotalaria juncea, Desmodium triflorum, Glycine max, Pisum
sativum, Tephrosia purpurea, Vicia faba, Vigna mungo, V. radiata, V.
unguiculata, Lycopersicon esculentum, Nicotiana tabacum, Solanum melongena, S.
capsicastrum, S. tuberosum and many other species necrotic and chlorotic local
lesions, systemic wilting, necrosis, spotting, streaking, mosaic, mottling,
leaf shape malformation, vein yellowing, ringspots, line patterns, yellow
netting and flower colour-breaking. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Thrips tabaci, T. setosus, T.
parmi, Frankliniella schultzei, F. occidentalis, F. fusca and Scirtothrips
dorsalis. (18) Transmitted by Thysanoptera. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus multiplies in
the vector <probably>. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Cho et al. (1989). (37) Probably distributed worldwide.
(39) Spreads in Afghanistan, or Algeria, or Argentina, or Australia, or
Austria, or Belgium, or Bolivia, or Brazil, or Bulgaria, or Canada, or Chile,
or China, or Cote d'Ivoire, or Cyprus, or the former Czechoslovakia, or Egypt,
or France, or Germany, or Greece, or Guyana, or Haiti, or India, or Ireland,
or Israel, or Italy, or Jamaica, or Japan, or Libya, or Madagascar, or
Malaysia, or Malta, or Mauritius, or Mexico, or Nepal, or the Netherlands, or
New Zealand, or Niger, or Nigeria, or Pakistan, or Papua New Guinea, or
Paraguay, or Poland, or Portugal, or Puerto Rico, or Reunion, or Romania, or
Senegal, or South Africa, or Spain, or Sri Lanka, or Suriname, or Sweden, or
Switzerland, or Taiwan, or Tanzania, or Thailand, or Turkey, or the UK, or the
USA, or the former USSR, or Uganda, or Uruguay, or the former Yugoslavia, or
Zaire, or Zimbabwe. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Catharanthus
roseus local black spots, leaves sometimes becoming yellow and abscissing;
systemic mosaic and leaf deformation. Cucumis sativus chlorotic spots with
necrotic centres in cotyledons; not systemic. Petunia × hybrida cvs Pink
Beauty, Minstrel necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii,
N. glutinosa, N. tabacum necrotic local lesions; systemic necrotic patterns
and leaf deformation. Tropaeolum majus symptomless local infection; systemic
necrotic spotting and streaking. (45) Gomphrena globosa, Nicotiana glutinosa,
N. rustica, Tropaeolum majus. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (L), Petunia ×
hybrida cvs Pink Beauty, Minstrel (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus
retroflexus, or Ananas comosus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Belamcanda chinensis,
or Bidens pilosa, or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Calendula
officinalis, or Canavalia gladiata, or Canavalia obtusifolia, or Canavalia
occidentalis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia
occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Catharanthus roseus, or Cheiranthus cheiri,
or Cichorium endiva, or Crotalaria juncea, or Cucumis sativus, or Dahlia
pinnata, or Datura stramonium, or Desmodium triflorum, or Glycine max, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Hippeastrum hybridum, or

Features of the genome: sRNA is an ambisense RNA with two terminal ORFs that
are expressed via subgenomic mRNAs. that in the genomic strand is of 52.4K and
in the complementary strand of 28.8K (the nucleocapsid protein). sRNA has long
terminal untranslated regions that are of inverted complementary to each
other, and also an intergenic stable hairpin structure. Preliminary data of
the mRNA indicates it is all negative strand. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in
infected cells <2 mRNAs for sRNA>. (132) Virion protein(s) four. (133) Mr <of
the largest> 120000. (134) L protein. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 78000. (136) G1
membrane glycoprotein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 58000. (138) G2 membrane
glycoprotein. (139) Mr of 4th largest 27000. (140) N protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Mohamed et al. (1973); Tas et al. (1977). (146) Amino acid
sequence: Haan et al. (1990). (148) Virion proteins glycosylated <G1 and G2>.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape.
(176) Clusters of virions in the cell vacuole, which possibly bud from the
cisternae of endoplasmic reticulum. (179) Tospovirus: Bunyaviridae. (180) :
Bunyaviridae. (184) The structure of the genome resembles that of
arthropod-borne phleboviruses (Bunyaviridae), but their sequences are not
significantly similar A tomato spotted wilt like virus first found in
Impatiens species, and then considered to be a strain of the virus, is now
called Impatiens necrotic spot virus, and is recognised as a distinct member
of the tospovirus group; (de Avila et al., 1992). (187) Best, R.J. (1968).
Adv. Virus Res. 13: 65. Brittlebank, C.C. (1919). J. Agric. Victoria, Aust.
17: 213. Brunt, A.A. (1959). Nature, Lond. 183: 627. Cho, J.J., Mau, R.F.L.,
German, T.L., Hartmann, R.W., Yurdin, L.S., Gonsalves, D. and Provvidenti, R.

Tomato top necrosis (?) nepovirus

      (1) R. Stace-Smith, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: ToTNV. (5) ICTV decimal
code 18.0.3.T.008. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From
Indianna, Missouri and Illinois, U.S.A. (10) By Imle and Samson (1942). (11)
Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Lycopersicon esculentum rings
and lines on young leaves; stripes on the stem; concentric rings on the fruit.
(39) Spreads in the USA. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium
quinoa local lesions and systemic necrosis. C. murale local lesions only.
Nicotiana tabacum mild ring and line patterns. N. affinis numerous faint small
rings. Datura stramonium indefinite rings and lines. (44) Tetragonia
tetragonioides, Beta vulgaris, Zinnia elegans, Brassica campestris ssp. rapa,
Cucumis sativus. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Chenopodium
quinoa (L), Nicotiana tabacum (L), Lycopersicon esculentum (W). (47)
Amaranthus retroflexus, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Datura stramonium, or Datura tatula, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or
Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana affinis,
or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum
tuberosum. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica
oleracea var. capitata, or Chenopodium album, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata, or Nicotiana glutinosa,
or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Zinnia elegans. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Solanaceae <10/12>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <2/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <2/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Imle
and Samson (1942). (54) TIP: 58 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus
<1:500>. (60) Method: Bancroft (1968). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 26 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in
profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Three
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient <of the fastest> 126 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 52 S <T>, or 102
S <M>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.71 <M>, or 1.82 <B>. (179) <Possible> Nepovirus:
Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: arabis mosaic, raspberry ringspot, strawberry latent ringspot,
tobacco ringspot, tomato black ring and tomato ringspot viruses. (186) This
virus was isolated and studied in the 1960's. Stace-Smith obtained an isolate
from Purdue University, where it was last studied. However, the culture was
not infective, and no other source is known. (187) Bancroft, J.B. (1968).
Phytopathology 32: 1037. Harrison, B.D. and Murant A.F. (1977). CMI/AAB Descr.
Pl. Viruses No. 185, 4 pp. Imle, E.P. and Samson, R.W. (1942). Phytopathology
58: 1360. .


Tomato vein clearing nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) S. Yamashita, 1987. (2) Synonyms: tomato vein yellowing virus,
possibly eggplant mottled dwarf rhabdovirus. (3) Standard acronym: TVYV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 62.0.5.0.003. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum.
(9) From Tokyo, Japan. (10) By Kano et al. (1981a). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Lycopersicon esculentum vein-clearing and vein-yellowing, mottling, leaf
crinkle and dwarfing. (14) Transmitted by a vector <probably>. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Kano et al. (1981a); Kano et al. (1981b);
Kano et al. (1985). (39) Spreads in Japan. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Lycopersicon esculentum systemic local lesions; vein-clearing,
vein-yellowing, leaf crinkling. Nicotiana glutinosa systemic necrotic local
lesions, vein-clearing, vein-yellowing. N. rustica local and systemic necrotic
local lesions, vein-yellowing. Petunia × hybrida local and systemic chlorotic
or systemic local lesions, vein-clearing, vein-yellowing. Datura stramonium
necrotic local lesions. Chenopodium murale, Tetragonia tetragonioides
chlorotic local lesions. (44) Solanum melongena, Chenopodium amaranticolor,
Gomphrena globosa, Lactuca sativa, Phaseolus vulgaris. (45) Lycopersicon
esculentum, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. rustica, Petunia × hybrida. (46)

W), Chenopodium murale (L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L). (47) Chenopodium
murale, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Petunia × hybrida, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or

globosa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Oryza sativa, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis
floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum tuberosum, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Triticum aestivum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata,
or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Solanaceae
<5/10>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Apocynaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <4/4>, or

or Solanaceae <5 /10>. (53) Kano et al. (1981a); Kano et al. (1981b); Kano et
al. (1985). (54) TIP: 40 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days <4°C>, or 0.5-1 days <20°C>.

Tomato yellow leaf curl bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Cohen, 1988. (2) Synonyms: tomato leaf curl virus.
(3) Standard acronym: TYLCV-Is, TYLCV-Sr, TYLCV-Th, TYLCV-Ye. (5) ICTV decimal
code 29.0.3.0.043. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9) From
Israel. (10) By Cohen and Harpaz (1964). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Lycopersicon esculentum plants stunted with small chlorotic puckered leaves;
fruit yield much decreased. Cynanchum acutum, Malva parviflora symptomless
infection. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (29) Virus does not require a
helper virus for vector transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <poorly>. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (36) Studies reported by Cohen et al.
(1988), Ioannou (1987) epidemiology of tomato yellow leaf curl virus in the
Jordan valley and in Cyprus; Sharaf (1986) control by insecticides; Al-Musa
(1982), Cohen and Melamed-Madjar (1978) control by trap plants and yellow
mulches; Pilowsky and Cohen (1974) resistant cultivars. (39) Spreads in
Cyprus, India, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Nigeria, Senegal, Sudan,
Thailand, Tunisia, and Turkey <Verma et al., 1975; Lana and Wilson, 1976>.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Lycopersicon esculentum severe
systemic leaf chlorosis and malformation. Datura stramonium interveinal leaf
chlorosis. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. benthamiana systemic vein clearing, then
downward curling of the leaf and its margins. Phaseolus vulgaris interveinal
chlorosis, downward curling of the leaves. (44) Nicotiana rustica, Physalis
floridana, Vicia faba, Gomphrena globosa, Cucumis sativus. (45) Lycopersicon
esculentum, Datura stramonium. (46) Lycopersicon esculentum (W), Datura
stramonium (W). (47) Cynanchum acutum, or Datura stramonium, or Hyoscyamus
desertorum, or Lens culinaris, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Malva nicaensis, or Malva parviflora, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Sonchus oleraceus. (48) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Althaea rosea,
or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Arachis hypogaea, or Atriplex, or Beta vulgaris,
or Calotropis aegyptia, or Capparis aegyptia, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Cucumis sativus, or Gomphrena globosa, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Hibiscus
rosa-sinensis, or Lavatera cretica, or Lonicera, or Lycium, or Medicago
sativa, or Momordica balsamina, or Nerium oleander, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Ochradenus baccatus, or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Plumbago
capensis, or Polygonum equisetiforme, or Portulaca oleracea, or Prosopis
farcta, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum incanum, or Solanum villosum, or
Tamarix, or Tribulus, or Vicia faba, or Withania somnifera, or Xanthium
strumarium, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Asclepiadaceae <1/2>, or Compositae <1/3>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/6>, or Malvaceae <2/7>, or Solanaceae <7/13>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Asclepiadaceae <1/2>, or
Capparidaceae <1/1>, or Caprifoliaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or
Compositae <2/3>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Mimosoideae <1 /1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/6>, or
Malvaceae <5/7>, or Plumbaginaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or
Portulacaceae <1/1>, or Resedaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/13>, or
Tamaricaceae <1/1>, or Zygophyllaceae <1 /1>. (60) Method: Czosnek et al.
(1988). (61) Virions geminate. (64) Virions 20 nm in diameter. (65) Virions
<dimers> 30 nm in length. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 5.5 kb. (92) Genome of
two parts. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.787 kb. (94) The 2nd largest
2.7 kb. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L12219 Em(40)_vi:GETYLREPO

and J.M. Thresh. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford. Makkouk, K.M. and
Shebab, S. (1978). Abstr. 3rd Int. Congr. Pl. Path., p. 51. Marco, S., Cohen,
S., Harpaz, I. and Birk, Y. (1975). J. Insect Physiol. 21: 1821. Russo, M.,
Cohen, S. and Martelli, G.P. (1980). J. gen. Virol. 49: 209. Sharaf, N.
(1986). Agric., Ecosystems and Environ. 17: 111. Verma, H.N., Srivastava, K.M.
and Mathur, A.K. (1975). Pl. Dis. Reptr 59: 494.


Tomato yellow mosaic bigeminivirus

      (1) R. Lastra, 1985. Revised by K.W. Buck, 1989. (2) Synonyms: virus del
mosaico dourado do tomateiro, virus del mosaico amarillo del tomate. (3)
Standard acronym: ToYMV. (4) Strains: tomato yellow leaf curl and tomato
yellow mosaic, induce similar symptoms but seem not to be related. (5) ICTV
decimal code 29.0.3.0.048. (8) First reported in Lycopersicon esculentum. (9)
From Brazil. (10) By Matys et al. (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Lycopersicon hirsutum yellow mosaic. L. esculentum yellow mosaic, stunting,
small leaves. L. pimpinellifolium, Solanum tuberosum mild yellow mosaic. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Bemisia tabaci. (18) Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner <for up to 7 days>. (26) Virus retained when the vector
moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation <poorly when inoculum is from old tissue>. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39)
Spreads in Brazil and Venezuela. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Datura stramonium, Nicotiana benthamiana systemic yellow mosaic. Nicandra
physalodes, Petunia × hybrida, Physalis peruviana systemic mild yellow mosaic.
Nicotiana glutinosa systemic yellow spots at base of first infected leaves,
then mosaic. N. tabacum cv. Samsun systemic mosaic and leaf deformation. (44)
Chenopodium quinoa, Euphorbia heterophylla, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna
unguiculata, Sida rhombifolia, Datura metel. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N.
tabacum cv. Samsun. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), N. glutinosa (W). (47)
Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Lycopersicon hirsutum, or
Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Physalis peruviana, or Solanum melongena,
or Solanum tuberosum. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica oleracea var.
botrytis, or Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo,
or Datura metel, or Euphorbia heterophylla, or Gossypium hirsutum, or Lens
culinaris, or Momordica balsamina, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Phaseolus
lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Sida
rhombifolia, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Solanaceae <13/16>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or
Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Malvaceae <2/2>,
or Solanaceae <3/16>. (52) Mainly Solanaceae infected. (53) Uzcátegui and
Lastra (1978). (54) TIP: 40-42 °C. (55) LIV: 0.01 days <15 minutes>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 1. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy:
best stained with UA. (60) Method: Lastra et al. (1981). (61) Virions
geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 18-20 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 70 S <N.B. unfixed virions disrupt in CsCl>. (84)
Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (86) Virions 0 %
lipid. (88) Genome consists of DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91)
Total genome size 5.096 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part <the larger> 2.588 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 2.508 kb <Hamilton et
al., 1984>. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Hamilton et al. (1981).
(109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (112)
Additional factor not required for infectivity. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid
not found in the virions. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 28000. (134)
Coat protein. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found
in nuclei and in nucleoli. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175)
Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Clusters of virions. (177) They contain
virions. (178) Other cellular changes: fibrillar rings in the nucleus that may
be where virions assemble, and are composed of DNA and protein. (179)
Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: African cassava mosaic and beet curly top
viruses, but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
maize streak, wheat dwarf, chloris striate mosaic and tobacco yellow dwarf
viruses. (187) Anzola, D. and Lastra, R. (1985). Phytopath. Z. 112: 363. De
Uzcátegui, R.C. and Lastra, R. (1978). Phytopathology 68: 985. Hamilton,
W.D.O., Bisaro, D.M. and Buck, K.W. (1982). Nucl. Acids Res. 10: 4901.
Hamilton, W.D.O., Saunders, R.C., Coutts, R.H.A. and Buck, K.W. (1981). FEMS
Microbiol. Lett. 11: 263. Hamilton, W.D.O., Stein, V.E., Coutts, R.H.A. and
Buck, K.W. (1984). EMBO J. 3: 2197. Lastra, R. and Anzola, D. (1978). Agron.
trop. 28: 473. Lastra, R. and Gil, F. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 524. Lastra,
R., de Uzcátegui, R.C. and Gil, F. (1981). Abstr. Vth Int. Congr. Virol.,
Strasbourg, p.206. Matys, J.C., Silva, D.M., Oliveira, A.R. and Costa, A.S.
(1975). Summa Phytopath. 1: 267. Roberts, I.M., Robinson, D.J. and Harrison,
B.D. (1984). Rep. Scottish Crop Res. Inst., 1985, p. 179.


Tradescantia-Zebrina potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: TZV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.085. (8) First reported in Tradescantia albiflora. (9) From
Minnesota, U.S.A. (10) By Lockhart et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Tradescantia spp., Commelina diffusa, Tradescantia spathacea mosaic and
malformation of leaves, stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Rhopalosiphum padi, Myzus
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the
USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Tradescantia albiflora, T.
blossfeldiana, T. fluminensis, T. navicularis, T. spathacea, T. zebrina mosaic
and malformation of leaves, stunting. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Chlorophytum
comosum, Commelina elegans, Nicotiana clevelandii. (45) Tradescantia
albiflora, T. spathacea, T. zebrina. (46) Tradescantia zebrina (W). (47)
Commelina diffusa, or Tradescantia albiflora, or Tradescantia blossfeldiana,
or Tradescantia fluminensis, or Tradescantia navicularis, or Tradescantia
spathacea, or Tradescantia zebrina. (48) Avena sativa, or Beta vulgaris, or
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Capsicum annuum, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Chlorophytum comosum, or Commelina
elegans, or Cucumis metuliferus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Helianthus annuus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lactuca
sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Secale cereale, or Triticum
aestivum, or Tulipa gesneriana, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea
mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Commelinaceae <7/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>,
or Anthericaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Commelinaceae <1/8>, or
Compositae <3/3>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae
<5/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Liliaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae
<8/8>. (53) Lockhart et al. (1981). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Lockhart et al. (1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 754 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions.
(179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: bean common mosaic, bean yellow mosaic,
bidens mottle, blackeye cowpea mosaic, commelina mosaic, dasheen mosaic, maize
dwarf mosaic, papaya ringspot, pepper mottle, potato Y, tobacco etch and
watermelon mosaic viruses. It is not known if it is related to potyviruses
reported in Commelina diffusa in Guadeloupe (Migliori and Lastra, 1978) and in
12 species of Commelinaceae in Florida, U.S.A. (Baker and Zettler, 1986).
(187) Baker, C. and Zettler, F.W. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 372. Lockhart,
B.E.L., Betzold, J.A. and Pfleger, F.L. (1981). Phytopathology 71: 602.
Migliori, A. and Lastra, R. (1978). Annls. Phytopath. 10: 467.


Trichosanthes mottle (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: TrMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.086. (8) First reported in Trichosanthes rostrata. (9) From Japan.
(10) By Yonaha et al., 1988. (13) Trichosanthes rostrata leaf mottling. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (23) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (38) Spreads in the Eastern Asian region. (39) Spreads in Japan.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Benincasa hispida, Cucumis sativus,
Cucurbita maxima × C. moschata, C. moschata, Luffa cylindrica and Momordica
charantia systemic chlorotic spotting. Citrullus lanatus, Cucumis melo,
Lagenaria leucantha and Trichosanthes anguina systemic vein clearing, vein
necrosis, mottling and/or distortion. Trichosanthes rostrata systemic
mottling. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. murale, C. quinoa, Datura
stramonium, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa. (45) Cucurbita pepo. (46)
Cucurbita pepo (W). (47) Benincasa hispida, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima × C. moschata, or Cucurbita

Cucurbitaceae <12/12>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (54)
TIP: 50 °C. (55) LIV: 5-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (60) Method: Yonaha
et al., 1988. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 750 nm. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels.
(179) <Possible> unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: papaya leaf-distortion mosaic. (182)

yellow mosaic and watermelon mosaic-2 viruses. (187) Yonaha, T., Tamori, M.,
Fujiwara, Y. and Ishimine, M. (1988). Bull. Coll. Agric. Univ. Ryukus 35:
1-15.


Tropaeolum 1 potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (2) Synonyms: isanu mosaic virus. (3) Standard
acronym: TV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.087. (8) First reported in
Tropaeolum tuberosum. (9) From material imported to U.K. from Peru. (10) By
A.A. Brunt and R.S. Phillips, unpublished information. (13) Tropaeolum
tuberosum leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii and N. megalosiphon
chlorotic local lesions; systemic leaf chlorosis. (47) Nicotiana benthamiana,
or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Tropaeolum tuberosum.
(50) Solanaceae <3/3>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (61) Virions filamentous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of <c.> 750 nm. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: 17 other potyviruses. (184) It is not yet
known if the virus is related to a potyvirus isolated from Tropaeolum
tuberosum in Bolivia (Delhey and Monasterios, 1977). (186) Tropaeolum
potyviruses 1 and 2 frequently occur as a mixture, isanu mosaic virus, in
Tropaeolum tuberosum. (187) Delhey, R. and Monasterios, T. (1977). Z.
PflKrankh. PflPath. PflSchutz. 84: 224. Mathu, R.W. (1987). M.Sc. Thesis, pp.
91, University of London, U.K.


Tropaeolum 2 potyvirus

Tropaeolum tuberosum. (9) From material imported to U.K. from Peru. (10) By

tuberosum leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an
insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted
by seed. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii and N. megalosiphon
chlorotic local lesions; systemic leaf chlorosis. Tropaeolum majus systemic
leaf chlorosis. Datura metel, Nicotiana sylvestris and Zinnia elegans
chlorotic local lesions. Nicotiana plumbaginifolia and Helianthus annuus
symptomless systemic infection. (47) Datura metel, or Helianthus annuus, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or
Nicotiana plumbaginifolia, or Nicotiana sylvestris, or Tropaeolum majus, or
Tropaeolum tuberosum, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Compositae <2/2>, or Solanaceae

clear modal length. (70) Virions of <c.> 750 nm. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
potato Y potyvirus is distantly related. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: 17 other potyviruses. (184) It is not yet known if the
virus is related to a potyvirus isolated from Tropaeolum tuberosum in Bolivia
(Delhey and Monasterios, 1977). (186) Tropaeolum potyviruses 1 and 2
frequently occur as a mixture, isanu mosaic virus, in Tropaeolum tuberosum.

84: 224. Mathu, R.W. (1987). M.Sc. Thesis, University of London, U.K., pp. 91.


Tuberose potyvirus

      (1) M.N. Pearson, 1991. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.11. (8) First
reported in Polianthes tuberosa. (9) From Pukekohe, New Zealand. (10) By
Pearson and Horner (1986). (11) Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12)
Symptoms leaf mottling. (13) Polianthes tuberosa irregular foliar mottling.
(15) Spread in infected vegetative planting material. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in New Zealand. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Polianthes tuberosa leaf mottling. (44) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Nicotiana clevelandii, N. glutinosa, Phaseolus
vulgaris. (45) Polianthes tuberosa. (47) Polianthes tuberosa. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium
quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Vicia faba, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Agavaceae <1/1>.
(51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <5/5>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Solanaceae <5/5>. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron
microscopy: negatively-stained virions from cut leaf edges, better than sap
extracts. (60) Method: Horner and Pearson (1988). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 749 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.038. (166) Replication does
not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, mesophyll and
meristems. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Stacked plates
(laminated aggregates) thought to be parts of cylindrical or pinwheel
inclusions. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions:
tulip breaking virus. (187) Horner, M.B. and Pearson, M.N. (1988). J.
Phytopath. 122: 261. Pearson, M.N. and Horner, M.B. (1986). Australas. Plant
Path. 15: 39.


Tulare apple mosaic ilarvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (3) Standard acronym: TAMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
10.0.2.02.06. (8) First reported in Malus sylvestris. (9) From the U.S.A. (10)
By Yarwood (1955). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Corylus avellana, Malus
sylvestris conspicuous leaf chlorosis. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in France and the U.S.A. (California). (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana tabacum local necrotic lines and rings;
systemic necrotic rings and oak-leaf patterns, but later formed leaves are
symptomless. Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Bountiful brown local lesions; no systemic
infection. (45) Catharanthus roseus, Nicotiana tabacum. (46) Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Bountiful (L), Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Catharanthus roseus,
or Corylus avellana, or Malus sylvestris, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Corylaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (54)
TIP: 62 °C <in sap containing reducing agent>. (55) LIV: 0.0069 days. (60)
Method: Mink and Bancroft (1962); Mink et al. (1963); Fulton (1967). (61)
Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 33 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 118 S. (78) Of
the other(s) 93 and 108 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.36. (84) Virions contain 12
% nucleic acid. (85) Virions 88 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base composition 24 % G. (101)
Base composition 24 % A. (102) Base composition 21 % C. (103) Base composition
31 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 19000. (134) Coat protein. (147)
Amino acid composition: Barnett and Fulton (1969). (179) Ilarvirus:
Bromoviridae <subgroup 2>. (180) : Bromoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: citrus leaf rugose virus. (186) The virus has
been isolated from a single apple tree (since removed) in Tulare County,
California, and later from hazel in France (Cardin and Marenaud, 1975). (187)
Barnett, O.W. and Fulton, R.W. (1969). Virology 39: 556. Cardin, L. and
Marénaud, C. (1975). Annls. Phytopath. 7: 159. Fulton, R.W. (1956).
Phytopathology 46: 694. Fulton, R.W. (1967). Virology 32: 153. Fulton, R.W.
(1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 42, 3 pp. Gilmer, R.M. (1958).
Phytopathology 48: 432. Lister, R.M. and Saksena, K.N. (1976). Virology 70:
440. Mink, G.I. (1965). Virology 26: 700. Mink, G.I. and Bancroft, J.B.
(1962). Nature, Lond. 194: 214. Mink, G.I., Bancroft, J.B. and Nadakavukaren,
M.J. (1963). Phytopathology 53: 973. Uyeda, I. and Mink, G.I. (1983).
Phytopathology 73: 47. Yarwood, C.E. (1955). Hilgardia 23: 613.

Tulip breaking potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (2) Synonyms: lily mosaic virus, lily mottle
virus, lily streak and tulip mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: TBV. (4)
Strains: severe tulip breaking virus; mild tulip breaking virus. (5) ICTV
decimal code 57.0.1.0.070. (8) First reported in Tulipa spp. (9) From Surrey,
England. (10) By Cayley (1928, 1932). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Tulipa spp.
and Darwin hybrids colour-breaking of flowers and leaf chlorosis. Lilium spp.
and Mid-Century hybrids leaf chlorosis and degeneration. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae,
Aphis gossypii, A. fabae, Macrosiphum euphorbiae, Dysaphis tulipae,
Aulocorthum circumflexum. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (29) Virus does not require a helper virus for vector
transmission. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (37)
Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43)
Lilium formosanum mottle, malformed leaves and flowers. Tulipa hybrids flower
colour- breaking. (44) Not known to infect any herbaceous indicator species.
Narcissus pseudonarcissus, Hyacinthus orientalis and Hippeastrum hybridum.
(45) Tulipa varieties Croisette, Grand Pride and Paljas. Lilium varieties
Concorde and Sterling Star. (46) None known, but Lilium formosanum (W) could
be used. (47) Calochortus, or Fritillaria pudica, or Lilium <cvs Concorde,
Sterling Star>, or Lilium formosanum, or Lilium longiflorum, or Ornithogalum
thyrsoides, or Tulipa, or Tulipa hybrids, or Zigadenus fremontii. (48) Allium
cepa, or Amaranthus retroflexus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Avena sativa, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine
max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Hippeastrum hybridum, or Hyacinthus orientalis,
or Narcissus pseudonarcissus, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Saccharum officinarum, or Secale cereale, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Torenia fournieri, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zea mays, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Calochortaceae <1/1>, or Hyacinthaceae <1/2>, or Liliaceae
<6/6>, or Melanthiaceae <1/1>. (51) Alliaceae <1/1>, or Amaranthaceae <2/2>,
or Amaryllidaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <4/4>, or Hyacinthaceae <1/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Scrophulariaceae <1 /1>, or Solanaceae
<5/5>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (52) Brierley and Smith (1944) inoculated 79
dicotyledonous species from 66 genera and 22 families with tulip breaking
virus, and back tested by inoculation to Lilium formosanum. All tests were
negative, but the species were not named, and in a further survey, 39
monocotyledous species also proved to be insusceptible. (53) Brierley and
Smith (1944). (54) TIP: 65-70 °C. (55) LIV: 4-6 days <in lily sap>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Derks et al.
(1982). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions

Taxon ID: 12229. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): S44147

the cytoplasm, or viroplasms <N.B. these differ from the X-bodies produced by
lily symptomless virus ; McWhorter, 1940>, or pinwheels. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related

Tulip chlorotic blotch potyvirus

      (1) W.P. Mowat, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: TCBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.071. (8) First reported in Tulipa spp. (9) From Australia. (10) By
Mowat (1985). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms pale green blotches or
streaks in leaves. Colour break symptoms in flowers. (13) Tulipa spp.
blotching or streaking of leaves. Flower break symptoms indistinguishable from
those caused by tulip breaking virus. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic
chlorotic mottle and chlorotic local lesions. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana
systemic chlorotic mottle. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic chlorotic mottle,
sometimes with veinal necrosis. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic
local lesions; not systemic. (44) Beta vulgaris, Brassica campestris, B.
campestris ssp. rapa, Cucumis sativus, Lilium formosanum. (45) Nicotiana
benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii,
or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or
Tulipa, or Vicia faba. (48) Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Coriandrum sativum, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or Dianthus barbatus, or Lilium
formosanum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana,
or Pisum sativum, or Poa annua, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/6>, or Liliaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae
<8/10>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<1/3>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/6>, or Liliaceae <1/2>, or
Solanaceae <2 /10>, or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (53) Mowat (1985). (54) TIP: 50-60
°C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions <probably>.
(60) Method: Mowat (1985). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 720 nm. (71)
Virions 12 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76)
One sedimenting component in purified preparations, or two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (178) Other cellular changes:
interference with pigment formation in petals (Mowat, 1985). (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bean yellow mosaic virus. (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: tulip breaking, pepper veinal mottle, tobacco etch and
potato Y viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ability to infect
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa and failure to react with antiserum to
tulip breaking virus virions. (187) Mowat, W.P. (1985). Ann. appl. Biol. 106:
65.


Tulip halo necrosis (?) virus

      (1) W.P. Mowat, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.40. (8) First
reported in Tulipa spp. (9) From the U.K. (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms
necrotic local lesions in leaves and flower stems; often with translucent
border. (13) Tulipa spp. necrotic local lesions in leaves and flower stems;
often with translucent border. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae (after
short or long acquisition feeds). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <inoculum for Chenopodium quinoa prepared in 0.07M PO4 buffer pH 8
containing 0.2M 2mercaptoethanol is much more infective than that prepared in
the same buffer at pH 7 without reducing agent>. (40) Found, but with no
evidence of spread, in the U.K. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic and chlorotic local
lesions and veinal necrosis. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Phaseolus vulgaris brown local lesions,
rings. Datura stramonium necrotic local lesions and multiple green rings;
sometimes systemic. Nicotiana benthamiana chlorotic local lesions, becoming
necrotic; necrosis and chlorotic mottle. Nicotiana clevelandii necrotic and
chlorotic local lesions, veinal necrosis and mottle. Beta vulgaris necrotic or
green local lesions. Nicotiana debneyi necrotic local lesions; systemic.
Nicotiana tabacum cv. Xanthi-nc necrotic local lesions; necrotic spots and
rings. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (W), Chenopodium quinoa (L). (47) Beta
vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Tulipa. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Liliaceae <1/1>,
or Solanaceae <7/7>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (53) Mowat (1971). (54) TIP: 45
°C. (55) LIV: 0.25 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (57) Infectivity of sap not
changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (60) Method: Mowat (1971). (179)
(Ungrouped). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: the virus and cucumber mosaic
virus, tobacco necrosis virus, tomato bushy stunt and tulip X viruses all all
cause similar symptoms in tulips. These viruses are best distinguished by
electron microscopy and serology. (186) Studies involving centrifugation of
sap extracts, and the effect of diethyl ether treatment strongly suggests that
THN is caused by a virus, but no virions have been seen. Extracts treated with
water saturated phenol are not infective. (187) Mowat, W.P. (1970). Ann. appl.
Biol. 66: 17. Mowat, W.P. (1971). Acta Hort. 23: 283. Mowat, W.P. (1971). Ann.
appl. Biol. 69: 147.

      (5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.41. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35284. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): X63630 Em(43)_vi:Tmvcprna
Gb(89)_vi:Tmvcprna Tulip mosaic virus gene for coat protein. 7/94 1,479bp.
(179) (Ungrouped).


Tulip X potexvirus

      (1) W.P. Mowat, 1990. (3) Standard acronym: TVX. (5) ICTV decimal code
56.0.1.0.019. (8) First reported in Tulipa sp. (9) From the U.K. (10) By Mowat
(1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms chlorotic or necrotic grey-brown
streaking of leaves; streaks of intensified pigment (or of necrosis) in
petals. (13) Tulipa spp. chlorotic or necrotic grey-brown streaking of leaves;
streaks of intensified pigment (or of necrosis) in petals. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (15) Manual inoculation of tulips is only
occasionally successful, thus spread by contact between plants may be rare.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted
by contact between plants <probably>. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in the U.K. and Sweden. (41) Many (>9) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions and
chlorotic mottle. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Trifolium
incarnatum chlorotic local lesions; systemic chlorotic mottle. Spinacia
oleracea, Nicotiana benthamiana, Apium graveolens, Viola odorata symptomless
systemic infection. (44) Brassica campestris, Trifolium pratense, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. tabacum cv. White Burley. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C.
quinoa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Anthriscus cerefolium, or
Apium graveolens, or Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Coriandrum sativum, or Cucumis sativus, or Daucus
carota, or Gomphrena globosa, or Heracleum sphondylium, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Petroselinum crispum, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Tulipa, or
Viola odorata. (48) Brassica campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or
Capsicum annuum, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Lactuca
sativa, or Lilium formosanum, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi,
or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia
× hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Setaria italica, or
Trifolium pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/7>, or Liliaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <2/10>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <6/6>, or Violaceae <1 /1>. (51)
Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/7>, or Liliaceae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <8/10>.
(53) Mowat (1982). (54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 30 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 9. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Mowat (1982). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 495 nm. (71)
Virions <c.> 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure.
(75) Pitch of basic helix 3.25 nm. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 118 S. (78) Of
the other(s) 102 S. (84) Virions contain 8 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 92 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (91) Total genome size 6.459 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.459 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Mowat (1982): two cycles of precipitation with 8%
polyethylene glycol (Mr 6000) in the presence of 0.2M NaCl. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 22500 <sometimes one of 19000 is found>. (171)
Virions found in epidermal cells of leaves. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Spindle shaped.
(177) They contain virions. (179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: hydrangea ringspot and viola mottle viruses.
(182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bamboo mosaic, cactus X,
clover yellow mosaic, foxtail mosaic, lily X, narcissus mosaic, nerine X,
plantain X and potato X viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: symptoms in
tulip resemble those caused by other viruses, but systemic line patterns in
Chenopodium amaranticolor and the failure to infect Nicotiana clevelandii,
combined with the presence of potexvirus virions, give a reliable diagnosis,
especially when confirmed by serological tests. (187) Mowat, W.P. (1982). Ann.
appl. Biol. 101: 51. Mowat, W.P. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 276,
4pp.


Turnip crinkle carmovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: TCV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.012. (8) First reported in Brassica campestris ssp. rapa. (9) From
Scotland. (10) By Broadbent and Blencowe (1955). (11) Symptoms persist. (13)
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa mottling and leaf distortion; stunting of
plants. Brassica napus var. napobrassica faint leaf chlorosis or symptomless
infection. Brassica sinapis severe leaf distortion. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Phyllotreta (nine
species) and Psylloides (two species). (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed.
(39) Spreads in the UK and the former Yugoslavia. (41) Many (>9) families
susceptible. (43) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis local chlorotic lesions;
systemic leaf mottling and crinkling. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa,
Datura stramonium local chlorotic lesions; no systemic infection. Chenopodium
murale local chlorotic lesions; systemic chlorotic flecking. Tetragonia
tetragonioides local chlorotic lesions; symptomless systemic infection. (45)
Brassica juncea, Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis. (46) Brassica juncea
(W), Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis (W), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L),
C. murale (L), C. quinoa (L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L). (47) Brassica
campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica napus var. napobrassica,
or Brassica oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or
Brassica sinapis, or Capsella bursa-pastoris, or Catharanthus roseus, or
Cheiranthus cheiri, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Lunaria annua, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or Raphanus sativus, or
Sinapis alba, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Beta
vulgaris, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Vicia faba. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/5>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <13/13>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/5>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <1/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/5>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<2/2>, or Solanaceae <2/5>. (53) Broadbent and Heathcote (1958). (54) TIP: 95
°C. (55) LIV: <more than> 42 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 6. (60)
Method: Hollings and Stone (1969). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 129 S. (79)
Density 1.34 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.48. (84) Virions contain 17
% nucleic acid. (85) Virions 83 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 4.2 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 4.2 kb. (110) Poly A
region absent. (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Carrington et al. (1987).
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 11988. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): M22445

Turnip mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R. Provvidenti, 1981. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: anemone mosaic
virus, cabbage A virus (Walker et al., 1945; Yoshii, 1963), cabbage black ring
virus (Tompkins et al., 1938), cabbage black ringspot virus (Smith, 1935),
cabbage ring necrosis virus (Larson and Walker, 1941), daikon mosaic virus
(Yoshii, 1963), horseradish mosaic virus (Pound, 1948; Yoshii, 1963), radish P
virus (Tochihara, 1959; Yoshii, 1963), tigridia mosaic virus (Brunt, 1976;
Smith and Brierley, 1944). (3) Standard acronym: TuMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.072. (8) First reported in Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, B.
japonica, B. campestris ssp. rapa. (9) From the U.S.A. (10) By Schultz (1921).
(11) Symptoms persist. (13) Capsella bursa-pastoris, Brassica nigra, Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, Stellaria media, Trifolium hybridum, Alliaria
officinalis, Calanthe sp., Hesperis matronalis chlorotic local lesions,
mosaic, mottling, puckering or rugosity. Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis,
B. campestris ssp. rapa, B. japonica. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by 4050 spp. especially Myzus
persicae and Brevicoryne brassicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed
worldwide. (39) Spreads in Australia, China, and the UK. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. Brassica nigra, Brassica oleracea var. capitata, Cichorium endiva,
Cucurbita pepo, Pisum sativum, Nicotiana glutinosa, Petunia × hybrida,
Spinacia oleracea systemic mosaic, rugosity. Brassica campestris ssp.
pekinensis chlorotic local lesions; systemic mosaic, rugosity. (45) Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, B. campestris ssp. rapa, B. perviridis, Nicotiana
glutinosa, Petunia × hybrida. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa
(L), Nicotiana tabacum (W). (47) Alliaria officinalis, or Amaranthus caudatus,
or Beta vulgaris, or Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica

Turnip rosette sobemovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: TRoV. (5) ICTV decimal code
67.0.1.0.010. (8) First reported in Brassica campestris ssp. napus and ssp.
rapa. (9) From Scotland, U.K. (10) By Blencowe and Broadbent, 1957. (13)
Brassica campestris ssp. napus chlorotic vein-banding and severe stunting.
Brassica campestris ssp. rapa necrosis of veins, leaf distortion and severe
stunting ("rosetting"). (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in the UK. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Brassica
campestris ssp. napus and ssp. rapa local chlorotic or necrotic lesions;
systemic necrosis of veins and petioles, severe stunting. Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis local necrotic and/or chlorotic lesions; occasional systemic
veinal necrosis and leaf distortion. (44) Nicotiana tabacum. (45) Brassica
campestris ssp. rapa. (46) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis (L). (47)
Bauhinia purpurea, or Brassica campestris ssp. napus, or Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa, or Nicotiana bigelovii, or
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum. (48) Nicotiana tabacum. (50)
Cruciferae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/3>.
(51) Solanaceae <1/3>. (53) Hollings and Stone 1969. (54) TIP: 90 °C. (55)
LIV: <more than> 30 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5-6. (60) Method: Hollings and
Stone (1969, 1973). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 28 nm in diameter. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 112 S. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.56.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (100) Base composition 25 %
G. (101) Base composition 26 % A. (102) Base composition 22 % C. (103) Base
composition 27 % U. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 27700. (134) Coat
protein. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179) Sobemovirus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: 27 viruses with isometric
virions. (187) Blencowe, J.W. and Broadbent, L. (1957). Rep. Rothamsted exp.
Stn. 1956, p.105. Broadbent, L. and Heathcote, G. (1958). Ann. appl. Biol. 46:
585. Hollings, M. and Stone, O.M. (1969). Zbl. Bakt. ParasitKde. Abt 2, 123:

Turnip yellow mosaic tymovirus

      (1) P.L. Guy, 1985; A.J. Gibbs, 1987. (2) Synonyms: cardamine yellow
mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: TYMV. (4) Strains: Type or TYMV-1 isolates
include the type (Cambridge), honesty, Rademacher and the closely related
Australian isolates Club Lake, Blue Lake, RR, Lake Albina; the cauliflower or
TYMV-2 isolates include cauliflower (Northumberland), Rothamsted and Denmark.
(5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Brassica campestris
ssp. pekinensis. (9) From Europe. (10) By Markham and Smith (1949). (13)
Brassica spp. and many Brassicaceae vein clearing and mosaic or blotching
symptoms. Cardamine lilaciana sward forming variant vein clearing and mosaic.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Phyllotreta and Psylloides species (flea beetles) and Phaedon cochleariae
(the mustard beetle) in Europe and Pedilophorus sp in Australia. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <of
Camelina sativa (Hein, 1984)>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Broadbent (1957). (38) Spreads in the Eurasian region <in
the north west>. (39) Spreads in Australia. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, Raphanus sativus vein
clearing and mosaic or blotching. (44) Chenopodium quinoa, Nicotiana
glutinosa, Pisum sativum. (45) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis. (46)
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis (W). (47) Barbarea vulgaris, or Brassica
campestris, or Brassica campestris ssp. chinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
napus, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp.
rapa, or Brassica carinata, or Brassica juncea, or Brassica nigra, or Brassica
oleracea var. botrytis, or Brassicaceae, or Camelina sativa, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Cardamine lilaciana <sward forming variant>, or Cheiranthus
cheiri, or Cleome spinosa, or Conringia orientalis, or Crambe abyssinica, or

campestre, or Lunaria annua, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Matthiola incana,

20 sequences. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is
subgenomic mRNA <with Mr 180000 coding for coat protein (Ricard et al., 1977;
Pleij et al., 1977; Higgins et al., 1978)>. (123) Subgenomic mRNA found in

(146) Amino acid sequence: Peter et al. (1972). (164) Genome replicates in
association with chloroplasts <in vesicles in the margins of the chloroplasts,
that form as an invagination of the outer chloroplast bilayer membrane and
open to the cytoplasm>. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus.
(171) Virions found in leaves and all parts of the host plant including the
apical meristem but mainly in the leaf lamina. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm <in electron dense material close to or replacing the endoplasmic
reticulum>. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular
changes: the formation of vesicles deriving from the bilayer of the
chloroplast membrane and the rounding of chloroplasts. (179) Tymovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: type 1 (TYMV-1) strains, which
are indistinguishable, but TYMV-2 isolates, which are distinct; kennedya
yellow mosaic, dulcamara mottle and scrophularia mottle viruses are more
distantly related. Nucleotide sequencing confirms these results and shows that
European and Australian TYMV-1 isolates differ by about 5%. TYMV-1 and TYMV-2
genome sequences differ by around 10%. (187) Broadbent, L. (1957). Agric. Res.

R.E.F. (1970). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 2, 4 pp. Matthews, R.E.F.

Reinbalt, J., Collot, P. and Duranton, H. (1972). Virology 49: 615. Pleij,
C.W.A., Mellema, J.R., Noort, A. and Bosch, L. (1977). FEBS Lett. 80: 19.
Ricard, B., Barreau, C., Renaudin, H., Moucher, C. and Bové, J.M. (1977).
Virology 79: 231.


Ullucus C comovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: UVC. (5) ICTV decimal code
18.0.1.0.016. (8) First reported in Ullucus tuberosus. (9) From plants
obtained from South America. (10) By Brunt et al. (1982a). (13) Ullucus
tuberosus symptomless infection. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (39) Spreads in Bolivia and Peru. (41) Several (3-9) families
susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic local lesions
and systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium murale chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. Tetragonia tetragonioides local lesions; not systemic. Nicotiana
clevelandii symptomless infection of inoculated leaves; not systemic. (44)
Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Gomphrena globosa, Cucumis sativus, Phaseolus
vulgaris. (45) Chenopodium quinoa, Ullucus tuberosus. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (W), Chenopodium quinoa (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Ullucus tuberosus. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or
Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Cucumis sativus,
or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Physalis floridana,
or Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata.
(50) Basellaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <1/12>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <5/5>, or Portulacaceae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <11/12>. (54) TIP: 70-75 °C. (55) LIV: 45-112 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 7-8. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Brunt
et al. (1982b). (61) Virions isometric. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66)
Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) Three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient <of the fastest> 116 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 51
S <T>, or 95 S <M>. (79) Density 1.404 g cm3 in CsCl <M>, or 1.463 g cm3 in
CsCl <B>. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.58 <M>, or 1.65 <B; all corrected for light
scattering>. (84) Virions contain 38 % nucleic acid <B>, or 30 % nucleic acid
<M>, or 0 % nucleic acid <T>. (85) Virions 62 % protein <B>, or 70 % protein
<M>, or 100 % protein <T>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(91) Total genome size 10.7 kb. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 6.2 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 4.5 kb. (132)
Virion protein(s) two. (133) Mr <of the larger> 45100. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
20700. (179) Comovirus: Comoviridae. (180) : Comoviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: cowpea mosaic virus is distantly related. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: Andean potato mottle, bean pod
mottle, bean rugose mosaic, broad bean stain, cowpea severe mosaic, broad bean
true mosaic, glycine mosaic, quail pea mosaic, radish mosaic, red clover
mottle and squash mosaic viruses. (187) Brunt, A.A., Phillips, S., Jones,
R.A.C. and Kenten, R.H. (1982a). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 65. Brunt, A.A.,

Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 277, 4 pp.


Ullucus mild mottle tobamovirus

      (1) A.A.Brunt and S. Molyneux, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: UMMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 71.0.1.0.014. (8) First reported in Ullucus tuberosus. (9)
From in plants from Peru. (10) By Brunt et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms disappear
soon after infection. (13) Ullucus tuberosus plants also naturally infected
with other viruses. Inoculated plants show mottling. (14) Transmitted by means
not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus transmitted by contact between
plants. (36) Studies reported by Brunt et al. (1982). (39) Spreads in Peru.
(41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Datura metel, Nicotiana
clevelandii, N. benthamiana systemic chlorosis. Nicotiana glutinosa, N.
megalosiphon, N. rustica, N. tabacum chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not
systemic. Chenopodium capitatum severe systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa chlorotic rings or local lesions; not systemic. (44)
Capsicum frutescens, Solanum tuberosum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Vicia faba, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii and N. benthamiana. (46) Chenopodium
quinoa (L), Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), Chenopodium murale (L), Nicotiana
glutinosa (L). (47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium capitatum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa,
or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Montia perfoliata, or Nicandra physalodes, or
Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Ullucus tuberosus. (48) Arachis hypogaea, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Capsicum frutescens, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Pisum sativum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba,
or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Basellaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <4/4>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Portulacaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <13/15>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Cruciferae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Solanaceae <2/15>. (53) Brunt et al.
(1982); Brunt (1986). (54) TIP: 90-95 °C. (56) DEP: log10 minus 7. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Brunt (1986). (61) Virions rodshaped.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 300 nm. (71) Virions 18 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obvious. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 2.4

(84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 6.4 kb. (92)

protein(s) one. (133) Mr 21000. (134) Coat protein. (146) Amino acid sequence:
Van Regenmortel and Brunt, in Brunt (1986). (171) Virions found in all parts
of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) Tobamovirus. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: ribgrass mosaic virus. (182)
Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cucumber green mottle mosaic,
frangipani mosaic, odontoglossum ringspot and sunn-hemp mosaic viruses (Brunt
et al., 1982; Duarte, 1986). (187) Brunt, A.A., Phillips, S., Jones, R.A.C.
and Kenten, R.H. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 65. Brunt, A.A. (1986). In: The
