Ullucus mosaic potyvirus

      (1) S. Phillips, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: UMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.089. (8) First reported in Ullucus tuberosus. (9) From Peru and
Bolivia. (10) By Brunt et al. (1982). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Ullucus
tuberosus systemic leaf mottling and malformation. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted
by contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Bolivia and Peru. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii spotty systemic
chlorosis. N. benthamiana systemic chlorosis and malformation. N. glutinosa ×
N. clevelandii systemic chlorotic rings and leaf malformation. Physalis
floridana systemic chlorotic mosaic. Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor
chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Phaseolus vulgaris, Vigna
unguiculata, Trifolium incarnatum, Solanum tuberosum, Capsicum annuum. (45)
Nicotiana clevelandii, Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana glutinosa × N.
clevelandii, Nicotiana debneyi. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (W) and Nicotiana benthamiana (W).
(47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa,
or Gomphrena globosa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Nicotiana debneyi, or Nicotiana glutinosa × N. clevelandii, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Physalis floridana, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Ullucus
tuberosus. (48) Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Capsicum annuum, or
Cucumis sativus, or Datura metel, or Datura stramonium, or Ipomoea nil, or
Ipomoea setosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanum demissum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Verbesina encelioides, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae
<1/1>, or Basellaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Solanaceae <9/16>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or Convolvulaceae <2/2>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>,
or Solanaceae <7/16>. (53) Brunt et al. (1982). (54) TIP: 65 °C <in Nicotiana
clevelandii sap>. (55) LIV: 8-16 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 5. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Brunt et al. (1982). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 752 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 150 S. (84)
Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91) Total genome size 9 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 9 kb. (120) Nongenomic nucleic
acid not found in the virions. (133) Mr 32000. (134) Coat protein. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not
contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181)
Virus(es) with serologically related virions: alstroemeria mosaic (SDI 8),
bidens mottle (SDI 6), dasheen mosaic (SDI 4), iris severe mosaic (SDI 7) and
potato Y (SDI 6) viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: asparagus 1, bean yellow mosaic, bean common mosaic, beet mosaic,
blackeye cowpea mosaic, carnation vein mosaic, clover yellow vein, datura
shoestring, hyacinth mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, iris mild mosaic, lettuce
mosaic, passiflora woodiness, pepper veinal mottle, peanut mottle, sweet
potato feathery mottle, narcissus yellow stripe, tobacco etch, tulip breaking,
watermelon mosaic and yam mosaic viruses. (187) Brunt, A.A., Phillips, S.,
Jones, R.A.C. and Kenten, R.H. (1982). Ann. appl. Biol. 101: 65. de Silva,
D.P. (1986). M.Sc. Thesis, 65 pp. University of Reading, U.K.


Urd bean leaf crinkle virus

      (1) S.P.S. Beniwal and Y.L. Nene, 1983. (2) Synonyms: blackgram leaf
crinkle virus, bean urd leaf crinkle virus. (5) ICTV decimal code
79.0.P.DE.43. (8) First reported in Vigna mungo. (9) From the Pantnagar
District, Nainital, India. (10) By Kolte and Nene (1972). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Cajanus cajan, Vigna aconitifolia, V. mungo, V. radiata, V.
unguiculata leaf puckering and malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Henosepilachna
dodecastigma. (18) Transmitted by Coleoptera. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by
seed <18%>. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in India. (41)
Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus cv. National Pickling
systemic mosaic, rugosity, leaf malformation. Lagenaria cylindrica systemic
rugosity, leaf malformation, yellowing. Macroptilium lathyroides, Phaseolus
vulgaris cv. Top Crop symptomless systemic infection. Vigna aconitifolia, V.
mungo, V. radiata, V. unguiculata rugosity, leaf malformation. (44)
Chenopodium amaranticolor, Datura stramonium. (45) Cucumis sativus, Lagenaria
cylindrica, Vigna aconitifolia, V. mungo, V. unguiculata. (46) Cucumis sativus
cv. National Pickling (W), Lagenaria cylindrica (W), Vigna aconitifolia (W),
V. mungo (W), V. unguiculata (W). (47) Cajanus cajan, or Cucumis sativus, or
Lagenaria cylindrica, or Macroptilium lathyroides, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Vigna aconitifolia, or Vigna mungo, or Vigna radiata, or Vigna unguiculata.
(48) Arachis hypogaea, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia tora,
or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis
tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Gossypium hirsutum, or Helianthus annuus, or Lablab purpureus, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Pisum sativum, or
Sesamum indicum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vicia
faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. sesquipedalis . (50) Cucurbitaceae <2/4>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <7/18>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<5/5>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/4>, or
Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <11/18>, or
Malvaceae <1/1>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <5 /5>, or Tetragoniaceae
<1/1>. (53) Kolte and Nene (1975); Bharathan (1980); Beniwal et al. (1983).
(54) TIP: 60-70 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4. (57)
Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Beniwal and Nene: PEG and column
chromatography. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64)
Virions 25-30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (84) Virions contain 17 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome
consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (92) Genome unipartite. (166)
Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in chloroplasts. (174)
Inclusions absent from infected cells. (178) Other cellular changes:
hypertrophy of infected cells. Mitochondria become filiform. (179)
(Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean pod
mottle, bean rugose mosaic, bean yellow stipple, blackgram mottle, cowpea
mosaic, cowpea severe mosaic, cowpea chlorotic mottle, southern bean mosaic,
squash mosaic, turnip crinkle and turnip yellow mosaic viruses. (186) In
addition to this beetle-transmitted crinkle virus of green gram (Kolte and
Nene, 1972), two others causing crinkle diseases of green gram are known. One
is transmitted by aphids (Dingra, 1975), and the other by whitefly
(Narayanasamy and Jaganathan, 1974). (187) Beniwal, S.P.S. and Bharathan, N.
(1980). Indian Phytopath. 33: 600. Beniwal, S.P.S. and Chaubey, S.N. (1979).
Seed Research 7: 175. Beniwal, S.P.S, Kolte, S.J. and Nene, Y.L. (1980). Ind.
J. Mycol. Pl. Path. 9: 188. Beniwal, S.P.S, Bharathan, N. and Chaubey, S.N.
(1983). Indian Phytopath. 36: 577. Bhaktavatsalam, G., Nene, Y.L. and Beniwal,
S.P.S (1982). Indian Phytopath. 35: 683. Bharathan, N. (1980). M.Sc. Thesis,
G.B. Pant. Univ. Tech., Pantnagar, Nainital, U.P. India. Dingra, K.L. (1975).
Indian Phytopath. 28: 80. Kolte, S.J. and Nene, Y.L. (1972). Indian Phytopath.
25: 401. Kolte, S.J. and Nene, Y.L. (1975). Indian Phytopath. 28: 430.
Narayanasamy, P. and Jaganathan, T. (1974). Madras Agric. J. 61: 979. Nene,
Y.L. (1972). G. B. Pant. Univ. Agric. Tech. Bull. 4: 191.


Vallota mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and P. Jeyanandarajah, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ValMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.090. (8) First reported in Vallota speciosa.
(9) From the Netherlands. (10) By Inouye and Hakkaart (1980). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Vallota speciosa chlorotic leaf striping and flower breaking.
(14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted
by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (39)
Spreads in the Netherlands. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the
U.K. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show chlorotic local lesions. (43) Vallota speciosa chlorotic
leaf striping. Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Hyoscyamus niger
chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Tetragonia tetragonioides chlorotic
local lesions, green ringspots and/or green spots; not systemic. Gomphrena
globosa red-edged local lesions; not systemic. Freesia spp. systemic mosaic.
Nicotiana clevelandii, Spinacia oleracea symptomless infection. (44) Datura
stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, N. tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Cucumis
sativus. (45) Vallota speciosa. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa
(L), Hyoscyamus niger (L), Tetragonia tetragonioides (L). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Freesia, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Hyoscyamus niger, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Spinacia oleracea, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Vallota speciosa. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Datura stramonium, or
Glycine max, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Physalis floridana, or Pisum sativum, or Raphanus sativus, or Sesamum indicum,
or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis , or Zinnia elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Amaryllidaceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/4>, or Iridaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/9>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/4>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <3/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>,
or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <7/9>. (53) Inouye and Hakkaart (1980).
(54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 4-8 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 750 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72) Axial canal
obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in leaves and
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Inouye, N.
and Hakkaart, F.A. (1980). Neth. J. Pl. Path. 86: 265.


Vanilla mosaic potyvirus

      (1) F.W. Zettler and G.C. Wisler, 1986. (2) Synonyms: Tongan vanilla
virus. (3) Standard acronym: VanMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.091. (8)
First reported in Vanilla tahitensis. (9) From Huahine, Raiatea, Tahaa and
Tahiti, French Polynesia. (10) By Wisler et al. (1986). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Vanilla tahitensis, Vanilla pompona leaf mosaic and malformation. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in French
Polynesia on the islands of Huahine, Raiatea, Tahaa and Tahiti. (43) Vanilla
pompona no symptoms in leaves inoculated by aphids but then systemic terminal
necrosis and mosaic and malformation. (47) Vanilla pompona, or Vanilla
tahitensis. (50) Orchidaceae <2/2>. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 767 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (171) Virions found in mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and
unusual in shape. (176) Scrolls and laminated aggregates. (179) Potyvirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: bidens mottle and tobacco etch viruses are serologically related to,
but distinct from, vanilla mosaic potyvirus in SDS immunodiffusion tests. In
tests with dasheen mosaic virus, and its homologous antiserum, bands of
precipitate formed that were fully confluent with those of the vanilla
potyvirus. (187) Wisler, G.C., Zettler, F.W. and Mu, L. (1986). Phytopathology
76: 1091. Wisler, G.C., Zettler, F.W. and Mu, L. (1987). Amer. Orchid Soc.
Bull. 56: 381. Wisler, G.C., Zettler, F.W. and Mu, L. (1987). Plant Dis. 71:
1125.


Vanilla necrosis potyvirus

      (1) M.N. Pearson and S.P. Pone, 1989. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.073. (8) First reported in Vanilla fragrans. (9) From Tonga. (10) By
Pearson and Pone (1988). (11) Symptoms persist <but symptoms patchy>. (13)
Vanilla fragrans chlorotic blotching or streaking and malformed margins of tip
leaves which, as they age, develop brown scab-like and necrotic local lesions,
which also form on the vines causing die-back. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by <possibly> an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis gossypii
and Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (39) Spreads in Fiji and Tonga. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis and leaf malformation. (43)
Nicotiana benthamiana systemic vein chlorosis and malformed leaves. Nicotiana
clevelandii mild systemic mottling. Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local
lesions; not systemic. C. quinoa diffuse chlorotic local lesions; not
systemic. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, N. clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or
Vanilla fragrans. (48) Cassia occidentalis, or Cassia tora, or Chenopodium
murale, or Colocasia esculenta, or Datura stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or
Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Chenopodiaceae <2/3>, or
Orchidaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/6>. (51) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Araceae
<1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>, or Solanaceae <4/6>. (52) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, C. quinoa and Nicotiana clevelandii only successfully infected
from Nicotiana benthamiana but not directly from Vanilla fragrans. (53)
Pearson et al. (1990). (54) TIP: 58-60 °C. (55) LIV: 1-2 days. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Pearson et al.
(1990). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 775
nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35283. (132) Virion
protein(s) one. (133) Mr 32700. (134) Coat protein. (145) Method of
preparation: Pearson et al. (1990). (171) Virions found in leaves and
mesophyll. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177) They do not contain
virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (182) Virus(es)
with serologically unrelated virions: alstroemeria mosaic, asparagus I, bean
yellow mosaic, commelina Y, dasheen mosaic, hippeastrum mosaic, iris mild
mosaic, iris severe mosaic, narcissus late season yellows, narcissus
degeneration, narcissus yellow stripe, nerine yellow stripe, potato Y, turnip
mosaic, tulip breaking, watermelon mosaic 2, yam mosaic and vanilla mosaic
viruses. (187) Pearson, M.N. and Pone, S.P. (1988). Australas. Pl. Path. 17:
59. Pearson, M.N., Brunt, A.A. and Pone, S.P. (1990). J. Phytopath. 128: 46.


Velvet tobacco mottle sobemovirus

      (1) J.W. Randles, 1986. (2) Synonyms: tobacco velvet mottle virus. (3)
Standard acronym: VTMoV. (5) ICTV decimal code 67.0.1.0.011. (8) First
reported in Nicotiana velutina. (9) From Cobblers Sandhill and Innamincka,
northeastern South Australia. (10) By Randles et al. (1981). (11) Symptoms
persist. (13) Nicotiana velutina systemic mosaic and leaf malformation. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Cyrtopeltis nicotianae: Miridae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner
<atypically>. (27) Virus does not multiply in the vector. (29) Virus does not
require a helper virus for vector transmission <Gibb and Randles, 1988>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (39) Spreads in Australia <Randles et al., 1981; G. Behncken and J.W.
Randles, unpublished data; Horton, 1981>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible.
(43) Nicotiana clevelandii chlorotic to necrotic local lesions, then systemic
vein yellowing and mosaic. Nicotiana glutinosa, N. × edwardsonii mild systemic
mosaic. Nicotiana velutina systemic vein yellowing and mosaic. (44) Solanum
nodiflorum. (45) Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (L). (47)
Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana velutina, or
Nicotiana × edwardsonii. (48) Solanum nodiflorum. (50) Solanaceae <4/5>. (51)
Solanaceae <1/5>. (52) An isolate of velvet tobacco mottle virus freed from
the satellite RNA did not cause local lesions in Nicotiana clevelandii
(Francki et al., 1986). (53) Francki et al. (1985). (54) TIP: 70 °C. (58) Leaf
sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Randles et al. (1981). (61) Virions
isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions <c.> 30 nm in diameter.
(66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere
arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 115 S. (79) Density 1.37 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions
contain 20 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 80 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid.
(88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total
genome size 4.2 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part
4.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Gould (1981); Randles et al.
(1981). (108) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with proteases. (109)
Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent. (116)
Nucleotide sequence references: Randles et al. (1981); Gould (1981); Haseloff
and Symons (1982); Keese and Symons (1986). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12473. (120)
Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions. (121) Is subgenomic mRNA <c.1.77
kb for RNA1a and c.0.71 kb for RNA1b, and RNA2 which is of 366-367 nucleotides
and has a circular, viroid-like structure, and RNA3, which is the same size
and sequence as RNA2, but linear>. (132) Virion protein(s) one <in native>, or
three <in dissociated preparations>. (133) Mr 37000. (134) Coat protein. (135)
Mr of 2nd largest 33000. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 31500. (145) Method of
preparation: Chu and Francki (1983); Randles et al. (1981). (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in cell vacuoles.
(174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are membranous
bodies. (179) Sobemovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
solanum nodiflorum mottle virus (SDI 1-2). (182) Virus(es) with serologically
unrelated virions: lucerne transient streak, subterranean clover mottle,
southern bean mosaic, broad bean mottle, carnation ringspot, cymbidium
ringspot, galinsoga mosaic, glycine mottle, narcissus tip necrosis, red clover
necrotic mosaic, saguaro cactus, tomato bushy stunt and turnip crinkle viruses
(Randles et al., 1981; Francki et al., 1983; Tremaine and Hamilton, 1983).
(184) Velvet tobacco mottle virus (VTMoV) may be distinguished from solanum
nodiflorum mottle virus (SNMV) in host tests; Nicotiana velutina and N.
glutinosa are infected systemically by VTMoV, but not by SNMV, whereas Solanum
nodiflorum is infected by SNMV but not VTMoV (Randles et al., 1981; Greber,
1981). VTMoV is serologically unrelated to two other viruses which have
satellite RNAs, namely lucerne transient streak and subterranean clover mottle
viruses (Tien et al., 1981; Francki et al., 1983); these satellites differ in
size and sequence from that of VTMoV (Keese et al., 1983; Francki et al.,
1985), but those of both VTMoV and SNMV replicate in plants infected with
lucerne transient streak virus (Jones and Mayo, 1983; 1985). (185) Best tests
for diagnosis: VTMoV has virions serologically related to those of SNMV, which
has a genome with 20-50% homology (Gould and Hatta, 1981), but it fails to
infect Solanum nodiflorum and has a smaller satellite (Haseloff and Symons,
1982). (186) The virus occurs in gut, haemolymph and faeces, but not salivary
glands, of its mirid vector. (187) Chu, P.W.G. and Francki, R.I.B. (1983).
Virology 129. 350. Francki, R.I.B., Grivell, C.J. and Gibb, K.S. (1986).
Virology 148. 381. Francki, R.I.B., Randles, J.W., Chu, P.W.G., Rohozinski, J.
and Hatta, T. (1985). In: Subviral Pathogens of Plants and Animals, Viroids
and Prions, pp. 265-297; ed. K. Maramorosch and J.J. McKelvey. Academic Press,
New York. Francki, R.I.B., Randles, J.W., Hatta, T., Davies, C. and Chu,
P.W.G. (1983). Pl. Path. 32: 47. Gibb, K.S. and Randles, J.W. (1988). Ann.
appl. Biol. 112: 427. Gibb, K.S. and Randles, J.W. (1990). Ann. appl. Biol.
116: 513. Greber, R.S. (1981). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 34: 369. Gould, A.R.
(1981). Virology 108: 123. Haseloff, J. and Symons, R.H. (1982). Nucl. Acids
Res. 10: 3681. Horton, P. (1981). J. Adelaide Bot. Gard. 3: 1. Jones, A.T. and
Mayo, M.A. (1983). J. gen. Virol. 64: 1771. Jones, A.T. and Mayo, M.A. (1985).
Rep. Scottish Crop Res. Inst. 1984, p.190. Keese, P. and Symons, R.H. (1986).
In: Viroids and Viroid-Like Pathogens, p. 1; ed. J.S. Semancik. CRC Press,
Boca Raton, Florida. Keese, P., Bruening, G. and Symons, R.H. (1983). FEBS
Lett. 159: 185. Randles, J.W. and Francki, R.I.B. (1986). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 317, 5 pp. Randles, J.W., Davies, C., Hatta, T. and Francki,
R.I.B. (1981). Virology 108: 111. Tien, P., Davies, C., Hatta, T. and Francki,
R.I.B. (1981). FEBS Lett. 132: 353. Tremaine, J.H. and Hamilton, R.I. (1983).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 274, 6 pp.


Velvet tobacco mottle virus viroid-like satellite RNA

      (5) ICTV decimal code 64.0.5.4.007. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): J02439 Em(40)_vi:VTMOVR2 Gb(84)_vi:MTVR2 Velvet tobacco mottle virus
circular viroid-like RNA (RNA 2). 4/90 366bp. 1 sequence. (179) Satellite RNA.


Vicia alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.J. Cockbain, 1982. Revised 1983. (3) Standard acronym: VCV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.015. (8) First reported in Vicia faba. (9) From
Hertfordshire, U.K. (10) By Kenten et al. (1978). (13) Vicia faba symptomless.
(31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not
transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (35)
Virus transmitted by pollen to the seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Germany, the Netherlands and the U.K. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (45) Vicia faba. (47) Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Cockbain: grind frozen tissue in 0.5M phosphate buffer, pH 8.0
containing 0.01M EDTA and 0.4% 2-mercaptoethanol with chloroform/butanol (1 g
leaf: 2 ml buffer: 0.5 ml chloroform: 0.5 ml N-butanol) followed by
differential centrifugation. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (79) Density 1.38
and 1.39 g cm3 in CsCl. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae. (180) :
Partitiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: bean
leaf roll, broad bean mottle, broad bean true mosaic, broad bean wilt,
carnation cryptic, crimson clover latent, pea enation mosaic and southern bean
mosaic viruses. (187) Kenten, R.H., Cockbain, A.J. and Woods, R.D. (1978).
Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1977. p.222.


Vigna sinensis mosaic (?) rhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1989. (2) Synonyms: cowpea mosaic virus. (3) Standard
acronym: VSMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 62.U.P.0.054. (8) First reported in Vigna
unguiculata ssp. unguiculata (syn. Vigna sinensis). (9) From Brazil. (10) By
Kitajima and Costa (see Peters, 1981; Francki et al., 1981). (13) Vigna
unguiculata. (39) Spreads in Brazil. (47) Vigna unguiculata. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (179) Unassigned rhabdovirus. (180) :
Rhabdoviridae. (187) Francki, R.I.B., Kitajima, E.W. and Peters, D. (1981).
In: Handbook of Plant Virus Infection and Comparative Diagnosis, ed. E.
Kurstak. Elsevier/North Holland Biomedical Press, Amsterdam. Peters, D.
(1981). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 244, 6pp.


Viola mottle potexvirus

      (1) V. Lisa, 1986; G.R. Johnstone, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: VMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.020. (8) First reported in Viola odorata. (9) From
Liguria, Italy. (10) By Lisa and Dellavalle (1977). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Viola odorata leaf mottling, white stripes on petals. (14) Transmitted by
means not involving a vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Australia, France, and Italy. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Amaranthus caudatus necrotic local lesions;
systemic mottle. Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions; systemic
mosaic. Gomphrena globosa necrotic local lesions; systemic infection usually
latent. Nicotiana clevelandii symptomless local infection, not systemic. (44)
Datura stramonium, Nicotiana tabacum, Nicotiana glutinosa, Cucumis sativus.
(45) Chenopodium quinoa. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L), Gomphrena globosa (L).
(47) Amaranthus caudatus, or Amaranthus hybridus, or Antirrhinum majus, or
Beta vulgaris, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Dianthus barbatus, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Primula malacoides,
or Primula obconica, or Solanum melongena, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium pratense, or Viola odorata, or Viola tricolor.
(48) Callistephus chinensis, or Cucumis sativus, or Datura stramonium, or
Hydrangea macrophylla, or Lupinus albus, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or
Tagetes patula, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Zinnia
elegans. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Caryophyllaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<6/6>, or Compositae <1/4>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/5>, or
Primulaceae <2/2>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/6>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1 /1>, or Violaceae <2/2>. (51) Compositae <3/4>, or
Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or Hydrangeaceae <1/1>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/5>, or Solanaceae <4/6>. (53) Lisa and
Dellavalle (1977). (54) TIP: 95 °C. (55) LIV: 240 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 9-10. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (60) Method: Lisa and
Dellavalle (1977); Richardson et al. (1981). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 478-495 nm. (71) Virions <c.> 13 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal <faint indication> obvious. (74) Basic helix obscure. (75)
Pitch of basic helix 3.5 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.31 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 6 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7.2 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 7.2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Lisa et al. (1982). (100) Base composition 22.8 % G. (101)
Base composition 26.4 % A. (102) Base composition 30.3 % C. (103) Base
composition 20.5 % U. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 21473. (134) Coat protein. (146) Amino
acid sequence: Bendena and Mackie (1986). (147) Amino acid composition: M.N.
Short (unpublished data) cf. Lisa et al. (1982). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion
proteins isolated <Bendena and Mackie (1986)>. (153) One protein found. (154)
Mr 160000. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions
found in mesophyll, epidermis and all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: cactus virus X
(strains B5 and 884), and hydrangea ringspot virus (Lisa and Dellavalle, 1977)
are distantly related as are foxtail mosaic virus (Short, 1981), nerine virus
X (Agapanthus isolate; Phillips and Brunt, 1980) and tulip virus X (Mowat,
1979). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: cactus virus X
(strains CC10 and K11), clover yellow mosaic, narcissus mosaic, papaya mosaic,
pepino mosaic, white clover mosaic, cymbidium mosaic and potato virus X
viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: viola mottle virus is often mixed
with cucumber mosaic virus in naturally-infected violets, but these can be
easily distinguished by electron microscopy, or better by ISEM. The ability of
viola mottle virus to infect Chenopodium amaranticolor also helps. (187)
Bendena, W.G. and Mackie, G.A. (1986). Virology 153: 220. Lisa, V. and
Dellavalle, G. (1977). Phytopath. Z. 89: 82. Lisa, V., Boccardo, G. and Milne,
R.G. (1982). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 247, 4 pp. Mowat, W.P. (1979).
Rep. Scottish Hort. Res. Inst. 1978, p.126. Phillips, S. and Brunt, A.A.
(1980). Acta Hort. 110: 65. Richardson, J.F., Tollin, P. and Bancroft, J.B.
(1981). Virology 112: 34. Short, N. (1981). Rep. John Innes Inst. 1980, p.126.


Voandzeia distortion mosaic potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1990. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.DE.12. (8) First
reported in Vigna subterranea (syn. Voandzeia subterranea). (9) From the Ivory
Coast. (10) By Fauquet and Thouvenel (1987). (13) Vigna subterranea severe
leaf chlorosis, malformation, and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora and A.
spiraecola. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire. (43) Vigna subterranea
conspicuous leaf chlorosis and malformation. (47) Vigna subterranea. (50)
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (54) TIP: 50-55 °C. (55) LIV: 14 days <at
4°C, or a few hours at 24°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap
contains few virions. (60) Method: Fauquet and Thouvenel (1987). (61) Virions

Voandzeia necrotic mosaic tymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and A. Monsarrat, 1988. (3) Standard acronym: VNMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.017. (8) First reported in Vigna subterranea (syn.
Voandzeia subterranea). (9) From the Ivory Coast. (10) By Fauquet et al.
(1981). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Vigna subterranea mosaic, necrosis and
malformation of leaves, occasionally lethal. (15) Possibly transmitted by a
vector. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus
transmitted by grafting. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (36) Studies
reported by Monsarrat et al. (1984). (39) Spreads in Cote d'Ivoire. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Vigna subterranea systemic chlorosis, veinal
necrosis and leaf malformation. Lablab purpureus, Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata chlorotic local lesions, then systemic leaf chlorosis. Chenopodium
amaranticolor necrotic local lesions; not systemic. (44) Arachis hypogaea,
Phaseolus vulgaris, Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana glutinosa, Abelmoschus
esculentus. (45) Vigna subterranea, Lablab purpureus, Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L). (47) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Lablab purpureus, or Vigna subterranea, or Vigna
unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
sesquipedalis , or Vigna unguiculata ssp. unguiculata. (48) Abelmoschus
esculentus, or Amaranthaceae, or Arachis hypogaea, or Chenopodiaceae, or
Cruciferae, or Leguminosae, or Malvaceae, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Passifloraceae, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Solanaceae.
(50) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/8>. (51)
Amaranthaceae, or Chenopodiaceae, or Cruciferae, or Leguminosae, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/8>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Passifloraceae, or
Solanaceae <2/2>. (52) An unspecified 82 species in Amaranthaceae,
Chenopodiaceae, Cruciferae, Leguminosae, Malvaceae, Passifloraceae and
Solanaceae are not infected. (53) Monsarrat et al. (1984). (54) TIP: <in Vigna
subterranea sap> 70 °C. (55) LIV: <2 days at 10°C and> 10 days <at 4°C or
-20°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Monsarrat et al. (1984). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions angular in profile.
(67) Virions without a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 113 S <B>. (78) Of the other(s) 51 S <T>. (79) Density 1.45 g cm3 in
CsCl <B>, or 1.29 g cm3 in CsCl <T>. (82) Isoelectric point pH 4.65. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.75 <B>, or 0.64 <T>. (84) Virions contain 35 % nucleic acid
<B>. (85) Virions 65 % protein <B>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 20000. (134) Coat
protein. (171) Virions found in leaves and mesophyll. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
crystals in the cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular
changes: the occurence of peripheral vesicles in chloroplasts bounded by a
double membrane. (179) Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: kennedya yellow mosaic, desmodium yellow mottle, okra mosaic and
turnip yellow mosaic viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: cacao yellow mosaic and clitoria yellow vein viruses. (187) Fauquet,
C., Monsarrat, A. and Thouvenel, J.-C. (1981). Abstr. 5th. Congr. Virol.,
Strasbourg, 1981, p. 273. Fauquet, C., Monsarrat, A. and Thouvenel, J.-C.
(1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 279, 4 pp. Monsarrat, A., Fauquet, C.
and Thouvenel, J.-C. (1984). C.r. hebd. Seanc. Acad. Sci. Paris, Series
III299: 53.


Watercress yellow spot virus

      (1) J.A. Walsh, 1991. (2) Synonyms: virus des taches jaunes du cresson.
(5) ICTV decimal code 79.0.P.DE.44. (8) First reported in Rorippa
nasturtium-aquaticum. (9) From France. (10) By Spire (1962). (11) Symptoms
vary cyclically over a few weeks, vary seasonally, and disappear soon after
infection <sometimes>. (12) Symptoms chlorotic spotting and blotching. (13)
Rorippa nasturtium-aquaticum chlorotic spotting and blotching, mainly on leaf
veins, some leaves malformed and maybe totally chlorotic. (14) Transmitted by
<probably> a vector. (16) Transmitted by <probably> a fungus. (17) Transmitted
by probably Spongospora subterranea f.sp. Nasturtium. (21) Transmitted by
Plasmodiophorales. (24) Not transmitted by Myzus persicae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation <with great difficulty>. (36) Studies
reported by Spire (1962); Walsh et al. (1989a); Walsh (1990); Walsh and Phelps
(1991). (39) Spreads in France and the UK <Spire, 1962; Walsh et al., 1989a>.
(41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly
show necrotic local lesions, then indistinct chlorotic blotches or ringspots.
(43) Rorippa nasturtium-aquaticum spotting and blotching, but less severe than
in naturally infected plants. Chenopodium quinoa necrotic local lesions, not
systemic. Nicotiana clevelandii indistinct chlorotic blotches, sometimes
ringspots, not systemic. Brassica juncea cv. Tendergreen symptomless.
Nicotiana glutinosa ringspots, not systemic. Brassica napus var. napus cv.
Mikado pinpoint necrotic local lesions. Barbarea verna symptomless.
Chenopodium amaranticolor necrotic local lesions, not systemic. (44) Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, Lactuca sativa, Brassica campestris ssp. rapa cv.
Just Right, Nicotiana tabacum cv. White Burley. (46) Chenopodium quinoa (L),
C. amaranticolor (L), Nicotiana clevelandii (L). (47) Barbarea verna, or
Brassica juncea, or Brassica napus var. napus <cv. Mikado>, or Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Rorippa nasturtium-aquaticum. (48)
Brassica campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Brassica campestris ssp. rapa <cv.
Just Right>, or Lactuca sativa, or Nicotiana tabacum. (50) Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Cruciferae <4/6>, or Solanaceae <3/4>. (51) Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <2/6>, or Solanaceae <1/4>. (53) Walsh et al. (1989b). (54) TIP: 65
°C. (55) LIV: <less than> 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (57) Infectivity
of sap decreased by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM often required to see virions in leaf
sap. (60) Method: Walsh et al. (1989a). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions
not enveloped. (64) Virions 27 nm in diameter <Spire, 1962>, or 37-38 nm in
diameter <Walsh et al., 1989a>. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions
with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement <sometimes>. (76) <Probably> one
sedimenting component in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient
133.8 S. (79) Density 1.335 g cm3 in CsCl. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.53-1.66.
(84) Virions contain 18 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome <possibly> consists of
RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) <Possibly> linear. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 43500. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found in roots and sometimes
in leaves. (179) (Ungrouped). (184) Shares some properties with tombusviruses,
including the sedimentation coefficient of the virions and the coat protein
molecular weight, but its virions are unstable, and are larger than those of
tombusviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: sero-diagnosis by ELISA, ISEM
and gel diffusion. (186) Watercress chlorotic leafspot, although initially
attributed to virus infection (Tomlinson and Hunt, 1987), is now considered to
be induced by a virus-like agent (Tomlinson, 1988). (187) Spire, D. (1962).
Ann. Epiphyt. 13: 39. Walsh, J.A. (1990). First Symp. of Int. Working Group on
Plant Viruses with Fungal Vectors, German Phytomedical Society. Ulmer,
Stuttgart, 173 Walsh, J.A. and Phelps, K. (1991). Pl. Path. in press.
Tomlinson, J.A. (1988). In: Viruses with Fungal Vectors; ed. J.I. Cooper and
M.J.C. Asher. Wellesbourne, U.K., Association of Applied Biologists.
Tomlinson, J.A. and Hunt, J. (1987). Ann. appl. Biol. 110: 75. Walsh, J.A.,
Clay, C.M. and Miller, A. (1989a). EPPO Bull. 19: 463. Walsh, J.A., Clay,
C.M., Miller, A. and Rowe, J.C. (1989b). Aspects Appl. Biol. 22: 101.


Watermelon chlorotic stunt bigeminivirus

      (1) D.G.A. Walkey and P. Jones, 1989. (3) Standard acronym: WmCSV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.049. (8) First reported in Citrullus vulgaris. (9)
From the Peoples Democratic Republic of South Yemen. (10) By Jones et al.
(1987). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Citrullus vulgaris, C. colocynthis
crinkling and chlorotic mottling of young leaves; severe stunting. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
probably Bemisia tabaci, but this has still to be confirmed. (18) Transmitted
by Aleyrodidae. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32)
Virus transmitted by grafting. (36) Studies reported by Jones et al. (1988);
Walkey et al. (1989). (39) Spreads in Saudi Arabia <possibly>, or Yemen <the
north and south>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show systemic mosaic, mottling, ringspotting or
necrosis. (43) Citrullus vulgaris systemic chlorotic mottling, crinkling and
malformation of tip leaves. (45) Citrullus vulgaris cvs Sugar Baby, Charleston
Grey and other cultivars. (47) Citrullus colocynthis, or Citrullus lanatus, or
Citrullus vulgaris. (48) Coccinea grandis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
sativus, or Cucurbita pepo. (50) Cucurbitaceae <3/7>. (51) Cucurbitaceae
<4/7>. (52) Has only been graft transmitted to Citrullus vulgaris. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: ISEM trapping procedures
have so far been essential to see virions. (60) Method: purification is
difficult because of the very small concentrations of virions in plants after
symptoms show. (61) Virions geminate. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions
<individual virions of geminate pair are c.> 19 nm in diameter. (65) Virions
19 nm in length. (66) Virions rounded in profile. (67) Virions without a
conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35341. (118) Sequence
database accession code(s): X79430 Em(40)_vi:WCSVAC1 Gb(84)_vi:WCSVAC1
Watermelon chlorotic stunt virus AC1 gene (partial). 5/94 410bp. 1 sequence.
(179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: African cassava mosaic and squash leaf
curl viruses. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: beet curly
top virus. (184) No homology found in tests with probes to watermelon curly
mottle virus. (187) Alhubaishi, A.A., Walkey, D.G.A., Webb, M.J.W., Bolland,
C.J. and Cook, A.A. (1987). FAO Pl. Prot. Bull. 35: 135. Jones, P., Satar,
M.H.A. and Alkaff, N. (1987). Rep. Rothamsted Exp. Stn. 1987, p. 76. Jones,
P., Sattar, M.H.A. and Alkaff, N. (1988). Asp. Appl. Biol. 17: 203. Walkey,
D.G.A., Alhubaishi, A.A. and Webb, M.J.W. (1989). Trop. Pest Manag. 36: 195.


Watermelon curly mottle bigeminivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and S. Molyneux, 1986. (3) Standard acronym: WmCMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 29.0.3.0.050. (8) First reported in Citrullus lanatus,
Cucumis melo var. cantalupensis. (9) From Arizona, U.S.A. (10) By Brown and
Nelson (1984). (13) Citrullus lanatus and Cucumis melo var. cantalupensis leaf
chlorosis, vein-banding, curling and stunting. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Bemisia tabaci. (18)
Transmitted by Aleyrodidae. (25) Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26)
Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (27) Virus does not multiply in the
vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny of the vector.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by
grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies
reported by Brown and Nelson (1986). (39) Spreads in the USA <Arizona>. (43)
Citrullus lanatus, Cucurbita maxima, C. moschata, C. pepo, Phaseolus vulgaris
cv. Red Kidney severe systemic leaf mottling and curling. Cucumis melo, C.
sativus mild systemic leaf mottling and leaf curling. (47) Citrullus lanatus,
or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis melo var. cantalupensis, or Cucumis sativus, or
Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Phaseolus
vulgaris. (48) Beta vulgaris, or Carthamus tinctorius, or Chenopodium
capitatum, or Cichorium endiva, or Daucus carota, or Gossypium hirsutum, or
Helianthus annuus, or Lactuca sativa, or Medicago sativa, or Physalis
peruviana, or Raphanus sativus, or Rumex acetosa, or Sonchus oleraceus, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Zea mays, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Cucurbitaceae <7/7>,
or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae
<6/6>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Gramineae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/2>, or Malvaceae <1/1>, or Polygonaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <1/1>, or
Umbelliferae <1 /1>. (53) Brown and Nelson (1986). (58) Leaf sap contains few
virions. (60) Method: Brown and Nelson (1986). (61) Virions geminate. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (179) Bigeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) :
Geminiviridae. (187) Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R. (1984). Phytopathology 74:
1136. Brown, J.K. and Nelson, M.R. (1986). Phytopathology 76: 236.


Watermelon Moroccan mosaic (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A.Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: Moroccan watermelon mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: MWMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.T.053. (8) First reported
in Citrullus lanatus. (9) From Morocco. (10) By Fischer and Lockhart (1974).
(13) Citrullus lanatus, Cucumis melo, Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita pepo and
Malva parviflora leaf chlorosis. (39) Spreads in Morocco. (47) Citrullus
lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Malva
parviflora. (50) Cucurbitaceae <4/4>, or Malvaceae <1/1>. (179) <Possible>
unassigned potyvirus. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Fischer, H.U. and Lockhart
B.E.L. (1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr. 58: 143. McKern, N.M., Strike, P.M., Barnett,

Watermelon mosaic 1 potyvirus

      (1) D.E. Purcifull, J.R. Edwardson, E. Hiebert and D. Gonsalves, 1986;
R.S. Greber, 1986. (2) Synonyms: papaya ringspot virus type W, watermelon
papaya ringspot. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.045. (8) First reported in
Citrullus lanatus. (10) By Webb (1965). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucurbita
pepo mosaic, green blistering, leaves and fruit malformed. Citrullus lanatus,
Cucumis melo, Melothria pendula, Momordica charantia mosaic, mottling, leaves
malformed. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17)
Transmitted by Myzus persicae, Acyrthosiphon (Aulacorthum) solani, Aphis
craccivora and Macrosiphum euphorbiae (Karl and Schmelzer, 1971). (18)
Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (38) Spreads in the Middle East and the South and Central American
region. (39) Spreads in Australia, China, France, Germany, India, Italy,
Mexico, and the USA. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (43) Cucurbita pepo
mosaic, green blistering, leaves and fruit malformed. Cucumis metuliferus cv.
Accession 2459 systemic mottle or mosaic. Luffa acutangula systemic chlorotic
mottling or spotting. (44) Carica papaya, Cucumis metuliferus plant
introduction PI 292190, Nicotiana benthamiana, Phaseolus vulgaris cv.
Bountiful. (45) Cucurbita maxima, Cucurbita moschata, Cucurbita pepo. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L) but not for all isolates, Chenopodium quinoa (L)
but not for all isolates, Cucumis melo cv. B633 (L), Cucumis sativus (W),
Cucurbita pepo (W). (47) Carica papaya, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
metuliferus <cv. Accession 2459>, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or
Cucurbita moschata, or Cucurbita pepo, or Luffa acutangula, or Macroptilium
lathyroides, or Melothria pendula, or Momordica charantia. (48) Carica papaya,
or Cucumis metuliferus, or Myosotis sylvatica, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Phaseolus vulgaris <cv. Bountiful>. (50) Caricaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<2/2>, or Cucurbitaceae <10/10>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>. (51)
Boraginaceae <1/1>, or Caricaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/10>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/2>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (52) Many watermelon
mosaic virus 2 isolates (Purcifull, Hiebert and Edwardson, 1984) do not infect
Luffa acutangula, and therefore this species has been used to obtain PRSV
isolates free from watermelon mosaic virus 2 (Webb, 1965; Greber, 1978; D.
Purcifull, unpublished data). (53) Wang et al. (1978); Adlerz (1972a; 1972b);
Milne and Grogan (1969); Purcifull and Hiebert (1979); Yeh et al. (1984). (54)
TIP: 60 °C. (55) LIV: 40-60 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (58) Leaf sap
contains many virions. (60) Method: Gonsalves and Ishii (1980); modification
of the method described by Purcifull and Hiebert (1979) for a type W isolate.
Both purification methods are outlined in the CMI/AAB description No. 292.
(61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 760-800 nm.
(71) Virions 12 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations. (79) Density 1.32 g cm3 in CsCl. (84) Virions contain 5.5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94.5 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 11.4 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 11.4 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic
acid isolated by Brakke and van Pelt (1970); de Mejia (1984); Hiebert et al.
(1984); de Mejia et al. (1984). (106) 5' terminus of RNA has a VPg. (110) Poly
A region present. (111) Poly A region at the 3' terminus (Nagel and Hiebert,
1985). The 3' end cloned and expressed in E. coli. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12205.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 36000-36500 <two smaller proteins with
Mrs of 31000-34000 and 26000-27000 have been found, and virions stored for 2
months contained primarily the smaller one, which presumably results from
proteolytic degradation>. (145) Method of preparation: Purcifull and Hiebert
(1979), Gonsalves and Ishii (1980), Baum (1980). (152) Viruscoded nonvirion
proteins isolated <Yeh (1984) for cylindrical (pinwheel) inclusion (CI)
protein and by de Mejia (1984) for amorphous inclusion body (AI) protein>.
(153) Two proteins found. (154) Mr <of the largest> 69000-70000. (155) For CI.
(156) Mr of 2nd largest 51000. (157) For AI, a helper protein for aphid
transmission. (166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171)
Virions found in mesophyll, epidermis and phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
amorphous Xbodies and pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: the Guadeloupe isolate of papaya ringspot is
very closely related, but distinct (Quiuot-Douine et al., 1986). Furthermore
PRV-W reacts with the D-protein of tobacco etch virus (Shepard et al., 1974)
and the virion proteins and CI proteins of a potyvirus isolate from cucurbits
in Morocco (Fischer and Lockhart, 1974). (187) Adlerz, W.C. (1972a). J. econ.
Ent. 65: 1303. Adlerz, W.C. (1972b). Pl. Dis. Reptr 56: 563. Baum, R.H.
(1980). Ph.D. Thesis, Univ. of Florida 99 pp. Baum, R.H. and Purcifull, D.E.
(1981). Phytopathology 71: 202. Brakke, M.K. and van Pelt, N. (1970). Virology
42: 699. de Mejia, M.V.G. (1984). Ph.D. Thesis, Univ. of Florida 52 pp. de
Mejia, M.V.G., Hiebert, E. and Purcifull, D.E. (1984). Phytopathology 74:
1015. de Mejia, M.V.G., Hiebert, E. and Purcifull, D.E. (1985a). Virology 142:
24. de Mejia, M.V.G., Hiebert, E. and Purcifull, D.E. (1985b). Virology 142:
34. Edwardson, J.R. and Christie, R.G. (1984). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn Monog No.
14, 398 pp. Fischer, H.U. and Lockhart, B.E. (1974). Pl. Dis. Reptr 58: 143.
Gonsalves, D. and Ishii, M. (1980). Phytopathology 70: 1028. Greber, R.S.
(1978). Aust. J. agric. Res. 29: 1235. Hiebert, E., Thornbury, D.W. and
Pirone, T.P. (1984). Virology 135: 1. Karl, E. and Schmelzer, K. (1971). Arch.
PflSchutz. 7: 3. Makkouk, K.M. and Lesemann, D.E. (1980). Plant Dis. 64: 789.
Milne, K.S. and Grogan, R.G. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 809. Purcifull, D.E.
(1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 84, 3 pp. Nagel, J. and Hiebert, E.
(1985). Virology 143: 435. Purcifull, D.E. and Hiebert, E. (1979).
Phytopathology 69: 112. Purcifull, D.E., Hiebert, E. and Edwardson, J.R.
(1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 293, 7 pp. Purcifull, D.E., Edwardson,
J.R., Hiebert, E. and Gonsalves, D. (1984). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.

(1984). Ph.D. Thesis, Cornell Univ., 98 pp. Yeh, S.D., Gonsalves, D. and
Provvidenti, R. (1984). Phytopathology 74: 1081.


Watermelon mosaic 2 potyvirus

      (1) D. Purcifull, 1981. (2) Synonyms: marrow mosaic virus (Raychaudhuri
and Varma, 1975; Varma, 1988), melon mosaic virus (Iwaki et al., 1984; Komuro,
1962), watermelon mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: WMV-2. (4) Strains:
soybean mosaic virus (Frenkel et al., 1989; Yu et al., 1989; and D.D. Shukla,
personal communication), indeed it is proposed that all are a single species
and should be called soybean mosaic virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.073.
(8) First reported in Citrullus lanatus. (10) By Webb et al. (1965). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Cucurbita pepo, Cucumis melo, C. sativus, Citrullus
lanatus and some legumes mosaic, mottling, leaf shape malformation. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Myzus persicae, Aphis craccivora; at least 29 species of aphids transmit
watermelon mosaic 2 potyvirus (Edwardson and Christie, 1986). (18) Transmitted
by Aphididae. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (37) Probably distributed worldwide. (41) Many (>9)
families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor chlorotic local lesions;
not systemic. Cucurbita pepo systemic mosaic and occasional leaf malformation.
Pisum sativum cv. Alaska necrotic local lesions; systemic mottling and
necrosis. Nicotiana benthamiana systemic mosaic. (44) Pisum sativum cv. Little
Marvel, Nicotiana glutinosa. (45) Cucurbita pepo cvs Small Sugar, Zucchini,
Nicotiana benthamiana. (46) Abelmoschus esculentus, Chenopodium amaranticolor,
C. quinoa, Lavatera trimestris (L). (47) Abelmoschus esculentus, or Amaranthus
caudatus, or Astragalus sinicus, or Atriplex hortensis, or Capsella
bursa-pastoris, or Cassia occidentalis, or Catharanthus roseus, or Celosia
argentea, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
foetidum, or Chenopodium foliosum, or Chenopodium hybridum, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cichorium endiva, or Citrullus lanatus, or
Coriandrum sativum, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
metuliferus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata,
or Cucurbita okeechobeensis, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or
Datura stramonium, or Euphorbia marginata, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena
globosa, or Ipomoea nil, or Lathyrus odoratus, or Lavatera trimestris, or
Luffa acutangula, or Lupinus albus, or Lupinus angustifolius, or Macroptilium
lathyroides, or Macrotyloma uniflorum, or Medicago hispida, or Medicago
sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Melilotus officinalis, or Nicotiana
benthamiana, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
megalosiphon, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum,
or Senecio vulgaris, or Sesamum indicum, or Sonchus oleraceus, or Spinacia
oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Torenia fournieri, or Trifolium
incarnatum, or Trifolium pratense, or Valeriana officinalis, or Vicia faba, or
Vicia sativa, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata ssp. cylindrica, or
Zinnia elegans. (48) Beta macrocarpa, or Beta vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or
Cheiranthus cheiri, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Ocimum basilicum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Pisum sativum <cv. Little Marvel>, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vigna
angularis. (50) Amaranthaceae <3/3>, or Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae
<9/11>, or Compositae <4/4>, or Convolvulaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/2>, or
Cucurbitaceae <9/9>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae
<1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <21 /22>, or Malvaceae <2/2>, or
Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6/8>, or
Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>, or Valerianaceae <1/1>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <2/11>, or Cruciferae <1/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <2/22>, or Solanaceae <3/8>, or Tropaeolaceae
<1/1>. (53) Edwardson (1974); Horváth et al. (1975); Greber (1978); Hampton et
al. (1978); Horváth (1979); Lecoq et al. (1981); Edwardson and Christie

      (1) A.A.Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: WWBV. (5) ICTV decimal code
74.0.2.0.013. (8) First reported in water from the River Weddel. (9) From

Welsh onion yellow stripe (?) potyvirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (2) Synonyms: onion yellow dwarf virus Brazil
(Costa et al., 1971), onion yellow dwarf virus Japan (Fukami et al., 1989;
Sako et al., 1991; Yoshino and Yasu, 1965). (5) ICTV decimal code

(10) By Van Dijk and Sutarya (1992). (13) Allium chinense (rakkyo), A.
fistulosum (Welsh onion) yellow leaf striping. (14) Transmitted by a vector.
(16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae,
Rhopalosiphum maidis, Acyrthosiphon pisum. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25)
Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (39) Spreads in Brazil, Indonesia, and Japan. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Allium fistulosum, A. vineale (crow garlic)
systemic yellow leaf striping. Allium cepa var. cepa (onion) cv. Stuttgarter
Riesen bright systemic leaf striping, leaf distortion and stunting.
Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa local chlorotic lesions, no systemic
infection. (44) Allium tuberosum (Chinese chive), A. sativum (garlic), A.
porrum (leek). (45) Allium cepa var. cepa cv. Stuttgarter Riesen. (46) Allium
cepa var. cepa cv. Stuttgarter Riesen. (47) Allium cepa, or Allium cepa var.

A.S., Costa, C.L., Nagani, H. and Kitajima, E.W. (1971). O. Biologica 37: 157.

Wheat American striate mosaic nucleorhabdovirus

      (1) R.G. Timian, 1987. (2) Synonyms: oat rhabdovirus, oat striate
rhabdovirus, oat striate mosaic virus, American wheat striate mosaic virus,
wheat striate mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: WASMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
62.0.4.0.009. (8) First reported in Triticum vulgare. (9) From South Dakota,
U.S.A. (10) By Slykhuis (1953). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Triticum dicoccum,
T. vulgare, T. durum, Bromus inermis, Eragrostis cilianensis, Panicum
capillare faint chlorotic streaks along the veins, clearest on the abaxial
surfaces of leaves, then necrosis. Brown necrotic spots and streaks develop in
some cultivars. Wheat plants die or become stunted with sterile heads. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Elymana virescens and Endria inimica. (18) Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner. (26) Virus lost by the vector when it
moults. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36)
Studies reported by Slykhuis (1953); Slykhuis (1963). (38) Spreads in the
North American region. (39) Spreads in Canada and the USA. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show severe
striate mosaic. (43) Avena sativa, Eragrostis cilianensis, Panicum capillare
and Triticum durum severe chlorotic striping. Hordeum vulgare and Zea mays
mild chlorotic striping. (44) Triticum vulgare. (45) Bromus inermis, Triticum
durum. (46) Triticum durum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Bromus inermis, or
Bromus secalinus, or Bromus tectorum, or Echinochloa crus-galli, or Eragrostis
cilianensis, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or
Panicum capillare, or Panicum miliaceum, or Secale cereale, or Setaria
viridis, or Triticum dicoccum, or Triticum durum, or Triticum vulgare, or Zea
mays. (48) Agrostis alba, or Dactylis glomerata, or Elytrigia intermedia, or
Elytrigia repens, or Phleum pratense, or Poa compressa, or Poa pratensis, or
Triticum vulgare. (50) Gramineae <17/24>. (51) Gramineae <8/24>. (52) Few
species tested, none of them dicotyledons. (53) Slykhuis (1953); Slykhuis
(1963). (54) TIP: 55 °C. (55) LIV: 3 days <at 4°C or -10°C>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 5. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: fix
with gluteraldehyde before mounting in PTA. (60) Method: Ahmed et al. (1970),
for infective virus; Thottappilly and Sinha (1973) for antigen. (61) Virions
rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (68) Virions usually straight.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 200-250 nm. (71)
Virions 75 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obvious. (73) Axial canal 23 nm in
diameter. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations, or two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 875 S <major component>. (84) Virions contain 5 %
nucleic acid. (85) Virions 68 % protein. (86) Virions 25 % lipid. (87) Also
carbohydrate (probably) 2%. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 7 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest
(or only) genome part 7 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Sinha et al.
(1976). (100) Base composition 26.4 % G. (101) Base composition 21.3 % A.
(102) Base composition 22.5 % C. (103) Base composition 29.8 % U. (132) Virion
protein(s) four. (133) Mr <of the largest> 145000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest
92000. (136) Glycoprotein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 59000. (138) N protein.
(139) Mr of 4th largest 25000. (145) Method of preparation: Trefzger et al.
(1976). (147) Amino acid composition: Sinha et al. (1976). (164) Genome
replicates in nuclei and in cytoplasm <associated with the nuclear membrane
and within cytoplasmic cisternae>. (166) Replication does not depend on a
helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots, mesophyll, epidermis,
vascular parenchyma, companion cells and all parts of the host plant. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm, in nuclei, and in the perinuclear space. (178)
Other cellular changes: the plasma membrane separating from the cell wall.
(179) Nucleorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae. (180) : Rhabdoviridae. (185) Best
tests for diagnosis: Wheat streak mosaic rymovirus is transmitted mechanically
and by mites whereas wheat striate mosaic cytorhabdovirus is transmitted by
Endria inimica but not mechanically. (187) Ahmed, M.E., Sinha, R.C. and
Hochster, R.M. (1970). Virology 41: 768. Sinha, R.C. and Behki, R.M. (1972).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 99, 4 pp. Sinha, R.C., Harwalkar, V.R. and
Behki, R.M. (1976). Phytopath. Z. 87: 314. Slykhuis, J.T. (1953).

Thottappilly, G. and Sinha, R.C. (1973). Virology 33: 312. Trefzger-Stevens,
J. and Lee, P. (1976). Virology 78: 144.

Wheat dwarf monogeminivirus

      (1) K. Lindsten, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: WDV. (4) Strains: barley
and wheat strains. (5) ICTV decimal code 29.0.1.0.012. (8) First reported in
Triticum aestivum. (9) From the former Czechoslovakia. (10) By Vacke (1961).
(11) Symptoms persist. (12) Symptoms yellowing and dwarfing. (13) Avena sativa
yellowing and dwarfing. Hordeum vulgare yellowing and dwarfing, poor cropping.
Lolium multiflorum, Poa annua growth reduction. Secale cereale, Triticum
aestivum yellowing and severe dwarfing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Psammotettix alienus. (18)
Transmitted by Cicadellidae. (24) Not transmitted by Javesella pellucida,
Laodelphax striatellus, Macrosteles laevis. (25) Transmitted in a persistent
manner. (26) Virus retained when the vector moults. (27) Virus does not
multiply in the vector. (28) Virus not transmitted congenitally to the progeny
of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Lindsten
(1980; 1991). (39) Spreads in Bulgaria, the former Czechoslovakia, France,
Hungary, and the former USSR. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in
Sweden. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected
plants mostly show yellowing and severe dwarfing. (43) Avena sativa yellowing
and dwarfing. Bromus secalinus yellowing, plants die prematurely. Hordeum
vulgare dwarfing, poor heads and yellowing. Lolium perenne symptomless. L.
remotum yellowing. Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum yellowing and severe
dwarfing, no crop. (44) Dactylis glomerata, Festuca spp., Phleum pratense, Poa
pratensis, Zea mays. (45) Lolium multiflorum, Poa annua, Triticum aestivum,
Hordeum vulgare for the barley strain. (46) Bromus secalinus (W), Lagurus
ovatus (W), Triticum aestivum (W), Hordeum vulgare (W). (47) Avena sativa, or
Avena strigosa, or Bromus secalinus, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lagurus ovatus, or
Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Lolium remotum, or Lolium
temulentum, or Poa annua, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum
durum. (48) Bromus inermis, or Bromus mollis, or Dactylis glomerata, or
Echinochloa crus-galli, or Elytrigia repens, or Festuca pratensis, or Phalaris
arundinacea, or Phleum pratense, or Poa pratensis, or Setaria italica, or
Setaria viridis, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <13/25>. (51) Gramineae <12/25>.
(53) Lindsten (1991); Vacke (1972). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Bisztray et al. (1989); Lindsten et al. (1980). (61) Virions geminate.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 18 nm in diameter. (65) Virions 30 nm
in length. (66) Virions angular in profile. (67) Virions without a conspicuous
capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting component in purified
preparations, or two sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 70 S. (78) Of the other(s) 50 S. (83) A260/A280
ratio 1.3-1.4. (84) Virions contain 20 % nucleic acid. (88) Genome consists of
DNA. (89) Singlestranded. (90) Circular. (91) Total genome size 2.749 kb. (92)
Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2.749 kb. (108)
Infectivity lost when deproteinised with proteases. (117) NCBI Taxon ID:
10834. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): D00305 Em(40)_vi:GEWDVASD
Gb(84)_vi:WDVASD Wheat dwarf virus (WDV), virion-associated small DNA. 4/90
80bp. X02869 Em(40)_vi:GEWDVXX Gb(84)_vi:GEWDVXX Wheat dwarf virus (WDV)
genome. 9/93 2,749bp. X82104 Em(43)_vi:Wdvgns Gb(89)_vi:Wdvgns Wheat dwarf
virus genes for V1, V2, C1-1, C1-2 and Cx. 10/94 2,750bp. (119) Features of
the genome: see MacDowell et al. (1985); Matzeit et al. (1990); Woolston et
al. (1988). (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (123)
Subgenomic mRNA not found in infected cells. (132) Virion protein(s) one.
(133) Mr 28000. (164) Genome replicates in nuclei. (166) Replication does not
depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and roots. (172)
Virions found in nuclei. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Monogeminivirus: Geminiviridae. (180) : Geminiviridae. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: chloris striate mosaic and maize streak
viruses. (183) Triticum aestivum (wheat) and Hordeum vulgare (barley) react
differently to infection with the common and barley strains. The barley strain
causes dwarfing, poor heads and yellowing in barley, but which is resistant to
wheat strains. (184) Not serologically related to other geminiviruses tested.
(185) Best tests for diagnosis: transmission by Psammotettix alienus to wheat
and barley plants, and serological tests. (187) Bisztray, G., Gaborjanyi, D.
and Gaborjanyi, R. (1989). Z. PflKrankh. PflSchutz. 96: 449. Lindsten, K.,
Vacke, J. and Gerhardson, B. (1970). Nat. Swedish Inst. Pl. Prot. Contr. 14:
281. Lindsten, K. (1980). Vaxtskyddsnotiser 44: 54. Lindsten, K. (1985).
Abstr. A.A.B. Virol. Gp., Cambridge p. 36. Lindsten, K. (1991). In: Proc. 6th

K., Lindsten, B., Abdelmoeti, M. and Junti, N. (1980). In: Proc. 3rd. Conf. on
Virus Diseases of Gramineae in Europe, Rothamsted, May 1980. MacDowell, S.W.,

Wheat European striate mosaic (?) tenuivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1992. (2) Synonyms: European wheat striate mosaic virus,
oat striate and red disease virus (Lindsten, 1961). (3) Standard acronym:
EWSMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.T.007. (8) First reported in Triticum
aestivum. (9) From Europe. (10) By Slykhuis and Watson (1958). (13) Lolium
perenne, Triticum aestivum chlorotic spotting and streaking of leaves, general
chlorosis, stunting and death of plants. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Javesella pellucida, J. dubia,
J. obscurella. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25) Transmitted in a
persistent manner. (27) Virus multiplies in the vector. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (36) Studies reported by Ammar (1975); Lindsten
(1979). (39) Spreads in the former Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, Germany,
Poland, Romania, Spain, Sweden, and the UK. (43) Avena sativa, Hordeum
vulgare, Lolium multiflorum, L. perenne, Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum
chlorotic spotting and fine chlorotic streaking of leaves, general chlorosis.
(45) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum. (46)
Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium
multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum. (50)
Gramineae <6/6>. (53) Slykhuis and Watson (1958); Ikäheimo (1964); Vacke and
PrusHa (1961). (60) Method: Serjeant (1967). (61) Virions filamentous. (63)
Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with no
clear modal length. (71) Virions 3 nm wide. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <less than> 178 S. (171)
Virions found in leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm.
(177) They do not contain virions. (179) <Possible> Tenuivirus. (187) Ammar,
E.-D. (1974). Riv. Patol. Veg. 10: 143. Ammar, E.-D. (1975). Ann. appl. Biol.
79: 195. Ammar, E.-D. (1975). Ann. appl. Biol. 79: 203. BrcHak, J. (1979). In:
Leafhopper Vectors and Plant Disease Agents, p. 97; eds K. Maramorosch and
K.F. Harris. Academic Press, New York. Gingery, R.E. and Plumb, R. (1988). In:
The Plant Viruses, Vol. 4, The Filamentous Viruses, p. 297; ed. R.G. Milne.
Plenum Press, New York. Ikäheimo, K. (1964). Ann. Phytopath. Fenniae 3: 133.
Lindsten, K. (1961). Ann. Roy. agric. College, Sweden 27: 199. Lindsten, K.
(1979). In: Leafhopper Vectors and Plant Disease Agents, p. 155; eds K.
Maramorosch and K.F. Harris. Plenum Press, New York. Nuorteva, P. (1965).
Zool. Beitr. (N.F.) 11: 191. Serjeant, E.P. (1967). Ann. appl. Biol. 59: 39.
