and PrusHa, V. (1961). Biol. Plant 3: 277. Watson, M.A. and Sinha, R.C.
(1959). Virology 8: 139.


Wheat Iranian stripe (?) tenuivirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (5) ICTV decimal code 69.0.1.T.DE.5. (8) First
reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From Iran. (10) By Heydarnejad and
Izadpanah (1989). (47) Triticum aestivum. (50) Gramineae <1/1>. (179)
<Possible> Tenuivirus. (187) Heydarnejad, J. and Izadpanah, K. (1989). Proc.
9th Pl. Prot. Congr. Iran, p.160. Ferdowsi Univ., Mashad, Iran.


Wheat soil-borne mosaic furovirus

      (1) A.J. Gibbs, 1995. (2) Synonyms: wheat viruses 1 and 2, soil-borne
wheat green mosaic virus, wheat mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: SBWMV. (4)
Strains: green mosaic, yellow mosaic and rosette strains. (5) ICTV decimal
code 27.0.1.0.005. (8) First reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From the
U.S.A. (10) By McKinney (1923). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally <brightest in
spring>. (13) Triticum aestivum (winter wheat) and Hordeum vulgare light green
to yellow leaf mosaic, roots stunted, severe rosetting and tillering of
susceptible cultivars (Brakke, 1971). (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis; Estes and
Brakke (1966). (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales <Brakke, 1971>. (31)
Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (36) Studies reported by Himmel et al. (1991). When the virus is
transmitted to plants of resistant cultivars by growing them in infested soil,
their roots are as susceptible as those of other cultivars, but the virus does
not spread systemically (Myers et al. 1993). (39) Spreads in China, Italy,
Japan, and the USA <Cai et al. (1983); Canova (1966); Putnam et al. (1994);
Saito et al. (1964)>. (41) Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Triticum
aestivum and other Triticum spp. mosaic and rosetting. (44) Elytrigia repens,
Avena sativa, Bromus inermis, Cucumis sativus, Lycopersicon esculentum,
Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris, Zea mays. (45) Triticum aestivum cv.
Michigan Amber and others. (46) Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L),
Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Bromus commutatus, or Bromus tectorum, or
Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Avena byzantina, or Avena sativa,
or Bromus inermis, or Cucumis sativus, or Elytrigia repens, or Lycopersicon
esculentum, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Zea mays. (50)
Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Gramineae <5/10>. (51) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>, or
Gramineae <5/10>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <2/2>.
(54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 4000 days <at least, in dried leaves>. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Gumpf
(1971). (61) Virions rodshaped. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions
usually straight. (69) Virions with clear modal lengths. (70) Virions of
82-110 nm <T>, or 138-160 nm <M>, or 280-300 nm <B>. (71) Virions 20 nm wide.
(72) Axial canal obvious. (76) Two sedimenting components in purified
preparations, or three sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77)
Sedimentation coefficient 212 S <of the fastest>. (78) Of the other(s) 173 S.
(83) A260/A280 ratio 1.2. (84) Virions contain 5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions
95 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (92) Genome of two parts <Shirako and Brakke,
1984>. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 6.5 kb. (94) The 2nd largest 3.5 kb.
(117) NCBI Taxon ID: 28375. (118) Sequence database accession code(s): L07937
Em(40)_vi:WMORNA1A Gb(84)_vi:WMORNA1A Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus (SBWMV)
complete RNA 1 segment: 150 kDa protein, 209 kDa readth L07938
Em(40)_vi:WMORNA2A Gb(84)_vi:WMORNA2A Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus (SBWMV)
complete RNA 2 segment: 84 kDa readthrough protein, 19 X81639 Gb(84)n:SBWMV19K
Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus genomic RNA2. 9/94 3,592bp. X89078
Em(44)n:Sbwmvcoat Gb(90)_vi:Sbwmvcoat Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus gene for
coat protein. 6/95 666bp. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid found in the virions.
(122) Nongenomic nucleic acid deletion variants of the genomic RNAs. (132)
Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 19700. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions found
in roots and, occasionally, leaves. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm and amorphous Xbodies.
(179) Furovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: tobacco
mosaic tobamovirus (Brunt and Shikata, 1986). (183) Isolates vary greatly in
virion lengths, those from Japan are serologically related to those from the
U.S.A., but infect Nicotiana tabacum and Zea mays. (187) Brakke, M.K. (1971).
CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 77. 4 pp. Brunt, A.A. and Richards, K.E.
(1989). Adv. Virus Res. 36: 1. Brunt, A.A. and Shikata, E. (1986). In: The
Plant Viruses, No. 2 The Rod-Shaped Plant Viruses eds M.H.V. van Regenmortel
and H. Fraenkel-Conrat, p. 305, Plenum Press, New York. Cai, W., Peng, X. and
Mang, K. (1983). Acta Phytopathol. Sin. 13: 7. Canova, A. (1966). Phytopathol.
Medit. 5: 53. Gumpf, D.J. (1971). Virology 43: 586. Himmel, P.T., Hewings,
A.D. and Glawe, D.A. (1991). Plant Dis. 75: 1008. McKinney, H.H. (1923). J.
Agric. Res. 23: 771. Myers, L.D., Sherwood, J.L., Siegerist, W.C. and Hunger,
R.M. (1993). Phytopathology 83: 548. Putnam, M.L., Carroll, T.W. and French,
R. (1994). Plant Dis. 78: 102. Saito, Y., Takanashi, K., Iwata, Y. and
Okamoto, H. (1964). Bull. Natl. Inst. Agric. Sci., Tokyo, Ser. C 1964: 1711.
Shirako, Y. and Brakke, M.K. (1984). J. gen. Virol. 65: 119. Shirako, Y. and
Wilson, T.M.A. (1992). Virology 195: 16.


Wheat spindle streak mosaic bymovirus

      (1) K.Z. Haufler, 1988. (3) Standard acronym: WSSMV. (4) Strains: wheat
yellow mosaic virus (Usugi and Saito, 1979; Wiese, 1987). (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.3.0.006. (8) First reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From Ontario,
Canada. (10) By Slykhuis (1960). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally and disappear
soon after infection <symptoms develop best at 20°C or less>. (13) Secale
cereale, Triticum aestivum, T. durum chlorotic streaking. (14) Transmitted by
a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa graminis.
(21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical
inoculation <but not readily>. (32) Virus not transmitted by grafting. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Slykhuis
(1970); Slykhuis (1974); Wiese et al. (1974); Haufler and Fulbright (1986);
Van Koevering et al. (1987). (39) Spreads in France, Germany, India, Italy,
Japan, and the USA <possibly also China>. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible
<No susceptible dicotyledonous species are known>. (43) Secale cereale,
Triticum aestivum, T. durum chlorotic streaking. (45) Triticum aestivum. (46)
Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum, or Triticum
durum. (50) Gramineae <3/3>. (53) Slykhuis (1961); Slykhuis (1970); Jackson et
al. (1976); Proeseler and Stanarius (1983); Bays et al. (1985). (54) TIP:
45-50 °C <for 10 minutes>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 1-5. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions. (60) Method: Haufler and Fulbright (1985; unpublished). (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous
<but only slightly>. (69) Virions with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of
300-2000 nm <modal length probably 700-1000 nm>. (71) Virions 16 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) One sedimenting component
in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.28 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density
1.20-1.21 g cm3 in caesium sulphate. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35285. (118)
Sequence database accession code(s): X73883 Gb(84)_vi:WSSMVRNA Wheat spindle
streak mosaic virus RNA. 6/94 4,646bp. (132) Virion protein(s) three. (133) Mr
<of the largest> 35000-36000. (135) Mr of 2nd largest 30000. (136) Coat
protein. (137) Mr of 3rd largest 27000. (138) Coat protein. (154) Mr 69000.
(155) Cytoplasmic inclusion protein. (171) Virions found in leaves, roots,
mesophyll and vascular parenchyma. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (177)
They do not contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: disruption of
organelles (chloroplasts, mitochondria swell and then are disrupted). (179)
Bymovirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: barley yellow mosaic, oat mosaic and rice
necrosis mosaic; wheat spindle streak and wheat yellow mosaic viruses are now
considered the one species. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Symptoms of the
virus appear first in the spring, those of barley yellow dwarf virus and wheat
streak mosaic virus appear later, those of wheat soil-borne mosaic virus are
also brightest in cool weather, but are brighter. (186) Although this virus is
probably a strain of wheat yellow mosaic bymovirus, it is listed separately
here. (187) Bays, D.C., Cunfer, B.M. and Demski, J.W. (1985). Plant Dis. 69:
1094. Haufler, K., Zagula, K.R. and Fulbright, D.W. (1986). Plant Dis. 70: 31.
Haufler, K., Zagula, K.R. and Fulbright, D.W. (1985). Phytopathology 75: 1349.
Jackson, A.O. et al. (1976). Pl. Dis. Reptr 60: 202. Proeseler, G. and
Stanarius, A. (1983). Arch. Phytopathol. Pflanzenschutz, Berlin 19: 345.
Slykhuis, J.T. (1960). Can. Pl. Dis. Surv. 40: 43. Slykhuis, J.T. (1961). Can.
Pl. Dis. Surv. 41: 330. Slykhuis, J.T. (1970). Phytopathology 60: 319.
Slykhuis, J.T. (1974). Phytopathology 64: 554. Slykhuis, J.T. (1976). CMI/AAB
Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 167, 3 pp. Usugi, Y. and Saito, Y. (1976). Ann.
Phytopath. Soc. Japan 42: 12. Van Koevering, M., Haufler, Z., Fulbright, D.W.,
Isleib, T.C. and Everson, E.H. (1987). Phytopathology 77: 742. Weise, M.V.
(1987). Compendium of Wheat Diseases 2nd Ed. Amer. Phytopath. Soc. St Paul,
Minnesota. Wiese, M.V., Ravenscroft, A.V. and Everson, E.H. (1974). Pl. Dis.
Reptr 58: 522.


Wheat streak mosaic rymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1995. (3) Standard acronym: WSMV. (4) Strains: Several
variants giving different symptoms have been described. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.2.0.006. (8) First reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From the U.S.A.
(10) By McKinney (1937). (13) Echinochloa, Panicum, Setaria spp. usually
severe mosaic. Triticum aestivum severe leaf mosaic, necrosis of tillers,
stunting and crop loss. Zea mays mild mosaic (some cultivars only). (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a mite. (17) Transmitted by
Aceria tulipae. (19) Transmitted by Eriophyidae. (28) Virus not transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus transmitted by seed <very low levels>. (36) Studies reported by
Slykhuis (1955); Ashworth and Futrell (1961); Orlob (1966); Nault and Styer
(1969). (39) Spreads in Canada, Jordan, Romania, and the USA. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (43) Avena sativa, Hordeum vulgare, Poa compressa,
Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum, Zea mays (some cultivars) systemic mosaic.
(44) Elytrigia repens, Bromus inermis, Hordeum jubatum, Saccharum officinarum,
Sorghum bicolor. (45) Triticum aestivum (especially cvs Michigan, Amber and
Kent). (46) Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Aegilops, or Agropyron, or Avena
sativa, or Bromus, or Digitaria, or Echinochloa, or Eragrostis, or Hordeum, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Lolium, or Panicum, or Phalaris, or Poa, or Poa compressa,
or Secale cereale, or Setaria, or Stipa, or Triticum aestivum, or Zea mays.
(48) Bromus inermis, or Elytrigia repens, or Hordeum jubatum, or Saccharum
officinarum, or Sorghum bicolor. (50) Gramineae <19/24>. (51) Gramineae
<5/24>. (54) TIP: 54 °C. (55) LIV: 4-8 days <at 20°C, 12 months at 2°C, and at
least 16 years in dried leaf at 2°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (60) Method:
Brakke and Ball (1968). (61) Virions filamentous. (69) Virions with a clear
modal length. (70) Virions of 700 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <c.> 165 S. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.37. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded. (91)
Total genome size 8.5 kb. (92) Genome unipartite. (93) Largest (or only)
genome part 8.5 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Zagula et al.
(1992). (116) Nucleotide sequence references: Niblett et al. (1991); Zagula et
al. (1992). (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 31741. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
47000. (134) Coat protein. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels. (179) Rymovirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: ryegrass mosaic, agropyron mosaic and oat necrotic mottle viruses.
(187) Ashworth, L.J. and Futrell, M.C. (1961). Pl. Dis. Reptr. 45: 220.
Brakke, M.K. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 48, 4 pp. Brakke, M.K. and
Ball, E.M. (1968). Virology 36: 152. Brakke, M.K., Ball, E.M., Hsu, Y.-H. and
Langenberg, W.G. (1987). J. gen. Virol. 68: 281. Brakke, M.K., Skopp, R.N. and

Wheat yellow leaf closterovirus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1984. (3) Standard acronym: WYLV. (5) ICTV decimal code
17.0.1.0.007. (8) First reported in Hordeum vulgare, Triticum aestivum. (9)
From Japan. (10) By Inouye et al. (1973). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Avena
sativa, Lolium multiflorum leaf reddening. Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale,
Triticum aestivum leaf yellowing. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Rhopalosiphum maidis, R. padi.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a semipersistent manner.
(26) Virus lost by the vector when it moults. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in Italy and Japan. (41) Few
(<3) families susceptible. (43) Avena sativa, Lolium multiflorum leaf
reddening. Hordeum vulgare, Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum leaf yellowing.
(44) Oryza sativa, Zea mays. (45) Avena sativa, Triticum aestivum. (46) Avena
sativa (W); Triticum aestivum (W). (47) Avena sativa, or Hordeum vulgare, or
Lolium multiflorum, or Lolium perenne, or Secale cereale, or Triticum
aestivum. (48) Oryza sativa, or Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <6/8>. (51) Gramineae
<2/8>. (53) Inouye (1976). (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method:
Inouye (1976). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with no clear modal length. (70) Virions of 1600-1850 nm. (71) Virions
10 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obvious. (75) Pitch of
basic helix 3.4 nm. (171) Virions found in phloem. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
membranous bodies. (179) Closterovirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically
related virions: carnation necrotic fleck and carnation yellow fleck viruses,
but distantly. (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated virions: burdock

Patologia Veg. S. I, 16: 9. Inouye, T., Mitsuhata, K., Heta, H. and Hiura, U.
(1973). Nogaku Kenkyu 55: 1.


Wheat yellow mosaic bymovirus

      (1) T. Inouye, 1991. (2) Synonyms: soil-borne wheat yellow mosaic virus.
(4) Strains: wheat spindle streak mosaic virus (Weise, 1987). (5) ICTV decimal
code 57.0.3.0.006. (8) First reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From Japan.
(10) By Sawada (1927). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms mosaic.
(13) Triticum aestivum mosaic; chlorotic to necrotic streaks. (14) Transmitted
by a vector. (16) Transmitted by a fungus. (17) Transmitted by Polymyxa
graminis probably. (21) Transmitted by Plasmodiophorales. (24) Not transmitted
by Macrosiphum akebiae, Onychiurus matsumotoi, O. watanabei. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted
by pollen. (36) Studies reported by Ikata and Kawai (1940); Saito et al.
(1964). (39) Spreads in Canada, China, France, Japan, Korea D.P.R. (North),
and Korea Republic. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show mosaic. (43) Secale cereale, Triticum aestivum
mosaic. (44) Chenopodium amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus, Hordeum vulgare,
Nicotiana tabacum, Zea mays. (45) Triticum aestivum. (46) Triticum aestivum
(W). (47) Secale cereale, or Triticum aestivum. (48) Chenopodium
amaranticolor, or Cucumis sativus, or Elymus tsukushiensis var. transiens, or
Hordeum vulgare, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Poa annua, or
Zea mays. (50) Gramineae <2/6>. (51) Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae
<1/1>, or Gramineae <4/6>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/1>. (53) Ikata and Kawai (1940); Saito et al. (1968); Inouye (1969). (54)
TIP: <less than> 50 °C. (55) LIV: 1 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Usugi and Saito (1976). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with clear modal lengths <two>. (70) Virions of 275-300 nm, or 575-600
nm. (71) Virions 13-14 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.281 g cm3 in CsCl. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.14. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 35285. (171) Virions found in all
parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions
present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are amorphous Xbodies, membranous
bodies, and pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Bymovirus:
Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related
virions: barley yellow mosaic and rice necrosis mosaic viruses. (187) Hariri,
D., Courtillot, M., Zaoni, P. and Lapierre, H. (1987). Agronomie 7: 789.
Hibino, H., Usugi, T. and Saito, Y. (1981). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 47:
510. Ikata, S. and Kawai, I. (1940). Noji Kairyo Shiryo 154: 1. Inouye, T.
(1969). Nogaku Kenkyu 53:; 61. Lin, M.C. and Ruan, Y.L. (1986). Acta
Phytopath. Sinica 16: 73. Saito, Y., Tsuchizaki, T. and Hibino, H. (1968).
Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 34: 347. Sawada, E. (1927). Byochugai Zasshi 14:
444. Slykhuis, J.T. (1976). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 167. Usugi, T. and
Saito, Y. (1976). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 42: 12. Usugi, T. and Saito, Y.

Tsuchizaki, T. (1984). Ann. Phytopath. Soc. Japan 50: 63. Weise, M.V. (1987).

Minnesota.


White bryony mosaic (?) carlavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: bryony white mosaic virus. (3)
Standard acronym: WBMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 14.0.T.1.029. (8) First reported
in Bryonia dioica. (10) By Tomlinson and Carter (1969). (11) Symptoms persist.
(13) Bryonia dioica mosaic. (39) Spreads in the UK and France <Spire et al.,
1966; Quiot et al., 1979>. (47) Bryonia dioica. (50) Cucurbitaceae <1/1>. (61)
Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually
straight. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 650 nm. (71)
Virions 13 nm wide. (179) <Possible> Carlavirus. (186) Infected plants often
also contain a potyvirus. Four potyviruses, all causing conspicuous symptoms,
have been isolated from Bryonia spp; bryonia mottle virus occurs in Morocco
(Lockhart and Fischer, 1979), and the other three (P1, P2 and P3) were
isolated in northern Italy (Milne et al., 1980). The relationships of these
potyviruses are unknown. (187) Hollings, M., Stone, O.M. and Brunt, A.A.
(1967). Rep. Glasshouse Crops Res. Inst. 1966, p. 102. Lockhart, B.E.L. and
Fischer, H.U. (1979). Phytopath. Z. 96: 244. Milne, R.G., Masenga, V. and
Lovisolo, O. (1980). Phytopathol. Medit. 19: 115. Quiot, J.B., Douine, L. and
Gebre Selassie, K. (1979). Annls. Phytopath. 11: 283. Spire, D., Bertrand, J.
and Ferault, C. (1966). Ann. Epiphyt. 17: 121.

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1994. (3) Standard acronym: WBV. (5) ICTV decimal code

White clover 1 alphacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: red clover cryptic virus 1. (3)
Standard acronym: WCCV-1. (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3.0.016. (8) First
reported in Trifolium repens. (9) From Italy. (10) By Boccardo et al. (1985).

isometric. (63) Virions not enveloped. (64) Virions 30 nm in diameter. (66)

(92) Genome of two parts. (179) Alphacryptovirus: Partitiviridae <the type

White clover 2 betacryptovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: WCCV-2. (5) ICTV decimal
code 49.0.4.0.005. (8) First reported in Trifolium repens. (9) From Italy.
(10) By Boccardo et al. (1985). (13) Trifolium repens no symptoms. (31) Virus
not transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus not transmitted by
grafting. (34) Virus transmitted by seed. (40) Found, but with no evidence of
spread, in Europe, Japan, New Zealand and the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) None known. (45) Trifolium repens containing no other
viruses. (47) Trifolium repens. (50) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <1/1>. (60)
Method: Boccardo et al. (1985). (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 38 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) One sedimenting
component in purified preparations. (79) Density 1.375 g cm3 in CsCl. (83)
A260/A280 ratio 1.31. (84) Virions contain 24 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 76
% protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Doublestranded. (90) Linear. (91)
Total genome size 4.31 kb <pairs>. (92) Genome of two parts. (93) Largest (or
only) genome part <the larger> 2.238 kb <pairs>. (94) The 2nd largest 2.072 kb
<pairs>. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions
found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions absent from infected cells. (179)
Betacryptovirus: Partitiviridae <the type species>. (180) : Partitiviridae.
(181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: red clover 2 and hop
trefoil 2 betacryptoviruses. (184) Complementary cDNA probes to white clover 2
betacryptovirus failed to detect any homology with white clover 1 and 3
alphacryptoviruses. (186) This virus was originally described as white clover
temperate virus (Natsuaki et al., 1984), and was shown later to be a mixture
of white clover cryptic viruses 1, 2 and 3 (Natsuaki et al., 1986). (187)
Boccardo, G., Lisa, V. and Milne, R.G. (1983). In: Double-Stranded RNA
Viruses, p. 425; eds R.W. Compans and D.H.L. Bishop. Elsevier, New York.
Boccardo, G., Milne, R.G., Luisoni, E., Lisa, V. and Accotto, G.P. (1985).
Virology 147: 29. Boccardo, G., Lisa, V., Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1987).
Adv. Virus Res. 32: 171. Luisoni, E. and Milne, R.G. (1988). AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 332, 4 pp. Luisoni, E., Milne, R.G., Accotto, G.P. and Boccardo,
G. (1987). Intervirology 28: 144. Natsuaki, K.T., Natsuaki, T., Okuda, S.,
Teranaka, M., Yamashita, S. and Doi, Y. (1984). J. agric. Sci., Tokyo Nogyo

White clover mosaic potexvirus

      (1) P.L. Guy, 1980. Revised 1983. (2) Synonyms: clover mosaic virus, pea
wilt virus (Bos et al., 1959; Johnson, 1942). (3) Standard acronym: WClMV. (5)
ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.0.021. (8) First reported in Trifolium repens. (9)
From the U.S.A. (10) By Pierce (1935). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (13)
Trifolium spp. chlorotic mottling, streaking and systemic mosaic. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by contact
between plants. (34) Virus transmitted by seed <to 6% in Trifolium pratense>.
(37) Probably distributed worldwide <in temperate regions>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (43) Cucumis sativus necrotic local lesions. Phaseolus
vulgaris necrotic and chlorotic local lesions, systemic yellowing. Pisum
sativum chlorotic local lesions, leaf shape malformation. Trifolium spp.
systemic mosaic. Vicia faba necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. Vigna
unguiculata necrotic and chlorotic local lesions. (44) Chenopodium quinoa.
(45) Phaseolus vulgaris, Pisum sativum. (46) Phaseolus vulgaris. (47)
Antirrhinum majus, or Crotalaria spectabilis, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura stramonium, or Glycine max, or
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Medicago sativa, or Melilotus albus, or Nicotiana
debneyi, or Nicotiana megalosiphon, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana
sylvestris, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus, or Phaseolus vulgaris,
or Pisum sativum, or Trifolium hybridum, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Trifolium
pratense, or Trifolium repens, or Tropaeolum majus, or Vicia faba, or Vigna
unguiculata. (48) Amaranthus retroflexus, or Apium graveolens, or Beta
vulgaris, or Brassica oleracea var. capitata, or Calendula officinalis, or
Capsicum frutescens, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Matthiola incana, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana
tabacum, or Ricinus communis, or Solanum melongena, or Solanum nigrum, or
Tetragonia tetragonioides, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <14/14>, or Scrophulariaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<7/12>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/1>. (51) Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae
<3/3>, or Compositae <2/2>, or Cruciferae <2/2>, or Euphorbiaceae <1/1>, or
Solanaceae <5/12>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53)
Bancroft et al. (1960); Beczner and Vassanyi (1981). (54) TIP: 60 °C. (55)
LIV: 10-99 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4-5. (57) Infectivity of sap not
changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains many virions
<especially that from French bean, although often fewer in sap of infected
clover>. (60) Method: Francki and McLean (1968). (61) Virions filamentous.
(63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a
clear modal length. (70) Virions of 480 nm. (71) Virions 13 nm wide. (72)
Axial canal obscure. (73) Axial canal 3.5 nm in diameter. (74) Basic helix
obvious. (75) Pitch of basic helix 3.4 nm. (76) One sedimenting component in
purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient 119 S. (82) Isoelectric
point pH 4.5. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 94 %
protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 5.845 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 5.845 kb. (100) Base
composition 15.5 % G. (101) Base composition 31.8 % A. (102) Base composition
26.9 % C. (103) Base composition 25.7 % U. (106) 5' terminus of RNA has an
unusual type. (107) 5' terminus of RNA a nucleotide cap probably of the type
m7GpppG. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 12188. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): M18920 Em(40)_vi:WCP3EA Gb(84)_vi:WCP3EA White clover mosaic
potexvirus 3'-terminal RNA region encoding ORFs of 17K, 5' end; and of 13
X06728 Em(40)_vi:POWC1MVX Gb(84)_vi:POWC1MVX Potexvirus white clover mosaic
virus (WC1MV) RNA genome. 9/93 5,845bp. X16636 Em(40)_vi:POWCLMV4
Gb(84)_vi:POWCLMV4 White clover mosaic virus total genomic mRNA. 9/93 5,846bp.
3 sequences. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 14000-20000. (145) Method
of preparation: Miki et al. (1967); Koenig et al. (1971). (166) Replication
does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in all parts of the
host plant. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in
infected cells. (175) Inclusions are unusual in shape. (176) Cytoplasmic
banded bodies and few vesiculated aggregates. (177) They contain virions.
(179) Potexvirus. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions: potato
X, cactus X, hydrangea ringspot and clover yellow mosaic viruses, but
distantly. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: the banded body inclusions induced
by white clover mosaic virus are disrupted when preparing epidermal strips for
examination, but these inclusions distinguish white clover mosaic virus from
clover yellow mosaic virus. (187) Agrawal, H., Bos, L. and Chessin, M. (1962).
Phytopathology 62: 517. Bancroft, J.B., Tuite, J. and Hissong, G. (1960).
Phytopathology 50: 711. Beczner, L. and Vassanyi, R. (1981). Acta Phytopath.
Acad. Sci. Hung. 16: 109. Bos, L., Delvic, B. and van der Want, J.P.H. (1959).
Tijdschr. PlZiekt. 65: 89. Bucks, R. (1971). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No.
41, 4 pp. Edwardson, J.R. and Christie, R.G. (1986). Fla Agric. Exp. Stn
Monog. No. 14, p. 350. Forster, R.L.S., Bevan, M.V., Harrison, S.A. and
Gardner, R.C. (1988). Nucl. Acids Res. 16: 291. Francki, R.I.B. and McLean,
G.D. (1968). Aust. J. biol. Sci. 21: 1311. Fry, P.R., Grogan, R.G. and

and Knight, C.A. (1967). Virology 31: 55. Pierce, W.H. (1935). J. Agric. Res.
51: 1017.

Wild cucumber mosaic tymovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and A.J. Gibbs, 1989. (2) Synonyms: cucumber wild mosaic
tymovirus. (3) Standard acronym: WCMV. (5) ICTV decimal code 77.0.1.0.018. (8)
First reported in Marah macrocarpus. (9) From California, U.S.A. (10) By
Freitag (1952). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Marah macrocarpus, Marah oreganus,
Echinocystis sp. mild leaf chlorosis. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Acalymma trivittata. (18)
Transmitted by Coleoptera. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(32) Virus transmitted by grafting. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact
between plants. (39) Spreads in the USA <California and Oregon>. (41) Several
(3-9) families susceptible. (43) Cucurbita pepo, C. maxima, Citrullus lanatus,
Cucumis sativus chlorotic local lesions and systemic chlorosis. Catharanthus
roseus symptomless systemic infection. (44) Nicotiana tabacum, N. glutinosa,
Datura stramonium, Vigna unguiculata, Chenopodium amaranticolor. (45)
Cucurbita pepo (pumpkin and zucchini), Citrullus lanatus. (46) Citrullus
vulgaris (L) for some isolates, Cucumis melo (L) for some isolates. (47)
Catharanthus roseus, or Citrullus lanatus, or Citrullus vulgaris, or Cucumis
melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or
Echinocystis, or Marah macrocarpus, or Marah oreganus. (48) Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Datura
stramonium, or Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Vigna
unguiculata. (50) Apocynaceae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <9/9>. (51)
Chenopodiaceae <1/1>, or Cruciferae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<1/1>, or Solanaceae <3/3>. (53) Lindberg et al. (1956); Milne et al. (1969).
(54) TIP: 70 °C. (55) LIV: <more than> 28 days <at 20°C>. (56) DEP: log10
minus 4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether.
(58) Leaf sap contains many virions. (59) Electron microscopy: stable in all
stains. (60) Method: chloroform/nbutanol clarification, concentrated by PEG
then differentail centrifugation. (61) Virions isometric. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (64) Virions 28 nm in diameter. (66) Virions rounded in profile.
(67) Virions with a conspicuous capsomere arrangement. (76) Two sedimenting
components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation coefficient <of the
fastest> 119 S <possibly>. (78) Of the other(s) 53 S <possibly>. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 5.2. (84) Virions contain 35 % nucleic acid <B>. (85)
Virions 65 % protein <B>. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89) Singlestranded.
(90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 2 kb <6.3 kilobases>. (92) Genome
unipartite. (93) Largest (or only) genome part 2 kb. (99) Genomic nucleic acid
isolated by : standard methods. (100) Base composition 16.4 % G. (101) Base
composition 17 % A. (102) Base composition 41 % C. (103) Base composition 25.6
% U. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or detergent.
(132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 22200. (134) Coat protein. (171) Virions
found in mesophyll and all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found in
cytoplasm and in chloroplasts <in chronically infected leaves>. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the
cytoplasm. (177) They contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes:
development of vesicles in chloroplasts. (179) Tymovirus. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: ononis yellow mosaic and turnip yellow mosaic
viruses are most closely related; eggplant mosaic, Andean potato latent,
belladona mottle, dulcamara mottle, scrophularia mottle, okra mosaic and
desmodium yellow mottle viruses are related. (182) Virus(es) with
serologically unrelated virions: kennedya yellow mosaic, clitoria yellow vein
and cacao yellow mosaic viruses. (187) Allen, T.C. (1972). Virology 47: 467.
Allen, T.C. and Fernald, E.K. (1971). Pl. Dis. Reptr 55: 546. Brunt, A.A.,
Kenten, R.H., Gibbs, A.J. and Nixon, H. (1965). J. gen. Microbiol. 33: 81.
Freitag, J.H. (1952). Phytopathology 42: 8. Koenig, R. (1976). Virology 72: 1.
Lindberg, G.D., Hall, D.H. and Walker, J.C. (1956). Phytopathology 46: 489.
Macleod, R. and Markham, R. (1963). Virology 19: 190. Milne, K.S., Grogan,
R.G. and Kimble, K.A. (1969). Phytopathology 59: 819. Sinclair, J.B., Geil,
P.H. and Kaesberg, P. (1957). Phytopathology 47: 372. Walkers, H.J. (1969).
Adv. Virus Res. 15: 339. Van Regenmortel, M.H.V. (1972). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl.
Viruses No. 105, 4 pp.


Wild potato mosaic potyvirus

      (1) R.A.C. Jones and C.E. Fribourg, 1989. (2) Synonyms: potato wild
mosaic potyvirus. (3) Standard acronym: WPMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.T.093. (8) First reported in Solanum chancayense. (9) From Lachay in
the Peruvian coastal desert. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Solanum chancayense
severe leaf mosaic and deformation. Solanum muricatum (pepino) chlorotic
mosaic, rugosity and enations. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted
by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Myzus persicae. (18) Transmitted by
Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted
by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus not transmitted by contact between
plants. (36) Studies reported by Jones and Fribourg (1979); Jones (1981). (39)
Spreads in Peru. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42) Experimentally
infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles, ringspots or necrosis
leaf deformation. (43) Nicotiana clevelandii systemic mosaic. Nicotiana
bigelovii blotchy systemic mosaic with twisting and deformation of young
leaves. Nicotiana occidentalis systemic vein clearing, mosaic and leaf
curling. Nicotiana rustica chlorotic blotches with brown necrotic rings;
occasional systemic chlorotic leaf blotching. Solanum chancayense, S.
mochiquense systemic mosaic and deformation. (44) Solanum tuberosum, Datura
stramonium, Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium amaranticolor, Cucumis sativus.
(45) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. bigelovii, N. occidentalis, Solanum
chancayense. (46) Nicotiana clevelandii (W) and N. bigelovii (W). (47)
Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicandra physalodes, or Nicotiana benthamiana, or
Nicotiana bigelovii, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana occidentalis, or Nicotiana rustica, or
Nicotiana tabacum, or Physalis floridana, or Solanum berthaultii, or Solanum
brachycarpum, or Solanum chacoense, or Solanum chancayense, or Solanum
demissum, or Solanum megistacrolobum, or Solanum microdontum, or Solanum
mochiquense, or Solanum muricatum, or Solanum raphanifolium, or Solanum
vernei. (48) Amaranthus caudatus, or Anthriscus cerefolium, or Brassica
campestris ssp. pekinensis, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium
murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Clitoria ternatea, or Coriandrum sativum, or
Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita pepo, or Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, or Datura
stramonium, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon chilense, or Lycopersicon
pimpinellifolium, or Ocimum basilicum, or Phaseolus acutifolius, or Phaseolus
vulgaris, or Physalis peruviana, or Sesamum indicum, or Solanum demissum × S.
tuberosum, or Solanum tuberosum, or Vigna unguiculata, or Vigna unguiculata
ssp. cylindrica, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Solanaceae <22/28>. (51)
Amaranthaceae <2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <3/3>, or Compositae <1/1>, or
Cruciferae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Labiatae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <6/6>, or Pedaliaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae <6 /28>,
or Umbelliferae <2/2>. (53) Jones and Fribourg (1974); Jones et al. (1980).
(54) TIP: 60-65 °C. (55) LIV: 5-6 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 3-4. (58) Leaf
sap contains few virions. (59) Electron microscopy: neutral PTA stains virions
well. (60) Method: Fribourg (1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not
enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal
length. (70) Virions of 735 nm. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: Peru tomato, tobacco vein mottling, potato
Y, potato A, potato V, pepper veinal mottle, tobacco etch, henbane mosaic and
Colombian datura viruses. (183) Isolates from pepino may be a distinct strain.
They cause vein clearing, mosaic, leaf deformation and stunting in Nicotiana
glutinosa whereas the type isolate fails to infect this species. (184) Virions
of wild potato mosaic potyvirus were serologically most closely related to
those of Peru tomato virus, tobacco vein mottling virus, potato V virus and
potato Y virus. The type isolate of WPMV is readily distinguished from Peru
tomato virus, potato V virus and potato Y virus by its narrower host range,
distinctive symptoms and, unlike tobacco vein mottling virus, fails to infect
Nicotiana clevelandii (Fribourg and Nakashima, 1984; Jones and Fribourg, 1979;
Jones and Fribourg, 1986). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: No other viruses
known in Solanum chancayense. Other filamentous viruses in Solanum muricatum
(pepino) can be distinguished by electron microscopy and inoculation to
Solanum tuberosum (potato), which wild potato mosaic virus does not infect
(Jones et al., 1980; Dolby and Jones, 1988). (186) This virus was first found
in the `Lomas' vegetation of the Peruvian coastal desert, where, in the
winter, low lying clouds moisten the desert. Very few plant species survive in
this habitat, Solanum chancayense is one; it survives in summer as underground
tubers and some are infected with wild potato mosaic potyvirus. Spread from
plant to plant is by aphids. WPMV is also found in cultivated pepino in
irrigated coastal valleys, far from Lomas vegetation. There it is spread in
infected cuttings and from plant to plant by aphids. (187) Dolby, C.A. and
Jones, R.A.C. (1988). Ann. appl. Biol. 112: 231. Fribourg, C.E. (1979).
Phytopathology 69: 441. Fribourg, C.E. and Nakashima, J. (1984).
Phytopathology 74: 1363. Jones, R.A.C. (1981). In: Pests, Pathogens and
Vegetation, p. 89; ed. J.M. Thresh. Pitman, London. Jones, R.A.C. and
Fribourg, C.E. (1979). Phytopathology 69: 446. Jones, R.A.C. and Fribourg,
C.E. (1986). CMI/AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 316, 4 pp. Jones, R.A.C., Koenig,
R. and Lesemann, D.-E. (1980). Ann. appl. Biol. 94: 61.


Wineberry latent virus

      (1) A.T. Jones, 1991. (2) Synonyms: loganberry calico virus. (3)
Standard acronym: WLV. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.020. (8) First reported
in Rubus phoenicolasius. (9) From Scotland in imported material. (10) By Jones
(1977); Jones et al. (1990). (11) Symptoms vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms
chlorotic or yellow line pattern. (13) Rubus phoenicolasius symptomless.
However, it has been shown to induce calico disease-like symptoms in
blackberry. (24) Not transmitted by Macrosiphum euphorbiae. (31) Virus
transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (32) Virus transmitted by grafting.
(33) Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (35) Virus not transmitted by pollen. (39) Spreads in the
USA. (40) Found, but with no evidence of spread, in the U.K. (41) Few (<3)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show necrotic
or red local lesions. (43) Gomphrena globosa, Chenopodium album, C.
amaranticolor, C. ambrosioides, C. murale, C. quinoa necrotic local lesions.
(44) Nicotiana clevelandii, N. debneyi, N. glutinosa, N. tabacum, Phaseolus
vulgaris. (45) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa, Gomphrena globosa. (46)
Chenopodium amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L). (47) Beta macrocarpa, or
Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium ambrosioides,
or Chenopodium foetidum, or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Rubus phoenicolasius, or
Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia tetragonioides. (48) Apium graveolens, or
Datura stramonium, or Nicotiana clevelandii, or Nicotiana debneyi, or
Nicotiana glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia ×
hybrida, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Vicia faba. (50)
Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or Chenopodiaceae <8/8>, or Rosaceae <1/1>, or Solanaceae
<1/8>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3>, or
Solanaceae <7/8>, or Umbelliferae <1/1>. (53) Jones (1977). (54) TIP: <less
than> 70 °C. (55) LIV: <less than> 8 days <at 18°C>. (56) DEP: log10 minus
3-4. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with diethyl ether. (58)
Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Jones et al. (1990). (61) Virions
filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68) Virions usually flexuous. (69)
Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 620 nm. (71) Virions 12 nm
wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (76) <Sometimes> two
sedimenting components in purified preparations. (77) Sedimentation
coefficient 115-125 S. (79) Density 1.29 and 1.3 g cm3 in CsCl. (81) Density
1.25 and 1.26 g/cm3 in Cs2SO4. (83) A260/A280 ratio 1.26. (84) Virions contain
5 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions 95 % protein. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (90) Linear. (91) Total genome size 8.5 kb. (92) Genome
unipartite. (99) Genomic nucleic acid isolated by Jones: use proteinase K +
phenol. (120) Nongenomic nucleic acid not found in the virions. (125) 1 virus
specified dsRNA species found in infected cells. (126) Size of largest virus
specified dsRNA 17 kbp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr 31000. (145)
Method of preparation: Jones et al. (1990). (166) Replication does not depend
on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in leaves and all parts of the host
plant. (179) (Ungrouped). (182) Virus(es) with serologically unrelated
virions: 9 carlaviruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: ISEM and mechanical
inoculation to Chenopodium quinoa. (187) Jones, A.T. (1977). Ann. appl. Biol.
86: 199. Jones, A.T. (1985). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 304. Jones, A.T.,
Mitchell, M.J., McGavin, W.J. and Roberts, I.M. (1990). Ann. appl. Biol. 117:
571.


Winter wheat Russian mosaic (?) cytorhabdovirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt, 1991. (2) Synonyms: Russian winter wheat mosaic virus,
cereal mosaic virus. (3) Standard acronym: WWRMV (WWMV). (5) ICTV decimal code
62.U.P.0.055. (8) First reported in Triticum aestivum. (9) From the former
USSR. (10) By Sukhov (1943). (13) Triticum aestivum mosaic leaf symptoms. (14)
Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by
Psammotettix striatus, P. alienus. (18) Transmitted by Delphacidae. (25)
Transmitted in a persistent manner <circulative>. (28) Virus transmitted
congenitally to the progeny of the vector. (31) Virus not transmitted by
mechanical inoculation. (39) Spreads in the former USSR. (43) Triticum
aestivum mosaic leaf symptoms. (47) Triticum aestivum. (50) Gramineae <1/1>.
(61) Virions rhabdo or bulletshaped. (63) Virions enveloped. (69) Virions with
a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 260 nm. (71) Virions 60 nm wide
<Razvjazkina and Polyakova, 1967; 1969>. (171) Virions found in leaves. (172)
Virions found in cytoplasm. (179) <Probable> Cytorhabdovirus: Rhabdoviridae.
(180) : Rhabdoviridae. (187) Razvjaskina, G.M. and Poljakova, G.P. (1969).
Proc. 6th Conf. Czech. Pl. Virologists, Prague 1967. Czech. Acad. Sci.,
Prague, p. 129. Sukhov, K.S. (1943). C.R. (Dokl.) Acad. Sci. URSS 41: 73.
Shaskolskaya (1962). Zool. Zh. 41: 717.


Wisteria vein mosaic potyvirus

      (1) L. Bos, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: WVMV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.074. (8) First reported in Wisteria floribunda, W. sinensis. (9) From
the Netherlands and Italy. (10) By Bos (1970); Conti and Lovisolo (1970). (11)
Symptoms persist and vary seasonally. (12) Symptoms irregular vein mosaic.
(13) Wisteria floribunda, W. sinensis yellowing, vein clearing, flecking,
mottling or mosaic, some malformation. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16)
Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, Myzus
persicae. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent
manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (34) Virus not
transmitted by seed. (39) Spreads in the former Czechoslovakia, Italy, and the
Netherlands <and probably several other countries>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show
chlorotic, sometimes necrotic local lesions, sometimes followed by chlorotic
mottling to mosaic. (43) Atriplex hortensis, Chenopodium amaranticolor
chlorotic local lesions. Chenopodium quinoa chlorotic to yellow local lesions,
becoming green. Cicer arietinum chlorotic local lesions, then necrotic mosaic,
stunting and withering. Lupinus albus chlorotic, later necrotic, local lesions
followed by bright mosaic. Nicotiana clevelandii systemic chlorotic spots and
rings, sometimes faint chlorotic local lesions. N. tabacum cv. White Burley
chlorotic local lesions. Phaseolus vulgaris chlorotic, later necrotic local
lesions then, usually, systemic mottling, flecking or stippling. Pisum sativum
interveinal chlorotic spotting or mottling. Vicia faba chlorotic ring-like
local lesions; diffuse chlorotic systemic spots. (44) Beta vulgaris, Cucumis
sativus cv. Gele Tros, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, Vigna
unguiculata. (45) Pisum sativum, Nicotiana clevelandii. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), C. quinoa (L and W), Phaseolus vulgaris cv. Saxa (L and W).
(47) Atriplex hortensis, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium amaranticolor,
or Chenopodium murale, or Chenopodium quinoa, or Cicer arietinum, or
Crotalaria spectabilis, or Glycine max, or Gomphrena globosa, or Lathyrus
odoratus, or Lupinus albus, or Melilotus officinalis, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum, or Petunia × hybrida, or Phaseolus lunatus,
or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Pisum sativum, or Spinacia oleracea, or Tetragonia
tetragonioides, or Trifolium incarnatum, or Vicia faba, or Vicia sativa, or
Wisteria floribunda, or Wisteria sinensis, or Zinnia elegans. (48) Beta
vulgaris, or Capsicum annuum, or Cassia tora, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
pepo, or Datura stramonium, or Lycopersicon esculentum, or Nicotiana
glutinosa, or Nicotiana rustica, or Physalis floridana, or Trifolium pratense,
or Trifolium repens, or Vigna unguiculata. (50) Amaranthaceae <1/1>, or
Chenopodiaceae <6/7>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae
<14/17>, or Solanaceae <3/9>, or Tetragoniaceae <1/1>. (51) Chenopodiaceae
<1/7>, or Cucurbitaceae <2/2>, or Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/1>, or
Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/17>, or Solanaceae <6/9>. (53) Bos (1970); Conti
and Lovisolo (1970). (54) TIP: 55 °C, or 60 °C. (55) LIV: 2 days, or 12 days.
(56) DEP: log10 minus 3, or 5. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60)
Method: Bos (1970). (61) Virions filamentous. (68) Virions usually flexuous.
(69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750-775 nm. (72) Axial
canal obscure. (74) Basic helix obscure. (171) Virions found in leaves. (174)
Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are pinwheels and
unusual in shape. (176) Granular cytoplasmic inclusions. (177) They contain
virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es)
with serologically related virions: bean yellow mosaic, bean common mosaic and
clover yellow vein viruses. (185) Best tests for diagnosis: the virions of
WVMV are only distantly related serologically to those of bean yellow mosaic
virus and clover yellow vein virus when using polyclonal antisera. WVMV
differs from bean yellow mosaic virus in not infecting red clover and cowpea
and in infecting Chenopodium quinoa systemically. It differs from clover
yellow vein virus in not infecting cucumber (in which clover yellow vein virus
causes local lesions) and in not infecting white clover. (187) Bos, L. (1970).
Neth. J. Pl. Path. 96: 8. BrcHak, J. (1980). Biologia Pl. 22: 465. BrcHak, J.
and Králik, O. (1983). Zesz. probl. Postep. Nauk roln. 291: 69. Conti, M. and
Lovisolo, O. (1969/70). Riv. Patol. veg. Serie IV 5: 115. de Beni, P.V.
(1964). Ricerca Scientifica 34: 21.


Yam internal brown spot (?) badnavirus

      (1) A.A. Brunt and I.M. Roberts, 1987. (2) Synonyms: dioscorea
badnavirus. (5) ICTV decimal code 07.0.1.T.DE.3. (8) First reported in
Dioscorea alata. (9) From Barbados. (10) By Coursey (1967); Jeffers and
Headley (1967). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Dioscorea alata cv. White Lisbon
probably causes internal brown spot of tubers, either alone or together with
an uncharacterised potyvirus. (31) Virus not transmitted by mechanical
inoculation. (43) Dioscorea alata internal brown spots in tubers. (47)
Dioscorea alata. (50) Dioscoreaceae <1/1>. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions.
(59) Electron microscopy: virions often bind to cell debris. (61) Virions
bacilliform. (63) Virions not enveloped. (65) Virions 130 nm in length. (71)
Virions 29 nm wide. (171) Virions found in clusters in phloem parenchyma.
(172) Virions found in cytoplasm <close to the nuclei>. (174) Inclusions <may
be> present in infected cells <as clusters of virions bound together with
amorphous material>. (179) <Possible> Badnavirus. (187) Coursey, D.G. (1967).
J. Agric. Soc. Trinidad 67: 473. Harrison, B.D. and Roberts, I.M. (1973).
Trop. Agric., Trin. 50: 335. Jeffers, W. de C. and Headley, W. (1967). Minist.
Agric. Barbados Bull. 46: 7.


Yam mosaic potyvirus

      (1) J.C. Thouvenel, 1984; F. Nienhaus, 1987. (3) Standard acronym: YMV.
(5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.075. (8) First reported in Dioscorea
cayenensis. (9) From the Ivory Coast. (10) By Thouvenel and Fauquet (1977).
(11) Symptoms disappear soon after infection. (13) Dioscorea alata, D.
cayenensis, D. dumetorum, D. praehensilis, D. preussii, D. rotundata mosaic,
vein banding. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(17) Transmitted by Aphis craccivora, A. gossypii, Rhopalosiphum maidis,
Toxoptera citricidus. (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a
nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33)
Virus not transmitted by contact between plants. (34) Virus not transmitted by
seed <is by vegetative propagation>. (38) Spreads in the African region <in
the west>. (39) Spreads in Guadeloupe and Guyana. (41) Few (<3) families
susceptible. (43) Nicotiana benthamiana faint systemic chlorosis and mosaic.
Dioscorea cayenensis, D. praehensilis systemic mosaic and vein banding. (44)
Dioscorea composita, D. floribunda. (45) Nicotiana benthamiana, Dioscorea
cayenensis. (46) Nicotiana benthamiana (W), Dioscorea cayenensis (W). (47)
Dioscorea alata, or Dioscorea cayenensis, or Dioscorea dumetorum, or Dioscorea
praehensilis, or Dioscorea preussii, or Dioscorea rotundata, or Nicotiana
benthamiana. (48) Dioscorea composita, or Dioscorea floribunda. (50)
Dioscoreaceae <6/8>, or Solanaceae <1/1>. (51) Dioscoreaceae <2/8>. (53)
Thouvenel and Fauquet (1979). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 0.5-1 days. (56)
DEP: log10 minus 2-3. (57) Infectivity of sap not changed by treatment with
diethyl ether. (58) Leaf sap contains few virions. (60) Method: Thouvenel and
Fauquet (1979). (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped. (68)
Virions usually flexuous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions
of 785 nm. (71) Virions 15 nm wide. (72) Axial canal obscure. (74) Basic helix
obscure. (76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (82)
Isoelectric point pH 4.3. (84) Virions contain 6 % nucleic acid. (85) Virions
94 % protein. (86) Virions 0 % lipid. (88) Genome consists of RNA. (89)
Singlestranded. (109) Infectivity retained when deproteinised with phenol or
detergent. (117) NCBI Taxon ID: 41460. (118) Sequence database accession
code(s): Z48154 Em(44)n:Ymvcp3 Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp3 Yam mosaic virus RNA for coat
protein (N-terminus)(3). 6/95 456bp. Z48155 Em(44)n:Ymvcp4 Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp4
Yam mosaic virus RNA for coat protein (N-terminus)(4). 6/95 456bp. Z48156
Em(44)n:Ymvcp5 Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp5 Yam mosaic virus RNA for coat protein
(N-terminus)(5). 6/95 420bp. Z48157 Em(44)n:Ymvcp6 Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp6 Yam mosaic
virus RNA for coat protein (N-terminus)(6). 6/95 420bp. Z48172 Em(44)n:Ymvcp1
Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp1 Yam mosaic virus RNA for coat protein (N-terminus)(1). 6/95
456bp Z48173 Em(44)n:Ymvcp2 Gb(90)_vi:Ymvcp2 Yam mosaic virus RNA for coat
protein (N-terminus)(2). 6/95 456bp. (132) Virion protein(s) one. (133) Mr
34000. (171) Virions found in all parts of the host plant. (172) Virions found
in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected cells. (175) Inclusions are
pinwheels. (177) They do not contain virions. (179) Potyvirus: Potyviridae.
(180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with serologically related virions:
groundnut eyespot, Guinea grass mosaic and pepper veinal mottle viruses, but
distantly. (187) Thouvenel, J.C. and Fauquet, C. (1977). C. r. Acad. Sci.
Paris 284: 1947. Thouvenel, J.C. and Fauquet, C. (1979). Ann. appl. Biol. 93:
279. Thouvenel, J.-C. and Fauquet, C. (1986). AAB Descr. Pl. Viruses No. 314,
4 pp.

Zucchini yellow fleck potyvirus

      (1) C. Vovlas, 1991. (3) Standard acronym: ZYFV. (5) ICTV decimal code
57.0.1.0.076. (8) First reported in Cucurbita pepo. (9) From Apulia, southern
Italy. (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Cucurbita pepo yellow pin-points on leaves,
becoming completely yellow and necrotic, stunting and fruitlessness with
severe infection. (14) Transmitted by a vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect.
(18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted in a nonpersistent manner.
(31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (33) Virus transmitted by
contact between plants. (39) Spreads in Italy <the south>. (41) Several (3-9)
families susceptible. (42) Experimentally infected plants mostly show yellow
local lesions, systemic mottling. (43) Cucumis sativus necrotic local lesions,
systemic mottling. C. melo, Cucurbita maxima systemic yellow mottle. Cucurbita
pepo local lesions, total necrosis. Citrullus lanatus small local lesions and
yellow flecking. Lagenaria siceraria systemic vein clearing, mottling. (44)
Chenopodium quinoa, C. amaranticolor, Gomphrena globosa, Vigna unguiculata
ssp. unguiculata, Phaseolus vulgaris cvs Bountiful and La Victoire. (45)
Cucumis sativus, Cucurbita maxima, Cucumis melo, Lagenaria siceraria. (46)
Cucurbita pepo (L), Cucumis sativus (W), Cucumis melo (W), Citrullus lanatus
(L). (47) Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita
maxima, or Cucurbita pepo, or Ecballium elaterium, or Lagenaria siceraria.
(48) Celosia cristata, or Chenopodium amaranticolor, or Chenopodium quinoa, or
Gomphrena globosa, or Luffa acutangula, or Lupinus albus, or Nicotiana
clevelandii, or Nicotiana tabacum <cvs. White Burley, Xanthi>, or Ocimum
basilicum, or Phaseolus vulgaris, or Vicia faba, or Vigna unguiculata ssp.
unguiculata, or Zinnia elegans. (50) Cucurbitaceae <7/8>. (51) Amaranthaceae
<2/2>, or Chenopodiaceae <2/2>, or Compositae <1/1>, or Cucurbitaceae <1/8>,
or Labiatae <1/1>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <4/4>, or Solanaceae <2/2>.
(53) Vovlas et al. (1981). (54) TIP: 55-60 °C. (55) LIV: 30 days. (56) DEP:
log10 minus 4-5. (60) Method: systemically infected leaves homogenised in
potassium phosphate buffer and carbon tetrachloride with chloroform (1/2
volume each) for clarification. Precipitation with PEG. (61) Virions
filamentous. (69) Virions with a clear modal length. (70) Virions of 750 nm.
(76) One sedimenting component in purified preparations. (81) Density 1.30.
(166) Replication does not depend on a helper virus. (171) Virions found in
leaves. (172) Virions found in cytoplasm. (174) Inclusions present in infected
cells. (175) Inclusions are crystals in the cytoplasm, membranous bodies,
pinwheels, and unusual in shape. (176) Amorphous inclusions. (177) They
contain virions. (178) Other cellular changes: cytological modifications
caused mainly by fibriate bodies and other types of inclusions. (179)
Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (187) Martelli, G.P., Russo, M.
and Vovlas, C. (1981). Phytopathol. Medit. 20: 193. Vovlas, C. (1979). 3rd
Conf. of ISHS Working Group on Vegetable Crops, Bari, Italy. Volvas, C.,
Hiebert, E. and Russo, M. (1981). Phytopathol. Medit. 20: 123.


Zucchini yellow mosaic potyvirus

      (1) C. Büchen-Osmond and D. Purcifull, 1987. (2) Synonyms: muskmelon
yellow stunt virus (Lecoq et al., 1981; 1983). (3) Standard acronym: ZYMV. (4)
Strains: 22 isolates of the virus have been grouped into three pathotypes by
their effect on muskmelon line PI 414723 (Pitrat and Lecoq, 1984; Risser et
al., 1981; Lecoq and Pitrat, 1985 and unpublished data). ZYMV isolates differ
in the symptoms they cause (Lecoq et al., 1981; Provvidenti et al., 1984),
aphid transmissibility (Lecoq, 1986) or virulence towards a resistance gene
(Lecoq and Pitrat, 1985). (5) ICTV decimal code 57.0.1.0.077. (8) First
reported in Cucurbita pepo. (9) From Italy. (10) By Lisa et al. (1981). (11)
Symptoms persist. (13) Cucurbita pepo (zucchini squash), Cucumis melo
(muskmelon), Cucumis sativus (cucumber) and Citrullus lanatus (watermelon)
mosaic, yellowing, shoestring leaves, stunting, and fruit and seed
deformation. Melothria pendula mosaic, yellowing. (14) Transmitted by a
vector. (16) Transmitted by an insect. (17) Transmitted by Aphis citricola
(Purcifull et al., 1984), Aphis gossypii; Myzus persicae (Lecoq et al., 1981;
Lisa et al., 1981) and Macrosiphum euphorbiae (Lecoq, unpublished data) and
Aphis middletonii, Aphis craccivora, Acrythosiphon pisum, Lipaphis erysimi,
Uroleucon sp. (Adlerz, 1987). (18) Transmitted by Aphididae. (25) Transmitted
in a nonpersistent manner. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation.
(34) Virus not transmitted by seed <Lecoq et al., 1981; Dodds et al., 1984>.
(39) Spreads in Algeria, Australia, Egypt, France, Germany, Israel, Italy,
Japan, Jordan, Lebanon, Mauritius, Morocco, Spain, Taiwan, Turkey, the UK, and
the USA <Zucchini yellow mosaic virus has been isolated from the wild
perennial cucurbit Melothria pendula in Florida (Adlerz et al., 1983b)>. (41)
Several (3-9) families susceptible. (43) Chenopodium amaranticolor, C. quinoa
chlorotic local lesions; not systemic. Cucumis melo chlorotic local lesions;
systemic vein clearing, yellowing, mosaic, leaf deformation, stunting and
occasional necrosis. Cucurbita okeechobeensis systemic mosaic (N.B. this
species is not susceptible to most cucumber mosaic virus isolates). Cucurbita
pepo chlorotic local lesions; systemic vein netting, yellowing, mosaic and
leaf deformation, often lethal. Gomphrena globosa local lesions; not systemic
(N.B. this species is not infected by squash mosaic virus). Luffa acutangula
systemic mosaic or latent. Ranunculus sardous symptomless systemic infection
with most isolates (N.B. this species is not infected by papaya ringspot
virus-W or watermelon mosaic virus 2). (44) Lavatera trimestris but watermelon
virus 2 induces necrotic local lesions. (45) Cucurbita pepo. (46) Chenopodium
amaranticolor (L), Cucurbita pepo (W). (47) Chenopodium amaranticolor, or
Chenopodium quinoa, or Citrullus lanatus, or Cucumis melo, or Cucumis
metuliferus, or Cucumis sativus, or Cucurbita maxima, or Cucurbita moschata,

Potyvirus: Potyviridae. (180) : Potyviridae. (181) Virus(es) with
serologically related virions: watermelon mosaic virus II, bean yellow mosaic
virus (Lecoq et al., 1981; Lisa et al., 1981; Adlerz et al., 1983a; Lesemann,
1983; Lesemann et al., 1983; Makkouk and Abbasher, 1983; Purcifull et al.,
1984) and amaranthus leaf mottle viruses (Lovisolo and Lisa, 1976; V. Lisa and
G. D'Agostino, unpublished data), but distantly. (183) No serological
differences have been detected between Italian and other isolates of the virus
(Lecoq et al., 1983; Lesemann et al., 1983; Purcifull et al., 1984;
Provvidenti et al., 1984). Different isolates cross-protect in muskmelon
(Lecoq et al., 1981). (185) Best tests for diagnosis: Some isolates of ZYMV
cause symptoms similar to those attributed to other cucurbit viruses (cucumber
mosaic virus, watermelon mosaic virus 1, strain W of papaya ringspot virus,
watermelon mosaic virus 2 and squash mosaic virus), thus a diagnosis based on
symptoms is uncertain, and serological tests must be used. ZYMV frequently
occurs with other viruses in cucurbits, but can be isolated alone by
inoculating, for example, Cucurbita okeechobeensis and Ranunculus sardous.
ZYMV can be separated from squash mosaic by aphid transmission or by
inoculation to Gomphrena globosa. Zucchini yellow fleck potyvirus, found in
the the Mediterranean region (Vovlas et al., 1981), is not serologically
related to ZYMV (M. Russo, unpublished data). (187) Adlerz, W.C. (1987). Econ.

Zygocactus Montana X (?) potexvirus

      (1) M. Chessin, 1989. (2) Synonyms: zygocactus virus X, ZyV-58, cactus
zygocactus virus. (5) ICTV decimal code 56.0.1.T.D.13. (8) First reported in
Zygocactus truncatus. (9) From Missoula, Montana, U.S.A. (10) By Chessin and
Giri (1975). (11) Symptoms persist. (13) Zygocactus truncatus reddening of
pads. (31) Virus transmitted by mechanical inoculation. (40) Found, but with
no evidence of spread, in the U.S.A. (41) Few (<3) families susceptible. (42)
Experimentally infected plants mostly show systemic mosaics, mottles,
ringspots or necrosis. (43) Atriplex hastata systemic leaf mottling.
Chenopodium quinoa necrotic local lesions, systemic mosaic. Chenopodium
polyspermum systemic leaf mottling. Chenopodium album, C. giganteum, C.
urbicum chlorotic or necrotic local lesions; not systemic. Hablitzia tamnoides
chlorotic local lesions; systemic green flecking. (44) Amaranthus tricolor,
Chenopodium capitatum, C. hybridum, C. foliosum, Datura stramonium, Gomphrena
globosa, Nicotiana tabacum, N. rustica, N. sylvestris, Phaseolus vulgaris.

caudatus, or Atriplex hastata, or Chenopodium album, or Chenopodium giganteum,

      (5) ICTV decimal code 49.0.3. (6) Definitive species alfalfa 1, beet 1,

Leguminosae-Caesalpinioideae <1/3>, or Leguminosae-Papilionoideae <3/3 >, or
Polygonaceae <1/3>, or Portulacaceae <1/3>, or Rosaceae <1/3>, or Rutaceae
<1/3>, or Solanaceae <3/3>, or Tropaeolaceae <1/3>. (54) TIP: 60-63.25-65 °C.
(55) LIV: 2-7-16 days. (56) DEP: log10 minus 4 <2/2>. (58) Leaf sap contains
few virions <3/3>. (61) Virions filamentous. (63) Virions not enveloped <3/3>.
